Title: ¡Germenes! ¡Germenes! ¡Germenes! (Germs! Germs! Germs!)
Annotation: This humorous look at germs is told in simple verse with colorful illustrations. Written from the point of view of the germs, students are provided with information on how germs enter their bodies and what actions the students can take to prevent infection.
Author: Bobbi Katz

Title: ¡La senorita Nelson ha desaparecido! (Miss Nelson Is Missing!)
Annotation: When Miss Nelson's class misbehaves, she disappears. She is replaced by the dreaded substitute, Miss Viola Swamp, the meanest teacher in the world. This and other Miss Nelson books are great to be read aloud, especially by substitute teachers.
Author: Harry Allard

Title: ¡Por la gran cuchara de cuerno! (By the Great Horn Spoon!)
Annotation: Jack and his very proper manservant, Praiseworthy, sail from Boston to California during the Gold Rush to strike it rich and save his aunt’s mansion from creditors. While Jack grows into manhood, Praiseworthy finds love and breaks free of the social restrictions of being a butler. Their adventure is based on historically accurate situations of ship travel, gold fever, and life in the gold fields. The book is also available in English.
Author: Sid Fleischman
Standard: Not Applicable, HSS 4.1, HSS 4.3, HSS 5.8, HSS 8.8

Title: ¡Que monton de tamales! (Too Many Tamales)
Annotation: The importance of honesty is shown as four Latino children spend an unforgettable Christmas Eve searching for Maria's mother's diamond wedding ring, lost in the tamale masa (dough). The illustrations feature expressive oil paintings in warm tones that match the festive holiday mood. California author. Translated by Alma Flor Ada and F. Isabel Campoy.
Author: Gary Soto
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: ¡Que sorpresa de cumpleanos! (Birthday Swap)
Annotation: Each year Lori looks forward to celebrating her sister's birthday in August at her aunt's house in Mexico. However, this year's gathering brings an unexpected surprise. Striking colored-pencil drawings illustrate the spirit of Mexican birthday celebrations.
Author: Loretta Lopez

Title: ¿Hay algo mas pequeno que una musarana? (What's Smaller than a Pygmy Shrew?)
Annotation: This book shows how microscopes are used to see the tiniest parts of the universe which helps readers understand that the size of any object may be viewed in relation to things both smaller and larger. The acrylic-and-ink artwork includes touches of humor and shows proportions from elephants to atoms.
Author: Robert E. Wells
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)
Standard: PS K.1, LS K.2, I & E K.4, I & E 2.4, LS 3.3, PS 5.1, Math 1.MD.1-4, Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 5.MD.1-5

Title: ¿Quien quiere un rinoceronte barato? (Who Wants a Cheap Rhinoceros?)
Annotation: What could you do with a cheap rhinoceros? Find out lots of ideas in this story about the advantages of having a rhino. Black-and-white drawings accompany the humorous and imaginative text.
Author: Shel Silverstein

Title: 13 Words
Annotation: A dog attempts to cheer up his friend, a despondent bird, in a tale that introduces a series of random words—from “baby” to “haberdashery.” The writer crafts a plausible story using these random words as a focus. Bright, colorful artwork contains surprises lurking about. This book may be used as a model text for older students using a list of nouns and adjectives to incorporate into narrative writing.
Author: Lemony Snicket
Discipline: English-Language Arts/General , English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: 14 Cows for America
Annotation: An illustrated tale in which the Maasai people of Kenya present a gift of 14 cows to the United States as a gesture of comfort and friendship in the wake of the attacks of September 11, 2001. The paintings glow with oranges and reds, highlighting Kenya’s environment. Use as a mentor text with older children to write about 9/11, world peace, or multicultural relations.
Author: Carmen Agra Deedy
Topic: American History, Diversity, Global Historical Events and Figures, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: 1607: A New Look at Jamestown
Annotation: Describes the new research and archaeological discoveries at Jamestown and demonstrates how existing knowledge and historians' views can change. Clearly written and well illustrated, the book shows how previous beliefs about the Jamestown settlement are erroneous. Provides an excellent account of the Native American tribes’ history, relationships before and after the arrival of the colonists, and the process of colonization, including the challenges. Color photographs show interpreters in period costume photographed at Jamestown.
Author: Karen Lange
Topic: American History, Diversity, Economics, Geography, Government and Politics

Title: 1621: A New Look at Thanksgiving
Annotation: A well-researched book about Thanksgiving Day looks at the 1621 harvest feast from the perspectives of both the English colonists and the Wampanoag people. Photographs of Plimoth Plantation, a living history museum in Massachusetts, help the reader to visualize what life was like in 1621.
Author: Catherine O'Neill Grace, Margaret M. Bruchac

Title: 17 Kings and 42 Elephants
Annotation: This alliterative nonsense rhyme can be used to introduce division with remainders. A parade of 17 kings and 42 elephants makes its way through the jungle, so, how many elephants does each king have? Readers can experiment by changing the number of kings and elephants.
Author: Margaret Mahy
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, Mathematics

Title: 19 Varieties of Gazelle: Poems of the Middle East
Annotation: Features 60 new poems about the Middle East in response to the tragic events of September 11, 2001. The author draws on her Palestinian and American heritage to look at both the Middle East through the eyes of an American and the United States through the eyes of a Palestinian. The poems explore universal issues of hope, conflict, war, peace, people, and relations.
Author: Naomi Shihab Nye

Title: 1918 Influenza Pandemic, The
Annotation: The author describes the 1918 influenza pandemic, from how World War I soldiers spread the disease to recent scientific efforts to understand the virus that took between twenty and forty million lives worldwide. Archival material, clearly reproduced paintings, photos, and micrographs bring a strong sense of reality to the events. Pair this title with LISTENING FOR LIONS, a fictionalized version of these events by Gloria Whelan.
Author: Stephanie True Peters

Title: 26 Fairmount Avenue
Annotation: An autobiographical account of author Tomie dePaola’s childhood, this Newbery Honor Book (2000) centers on the building of his family’s new house at 26 Fairmount Avenue in 1938. Tomie has many adventures, including quitting kindergarten on the first day and spending time with his Nana. Readers will recognize many of the characters of dePaola’s fictional works throughout this story. Highlighted with detailed black-and-white drawings.
Author: Tomie dePaola

Title: 7 x 9 = Trouble!
Annotation: Wilson is a third-grader with some big problems. He just can’t remember his multiplication facts and must pass all of the timed tests. To make matters worse, even his little brother in kindergarten knows some of the multiples better than he does. Then the class hamster goes missing—and Wilson was the last one to hold the rodent. The story introduces the concept of counting by multiples, the finger pattern for the multiples of nine, and the commutative property.
Author: Claudia Mills

Title: 90 Miles to Havana
Annotation: After the Communist revolution in Cuba, nine-year-old Julian’s parents make the heartbreaking decision to send him and his older brothers to a camp for Cuban-exile children in Miami as part of Operation Pedro Pan. At the camp, where bullies run rampant, Julian struggles to escape the shadow of his older brothers and to stand on his own. Based on the author’s own experiences as a child refugee from Cuba.
Author: Enrique Flores-Galbis
Topic: Diversity, Global Historical Events and Figures, Immigration/Migration

Title: A cazar palabras (Hunting for Words)
Annotation: A young boy has lost some words. Piedra, cama, naranja, luna, and pan are nowhere to be found! In the meantime, the words wreak havoc during their escape and frustrate the boy to no end. The boy discovers the missing culprits during breakfast the next morning. Double-page illustrations highlight this reading adventure.
Author: Pepe Caccamo

Title: Abe Lincoln Crosses a Creek: A Tall, Thin Tale (Introducing His Forgotten Frontier Friend)
Annotation: In 1816, young Abe and his friend Austin decide to use a log to cross Knob Creek. When Abe falls into the water, Austin saves his life and Abe promises that he will never forget it. Even when he is the president of a war-torn country, Abe fondly remembers his old friend. Author Deborah Hopkinson tells the story in a folksy tone and addresses the unknowns in history when she recounts how Austin saves young Abe. The book features watercolor and pen-and-ink illustrations.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson

Title: Abe Lincoln Remembers
Annotation: Vivid, full-page paintings illustrate this fictional narrative that highlights Abraham Lincoln's accomplishments and his life. The imagined conversation is as told by the mature President in the White House. Ironically, it is set on the evening of April 14, 1865, just before Lincoln and his wife, Mary, are about to leave for Ford's Theatre. As he reflects on his childhood, he notes that much has come to pass and wonders "How much there is still to be done."
Author: Ann Warren Turner

Title: Abe's Honest Words: The Life of Abraham Lincoln
Annotation: Lincoln's life story is told in accessible and engaging prose. A powerful image of a great American president is presented, depicting the passion for humanity that defined Lincoln's life. Quotations from Lincoln are interspersed in the text. Illustrated with striking full-color paintings by Kadir Nelson.
Author: Doreen Rappaport

Title: Abernathy Boys, The
Annotation: A fictionalized account of the adventurous journey of nine-year-old Bud Abernathy and his five-year-old brother, Temp, who traveled mostly on horseback in 1904. They journeyed alone from their home in Oklahoma to Santa Fe, New Mexico, and back again, crossing the vast, desertlike no-man's-land in the Texas Panhandle known as the caprock. This read-aloud is filled with humor and wonderful dialogue.
Author: L. J. Hunt

Title: About Time: A First Look at Time and Clocks
Annotation: This is an entertaining and brief history of the concept of time, calendars, and clocks. An explanation of daytime, nighttime, and the seasons is provided; timekeeping methods, from sundials to atomic clocks, are introduced; and the Gregorian calendar is explained. Detailed watercolor illustrations on every page enhance the text.
Author: Bruce Koscielniak

Title: Abuela's Weave
Annotation: A young Guatemalan girl and her grandmother grow closer as they create some special traditional woven articles and then make a trip to the market in hopes of selling them. The warm relationship between the girl and her grandmother and many details are vividly described. The author portrays the beauty of his homeland's cultural traditions. The illustrations, acrylic-on-canvas paintings, bring dimension to the characters and adds authenticity to the setting.
Author: Omar S. Castañeda
Topic: Ethnic Studies, International Studies/World History, Lifestyles Around the World, Visual Arts
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Accidental Adventures of India McAllister, The
Annotation: India McAllister is a fourth-grader who was born in China and adopted by American parents. Her greatest hope is to have amazing adventures, and her daily life provides some. Her best friend, Colby, may be interested in her enemy, Amanda. At the same time, India is sorting out her feelings about her parents’ divorce and her father’s male partner, Richard. Told in the first person, this gentle story has occasional black-line drawings accompanied by India’s commentary.
Author: Charlotte Agell

Title: Ackamarackus: Julius Lester's Sumptuously Silly Fantastically Funny Fables
Annotation: This is a collection of six original animal fables, laced with humor, absurdities, wordplay, and alliteration. Each fable includes both a silly and a serious moral. Acrylic and collage illustrations are bright and exhilarating. Useful for reading aloud and discussing individuality, acceptance, and expression of negative feelings.
Author: Julius Lester

Title: Across the Blue Pacific: A World War II Story
Annotation: During World War II, Molly and her fourth-grade classmates wrote to people serving in the military. Molly chose to write to her neighbor, Ted, who was serving aboard a submarine in the Pacific. Told through free verse, the book presents details of life at that time and the loss of a loved one in the war. Illustrated with loose-lined ink and watercolor artwork that captures the time and place.
Author: Louise Borden

Title: Action Jackson
Annotation: In May and June of 1950, Jackson Pollock painted one of his most famous works, LAVENDER MIST. Through the illustrations and text, the reader learns about Pollock's unique painting method. Includes a short biography with archival photos. Notes, sources, and a bibliography are included.
Author: Jan Greenberg, Sandra Jordan
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.3

Title: Actual Size
Annotation: Jenkins fills this book with colorful cut-and-torn paper collage illustrations. The book's large format serves to provide amazing facts about animals - the actual size of the head of a bear, the length of an anteater's tongue, and the tooth of a great white shark, for example.
Author: Steve Jenkins
Standard: LS 1.2, LS 3.3, Math K.MD.1-4, Math 1.MD.1-4, Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 3.MD.1-8

Title: Ada Byron Lovelace and the Thinking Machine
Annotation: The daughter of famous romantic poet Lord Byron develops her creativity through science and math and writes the world's first computer program to demonstrate the capabilities of inventor Charles Babbage's thinking machine.
Author: Laurie Ann Wallmark
Topic: Mathematics, Women’s Studies, Mathematical Analysis, Mathematical Reasoning

Title: Adventures of Connie and Diego, The (Las aventuras de Connie y Diego)
Annotation: Tired of being laughed at because they were born with different colors on their bodies, a pair of twins run away to ask the animals where they belong. Turned away by the bear and the whale, they are accepted by the eagle. Alas, they cannot fly. Finally the tiger explains that they belong with humans. This tale of overcoming prejudice is told in English and Spanish. Bright artwork shows the twins drawn with many vivid colors.
Author: Maria Garcia

Title: Adventures of Daniel Boom, a.k.a. Loud Boy: Sound Off, The
Annotation: Daniel Boom is just like most kids, but with one exception: he has no “indoor voice.” As it turns out, Daniel was subjected to an experiment gone wrong as an infant and now learns of his “super powers.” Joining him are three pals who were also part of the experiment, and together they fight the evil, noise-hating mad scientist who is bent on making all kids behave. The first book in the “Adventures of Daniel Boom” series, this is a fun and colorful ride.
Author: D. J. Steinberg

Title: Adventures of Mark Twain by Huckleberry Finn, The
Annotation: Huck Finn has his turn to tell the story of his creator, Mark Twain. In Huck’s folksy twang, the book covers the life of Samuel Clemens: from his boyhood along the Mississippi River, to steamboat captain, to newspaper reporter, to a “for-real writer.” Reading the text aloud will bring Huck’s language to life. Illustrated with pen-and-ink and watercolor artwork. A time line of important dates in the life of Samuel Clemens is included.
Author: Robert Burleigh

Title: Adventures of Nanny Piggins, The
Annotation: Nanny Piggins, a common farm pig, answers Mr. Green’s ad for a nanny and takes on his three children, filling their days with fun, adventure, sweets, and love. The text is complemented by black-and-white illustrations. A humorous story suitable for reading aloud.
Author: R. A. Spratt

Title: Adventurous Life of Myles Standish and the Amazing-But-True Survival Story of Plymouth Colony, The
Annotation: A very readable biography of Myles Standish, military soldier and leader of the Plymouth Colony, who sailed aboard the Mayflower to help protect the Pilgrims and their settlement in North America. Religious movements, key figures, and a balanced account of Pilgrim–Indian relations are explained. Includes bibliographical references and an index.
Author: Cheryl Harness

Title: Advice for a Frog
Annotation: This selection depicts 14 exotic and/or endangered animals through poetry and larger-than-life paintings. Finely crafted verse features word play matched by the imaginative illustrations on double-page layouts. Included are pleas for environmental awareness and comments about each animal's status as of 1995. California author and illustrator.
Author: Alice Schertle
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, Science

Title: Aesop's Fables
Annotation: This collection presents 53 fables, each illustrated by a different artist from past editions, starting in the fifteenth century. Not only are the fables useful, but the book is fascinating in discussing illustration through the ages.
Author: Bernard Higton, Russell Ash
Illustrator: Alexander Calder, Arthur Rackham, Randolph Caldecott, Walter Crane
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary

Title: Aesop’s Fables
Annotation: Sixteen of Aesop’s fables are set in the grasslands of Africa and portray the characters using African animals such as zebras, kudus, and mongrel dogs. Illustrations are framed in stylized borders, created with watercolor and pencil, and reflect the African flavor of the author’s adaptations. Use for reading aloud in literature or character education studies or in art units.
Author: Beverley Naidoo
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Agua, El (The Water)
Annotation: The water cycle, uses and importance of water to humans and animals are explored in simple text. The overlays presented in the text clarify the concepts of water usage for the readers.
Author: Gallimard Jeunesse, Pierre-Marie Valat

Title: Agua, El (Water)
Annotation: Detailed and varied colored illustrations accompanied by simple, easy-to-understand explanations introduce young readers to the water cycle. The importance of water conservation is presented. See other books in the Mundo Maravilloso (A First Discovery Book) series.
Author: Diane Costa de Beauregard

Title: Aida
Annotation: Retells the story of Giuseppe Verdi's opera in which the love of the enslaved Aida, an Ethiopian princess, for an Egyptian general brings tragedy to all involved. Illustrated with stunning paintings that provide details.
Author: Leontyne Price
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Music
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.3

Title: Ain't Nothing But a Man: My Quest to Find the Real John Henry
Annotation: This photobiography reveals the author's search for the story of the real John Henry, who was made famous through many versions of a folk song. Author Scott Reynolds Nelson explains the research process and primary and secondary sources. The reader discovers how to be a credible historian and learns about railroad history and the folk hero John Henry. Archival photos are abundant, and sepia-toned illustrations enhance the sense of history. Includes appendixes.
Author: Marc Aronson, Scott Reynolds Nelson
Genre: Biography/Autobiography, Folklore, Narrative Nonfiction, Tall Tale
Topic: American History, Diversity, Ethnic Studies, Music
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Air
Annotation: Short vignettes illustrated with hand-colored photographs introduce the scientific and beneficial qualities of the air around us. The photographs will engage younger children and the text will explain more advanced concepts for older readers. See other books in the Elements series.
Author: Ken Robbins

Title: Airmail to the Moon
Annotation: Finding nothing from the Tooth Fairy, an angry Ora Mae accuses her family of stealing her tooth. Colorful scratchboard illustrations match the funny colloquial language and setting.
Author: Tom Birdseye

Title: Al Capone Does My Shirts
Annotation: A twelve-year-old boy named Moose moves to Alcatraz Island in 1935 (when guards' families were housed there). He has to contend with his extraordinary new environment in addition to life with his autistic sister. California author and California setting.
Publisher: G. P. Putnam's Sons/Penguin Young Readers Group
Author: Gennifer Choldenko
Award: John and Patricia Beatty Award, Newbery Honor

Title: Alamat ng Palay (The Legend of Rice)
Annotation: Since rice is the staple food of Filipinos, many stories exist about the rice plant, or palay. This book shows how the origin of palay is related to the livelihood of their ancestors before they became farmers. It shows how they change from nomads to settlers when they first learn how to plant palay.
Author: Victoria Anonuevo

Title: Albert Einstein: Genius of the Twentieth Century
Annotation: This is an early chapter-book introduction to the life and achievements of this famous scientist. His early life, later successes, and three major discoveries all are addressed. The well-written text and pleasing watercolors contribute to an informative and satisfying reading experience. A timeline is included.
Author: Patricia Lakin

Title: Alchemy and Meggy Swann
Annotation: Meggy arrives to work for her father, who is deeply involved in the world of alchemy and who has no time for his twelve-year-old daughter in this tale set in sixteenth-century London. Told with humor and accuracy, this story depicts a feisty young girl with a disability who is determined to make something of her life despite not being able to move around, except with walking sticks. Includes notes with bibliographical references and descriptions of Elizabethan culture.
Author: Karen Cushman
Topic: Diversity, International Studies/World History, Women’s Studies

Title: Aldo Applesauce
Annotation: Aldo Sossi, Aldo Applesauce, has a tough time adjusting to teasing and the nicknames popular in his new school. His only friend is a girl who wears a false moustache. Readers will want to explore other books by this popular author.
Author: Johanna Hurwitz

Title: Aldo Leopold: American Ecologist
Annotation: This is a biography about Aldo Leopold who wrote about the environment and the importance of protecting natural communities that included soils, water, plants, and animals as well as humans. This book contains many vintage photographs and traces Leopold's life as a forester, wildlife manager, and ecologist.
Author: Peter Anderson

Title: Alexander the Great
Annotation: A colorful overview of the life of Alexander the Great that discusses his family, bravery, education, military skills, defeat of the Persians, marriages, and death. Demi’s lavish, mixed-media illustrations and her signature red and gold tones highlight Alexander’s electrifying life.
Author: Demi

Title: Alexander, Who Used to Be Rich Last Sunday
Annotation: Alexander's grandparents give him a dollar and he is rich. Although he and his money are quickly parted, he comes to realize all the things that can be done with a dollar. The book is illustrated with pen-and-ink drawings that make the most of his humorous situation.
Author: Judith Viorst

Title: Alia's Mission: Saving the Books of Iraq
Annotation: Tells the true story of the chief librarian of the Central Library in Basra, Iraq, who was responsible for saving more than 70 percent of the valuable library collection before the beginning of the Iraq War in 2003. After being told that no help was available, the librarian took it upon herself to move books into neighbors' homes and shops for protection. Illustrated in a graphic format, this is an engaging book for reluctant readers.
Author: Mark Allen Stamaty
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, International Studies/World History, War, Women’s Studies

Title: Alibaru: La ronda de las estaciones (Alibaru: Seasons' Lyrics)
Annotation: This anthology of poems reflects the writing of some of the most popular modern-day Hispanic poets. Contributors to this text include Federico Garcia Lorca, Nicolas Guillen, Amado Nervo, and Alfonsina Storni.
Author: Jose Mariax Plaza (selector)

Title: Alice in Wonderland
Annotation: Illustrator Helen Oxenbury has adapted this classic with the creation of a magical world with funny, fabulous creatures and inviting landscapes as a backdrop for a modern Alice. Readers will enjoy comparing the original with this adaptation.
Author: Lewis Carroll

Title: Alice Ramsey's Grand Adventure
Annotation: In 1909 Alice Ramsey drove her Maxwell automobile from New York to San Francisco and thus became the first woman to drive coast-to-coast. This narrative, which can be enjoyed by all ages, shows one woman's determination and character.
Author: Don Brown

Title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland: A Pop-up Adaptation of Lewis Carroll’s Original Tale
Annotation: With his highly detailed pop-up wizardry, Robert Sabuda creates Wonderland in all of its glory. The intricately engineered paperwork and clever text take readers through the twists and turns Alice experiences as she navigates her way through the story, which is told with pop-ups. The original story is abridged, but it still moves at a fast pace and holds together.
Author: Lewis Carroll, Robert Sabuda
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Alison's Zinnia
Annotation: A floral journey through the alphabet occurs as Alison acquires an amaryllis for Beryl, who buys a begonia for Crystal, and so on. Colorful illustrations of flowers are presented in this great book for practicing the beginning sounds of nouns and verbs and identifying flowers. This selection is useful for lessons on figurative language and alliteration.
Author: Anita Lobel

Title: All About Sam
Annotation: In this story from the author's popular ANASTASIA KRUPNIK series, the Krupnik family's dynamics have changed with the addition of a new baby. Anastasia's baby brother, Sam, embraces his early life with humor and exuberance. This is a great read-aloud choice for the intermediate grades.
Author: Lois Lowry

Title: All About Turkeys
Annotation: Clear, informative text and rich, double-page watercolor illustrations show the wild turkey in its habitat along with details of head, feet, and feathers. Read-aloud text is larger, with details about the bird appearing in smaller type. Additional titles in this series are ALL ABOUT DEER, ALL ABOUT OWLS, ALL ABOUT ALLIGATORS, and ALL ABOUT RATTLESNAKES.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: All Joseph Wanted
Annotation: Joseph's mother is illiterate, like many other adults who have recently immigrated to America. She reluctantly learns to read through a library literacy program for adults. This is a good read-aloud story that allows for some open discussion of related issues.
Author: Ruth Yaffe Radin

Title: All of the Above
Annotation: Five urban middle school students in an after-school club and their disillusioned math teacher set out to build the world's largest tetrahedron to get themselves listed in the Guinness Book of World Records. The participants tell their own stories and their reasons for participating in the project. An author's note tells a bit about tetrahedrons and the actual project on which the novel is based.
Author: Shelley Pearsall

Title: All Stations! Distress! April 15, 1912: The Day the Titanic Sank
Annotation: This is a riveting account of the first and only voyage of the Titanic. Along with details of the disaster, Brown presents stories of the ultra-rich, who traveled in grand style, and of the poor, who sought a new life in America. There are firsthand accounts of families that were ripped apart as a result of this tragic event. Illustrated with somber watercolor artwork, this is a very accessible book for young readers.
Author: Don Brown

Title: All the Colors of the Earth
Annotation: Although children may appear different and their customs vary, all children are lovable and come in all the colors of the earth. Vibrant oil painting illustrations highlighted with rich earth tones illustrate the lyrical verse.
Author: Sheila Hamanaka

Title: All the Colors of the Race
Annotation: This poetry collection is written from the point of view of a child with a black mother and a white father. Illustrations portray a biracial family. The book is currently out of print.
Author: Arnold Adoff

Title: All the Way to America: The Story of a Big Italian Family and a Little Shovel
Annotation: Author–illustrator Dan Yaccarino shares his family’s immigration story. His great-grandfather sailed from Sorrento, Italy, to Ellis Island to seek the opportunities America offered. He arrived with a small shovel—a talisman from his family. The shovel appears throughout the story as it is passed to each generation. The time periods, work activities, and family connections are thoughtfully evoked through the bright, color illustrations and sepia-and-color photographs.
Author: Dan Yaccarino

Title: Almost Gone: The World's Rarest Animals
Annotation: This title presents 28 endangered animals. Each is introduced with basic facts, where it is found, and the conditions that threaten its welfare. Detailed and striking collage illustrations of each endangered animal are placed on a white background. Included is a section that memorializes animals that are now gone forever.
Author: Steve Jenkins

Title: Almost to Freedom
Annotation: This is a story about escape from slavery through the Underground Railroad as told by a rag doll that was part of two journeys. The large picture book format with glowing illustrations explains the dangers while showing the hope and the courage of the thousands who traveled to freedom on the Underground Railroad.
Author: Vaunda Micheaux Nelson

Title: Alphabet City
Annotation: Photo-realistic artwork introduces the letters of the alphabet in an urban setting. The artwork shows a series of images of objects and places in New York City that look like letters of the alphabet, from A to Z. The artwork is done in pastels, watercolors, gouache, and charcoal on hot pressed watercolor paper. Various perspectives are shown, and some use negative space.
Author: Stephen T. Johnson
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4

Title: Alvin Ailey
Annotation: The life, dancing, and choreography of Alvin Ailey are celebrated in this book. Ailey created his own modern dance company to explore the black experience. His impact on the world of dance has had a lasting effect.
Author: Andrea Davis Pinkney
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.4, VAPA M PreK-12.2

Title: Alvin Ho: Allergic to Girls, School, and Other Scary Things
Annotation: Chinese American Alvin Ho is a bright boy ready to enter second grade. He is a fan of superheroes and loves all things that explode. Because he is fearful of many things at school, he has never spoken a single word there, although he speaks clearly at home. This story shows Alvin’s world, through his eyes, with humorous text and drawings that will attract even the most reluctant reader. By the end of the story, Alvin is on the right road and has made a friend. Other adventures follow in sequels.
Author: Lenore Look

Title: Always Inventing: A Photobiography of Alexander Graham Bell
Annotation: This biography, with photographs and quotes from Bell himself, follows the well-known inventor from his childhood in Scotland through his lifelong efforts to develop ideas to improve people's lives.
Author: Tom L. Matthews

Title: Always Remember Me: How One Family Survived World War II
Annotation: Opening with end pages of family photos, this is the true story of a Jewish family’s survival during the Holocaust of World War II. Oma and her granddaughter, Rachel, go through two family picture albums at a family gathering—one showing Oma’s “first life” before the war, the other her “second life” after the war. The harsh reality of what this family faced during the years of World War II is presented through gouache illustrations in folk-art style. Documents and the events of the war are depicted as Rachel imagines what the experiences must have been like.
Author: Marisabina Russo
Topic: American History, Global Historical Events and Figures, War

Title: Amal and the Letter from the King
Annotation: This story of a dying child is based on a play written by one of India's foremost writers and educators.
Author: Chitra Gajadin

Title: Amanda Bean's Amazing Dream
Annotation: A young girl loves counting everything and anything. Her amazing dream makes her realize that learning how to multiply will enable her to count everything much faster. The story is enhanced by light ink-and-watercolor illustrations.
Author: Cindy Neuschwander
Classification: Counting Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Amazing Book of Mammal Records, The
Annotation: Find out about the largest, the smallest, and the fastest mammals, and many more record-breaking mammals.
Author: Samuel G. Woods

Title: Amazing Book of Shapes: Explore Math Through Shapes and Patterns, The
Annotation: This is an exploration of different shapes and patterns through a collection of creative projects. It contains a mirror bookmark for a symmetry project and a foldout section with shape stencils and pattern grids. Step-by-step photographs and clear instructions are also included. This book is currently out of print.
Author: Lydia Sharman

Title: Amazing Grace
Annotation: Grace loves to read stories and act them out. When her class decides to stage a production of PETER PAN, other children say she can't be Peter - because she's a girl and because she's black. However, Ma and Nana say she can do anything she sets her mind on, and Grace proves that they are right. This book is good for discussing self-image and promoting imagination.
Author: Mary Hoffman

Title: Amazing Harry Kellar: Great American Magician, The
Annotation: Harry Kellar lived and performed during the nineteenth and early twentieth century, first as a magician’s assistant and as a rising international star during the “Golden Age of Magic.” During his career, Kellar performed for Theodore Roosevelt’s family, mentored the Great Houdini, and established himself as one of the great magicians in the field. Illustrated with reproductions of advertising posters of the period and photographs. Includes a time line, bibliography, and annotated sources.
Author: Gail Jarrow
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Theatre, Visual Arts
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Amazing Life of Benjamin Franklin, The
Annotation: In oversize picture-book format, the life and times of Benjamin Franklin are masterfully told. Readers meet Ben Franklin - the printer's apprentice, the ghost-writer/editor, the printer, the inventor, the politician, the thinker, and the statesman. Franklin has often been called the "wisest American" because of his many talents and skills. This book celebrates his life and connects to eighth-grade history/social science curriculum.
Author: James Cross Giblin

Title: Amazing Paper Cuttings of Hans Christian Andersen, The
Annotation: Reveals another talent of Danish storyteller Hans Christian Andersen, who was also a gifted artist. His paper cuttings serve as the subject and principal illustrations of this book. Includes photographs.
Author: Beth Wagner Brust
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4

Title: Amazing Potato, The
Annotation: This is the definitive book about potatoes. Their journey through time - from humble Inca beginnings to becoming stars of today's fast-food world - is a story of historical importance. Recipes, anecdotes, and photographs contribute to a fascinating book that includes an index, notes, and a bibliography. Use it to enhance information presented on geography, world history, American history, and cuisine.
Author: Milton Meltzer

Title: Amber Brown Is Not a Crayon
Annotation: Amber is sad because her best friend, Justin, is moving away. When they stop speaking to each other because of a misunderstanding, Amber is afraid it is too late to recapture their friendship. This book is part of the Amber Brown series.
Author: Paula Danziger

Title: Amelia and Eleanor Go for a Ride
Annotation: This book is loosely based on an actual event from 1933. After dinner at the White House, Amelia Earhart and Eleanor Roosevelt take a night flight in a twin-motor airplane and then go for a ride in Eleanor's new automobile. This oversized book features graphite illustrations, highlighted with slight washes of color to complement this historical anecdote. It is useful for history lessons about people who make a difference and about the importance of individual action and character. The recipe for Eleanor's favorite dessert, Pink Clouds on Angel Food Cake, is included. California author.
Author: Pam Munoz Ryan

Title: Amelia Earhart: The Legend of the Lost Aviator
Annotation: This picture-book biography follows Amelia Earhart’s life from the time she first saw an airplane at age 10 to her tragic disappearance over the Pacific Ocean. Amelia had an unusual upbringing for her time. Her parents encouraged her interest in nontraditional activities for women. As an adult, Amelia spoke out on behalf of women’s equality and the need for women, as well as men, to follow their dreams. Historically accurate illustrations enhance the text.
Author: Shelley Tanaka
Topic: American History, Global Historical Events and Figures, Women’s Studies

Title: Amelia's Road (El camino de Amelia)
Annotation: Amelia, the daughter of Latino migrant farmworkers in California, longs for a permanent home. She finally attends a school where the teacher learns her name. She finds a special tree at the end of a road where she feels at home. When she and her family must leave again, she buries a box of treasures next to her special tree, hoping she will return one day. Bright acrylic paintings illustrate the text. California author.
Author: Linda Jacobs Altman

Title: America at War: Poems Selected by Lee Bennett Hopkins
Annotation: A varied collection of poems and paintings that express Americans’ experiences during wars—from the American Revolution to Iraq. Each section opens with a quotation and short comments about the conflict presented. Thoughts, words, experiences, and emotions are expressed throughout this powerful and emotional volume; some are those of well-known poets, while others are newly commissioned from today’s children’s poets. Striking watercolor illustrations accompany the poems.
Author: Lee Bennett Hopkins (editor)
Standard: HSS 5.6, HSS 8.1, HSS 8.8, HSS 8.10, HSS 10.6, HSS 10.8

Title: America Is Under Attack: September 11, 2001: the Day the Towers Fell
Annotation: This is a straightforward and unsentimental narrative for children who are too young to remember the attack on New York City’s Twin Towers in 2001. Brown describes the events in a way that makes them understandable to a young audience. Each double-page spread is illustrated with watercolor artwork that brings a strong sense of reality to the story. Brown also includes stories of survivors. A good choice for readers who enjoy true-to-life stories.
Author: Don Brown
Topic: American History, Global Historical Events and Figures

Title: America the Beautiful
Annotation: Majestic illustrations accompany the lyrics to Katharine Lee Bates’ famous song, “America the Beautiful.” The book includes American landscapes and scenes from different moments in history: buffaloes grazing, wheat fields, lighthouses, the two columns of light rising from the cityscape of New York where the World Trade Center once stood, and a space shuttle climbing into the Florida sky. Useful with young students to introduce the famous song and with older students to launch a discussion of geographical and historical information.
Author: Katharine Lee Bates
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.3, HSS 1.3, VAPA M PreK-12.5, VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5, HSS 5.8

Title: America, My New Home
Annotation: A young girl from Jamaica shares, through poems, her experiences and feelings about living in New York City. The poems present both the excitement and hardship of the immigrant experience as the girl writes about missing her “home.” Along the way, she discovers the riches of the library, the symphony, and the circus, and the magic of seeing snow for the first time. Read aloud when talking about the experience of coming to America, long ago or in present times.
Author: Monica Gunning

Title: American Bison: A Scary Prediction
Annotation: Vibrant pictures and a child-friendly layout make this an excellent choice for the study of American history. Focuses on how the American bison, once considered an endangered animal, is now back. Facts are laid out in a clear and engaging style. Each page features one or more pictures, and additional information is presented in captions or a fact box.
Author: William Kaper

Title: American Plague: The True and Terrifying Story of the Yellow Fever Epidemic of 1793, An
Annotation: This is an account of the yellow fever epidemic that swept through Philadelphia in 1793. It highlights the chaos that erupted when people began evacuating in droves, leaving the city without government, goods, or services. It also examines the efforts made by physicians (members of the Free African Society and others) to cure and care for the sick. Period prints and images illustrate the text.
Author: Jim Murphy
Award: James Madison Book Award, National Book Award, Newbery Honor, Robert F. Sibert Award

Title: American Story: 100 True Tales from American History, The
Annotation: Presents 100 short stories about real people and major moments in American history, arranged chronologically from 1565 to 2000, including the lost colony of Roanoke, Pocahontas, the Chicago fire, and the 2000 presidential election. Each selection is enhanced by detailed artwork featuring watercolor washes. Selections can be used as read-alouds to introduce a variety of topics in U.S. history.
Author: Jennifer Armstrong

Title: American Tall Tales
Annotation: A collection of tall tales celebrates such American folk heroes as Sally Ann Thunder Ann Whirlwind, Pecos Bill, John Henry, and Paul Bunyan. Woodcuts illustrate the incredible stories of each character and their adventurous experiences. This large-size book includes nine different legends.
Author: Mary Pope Osborne

Title: Americana Adventure
Annotation: Using clues left by his aunt, a young boy embarks on a cross-country tour that takes him to a wide variety of American cities and important landmarks, including Boston Harbor, the Golden Gate Bridge, and sights such as Mount Rushmore. Bright illustrations combine a seek-and-find element with bold colors.
Author: Michael Garland

Title: Amigo
Annotation: Desperately wanting a pet to love, a boy decides to tame a prairie dog who has already decided to tame the boy for his own pet. The poetic text tells how the boy considers what the animal needs to survive in its environment. Drawings in soft desert colors highlight this gentle story of friendship.
Author: Byrd Baylor

Title: Amigos del otro lado (Friends from the Other Side)
Annotation: In this story, Prietita establishes a friendship with a boy named Joaquin who has crossed the border. She defends her friend from the children in the neighborhood and protects him and his mother from the border patrol van that is cruising the street.
Author: Gloria Anzaldua

Title: Among the Odds and Evens: A Tale of Adventure
Annotation: In this story the numbers have personalities and distinct roles. They live in a habitat where numbers coexist and appreciate each other's attributes. The story presents a foundation for number sense. The story is illustrated with detailed figures over a watercolor background.
Author: Priscilla Turner

Title: Ananse and the Lizard: A West African Tale
Annotation: Ananse the Spider and scheming Lizard both are determined to marry the chief's daughter and get half of his kingdom. The bridegroom will be selected if he can correctly guess the princess's name. This is a variation of the Rumpelstiltskin story.
Author: Pat Cummings (reteller)

Title: Anansi the Spider: A Tale from the Ashanti
Annotation: In this traditional tale from West Africa, the spider Anansi sets out on a long journey. Threatened by Fish and Falcon, he is saved from terrible fates by his sons. But which of his six sons should he reward? The solution to his predicament is also an explanation for how the moon was placed in the sky.
Author: Gerald McDermott (reteller)

Title: Ancient Cliff Dwellers of Mesa Verde, The
Annotation: The Native Americans known as the Anasazi migrated to southwest Colorado in the first century A.D. They mysteriously disappeared in A.D. 1300 after constructing extensive dwellings in the cliffs of the steep canyon walls. California author.
Author: Caroline Arnold

Title: And Then It Rained
Annotation: Growing up in Vietnam during the war years does not stop three children from enjoying one of the most exciting moments of their lives: buying a puppy.
Author: Duc Tuan

Title: And Then What Happened, Paul Revere?
Annotation: Readers learn about Paul Revere's midnight ride to Lexington to warn the colonists that the British were coming and also that he made false teeth, silver spoons, church bells, and many other fascinating things. The book is available in paperback only. It has curriculum connections to fifth- and eighth-grade history/social science. Others titles in the series include YOU WANT WOMEN TO VOTE, LIZZIE STANTON?; WHAT'S THE BIG IDEA, BEN FRANKLIN?; WHERE WAS PATRICK HENRY ON THE 29th OF MAY?; and WHY DON'T YOU GET A HORSE, SAM ADAMS?
Author: Jean Fritz

Title: Andres Bonifacio: Ang Dakilang Supremo ng Katipunan (Andres Bonifacio: The Great Leader of the Katipunan)
Annotation: This biography sketches the life and heroism of Andres Bonifacio and narrates how he founded the Katipunan Movement that led to the united revolt of Filipinos against their Spanish conquerors.
Author: Rodolfo Desuasido

Title: Andy and the Lion
Annotation: In this classic story based on the story of ANDROCLES AND THE LION, Andy reads a book about lions, then meets and assists one with a thorn in his paw. When a lion escapes from the circus, Andy saves the day by calming him - the lion remembers how Andy took out the thorn from his paw. Teachers might encourage students to read classic Roman or Greek stories and write a contemporary story based on them. This book is available in paperback only.
Author: James Daugherty

Title: Ang Ating mga Ninuno (Our Ancestors)
Annotation: This award-winning book describes the origin, characteristics, and ways of life of Filipino ancestors. Based on anthropological, archaeological, and historical research, the information presented in the book broadens children's perspectives on Philippine history and society.
Author: Rene O. Villanueva

Title: Ang Hukuman ni Sinukuan (Sinukuan's Court)
Annotation: This folktale explains why male insects don't bite and why they linger around one's ears. It also describes how the turtle got its shell, why the firefly has light, and why other animals have certain characteristics.
Author: Roberto Alonzo

Title: Ang Kalakalang Galeon: Mula Maynila Hanggang Acapulco (The Galleon Trade: From Manila to Acapulco)
Annotation: The origins of the galleon trade between the Philippines and Mexico are traced during the Spanish period. The galleon trade's influences and effects on the economic development and personal livelihood of Filipinos are described and explained.
Author: Mike Bigornia

Title: Ang Kamatis ni Peles (Peles' Tomatoes)
Annotation: A grasshopper wants to start his own tomato plot. The book explores his funny experiences to make sure that his plants grow. The reader is provided with a good example of how hard work must be teamed up with the right knowledge in order to do something right.
Author: Alberta Angeles

Title: Ang Pag-ibig ni Maria Makiling (The Love of Maria Makiling)
Annotation: This legend depicts the story of a fairy who was good and kind to the townspeople until they did not repay her kindness. This legend persists, especially in the town in which the mountain named for the fairy is located.
Author: Rene O. Villanueva

Title: Ang Unang Barangay: Ang Pamumuhay ng Pilipino Bago Dumating ang mga Espanyol (The First Barangay: The Filipinos' Way of Life Before the Spaniards Arrived)
Annotation: This selection highlights the economic and social vibrancy of the indigenous peoples of the Philippines - with their unique language, literature, songs, dances, and religion - and presents the era before Spanish colonization.
Author: Rene O. Villanueva

Title: Angel Child, Dragon Child
Annotation: Ut, a Vietnamese girl attending school in the United States, is lonely for her mother, who remains in Vietnam. Then she makes a new friend, who presents her with a wonderful gift. Soft watercolor illustrations support this tender story.
Author: Michele Maria Surat

Title: Angel Child, Dragon Child
Annotation: Ut, a Vietnamese girl attending school in the United States, is lonely for her mother, who remains in Vietnam. Then she makes a new friend, who presents her with a wonderful gift. Soft watercolor illustrations support this tender story.
Author: Michele Maria Surat

Title: Angela Weaves a Dream: The Story of a Young Maya Artist
Annotation: A young Mayan girl, Angela, learns to weave in the tradition of her ancestors. This photo-essay features color photographs that show the carding, spinning and dyeing of the wool and close-up views of weaving designs and color schemes. The spiritual aspects of creating this art form are also explored. A glossary, bibliography, maps, and notes from the photographer and author are appended.
Author: Michele Sola

Title: Angelo
Annotation: While restoring the front of a church, Angelo, an old master plasterer, rescues an injured pigeon. In spite of his dislike for pigeons, Angelo finds himself spending all his spare time nursing her back to health. Years later the favor is returned twofold.
Author: David Macaulay

Title: Angels in the Dust
Annotation: ". . . Nothing's so bad that it isn't good for something." With those words Great-Grandma Annie tells her grandchildren about living on a farm during the Dust Bowl era in Oklahoma. Through all the hardships and heartbreak, Annie, her family, and her community persevere.
Author: Margot Theis Raven

Title: Angels Ride Bikes and Other Fall Poems (Los angeles andan en bicicleta y otros poems de otono)
Annotation: In this third volume of bilingual seasonal poems, Alarcon invites readers to experience fall in Los Angeles, the "City of the Angels." It is an excellent read-aloud and celebration of the simple joys of everyday life in the city. Includes spirited and bright illustrations and footnotes that offer explanations for unfamiliar terms in Spanish and English. California author and setting.
Author: Francisco X. Alarcon

Title: Animal Defenses: How Animals Protect Themselves
Annotation: The unusual defense mechanisms employed by animals are described in this well-illustrated text. This chapter book allows the reader to observe various mechanisms of protection including poisonous skin, camouflage, group living, and imitation.
Author: Etta Kaner

Title: Animal Sense
Annotation: This clever book of poems describes how animals use their senses in familiar and unfamiliar ways. "Living things all feel and sense their way through every happenstance." Each of the five senses is addressed through examples of three different animals. The author engages children in learning about how the five senses help animals survive in their environments.
Publisher: Alfred A. Knopf, Borzoi Books for Young Readers
Author: Diane Ackerman

Title: Animales nocturnos: La vida de noche en la selva tropical (Night Animals: Nightlife in the Tropical Rain Forest)
Annotation: Activities are presented and life cycles of nocturnal animals are described in this colorful, well-designed book. Plastic overlays, pictures, and text provide easy-to-understand information and facts about nocturnal animals.
Translator: Barry Croucher and Brin Edwards Barry Croucher and Brin Edwards
Author: Peter Riley

Title: Animals Asleep
Annotation: The sleep behavior of nineteen animals is described through watercolor illustrations and a brief text. Sleep patterns of animals ranging from the butterfly to the snake to the household dog are portrayed in a variety of habitats around the world. A glimpse at these sleeping behaviors conveys to the reader how animals’ behavior help ensure their survival.
Author: Sneed B. Collard, III

Title: Animals Christopher Columbus Saw: An Adventure in the New World
Annotation: This book describes animals that Christopher Columbus encountered during his exploration to the Americas in the late fifteenth century, including the rats and cats hiding on his ships, turtles, fish, sharks, dolphins, and whales in the sea. The ship’s log also describes lizards and parrots seen on the land. Full double-page spreads make this a great choice to share with a class or to use for individual research assignments.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: Animals on the Trail with Lewis and Clark
Annotation: This title retraces the journey of Lewis and Clark and blends their observations of previously unknown animals with modern information about those animals. The broader story is told as well, but the focus of the book is on the animals they encountered. Color photographs of animals and landscapes bring the adventures of the journey to life.
Author: Dorothy Hinshaw Patent

Title: Anne Frank
Annotation: This picture-book biography presents an engaging story of what Anne Frank was like as a child and her life before going into hiding. The story is set in the context of Hitler’s Germany and presents the anguish of leaving a happy childhood. It tells of Anne’s writing efforts and growing affection for Peter, a fellow fugitive. The story concludes with the Nazi raid of the annex. Illustrated with powerful, realistic paintings.
Author: Josephine Poole
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, War

Title: Anne Hutchinson's Way
Annotation: A fictionalized story of the life of Anne Hutchinson told through the eyes of her young daughter, Susanna. Anne Hutchinson arrived with her family in Massachusetts in 1634, but she was soon banished for holding religious meetings and for teaching ideas that were disputed by Puritan ministers. Lifelike paintings accompany the text.
Author: Jeannine Atkins
Topic: American History, Immigration/Migration, Religion/Spirituality, Women’s Studies

Title: Anne of Green Gables
Annotation: More than a hundred years after its original publication, the story of this spunky, red-haired orphan whose imagination and daring actions disrupt ordinary life in Avonlea, Prince Edward Island, still engages readers. A read-aloud choice for multiple ages. Anne’s fictional life continues through several sequels.
Author: L. M. Montgomery

Title: Annie and the Old One
Annotation: Annie's Navaho grandmother, the Old One, has told her family that when the rug on the loom is finished, it will be time for her to return to the earth as all living things do when they are old. Annie cannot bear to think of her grandmother dying, and decides to prevent the completion of the rug. Annie learns much about living, dying, and accepting the inevitable as this story unfolds.
Author: Miska Miles

Title: Anno's Math Games
Annotation: A variety of sections provoke mathematical thinking, highlighting differences, putting things together and taking them apart, numerical order, and size differences. Each chapter has several problems in different contexts to solve. Simple watercolor artwork highlight the concepts.
Author: Mitsumasa Anno
Standard: Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 3.G.1-2, Math 3.MP.1-8, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 4.G.1-3, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.MD.1-5, Math 5.G.1-6, Math 6.RP.1-3

Title: Anno's Math Games II
Annotation: In this second volume of math games Anno introduces cause and effect, the meaning of counting and measuring, and the rudiments of particle physics. The book ends with notes for the adult reader on the math concepts. This title is currently out of print.
Author: Mitsumasa Anno
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Mathematical Reasoning, Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)
Standard: Math K.CC.1-7, Math K.MD.1-4, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 1.G.1-3, Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 5.MD.1-5

Title: Annushka’s Voyage
Annotation: An immigrant story of two sisters who journey from Russia to America to join their father in New York. The sisters carry with them the Sabbath candlesticks given to them by their grandmother that help them on their journey. Illustrated with detailed pen-and-ink artwork using acrylic and colored pencil.
Author: Edith Tarbescu
Standard: HSS K.2, HSS K.6, HSS 1.3, HSS 1.4, HSS 2.1

Title: Ant Cities
Annotation: Ants live and work together to build and maintain their cities. Facts are presented as readers peek inside the ant tunnels where information is revealed about their food, life cycle, and the roles of the various ants. Illustrated in bright, cartoonlike pictures with instructions for building an ant farm. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out-Science series.
Author: Arthur Dorros

Title: Antarctic Antics: A Book of Penguin Poems
Annotation: This lively collection of 13 poems and riddles about penguins is illustrated with comical paintings. The humorous poems include some factual information on penguin life. This work is an excellent choice for reading aloud.
Author: Judy Sierra
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, Science

Title: Antarctic Journal: Four Months at the Bottom of the World
Annotation:
This travel journal chronicles a four-month stay by the author/illustrator at Palmer Station in Antarctica. Letters, journal entries, and sketches provide general information about the windiest, coldest, and most forbidding region on Earth. The journal is also illustrated with photos that highlight encounters with birds, sea mammals, and natural phenomena. 
It can also be used as a writing model.
Author: Jennifer Owings Dewey
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: Antarctic Journal: The Hidden Worlds of Antarctica's Animals
Annotation: The animal life of Antarctica around Palmer Station during the spring and summer is described. The author and artist/zoologist document their three-month stay through text, full-color illustrations, pencil drawings, and photographs that feature the frozen desert's unique food chain. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Meredith Hooper

Title: Anthology for the Earth
Annotation: The fragile ecology of Earth is presented in this collection of poetry and bits of prose by various authors. Illustrated by 30 different artists, this picture book for older readers includes selections by contemporary and classic writers. Brief biographies of the contributors are included.
Author: Judy Allen (editor)

Title: Anthropologist: Scientist of the People
Annotation: This story follows the work of an anthropologist studying the Ache of Paraguay, one of the few remaining hunter-gatherer peoples in the world. The full-color photographs bring a sense of realism to her methods of observation, collection of data, and analysis. See other books in the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Mary Batten

Title: Anton Pirulero (Anton Pirulero)
Annotation: This collection of poems for children features colorful illustrations and a view into the Hispanic culture. Illustrated by Claudia de Teresa and others.
Author: Alma Flor Ada, F. Isabel Campoy

Title: Antonio en el pais del silencio (Antonio in the Country of Silence)
Annotation: Life is lonely for Antonio after his family immigrates to Germany. But after finding comfort in the friendship of two special people, Antonio begins to adjust to this strange new land.
Author: Mercedes Neuschafer-Carlon

Title: Any Small Goodness: A Novel of the Barrio
Annotation: After moving from Mexico to the barrio of East Los Angeles with his family, Arturo and his friends share experiences dealing with a teacher who wants to Americanize their names, playing basketball, and championing the school librarian. Short, upbeat vignettes make this a good read-aloud choice. Includes a glossary of Spanish words. California author and California setting.
Author: Tony Johnston

Title: Apples to Oregon: Being the (Slightly) True Narrative of How a Brave Pioneer Father Brought Apples, Peaches, Pears, Plums, Grapes, and Cherries (and Children) across the Plains
Annotation: A pioneer father transports his beloved fruit trees and his family to Oregon in the mid-nineteenth century. Based loosely on the life of Henderson Luelling, a pioneer who transported plants and fruit trees to Oregon in 1847. Illustrated with oil paintings.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson

Title: Apprentice of the Taoist Priest
Annotation: An impatient young man fails to learn from his Taoist teacher because he lacks perseverance in this traditional Chinese fairy tale.
Author: Song Ling Pu

Title: Archaeologists Dig for Clues
Annotation: A boy and his friends go on a dig in a local cornfield with their archaeologist friend Sophi and make discoveries about how scientists learn about the past. They learn that small pieces of stone, bone, or fossils are clues to long ago. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out-Science series.
Author: Kate Duke

Title: Arctic Adventures: Tales From the Lives of Inuit Artists
Annotation: This book offers four distinct stories based on the lives of modern Inuit artists Pudlo Pudlat, Kenojuak Ashevak, Jessie Oonark, and Lazarusie Ishulutak. Each story is accompanied by detailed illustrations (in colored pencil and mixed media) highlighting the artists and showing creatures from the Arctic landscape. Includes short biographical profiles of each artist, reproductions of the artists’ work, a glossary, and a bibliography.
Author: Raquel Rivera

Title: Arctic Lights, Arctic Nights
Annotation: The author describes the unique light phenomena of arctic Alaska and the ways in which animals adapt to the temperature and daylight changes that occur from one summer solstice to the next. The quiet text tells of the migration of birds and caribou, the hibernation of bears, and the changing coat of the arctic hare. Acrylic artwork provides details to the text, which concludes with a map of Alaska and a glossary.
Author: Debbie S. Miller

Title: Are We Alone? Scientists Search for Life in Space
Annotation: The author presents a study of space and the possibility of extraterrestrial civilizations, UFO sightings throughout the twentieth century, crop circles, and other paranormal occurrences. Well-placed color photographs and illustrations play an important role in helping readers to understand the science concepts presented.
Author: Gloria Skurzynski

Title: Aristoteles y el pensamiento científico (Aristotle and Scientific Thought)
Annotation: This book chronicles the life of Aristotle and his major philosophies. It also gives a quick overview of his world and times, and explains how his ideas set him apart from his contemporaries. Other titles in the Pioneros de la Ciencia (Pioneers of Science) series that have been translated into Spanish include LOUIS PASTEUR Y LOS GERMENES (LOUIS PASTEUR AND GERMS), MARIE CURIE Y EL RADIO (MARIE CURIE AND RADIUM), GUGLIELMO MARCONI Y LA RADIO (GUGLIELMO MARCONI AND THE RADIO), CHARLES DARWIN Y LA EVOLUCION (CHARLES DARWIN AND EVOLUTION), and ISAAC NEWTON Y LA GRAVEDAD (ISAAC NEWTON AND GRAVITY).
Author: Steve Parker
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Arithme-Tickle: An Even Number of Odd Riddle-Rhymes
Annotation: Eighteen silly rhyming riddles involve addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, telling time, logic, and general knowledge. Simple and complex puzzles keep young mathematicians challenged in a fun way. Bright watercolor illustrations keep the tone cheery, and answers are available in mirror writing at the end of each riddle.
Author: J. Patrick Lewis
Standard: Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.MP.1-8, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.OA.1-3, Math 5.MP.1-8

Title: Armando and the Blue Tarp School
Annotation: Armando and his father are trash pickers in Tijuana, Mexico. When señor David, a teacher from New York City, brings his “school”—a blue tarp set down near a garbage dump—to their neighborhood, Armando wants more than anything to attend the school. His father is reluctant but is later convinced that education is important. Based on a true story. Includes a glossary and a note from the authors, both of whom live in California.
Author: Edith Hope Fine, Judith Pinkerton Josephson
Topic: Diversity, Economics, Ethnic Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Around the Pond
Annotation: The interdependent lives of plants and animals that inhabit the ecosystem of a healthy pond is highlighted through the seasons by means of fictional vignettes and short sections providing further information. This picture book is illustrated with soft, realistic paintings that enhance the readable text. See other books in the Wild Wonders series.
Author: Ann C. Cooper

Title: Around The World: Three Remarkable Journeys
Annotation: This graphic novel relates the journeys around the world of three Americans who were inspired by Jules Verne’s adventure. Different modes of transportation were chosen. Thomas Stevens rode a high-wheel bike; Nellie Bly successfully broke Verne’s record, traveling by boat and train; and Joshua Slocum sailed around the world in a 36-foot sloop. The artwork and panels capture the adventure of the three individuals, and each story is followed by an epilogue.
Author: Matt Phelan

Title: Around the World: Who's Been Here?
Annotation: A teacher travels around the world viewing animals in their natural habitats and writes back to her class about her findings. The story is told through her letters in a first-person narrative and includes double-spread paintings accompanied by small drawings that provide details of her experiences. The question "Who's been here?" is posed and readers examine the clues to come up with an answer.
Author: Lindsay Barrett George

Title: Arrow to the Sun: A Pueblo Indian Tale
Annotation: A Pueblo Indian boy is the son of the Sun God and wishes to meet his father. He is shaped into an arrow and shot toward the Sun. He meets several tests while on his quest and then returns to Earth to teach man of the Sun's spirit. The vibrant artwork holds great appeal for all ages. This selection is also available in Spanish.
Author: Gerald McDermott
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary

Title: Arrowhawk
Annotation: A wild hawk is struck by a poacher's arrow while sitting on a fence post eating his catch. Seriously injured, the hawk tries in vain to remove the arrow. He then attempts to continue hunting to stay alive. Near death, the hawk is captured by wildlife preservationists, named Arrowhawk, nursed back to health, and released to once again to live in the wild. This selection includes the facts of the story on which this book is based as well as information about red-tailed hawks.
Author: Lola M. Schaefer

Title: Art & Max
Annotation: Art, a horned lizard who is an accomplished artist, and his friend Max, a smaller lizard and a beginning artist, share an interest in painting. When Art suggests that Max create a painting, Max becomes the canvas for the work. Bright paints begin flying. A playful way to explore the basics of art: line, color, and imagination.
Author: David Wiesner

Title: Art Lesson, The
Annotation: Having learned to be creative by drawing pictures at home, young Tommy is dismayed when he goes to school and finds the art lesson there is much more regimented. The art teacher asks the class to copy her as she draws, and Tommy must use a box of school crayons and only one piece of paper. Ultimately, a compromise is reached as Tommy copies the teacher’s drawing and then is given another piece of paper with which he can do his own work. Illustrated with dePaola’s signature humor and flair.
Author: Tomie dePaola

Title: Art of Freedom: How Artists See America, The
Annotation: Focusing on diversity in the United States, this book presents a variety of definitions of freedom. Each definition is accompanied by a fine reproduction of a famous work of art. The works include images of farms and cities, baseball and jazz, hard work and sacrifice, native peoples and immigrants. Concludes with notes about each picture that present further information about the artists and their work.
Author: Bob Raczka
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: HSS K.2, HSS 1.3, VAPA V PreK-12.3

Title: Art of Miss Chew, The
Annotation: The author tells the story of her days in elementary school as a struggling reader. Her sensitive teacher noticed her art ability and arranged for her to attend a high-school art class. Not only did she excel in the class, she also discovered the cause of her reading problem. This book highlights the importance of the arts and reinforces the importance of looking at each person as an individual. The pencil-and-marker art is full of color and reflects the relationships and emotions of the characters.
Author: Patricia Polacco

Title: Arthur, for the Very First Time
Annotation: Ten-year-old Arthur spends the summer with two relatives, his eccentric great-aunt and great-uncle. This experience helps him look at himself and his family differently.
Author: Patricia MacLachlan

Title: Artist to Artist: 23 Major Illustrators Talk to Children About Their Art
Annotation: This anthology brings together a variety of children’s illustrators as they share their stories and write about their lives and their art. For each illustrator, there are photographs of his or her early work, studios, materials used, sketches, finished works, and self-portraits. An excellent choice for libraries, art teachers, budding artists, and fans of children’s books.
Author: David Briggs (editor)
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2

Title: As Good as Anybody: Martin Luther King Jr. and Abraham Joshua Heschel’s Amazing March Toward Freedom
Annotation: In the southern United States prior to the civil rights movement, young Martin Luther King Jr. finds it difficult to accept the way he and others are treated. As a young preacher, he begins to draw crowds—and he supports the Montgomery boycott and other protests. Abraham, who as a young Jewish boy in Poland witnessed similar discrimination, answers Martin Luther King Jr.’s call and joins the preacher in leading a march in Alabama, from Selma to Montgomery. Illustrated with full-page paintings that bring drama and realism to the story.
Author: Richard Michelson

Title: Ashanti to Zulu: African Traditions
Annotation: This Caldecott Medal award-winner, with full-page illustrations and brief text, describes 26 African tribes and their customs - from A to Z. The richly colored illustrations show the people in typical dress as well as their land, animals, and homes.
Author: Margaret Musgrove
Classification: Alphabet Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Ashley Bryan: Words to My Life’s Song
Annotation: This autobiography of artist and writer Ashley Bryan is told through collages composed of words, vintage photographs, and original artwork. He tells how he was raised amid a series of worldwide disasters and events, including the Great Depression and World War II. This book will inspire artists of every age.
Author: Ashley Bryan

Title: Asi es Josefina: Una nina americana (Meet Josefina: An American Girl)
Annotation: Josefina's mother has just died. Now it is up to Josefina and her four older sisters to help keep their New Mexican ranch running smoothly. When tia Dolores moves in, she provides the young girls with the help they need and also teaches them about life itself.
Author: Valerie Tripp

Title: Ask Albert Einstein
Annotation: This is a fictionalized account of how a seven-year-old girl wrote to Albert Einstein to ask him to help her older sister with a math problem. In this story, based on a 1952 NEW YORK TIMES article, Einstein responds in a unique but ultimately helpful way. Cartoon illustrations are rendered in a nostalgic style. Included are quotations from Einstein.
Author: Lynne Barasch

Title: Asombroso armadillo, El (The Amazing Armadillo)
Annotation: The life cycle, physical characteristics, and migratory patterns of armadillos are discussed in this well-translated book. The detailed close-up photographs will entice students to explore further about this fascinating creature.
Author: Dee Stuart

Title: Asteroid Impact
Annotation: Vividly colored artwork enhances dramatic text that tells the story of an enormous asteroid which struck Earth 65 million years ago and may have been responsible for the extinction of dinosaurs at the end of the Cretaceous Period. It is important to emphasize that this is not the only hypothesis for the extinction. A question and answer section, a bibliography, and an index are included.
Author: Douglas Henderson

Title: At Gleason’s Gym
Annotation: This book focuses on the action at Gleason’s Gym in Brooklyn, New York, where famous boxers such as Muhammad Ali and Jake LaMotta once trained. The story is presented through the eyes of Sugar Boy, a nine-year-old boxing champion, but it also shows girls in training. Vibrant illustrations enhance the text. Includes a glossary.
Author: Ted Lewin
Topic: Motor Skills/Movement Patterns, Nutrition and Physical Activity, Physical Fitness

Title: At Home with the Gopher Tortoise: The Story of a Keystone Species
Annotation: The gopher tortoise is a keystone species; more than 300 different animals depend on this tortoise’s burrow for survival. The burrow provides creatures with shelter, food, or a place to raise their young. This tale of ecological interdependence combines with the book’s full-color acrylic illustrations to reveal the gopher tortoise’s world, both below and above ground. Children learn that a single species is important to many other species in the environment.
Author: Madeleine Dunphy

Title: Atlas of the Animals, The
Annotation: This book offers an overview of the animal kingdom. It provides descriptions and illustrations of the adaptations of animals, endangered status, and habitats on a continent by continent basis.
Author: Linda Sonntag

Title: Atomos y moleculas (Atoms and Molecules)
Annotation: Atoms and molecules are explored with colorful illustrations, photographs, charts, and sidebars to accompany the text. This book is a good introduction into the world of atoms. See other books in the Understanding Nature  series.
Author: Maria Dolores Martinez i No
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Audubon: Painter of Birds In the Wild Frontier
Annotation: This selection is a picture-book biography of Audubon, the American naturalist most famous for his detailed paintings of birds. The author uses primary and secondary sources in her engaging narrative of the activities and achievements of Audubon, including the natural experiences that shaped his work, his meeting with Daniel Boone, and his experience in an earthquake. The watercolor, pen, and pencil illustrations and some of Audubon’s own artwork enhance this book.
Author: Jennifer  Armstrong

Title: Aunt Clara Brown: Official Pioneer
Annotation: Former slave Clara Brown bought her freedom in 1859 and traveled to Colorado in search of the daughter who had been sold away from her years before. Driven by a desire to find her child and a passion to help others, Clara used her newfound wealth to help other freed slaves start over.
Author: Linda Lowery

Title: Aunt Harriet’s Underground Railroad in the Sky
Annotation: Using the same motif of flying that she used in TAR BEACH, and featuring the children from that book, Cassie and BeBe, author Faith Ringgold presents a fantasy in which the children take to the sky and meet a “ramshackled train in the sky” with Harriet Tubman as the conductor. When Cassie is left behind, she aims to reunite with her younger brother by retracing the steps taken by slaves who traveled the Underground Railroad. Illustrated with Ringgold’s signature style: primitive-looking artwork featuring bold colors.
Author: Faith Ringgold

Title: Auntie Yang’s Great Soybean Picnic
Annotation: Two sisters from Indiana look forward to visiting their cousin’s house outside Chicago. They originally came to the United States to study, and they stayed in America because war in China prevented them from going back. While on a country drive one day, the sisters see a soybean field. Excitedly, they ask the farmer if they may pick some. So begins an annual soybean picnic that gets bigger and bigger each year. A loving look at a family tradition, this book was illustrated by a ceramic artist who painted each scene on a plate.
Author: Ginnie Lo
Topic: Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Author: A True Story
Annotation: This funny, lighthearted autobiography tells of the successes and disappointments of being an author. Illustrated with Lester's own childlike, comic cartoons, the book shows that even if writing is a struggle, it can still be enjoyable. This selection is useful for lessons in language arts because it describes the roles and contributions of authors and illustrators to print materials.
Author: Helen Lester

Title: Autobus magico: En el cuerpo humano, El (Magic School Bus: Inside the Human Body)
Annotation: Miss Frizzle takes her students on the Magic School Bus to explore the wonders of the human body. Colorful illustrations and a text that delivers a lot of information with a comic book style draw readers into the subject. See other books in the Magic School Bus series.
Author: Joanna Cole

Title: Autobus magico: En el interior de la tierra, El (Magic School Bus: Inside the Earth
Annotation: On a special field trip, the Magic School Bus takes Ms. Frizzle and her class deep into Earth. They learn first-hand about different kinds of rocks and Earth's formation. The detailed illustrations offer an opportunity for further exploration. Other books in the Magic School Bus series include EL AUTOBUS MAGICO: EN EL CUERPO HUMANO (THE MAGIC SCHOOL BUS: INSIDE THE HUMAN BODY), EL AUTOBUS MAGICO: EN EL SISTEMA SOLAR (THE MAGIC SCHOOL BUS: LOST IN THE SOLAR SYSTEM), and EL AUTOBUS MAGICO: JUEGA A LA PELOTA (THE MAGIC SCHOOL BUS PLAYS BALL).
Author: Joanna Cole

Title: Aves rapaces, Las (Birds of Prey)
