Annotation: This book gives an explanation of habitats and life cycles of numerous birds of prey from eagles to vultures. Other books in the Esa Horrible Ciencia (Horrible Science) series include LAS ABERJAS (THE BEES), LOS CASTORES Y LOS TOPOS (BEAVERS AND MOLES), LAS HORMIGAS (ANTS), LAS MARIPOSAS (BUTTERFLIES), LOS ARANAS (SPIDERS), and LAS AVES Y LOS MURCIELAGOS (BATS).
Author: Maria Angels Julivert

Title: B. Franklin, Printer
Annotation: This biography of Benjamin Franklin is filled with original quotations by Franklin. The text is accompanied by archival prints and includes maps, chronologies, source notes, recommended Web sites, a bibliography, and index.
Author: David A. Adler

Title: Ba Nam (Mrs. Nam)
Annotation: This selection explains the story of Thanh Minh, a Vietnamese holiday that honors ancestors.
Author: Jeanne M. Loc

Title: Babe: The Gallant Pig
Annotation: Babe the pig is brought home from auction by Farmer Hogget; is adopted by the sheepdog, Fly; and teaches the farm animals about politeness and courtesy. But the surprise occurs when Babe becomes a "pigdog" at the national sheepdog trials.
Author: Dick King-Smith

Title: Babushka Baba Yaga
Annotation: Baba Yaga yearns to be a babushka, and dresses as one to fool the villagers. She thus becomes Victor's babushka and now has a child to love. When the children of the village are told of the many evils of Baba Yaga, she flees into the forest. But when Baba Yaga saves Victor from the wolves, she becomes the village's beloved Babushka Baba Yaga.
Author: Patricia Polacco

Title: Baby Flo: Florence Mills Lights Up the Stage
Annotation: Florence Mills was a well-known African American dancer, singer, and comedian during the Harlem Renaissance. This picture book for older readers centers on her early years. Florence was admired by audiences around the world and by legends of the jazz age before her early death at the age of thirty-one. Informative for students interested in the performing arts as well as those wanting to know more about the Harlem Renaissance. Includes an author’s note and historical photographs. California author.
Author: Alan Schroeder
Topic: Dance, Diversity, Visual Arts, Women’s Studies
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Babymouse: Rock Star
Annotation: Spunky, ambitious, and known to daydream, Babymouse strives to improve her skills as a flutist while standing up to the school bully, Felicia Furrypaws. She befriends Penny, a talented poodle who is another victim and who helps Babymouse make her dreams come true. This fourth book in the Babymouse series has a fast-moving plot, silly situations, and pink-toned, black-and-white illustrations. Those who enjoy graphic novels will find it endearing.
Author: Jennifer L. Holm, Matthew Holm

Title: Bach’s Goldberg Variations
Annotation: A fictional account centering on the composition and naming of one of Johann Sebastian Bach’s most famous works. Seventeenth-century composer J. S. Bach helps young organist Johann Gottlieb Goldberg by giving him lessons and presenting him with a composition that has come to be called “The Goldberg Variations.” Includes historical notes, watercolor artwork reflecting the baroque period, and an audio CD of Bach’s “Goldberg Variations.”
Author: Anna Harwell Celenza

Title: Back in the Beforetime: Tales of the California Indians
Annotation: This collection retells 22 legends from various California Indian tribes. Coyote, the "trickster" of the animal world, figures prominently in these creation tales detailing the geography, animal life, and people of California. California author.
Author: Jane Louise Curry (adapter)

Title: Back of the Bus
Annotation: A young African American boy and his mother are riding the same bus that Rosa Parks is on when she takes her famous stand for equal rights. The event is told through the eyes of the boy as he entertains himself by letting his marble roll up and down the aisle with the movement of the bus. The bus stops suddenly, and after a commotion in the aisle he sees Mrs. Parks being taken away. Illustrated with oil paintings that enhance the story.
Author: Aaron Reynolds

Title: Bad Case of Stripes, A
Annotation: Camilla Cream loves lima beans but won't eat them because her friends hate them. Her constant concern over what others think of her causes Camilla to break out in a "bad case of stripes," for which she finally finds the perfect solution. Expressive, surreal illustrations offer varying perspectives in a picture-book format. California author and California illustrator.
Author: David Shannon

Title: Bad News for Outlaws: The Remarkable Life of Bass Reeves, Deputy U.S. Marshal
Annotation: Chronicles the life of Bass Reeves, a former slave who was recruited as a deputy United States marshal because of his ability to communicate with the Native Americans in the area that eventually became Oklahoma. Reeves was exceptional at tracking down fugitives and bringing them to justice. This well-researched picture book for older readers features bold, full-page paintings and lively text. It also includes a glossary, time line, and bibliographical references. Coretta Scott King Author Winner in 2010.
Author: Vaunda Micheaux Nelson

Title: Bad River Boys: A Meeting of the Lakota Sioux with Lewis and Clark
Annotation: Based on William Clark’s account, this story focuses on an encounter between Lewis and Clark’s expedition and three young Lakota boys. With no interpreter aboard the expedition’s boat, the encounter is uneasy—and it seems likely that there will be an outbreak of violence. However, everyone is put at ease with the appearance of Seaman, the expedition’s dog, and York, an African American who is part of the expedition. The story is told from the perspective of the three Native American boys. Illustrated with full-color oil paintings.
Author: Virginia Driving Hawk Sneve

Title: Badger's Parting Gifts
Annotation: Badger does not want his friends to feel sad about his imminent death, but they are overwhelmed by their loss until they start sharing the special moments they have experienced with him and realize that he will always be with them. Pen-and-ink watercolors keep the story's mood hopeful.
Author: Susan Varley

Title: Bald Eagle
Annotation: A nature artist provides a close-up look at two bald eagle nestlings and provides a detailed account of the life cycle, characteristics, and migration of the bald eagle. Large watercolor artwork, black-ink drawings, and two levels of text provide a variety of information sources for young naturalists.
Author: Gordon Morrison

Title: Bald Eagle Returns, The
Annotation: The informative text in this revision of WHERE BALD EAGLES GATHER (Clarion, 1984), describes how bald eagles have recovered from the threat of extinction, eagle behavior, and how they raise their families. Background information is also included as to why they are the national bird of the United States. The book is illustrated with large, captioned, full-color photographs.
Author: Dorothy Hinshaw Patent

Title: Ballad of Lucy Whipple, The
Annotation: Desiring to return to Massachusetts, Lucy tries desperately to change her mother's mind about working in the gold fields of California. Writing helps Lucy to understand her conflicting feelings about this wild land. California author and setting.
Author: Karen Cushman

Title: Ballad of Mu Lan, The
Annotation: Fa Mu Lan, a heroine of ancient China, took her father's place in the army and led it to victory. The traditional theme is her deed of filial devotion, a much-valued trait. The full original text of the ballad is provided.
Author: Song Nan Zhang

Title: Ballad of Mulan, The
Annotation: Taking the place of her frail father as a soldier defending her people from invaders, a brave Chinese girl masquerades as a soldier and fights, leads, and ultimately returns home as a triumphant general. The book is illustrated by the author using traditional Chinese motifs in pen and ink and watercolor. Regional dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text.
Author: Song Nan Zhang

Title: Ballet for Martha: Making Appalachian Spring
Annotation: Tells the story of the creation of the ballet Appalachian Spring, from its inception through its creation and performance. Highlights the collaboration between innovative choreographer Martha Graham, composer Aaron Copeland, and artist Isamu Noguchi, who worked together to create this masterpiece of dance and music. The poetic prose, accompanied by line and watercolor illustrations, conveys the simplicity of a pioneer wedding.
Author: Jan Greenberg, Sandra Jordan
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.3

Title: Ballet of the Elephants
Annotation: Tells the story of how circus owner John Ringling North, choreographer George Balanchine, and composer Igor Stravinsky teamed up to create the “Circus Polka,” a ballet performed by 50 elephants and 50 dancers. Describes the opening-night performance in 1942. Bright and muted watercolor-and-ink illustrations capture the movement of this unusual partnership. Concludes with author notes and black-and-white photos of the ballet, along with additional facts.
Author: Leda Schubert

Title: Ballet Shoes
Annotation: Tells the stories of three adopted sisters who take dancing and stage training: one becomes an actress, the second becomes a ballerina, and the third becomes a pilot. Living in London, each sister is determined to make a name for herself—and in the process, the sisters discover that each sibling has a special talent.
Author: Noel Streatfeild
Topic: Dance, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, Theatre
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.4, VAPA D PreK-12.5, VAPA T PreK-12.1, VAPA T PreK-12.3, VAPA T PreK-12.4, VAPA T PreK-12.5

Title: Balloon Boy of San Francisco, The
Annotation: In 1853, fourteen-year-old Ready Gates, a San Francisco newsboy, struggles to support his family. He is always ready to supplement his income with an odd job. He shows up at San Francisco’s first hot-air-balloon flight, hoping to sell peanuts. His small body size makes him the person selected to pilot the balloon. Ready makes history and becomes something of a celebrity. The story is based on an actual event and includes good descriptions of nineteenth-century San Francisco. The book also includes a map of the balloon’s flight path. California author.
Author: Dorothy Kupcha Leland

Title: Balloons Over Broadway: The True Story of the Puppeteer of Macy’s Parade
Annotation: Tony Sarg loved all things that moved. His rigged pulleys and ropes from his bedroom window to feed chickens, and he eventually began to make marionettes. R. H. Macy hired Sarg to create “puppet parades” for the famous department store’s holiday windows and “puppets” for Macy’s outdoor parade. Collage illustrations are enhanced by various typefaces, old newspaper articles, silhouettes, and occasional comic strips.
Author: Melissa Sweet
Genre: Biography/Autobiography, Historical Fiction, Narrative Nonfiction, Nonfiction

Title: Ballot Box Battle
Annotation: Cordelia, a young girl, lives next door to Elizabeth Cady Stanton. Cordelia befriends Mrs. Stanton and is literally dragged to a voting booth, where Mrs. Stanton is denied the right to cast her ballot in the election for the U.S. presidency. Mrs. Stanton encourages Cordelia to become the best at everything she does, to take risks, and to show that she is every bit as worthy as her brother to fulfill her potential.
Author: Emily Arnold McCully
Topic: American History, Diversity, Government and Politics, Personal and Community Health, Women’s Studies

Title: Baloney (Henry P.)
Annotation: A transmission received from outer space in a combination of different Earth languages tells of an alien schoolboy's fantastic excuse for being late to school again. His excuse culminates with an explanation of how he was assisted by the Law of Gravity in his efforts to get away from some "Astro guys" who wanted to eat him.
Author: Jon Scieszka
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Bananas!
Annotation: Information describing the growth cycle, varieties, history, and nutritional value of bananas is presented with pages that are highlighted with bamboo frames. Humorous cartoon illustrations provide visual support to the information. The book includes trivia, recipes, jokes, and riddles.
Author: Jacqueline Farmer

Title: Band of Angels: A Story Inspired by the Jubilee Singers, A
Annotation: Ella Sheppard was born a slave, but her freedom was purchased by her father. After the Civil War, she made her way to Fisk School and became the pianist for the Jubilee Singers, whose concert tour introduced spirituals to the world. The large illustrations are rendered in golden tones of watercolor and colored pencil.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Bandit's Moon
Annotation: Orphan Annyrose sets off to find her brother in the California gold fields, is held hostage by O. O. Mary, and rescued by the notorious outlaw Joaquin Murietta. Thinking Annyrose is a boy, Murietta spares her life after she promises to teach him to read so that he can find out what is being said about him in newspapers and on posters. California author and setting.
Author: Sid Fleischman

Title: Barefoot Book of Stories from the Opera, The
Annotation: Summaries of seven opera plots that appeal to children are presented. Includes information about famous opera houses, the activities behind the scenes, traditional voices, and composers. Stories include Mozart’s “The Magic Flute,” Engelbert Humperdinck’s “Hansel and Gretel,” and Rimsky-Korsakov’s “Christmas Eve,” among others. Ink-and-watercolor illustrations depict characters and stories. Two CDs feature Miranda Richardson narrating the stories. Available only in paperback.
Author: Shahrukh Husain
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA T PreK-12.3

Title: Barefoot: Escape on the Underground Railroad
Annotation: Told from the point of view of the woodland animals, this story is about a runaway slave who escapes his pursuers, partly with the help of the animals.
Author: Pamela Duncan Edwards

Title: Barn Owl, The
Annotation: In an old barn, a pair of endangered barn owls hunt, court, mate, nest, and raise their young over the course of a year. Strong, narrative information is enriched with naturalistic paintings. Included are an index, a glossary, and endnotes with contacts for further information. See other books in the Animal Lives series.
Author: Sally Tagholm

Title: Barrio: Jose's Neighborhood
Annotation: Full-color photographs detail life in a Latino barrio in San Francisco. The school, recreation, holidays, and family life of an eight-year-old boy who lives there are described. California setting.
Author: George Ancona

Title: Baseball Hour
Annotation: This book blends illustrations and text to describe a typical baseball practice. A multicultural team of young boys and girls demonstrate drills and  teamwork. The photo-realistic illustrations capture the children’s  warm-up exercises, their baseball skills in practice, a warm-up game, and a circle of hands forming “a wheel of friends.”
Author: Carol Nevius

Title: Baseball Saved Us
Annotation: A Japanese American boy learns to play baseball when he and his family are forced to live in an internment camp during World War II. Together, he and his father decide to build a baseball diamond and establish a baseball league in the grim surroundings of the camp. His ability to play the game and resolve to do his best help him after the war is over as well. This story connects to eighth-grade history/social science. California setting.
Author: Ken Mochizuki

Title: Basketball Belles: How Two Teams and One Scrappy Player Put Women’s Hoops on the Map
Annotation: In this picture book, Agnes Morley describes her experience of playing basketball for Stanford University and explains how the sport was adapted for women. Agnes and her teammates competed in the first all-female intercollegiate basketball game, played between Stanford and the University of California, Berkeley. The book includes an author’s note with biographical details about the players, a time line, information about the history of women’s basketball in the United States, and a photograph of the 1896 Stanford women’s basketball team. California author.
Author: Sue Macy
Standard: PE K-8.5, HSS K.6, HSS 1.5, HSS 3.3, HSS 4.4

Title: Bat Boy and His Violin, The
Annotation: Reginald would rather play his violin than baseball. His father is managing the worst team in the Negro Leagues and makes Reginald the bat boy. When his music in the dugout seems to have a positive effect on the team's performance, Reginald's father is very pleased with his son's musical talent. The book can be used in conjunction with YANG THE YOUNGEST AND HIS TERRIBLE EAR.
Author: Gavin Curtis

Title: Bat Jamboree
Annotation: Fifty-five bats perform in a toe-tapping, wing-flapping review. The bats, starting with ten at the bottom, then rows of nine, eight, seven, six, five, four, three, two, one, make a pyramid of 55 bats awaiting the grand finale.
Author: Kathi Appelt
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Number Sense

Title: Bats! Strange and Wonderful
Annotation: This overview of bats provides basic information about the variety of bats and their habits. Appealing watercolor illustrations and engaging text provide information on the anatomy, unique abilities, and environmental benefits of bats.
Author: Laurence P. Pringle

Title: Bats, Bugs, and Biodiversity: Adventures in the Amazonian Rain Forest
Annotation: This is a vivid account of the exploration and adventures of school-age children in the Amazonian rain forest in Peru. They learned how to survive, to respect the native peoples, and developed an understanding of the natural environment. Text and extraordinary photographs provide remarkable insight into this unfamiliar and endangered world.
Author: Susan E. Goodman

Title: Battle Begins, The
Annotation: In this first book of the “Underworlds” series, Owen Brown thinks life is normal until he gets to school late one day—just in time to see the floor open up and swallow his best friend, Dana. The story follows Owen and two friends as they seek to rescue Dana in the Underworld, where they encounter numerous mythological figures and gods as well as humorous situations. Illustrated with black-and-white sketches of mythical monsters, this book provides a good introduction to mythological figures. Recommended for reluctant readers.
Author: Tony Abbott

Title: Be a Friend to Trees
Annotation: This easy-to-read book discusses the importance of trees as sources of food and oxygen for people and wild animals. Diagrams and full-color labeled illustrations complement the text. The author recommends actions such as conserving and recycling paper. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out-Science series.
Author: Patricia Lauber
Standard: LS K.2, ES K.3, ES 2.3, LS 3.3, LS 4.3

Title: Bean Thirteen
Annotation: Try as they may, Ralph and Flora cannot evenly divide the 13 beans they picked for dinner. Mathematically, the task is impossible—but Flora has a solution. This title, with its bright digital illustrations and effective pacing, reinforces the concepts of grouping, division, remainders, and prime numbers and may be used to introduce division.
Author: Matthew McElligott
Grade Level Span: Preschool/Pre thru K, K thru 2, 3 thru 5

Title: Bear Called Paddington, A
Annotation: When Mr. and Mrs. Brown find a small bear at Paddington Station, he becomes one of the family. The delightful adventures of Paddington amaze the Brown household.
Author: Michael Bond

Title: Bear Named Trouble, A
Annotation: Trouble is a hungry, young Alaskan brown bear that breaks into the Alaska Zoo in Anchorage and kills a goose, a favorite animal of children visiting the zoo. The zookeeper's son, Jonathan, loved the goose and is angry but does not want to see the bear destroyed. He comes to realize that the bear was behaving only in the ways of a wild animal. The story is told in alternating voices - those of Trouble and Jonathan. The story is based on a true incident.
Author: Marion Dane Bauer

Title: Bear’s Picture
Annotation: A bear is painting a picture with creative squiggles and bright colors. Two gentlemen pass by and announce that “bears can’t paint pictures.” In spite of the criticism, the bear continues to paint what he likes. As the two men continue to criticize the bear, they slowly disappear into the stream that is depicted in the painting. Illustrated with mixed-media artwork in D. B. Johnson’s striking cubist style.
Author: Daniel Pinkwater
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Bears Make Rock Soup
Annotation: Illustrated with lively watercolors, this collection of stories is inspired by paintings that depict the special relationships between the plains, the woodland Indians, and such animals as bears, deer, moose, crows, and loons.
Author: Lise Erdrich

Title: Bearskin
Annotation: A brave young man, raised by a bear with unusual powers, rescues a princess from a menacing dragon and fulfills a prophecy made long ago that he would marry the King's daughter.
Author: Howard Pyle

Title: Beasts of Clawstone Castle, The
Annotation: With their parents in America for the summer, Madlyn and Rollo are sent to their aunt and uncle’s castle in northern England. Times are tough, and tourists are going to the fancier castle down the road. Madlyn and Rollo decide to help their aunt and uncle save the castle and their prized cattle from a villainous doctor; they enlist a group of ghosts to entertain the tourists. The children encounter humorous situations and a great mystery.
Author: Eva Ibbotson
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Lifestyles Around the World

Title: Beat the Story-Drum, Pum-Pum
Annotation: Five Nigerian folktales are presented in this collection: "Hen and Frog," "Why Bush Cow and Elephant Are Bad Friends," "The Husband Who Counted the Spoonfuls," "Why Frog and Snake Never Play Together," and "How Animals Got Their Tails." The tales are accompanied by bold woodcuts in ochre, red, and black.
Author: Ashley Bryan (editor)

Title: Beatrix Potter
Annotation: This beginning-level biography captures the essence of Beatrix Potter's long life and her work as an author and illustrator of children's books beloved the world over. This selection includes archival photographs and drawings rendered by Potter. It is part of the Tell Me About series of beginning biographies.
Author: John Malam
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Beautiful Blackbird
Annotation: In a story of the Ila people, the colorful birds of Africa ask Blackbird, whom they think is the most beautiful of birds, to decorate them with some of his "blackening brew." The overlapping collage images fill the pages with energy and color.
Author: Ashley Bryan

Title: Beautiful Warrior: The Legend of the Nun's Kung Fu
Annotation: When a bandit wants Mingyi for his bride, she asks him to wait one year and then challenges him to a kung fu contest. She seeks out a Buddhist nun, Wu Mei, to teach her the skills in martial arts that will save her from marriage to the bandit. This suspenseful story has detailed, misty landscapes in watercolor, tempera, and pastel that, along with notes, enhance a story that deals with Chinese philosophy, sex-role models, and determination. Use this selection along with the Mulan stories.
Author: Emily Arnold McCully

Title: Beauty of the Beast: Poems from the Animal Kingdom
Annotation: Vibrant watercolor illustrations bring to life 20 poems about insects, sea creatures, reptiles, amphibians, birds, and mammals and support a wide variety of poetic styles, including haiku and humor. The poems found in this collection are for science teachers and animal lovers.
Author: Jack Prelutsky
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, Science

Title: Bebop Express
Annotation: A rollicking, rhythmic express train travels from New York to New Orleans, picking up jazz musicians along the way. Soon a bebop combo is swinging amid bright collage paintings accompanied by onomatopoetic jazz sounds. This selection addresses jazz, geography, and rhyme. A read-aloud choice.
Author: H. L. Panahi
Grade Level Span: Preschool/Pre thru K, K thru 2, 3 thru 5

Title: Because . . .
Annotation: A young boy who lives with his grandmother is terribly embarrassed as she leapfrogs, flops, slides, does cartwheels, and more. He comes to realize that she is not just having fun but has a reason for each strange action: “Because . . .” she continues to answer, “I am a dancer!” Lighthearted watercolor illustrations add just the right amount of humor.
Author: Mikhail Baryshnikov
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.2

Title: Because of Mr. Terupt
Annotation: Seven different students tell the story of their fifth-grade year. Short chapters alternate with the voice of each student. The school year begins with a new, energetic teacher who really understands the students and makes learning fun. The personal stories of each character come together when a prank results in a tragedy. This is a powerful story that will lead to discussion.
Author: Rob Buyea

Title: Because of Winn-Dixie
Annotation: When Opal and her father, the preacher, move to Florida, Opal goes into a Winn-Dixie supermarket and comes out with a dog. With the help of her new pal, Opal makes a variety of new, interesting friends. She spends the summer collecting stories about them and thinking about her absent mother. This is a funny and unforgettable coming-of-age novel.
Author: Kate DiCamillo
Discipline: History/Social Science, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Becoming Joe DiMaggio
Annotation: In this verse novel, Joseph Paul, born in 1936 and named after the great Joe DiMaggio, learns about his namesake from his beloved grandfather, Papa-Angelo. From these two figures, Joseph Paul learns to overcome the fact that his father is in prison and that he can realize his dream of becoming a doctor.
Author: Maria Testa

Title: Becoming Naomi León
Annotation: Naomi León and her little brother, Owen, live with Gram in a California trailer park. When Naomi’s errant mother, accompanied by an unsavory boyfriend, resurfaces to claim her, Naomi, Gram, and Owen flee in “Baby Beluga,” Gram’s trailer, to Mexico. They go in search of the children’s father, a wood carver in Mexico, with whom they can stay. California author.
Author: Pam Muñoz Ryan
Topic: Ethnic Studies, Immigration/Migration, Visual Arts, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Bee Tree, The
Annotation: A little girl's grandfather teaches her to savor the sweetness of reading by taking her on a bee chase. The honey they gather is used as an object lesson to show the value of reading. This story is based on a Polacco family tradition.
Author: Patricia Polacco

Title: Bee-Man of Orn, The
Annotation: The Bee-Man lives humbly in a hut that resembles an immense beehive. He is visited by a young sorcerer who tells him he is not what he seems. The Bee-Man begins a quest to discover his true identity. The text of Stockton's 1887 short story is accompanied by Lynch's watercolor-and-gouache paintings that reflect this mysterious world. Includes a DVD showing the artist at work in his studio.
Author: Frank R. Stockton
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements

Title: Beethoven Lives Upstairs
Annotation: The letters exchanged between ten-year-old Christoph and his uncle show how Christoph's feelings for Mr. Beethoven, the eccentric boarder who shares his house, change from anger and embarrassment to compassion and admiration. A music compact disc is available that includes both the story and excerpts from Beethoven's music.
Author: Barbara Nichol
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Beetle Book, The
Annotation: Introduces beetles, with an overview of basic beetle anatomy, senses, behaviors, life cycles, communications, and defenses. Life-size torn and cut paper collage artwork in Jenkin’s detailed signature style provide a proper perspective for comparisons. A list of featured beetles, along with their Latin names, and their principal geographic locations is included.
Author: Steve Jenkins
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Winner

Title: Before John Was a Jazz Giant: A Song of John Coltrane
Annotation: A biography of John Coltrane that focuses on his childhood and adolescent years and discusses his inspirations, influences, family, the development of his musical talent, and more. Illustrated with vibrant artwork and lyrical stanzas that add zest to the story. An author’s note at the end fills in biographical detail and recommends books and CDs.
Author: Carole Boston Weatherford

Title: Before There Was Mozart: The Story of Joseph Boulogne, Chevalier de Saint-George
Annotation: Joseph Boulogne, Chevalier de Saint-George, was born in the West Indies, the only son of a white plantation owner of French nobility and a slave. Raised as a privileged child, Saint-George was exposed to music at an early age and became a musical prodigy. He was a contemporary of Mozart, and though the two composers performed in the same hall, they never met. This book is illustrated with mixed-media paintings that depict scenes of the West Indies and of wealthy Parisians. An author’s note provides details about Saint-George’s later years.
Author: Lesa Cline-Ransome

Title: Before We Were Free
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Anita is faced with the average adolescent obsessions: boys and her appearance. She becomes aware of the mounting political danger to her family in the Dominican Republic of the early 1960s. With her mother, Anita goes into hiding and keeps a secret diary as a means of coping with traumatic events. The first-person narrative and suspenseful plot will elicit thought-provoking discussions about growing up, family ties, courage, the cost of freedom, and political views. Useful in the study of Latin American history and culture.
Author: Julia Alvarez

Title: Behind the Couch
Annotation: Readers follow Zachary through a strange world of fantasy after he drops Wallace, his stuffed pig, behind the couch. Behind the couch is a forest of furniture legs, dust creatures, old toys, and other people looking for possessions in the world "behind the couch."
Author: Mordicai Gerstein

Title: Behind the Mask: A Book About Prepositions
Annotation: Provides an engaging lesson on prepositions. Vivid, double-page illustrations accompany rhyming text that defines the purpose of prepositions. Prepositions are highlighted and are presented in large type size so that children can see them if the book is used as a read-aloud. An excellent resource for grammar lessons, the book provides an effective review of prepositions for students in middle and upper grades. California author–illustrator.
Author: Ruth Heller
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Behind the Museum Door: Poems to Celebrate the Wonders of Museums
Annotation: Fourteen poems by stellar children’s poets describe what can be found in different kinds of museums. Poets include J. Patrick Lewis, Myra Cohn Livingston, Lillian Moore, and others. The artwork is bright and cheerful in acrylic paint, oil pastel, and colored pencil. It is filled with enough details that children will want to study the art—just like in a museum. Lee Bennett Hopkins is the selector of this collection of poems.
Author: Lee Bennett Hopkins (editor)
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Visual Arts, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Behold the Beautiful Dung Beetle
Annotation: Simple science text and dramatic illustrations give a close-up view of the fascinating world of the dung beetle. When an animal lightens its load, dung beetles race to the scene. They battle over, devour, hoard, and lay their eggs in the precious poop. Dung is food, drink, and fuel for new life—as crucial to these beetles as the beetles are to many habitats, including our own.
Author: Cheryl Bardoe

Title: Belle, the Last Mule at Gee’s Bend: A Civil Rights Story
Annotation: Alex, a contemporary African American boy, wonders why Belle—a mule—is allowed to eat as many collard greens as it wants. Miz Pettway explains to Alex that when Martin Luther King, Jr., came in 1965 to sign up black residents to vote, Belle and other mules brought the black community to register after the ferry was shut down. When Dr. King was killed, Belle and another mule pulled his casket through the streets of Atlanta. Based on a true story and illustrated with acrylic artwork, this book is useful for learning about Dr. King and the civil rights movement.
Author: Bettye Stroud, Calvin Alexander Ramsey

Title: Ben and Me: A New and Astonishing Life of Benjamin Franklin as Written by His Good Mouse Amos
Annotation: Amos the mouse, good friend of Benjamin Franklin, tells the "real" story of the great patriot's life. The events he retells include the invention of the Franklin stove, the invention of electricity, and the Revolutionary War. This delightful read-aloud book can enhance the history/social science curriculum and is often overlooked for newer fiction.
Author: Robert Lawson

Title: Ben Franklin and the Magic Squares
Annotation: A fictionalized account highlights Ben Franklin and his lifelong interests as an inventor, publisher, scientist, writer, and patriot. One of his inventions was the magic square, which he published in his newspaper for his readers. A magic square is a nine-cell grid in which three numbers add vertically, horizontally, and diagonally to the same sum. Information on how to create a magic square is included at the end of the book. Part of Scholastic’s “Step into Reading” series.
Author: Frank Murphy

Title: Benjamin Franklin: The Man Who Could Do Just About Anything
Annotation: Provides readers with a true sense of who Benjamin Franklin was, in addition to his accomplishments. Clear, thoughtful descriptions of and anecdotes from Franklin’s life, along with the accessible text, make this a good biography choice for reluctant readers. Recommended as a beginning biography and for older students reading below grade level.
Author: Sneed B. Collard III

Title: Benno and the Night of Broken Glass
Annotation: Benno, an orange and white cat, spends his days in Berlin, doing all the things cats like to do. One night, fires spread across his neighborhood, and glass is shattered everywhere. This is the tragic story of Kristallnacht (Night of Broken Glass) as observed by the cat. Illustrated with collage artwork and drawings. Includes an afterword with photographs. Pair this book with THE CATS IN KRAZINSKI SQUARE (2004) by Karen Hesse for another view of the Holocaust.
Author: Meg Wiviott
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, War

Title: Bessie Smith and the Night Riders
Annotation: On a hot August night in 1927, African American blues singer Bessie Smith single-handedly scares off Ku Klux Klan members who try to disrupt her show in Concord, North Carolina. The story is based on an actual incident “dressed up a little for dramatic effect.” The vibrant color and expression of the acrylic illustrations make the story come to life. Includes an author’s note and bibliography.
Author: Sue Stauffacher
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Best Book of Fossils, Rocks and Minerals, The
Annotation: A variety of rocks, minerals, fossils, and gems all contribute to an understanding of mineralogy. This book discusses where to find rocks and minerals, how they're formed, and how to identify them. The illustrations are easy to follow and contain additional facts that are both interesting and surprising.
Author: Chris Pellant

Title: Best Book of Volcanoes, The
Annotation: Information about volcanoes, including how they are formed, where they are located, how they have impacted Earth, and descriptions of famous eruptions is presented. Full-page illustrations provide visual information. A glossary and an index for research are included.
Author: Simon Adams

Title: Best Christmas Pageant Ever, The
Annotation: The whole town thinks that the Herdmans are the worst kids in the whole, wide world. They "steal" all the main parts in the Christmas pageant and then their interpretations are "off the wall" and even sacrilegious. And yet, as time and rehearsals pass and the performance begins, something special happens to the attitudes of both the community and the Herdmans. The sequel to this book is BEST SCHOOL YEAR EVER.
Author: Barbara Robinson

Title: Best of Times: Math Strategies That Multiply, The
Annotation: Engaging rhymes present multiplication through the use of numbers from zero through ten. Young readers are encouraged to arrive at answers on their own rather than by memorizing. For example, multiplying by two means you can multiply by four and even by eight. Colorful and clear digital artwork shows animals engaged in a variety of activities, such as painting, dancing, fishing.
Author: Greg Tang

Title: Best Story, The
Annotation: The young girl in this whimsically illustrated adventure is on a mission to win a writing contest so that she can win a roller-coaster ride with her favorite author. She solicits the advice of everyone in her zany family and comes to some profound conclusions about what elements are the most important to good writing. An excellent read-aloud choice for workshops on writing.
Author: Eileen Spinelli

Title: Between Earth and Sky: Legends of Native American Sacred Places
Annotation: With the retelling of some Native American legends a young boy learns that everything living and inanimate has its place, should be considered sacred, and given respect. The short legends are told in free-verse and are accompanied by full-page oil paintings in Locker's signature style. Various ecosystems across the United States are shown.
Author: Joseph Bruchac
Discipline: History/Social Science, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, Science

Title: Beyond the Dance: A Ballerina’s Life
Annotation: Photographs and text provide an autobiographical account of the life of ballerina Chan Hon Goh in Communist China. Born to dancer parents, the narrative tells about her early childhood in Beijing, her family’s flight to Canada, her rigorous training, and her artistic achievements. This intimate look at the life of a dancer will appeal to students of ballet and to children who understand what it means to pursue a dream.
Author: Chan Hon Goh
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.5

Title: Bicycle Man
Annotation: Sports day at a small mountain school in occupied Japan has Japanese students watching in awe as an African American soldier performs amazing feats on the school principal's bicycle. The solider is urged on by his red-haired buddy, who also interacts warmly with the students. Say's delicate pen-and-ink drawings match the exuberance of the text and are well displayed in picture-book format. California author/illustrator.
Author: Allen Say

Title: Big Bang! The Tongue-Tickling Tale of a Speck That Became Spectacular
Annotation: Imagine that the universe was once just a small speck the size of a piece of dust. Then it expanded until it was large enough to see. Then, in a way, it "sneezed!" The theory of the beginning of the universe is explained in this way in this colorful and dynamic picture book.
Author: Carolyn Cinami DeCristofano

Title: Big Bug Book
Annotation: This concept book presents a close-up look at 13 of the world's largest insects, set against such everyday objects as a fish bowl or crayons to give a sense of scale. Framed text faces the "larger-than-life" illustrations. Students will be inspired to look in nature for the real insects.
Author: Margery Facklam

Title: Big Elephant in the Room, The
Annotation: A donkey tells his friend that they need to talk about “the big elephant in the room”—an expression that leads to all kinds of misunderstandings. This book would be an effective mentor text for older students for humorous, anecdotal, or autobiographical writing tasks. It may also serve as a model for teaching the concept of an idiom.
Author: Lane Smith
Discipline: English-Language Arts/General , English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Big Numbers: And Pictures that Show Just How Big They Are!
Annotation: This oversized, colorful book clearly illustrates big numbers in a comical cartoon style. It begins with one pea on a plate and goes on to show 10, 100, 1,000, 10,000, and beyond. Explanations of exponents, infinity, distance, and size are given using dialogue balloons and insets as well as text.
Author: Edward Packard
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Number Sense

Title: Big Plans
Annotation: An unrepentant little boy, sent to the corner for bad behavior, thinks about his big plans for the future. The story will amuse readers of all ages with its jocular treatment of the incorrigible lad who has grand plans to dominate the world. Useful as a mentor text (autobiography, humor, imagination) or as a model for teaching how to write dialogue. The book’s humor and its unique, quirky illustrations will appeal to reluctant readers.
Author: Bob Shea

Title: Big Rivers: The Missouri, the Mississippi, and the Ohio, The
Annotation: The great flood of 1993 along the Mississippi River is described in clear, simple text. The book begins and ends with a discussion of the water cycle and highlights flooding along the mighty Midwest rivers. The book is illustrated with full-color watercolor illustrations that are captioned to explain what is happening.
Author: Bruce Hiscock

Title: Big Rock, The
Annotation: This concept book tells how a large granite rock in the forest came to be and its changes over time. Geological terms are explained and can be enhanced with teacher support. Full-page, realistic illustrations help to clarify the story.
Author: Bruce Hiscock
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Big Storm, The
Annotation: In the spring of 1982, a devastating storm moved across the United States, causing heavy rain, avalanches, blizzards, and tornadoes. The stages of the storm are clearly explained, providing a wealth of information about basic weather phenomena. The illustrations depict the meteorologists, and children reacting to the weather in various ways. Can be read aloud to introduce changing weather patterns.
Author: Bruce Hiscock

Title: Big Wig: A Little History of Hair
Annotation: Brief and entertaining paragraphs accompanied by full-page illustrations chronicle the history of people’s relationship with hair, from prehistory to the present. The fashion and foolery of the various styles and hair customs is presented in an engaging and humorous way. Includes an author’s note with additional details.
Author: Kathleen Krull
Topic: American History, Diversity, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Bill Peet: An Autobiography
Annotation: The autobiography of one of America's most beloved picture book creators describes his process of becoming an illustrator as well as his experience as a Disney artist. This selection serves as an excellent resource for those interested in illustrators and Disney films.
Author: Bill Peet
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing
Award: Caldecott Honor, Golden Kite Author Honor, Golden Kite Illustration Honor

Title: Bink and Gollie
Annotation: Part picture book, part graphic novel, and part early reader, this collection of three short stories feature best friends Bink and Gollie. Physically, the two girls are very different: Bink is blond and short, and Gollie is tall and lanky. They agree about many things but also experience some friction and learn how to compromise. Illustrated with cartoon-style artwork that brings fresh humor to the stories.
Author: Alison McGhee, DiCamillo Kate

Title: Birchbark House, The
Annotation: This story is set on an island in Lake Superior in the year 1846. Omakayas, an eight-year-old Ojibwa Indian child, adores her baby brother, thinks her older brother is obnoxious, and is jealous of her beautiful older sister. When tragedy strikes, Omakayas pulls together all her inner resources to survive. The story is rich in the day-to-day details of life in another time, culture, and place.
Author: Louise Erdrich
Topic: American History, Diversity, Ethnic Studies, Women’s Studies

Title: Bird Alphabet Book, The
Annotation: This illustrated alphabet book gives content-rich details about the diversity of birds and how they interact with their habitats. This is one of the Alphabet Series of alphabet books by this author that focus on science.
Author: Jerry Pallotta

Title: Bird Boy
Annotation: Chang, a mute Chinese boy whose father uses cormorants to fish, begins to help his father fish. He is entrusted to raise the cormorant chicks, but is challenged by the continual harassing of neighboring bullies. Illustrations bring the Chinese fishing culture to life for the reader.
Author: Elizabeth Starr Hill

Title: Bird House, The
Annotation: A troubled girl discovers a country house, a haven for birds, is inhabited by an old woman. Through the actions of the birds she is brought to the old woman and discovers acceptance. Realistic watercolors enhance the mysterious tale. Many birds are named in the book and it includes information about what attracts the birds. Can be used as an introduction to primary science units on birds.
Author: Cynthia Rylant

Title: Bird Lake Moon
Annotation: Contemporary fiction set on a lake during summer vacation. Twelve-year-old Mitch and his mother take temporary refuge with her parents, who live on Bird Lake, after Mitch’s father leaves them for another woman. When a family moves in next door, Mitch becomes angry, as he imagined the empty house might belong to him and his mother someday. The boy in that house is ten and is also suffering; it is the first time he and his family have returned to the house since a tragedy occurred at the lake many years ago. Strong characters and true-to-life exploits make this an appealing title for readers in middle grades.
Author: Kevin Henkes

Title: Bird Watch: A Book of Poetry
Annotation: Fourteen species of birds, including the crow, finch, swan, and hummingbird, are presented in verse. The poems vary in length from a few lines to several stanzas, each capturing a unique quality or characteristic of a bird. The poems are supported by detailed watercolor paintings. The final page includes information on avian colorings, ranges, and habits.
Author: Jane  Yolen

Title: Birdbrain Amos
Annotation: When Amos the hippopotamus advertises for a bird to help him with his pesky bug problem, the tick bird who answers his ad creates new problems by building a nest on Amos's head. Droll illustrations in a cartoon style add humor to the story.
Author: Michael Clark Delaney

Title: Birds of a Feather
Annotation: Fourteen poems are paired with spectacular color photographs to provide an intimate observation of 14 bird species. Skillful poems of free verse, haiku, and rhyming couplets provide facts about the appearance and characteristics of each species. The book features short sidebars with factual information. The foreword was written by Donald Kroodsma, a well-known ornithologist.
Author: Jane Yolen

Title: Birds of Killingworth, The
Annotation: This fable is based on Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's poem of the same title. The setting is colonial America, and the people of Killingworth plan to eliminate the birds that eat their crops. Young Almira and the schoolmaster are publicly against the scheme, but the birds are killed anyway. Next, the village is wrought with an insect plague because their natural predators, the birds, have been killed. Schoolchildren come to the rescue with baby birds they had saved and had nurtured over the past months. California author.
Author: Robert D. San Souci

Title: Birds on a Wire: A Renga ’Round Town
Annotation: The text of this book is a renga, a poem in which one author writes one verse and another writes the next, linking the two. The poems describe the places and people one might see walking down the main street of a small American town. Illustrated with realistic watercolor artwork that connects one scene to another and provides visual clues as to what has come before and what will come next. Use as a model text for student writing.
Author: J. Patrick Lewis, Paul B. Janeczko

Title: Black and Blue Magic
Annotation: Harry Houdini Marco is not the deft person his name implies, but rather someone who is always falling over his own feet or failing to catch easy fly balls. The prospect of facing a long, dreary summer at his mother's boarding house is dramatically changed by a temporary boarder who provides Harry with a vial of magic potion, enabling him to sprout wings and fly over the city at night. California author and setting.
Author: Zilpha Keatley Snyder

Title: Black Cat
Annotation: Traveling along quiet city streets, over rooftops, and into the subway, a sleek black cat explores the city. The book's use of a simple rhyming refrain encourages children's participation. Paint is layered on photographs that form the backgrounds and cutouts of a cat are added.
Author: Christopher Myers

Title: Black Frontiers: A History of African American Heroes in the Old West
Annotation: Readers become acquainted with the African Americans who migrated westward after the Civil War as cowboys, homesteaders, miners, businessmen and businesswomen, frontier guides, and trappers. Archival photographs present a first-hand look at life for black pioneer families, and quotes from journals of the day lend authentic detail. One chapter on dime novels includes an excerpt using the language of the day.
Author: Lillian Schlissel

Title: Black Is Brown Is Tan
Annotation: These biracial poems are about a family with a white father and a black mother. The family members enjoy being with each other and doing family things.
Author: Arnold Adoff

Title: Black Pearl, The
Annotation: Sixteen-year-old Ramon joins his father to dive for pearls in Baja California. Rejecting the village legends about a monster fish called Manta Diablo, Ramon captures the great black pearl of his dreams. But when strange events afflict him, he realizes that there may be truth in the old tales.
Author: Scott O'Dell

Title: Black Stallion, The
Annotation: When the steamer "Drake" is shipwrecked off the Spanish coast, there are only two survivors: young Alec Ramsay and a beautiful spirited horse that Alec calls The Black. Following their rescue, their adventures continue together in America. This Golden Anniversary edition is illustrated with lovely pencil sketches and includes a foreword about the author and the writing of this classic story.
Author: Walter Farley

Title: Black Storm Comin'
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Colton, son of a black mother and a white father, takes a job with the Pony Express in 1860 after his father abandons the family. As a rider, Colton risks his life to deliver an important letter that may affect the growing conflict between the North and South. This fast-paced fictional story brings an early chapter of U.S. history to life. California author.
Author: Diane Lee Wilson

Title: Black-Eyed Susan
Annotation: This short novel is a poetically told tale about a pioneer family's adjustment to life on the prairie. Ten-year-old Susie senses her mother's increasing loneliness, despondency, and sense of isolation and gradually helps her to change her attitude about the Dakota territory.
Author: Jennifer Armstrong

Title: Blackberries in the Dark
Annotation: Austin visits his grandmother the summer after his grandfather died. All around him are memories of and things that belonged to his grandfather. Before the end of the visit, he and his grandmother create some new memories to share, and they remember grandfather together. The book is available in paperback only. California author.
Author: Mavis Jukes

Title: Blind Man and the Cripple, The; and Orchard Village
Annotation: This book contains two Vietnamese folktales. In the first tale a blind man and a disabled man cooperate to overcome danger. In the second tale no one claims the gold that has been found so the villagers agree to use it in a way that will benefit everyone.
Author: - Unknown

Title: Blizzard! The Storm that Changed America
Annotation: The Great Blizzard of 1888 in the northeast brought 72 hours of hurricane-force winds and unrelenting snow. The author creates vivid scenes featuring first-person accounts as individuals cope with the loss of food, heat, communications, and homes. Photographs, drawings, and maps illustrate the course of the storm. In the aftermath, legislation created the United States Weather Bureau. Bibliographic references and an index are included.
Author: Jim Murphy

Title: Blockhead: The Life of Fibonacci
Annotation: The boy who became the greatest mathematician of the Middle Ages was chastised by his teacher for daydreaming and was called “blockhead” by other students. An adviser to his father was the only one who recognized Fibonacci’s fascination with numbers. Told in a lighthearted first-person narrative, this introduction to Fibonacci’s ideas will entertain and inspire children who are interested in mathematics. Illustrated with watercolor and black-ink artwork. Useful for introducing Fibonacci’s concepts or just as an engaging read-aloud.
Author: Joseph D’Agnese

Title: Blood, Bones, and Body Bits
Annotation: Scientific information about the human body is offered in an engaging format for the middle school crowd in this title from a series. The science of things which some would consider gross, disgusting, or repulsive are explained to the reader. Cartoonlike drawings accompany the text. The book includes details about diseases, body odors, and body pain. This book should be reviewed by an adult to determine appropriateness for specific readers. Also available in the Horrible Science series is DISGUSTING DIGESTION and SUFFERING SCIENTISTS.
Author: Nick Arnold
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Blue So Blue, A
Annotation: A little boy who loves to paint and who is never without a paintbrush travels around the world in his dreams, searching for the perfect color blue. He starts at a museum, and the friendly guard sends him to the Big Blue Sea. After many adventures, the boy discovers that the blue he is looking for is in his mother’s eyes. Illustrated with striking artwork in many shades of blue.
Author: Jean-Francois Dumont
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3

Title: Bluebird Summer
Annotation: The farm isn't the same after Grandma's death. Her grandchildren work to restore the garden that Gramps had to let go. By placing a birdhouse in the garden, they bring bluebirds back to the garden. Includes brief information about bluebirds.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson

Title: Blues Journey
Annotation: Text and image are combined into a work of art as the story explains and defines the blues by taking fragments of blues songs and creating poetry with them. A call-and-response accompanies each painting. Beautiful poetry and collage artwork in blue ink and brown paper will entice. Includes a timeline and glossary of blues terms. Useful for units on music and poetry.
Author: Walter Dean Myers
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.4, VAPA M PreK-12.5

Title: Blues of Flats Brown, The
Annotation: To escape an abusive master, a junkyard dog named Flats runs away and makes a name for himself by playing the blues, from Mississippi to New York City. When his master catches up with him, the dog helps the man see he should be a different kind of person. Illustrated with pastel artwork that features variations of blue. Includes the lyrics and music for “The New York City Blues.”
Author: Walter Dean Myers
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3

Title: Bobby vs. Girls (Accidentally)
Annotation: Fourth-grader Bobby Chan has problems that seem to revolve around girls. His former best friend, Holly, is for some reason now his sister Jillian’s best friend; Jillian is obsessed with Bobby’s goldfish; and Holly has decided to run against Bobby for student council. Bobby and Holly get into a fight, and soon it is boys against girls in the fourth grade. Illustrated with drawings that add dimension to this humorous chapter book.
Author: Lisa Yee

Title: Bodies from the Ash: Life and Death in Ancient Pompeii
Annotation: This photo-essay provides an introduction to the city of Pompeii and the catastrophic eruption of Mount Vesuvius that immortalized its inhabitants by burying them under ash and pumice. Part history/archaeology, part science, the text is illustrated with many color and black-and-white photos, including those of the famous plaster casts made from the cavities left by the victims' bodies inside the volcanic material. Maps and other graphics, a bibliography of resources for adult readers, and an index are included.
Author: James M. Deem
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Bodies from the Ice: Melting Glaciers and the Recovery of the Past
Annotation: Investigates the science and secrets that glaciers reveal about people who lived long ago. Includes photographs, sidebars, an index, historical paintings, suggested books and Web sites, and a list of glaciers to visit. The authors feature sections on the discovery in 1991 of a mummified body in northern Italy, sacrificed children in the Andes Mountains, and the mystery of the disappearance of mountaineer George Mallory on Mount Everest. This is an interdisciplinary title with connections to science, history, archaeology, glaciology, and climatology. An ALA Notable Children’s Book for 2009.
Author: James M. Deem
Topic: Earth Science, Geography, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Bold and Bright: Black-and-White Animals
Annotation: Some of the world's most beloved animals - panda bears, penguins, and zebras - are black-and-white animals. This book explains the practical and beneficial functions of their markings. Bold, double-page spread illustrations place these creatures against their multi-colored environment.
Author: Dorothy Hinshaw Patent

Title: Bon Appetit! The Delicious Life of Julia Child
Annotation: Bright, cartoon-style panels with handwritten text tell the life story of Julia Child, the famous chef, author, and TV star. As a child growing up in Pasadena, California, Julia was a tomboy and was known for her pranks. This engaging story tells of her life, love, and ultimate success in writing the definitive book for Americans on French cooking. Filled with humorous moments and a few recipes, this is a story that will be appreciated by young “foodies.”
Author: Jessie Hartland
Topic: Lifestyles Around the World, Women’s Studies

Title: Bone Detectives: How Forensic Anthropologists Solve Crimes and Uncover Mysteries of the Dead, The
Annotation: A mapmaker on a routine survey discovers a human skull and thus begins the unraveling of a murder mystery where the chief sleuths are forensic anthropologists. Tracing the investigation and scientific analysis of physical evidence, the author introduces the history of forensics and demonstrates how scientists help criminologists solve tough mysteries. This book investigates cases and describes scientific techniques used for analysis.
Author: Donna M. Jackson
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Bone Man: A Native American Modoc Tale, The
Annotation: Nulwee, a young Modoc boy, must confront and destroy the enormous skeleton creature known as Bone Man to replenish the earth and repopulate his village. Two-page scratchboard illustrations are darkly dramatic and depict authentic Modoc clothing, artifacts, and shelters. Appended author and artist notes provide background information in support of this rite-of-passage tale. California setting.
Author: Laura Simms

Title: Bone: Out from Boneville
Annotation: The Bone cousins are run out of their hometown (Boneville) only to encounter a scorching desert, a forested valley filled with terrifying creatures, and characters that help them find their way home. Dark forces attempt to thwart their journey back, and just when it seems they are safe, their adventures continue. With colorful art, an exciting, funny, and sometimes scary storyline, and rich character development, this first book in a series of nine may appeal to reluctant readers and those who enjoy comic books.
Author: Jeff Smith
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General , Literacy/Motivation

Title: Bones Rock!: Everything You Need to Know to Be a Paleontologist
Annotation: This comprehensive guide to paleontology for young readers explains how to dig for fossils, clean them, keep records, and develop and test theories. Projects from the authors' experiences, are described, including the excavation of the Tyrannosaurus Rex known as Sue. This book is illustrated with high-quality color photographs, diagrams, and drawings.
Author: Kristin Donnan, Peter Larson

Title: Bones: Our Skeletal System
Annotation: Full-page illustrations including photographs, drawings, and X-rays complement basic information about the human skeleton. Explanations of each skeletal section emphasize the importance of bones in the healthy functioning of the human body. Each section includes suggested activities related to parts of the body.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Bones: Skeletons and How They Work
Annotation: Explores the details of human and animal bones, comparing the differences between the skeletal structures of various species. Several gatefolds display the skeletons of numerous creatures. Illustrated with Jenkins’s signature collage artwork, this is a visual book with short excerpts of text that will appeal to a variety of readers. Sidebars include quirky facts about bones.
Author: Steve Jenkins

Title: Book
Annotation: Celebrating the pleasures of reading, the author uses the quiet metaphors of a tree, a door, a farm, and other objects in poetic text to show the magic of a book. Softly blurred watercolors by Peter Catalanotto support and highlight the text. This selection is useful for English–language arts instruction in metaphors and figurative language.
Author: George Ella Lyon

Title: Book Itch, The: Freedom, Truth, and Harlem's Greatest Bookstore
Annotation: This book tells the story of the National Memorial African Bookstore, founded in Harlem by Lewis Michaux in 1939.
Author: Vaunda Micheaux Nelson

Title: Bookmarks Are People Too!
Annotation: Hank's class is putting on a play, and Hank wants the lead part, Aqua Fly, but he freezes in his audition and can only buzz like a fly, so his teacher creates a special part for Hank.
Author: Henry Winkler, Lin Oliver

Title: Bookspeak! Poems About Books
Annotation: Twenty book-themed poems cover various aspects of books, reading, and the literary experience. This is perfect material for performance, sharing in classrooms, and teaching young writers. Illustrated with a quirky mix of collage, drawings, and digital images.
Author: Laura Purdie Salas
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Lifestyles Around the World
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Winner

Title: Bookworm's Feast: A Potluck of Poems, The
Annotation: This delightful collection of poems on a variety of topics is organized according to the courses of a meal - appetizers, sherbets, entrees, sumptuous side dishes, and delectable desserts. The selections include wordplay, limericks, and valentinelike verse.
Author: J. Patrick Lewis

Title: Boom Town
Annotation: After her family arrives in California, where her father intends to search for gold, Amanda decides to start a pie-baking business. Her business is so successful that other business are established in the town. The story includes Amanda's gooseberry pie recipe. Other titles in the series include NINE FOR CALIFORNIA and TAKING CHARGE. California author and setting.
Author: Sonia Levitin

Title: Borreguita and the Coyote: A Tale from Ayutla, Mexico
Annotation: In this classic Native American trickster tale, a clever lamb uses her unique wiles to keep a dim-witted coyote from eating her. Vibrant-hued Southwestern-style illustrations accompany the text.
Author: Verna Aardema

Title: Borrowers, The
Annotation: This classic tale tells of the little folks, the Borrowers, living in the walls of a house belonging to a full-size human family. All of the Borrower resources and belongings are made from tidbits they have borrowed from the owners of the house. In reading this book, several math integrations are possible. These include scale, comparisons, ratio, and proportion. Other titles about these tiny people are THE BORROWERS AFIELD, THE BORROWERS AFLOAT, and THE BORROWERS AVENGED.
Author: Mary Norton

Title: Boss of the Plains: The Hat That Won the West
Annotation: This story presents John Stetson's journey west to Colorado to pan for gold and his subsequent inspiration instead to design a hat to protect those on the frontier from sun, rain, wind, and snow. Paper, pencil, and paint collages add authenticity.
Author: Laurie M. Carlson

Title: Boston Tea Party, The
Annotation: Describes the events before, during, and after the Boston Tea Party that helped precipitate the Revolutionary War. The decisions of the British Parliament, the reactions of the American colonists, and events in Boston are included. Illustrated with detailed impressionistic paintings that complement the text. Use with students to further their understanding of the politics of the times. An afterword and timeline are included.
Author: Steven Kroll

Title: Bottle Houses: The Creative World of Grandma Prisbrey
Annotation: When Grandma Prisbrey decided to settle down on her land in California, she didn't have the money to build a house. A visit to the dump leads to the construction of several buildings from found material, especially bottles. The gouache illustrations portray the beauty of the buildings. Includes an author note and photographs of the Bottle House. California setting.
Author: Melissa Eskridge Slaymaker
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Bound for Oregon
Annotation: A fictional tale of nine-year-old Mary Ellen Todd’s journey from Arkansas to Oregon with her family in a covered wagon in 1852. This pioneer family demonstrates determination and courage as they travel 2,000 miles along the Oregon Trail to fulfill their dream of finding a better life. The story is based on the true account of Mary Ellen Todd’s journey to Oregon.
Author: Jean Van Leeuwen

Title: Boundless Grace
Annotation: Amazing Grace is an avid fairy-tale purist who continues her passionate celebration of life and her endless quest to know exactly where she belongs in the world. Grace travels to Gambia, Africa, to visit her long-absent father. She encounters a new stepmother and two tiny siblings, making real-life connections to the fairy tales she adores. The strong message is that fathers can love their children equally, even from a distance. The book is a sequel to AMAZING GRACE (1991).
Author: Mary Hoffman
Topic: Diversity, Geography, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, Personal and Community Health, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Box Turtle at Long Pond
Annotation: The day in the life of a male box turtle is illustrated through engaging text and full-color, realistic paintings. The story is told from the turtle's perspective. This is a fine introduction to carefully documented and detailed information on pond ecology. Can be paired with BOX TURTLE AT SILVER POND LANE by Susan Korman to compare the female and male box turtle as well as writing and illustration styles.
Author: William T. George

Title: Box Turtle at Silver Pond Lane
Annotation: A day in the life of a female box turtle is told as she feeds, sleeps in a hollow log, builds her nest, and lays four eggs. The oil paintings of the pond environment are enriched by detail and complement the text. Can be paired with BOX TURTLE AT LONG POND by William T. George to compare the male and female box turtle as well as writing and illustration style.
Author: Susan Korman

Title: Boxes for Katje
Annotation: In post-war Holland Katje receives a care package from Janie in Mayfield, Indiana. The care packages progressively become larger and larger as the whole community of Mayfield contributes to the effort. To repay the kindness, Katje's village sends a box of tulip bulbs to their American friends. Based on a true story.
Author: Candace Fleming

Title: Boy and a Jaguar, A
Annotation: A renowned cat conservationist reflects on his early childhood struggles with a speech disorder, describing how he only spoke smoothly when he was talking with animals. From these experiences he decided to become a supporter of animal rights.
Author: Alan Rabinowitz
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Mental, Emotional, and Social Health

Title: Boy Called Dickens, A
Annotation: A cold and bleak winter scene in London opens this fictional account of the early life of Charles Dickens. Twelve-year-old Charles is on his way to a factory job he took after his family was sent to debtors’ prison. To pass the long hours in the boot-blacking factory, Charles turns the events he witnesses into stories that entertain his companions. Eventually his family is released from prison, and he is allowed to attend school. Illustrated with mixed-media artwork. Concludes with an author’s note.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson

Title: Boy Called Slow: The True Story of Sitting Bull, A
Annotation: This selection tells of the boyhood of a real Lakota Sioux named Slow growing up in the 1830s. Longing for his permanent, adult name, Slow focuses on becoming a warrior, proves his courage, and earns his new name - Sitting Bull.
Author: Joseph Bruchac

Title: Boy in the Garden, The
Annotation: Jiro’s mother reads an ancient Japanese tale about a magical crane that was also a woman, wife, and weaver until a promise was broken. A second story tells of Jiro encountering a crane in the garden just as he remembered, and the story comes alive in his dreams. The double-page spread features text on a white background faced by brilliant watercolor illustrations. A tale that highlights the power of imagination.
Author: Allen Say

Title: Boy Named Beckoning: The True Story of Dr. Carlos Montezuma, Native American Hero, A
Annotation: An illustrated biography of the life of Carlos Montezuma, a Yavapai Indian who grew up to be a Native American hero. Chronicles his childhood, in which he was kidnapped in 1866, sold into slavery, and adopted by an Italian photographer who raised him like a son. Discusses what he learned when he set out to uncover his family’s past and highlights his work as a doctor. Illustrated with photographs and watercolor paintings.
Author: Gina Capaldi
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: Boy Named Chong, A
Annotation: A young immigrant from Laos struggles in his adjustment to life in America and finally finds success, thanks to the encouragement of his American teacher. Black-and-white illustrations highlight the text. Regional dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text. Available in paperback.
Author: Heather Marchant

Title: Boy of the Three-Year Nap
Annotation: Taro, the laziest person in the village, is so lazy that he would nap for three years if no one were to awaken him! Taro's lazy ways are challenged when he falls in love with a rich merchant's daughter and concocts a scheme to marry into wealth. The illustrations feature three-quarter and full-page color artwork detailing Japanese landscapes, architecture, and lifestyle. California illustrator.
Author: Dianne Snyder

Title: Boy on Fairfield Street: How Ted Geisel Grew Up to Become Dr. Seuss
Annotation: This picture book biography focuses on Ted Seuss Geisel's first 22 years of life in Springfield, Massachusetts. It lays the background knowledge for Dr. Seuss fans to understand how he came to be a writer and illustrator. Includes bibliography, illustrations index. California author.
Author: Kathleen Krull

Title: Boy Who Could Fly Without a Motor, The
Annotation: It is 1935, Franklin Roosevelt is President, and Jon Jeffers is nine years old. He is also stuck on a small, rocky island off the coast of San Francisco with his mother and his lighthouse-keeper father. Jon's desire for friendship and interest in ghosts and magic lead him into adventure, disaster, and more when an ancient magician arrives on the beach and offers Jon the secret of human flight. California author. See other award-winning titles by this author.
Author: Theodore Taylor

Title: Boy Who Drew Birds: A Story of John James Audubon, The
Annotation: Living in Pennsylvania, far from his native home in France, young John James Audubon comes up with the idea of banding the legs of his pewee flycatcher bird friends to see if they will return in the spring to the nests they abandoned the previous fall. This blending of fiction and fact is handsomely illustrated with artwork that combines colored pencil and watercolor with photographs of nests, feathers, and fossils.
Author: Jacqueline Davies
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, Science

Title: Boy Who Harnessed the Wind, The
Annotation: Born in Malawi, where terrible drought and famine forced him to quit school and almost claimed his life, William dreamed of building a windmill that would bring electricity to his farm and community. Although his community thought he was crazy, William persevered. Using parts he scavenged from the local dump and an outdated book stolen from his school library, William made his dream a reality.
Author: Bryan Mealer, William Kamkwamba
Topic: Ethnic Studies, Global Social Issues, Lifestyles Around the World, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Mathematical Analysis, Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)

Title: Boy Who Invented TV: The Story of Philo Farnsworth, The
Annotation: This book begins by asking the reader to imagine what it was like growing up on a farm in the American West in 1906, without a TV. What follows is a biography of a little-known man whose invention was one of the most influential in history. At age fourteen, while plowing a field, Philo Farnsworth thought of a way to create television. Other inventions are also mentioned. Illustrations in acrylic wash with colored pencils complement the engaging text.
Author: Kathleen Krull
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: Boy Who Loved Math, The: The Improbable Life of Paul Erdos
Annotation: Most people think of mathematicians as solitary, working away in isolation. And, it's true, many of them do. But Paul Erdos never followed that path. At the age of four, he could ask you when you were born and then calculate the number of seconds you had been alive in his head. But he didn't learn to butter his own bread until he turned twenty. Instead, he traveled around the world, from one mathematician to the next, working on a number of publications.
Author: Deborah Heiligman

Title: Boy Who Loved to Draw: Benjamin West, The
Annotation: This is an illustrated account of the life of the painter Benjamin West, known on both sides of the Atlantic for his artwork. The three easy-to-read chapters relate events of his childhood and his overwhelming interest in drawing.
Author: Barbara Brenner
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: HSS K.3, HSS K.6, HSS 1.4, HSS 1.5, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.5, HSS 5.4, HSS 5.6, HSS 5.8, HSS 8.8

Title: Boy, Were We Wrong About Dinosaurs!
Annotation: The author describes how theories about dinosaurs change constantly as new discoveries are made. She provides information about such topics as scales and feathers, colorization, and infant care. She also explains that many books on library shelves or even those available in book stores may be presenting theories that are no longer considered valid. Bright artwork illustrates the changing ideas.
Author: Kathleen V. Kudinski

Title: Boys of Steel: The Creators of Superman
Annotation: Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster, growing up in Cleveland during the Great Depression, created Superman. Designed to look like a 1930s comic book, this picture book tells how Siegel and Shuster came up with the idea and the look of Superman and discusses their struggles to sell their story to a publisher. An afterword details their lifelong financial struggles and legal battles with DC Comics over the rights to the Superman character.
Author: Marc Tyler Nobleman
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Bracelet
Annotation: Emi, a Japanese American girl, receives a friendship bracelet from her Caucasian friend as Emi, her mother, and her older sister are relocated to an internment camp, where they live in a horse stable during World War II. Watercolor illustrations provide historical detail and poignancy as Emi loses the bracelet and copes with new and frightening surroundings. California author and setting.
Author: Yoshiko Uchida

Title: Brain: Our Nervous System, The
Annotation: This book describes the anatomy of the brain and the nervous system. It explains how together they function to enable us to think, feel, move, and remember. The vivid photographs add to the usefulness of the work in supporting the narrative text. This is one of a series of science books by this author.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: BrainJuice: Science, Fresh Squeezed!
Annotation: This small volume of 41 poems illustrates principals of earth science, life science, and physical science. Each poem is presented with humor and interesting facets about the targeted science. The illustrations are droll drawings that add humor to each poem. Memory joggers are presented that will help students remember important scientific information. This book offers a good integration of science and poetry. It can be used to introduce science units or for students to enjoy as literature.
Author: Carol Diggory Shields
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Brave as a Mountain Lion
Annotation: Spider, a young Shoshone Indian boy, dreads participating in his all-school spelling bee, to which the entire community has been invited. When his father, grandmother, and brother discover that he is afraid to be up on stage, they all give him advice. But it is in his namesake that Spider discovers his own courage. Watercolor-and-pastel illustrations vividly evoke contemporary reservation life and portray a positive family role model. California author.
Author: Ann Herbert Scott

Title: Brave Girl: Clara and the Shirtwaist Makers’ Strike of 1909
Annotation:
