This is the true story of Clara Lemlich, a young Ukrainian immigrant who led the largest strike of women workers in the history of the United States. 

When Clara arrived in America, she couldn't speak English. She didn't know that young women had to go to work, that they traded an education for long hours of labor, that she was expected to grow up fast.

But that didn't stop Clara. She went to night school, spent hours studying English, and helped support her family by sewing in a shirtwaist factory.

Clara never quit, and she never accepted that girls should be treated poorly and paid little. Fed up with the mistreatment, Clara led the largest walkout of women workers the country had seen.
Author: Michelle Markel

Title: Brave Harriet: The First Woman to Fly the English Channel
Annotation: Harriet Quimby, an American woman, was the first female to receive a pilot's license and the first to make a solo flight across the English Channel. Told in first-person narrative, this illustrated story briefly recounts her flight from England in 1912. She is depicted as a courageous, goal-oriented woman whose accomplishment was eclipsed by the sinking of the Titanic on the day she safely landed in France. California author.
Author: Marissa Moss

Title: Brave Jing Wei Bird, A
Annotation: This illustrated book retelling a famous, classical Chinese myth is written in traditional Chinese.
Author: Hui Fen Pan, Xiu Ling Zhan

Title: Brendan Buckley’s Universe and Everything in It
Annotation: Brendan is a biracial kid with a passion for rocks and minerals. While on summer vacation, he meets an older gentleman at a rock and mineral show who turns out to be the white maternal grandfather he has never known. Brendan’s mother is estranged from this grandfather because she is married to Brendan’s African American father. Knowing that his mother becomes furious whenever her father’s name is mentioned, Brendan decides to get to know his grandfather in secret. A worthwhile book that can be used to introduce discussions about race and prejudice.
Author: Sundee T. Frazier

Title: Brianna, Jamaica, and the Dance of Spring
Annotation: When her sister Nikki gets sick, Brianna hopes to play her part as the butterfly queen in the Dance of Spring, but then another disaster strikes. Children will relate to the sibling rivalry and dreams of stardom. The watercolor-and-pastel illustrations capture the excitement of the dance class, offering images of group action and individual children.
Author: Juanita Havill

Title: Bridge to Terabithia
Annotation: Jess and Leslie become special friends as they create a magical secret world that they call Terabithia. But when a tragic accident causes Leslie's death, Jess is forced to face life alone. This junior novel confronts many of the issues teens face and is great for literature circles. This selection depicts emotional intensity.
Author: Katherine Paterson

Title: Bring on the Beat
Annotation: Illustrations and rhyming text evoke the rhythms of jazz music. Set in Harlem in the 1930s, the story centers on a jazz trio that plays on a street corner. From doorways and stoops, people of all ages come to listen. The book is a tribute to Duke Ellington, “with a nod toward Klee and Kandinsky.” Illustrated with black-and-white art and occasional splashes of neon color.
Author: Rachel Isadora
Grade Level Span: Preschool/Pre thru K, K thru 2, 3 thru 5

Title: Bringing the Rain to Kapiti Plain: A Nandi Tale
Annotation: This African tale is told in cumulative rhyme and introduces the animals of the Kapiti Plain. In the telling the problems created by the lack of rain are revealed. Full-color, double-page illustrations show the changing environment and how it is transformed into a lush, livable habitat when the rain returns.
Author: Verna Aardema

Title: Bronzeville Boys and Girls
Annotation: This collection of 34 illustrated poems by Pulitzer Prize winner Gwendolyn Brooks reflects the experiences and feelings of African American children who live in big cities. The title is derived from a historically black neighborhood in Chicago. First published in 1956, this edition features bright new artwork by Faith Ringgold.
Author: Gwendolyn Brooks

Title: Brooklyn Bridge
Annotation: The planning, engineering facts and history of the Brooklyn Bridge are revealed in this book. The book describes this first large-scale use of steel in this 16-year project. The book is illustrated with acrylic paintings that are reproductions of photographs and includes labeled diagrams, cross sections, and a list of the bridge's specifications.
Author: Lynn Curlee
Topic: Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Mathematical Reasoning

Title: Brother Cat and Brother Rat; and The Rooster's Antlers
Annotation: This collection contains two stories that incorporate elements of the 12 zodiac signs of the lunar year. Both tales involve the antics of tricksters.
Author: - Unknown

Title: Brother for Celia, A
Annotation: Everyone is fussing over her new baby brother, and Celia feels neglected and upset.
Author: Maria Martinez

Title: Brothers
Annotation: Having arrived in San Francisco from China to work in his brother’s store, Ming is lonely until an Irish boy befriends him. As a result of their friendship, Ming learns some English, which enables him to promote his brother’s store to customers outside of Chinatown, improving the family business. The photo-realistic paintings reveal details about life in San Francisco’s Chinatown in the 1880s. Useful for making connections to units on California history, immigration, and multicultural friendship.
Author: Yin

Title: Brothers at Bat: The True Story of an Amazing All-Brother Baseball Team
Annotation: From the 1860s to the 1940s, there were at least 29 baseball teams made up of brothers playing every position. The Acerra family, with 12 boys and an age range of 20 years, was one of those teams. They played baseball together for longer than any other all-brothers team and were honored by the Baseball Hall of Fame. Illustrated with mixed-media artwork and traced and shaded in black crayon. Includes notes from the author and the illustrator.
Author: Audrey Vernick

Title: Brothers in Hope: The Story of the Lost Boys of Sudan
Annotation: Based on actual events, this book offers a fictionalized first-person account of the experiences of a band of young Sudanese boys who walk nearly 1,000 miles in search of refuge after their villages are destroyed by civil war. Traveling by night and hiding from soldiers and animals, they eventually make it to Ethiopia, but civil war once again causes them to flee to Kenya. Some are able to make it to America. An afterword describes what happened when those 3,800 boys resettled in the United States.
Author: Mary Williams

Title: Brothers of the Knight
Annotation: In this contemporary retelling of the fairy tale TWELVE DANCING PRINCESSES, an African American minister in Harlem endeavors to discover why the shoes of his 12 sons are worn to pieces every morning. The snappy text and high-energy pictures put a fun twist on a classic fairy tale.
Author: Debbie Allen

Title: Bud, Not Buddy
Annotation: Ten-year-old Bud - "not Buddy" - Caldwell is an orphan on the run during the Great Depression. He escapes from an abusive foster home to find the man he believes to be his father. One dilemma after another uncovers a tough character who perseveres and triumphs in his quest. See also THE WATSON'S GO TO BIRMINGHAM-1963.
Author: Christopher Paul Curtis
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.4, VAPA M PreK-12.5
Award: Coretta Scott King Author Winner, Golden Kite Author Honor, Newbery Winner

Title: Buddha’s Diamonds, The
Annotation: Set in postwar Vietnam, this story comes from co-author Thay Phap Niem’s childhood. Tinh is ten years old and learns from his father about how to support the family using a fishing boat. When a storm comes, Tinh’s courage is tested. Cultural and Buddhist references are woven into this coming-of-age story. A glossary and author’s notes provide background information. This is a good choice for classroom discussions about responsibility, honesty, and faith. California author.
Author: Carolyn Marsden, Thay Phap Niem
Topic: Diversity, Lifestyles Around the World, Religion/Spirituality

Title: Buddy: The Story of Buddy Holly
Annotation: A picture-book biography of the rock-and-roll musician who pioneered a new kind of music. Told in a folksy Texas twang, it describes Buddy Holly’s childhood, his family’s involvement with music, and how he became a recording star. The story is enhanced with handsome, realistic pictures of kids dancing or Buddy playing rock and roll. Be sure to add some recordings of rock and roll when sharing this title.
Author: Anne Bustard

Title: Buffalo and the Indians: A Shared Destiny, The
Annotation: The long-lasting relationship between the buffalo and the Plains Indians is traced from prehistoric times to the present. Large, full-color photos and reproductions of artwork from famous painters accompany this compelling narrative.
Author: Dorothy Hinshaw Patent

Title: Buffalo Are Back, The
Annotation: Describes the centuries when Native Americans used the buffalo for food, shelter, and clothing and tells how the buffalo made a comeback in the American Midwest. The author follows the policies that brought about the destruction of the native grasslands and mass shootings of buffalo. She continues through the 1930s, when the grasslands were replanted with native grasses, allowing the return of many buffalo to prairie preserves. Illustrated with landscape paintings. Offers sources to visit in person or online.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: Buffalo Music
Annotation: Based on the life of Mary Ann Goodnight, this delightful fictional account of her fight to save buffalo herds from extinction in the 1800s is rich with regional language and is an excellent choice as a read-aloud. Fearful that buffalo would be gone “like the dew before the sun,” Goodnight helped to breed and form the herds that still roam Yellowstone National Park. The illustrations enhance this well-told story of one woman’s notion to hear “buffalo music” again in her lifetime.
Author: Tracey E. Fern

Title: Buffalo Soldier, The
Annotation: Realizing that his future lies in owning land, not just in being free, a young man raised as a slave becomes a buffalo soldier—a member of an all-black cavalry regiment formed to protect white settlers from Indians, bandits, and outlaws. The story is told in the first person, beginning in the man’s youth (when slaves were finally emancipated), and pictures him at the end of his life as an old man, proud of his grandson who is serving in World War II. Illustrated with watercolor paintings. Includes an author’s note and bibliography.
Author: Sherry Garland

Title: Buffalo Storm, The
Annotation: Hallie and her parents join a wagon train to Oregon, leaving her beloved grandmother behind. Hallie learns to face frightening storms, as well as other new fears, by wrapping herself in her grandmother’s quilt and remembering the comforting words her grandmother said to her. The story is illustrated with textured pastel and watercolor artwork. A good read-aloud choice for the study of the Westward Movement.
Author: Katherine Applegate

Title: Bug Boy
Annotation: A third-grade boy with a passion for insects receives a mysterious Bug-a-View magnifier that changes him into any insect he places in the viewer. Life suddenly becomes much more interesting. Facts about insects are integrated into this humorous tale and the lively text is illustrated with black-ink sketches. The sequel is BUG GIRL.
Author: Carol Sonenklar

Title: Bug Faces
Annotation: The full-page photographs in this book introduce the physical structures that are unique to certain bugs. Photographs of thousands of tiny eyes show how the deer fly has the appearance of having two big green and red eyes. The author includes fascinating information about many other insects and spiders. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Darlyne A. Murawski

Title: Bug Girl
Annotation: In this sequel to BUG BOY, third-grade Charlie, a bug enthusiast, changes into a beetle and is caught by another student. He is rescued from being pinned to a board by his friend, Suzanne, who changes herself into an ant using his Bug-a-View device. Fast-paced action is highlighted by humorous black-ink sketches.
Author: Carol Sonenklar

Title: Bug Off! A Swarm of Insect Words
Annotation: This is a clever word book featuring vocabulary words relating to insects including bees, moths, and ants. The artwork features the insects as they dramatically act out the meaning of each word. The artwork also brings meaning to the figurative language while the humorous insect images encourage wordplay.
Author: Catherine Hepworth

Title: Bug Scientists, The
Annotation: This book presents profiles of entomologists, each representing a unique job. Included are a professor who engages students in cockroach races and another who uses bugs to assist police in solving crimes. The text is engaging and supported by full-color photographs that bring the jobs and information about insects alive. Also introduced are the Monarch Watch program and the students who participate in it. This book is a part of the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Donna M. Jackson

Title: Bug Watching with Charles Henry Turner
Annotation: This biography about Charles Henry Turner, a Black African American scientist living in the late 1800s and early 1900s. He studied the connections between insects and their adaptations to their environments. He was also known for his research on ant behavior. Charts, mazes, and diagrams are included in this excellent biography. See other books in the Naturalist's Apprentice series.
Author: Michael Elsohn Ross

Title: Bugs Before Time: Prehistoric Insects and Their Relatives
Annotation: Fascinating facts and appealingly realistic watercolors on every page provide an interesting introduction to prehistoric insects. The physical characteristics, habits, and natural environment of a number of prehistoric insects are described. Some of these prehistoric insects, including ants, spiders, cockroaches, centipedes, and dragonflies, still exist today. Concluding pages provide a geologic timeline that shows when insects evolved, an extensive reading list that includes magazine articles and Web sites, and a glossary.
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
Author: Cathy Camper

Title: Building on Nature: The Life of Antoni Gaudí
Annotation: Gaudí, born in 1852 in Catalonia, was an innovative architect who changed the world of architecture with his unique style. His love of the natural world was a continuing influence in his work, and he incorporated nature in all his creations. Using short sentences that are poetic at times, along with gouache illustrations done in earth tones, this author–illustrator team pays homage to a man whose work has been an inspiration to many.
Author: Rachel Rodríguez

Title: Bunnicula
Annotation: When a little rabbit called Bunnicula enters the Monroe household, vegetables begin turning white, and Chester the cat is convinced that Bunnicula is a vampire rabbit who sucks the juices out of vegetables. This is the first in a series of rollicking stories about Harold, Chester, and Bunnicula. Other titles by this author include HOWLIDAY INN (1982), CELERY STALKS AT MIDNIGHT (1983), and RETURN TO HOWLIDAY INN (1992). The books are also available on audiocassettes.
Author: Deborah Howe, James Howe

Title: Bunyans
Annotation: Tall-tale hero Paul Bunyan is portrayed as a family man who carves out famous natural monuments across America. Exuberant paintings extend the text's humor and hyperbole as such places as Old Faithful, Niagara Falls, and the Rocky Mountains are "created" to cope with Bunyan family problems, including dirty dishes, bears, and wandering children. California author/illustrator.
Author: Audrey Wood

Title: Buried Treasure: Roots and Tubers
Annotation: The origin, history, use, and production of some common roots and tubers is presented in a well-researched presentation. General plant information introduces chapters on potatoes, sweet potatoes, carrots, turnips, and others. Watercolor and ink diagrams are combined with full-color photographs and historical reproductions to enhance awareness of how these plants are viewed in other countries. Recipes are included. See other books in the Plants We Eat series such as COOL AS A CUCUMBER, HOT AS A PEPPER: FRUIT VEGETABLES and other books by the same authors.
Author: Meredith Sayles Hughes, Tom Hughes

Title: Burp! The Most Interesting Book You'll Ever Read About Eating
Annotation: This bright, fact-filled book describes the digestive process, what food is made of, and how the body breaks it down. It also has biographical information about scientists who have contributed to our understanding of food and the digestive process, and presents simple experiments that illustrate some of the truths about food. See other books in the Mysterious You series.
Author: Diane Swanson

Title: Busing Brewster
Annotation: In 1974, two young African American brothers are bused to school in Boston, and they are nervous about attending a white school for the first time. Their bus is met by angry white parents. After a scuffle, the boys are sent to the school library, where the school librarian provides encouragement. Stylized mixed-media collages composed of shapes and patterned fabrics depict the time period. An author’s historical note provides background on public-school integration.
Author: Richard Michelson

Title: Butterfly Count
Annotation: Amy and her mother look for a special butterfly while attending a July 4th Butterfly Count at a prairie restoration site. This title includes information about butterflies and details on how to take part in the North American Butterfly Count. Full-color artwork shows the flora and fauna of the plains, with exceptional detail paid to the wildflowers and butterflies. An illustrated glossary is included.
Author: Sneed B. Collard, III

Title: Butterfly Eyes and Other Secrets of the Meadow
Annotation: Poetry riddles ask questions that are followed by narrative text that explains the creature or aspect of nature questioned in the poems. The book captures a day in a meadow, from sunrise to twilight, and introduces a wide variety of things seen in a meadow habitat. The scratchboard illustrations are bold and filled with many details that will fascinate the reader. This book is a wonderful integration of science, poetry, art, and information literacy.
Author: Joyce Sidman

Title: Butterfly Is Patient, A
Annotation: Lyrical text and detailed watercolor illustrations introduce young readers to the life cycle, characteristics, and behavior of butterflies. The book discusses metamorphosis, pollination, camouflage, migration, individual features and functions, and the differences between butterflies and moths. The endpapers feature 32 caterpillars in the front and 34 butterflies in the back.
Author: Dianna Hutts Ashton

Title: Butternut Hollow Pond
Annotation: The cycle of life from dawn to midnight around a North American pond is presented through watercolor landscapes. The detailed illustrations include animals and are accompanied by a text rich in sensory language. Five vignettes present the complex cycle of predator and prey as well as the interdependence of this habitat.
Author: Brian J. Heinz

Title: By the Great Horn Spoon!
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Jack Flagg and his butler hide in potato barrels on a ship bound for the California gold fields. The former impeccable butler proves that he is indispensable to the Captain when he captures a thief and saves the ship's cargo—and all before reaching California. The adventures, filled with humor and ingenuity continue after they reach their destination. California author and setting.
Author: Sid Fleischman
Topic: American History, Economics, English-Language Arts/General, Geography, Immigration/Migration

Title: Cabin on Trouble Creek
Annotation: The year is 1803, and twelve-year-old Daniel, ten-year-old Will, and Pa have arrived in the wilderness of Ohio to build a farm in the forest. Pa leaves the boys to fetch the rest of the family from their former home and tells the boys he will return in five weeks—but it ends up taking 10 months for the family to arrive, and the boys must survive entirely on their own in a harsh environment. Based on an actual incident. Good read-aloud.
Author: Jean Van Leeuwen

Title: Cache of Jewels and Other Collective Nouns, A
Annotation: Ruth Heller provides an engaging lesson on collective nouns. Vivid double-page illustrations accompany rhyming text that addresses a variety of collective nouns. The book provides an effective review of collective nouns for older students and may be used to introduce collective nouns in the lower grades and to English learners. Look for other titles in the “World of Language” series.
Author: Ruth Heller
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Cactos (Cactus)
Annotation: Color photographs and simple passages introduce readers to cacti with basic information, their characteristics, and their distribution. Other titles in the Los Jardines de la Tierra (The Earth's Garden) series include ARBOLES (TREES), FLORES (FLOWERS), PLANTAS INECTIVORAS (INSECT-EATING PLANTS), PLANTAS SINGULARES (STRANGE PLANTS), and SETAS Y HONGOS (MUSHROOMS).
Author: Jason Cooper

Title: Caddie Woodlawn
Annotation: Portrays the lively adventures of Caddie Woodlawn, an eleven-year-old tomboy who lives on the Wisconsin frontier in 1864 with her pioneer family. This classic Newbery Medal winner is based on the life and memories of the author’s grandmother. A terrific read-aloud. Vocabulary reflects the language of the time.
Author: Carol Ryrie Brink

Title: Calder Game, The
Annotation: When seventh-grader Calder Pillay disappears from a remote English village, along with an Alexander Calder sculpture to which he has felt strangely drawn, his friends Petra and Tommy fly from Chicago to help his father find him. This mystery is filled with information about Calder’s mobiles and sculptures as well as information on how to make mobiles. Also by the same author: CHASING VERMEER and THE WRIGHT 3.
Author: Blue Balliett

Title: California Gold Rush: An Interactive History Adventure, The
Annotation: Describes the events of the California Gold Rush, revealing historical details of how miners traveled, how they looked for gold, and their impact on California’s history. An engaging format for readers, as they are asked to select what happens next, with all choices and consequences based on historical fact. Illustrated with primary-source pictures.
Author: Elizabeth Raum

Title: Calvin Coconut: Trouble Magnet
Annotation: In this series opener about Calvin Coconut, a boisterous nine-year-old boy who lives in Hawaii, Calvin just can’t seem to stay out of trouble at home or at school. He is forgetful, avoids responsibility, and often becomes excitable. Calvin’s adventures are enhanced by lighthearted illustrations throughout. A good choice for new chapter-book readers.
Author: Graham Salisbury

Title: Cam Jansen and the Ghostly Mystery
Annotation: Cam witnesses a robbery and uses her intellect and photographic memory to identify the disguised thief and solve the case. This book is part of a good mystery series for beginning readers. Additional titles include CAM JANSEN AND THE MYSTERY OF THE DINOSAUR BONES (1981) and ONION SUNDAES (1994).
Author: David A. Adler

Title: Camping Trip That Changed America, The: Theodore Roosevelt, John Muir, and Our National Parks
Annotation: Naturalist John Muir wrote a book about the vanishing wild forest, which President Theodore Roosevelt read. In 1903, the two set out on a camping trip where they roughed it in the outdoors. They shared the need to preserve the beauty of the area in what was to become Yosemite National Park. Illustrated with watercolor paintings and pen drawings. Useful for encouraging further research.
Author: Barb Rosenstock
Standard: HSS K.2, HSS K.6, HSS 1.4, HSS 1.5, ES 2.3, HSS 2.1, HSS 2.5, ES 4.4, ES 4.5, HSS 4.1, HSS 4.4

Title: Camping with the President
Annotation: In 1903 President Theodore Roosevelt visited wilderness areas of the country and asked to visit with naturalist John Muir in Yosemite. They camped together for four days, riding on horseback through the sequoia forests and living in tents at the foot of Bridalveil Fall. Includes detailed watercolor illustrations, bibliographical references, and short biographies of President Roosevelt and John Muir. California author.
Author: Ginger Wadsworth
Topic: American History, Geography, Life Science (Biology), Physical Fitness
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: Can We Save the Tiger?
Annotation: Using the experiences of a few endangered species as examples, Martin Jenkins highlights the ways in which human behavior can either threaten or conserve the animals that live on Earth. The journal-style format of this large, lengthy picture book is complemented by detailed pencil sketches and full-color, photo-realistic artwork. The book issues a quiet challenge to readers and serves as an introduction to a unit on endangered species.
Author: Martin Jenkins

Title: Can You Count to a Googol?
Annotation: Clever illustrations carry the concept of powers of ten through increasingly larger and larger numbers; millions, billions, trillions, and on through the googol and beyond. Wells gives uses for very large numbers such as calculating the number of atoms in the universe, the distance in miles from our sun to Proxima Centauri, and dating things such dinosaurs and stars. The final page tells how the googol got its name.
Author: Robert E. Wells

Title: Can You Guess My Name?: Traditional Tales Around the World
Annotation: A collection of 15 folktales from all over the world, including stories that resemble "The Three Pigs" and "The Bremen Town Musicians." Good to use in comparing different versions of the same story. California author.
Author: Judy Sierra (selector)

Title: Can You Hear It?
Annotation: Reproductions of art masterpieces are paired with selections of classical music that are included on an accompanying CD. In each pairing, the author provides suggestions of what children might find in the art as they listen to the music. Also includes information about musical instruments, artists, and the composers featured in the book and on the CD.
Author: William Lach
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.4, VAPA M PreK-12.5, VAPA T PreK-12.1, VAPA T PreK-12.3, VAPA T PreK-12.4, VAPA T PreK-12.5

Title: Can't You Sleep Little Bear?
Annotation: Big Bear tries to dispel Little Bear's fear of the dark by lighting larger and larger lanterns. Nothing works until Big Bear takes Little Bear outside and shows him that the light of the moon is everywhere.
Author: Martin Waddell

Title: Canada Geese Quilt
Annotation: In Vermont in the 1940s, ten-year-old Ariel has feelings of displacement because of a new baby coming. Her grandmother encourages Ariel to help her make a quilt for the baby, but after starting the quilt Grandma suffers a stroke, and it is up to Ariel to finish the quilt and help her grandmother work toward recovery.
Author: Natalie Kinsey-Warnock

Title: Candy Corn
Annotation: This poetry collection features 24 imaginative poems about such diverse topics as auto-parts stores, rotten pumpkins, school buses, and candy corn! Each piece of word play is allotted two pages and is accompanied by the author's tinted ink sketches and watercolors.
Author: James Stevenson

Title: Canopy Crossing: A Story of an Atlantic Rainforest
Annotation: A male black-faced lion tamarin journeys across the canopy of the Brazilian rain forest in search of a mate. In the process the reader learns about the habits of tamarins as well as the life cycle of the rain forest. The full-color illustrations are rich in detail. The book concludes with a factual endnote giving a brief history of the Atlantic rain forest including environmental threats and the endangered status of tamarins. An audiotape is included.
Author: Ann Whitehead Nagda

Title: Caperucita roja y los 40 ladrones (Red Riding Hood and the Forty Thieves)
Annotation: Using popular fairy tale figures as main characters, this collection of poems breathes new life into favorite stories such as Cinderella, Sleeping Beauty, and Pinocchio. Black-and-white drawings illustrate the new adventures of these classic characters.
Author: Ma Carmen Diez Navarro

Title: Capoeira
Annotation: Capoeira is a game, dance, and martial art. This photo essay describes how capoeira is played today in the United States and Brazil, introducing its history and origins in the African slave culture of seventeenth-century Brazil. The children at the Mandinga Academy in Oakland, California, are featured throughout the book. Includes a glossary of Portuguese words and Web sources. Color photos enhance the text.
Author: George Ancona
Topic: Dance, Diversity, Motor Skills/Movement Patterns, Music, Physical Fitness, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Captivating, Creative, Unusual History of Comic Books, The
Annotation: Written in the format of a comic book, this title provides an overview of the history of comic books. Readers are introduced to various forms of comics, such as manga and graphic novels; learn of the creation and evolution of popular comic heroes and villains; and explore major trends in the world of comics. Includes bibliographical references, an annotated time line, and an index.
Author: Jennifer M. Besel
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, Literacy/Motivation
Standard: VAPA T PreK-12.3, VAPA T PreK-12.4, VAPA T PreK-12.5

Title: Carmine's Story: A Book About a Boy Living with AIDS
Annotation: A young AIDS patient describes the disease, how he got it, and how it affects his daily life in this sensitive first-person narrative. The book is illustrated with striking black-and-white photographs that bring reality to this young boy's short life.
Author: Arlene Schulman

Title: Carnation, Lily, Lily, Rose: The Story of a Painting
Annotation: A collection of more than 35 paintings and drawings by John Singer Sargent, along with the true account of Kate Millet, who as a child had been one of Sargent’s models. The book relies on actual letters and remembrances and is illustrated with excellent reproductions of Sargent’s paintings, photos, and sketches.
Author: Hugh Brewster

Title: Carnival of the Animals
Annotation: Inspired by Camille Saint-Saëns’ music, this story is about a tricky young boy who slips away from his teacher during a field trip to a natural history museum. After the museum closes, the boy sees all of the people he knows transformed into animals. The book is illustrated with playful watercolor images. It includes a CD with Saint-Saëns’ musical piece and actor John Lithgow’s dramatic recitation of the text.
Author: John Lithgow

Title: Carnival of the Animals: Poems Inspired by Saint-Saëns’ Music
Annotation: A collection of 14 poems inspired by Camille Saint-Saëns’ “Zoological Fantasy,” this book is accompanied by a 55-minute CD featuring a reading of the poems and music performed by the Apollo Chamber Players. Illustrated with watercolor artwork that brings the poems to life.
Author: Judith Chernaik

Title: Case of the Lost Boy, The
Annotation: King, a golden retriever, narrates the story of how he was abandoned by his family, ended up in the pound, and then was adopted by a young boy named Conner and renamed Buddy. While Buddy is trying to find out what happened to his family, Conner disappears. Buddy tries to find him and is assisted by a cat who can read. Humor, a variety twists and turns, and a lovable dog make this a fine beginning chapter book. Illustrated with occasional black-line drawings, the book is the first installment of “The Buddy Files” series.
Author: Dori Hillestad Butler

Title: Case of the Mummified Pigs and Other Mysteries in Nature, The
Annotation: This book provides descriptions of the scientific research into 14 mysterious occurrences in nature. Insight into the experimental methods, processes, and networking scientists used to unravel each mystery are highlighted. Food chains, food webs, symbiosis, the purpose of decomposers, and the exchange of energy and nutrients among organisms and with the environment are included. Provided are examples of how scientists form hypotheses, use clues and evidence, conduct experiments, and network with each other.
Author: Susan E. Quinlan

Title: Case of the Vanishing Golden Frogs: A Scientific Mystery, The
Annotation: The golden frog started to vanish in the late 1990s, prompting a scientific investigation to determine what was causing the species to die. Scientists from around the world worked together to determine that a fungus is responsible for the deaths of many of these frogs. Steps are being taken to preserve the remaining population. Illustrated with colorful photographs, microscopic views, and maps. A fine example of the scientific method in action. Includes bibliographical references, a glossary, and an index.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: Caseta magica, La (The Phantom Tollbooth)
Annotation: Milo enters a world full of imaginary creatures when he drives his toy car through a toy tollbooth. Milo meets "1/2 a boy" who represents .58 since he is the member of the average family that has 2.58 kids. A journey through a land where Milo learns the importance of words and numbers provides a cure for his boredom. Through wordplay and humor the reader is introduced to examples of decimals, fractions and other mathematical ideas. It is also available in a English edition.
Author: Norton Juster
Standard: Math 3.NF.1-3, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.NF.1-7, Math 5.MD.1-5, Math 5.MP.1-8, Math 6.NS.1-8, Math 6.EE.1-9, Math 6.MP.1-8

Title: Casey at the Bat: A Ballad of the Republic Sung in the Year 1888
Annotation: Thayer's timeless ballad of the nineteenth-century baseball star is illustrated to look like a newly discovered, 100-year-old scrapbook. The illustrator uses sepia tones to weave real and photographically realistic reproductions of artifacts - such as period baseball cards, tickets, advertisements, and other memorabilia - into the narrative to present a portrait of a bygone era.
Author: Ernest L. Thayer

Title: Cat and Rat: The Legend of the Chinese Zodiac
Annotation: Introduces the Chinese zodiac and relates how each of the 12 signs was named for an animal selected by the Jade Emperor. Includes a table showing the signs for the years 1900 through 2007 and the character traits of each sign. The book has a striking design and is illustrated with charcoal and pastel art.
Author: Ed Young
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, International Studies/World History, Lifestyles Around the World, Mathematics, Religion/Spirituality, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Cat Running
Annotation: Rural life in 1930s California is introduced through the eyes of Cat Kinsey, the fastest sixth-grade runner at Brownwood School. Cat's title is jeopardized when her father won't allow her to wear pants for the race and a newly arrived, barefooted, displaced Dust Bowl Oklahoman becomes a rival. A dramatic race to outdistance death, however, helps Cat resolve issues of poverty, prejudice, and the desire to help those in need. California author and setting.
Author: Zilpha Keatley Snyder

Title: Cat with the Yellow Star: Coming of Age in Terezin, The
Annotation: Holocaust survivor Ela Weissberger describes her childhood experience of being imprisoned with her family at Terezin, a Nazi concentration camp. She tells of her participation, along with other children, in a performance of the opera “Brundibar,” in which she played a cat. Illustrated with sepia-tone family photographs and full-color children’s artwork throughout.
Author: Ela Weissberger, Susan Goldman Rubin
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Music, War
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Cats in Krasinski Square
Annotation: A young girl and her older sister have escaped from Warsaw’s ghetto and work to get food to their family and friends still behind the ghetto walls. The youngest sister, who is the narrator of the story, has befriended dozens of displaced and stray cats in Krasinski Square. The cats become the means for bypassing the Gestapo so food can be sneaked into the ghetto. Based on an actual World War II incident.
Author: Karen Hesse

Title: Catwings
Annotation: Roger, Thelma, James, and Harriet are four city kittens who are born with wings. Their loving mother, concerned for their safety in the urban environment, urges them to move to the country. This is the tale of their many adventures with winged and other creatures in the countryside. Sequels include CATWINGS RETURN and WONDERFUL ALEXANDER AND THE CATWINGS. Children will enjoy the small size of this book and the charming illustrations. California author.
Author: Ursula K. Le Guin

Title: Cave Paintings to Picasso: The Inside Scoop on 50 Art Masterpieces
Annotation: Introduces 50 celebrated works of art, including King Tut’s sarcophagus and Andy Warhol’s paintings of Campbell’s soup cans. Each spread features a reproduced image of a selected piece of artwork, a timeline indicating where the artist and the work fall in history, a short narrative about the artist, and how the work was produced (or in the case of an artifact, the origins of the piece).
Author: Henry Sayre

Title: Cay, The
Annotation: In 1942 an elderly black man and a young white boy are victims of a shipwreck and are stranded on a Caribbean island. In the day-to-day struggle to survive, the differences between age and youth, black and white, and innocence and experience become secondary to the characters' need to understand each other and transcend their differences. This story uses the dialectic language of the setting and of the day. California author.
Author: Theodore Taylor

Title: Celebrate Cinco de Mayo with the Mexican Hat Dance
Annotation: This is an English translation of the book CELEBRA EL CINCO DE MAYO CON UN JARABE TAPATIO. A teacher introduces her students to the Mexican hat dance in celebration of Cinco de Mayo. Includes details on the holiday’s history and traditions. The rhyming story is illustrated with bright artwork.
Author: Alma Flor Ada, F. Isabel Campoy

Title: Celebrate! Stories of the Jewish Holidays
Annotation: Introduces the eight key holidays of the Jewish year, including the seven major annual holidays and the weekly holiday of the Sabbath, exploring the background, meaning, and celebration of each. Illustrated with dramatic paintings. Useful in the study of the ancient Hebrews. Includes craft ideas and recipes.
Author: Gilda Berger
Topic: International Studies/World History, Lifestyles Around the World, Religion/Spirituality, Visual Arts, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Celebrating a Quinceanera: A Latina's 15th Birthday Celebration
Annotation: This easy-to-read text describes ten-year-old Ariana helping cousin Cynthia prepare for her upcoming quinceanera. Includes index, glossary, some terminology in Spanish, and information about Our Lady of Guadalupe. Useful for units on religious celebrations, family and community life, traditions, and diversity. California author.
Author: Diane Hoyt-Goldsmith
Classification: Easy Reader, Photo Essay, Struggling Reader

Title: Celebrating America: A Collection of Poems and Images of the American Spirit
Annotation: The blend of artistry in both print and visual media highlight this anthology. More than 60 poems celebrate the land, the people, and the spirit of America.
Author: Laura Whipple (compiler)

Title: Celebrating Chinese New Year
Annotation: This photo-essay is set in San Francisco and follows Ryan Leong and his family as they prepare to celebrate the Chinese New Year. California author, setting, and photographer.
Author: Diane Hoyt-Goldsmith

Title: Celebrating New Year and Miss Yuan Shiau
Annotation: This book contains two Vietnamese folktales that explain the traditions of the lunar new year and Yuan Shiau Day (Lantern Festival Day). It is a good resource for understanding cultural festivals.
Author: - Unknown

Title: Celebrating Ramadan
Annotation: This book provides a thorough but brief introduction to Islam and the holy month of Ramadan. American fourth grader Ibraheem and his family live in New Jersey and follow the teachings of the Koran. Color photographs and inserts illustrate the customs. Useful for learning about religions, Islam, Muslims, Ramadan, and respecting differences. California author.
Author: Diane Hoyt-Goldsmith

Title: Celebritrees: Historic and Famous Trees of the World
Annotation: A look at 14 famous trees from around the world. Some are famous for their physical characteristics; others are famous for their spiritual significance. Each tree has a double-page spread that includes an introduction to the tree, the reason for the tree’s inclusion in the book, and artwork done with acrylic ink, colored pencil, and watercolor.
Author: Margi Preus

Title: Celia Cruz, Queen of Salsa
Annotation: When Celia Cruz was a child in Cuba, everyone said she sang like a bird. Although her father wanted Celia to become a teacher, her teacher advised her to take a chance on a musical career. After studying at Cuba’s National Music Conservatory, she was hired as lead singer by the most popular band in Cuba. In 1960 Celia left Cuba for the United States, where she enjoyed added success. The bold, bright illustrations in this book evoke both salsa music and the Cuban culture. Includes an author’s note, glossary, and selected discography. California author.
Author: Veronica Chambers

Title: Cello of Mr. O, The
Annotation: Told through the voice of a young girl, this story of a war-ravaged city describes the horrors of the war, bombings, shortages of food, and uncertainty. Mr. O takes his cello to the town square to perform Bach as if he were on a concert stage. When his priceless cello is destroyed by a mortar shell, he finds the courage to return the next day with a harmonica and continues to play the works of Bach. Watercolor illustrations and vivid images depict a city and civilians under siege.
Author: Jane Cutler
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.4

Title: Central Heating: Poems About Fire and Warmth
Annotation: This collection of 19 poems explores a multiplicity of images related to the power of fire and heat, including literal, figurative, useful, and destructive themes. Hot topics, supported through creative vocabulary, fill the pages. A fiery red text is combined with linocuts and wash illustrations.
Author: Marilyn Singer
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, Science

Title: César: Sí, Se Puede! Yes, We Can!
Annotation: This collection of poems about California labor activist César Chavez describes his life and philosophical beliefs and includes quotations. David Diaz’s illustrations are computer-generated soft pastels and rendered in a folk-art style. Good read-aloud with many Spanish words and phrases. Includes notes, a chronology, a list of sources, a prose narrative, a selection of quotations by Chavez, and a glossary.
Author: Carmen T. Bernier-Grand

Title: Chameleons on Location
Annotation: Illustrated with more than 25 color photographs, the text focuses on three chameleon species found in the rain forests of Madagascar. This book is part of the On Location series.
Author: Kathy Darling

Title: Chang's Paper Pony
Annotation: During the California Gold Rush, Chang wanted a pony, but couldn't afford one until a friend found a solution. An author's note is appended, detailing historical background. The story has a connection to fourth-grade history/social science.
Author: Eleanor B. Coerr
Standard: HSS K.1, HSS K.6, HSS 1.4, HSS 1.5, HSS 1.6

Title: Charca, La (Pond Life)
Annotation: Text, pictures, photographs, diagrams, and charts help provide clarification about plant and animal life in ponds. Other books in the Descubre y Experimenta: Ciencia Divertida (Fun with Simple Science) series includes LUZ Y COLOR (LIGHT AND COLOR), CULTIVO DE PLANTAS (CULTIVATING PLANTS), SONIDA Y MUSICA (SOUND AND MUSIC), and SOMBRAS Y REFLEJOS (SHADOWS AND REFLECTIONS). Each book covers separate science concepts and ideas. Activities and easy-to-follow directions help support science concepts.
Author: Barbara Taylor

Title: Charles Darwin y la evolucion (Charles Darwin and Evolution)
Annotation: This title focuses on Charles Darwin, providing information about his early life and education, the time in which he lived, his scientific travels, and the resulting observations that led to the development of his theory of evolution. Clear writing is enhanced by illustrations, photographs, and a timeline. Other titles in the Pioneros de la Ciencia (Pioneers of Science) series that have been translated into Spanish include LOUIS PASTEUR Y LOS GERMENES (LOUIS PASTEUR AND GERMS), MARIE CURIE Y EL RADIO (MARIE CURIE AND RADIUM), GUGLIELMO MARCONI Y LA RADIO (GUGLIELMO MARCONI AND THE RADIO), GALILEO Y EL UNIVERSO (GALILEO AND THE UNIVERSE), and ISAAC NEWTON Y LA GRAVEDAD (ISAAC NEWTON AND GRAVITY).
Author: Steve Parker

Title: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
Annotation: Charlie Bucket, so poor that he can only afford one candy bar a year, wins candy for life and a tour of Willie Wonka's top-secret chocolate factory. There are four other prizewinners, each a selfish child with a nasty personality. The story is filled with excitement, fantasy, humor, and moral lessons. This selection is the first of a series about Charlie Bucket.
Author: Roald Dahl

Title: Charlie Parker Played Be Bop
Annotation: Introduces the musical style of jazz known as “be bop” as played by legendary African American saxophonist Charlie Parker. The recording of "be bop" inspired the author to create this book, so the rhythm of the text matches the rhythms of the song. Illustrated with bright artwork in Raschka’s signature style.
Author: Chris Raschka

Title: Charlotte's Web
Annotation: A bashful and naive young pig named Wilbur becomes friends with a spider named Charlotte, who saves Wilbur's life by convincing the farmer and community members that he is no ordinary porker. This much-loved story is also available on audiocassette.
Author: E. B. White

Title: Chasing Vermeer
Annotation: When seemingly unrelated and strange events start to happen and a precious Vermeer painting disappears, eleven-year-olds Petra and Calder combine their talents to solve an international art scandal. Set in Chicago’s Hyde Park neighborhood at the University of Chicago’s Lab, this debut novel is a true art mystery that mixes mystery, puzzles, possibilities, and art.
Author: Blue Balliett
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4

Title: Chato and the Party Animals
Annotation: When Chato the Cat discovers that his best friend, Novio Boy has never had a birthday party, he plans a surprise party. Everything is set except that Chato forgets to invite the guest of honor. The mural-like acrylic-on-scratchboard artwork extends the story with vitality and color. Humor and Latino symbolism are embedded in the illustrations. California author, illustrator, and setting.
Author: Gary Soto

Title: Chato's Kitchen (Chato y su cena)
Annotation: Chato, a low-riding gato (cat), and his pal Novio Boy plan a dinner for the new mouse neighbors, intending to dine on them for the main course. Their plan is foiled, however, by the quick-thinking mice. Awarded the Pura Belpre award, the scratchboard illustrations are controversial because one of the cats is wearing a red bandanna. California author. Translated by Alma Flor Ada and F. Isabel Campoy.
Author: Gary Soto
Award: California Young Reader Medal, Pura Belpre Illustration Winner

Title: Cheetah
Annotation: Set on the backdrop of the Serengeti Plain, the daily life of a female cheetah is presented as she stalks, hunts, and provides for her two cubs. Naturalistic acrylic paintings highlight the action and panoramic views of the African plains. An afterword provides information on the status of this endangered species as well as on conservation efforts.
Author: Taylor Morrison

Title: Cherry Tree, The
Annotation: Set in the foothills of the Himalayas, this is a story from India. Six-year-old Rakhi eats cherries on her way home from the bazaar. When her cherries are gone, her grandfather suggests that she plant one of the cherry seeds. She does, and over the years she cares for it. On her tenth birthday, the first pink blooms appear. Illustrated with soft watercolor and collage artwork.
Author: Ruskin Bond
Topic: Lifestyles Around the World, Religion/Spirituality, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Cheyenne Again
Annotation: In the late 1880s, a Cheyenne boy named Young Bull is forced to leave the reservation and attend school to learn the white man’s ways. He is housed in barracks, taught by Indians who have adopted the white man’s ways, and told that Indian ways are not good. The boy’s point of view is portrayed. Vivid artwork captures the deep emotions depicted throughout this story. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: Chicken Feathers
Annotation: Relates the story of the summer when Josh, who lives on a chicken farm, waits for the birth of his sister while his mother is in labor in the hospital. His pet chicken Semolina talks, but only to him. Semolina discovers a plan by the red fox to extort eggs from the chickens. Because Semolina has developed a taste for Grandma’s brew, she demands “brown water” as payment for her information. Illustrated with a few pencil drawings.
Author: Joy Cowley

Title: Chico Mendes: Defender of the Rain Forest
Annotation: This is a biography about Chico Mendes and his efforts to save the environment of the tropical forests in Brazil by supporting sustainable uses of the plants in the forest. Black-and-white and color photographs accompany the text. See other books in the Gateway Green Biography series. California author.
Author: Joann J. Burch

Title: Child of the Owl
Annotation: The story is set in 1960 in San Francisco's Chinatown. Casey, a Chinese American teen, slowly discovers the value of her Chinese heritage while living with her grandmother. The story examines the effects of Casey's father's gambling addiction on the lives of the other family members. California author and setting.
Author: Laurence Yep

Title: Child's Calendar, A
Annotation: A year in New England is viewed month by month and season by season in poems told through the voice of child. Lush paintings highlight a multiracial, all-ages cast as they participate in seasonal activities and celebrations.
Author: John Updike
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, Science

Title: Child's Garden of Verses, A
Annotation: Stevenson's poems in this collection reflect the fantasy of childhood dreams and perceptions. More than 70 full-color and black-and-white illustrations enhance the text. These poems are especially suited for memorization by students.
Author: Robert Louis Stevenson

Title: Child's Introduction to Ballet: The Stories, Music, and Magic of Classical Dance, A
Annotation: Presents the stories, music, and magic of classical dance. Features a collection of 19 stories and an audio CD that introduces children to the world of classical ballet. The book provides information on some of the world’s greatest ballets, dancers, choreographers, and composers.
Author: Laura Lee
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA D PreK-12.3

Title: Children Just Like Me
Annotation: Children from over 30 countries tell about their families, customs, schools, hobbies, cities, and villages. The format is that of a visual encyclopedia filled with color photographs and large pictures of each of the children. This selection includes an index.
Author: Anabel Kindersley, Barnabas Kindersley

Title: Children of Alcatraz: Growing Up on the Rock
Annotation: Brief, engaging text, accompanied by period photographs, profile several generations of children who grew up on Alcatraz Island. Beginning with the use of the island by Native Americans, the book presents periods when “The Rock” was used as a lighthouse, a military installation, and a prison and continues through the Native American occupation of the island that occurred between 1969 and 1971. It also covers the island’s present-day status as a national park. Includes personal stories and interviews with surviving Alcatraz children. Useful for units on California history.
Author: Claire Rudolf Murphy

Title: Children of Summer: Henri Fabre's Insects
Annotation: Ten-year-old Paul describes the work of his father, nineteenth-century entomologist Jean-Henri Fabre. This selection is an appealing book for the student who enjoys scientific pursuits and the study of insects.
Author: Margaret J. Anderson

Title: Children of the Dust Bowl: The True Story of the School at Weedpatch Camp
Annotation: The plight of Depression Era migrant workers who escaped from Dust Bowl Oklahoma and relocated in California's San Joaquin Valley is portrayed in this account. The author explores the prejudice against these newcomers, their forced existence in the federal labor camp at Arvin, California, and the remarkable school superintendent who provided opportunities for the children and changed their lives. Primary source photographs document this uplifting story of an otherwise bleak chapter in California's history. California author and setting.
Author: Jerry Stanley
Award: John and Patricia Beatty Award, Orbis Pictus Award

Title: Children of the Earth...Remember
Annotation: This book illustrates the interrelationships of animals and people in protecting the natural world. Dramatic, original paintings convey the author's love of the environment. This book could be used to introduce a unit on environmental studies.
Author: Schim Schimmel

Title: Children of the Gold Rush
Annotation: The adventures and hardships that children experienced during the Gold Rush are chronicled in journals and diaries. Their daily lives and hopes are recorded almost as if they found comfort in writing, leaving behind a record of what living during those harsh times was like.
Author: Claire Rudolf Murphy

Title: Children of the Wild West
Annotation: This photo-essay provides aspects of how pioneer and Indian children lived in the old West from 1840 to the early 1900s. Archival photographs help show that children are children no matter when they lived or their ethnicity.
Author: Russell Freedman

Title: Children Read Tang Poetry
Annotation: This four-volume selection of Tang dynasty poems is well-illustrated and appeals to young readers.
Author: - Unknown

Title: Chimpanzees I Love: Saving Their World and Ours, The
Annotation: This is an engaging account by world-renowned scientist Jane Goodall of her life studying chimpanzees in Tanzania, Africa. She shares what she has learned in her long involvement with these primates. The book includes color photographs showing the chimps in the wild, in zoos, and in labs.
Author: Jane Goodall

Title: Chinese History
Annotation: This six-volume set of Chinese history is divided by dynasties: Volume 1: Ch'in and Han; Volume 2: Three Kingdoms; Volume 3: Tang; Volume 4: Sung and Chin; Volume 5: Yuan and Ming; Volume 6: Ch'ing. The volumes are clearly written and contain useful historical background knowledge in an accessible format.
Author: - Unknown

Title: Chinese Mythology Collection
Annotation: Ten well-known classical Chinese myths are retold in this collection. One myth is "Kua Fu Races with the Sun," in which a strong man races the Sun to bring light to his people. Other popular myths include "Nyu Wa Mended the Sky," "Foolish Old Man Moves a Mountain," and "A Brave Jing Wei Bird." The book is written in simplified Chinese.
Author: Xue Mei Li

Title: Chitty Chitty Bang Bang Flies Again
Annotation: The Tooting family finds an old engine that they install in a camper, unaware that it is the original engine of a magical car. The family is launched on a grand adventure to recover all the parts of Chitty Chitty Bang Bang. This sequel to Ian Fleming’s original stands on its own and is accompanied by humorous black-and-white drawings that depict this interracial family’s adventures.
Author: Frank Cottrell Boyce

Title: Chomp! A Book About Sharks
Annotation: This book provides a simple explanation of what sharks look like, how they hunt, what they eat, and how they are born. Unfamiliar terms are explained and the book includes a pronunciation guide. Detailed color photographs and an easy-to-read text will support reluctant readers. See other books in the Hello Reader! series.
Author: Melvin Berger

Title: Christmas in the Big House, Christmas in the Quarters
Annotation: The sights and sounds of the last Christmas celebration on a Virginia plantation before the Civil War are remembered by the slave owners in the big house and the slaves in the quarters. This selection includes full-color illustrations, riddles, rhymes, recipes, notes, and a bibliography.
Author: Patricia C. McKissack

Title: Christmas Sonata
Annotation: A young boy and his mother spend Christmas with his dying cousin in Minnesota in 1943. The two cousins discover that Santa really does exist.
Author: Gary Paulsen

Title: Christo and Jeanne-Claude: Through the Gates and Beyond
Annotation: A lively introduction to the lives and work of Christo and Jeanne-Claude, the artistic duo known for creating public art. Many projects are discussed, including two in California: The Running Fence and The Umbrellas. A detailed section focuses on The Gates art project in New York’s Central Park. Illustrated with photographs of the artists and their work in various stages. The book provides explanations as to the nature of art and why an artist would invest in transient art.
Author: Jan Greenberg, Sandra Jordan

Title: Christopher Mouse: The Tale of a Small Traveler
Annotation: A small white mouse is sold to a pet store and then from one home to another. His adventures are documented in a first-person narrative with poetry sprinkled along the way. Illustrated with occasional pen-and-ink drawings that add detail to the story. A good read-aloud choice.
Author: William Wise

Title: Cim Xeeb Haav Txiv Daw (Recognition of Deur Valley)
Annotation: The songs, chants, and poems in this collection are often recited at various Hmong ceremonies. It is written in Green Hmong.
Author: Yves Bertrais (editor)

Title: Cinco de Mayo: Celebrating the Traditions of Mexico
Annotation: Rosie, a young Mexican American girl from California learns about the history of Cinco de Mayo and her culture’s traditions for celebrating. Engaging text and color photographs give readers information as well as a glance of what life is like in Rosie’s community. Small, cut-paper silhouettes in bright colors add a festive look to the book.
Author: Diane Hoyt-Goldsmith

Title: Cinderella or the Little Glass Slipper
Annotation: The classic tale of Cinderella is retold as she leaves behind a glass slipper in her haste to flee the palace before her fairy godmother's magic loses effect. Illustrator Marcia Brown chose to set her version of Cinderella in the eighteenth-century French court and her illustrations reflect the refinement of the period as well as the author's interest in ballet.
Author: Charles Perrault

Title: Cinderella Skeleton
Annotation: This unique and humorous version of Cinderella is told in rhyming verse. Cinderella is a skeleton living in a graveyard with her stepmother. The illustrations conjure up the worst in each person, making the entire book spooky, gruesome, and very funny. California author.
Author: Robert D. San Souci

Title: Circle Unbroken: The Story of a Basket and Its People
Annotation: Hoping to keep the history of her people and their African heritage alive, a grandmother tells the tale of the Gullah baskets to her granddaughter. The beautiful sweetgrass baskets were brought from West Africa to South Carolina and Georgia by the family’s ancestors. The poetic text is illustrated with exquisite watercolor paintings. This excellent read-aloud for middle- and upper-grades students introduces a little-known part of American history and its connection to family heritage.
Author: Margot Theis Raven
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Citizen Scientists: Be a Part of Scientific Discovery from Your Own Backyard
Annotation: Presents chapters on monarch butterflies, birds, frogs, and butterflies. Encourages readers to participate in hands-on activities to understand creatures that children might well find intriguing in their own backyard. Illustrated with full-color photographs.
Author: Loree Griffin Burns

Title: City by the Bay: A Magical Journey Around San Francisco, The
Annotation: A bright and lively presentation of the sights and sounds in and around San Francisco, including the Golden Gate Bridge, cable cars, Union Square, Chinatown, and much more. Each famous landmark comes to life with detailed collage artwork. The book includes a Fun Facts section and Explorer Guide. California author and illustrator.
Author: Tricia Brown

Title: City of Angels: In and Around Los Angeles
Annotation: Presents a variety of communities in the sprawling city of Los Angeles—from Chinatown to Beverly Hills, and from Olvera Street to Hollywood. Twenty of these unique neighborhoods are highlighted with a short history and colorful events that show the past and present. Illustrated with bright, detailed collage paintings that have angels hidden in each painting. Includes a map and timeline of the city's history. California illustrator.
Author: Brian Lewis, Julie Jaskol

Title: City of Gold and Lead
Annotation: Will, Beanpole, and Henry manage to escape the invasion of the Tripods and then set out on a secret mission to penetrate the City of the Tripods to learn more about the strange beings that rule the earth. This book is available in paperback only and is part of a series.
Author: John Christopher

Title: Clara and the Bookwagon
Annotation: Clara, a young farm girl, borrows her first library book from a traveling book wagon. Her world is transformed as she explores the limitless possibilities of reading. Her dream of learning about life beyond her rural 1905 Maryland home is fulfilled. California author.
Author: Nancy Smiler Levinson

Title: Clara Lee and the Apple Pie Dream
Annotation: This beginning chapter book is told from a first-person perspective. Third-grader Clara Lee, a Korean American, dreams of being chosen Little Miss Apple Pie for her town’s apple festival. Her biggest challenge is to overcome her fear of public speaking. She dreams that her grandfather has died. When she is told that it is a sign of good luck, things begin to turn around for her. A warm and engaging story with occasional drawings that enhance the narrative.
Author: Jenny Han

Title: Clara Rounds Cape Horn
Annotation: Not all nineteenth-century travelers to California came by wagon train. In this book, nine-year-old Clara Frances Allen sets off for California aboard a sailing ship in 1845. Told through Clara’s diary, this fictional account of the long journey describes small adventures and interesting sights and holds a wealth of information about sailing around Cape Horn in the mid-nineteenth century. Includes a glossary, maps, and bibliography.
Author: Gail Langer Faber, Michele Lasagna

Title: Class Clown
Annotation: At first, Lucus Cott enjoys his reputation of being the third-grade class clown. His pranks are usually "good intentions gone wrong," and he vows that he will become a perfect student. However, it is with some difficulty that he learns there is a right and wrong way to use his humor. TEACHER'S PET and CLASS PRESIDENT are from the same series.
Author: Johanna Hurwitz

Title: Clatter Bash! A Day of the Dead Celebration
Annotation: As family members bring offerings to the cemetery at sunset for the Mexican celebration of the Day of the Dead, the skeletons begin lifting lids off the coffins, leaving their graves so they can party. The spare text includes rhyming words that echo the Spanish/English onomatopoeic sounds. The illustrations are cut-paper collages, accented with brilliant paint and designs. An afterword explains the holiday and its customs.
Author: Richard Keep
Topic: Diversity, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Clementine's Letter
Annotation: After learning that her favorite teacher will be leaving for a trip to Egypt and will be absent for the remainder of the year, Clementine devises a plan to get rid of the substitute and get Mr. D'Matz to stay.
Author: Sara Pennypacker
Award: California Young Reader Medal, Christopher Award

Title: Cloak for the Dreamer, A
Annotation: A tailor asks his three sons to make colorful cloaks from small pieces of cloth sewn together. The older sons use square and triangular pieces and make fine cloaks. But the youngest son chooses circles and his cloak will not keep out the wind. The father uses geometry to solve the problem cleverly. This story fits with a unit on tessellations or a unit on shapes within shapes.
Author: Aileen Friedman
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)

Title: Close Encounters: Exploring the Universe with the Hubble Space Telescope
Annotation: This science concept book describes what scientists have been able to deduce about the nature of our solar system and the universe, based on data collected by the Hubble telescope.
Author: Elaine Scott

Title: Close to the Wind: The Beaufort Scale
Annotation: Presents fictional journal entries by a young midshipman in the late 1800s and describes the weather conditions on the Beaufort Scale, which is used to measure the force of winds at sea. Much history and information are incorporated in both the text and the handsome and detailed watercolor-and-gouache paintings of ships at sea. Use when discussing the sea voyages to California during the Gold Rush.
Author: Peter Malone
Topic: American History, Global Historical Events and Figures

Title: Cloud Spinner, The
Annotation: A young boy has the amazing gift of being able to weave beautiful cloth out of clouds, in gold, white, and crimson. He spins just enough thread for two scarves because his mother has taught him that “enough is enough.” When the King sees the beautiful scarves, he demands that the boy weave one for him, but one is not enough. When all the clouds have been woven into cloth for the King, there is no more rain and the land suffers. When the boy is given back his scarves, he releases them into clouds, and the land is healed. Illustrated with artwork that has hidden pictures and objects for readers to find.
Author: Michael Catchpool

Title: Co Tich Nhi Dong (Legend Stories Book for Children)
Annotation: This book contains six traditional folktales that teach a variety of lessons, such as the meaning of friendship; the importance of education; and the value of hard work, family love, and contentment.
Author: Tran Van Dien (editor)

Title: Coast Mappers, The
Annotation: The California Gold Rush intensified the need for reliable maps of the Pacific Coast. In 1850 three scientists were sent by the U.S. Coast Survey to chart the coast. The scientists faced years of adventure and difficulties. The illustrations show the beauty of the country and the methods and tools used to create the maps.
Author: Taylor Morrison

Title: Cockroach Cooties
Annotation: Two contemporary Chinese brothers living in the Chinatown section of San Francisco discover that the key to dealing with the school bully, "Arnie-zilla," is to frighten him with Hercules, the pet cockroach. In the end, ground-up crickets in chocolate chip cookies and empathy for Arnie's difficult home situation bring about friendship for the three characters. California author and setting.
Author: Laurence Yep

Title: Cod's Tale, The
Annotation: This lively story relates the history and threatened extinction of the cod fish, a fish so common it was taken for granted and ultimately threatened. Lavishly illustrated with detailed and humorous watercolor paintings, it includes a timeline and a bibliography for further reading.
Author: Mark Kurlansky

Title: Cold Feet
Annotation: This tale is a retelling of an old Scottish legend. When a poor, wandering bagpiper steals a dead man's boots and uses them to play a trick on an unfriendly farmer, he finds the trick turned back on him. The cool gray tones of the watercolor illustrations add spookiness to this ghostly legend, which is a good read-aloud.
Author: Cynthia DeFelice

Title: Colonial Voices: Hear Them Speak
Annotation: In colonial Boston, Ethan, a young printer’s errand boy, must deliver an important message to the Patriots. Everyone has an opinion about the King of England and his tea tax, and everywhere Ethan goes there is a sense of urgency. Ethan witnesses events and the daily practices of the printer, the shoemaker, the basket trader, and others. Illustrated with ink-and-watercolor artwork.
Author: Kay Winters

Title: Color
Annotation: This rhyming concept book shows young readers how artwork gets reproduced from pictures to the printed page. Included are different art media and an explanation of how colors are mixed to create other colors. Also included are a four-page, acetate printer's proof and a sample finished work. See other books by this California author.
Author: Ruth Heller
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary

Title: Colt
Annotation: Colt, a boy with spina bifida and a new step-family, overcomes his fear and anger at being thrust into a Horses for the Handicapped program. A pivotal event has Colt overcoming his limitations and maturing from a self-pitying whiner into a self-assured young man.
Author: Nancy Springer

Title: Come Back Salmon: How a Group of Dedicated Kids Adopted Pigeon Creek and Brought It Back to Life
Annotation: This photo-essay describes the efforts of the Jackson Elementary School in Everett, Washington, to clean up a nearby stream, stock it with salmon, and preserve it as a place where the salmon can return to spawn. This book shows that kids can make a difference if they care!
Author: Molly Cone

Title: Coming to America: A Muslim Family's Story
Annotation: This book depicts the joys and hardships experienced by a Muslim family who immigrates to New York City from Alexandria, Egypt, in the hope of finding a better life. The roles, activities, and struggles of the parents and their three children are described through text. The book also includes full-color photos.
Author: Bernard Wolf

Title: Como crece una semilla (How a Seed Grows)
Annotation: In simple, clear text this book describes how a seed gets water, nutrients, and sunlight and highlights the life cycle of a bean plant. It offers instruction on how to plant bean seeds in eggshells and encourages the reader to observe their development. The bright detailed pictures dramatize how a little seed may become a flower, a vegetable, or even a huge oak tree. See other books in the Aprende y Descubre la Ciencia (Let's-Read-And-Find-Out Science) series.
Author: Helene J. Jordan

Title: Como nacio el arco iris (How the Rainbow Came to Be)
Annotation: This folktale depicts the three primary colors who want to paint the gray planet Earth. Unable to agree, they each take their own paint and find that they can blend their colors to make more beauty. In celebration of their accomplishment, they create the rainbow.
Author: Alma Flor Ada
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Compost Critters
Annotation: The author describes what happens in a compost pile and how creatures, from bacteria and mites to millipedes and earthworms, aid in the process of turning compost into humus. Stunning, close-up colored photographs show a variety of decomposers and other living things that help to produce a rich soil amendment.
Author: Bianca Lavies

Title: Conejito y el mar (Little Rabbit and the Sea)
Annotation: Conejito wants nothing more than to become a sailor. While stuck on land, he asks his family to describe the sea for him. One day, when a sea gull brings the sea to Conejito, he finally realizes that the sea was everything he ever dreamed of and more.
Author: Gavin Bishop

Title: Confucius: The Golden Rule
Annotation: This book acquaints readers with Confucius, who was born in 552 B.C. in China. Freedman weaves facts, legends, and the philosopher's words to reveal a man of deep beliefs and great humor. It includes many of Confucius' wise sayings. Beautiful collage paintings and designs add to this outstanding work. Useful in character education and for investigating religions, philosophy, biographies, ancient Chinese culture, and Confucius' influence.
Author: Russell Freedman

Title: Conservacion: Una forma inteligente de explicar a los ninos que es la conservacion (Conservation: An Intelligent Way to Explain to Children What Is Conservation)
Annotation: The benefits of global conservation are presented in a direct and easy-to-read format. Colorful illustrations on each page help show the importance of conserving our environment.
Author: Margaret Dunkle, Robert Ingpen

Title: Cook-A-Doodle-Doo!
Annotation: The story of the Little Red Hen is modernized by having her great-grandson, Big Brown Rooster, find her cookbook and decide to make strawberry shortcake, assisted by Turtle, Iguana, and Potbellied Pig. While they make the cake shown in colorful illustrations, margin information explains what is going on and how to bake a cake. The recipe is on the last page.
Author: Janet Stevens, Susan Stevens Crummel
Discipline: History/Social Science, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, Mathematics, Science
Standard: PS K.1, HSS K.1, I & E K.4, HSS 1.6

Title: Cool Melons Turn to Frogs: The Life and Poems of Issa
Annotation: The story of the life of Issa, a Japanese poet in the eighteenth century, is combined with 33 of his haiku poems, which reflect the poet's different experiences. The poems are accompanied by artwork and Japanese calligraphy. The text includes an explanation of haiku and how it is written and invites readers to try writing their own haikus. California author.
Author: Matthew Gollub (translator)
Illustrator: Kazuko J. Stone; Calligraphy: Keiko Smith

Title: Coolies
Annotation: During the mid-1800s, many Chinese immigrants made their way to San Francisco and were hired to build the Transcontinental Railroad. They were called "coolies," a derogatory term for Chinese workers. They were given the most dangerous jobs and were paid the least. This beautifully illustrated book gives a good picture of the part the Chinese laborers played in the building of America and especially California.
Author: - Yin

Title: Coretta Scott
Annotation: This poetic biographical sketch reverently celebrates the life of Coretta Scott King—from her childhood to her adult role as a female leader in the civil rights movement. The author and illustrator reveal the strength, beauty, and humility of King through prose and striking full-page paintings. A good resource for Black History Month or for studies of important women in American history.
Author: Ntozake Shange
Topic: American History, Diversity, Global Historical Events and Figures, Global Social Issues, Women’s Studies

Title: Corn Is Maize: The Gift of the Indians
Annotation: This factual book relates the story of corn: how it is grown, how it is used, how it is celebrated, and how the Native Americans helped the first white people in America to survive by growing and harvesting it.
Author: - Aliki
Standard: LS K.2, HSS K.3, HSS K.6, LS 1.2, LS 2.2, HSS 1.5, HSS 1.6, LS 3.3, HSS 2.4, HSS 3.2, HSS 5.1

Title: Corner of the Universe, A
Annotation: With the surprising arrival of a mentally disabled uncle, twelve-year-old Hattie's world is turned upside down. Set in the 1960s, this novel by Ann Martin draws on her own childhood.
Author: Ann M. Martin

Title: Cornhusk, Silk, and Wishbones: A Book of Dolls from Around the World
Annotation: This book presents a collection of dolls from 1000 B.C. to the present, from all the continents. The dolls are arranged in alphabetical order according to type, accompanied by an informative paragraph about the doll, including its origin and time period, as well as cultural and historical information. A full-color photograph helps to reveal clothing and the culture of the time. A section on the art of doll collecting is included along with a bibliography and a two-page map showing the origin of each doll.
Author: Michelle Markel

Title: Cosechando esperanza: la historia de Cesar Chavez (Harvesting Hope: The Story of Cesar Chavez)
Annotation: This picture book biography relates the life of Cesar Chavez and his efforts to organize the National Farm Workers Association to improve working and living conditions for migrant farm workers. The illustrations evoke the settings and the Hispanic culture. Also available in English. California author, illustrator, and setting. Translated by F. Isabel Campoy and Alma Flor Ada.
Author: Kathleen Krull
Award: Christopher Award, John and Patricia Beatty Award, Pura Belpre Illustration Honor

Title: Count Me a Rhyme: Animal Poems by the Numbers
Annotation: This title takes a look at numbers of nature's creatures in photographs and in poetry. The poems highlight information about a variety of animals, mirroring the animal in a variety of ways. Each spread also presents words related to the numbers and Roman numerals as well. Full-color photographs of animals give great attention to detail. This title can be used for choral reading.
Author: Jane Yolen
Standard: LS K.2, LS 1.2, LS 3.3, Math K.CC.1-7, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6

Title: Counting Coup: Becoming a Crow Chief on the Reservation and Beyond
Annotation: A memoir of Joseph Medicine Crow, the last traditional chief of his people, who describes his ancestors, ancient traditions, growing up on the reservation, World War II experiences, and how he earned the status of War Chief by completing the four war deeds required of a Crow warrior. Winner of the 2008 American Indian Youth Literature Award.
Author: Herman J. Viola, Joseph Medicine Crow

Title: Counting on Frank
Annotation: A boy asks questions about ordinary things including his dog, Frank. He uses these questions to make math and measurement fun and meaningful. This humorous book includes an introduction to the metric system and a collection of measurement activities to be used with children. The book is illustrated with detailed and colorful artwork that enhances the humor.
Author: Rod Clement
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry), Number Sense
Standard: I & E 6.7, I & E 7.7, I & E 8.9, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 5.MD.1-5, Math 6.G.1-6

Title: Counting on Grace
