Annotation: Grace, a twelve-year-old girl living in a small, rural town in Vermont in the early 1900s, and her friend Arthur, are taken out of school and put to work in a textile mill. Grace’s narrative tells about the dangerous working conditions and the encouragement of her teacher, who urges both children to write to the National Child Labor Committee. Gripping historical fiction that would be a good companion to the nonfiction book KIDS AT WORK (Russell Freedman, 1994).
Author: Elizabeth Winthrop

Title: Counting Our Way to the 100th Day
Annotation: This original approach to counting presents 100 poems, each dealing with the number 100 in a special way. Math play and word play cleverly introduce mathematical concepts. The illustrations are rendered in gouache, making use of bright colors and bold designs.
Author: Betsy Franco

Title: Covered Wagons, Bumpy Trails
Annotation: Told in rhyming quatrains, this story follows a pioneer family as they migrate across the Oregon Trail to California. Much information is packed into the short text. As the trip progresses, the baby grows, belongings are abandoned, and bad weather impacts the wagon train. Finally arriving in the Sacramento Valley, the family has little left except high hopes. Illustrated with watercolor artwork.
Author: Verla Kay

Title: Coyote and Badger: Desert Hunters of the Southwest
Annotation: The real predatory partnership of the coyote and badger in a drought-stricken New Mexico desert is the basis of this story about two animals hunting together. Full-color realistic watercolors reveal clues of human presence by the appearance of small petroglyphs and buried artifacts. This is an excellent example of adaptations in studies of animals. It can also be used in units about the desert or Native Americans.
Author: Bruce Hiscock

Title: Coyote Raid in Cactus Canyon
Annotation: Four young coyotes harass the animals in a desert canyon until they run into a rattlesnake. Arnosky's brightly detailed artwork accompanies the lively text to bring this habitat to life. Use as a read-aloud introduction to the desert and the variety of plants and animals that reside there.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: Coyote: North America's Dog
Annotation: In this nonfiction selection, the author introduces the coyote through his own observations of this somewhat controversial animal. The balanced text invites readers to form their own opinions, showing the coyote as hated and hunted, but also tolerated as part of the ecological balance and venerated in Native American lore. Black-and-white primary source materials and contemporary color photographs tell the coyote's story well and document typical behaviors. "Coyote Fact" sidebars throughout will attract browsers and reluctant readers.
Author: Stephen R. Swinburne

Title: Crab Moon
Annotation: While visiting a seaside cottage a young boy and his mother witness the seasonal spawning of horseshoe crabs on the shore under a full moon. The lyrical language is accompanied by rich oil paintings that catch the moonlit scene. A page of facts give children further information about the behavior, life cycle, and habitat of the horseshoe crabs.
Author: Ruth Horowitz

Title: Crawdad Creek
Annotation: Animals that live in and around a creek through the seasons are introduced. Readers are encouraged to use their senses to observe the natural world, to open their eyes, ears and hearts to the wilderness. Detailed paintings capture the wonder of the natural world in double-page spreads. This is a useful choice for units on ecology. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Scott Russell Sanders

Title: Crazy Horse’s Vision
Annotation: Presents the story of a young Lakota boy who became a brave warrior and the leader of his people. Crazy Horse sought divine inspiration when his tribe was invaded by white settlers. This is a beautifully illustrated book with engaging text told from a Native American point of view. The illustrations reflect the artwork and style of Plains Indians who were given ledger books when they were placed in Indian schools.
Author: Joseph Bruchac

Title: Creepy Crawlies
Annotation: Each double-page spread in this book presents a continuing story of a cat moving about the house. Information about the various and common domestic inhabitants found in and about the house and garden is included. Small portraits of the critters accompany full-page paintings showing the cat roaming indoors and outdoors.
Author: Hans Post

Title: Cricket in Times Square
Annotation: Chester Cricket unintentionally arrives in New York via picnic basket from Connecticut, and takes up residence in a Times Square newsstand. This intermediate novel presents the comic and tragic sights, sounds, and experiences of city life. Other books in the series include CHESTER CRICKET'S NEW HOME, CHESTER CRICKET'S PIGEON RIDE, etc.
Author: George Selden

Title: Cricket Songs: Japanese Haiku
Annotation: Brief, nonrhyming poems express the wonders of nature. The book is out of print but available in most libraries.
Author: Harry Behn (translator)

Title: Crickwing
Annotation: A disabled cockroach, plagued by rain forest predators, takes his frustration out on a group of leaf-cutter ants. In the end he saves the day for them when army ants attack. The book is illustrated with luminous acrylic and pencil artwork with black-and-white vignettes. It concludes with facts on ants and cockroaches. California author/illustrator.
Author: Janell Cannon

Title: Crictor
Annotation: Madame Bodot teaches school and Crictor, a pet boa, helps her teach the alphabet by twirling himself into the shapes of the individual letters. One day a burglar breaks into the house, and Crictor captures the thief and is awarded a hero's medal.
Author: Tomi Ungerer

Title: Crinkleroot's Nature Almanac
Annotation: The forest habitat through the seasons features wildflowers in the spring, otters swimming in the summer, and animal tracks in the winter snow. A clear and simple narrative makes this an appropriate choice for older reluctant readers. Humorous pen-and-ink illustrations are highlighted with color. Words and music for "Crinkleroot's Song" are included.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: Crocodile Safari
Annotation: Jim Arnosky explores south Florida by canoe and acquaints readers with the American crocodile. Information about these shy reptiles is integrated with a personal narrative. Detailed paintings accompany the text and highlight the differences between crocodiles and alligators. Many other inhabitants in this ecosystem are identified and illustrated. A song written by Arnosky about his trip completes the story and is included on a DVD that also shows his work along the lower Atlantic coastline.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: Crocodiles and Alligators
Annotation: Facts about the physical characteristics and behavior of various members of the crocodile family are presented in a narrative and interesting style. The author describes the ancient crocodilians that lived at the time of the dinosaurs. The dangers that threaten crocodiles and alligators today are discussed. The book is illustrated with vivid, full-color photographs.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Crooked Kind of Perfect, A
Annotation: Zoe, a ten-year-old musician, dreams of playing piano and performing at Carnegie Hall. However, Zoe’s father brings her a Perfectone D-60 organ instead of a piano. The short chapters are narrated in Zoe’s voice and reveal Zoe’s insecurities and her quirky family. The story carries the message that doing one’s best and believing in oneself are what truly matters.
Author: Linda Urban
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Crooked River
Annotation: In 1812, Rebecca and her sisters return to their Ohio frontier settlement and find that their father is holding captive a young Native American boy, who has been accused of murdering a white trapper. Rebecca and her sister Laura are to take food to the boy; as a result, the girls become protective toward him. Suspenseful and realistic, this story can be used as a discussion tool for Native American studies.
Author: Shelley Pearsall

Title: Crossing Bok Chitto: A Choctaw Tale of Friendship and Freedom
Annotation: In the 1800s, a Choctaw girl becomes friends with a slave boy from a plantation across the great river, and when she learns that his family is in trouble, she helps them cross to freedom. Written by a Choctaw storyteller and illustrated with strong, dignified, and forceful acrylic paintings by a Choctaw artist, this is a compelling picture-book story appropriate for reading aloud to all ages.
Author: Tim Tingle

Title: Crossing: How George Washington Saved the American Revolution, The
Annotation: This is the story of George Washington assuming the role of general and overseeing a group of ragtag rebels in 1776. Elated by their first victories, the rebels face the brutal might of Britain’s professional army. Washington has no wartime experience of this magnitude, but his sheer genius and vision carry this unruly group to eventual victory. Illustrations include maps and artwork reproductions. The book provides a time line, related Web sites, and a bibliography.
Author: Jim Murphy

Title: Crow Call
Annotation: Written from the author’s memories of 1945, when her father returned from World War II, this picture book deals with the experience of a child–parent reunion after a wartime separation. Eight-year-old Lizzie is quietly happy to accompany her father on a hunting trip to rid their farm of crop-eating crows. He notices her feelings about what will happen to the flying birds when she uses the crow-call whistle. The illustrations of the Pennsylvania countryside are executed in muted shades of fall and are integral to the story.
Author: Lois Lowry
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, War

Title: Cuaderno de besos (A Notebook Full of Kisses)
Annotation: Dedicated to Johnathan Prevette, the young American boy who was briefly expelled from school in the 1990s for kissing a girl on her cheek, this imaginative story tells about Paula's reactions upon hearing the incredible news on TV. To avoid possible expulsion from school, Paula decides to stop kissing her friends and numerous adults. She saves her kisses in a notebook, and unforeseen results occur. Paula's story could be used as a wonderful example of how cultural differences may cause misunderstandings.
Author: Alfredo Gomez Cerda

Title: Cuentame un cuento (The Nursery Storybook)
Annotation: This volume contains eight popular children's stories: "Little Red Riding Hood," "The Elves and the Shoemaker," "The Three Billy Goats Gruff," "The Princess and the Pea," "The Gingerbread Boy," "Goldilocks and the Three Bears," "The Three Little Pigs," and "Jack and the Beanstalk."
Author: Georgie Adams

Title: Cuentame un cuento 3 (Tell Me a Story 3)
Annotation: This book features seven of the most popular fairy tales by Grimm in an easy-to-read format. The timeless stories and modern watercolor illustrations make this book especially appropriate to read aloud to young ones or recommend to older children for independent reading.
Author: Concha Cardenoso (adapter)

Title: Cuentos del zorro (Fox's Stories)
Annotation: This collection of folktales highlights the traditional beliefs and practices of the people of Argentina. Nine amusing stories feature a scheming sly fox, who takes on a powerful jaguar and an intelligent quirquincho with unpredictable consequences.
Author: Gustavo Roldan

Title: Curious Critters
Annotation: Stunning close-up photographs of 21 critters common to North America accompany information about each creature. The lighthearted narrative is told in the first person. Photographs on a white background compel the reader to take a long look at each animal.
Author: David FitzSimmons

Title: Curse of the Ancient Mask and Other Case Files, The
Annotation: Ten-year-old Saxby Smart is a genius detective who attends school on the side. He takes on three unique cases for fellow classmates by using observation, deductive reasoning, and Internet research to solve each case. Readers solve the crimes alongside Saxby. Illustrated with ink drawings. This is Book 1 in the series “Saxby Smart: Private Detective,” a modern-day Encyclopedia Brown.
Author: Simon Cheshire

Title: Cut Down to Size at High Noon: A Math Adventure
Annotation: Welcome to the western town of Cowlick, where Louie is the haircutter. He uses scale drawings, illustrated on graph paper, to do extraordinary haircuts. One day, a stranger named Buzzsaw Bart appears in town and challenges Louie to a haircutting showdown at high noon. This story may be used to introduce concepts of scaling (both up and down) and proportions.
Author: Scott Sundby

Title: Cutaway Space Vehicles
Annotation: This book examines different types of machines used in space exploration, including probes, satellites, space shuttles, and rockets, and describes the work they do. It gives the reader the opportunity to look inside rockets, moon landers, and space shuttles to see how they work. The detailed, full-color illustrations reveal what goes on inside. See other books in the Cutaway series.
Author: Jon Richards
Illustrator: Alex Pang, Richard Rockwood, Simon Tegg
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: D Is for Democracy: A Citizen’s Alphabet
Annotation: Readers are taken through an alphabetical adventure detailing the U.S. government’s structure, political process, and parties, as well as the rights and responsibilities of citizens. The colorful artwork is done in an editorial-cartoon style and includes caricatures. An appendix encourages participation in government.
Author: Elissa Grodin
Topic: American History, Government and Politics, Law and Legal Studies

Title: D Is for Doufu: An Alphabet Book of Chinese Culture
Annotation: This book introduces Chinese culture, beliefs, and legends and explores the meanings of 23 Chinese words and phrases. It also provides a historical and cultural background covering 5,000 years. The Chinese terms are illuminated with both Chinese characters and hanyu-pinyin (romanized Chinese) followed by an English translation and narrative. Colorful Chinese folk art illustrates each of the 23 terms. Includes a history of the Chinese language, explanations of tones and sounds, and a timeline of Chinese history. California author.
Author: Maywan Shen Krach

Title: D'Aulaires' Book of Greek Myths
Annotation: Greek myths about the gods, the titans, and the heroes are told in a simple narrative style. The volume is large and is vividly illustrated. Young or reluctant readers will find this classic appealing.
Author: Edgar P. D'Aulaire, Ingri D’Aulaire

Title: Dab Neeg Txog Xuav Lub Cim Hnub Nyoog (Story of the Chinese Zodiac)
Annotation: This bilingual text retells the story of how the gods decided on the names of the Chinese zodiac by holding a race for the animals. It is illustrated with paper sculpture collage. Regional dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text. Translated by Tong Mua, Pao Vang, and Terfong Yang.
Author: Monica Chang

Title: Dab Neeg, Phau Ib (Folk Tales, Books 1, 2, and 3)
Annotation: These three volumes include 43 folktales from the Hmong of Laos. Black-line drawings introduce each folktale.
Author: Yves Bertrais (editor)

Title: Dadblamed Union Army Cow
Annotation: A faithful cow follows her owner, a Union soldier, to the Civil War and stays until the fighting is over. The headstrong cow causes problems for the troops as she travels along—but she also provides milk and warmth to the soldiers in their time of need. The cow receives a medal for “brave and unusual service to country” at the end of the war. Pencil and watercolor illustrations enhance this terrific read-aloud. Based on a true story.
Author: Susan Fletcher

Title: Dance, Mice, Dance! (Hmong: Seevcev, Nas Tsuag, Seevcev!)
Annotation: Flute player Jimmy Tune allows the influences of alcohol to rob him of his success, but he is given a chance to redeem himself when he is befriended by a group of happy, dancing mice. Full-page watercolor illustrations highlighted by black line are included. Regional dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text. Translated from Vietnamese by Nguyen Nguc Ngonl; and Hmong by Pao Vang and Ter F. Yang.
Author: Kuang-Ts’ai Hao (reteller)

Title: Dancing in the Wings
Annotation: Sassy tries out for a summer dance festival in Washington, DC, despite the other girls’ taunts that she is much too tall. The dialogue is realistic, and the full-color illustrations of the predominantly African American cast capture Sassy’s love of dance and her lively personality.
Author: Debbie Allen

Title: Dancing Kettle, The
Annotation: Japanese folktales, collected and retold by this California author, provide cultural connections between Asia and the Americans who have descended from immigrants of many nations.
Author: Yoshiko Uchida

Title: Dancing Larry
Annotation: When Madame Swoboda refuses to admit Larry the polar bear into ballet class, he refuses to admit defeat. Larry, his brother, and their polar bear friends form their own ballet company to express themselves in dance. After much practice, they perform in a recital. Illustrated with colorful pen-and-ink artwork.
Author: Daniel Pinkwater

Title: Dancing Teepees: Poems of American Indian Youth
Annotation: Native Americans did not have a written language, the poems in this book are taken from the oral traditions of various tribes. The theme of the collection is youth; and the soft pastel-and-watercolor illustrations use traditional Indian designs as well as modern interpretations of the individual poems.
Author: Virginia Driving Hawk Sneve

Title: Dancing Through Fire
Annotation: This story was inspired by Edgar Degas’ painting, “Dancer on the Stage” (“L’Etoile”). A young pupil of the Paris Opera Ballet in the 1870s strives to dance well and grow skillful enough to be able to join the ballet. Her mother works hard to support her; however, the Franco–Prussian War breaks out, causing hardships and occasional closures of the ballet. The artist Degas makes appearances throughout this coming-of-age story.
Author: Kathryn Lasky

Title: Dancing to Freedom: The True Story of Mao’s Last Dancer
Annotation: This is the author’s own story of how he was chosen to train as a ballet dancer in Maoist China, became an international star, and fulfilled his dream of seeing the world. Illustrated with a combination of traditional Chinese ink-and-watercolor brush painting and oil paintings. An author’s note explains what life was like under Mao Zedong.
Author: Li Cunxin
Topic: Dance, Diversity, Global Social Issues, Immigration/Migration, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Dancing Wheels
Annotation: Beautifully written and photographed, this book documents the lives of two dancers—a “stand-up” and a “sit-down”—who work together in a company named Dancing Wheels. The company features the combined talents of dancers both in and out of wheelchairs. Dramatic views of a Dancing Wheels production are captioned and attractively displayed; the text acquaints readers with individual dancers and their “can-do” attitude.
Author: Patricia McMahon
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA D PreK-12.5

Title: Dancing with Katya
Annotation: In the late 1920s, Anna tries to help her younger sister Katya regain her strength and joy in life and dancing after being crippled by polio at the age of five. After rehabilitation, Katya comes home. Despite heavy leg braces, Katya learns from Anna to dance in her own way. The watercolor illustrations capture the spirit of the story as well as Midwestern farm life in the early twentieth century. Personal notes by the author and the illustrator tell how polio affected their families.
Author: Dori Chaconas

Title: Dandelions
Annotation: This book offers a close-up look at this often-maligned plant that is also a beautiful flower. The physical characteristics and life cycle of this plant are explained along with some history. Six short chapters are illustrated with color photographs. See other books in the Early Bird Nature Book series.
Author: Kathleen V. Kudlinski

Title: Dany, ¿quieres cuidar a tu hermanita? (Will You Mind the Baby, Davy?)
Annotation: When his little sister comes along, Dany is still not quite ready to give up the role as the baby of the family. However, Dany soon realizes that being a big brother has its rewards and may be his most important job so far. Charcoal and color drawings illustrate the experience of a toddler's gradual adjustment to having a new family member.
Author: Brigitte Weninger

Title: Dao Dua Do (Red Watermelon Island)
Annotation: This orphan story teaches children that even in the worst situation, a person can prosper and succeed. The story takes place in eighteenth-century Vietnam.
Author: Tranh Huong Duong

Title: Darby
Annotation: Set in the 1920s, this novel portrays nine-year-old Darby, who stirs up trouble in her small South Carolina town when she writes a story for the local newspaper promoting racial equality. The Ku Klux Klan responds by burning a cross in her front yard and pelting her father's store with bricks. Written in the first-person narrative.
Author: Jonathon Scott Fuqua

Title: Dark Emperor and Other Poems of the Night
Annotation: This collection of poems celebrates the mysterious and dangerous world of night and describes the many things that hide in the dark. Each poem is illustrated with linocut artwork in double-page spreads and is linked with science concepts. The poems highlight insects, trees, animals, predators and their prey, and other living things associated with nighttime. The book includes a glossary. 2011 Newbery Honor.
Author: Joyce Sidman
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, English-Language Arts/Writing, Literacy/Motivation, Science
Award: Newbery Honor, Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: Darwin
Annotation: Presents a biography of Charles Darwin, with an introduction to his theory of evolution and the origin of his ideas. The book discusses Darwin’s voyage on the H.M.S. Beagle, a journey that allowed him to observe many animals, plants, and collected specimens. Excerpts from his writings are shown as handwritten entries on parchment sheets. Illustrated with woodcut artwork painted with watercolor. Includes a brief author’s note.
Author: Alice B. McGinty
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Life Science (Biology)

Title: Dave at Night
Annotation: This story is set in New York in 1926. Dave, a Jewish orphan, is sent to the Hebrew Home for Boys, where he is treated cruelly. He sneaks out at night and finds the world of the Harlem Renaissance filled with music and culture. This selection depicts abusive situations.
Author: Gail Carson Levine
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Dave the Potter: Artist, Poet, Slave
Annotation: A lyrical look at the life of a nineteenth-century South Carolina slave who was a noted potter. He signed his massive jars with poetry. The book describes his process for creating his jars and includes a photo of his work. Watercolor and collage illustrations complement the text.
Author: Laban Carrick Hill
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Winner

Title: David va al colegio (David Goes to School)
Annotation: David goes off to school with enthusiasm, but exasperates his teacher. Finally, he wins her over with his charm. Colorful, humorous, childlike illustrations characterize this lighthearted companion to the Caldecott Honor book NO, DAVID! California author/illustrator.
Author: David Shannon
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Day the Crayons Quit, The
Annotation: All Duncan wants to do is color, but the crayons have gone on strike, and they've left Duncan a pile of letters listing their grievances.
Author: Drew Daywalt
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Award: California Young Reader Medal, Christopher Award

Title: Day's Work, A
Annotation: Francisco and his grandfather from Mexico solicit work as gardeners and find themselves picking the wrong plants. Although they are desperate for work, Francisco learns from his grandfather that it is more important to be honest about one's mistakes than it is to make money. This thoughtful story includes strong watercolor illustrations. California author and setting.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: Day-Glo Brothers, The: The True Story of Bob and Joe Switzer's Bright Ideas and Brand-New Colors
Annotation:
This book is the story of two American brothers who invented fluorescent paint during the 1930's.

Bob Switzer was the practical and hardworking member of the team while his brother Joe was a creative amateur magician.
Author: Chris Barton
Topic: American History, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Visual Arts, War
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General , Science

Title: Days of Jubilee: The End of Slavery in the United States
Annotation: The book uses slave narratives, letters, diaries, military orders, and other documents to chronicle various stages leading to the emancipation of slaves in the United States.
Author: Fredrick McKissack, Patricia C. McKissack

Title: Dead End in Norvelt
Annotation: It is 1952, and twelve-year-old Jack Gantos is grounded for the summer when he accidentally shoots off his father’s Japanese rifle from World War II. Jack is chosen to help an eccentric neighbor write obituaries, which he agrees to do in order to get out of his room. He is also very interested in history, so the reader gets to follow his musings about various historic personalities and events. This book’s humor, wild and crazy happenings, and eccentric characters are memorable.
Author: Jack Gantos

Title: Deaf Musicians, The
Annotation: Lee, a jazz pianist, has to leave his band when he begins to lose his hearing. When he meets a deaf saxophone player in a sign-language class, a snazzy new band is born. Colorful, expressionist illustrations lend a retro feel to this book.
Author: Paul Dubois Jacobs, Pete Seeger
Topic: Diversity, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, Music

Title: Dear Children of the Earth: A Letter from Home
Annotation: Mother Earth writes a letter to the people on Earth asking for their help in conserving the planet. Original paintings by the author convey a love for the environment, while accompanying text asks the reader to reflect on the interrelationship between humanity and the natural world.
Author: Schim Schimmel
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: Dear Max
Annotation: Nine-year-old Max lives with his mother and is mourning his father’s death. He begins a year-long correspondence with author D. J. Lucas, sharing in letters, postcards, and drawings his sadness and concerns about his unnamed illness and being the class bully’s favorite target. D.J. Lucas responds by sharing her own worries about skydiving and writing—and a friendship is born. This epistolary novel is highlighted with black-line, cartoon-style drawings that complement the story perfectly. The book may help to spark classroom discussions about bullying.
Author: Sally Grindley

Title: Dear Mr. Rosenwald
Annotation: In the 1920s, the president of Sears, Roebuck and Co. provided seed money to build schools in the rural South as long as the community helped to raise funds. This story of a one-room school built in a proud African American community is told by a ten-year-old girl from a family of sharecroppers. Illustrated with striking gouache and colored-pencil artwork.
Author: Carole Boston Weatherford

Title: Dear Sylvia
Annotation: Though young Owen is challenged by spelling, he begins to write and follows through with letters to a classmate, Sylvia, who has moved away. His letters are funny and poignant as he relates what happens in his home and at school. All the details of his life are included, but he is unable to tell her the one thing he wants her to know: he loves her. A warm and engaging story.
Author: Alan Cumyn

Title: Dear Willie Rudd
Annotation: Miss Elizabeth remembers the kind and generous Willie Rudd, her family's black servant during her childhood. She writes a letter to Willie Rudd apologizing for the customs of those days that prevented him from eating with the family and entering the home through the front door. Miss Elizabeth lovingly finishes the letter, attaches it to a kite, and releases both to the wind and the night. The book is available in paper and prebind.
Author: Libba Moore Gray

Title: Decoding Data
Annotation: This title introduces how scientists use tables, graphs, and other math tools to make comparisons and draw conclusions; identifies different types of graphs; and discusses which kinds of graph are best used to display certain types of data. Practical examples of data and how they are displayed are provided.
Author: Rebecca L. Johnson

Title: Degas and the Dance: The Painter and the Petits Rats, Perfecting Their Art
Annotation: Explores the life and work of Edgar Degas, the nineteenth-century French artist who devoted most of his artwork to the subject of ballet. Written in association with the American Federation of Arts and the School of American Ballet, this book includes quotations and bibliographical references. The large-size format and art reproductions have visual appeal and will capture student interest. California author.
Author: Susan Goldman Rubin
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.3

Title: Degas and the Little Dancer: A Story about Edgar Degas
Annotation: Marie, a young girl in Paris, dreams of becoming a famous ballerina but cannot afford dancing school. She earns income for her parents by modeling for Edgar Degas at a ballet school. She realizes her dream, but not in the way she had thought. The popularity of Degas’ painting of Marie as the “Little Dancer” makes her famous. Illustrated with reproductions of artwork by Degas.
Author: Laurence Anholt
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3

Title: Delicious: The Life and Art of Wayne Thiebaud
Annotation: Chronicles the life and career of American painter Wayne Thiebaud, discussing his depictions of foods, people, farms, cities, and other subjects. Lavishly illustrated with many examples of Thiebaud’s artwork, including cakes and sweet treats. The text is enhanced with photos of the artist as a child and as an adult at his easel, as well as a self-portrait. California author.
Author: Susan Goldman Rubin
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3

Title: Delivering Justice: W. W. Law and the Fight for Civil Rights
Annotation: An illustrated account of postal worker and civil rights leader Westley Wallace (W. W.) Law and his role in the nonviolent movement to desegregate Savannah, Georgia, in the early 1960s. Savannah was the first Southern city to desegregate, three years before the federal Civil Rights Act became law. The oil and collage illustrations evoke the dignity and strength that characterized W. W. Law.
Author: Jim Haskins

Title: Descubriendo las estrellas (Discovering the Stars)
Annotation: This book serves as an introduction to the study of what makes a star. Children will enjoy this story about the stars in the galaxy and their role in the constellations. This is a blending of science and history.
Author: Lawrence Santrey

Title: Desert Giant: The World of the Saguaro Cactus
Annotation: The life cycle and ecosystem of the giant Saguaro cactus and the multitude of animals and plants it helps to support or affect is told in well-crafted text and lush, realistic paintings. Included is how the cactus provides homes for woodpeckers, owls, and hawks, and food for bats, birds, coyotes, and the indigenous people of Arizona's Sonoran Desert.
Author: Barbara Bash

Title: Desert Scrapbook, A
Annotation: The author shares her love of the Sonoran Desert through her verbal descriptions and handsome watercolors. It is packed with facts and detailed illustrations of the desert ecosystem. This book demonstrates how a scientist might record data from the field.
Author: Virginia Wright-Frierson

Title: Desert Song
Annotation: As the sun sets on the Sonoran desert, the nocturnal animals emerge and begin their quest for food. This illustrated story of the desert night ecosystem is told in free verse and depicts the flora and fauna of the desert.
Author: Tony Johnston

Title: Desert Trip
Annotation: A young girl and her mother backpack in the desert and learn about the plants, animals, birds, and rock formations. Soft watercolor illustrations and first-person narrative capture the magic of the desert and bring the reader/listener into the backpackers' adventure of discovery.
Author: Barbara A. Steiner

Title: Desert Voices
Annotation: In lyrical text, ten creatures describe their lives and the beauty of their desert home. Striking page design, highlighted with some color, create detailed images of the creatures and their desert habitat. A good read-aloud choice to introduce the desert habitat.
Author: Byrd Baylor

Title: Desiertos, Los (The Desert)
Annotation: The desert ecosystems from around the world are presented in an informative, easy-to-understand book. Maps, drawings, photographs, and pictures add to the clear and straightforward text. Scientific concepts such as adaptation and the effects of sun, wind, and man on the desert ecosystem are all included. See other books in the Planeta Vivo (The Modern Planet) series.
Author: Nuria Roca

Title: Destination Polar Regions
Annotation: In this photo essay, full-page photographs complement a short description of the polar regions including the adaptations of plants and animals. Included are the polar bear, narwhal, zooplankton, walrus, caribou, arctic wolf, grizzly bear, and the Weddell seal. Clear distinctions are drawn between the geography and the wildlife of the Arctic and Antarctic in the last two pages of the book. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Jonathan Grupper
Standard: LS K.2, ES K.3, LS 1.2, LS 3.3, ES 4.5, LS 6.5

Title: Destination Rocky Mountains
Annotation: The vastness and variety of the Rocky Mountain ecosystem is described highlighting animals that live there and how they use their adaptations for survival. The sharp, full-color photographs support the descriptions of the wildlife and landforms. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Jonathan Grupper
Standard: LS K.2, ES K.3, LS 1.2, LS 3.3, LS 4.2, LS 4.3

Title: Detective's Assistant, The
Annotation:
Eleven-year-old Nell Warne arrives on her aunt's doorstep lugging a heavy sack of sorrows. If her Aunt Kate rejects her, it's the miserable Home for the Friendless.

Luckily, canny Nell makes herself indispensable to Aunt Kate, and not just by helping out with household chores. For Aunt Kate is the first-ever female detective employed by the legendary Pinkerton Detective Agency. And Nell has a knack for the kind of close listening and bold action that made Pinkerton detectives famous in Civil War-era America. With huge, nation-changing events simmering in the background, Nell uses skills new and old to uncover truths about her past and solve mysteries in the present.

Based on the extraordinary true story of Kate Warne, this fast-paced adventure recounts feats of daring and danger...including saving the life of Abraham Lincoln!
Publisher: Little, Brown and Co. Books for Young Readers
Author: Kate Hannigan

Title: Dia en que tu naciste, El (On the Day You Were Born)
Annotation: Short descriptions of some of the natural phenomena of Earth are included in this read-aloud book. Each item is described in the context of welcoming a new person into the world. The last part of the book provides text-dense information on animal migration, Earth's rotation, gravity, the sun, the moon, stars, tides, rain, photosynthesis, atmosphere, and skin color.
Translator: Alma Flor Ada and F. Isabel Campoy Alma Flor Ada and F. Isabel Campoy
Author: Debra Frasier
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Dia's Story Cloth
Annotation: A young Hmong girl's experiences that led to her immigration to the United States are described and illustrated in this picture book. Her story is told by showing sections of an embroidered pa'ndau, or story cloth.
Author: Dia Cha

Title: Diablo de los numeros, El (The Number Devil: A Mathematical Adventure)
Annotation: Annoyed with his math teacher who assigns word problems and won't let him use a calculator, twelve-year-old Robert finds help from the number devil in his dreams. The author presents the great beauty and patterns of numbers through humor when introducing basic and complex mathematical ideas. The reader also learns about the achievements of celebrated mathematicians through the ages.
Author: Hans Magnus Enzensberger
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Mathematical Reasoning, Measurement & Geometry (Geometry), Number Sense
Standard: Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.NF.1-7, Math 6.RP.1-3, Math 6.NS.1-8, Math 6.EE.1-9, Math 6.MP.1-8, Math 7.RP.1-3, Math 7.NS.1-5, Math 7.EE.1-6, Math HS.NQ, Math HS.Functions

Title: Diario de Pedro, El (Pedro’s Journal)
Annotation: Written as a diary of a cabin boy whose task is to record the first voyage of Christopher Columbus. Personalities and historical events are shown in a realistic light. Pedro records his concerns about the natives taken aboard the ships. This is compelling reading that will appeal to many ages and bring events of American history into perspective.
Author: Pam Conrad
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, International Studies/World History, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Diary of a Spider
Annotation: A young spider discovers, day by day, that there is much to learn about being a spider, including how to spin webs and avoid vacuum cleaners. Humorous and whimsical, this book may stimulate interest in learning more about spiders and their habitats, structures, needs, and survival in the environment. Some accurate science facts are included in the story.
Author: Doreen Cronin

Title: Diary of a Worm
Annotation: A young worm discovers, as does a young child, that there are both good things and not-so-good things in life. Children will laugh at the sight of worms doing the hokey pokey at a school dance and sympathize when the young worm has a bad dream. This story is certain to have readers looking in soil to find a few worms to study - and perhaps learning how worms help take care of the earth. Some science facts are included in the story.
Author: Doreen Cronin

Title: Diccionario estrafalario (Eccentric Dictionary)
Annotation: This collection of more than 300 poems, arranged in alphabetical order, uses words from children's conversations, as well as common words to create a dictionary-styled book.
Author: Gloria Fuertes

Title: Diego Rivera: His World and Ours
Annotation: Introduces the life and work of Diego Rivera to young readers. His childhood and artistic career are described. Rivera drew from the history of Mexico and ancient Mexican art, incorporating modern influences to create his murals. Stylized, digitally enhanced illustrations, coupled with simple text, make this an accessible story. Back matter includes a glossary, an author’s note, bibliography, and selected sites for viewing Rivera’s murals.
Author: Duncan Tonatiuh
Topic: Diversity, Ethnic Studies, Lifestyles Around the World, Visual Arts

Title: Diego: Bigger Than Life
Annotation: This picture-book biography of Diego Rivera is written in free verse and is a companion piece to FRIDA (2007), also written by Bernier-Grand. First-person poems are paired with artwork to chronicle the life and work of one of the twentieth century’s greatest artists. Illustrated with David Diaz’s stylized, Aztec-inspired, mixed-media art. Includes four reproductions of Rivera’s paintings and a photograph of the artist. California illustrator.
Author: Carmen T. Bernier-Grand
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements
Award: Pura Belpre Illustration Honor, Pura Belpre Narrative Honor

Title: Different Like Coco
Annotation: Coco Chanel is presented as a lively girl who overcame poverty to become a fashion giant. She designed clothing that was simple, comfortable, and practical, and working women fell in love with her style. Humorous pen-and-ink drawings capture her personality and style. “Be yourself” is the message of this engaging picture-book biography.
Author: Elizabeth Matthews
Topic: Economics, Global Historical Events and Figures

Title: Dig, Wait, Listen
Annotation: A spadefoot toad waits under the sand for the rain, hears the sounds of other desert animals, and eventually mates and spawns other toads. The life cycle is illustrated with mixed-media watercolor pictures that incorporate a variety of colors, perspectives, and layouts. This is a read-aloud that can be used when teaching about the desert.
Author: April Pulley Sayre

Title: Digging for Bird-Dinosaurs: An Expedition to Madagascar
Annotation: Using words and full-color photographs, the author provides a glimpse into the life and work of paleontologist Cathy Forster. He follows her on an expedition to Madagascar, where she searches for evidence that dinosaurs and birds are related. Diagrams, maps, a bibliography of further reading, and an index are included. See other books in the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Nic Bishop

Title: Digging Up Dinosaurs
Annotation: This book introduces various types of dinosaurs whose skeletons and reconstructions are seen in museums and explains how scientists uncover, preserve, and study fossilized dinosaur bones. Detailed, well-researched drawings enhance the information presented.
Author: Aliki

Title: Dime como flotan los barcos (Tell Me How Ships Float)
Annotation: Scientists-to-be are exposed to simple experiments, activities, and projects involving weights and measurements, climatic principles, and aeronautics. Full-page, cartoonlike, color illustrations of children in common situations make this series inviting.
Author: Shirley Willis

Title: Dinosaur Discoveries
Annotation: Beginning with the meteor that may have caused the extinction of dinosaurs some 65 million years ago, Gibbons presents a brief history of the geologic periods of the Age of Dinosaurs. Illustrated with her signature bright artwork. Despite a few technical flaws related to recent discoveries, this presentation will inspire young students to research further.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Dinosaur Mountain: Graveyard of the Past
Annotation: The discoveries made at the Dinosaur National Monument quarry in Utah, a rich source of fossils, are described, and the detailed work of paleontologists is highlighted. The book is illustrated with color photographs of the digs and the work of the scientists.
Author: Caroline Arnold

Title: Dinosaur Mummies Beyond Bare-Bone Fossils
Annotation: From the scientists who, while digging in Montana, discovered the most complete dinosaur mummy ever found to descriptions of the earth's rarest fossils, this book describes the excitement of real scientists experience in their explorations and scientific discoveries. Detailed drawings, photographs, and quotes from actual scientists enliven the text. The book's explanations of theories and contradictions will stimulate the reader to learn more about paleontology. The featured scientists give narrative accounts of how they became interested in paleontology and of how they made their fossil discoveries. Photography is used to clarify verbal descriptions of fossil findings.
Author: Kelly Milner Halls

Title: Dinosaur Named Sue: The Story of the Colossal Fossil: The World's Most Complete T. Rex, A
Annotation: Text, color photographs, diagrams, and paintings assist in describing the journey of Sue, the most complete Tyrannosaurus Rex skeleton ever found as of 1999. The reader follows the scientific journey from the fossil excavation in South Dakota in 1990 to its arrival and reconstruction at Chicago's Field Museum.
Author: Pat Relf

Title: Dinosaur Parents, Dinosaur Young: Uncovering the Mystery of Dinosaur Families
Annotation: Changing theories of dinosaur life based on recent scientific discoveries and the historical trail of evidence are presented in a thoughtful style. Illustrated with color photographs, full-color paintings, and line drawings, the book includes suggested reading, a glossary, a dinosaur dictionary, and an index.
Author: Kathleen Weidner Zoehfeld

Title: Dinosaurios y otros animales prehistoricos (Dinosaurs and Other Prehistoric Animals)
Annotation: More than 200 entries are included in this well-designed, accurate, and colorful book. Entries include a picture, several paragraphs of text, and an at-a-glance fact book which places the dinosaur in time, place, and relationship to animals of today.
Author: Michael Benton

Title: Dinosaurs of Waterhouse Hawkins: An Illuminating History of Mr. Waterhouse Hawkins, Artist and Lecturer, The
Annotation: This is the true story of Victorian artist Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins, who built life-sized models of dinosaurs in the hope of educating the world about what these ancient animals were like. The text is illustrated with Victorian paintings. Extensive notes from the author and illustrator convey the thrill of research to young readers.
Author: Barbara Kerley
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, Science

Title: Dinosaurs! Strange and Wonderful
Annotation: Basic information about dinosaurs is presented with an explanation of how fossil records are often incomplete. It shows scientists at work and explains how recent discoveries continue to add new information about dinosaurs. The acrylic paintings show a variety of colors and patterns of the dinosaurs.
Author: Laurence P. Pringle

Title: Dinosaurs: Poems
Annotation: This is a collection of 18 poems by various authors including Lee Bennett Hopkins, Myra Cohn Livingston, Lilian Moore, and others paying homage to dinosaurs. The poems are accompanied by black-and-white, pen-and-ink drawings. Useful as supplementary material when studying dinosaurs and also for language arts lessons.
Author: Lee Bennett Hopkins (selector)

Title: Discovery of the Americas: From Prehistory Through the Age of Columbus, The
Annotation: This beautifully illustrated book explores the beginning of civilization: the land bridge connecting Asia and North America and the nomadic people who ventured across it and eventually settled in North, Central, and South America. It provides brief descriptions of the explorers who came, tried to settle down, and changed the native people. Although the book title uses Columbus’s name, the book actually continues beyond Columbus to the circumnavigation of the earth by Ferdinand Magellan.
Author: Betsy Maestro

Title: Dive to the Deep Ocean
Annotation: This is an exploration of the unique environment that thrives deep in the ocean. The use of photographs and line drawings enhance the uniqueness of the living organisms. This book can be used when studying tectonic movement, volcanic action, and undersea technology. As a marine scientist, the author takes great care in providing accurate information.
Author: Deborah Kovacs

Title: Dive!: My Adventures in the Deep Frontier
Annotation: A marine biologist relates some of her adventures investigating and exploring the marine ecosystem. Her activities include tracking whales, living in an underwater laboratory, and helping design a deep-water submarine. This book includes a glossary and an index. See other books in the National Geographic Society series. California author.
Author: Sylvia A. Earle
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Dizzy
Annotation: The story of jazz musician Dizzy Gillespie tells how, as an abused child, he fought his way through school until a teacher gave him a trumpet and helped him redirect his anger. He ultimately became a talented and successful innovator of bebop. The lyrical prose highlights Dizzy’s humor and playfulness and is illustrated with acrylic paintings. Includes an author’s note and a CD with musical selections.
Author: Jonah Winter

Title: Django
Annotation: Presents a biography of jazz guitarist Django Reinhardt, who developed the style of “gypsy jazz” in Paris during the 1920s and 1930s. He headlined nightclubs and was very successful even when a fire left his left hand so severely burned that it seemed he might never play guitar again. Django created a way to work around his injury, and he became the unparalleled master of syncopated jazz guitar. Vibrant paintings accompany this triumphant tale of a modern genius. Be sure to share some of his music with the story.
Author: Bonnie Christensen

Title: Do Re Mi: If You Can Read Music, Thank Guido d’Arezzo
Annotation: For many years, Guido d’Arezzo, a young man from Tuscany who became a monk, imagined that his system of lines and spaces could be used as written language for music. He was determined to make his ideas work. This book includes cut-paper collage illustrations made of papers from around the world.
Author: Angelo Mafucci, Susan L. Roth
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.3

Title: Do You Wanna Bet? Your Chance to Find Out About Probability
Annotation: Danny and Brian take you through a cornucopia of probability experiences in this lively tale. From forecasting weather to predicting a baby's name these two mathematicians rely on luck to win bets until they find out the true probabilities of their games. The story is illustrated with humorous pencil drawings.
Author: Jean Cushman

Title: Doctor Coyote: A Native American Aesop's Fables
Annotation: Shortly after Columbus came to the New World, a ship from Spain crossed the Atlantic carrying a book of Aesop's fables. The fables entered the Aztec world as trickster tales, and the Native American coyote became the chief character and trickster. The pen-and-ink watercolor illustrations evoke the modern Aztec culture, while the fables are from the 1500s.
Author: John Bierhorst

Title: Doctor De Soto
Annotation: Doctor De Soto, a mouse dentist who normally does not treat animals that are dangerous to mice, agrees to help a fox with a painful toothache. When the fox decides to eat the dentist and his wife despite their help, he is "outfoxed" by the mice. Black-line and watercolor drawings detail the humorous elements of this story.
Author: William Steig

Title: Dog Called Homeless, A
Annotation: Cally Fisher's mother has recently died, and her father and brother have withdrawn and don't communicate, as does Cally herself. But when the family moves from a house to an apartment, a large silver-gray dog starts hanging around. With the help of a homeless man named Jed; the dog, called Homeless; and a blind boy named Sam, Cally finally is able to communicate, heal, and bring the family together.
Author: Sarah Lean
Topic: Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health

Title: Dog of Discovery: A Newfoundland’s Adventures with Lewis and Clark
Annotation: This work of historical fiction provides details of the Lewis and Clark expedition, as witnessed by the Newfoundland dog Seaman, who accompanied the group. The story is told through the format of dated journal entries. Sketches from the Lewis and Clark expedition are included.
Author: Laurence P. Pringle

Title: Dog Who Sang at the Opera, The
Annotation: Pasha, a Russian wolfhound, is thrilled to be chosen as an extra in the festival scene of “Manon” at New York’s Metropolitan Opera House. On opening night, Pasha cannot resist singing along with the diva and has a moment of glory—but, much to her sadness, she is removed from the performance. Based on a real incident. Illustrated with watercolor and ink artwork.
Author: Jim West, Marshall Izen

Title: Dog Who Walked with God, The
Annotation: In this Kato Indian creation story, the familiar world emerges from empty, dark, and watery conditions. However, the newly created world is so lonely that even the Creator needs a companion - a dog - before setting foot here. Delicately realistic watercolors and detailed scenes illustrate the legend. California setting.
Author: Michael J. Rosen

Title: Dog-of-the-Sea-Waves
Annotation: Manu and his four brothers are the first humans to set foot on the Hawaiian Islands. The brothers plan to return to their old island home and bring their families and domestic animals back to make a new home. Manu does not like this plan until he befriends a sick Hawaiian monk seal, or as Manu calls him "Dog-of-the-Sea-Waves." Sequel to THE ISLAND-BELOW-THE-STAR. In English and Hawaiian.
Author: James Rumford

Title: Dolley Madison Saves George Washington
Annotation: During the War of 1812, Dolley Madison bravely rescued Gilbert Stuart’s life-size portrait of George Washington from the soon-to-be burned President’s Mansion when U.S. soldiers abandoned their post. Dolley stayed behind, even after the American soldiers fled. She dressed as a farm woman to get away and made sure the painting of Washington was safe. Illustrated with detailed watercolor artwork.
Author: Don Brown

Title: Don't Read This Book, Whatever You Do!
Annotation: Humorous short poems depict the ups and downs of school life. Many of the poems are based on the author's experiences as an elementary school teacher. See other books by this author/teacher.
Author: Kali Dakos

Title: Don't Talk to Me About the War
Annotation: Set in the Bronx (New York) in 1940, young Tommy has a routine: going to school, playing stickball, talking with his friend Beth, and listening to Brooklyn Dodgers games on the radio. When his mother becomes ill and he becomes more aware of the escalating war in Europe, his small, insular world is changed. An engaging work of historical fiction.
Author: David A. Adler

Title: Doña Flor: A Tall Tale About a Giant Woman with a Great Big Heart
Annotation: The very tall Doña Flor takes care of her village in the American Southwest by digging a river with her finger and making tortillas so large that five children use one as a raft. When a loud roar frightens the villagers, Doña Flor investigates and discovers a puma has amplified its small voice. The illustrations offer many opportunities to measure. On the last page, the puma falls asleep on Doña Flor’s big toe. Children can use ratio and proportion to estimate Flor’s height.
Author: Pat Mora
Award: Pura Belpre Illustration Winner, Pura Belpre Narrative Honor

Title: Donde viven los monstruos (Where the Wild Things Are)
Annotation: When Max gets in trouble and is sent to his room, his imagination changes the room into a forest near an ocean. In his boat he sails away to where the wild things are. He tames terrible monsters, is made their king, and romps with them, but he feels lonely. He wants someone who loves him best. He returns to his room and his hot supper.
Author: Maurice Sendak

Title: Doodler Doodling
Annotation: A little girl imagines on paper what will happen if she combines certain phrases. The quirky doodles created by illustrator Paul Zelinsky add character to the little girl and her story. Wonderful wordplay, drawings, and imagination make this a versatile story to share.
Author: Rita Golden Gelman
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Doorbell Rang, The
Annotation: When Ma makes a batch of cookies that look and smell like Grandma's, Sam and Victoria get ready to eat them. But every time they begin, the doorbell rings and friends come in to share the cookies. Will there be enough for everyone? This book's pattern makes it easy to read and provides good math practice for students. Watercolor illustrations by the author add to the dilemma and humor.
Author: Pat Hutchins

Title: Dot, The
Annotation: Vashti refuses to participate in art class until her art teacher challenges her to "just make a mark and see where it takes" her. Vashti makes an angry dot but after seeing it framed over her teacher's desk, vows she can do better. This little book encourages all of us to release the creative spirit that resides within.
Author: Peter H. Reynolds

Title: Dougal Dixon's Amazing Dinosaurs: The Fiercest, the Tallest, the Toughest, the Smallest
Annotation: Detailed dinosaur facts about meat-eaters, long-necked plant eaters, armored dinosaurs, and two-footed plant eaters are presented. Detailed drawings give clear and easy-to-follow information regarding the lives, habits, physiology, and cultures of these prehistoric animals.
Author: Dougal Dixon

Title: Down the Colorado: John Wesley Powell, the One-Armed Explorer
Annotation: A picture-book biography of John Wesley Powell, who traveled the length of the Colorado River over the course of 99 days in 1869, covering 1,000 miles and 500 rapids. This explorer and national hero lost his arm in the Civil War but never lost his determination to travel and explore. Episodes in Powell’s life are illustrated with full-page paintings and come from primary sources in the text.
Author: Deborah Kogan Ray
Topic: American History, Diversity, Geography, Immigration/Migration, Injury Prevention and Safety, Personal and Community Health

Title: Dr. Jenner and the Speckled Monster: The Search for the Smallpox Vaccine
Annotation: Marrin provides a detailed history of the deadly smallpox virus and chronicles Edward Jenner's efforts to discover a vaccine, a discovery that greatly impacted the world. Also discussed is the controversy surrounding the vials of frozen variola that were slated to be destroyed by December 31, 1993. This book is illustrated with black-and-white photographs.
Author: Albert Marrin

Title: Dragon Bones and Dinosaur Eggs: A Photobiography of Explorer Roy Chapman Andrews
Annotation: Explorer-adventurer, Roy Chapman Andrews, led five expeditions to the Gobi Desert to study the ecosystem. During these expeditions, he identified hundreds of previously unknown fossilized bones and living species of plants and animals, discovered that dinosaurs were egg layers, and pioneered modern paleontological field research. Andrews is introduced to the reader through the use of narrative text, photographs from his expeditions, and quotations from his writings. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Ann Bausum
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Dragon in the Sky: The Story of a Green Darner Dragonfly, A
Annotation: As a dragonfly migrates from New York to Florida, the reader learns fascinating details about its life cycle, feeding habits, amazing vision, and flying ability. The narrative text is engaging and packed with factual information. The watercolor and oil illustrations provide detailed and close-up views of the dragonflies and their development.
Author: Laurence P. Pringle

Title: Dragon’s Child: A Story of Angel Island, The
Annotation: In 1922, ten-year-old Gim Lew reluctantly leaves his village in China to accompany his father to America. Before departing, Gim must prepare for a grueling test to be given at California’s Angel Island, where strict officials strive to keep out unwanted immigrants. Includes facts about immigrating from China and the experiences of the author’s family. California author and California setting.
Author: Kathleen S. Yep, Laurence Yep

Title: Dragonwings
Annotation: In 1903 Moonshadow travels from a remote village in China to California to join his father, whom he has never seen. Despite tremendous difficulties and disasters, father and son struggle to build a life in San Francisco, working toward their dream of creating a dragon-like flying machine. California author and setting.
Author: Laurence Yep

Title: Drawing from Memory
Annotation: In the form of an album, Allen Say tells the story of his apprenticeship to a master cartoonist during World War II and the hard work he undertook after the war. Art was not considered an honorable profession, and Say describes how he chose to pursue his career at age thirteen even though his father disapproved of the path. Illustrated with panels, drawings, and paintings done in graphic-novel style. Honors and recognition: ALA Notable Children’s Book 2012; Notable Book for a Global Society 2012; Sibert Honor 2012.
Author: Allen Say
Topic: Diversity, Lifestyles Around the World, Visual Arts, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Winner

Title: Dream Something Big: The Story of the Watts Towers
Annotation: This is the story of the design and building of the Watts Towers in Los Angeles and of the builder, Simon Rodia, who was known as Uncle Sam. The story is told through the voice of a young girl who assists Uncle Sam in finding glass, tiles, and materials for his sculptures. As the Towers continue to rise, the young girl grows up and brings her own children to see the structure. Illustrated with collage artwork. Includes a double-page photograph of the Towers, an author’s note, and directions for creating a model of the Watts Towers.
Author: Dianna Hutts Aston

Title: Dreaming Up: A Celebration of Building
Annotation: This collection of poetry, illustrations, and photographs celebrates the works of children in spontaneous play, shaping and designing houses with a variety of materials—such as blankets, pillows, sticks, tubes, cardboard boxes, Legos, and mud pies. Facing pages mirror each design with a comparable (and notable) architectural structure from around the world. Each architect and model appears in a gallery afterword. This book explores the surprising ways in which childhood experiences can explode into the dreams and works of innovative architects.
Author: Christy Hale
Classification: Concept Book, Photo Essay, Picture Book

Title: Drinking Gourd: A Story of the Underground Railroad, The
Annotation: Tommy, the son of an Underground Railroad conductor, deliberately misleads the marshal and his posse in order to help his father lead an African American family to Canada, where they will find their first taste of freedom. This I Can Read selection is set in mid-nineteenth-century America.
Author: F. N. Monjo

Title: Drip! Drop! How Water Gets to Your Tap
Annotation: The water cycle, including evaporation and condensation, is explained by JoJo and her dog Willy. They describe how the water from the rivers, oceans, and lakes actually makes it into your house and through the faucet. The book is illustrated with cartoonlike color artwork with dialogue balloons.
Author: Barbara Seuling
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Drop in My Drink: The Story of Water on Our Planet, The
Annotation: The history of water on Earth is poetically told with reference to its importance to the formation and continuation of life. Full-color paintings brilliantly complement the text on the trip through time showing rain forests, oceans, and swampy landscapes. Included is information on the water cycle and water facts.
Author: Meredith Hooper

Title: Drop of Water: A Book of Science and Wonder
Annotation: This nonfiction selection illustrates the properties of water in its various states - ice, steam, frost, dew, and rainbow - and supplies basic explanations of related scientific terms and phenomena, including capillary attraction and surface tension. Stop-action color photographs and clear close-ups dramatize the presentation.
Author: Walter Wick

Title: Drumbeat in Our Feet
Annotation: A journey into the deeply rooted traditions, artistry, and energetic spirit that make up the world of African dance. Watercolor-and-pencil illustrations depict traditional dances and modern-day children learning the steps. The book includes a map of Africa and a pronunciation guide for African words.
Author: Patricia A. Keeler
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.3

Title: Ducks!
Annotation: This book describes the two kinds of ducks, diving ducks and dabbling ducks. In well-crafted text this prolific science writer discusses their environment, life cycle, adaptations, and endangered status. Two of the ducks (the Blue-Winged Teal and the Pintail) have been incorrectly labeled on page 3 of the book.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Duel! Burr and Hamilton’s Deadly War of Words
Annotation: Examines the Burr–Hamilton duel that occurred on July 11, 1804: Vice President Aaron Burr and the former Secretary of the Treasury, Alexander Hamilton, used dueling pistols to settle their political grievances. This book gives a “child-friendly” account of the negative campaigning and divisive politics that led to the most famous duel in American history. Features ink, watercolor, and gouache illustrations.
Author: Dennis Brindell Fradin

Title: Duke Ellington: The Piano Prince and His Orchestra
Annotation: The career of this jazz musician and composer is recalled as he and his orchestra created music that was beyond categorization. This book explores Ellington's musical path from his Washington, D.C., childhood to his 1943 Carnegie Hall performance. Lyrical text is combined with oil-painted scratchboard drawings.
Author: Andrea Davis Pinkney
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Author Winner, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Winner

Title: Dunderheads, The
Annotation: A group of misfit students, each with a specialized talent, conspire to carry out revenge on their kid-hating and unsympathetic teacher, Miss Breakbone, who has confiscated a treasure from a boy nicknamed Junkyard. The students devise a plan to sneak into Miss Breakbone’s fortified home, reclaim the trinket, and in doing so, teach her a lesson. The book’s bright illustrations feature characters with very expressive faces. Readers in middle grades will enjoy this short novel.
Author: Paul Fleischman

Title: Dust to Eat: Drought and Depression in the 1930s
Annotation: A photographic chronicle of the 1930s focuses on the Depression and the dust storms that crippled the Great Plains. The author examines the effects of the twin disasters on American society and domestic policy.
Author: Michael L. Cooper

Title: E-mergency!
Annotation: This zany alphabet book features personified letters that live in a five-story house. E takes a spill coming down the stairs and is replaced by O, causing havoc with communication. The book is full of wordplay, puns, and jokes, and its cartoon-style illustrations have an abundance of visual detail. Endpapers include a graph that shows the frequency with which the letter E appears in the English language.
Author: Ezra Fields-Meyer, Tom Lichtenheld

Title: Each Kindness
Annotation: Maya comes to school dressed in shabby ragged clothes and becomes the outcast new girl in a diverse classroom. The story is narrated by Chloe who leads her clique in rejecting and bullying Maya as she tries again and again to win acceptance and friendship. Then Maya stops coming to school. When Chloe's teacher gives a lesson about how even small acts of kindness can change the world, Chloe is stung by the lost opportunity for friendship, and thinks about how much better it could have been if she'd shown a little kindness toward Maya.
Author: Jacqueline Woodson
Topic: Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Personal and Community Health

Title: Each Little Bird That Sings
Annotation: Comfort Snowberger is an undertaker’s daughter in a small Southern town. Consequently, she has a clear understanding of life and death. As accustomed to death and dying as she thinks she is, she is not prepared for the tragedy that strikes her family. The writing in this book is never morbid; rather, it celebrates life and is uplifting. The first-person narrative is enriched with the addition of letters, news reports, recipes, and lists such as the “Top Ten Tips for First-Rate Funeral Behavior.”
Author: Deborah Wiles
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health

Title: Each Orange Had 8 Slices: A Counting Book
Annotation: This book offers children the opportunity to count as high as 54, provides practice in addition, and provides the chance to grasp the concept of multiplication. The bright graphics are laid out in double-page spreads supporting the concepts that are introduced.
Author: Paul Giganti, Jr.
Classification: Concept Book, Counting Book, Picture Book
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Number Sense

Title: Eagle Boy: A Pacific Northwest Tale
Annotation: A Pacific Northwest tale about an orphan Native American boy who, with the help of his friends, the majestic eagles, saves his village from starvation. With rich illustrations drawn from different perspectives, this story shows how an outcast can become a hero. Useful for study of California’s coastal regions.
Author: Richard Lee Vaughan

Title: Eagle's Song: A Tale from the Pacific Northwest, The
Annotation: After Ermine's brothers disappear, Eagle teaches him a dance that he passes on to his people. Detailed drawings of the Indians of the Northwest, their dress, their houses, and their motifs enhance this tale of love and sharing.
Author: Kristina Rodanas

Title: Earth Dragon Awakes: The San Francisco Earthquake of 1906, The
Annotation: Eight-year-old Henry and nine-year-old Chin love to read about heroes in popular “penny dreadful” novels, until they both witness real courage while trying to survive the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. The story is told through short chapters that are headlined with a timeline of the events of the earthquake. The afterword provides factual background information, an extensive bibliography, and archival photos. California author.
Author: Laurence Yep
Topic: American History, Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Immigration/Migration, Linguistics and Second Language Acquisition

Title: Earth Is My Mother, The
Annotation: Set in the canyons of the Southwest, this story shows how the dedication of one young girl can make a difference in the world. By following clues from a dream and taking photographs of endangered wilderness areas, eleven-year-old Sarah and a Native American environmentalist try to prevent the commercial development of a canyon. This beautifully illustrated novel connects geography, nature, the Cahuilla Indians, and an encounter with a mountain lion to make a perfect read-aloud for stirring the imagination and students’ can-do spirit.
Author: Elise Maclay
Topic: American History, Diversity, Economics, Geography, Government and Politics

Title: Earthdance
Annotation: A celebratory poem asks readers to imagine themselves as the earth, turning in space, facing the light, and feeling the green things growing and the oceans shifting. “Wiggle your shoulders / and mountains tremble and quake. Shake your hair and feel windswept grasses tickle your face.” A well-designed book with colorful artwork and careful placement of text.
Author: Joanne Ryder
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.2

Title: Earthmates: Poems
Annotation: This is a collection of 35 poems about creatures that roam the land. A variety of forms, including rhyme, free verse, and concrete poems contribute to the playfulness of this book. The book is illustrated with realistic watercolor paintings that highlight details of each animal.
Author: Patricia Hubbell

Title: Earthquakes
Annotation: This book examines the phenomena of earthquakes, describing how and where they occur. It also provides information on how earthquakes are detected and measured. Several major earthquakes are discussed as well as the damage that occurred. The striking photographs support the narrative text. This is one of a series of science books by this author.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Earthquakes
Annotation: This informative overview of the causes and detection of earthquakes uses photographs, colorful diagrams, quotes from eyewitnesses, and excerpts from news accounts of earthquakes to support the text. Subduction zones, seismic waves, fault lines, plate tectonics, shock waves, landslides, tsunamis, and earthquake prediction are discussed. Details about well-known earthquakes and their devastation are included throughout the book to illustrate specific concepts. Other titles in the Restless Planet series include FLOODS, STORMS, and VOLCANOES.
Author: Mark Maslin

Title: Earthquakes
Annotation: The clear, concise text of this book is full of fun facts and captivating illustrations. The dynamic illustrations give young readers a sense of the motion created when an earthquake occurs. The last part of the book presents a simple activity that simulates an earthquake through the use of a pan of sand. A great read-aloud book that will keep budding geologists engaged, this is a part of the Jump into Science series.
Author: Ellen J. Prager

Title: Earthshake: Poems from the Ground Up
Annotation: Twenty-two lively, creative poems are accompanied by colorful collage illustrations to celebrate the wonders of geology. The author highlights the unique features of the Earth including how the coasts of South America and Africa seem to fit together like a puzzle piece. Endnotes provide brief scientific and geographic information on the topic of each poem. Subjects covered include geodes, layers of the earth, continental drift, sedimentary rock formation, volcanoes, glaciers, erosion, plate tectonics, minerals, and fossils.
Author: Lisa Westberg Peters

Title: Earthsong: Based on Rogers's Popular Song "Over in the Endangered Meadow"
Annotation: Endangered animals are introduced through brilliant paintings and rhyming lyrics borrowed from the folk song "Over in the Meadow." The offerings include mammals, birds and reptiles from around the world. At the end are notes on the animals and musical notation for the song.
Author: Sally Rogers

Title: Earthsteps: A Rock's Journey Through Time
Annotation: A chunk of granite perched high on a mountaintop is dislodged and begins a 250 million year odyssey during which geologic forces transform it into a grain of sand in a sandstone rock ready to repeat the cycle. As it passes through the Triassic and Jurassic periods, the plant and animal life around it is highlighted. It contains a geologic time scale, a glossary, and a bibliography.
Author: Diane Spickert

Title: Eclipse, El (The Eclipse)
Annotation: A child from Mexico discovers the mysteries of an eclipse by using the scientific process. The well-designed book is simple to read in a unique horizontal format. Culturally diverse illustrations will be attractive to reluctant readers.
Author: Miguel Gongora Izquierdo

Title: Eco-Women: Protectors of the Earth
Annotation: The author describes the lives of famous women who worked to protect certain animals and their habitat. Included are Jane Goodall, who dedicated her life's work to saving and learning about chimpanzees; Wangari Maathai who spearheaded a movement to plant thousands of trees and other plants in Africa; and Barbara Kerr who invented a way to provide clean water to developing nations.
Author: Willow Ann Sirch

Title: Edgar Allan Poe’s Pie: Math Puzzlers in Classic Poems
Annotation: Author J. Patrick Lewis has rewritten 14 classic poems to present humorous and challenging math problems. Each poem features a poet, a parody of a featured poem, and a story problem. Answers are located at the bottom of each page. The last two pages of the book provide biographical information about the featured poets, including sketches of each writer. California illustrator Michael Slack’s full-page illustrations were created with Photoshop. Teachers may have students solve the problems and present the original poems.
Author: J. Patrick Lewis
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing, Mathematics
Standard: Math 3.MP.1-8, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.NF.1-7, Math 5.MP.1-8

Title: Edgar Degas: Paintings That Dance
Annotation: Written as a report by a fictitious student, this biography profiles the life and artwork of Edgar Degas. Insights into the life of Degas, along with a child’s drawings and reproductions of Degas’ work, are presented in this unique format. An entertaining blend of fact and humor.
Author: Maryann Cocca-Leffler
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Egg, The
Annotation: This brief, often playful examination of the mythology, legends, evolution, and biology of eggs is presented through short facts accompanied by large, colorful illustrations. The book also introduces egg-laying animals and the adaptations they have made to protect their eggs.
Author: Shelley Gill

Title: Egypt Game, The
Annotation: Six children of different ethnic backgrounds secretly play a game built on their own imagination and their fascination with ancient Egypt. The Egypt Game helps to solve one girl's personal problems and leads to the capture of a murderer. California author.
Author: Zilpha Keatley Snyder

Title: Eight Hands Round: A Patchwork Alphabet
Annotation: The letters of the alphabet are introduced with the names of early American patchwork quilt patterns. The origins of the designs, which were named by pioneers, are explained.
Author: Ann Whitford Paul

Title: El béisbol nos salvó (Baseball Saved Us)
Annotation: A Japanese American boy learns to play baseball when he and his family are relocated to a desert internment camp during World War II. The game of baseball allows him to endure the prejudice that he also encountered after the war. The book includes rich, figurative language (similes and metaphors) and is a Spanish translation of BASEBALL SAVED US.
Author: Ken Mochizuki
Topic: American History, Diversity, Global Historical Events and Figures, Immigration/Migration, War, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products
Discipline: History/Social Science, Physical Education, World Language

Title: El canto de las palomas (Calling the Doves)
Annotation: The author describes the first eight years of his life as the son of migrant workers in the fields of California. The story is told in bilingual text from a small boy's perspective showing the influences that both his parents had on his career as a poet. The vivid illustrations will attract young readers. California author and illustrator.
Author: Juan Felipe Herrera

Title: El chino (The Matador)
Annotation: This book relates, in picture-book format, the inspiring life story of Arizona-born Billy Wong, the first Chinese bullfighter. The full-page watercolors are sepia-toned prior to Billy's attendance at a bull fight in Spain. The illustrations become infused with color and action as he transforms himself into "El Chino," the matador! California author/illustrator.
Author: Allen Say

Title: El cochinito de Carlota (Charlotte's Piggy Bank)
Annotation: Carlota dreams of the many ways she could use the money saved in her piggy bank. She thinks of creative ways of raising money to fill it up, like selling her toys, helping neighbors, and doing chores at home. But Carlota discovers that the piggy bank has a mind of its own and soon learns an important life lesson.
Author: David McKee

Title: El cuento del conejo y el coyote (The Tale of Rabbit and Coyote)
