Annotation: In this humorous retelling of a Zapotec Indian folktale from Oaxaca, Mexico, Rabbit outwits Coyote in a story reminiscent of Brer Rabbit. The trickster rabbit escapes to the moon to avoid the coyote's revenge. The text contains some Spanish phrases, which are defined in a glossary. Tommie dePaola's vibrant full-page color illustrations are done in a Mexican folk-art style. California author.
Author: Tony Johnston

Title: El Deafo
Annotation: This funny and touching memoir in graphic-novel format traces the childhood of the author as she learns to use the "superpowers" of her self-proclaimed alter ego, El Deafo, to deal with the challenges of hearing loss. Her feelings of isolation and of simply wanting to fit in are explored through engaging illustrations and authentic interactions, drawing readers in to the story of Cece's journey.
Author: Cece Bell
Topic: Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Growth, Development, and Sexual Health, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health

Title: El dia que la boa de Jimmy se comio la ropa (The Day Jimmy's Boa Ate the Wash)
Annotation: On a field trip to the farm, Jimmy's boa gets loose and causes havoc. The humorous telling of this story is enhanced by the illustrator's detailed watercolor and black-line drawings.
Author: Trinka Hakes Noble

Title: El dueno de los animales (The Owner of the Animals)
Annotation: This collection of fine stories is about hunters from the northeastern region of Argentina. A glossary aids understanding of numerous Argentine regionalisms and the traditional beliefs and practices of the people.
Author: Jorge Accame

Title: El espiritu de Tio Fernando: una historia Del Dia de los muertos (Spirit of Tio Fernando: A Day of the Dead Story)
Annotation: In this bilingual story Fernando and his mother celebrate The Day of the Dead with their friends and family. His uncle died several years ago, and Fernando is concerned about reconnecting with his uncle's spirit. Through this special celebration he is able to remember him. Children can learn about the traditions associated with this special custom.
Author: Janice Levy

Title: El fantastico viaje del gato Cameron (The Wonderful Journey of Cameron Cat)
Annotation: Cameron the cat is too curious for his own good! His owner, Ana, does everything she can to keep him out of trouble, but her efforts are futile. Cameron causes a disaster in a moving van, gobbles down a family's picnic, and gets lost in the woods. The full-page color illustrations capture the excitement of Cameron's misadventures and add humor.
Translator: Gemma Gallart. Barcelona: Grupo Editorial Ceac/Tim
Author: Marjorie Newman

Title: El gigante egoista (The Selfish Giant)
Annotation: Wilde's well-known allegory about a selfish giant who becomes good when he befriends a young child is presented in this Spanish rendition of an English title. The full-page, pastel watercolors perfectly complement this tale of caring and love.
Author: Oscar Wilde

Title: El lugar mas bonito del mundo (The Most Beautiful Place in the World)
Annotation: Seven-year-old Juan lives with his grandmother in a remote village in the mountains of Guatemala. Juan must overcome many hardships in order to appreciate the beauty of the world around him. Told in simple first-person narrative.
Author: Ann Cameron

Title: El maravilloso viaje de Alejandro (Alexander's Little Journey)
Annotation: Alejandro can't decide what to do one rainy Sunday afternoon until his teddy bear suggests a boat trip. On their journey Alejandro and his teddy bear meet a strong whale, a kind tiger, and an angry pirate. The full-page watercolor illustrations make this fantasy a warm and entertaining book to read.
Author: Gisela Mehren

Title: El Nino: Stormy Weather for People and Wildlife
Annotation: This book analyzes the weather phenomenon of the El Nino current and the effects on people and wildlife. The readable and informative text is accompanied by full-color photographs and diagrams. A listing of other resources and Web site addresses is included.
Author: Caroline Arnold

Title: El osito usado (Used-Up Bear)
Annotation: Clara loves very much her old, shabby teddy bear, Osito. She makes him a new red flannel suit to look fashionable. The delicate line-and-watercolor illustrations are as clean and focused as in the original English edition.
Author: Clay Carmichael

Title: El pequeno conejo blanco (The Little White Rabbit)
Annotation: This cumulative Portuguese tale is about a little white rabbit who goes in search of cabbage to make soup but encounters a mean goat. Fortunately, a brave little ant helps solve the problem.
Author: Xose Ballesteros (adapter)

Title: El regalo magico (The Magic Shell)
Annotation: When Jaime Ramos moves to New York City from his mountain village in the Dominican Republic, life changes dramatically. Jaime feels loneliness and loss but also the challenges of new opportunities.
Author: Nicholasa Mohr

Title: El reino del reves (The Flip-Flop Kingdom)
Annotation: These charming rhymes tell about a slow-eating crocodile, a happy moon, a fishing cat, and a little girl and her collection of treasures that nobody wants.
Author: Maria Elena Walsh

Title: El soldadito de plomo (The Little Tin Soldier)
Annotation: This updated version of the brave little soldier by master Danish storyteller, Hans Christian Andersen, is a story of sacrifice and love.
Author: Hans Christian Andersen, Joseph Lluch (adapter)

Title: El traje nuevo del emperador (The Emperor's New Clothes)
Annotation: Two mischievous weavers convince the emperor they are making him beautiful new clothes, visible only to those fit for their posts, but when he wears them during a royal procession, a child recognizes that the emperor has nothing on. This edition is retold by 23 celebrities, and illustrated by 23 world-renown artists.
Author: Hans Christian Andersen

Title: Eleanor
Annotation: Eleanor Roosevelt's childhood is retold in storybook format. The story depicts her early childhood and how she developed self-confidence with the help of a boarding-school headmistress.
Author: Barbara Cooney

Title: Eleanor, Quiet No More: The Life of Eleanor Roosevelt
Annotation: Describes the transformation of Eleanor Roosevelt’s life: from an unhappy childhood to an adulthood where she becomes her own person and stands against injustice, believing that all people are entitled to dignity and equal protection under the law. Each two-spread gives a brief retelling of a significant event in her life and a quotation accompanied by a subdued pastel illustration. Author and illustrator notes, important dates, research sources, and related Web sites appear in the book’s final pages. This biography may be used to celebrate significant women in history.
Author: Doreen Rappaport
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures, Women’s Studies
Standard: HSS K.6, HSS 1.4, HSS 2.1, HSS 2.5, HSS 3.4

Title: Electric Ben: The Amazing Life and Times of Benjamin Franklin
Annotation: Benjamin Franklin (1706-1790) has been described as wise, funny, and always curious. He was a printer, inventor, statesman, ambassador, scientist, and electrical wizard. The pages pulse with facts, quotes, and captions, while the inventive design and intricately detailed illustrations make a striking tribute to the brilliant American.
Author: Robert Byrd
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures, Government and Politics, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Elena’s Serenade
Annotation: In Mexico, a little girl who wishes to be a glassblower is rebuked by her father, who says, “Who ever heard of a girl glassblower?” Undeterred, the girl disguises herself as a boy and lands a position as an apprentice, and along the way she gains confidence. Brightly illustrated with acrylic and crayon artwork.
Author: Campbell Geeslin
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Topic: Visual Arts, Women’s Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3

Title: Elephant in the Garden, An
Annotation: Lizzie, now in a Canadian nursing home, recalls her youth when her mother worked in the Dresden Zoo during World War II. Her mother’s special charge was a baby elephant that she brought home to avoid a mandate that large and potentially dangerous animals be destroyed. The family and the baby elephant set off to escape the city when the bombs begin to fall. The author’s notes describe the true events on which the book is based. See also Morpurgo’s WAR HORSE (1982) and a picture book for older readers, THE FAITHFUL ELEPHANTS (1988) by Yukio Tsuchiya.
Author: Michael Morpurgo
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, War

Title: Elephant Quest
Annotation: This adventure recounts the authors' travels in Botswana culminating in the sighting of an African elephant herd. Sketches and full-page watercolor paintings blend science and art, and provide a background for the insights into the behavior of a variety of animals in this grassland habitat. Two pages of elephant facts, an introductory map, and an index are included.
Author: Betsy Lewin, Ted Lewin

Title: Elephant Quilt: Stitch by Stitch to California, The
Annotation: When people headed west during the great migration of the mid-nineteenth century, they often said, “We're going to see the Elephant!”—meaning they were going to have a huge adventure. While Lily Rose and her family travel in a wagon train from Missouri to California in 1859, Lily Rose and Grandma stitch a quilt of their adventures. Inspired by an actual quilt sewn by Mary Margaret Hezlep in 1859, this picture book has bold illustrations filled with bits of quilt patterns and mixed-media paintings. Includes an author’s note, map, and sources.
Author: Susan Lowell
Topic: American History, Immigration/Migration, Visual Arts, Women’s Studies

Title: Elephant Scientist, The
Annotation: Recounts the author’s experiences of observing African elephants in their natural habitat and documenting a groundbreaking discovery about elephant communication: elephants can sense vibrations through their feet. Captioned, full-color photographs illustrate this addition to the “Scientists in the Field” series. Concludes with recommended books, DVDs, and Web sites; a glossary; and selected source notes.
Author: Caitlin O’Connell, Donna M. Jackson

Title: Elephant's Child, The
Annotation: This classic tale tells how the elephant got its trunk. Notable for the rhyme and rhythm of its language, the story provides a good model for students' writing. It is available in paperback only.
Author: Rudyard Kipling

Title: Elephants Can Paint, Too!
Annotation: An artist teaches Asian elephants to paint and raises funds and awareness for their plight as endangered animals. Historical facts and statistics about elephants inform and educate the reader and tell of the long relationship people have had with this intelligent animal. The straightforward narrative is illustrated with full-color photographs and features large, multicolored text.
Author: Katya Arnold
Culture: Cambodian/Cambodian American, East Indian/East Indian American
Standard: LS 1.2, LS 2.2, VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3

Title: Eleven
Annotation: When Sam celebrates his eleventh birthday, he can still barely read. Sam lives with his grandfather, whom he dearly loves, but something tells him that this may not be where he belongs. Distant memories and an old newspaper clipping nag at him day and night. With Caroline, a sympathetic friend from school, Sam gathers more information about his past. Together they work on a woodworking project that not only reveals more about Sam’s past and brings meaning to true friendship, but also brings to light Sam’s giftedness as a woodworker.
Author: Patricia Reilly Giff

Title: Eleventh Hour: A Curious Mystery, The
Annotation: Horace the elephant planned his eleventh birthday party with 11 games and 11 kinds of food to be eaten at eleven o’clock. While the guests are playing games, all the food disappears. Each detailed illustration offers some clues to help break the code that will solve the mystery. Solutions are provided in a sealed section at the end of the book. Children will enjoy looking for the mice that are hidden in each picture.
Author: Graeme Base

Title: Elijah's Angel: A Story for Chanukah and Christmas
Annotation: Young Michael worries about how his parents will feel if he brings home a Christmas angel that his friend Elijah has carved for him. He makes a menorah for Elijah and learns that friendship transcends religion. This is a story about Elijah Pierce, a renowned wood-carver.
Author: Michael J. Rosen
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Eliza Bing is (not) a Big, Fat Quitter
Annotation: After learning she cannot take a cake decorating class with her best friend, partly because her parents consider her a quitter, eleven-year-old Eliza tries to prove herself by sticking with a taekwondo class all summer.
Author: Carmella Van Vleet
Award: California Young Reader Medal, Christopher Award

Title: Elizabeth Leads the Way: Elizabeth Cady Stanton and the Right to Vote
Annotation: Tells of the life and achievements of the nineteenth-century women’s rights activist who fought for women’s voting rights. It begins with Stanton’s shocking realization of the law’s unfair treatment of women, especially regarding the right to vote. Describes the origins of the women’s rights movement and the effect of the Women’s Rights Conference in Seneca Falls, New York. The brief text is enhanced with full-page artwork.
Author: Tanya Lee Stone

Title: Elizabeth’s Song
Annotation: A fictionalized story inspired by the real life of African American folk musician Elizabeth Cotten. Young Elizabeth’s love of music is so strong that she teaches herself to play her older brother Louis’s guitar, left-handed and upside down. When he leaves home for a better life in the North, she works hard to earn enough money to buy her own guitar. At age eleven, she writes her first song, “Freight Train,” inspired by Louis’s departure on train Number 9. Descriptive language allows the reader to visualize the scenes. Illustrated with soft, realistic watercolor artwork. An epilogue provides factual information about Cotten.
Author: Michael Wenberg

Title: Ella Enchanted
Annotation: This fairy tale adaptation presents Ella (Cinderella) with a very unusual problem. A gift from one of her godmothers was obedience, and now Ella's life is miserable because she must follow every command, even if it is contrary to her wishes. When a young prince appears, Ella hopes that he can help her break the spell that holds her.
Author: Gail Carson Levine
Award: California Young Reader Medal, Newbery Honor

Title: Ella Fitzgerald: The Tale of a Vocal Virtuosa
Annotation: Ella's inspiring story is told in the voice of Scat Cat Monroe, a feline fan whose imagined narrative sings with infectious scat rhythms. The dramatic perspectives of the fantastical scratchboard illustrations offer jazzy improvisations of their own.
Author: Andrea Davis Pinkney
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary
Standard: HSS K.6, VAPA M PreK-12.3, HSS 2.5

Title: Ellen’s Broom
Annotation: Set during the Reconstruction period of the United States, this story tells of a young girl who gains a greater understanding of her heritage and of freedom when laws change and her parents are able to register legally as husband and wife. Previously, her parents marked their union with a broom wedding, which brought little security as slave families could be separated and sold at the whim of their master. Illustrated with linoleum block prints.
Author: Kelly Starling Lyons

Title: Ellie’s Chance to Dance
Annotation: After moving from Chicago to Oxford, England, ten-year-old Ellie worries about making new friends at school and caring for her mother (who has multiple sclerosis) while also preparing to audition for the resident dancers training program at London’s Royal Ballet School. Ellie shares her thoughts through diary entries interspersed throughout the narrative.
Author: Alexandra Moss
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.5, VAPA T PreK-12.3

Title: Ellington Was Not a Street
Annotation: Ntozake Shange presents an illustrated poem in which she recalls growing up in the company of W.E.B. Du Bois, Dizzy Gillespie, Paul Robeson, and other great African American men who were instrumental in changing American culture and society.
Author: Ntozake Shange
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Ellis Island: Doorway to Freedom
Annotation: Between 1892 and 1954, more than 16 million immigrants were processed on Ellis Island in upper New York Bay. This book is a pictorial history of the island from the 1600s to the present day, as people now come to tour the Ellis Island Immigration Museum. The succinct text is enhanced by photolike illustrations rendered in pencil and watercolor. A glossary and index make this book a nice beginning research tool.
Author: Steven Kroll

Title: Emma Dilemma: Big Sister Poems
Annotation: Jessica, a fourth-grader, has a dilemma centering on her daily interactions with her three-year-old sister. It is a situation that will not go away anytime soon. This heartwarming series of 34 poems captures the complicated relationship between the sisters: the moments of annoyance that shift to ones of tenderness and humor. The brief text and the expressive pen-and-ink illustrations reflect the range of emotions of each character. California author.
Author: Kristine O’Connell George

Title: Emma Jean Lazarus Fell Out of a Tree
Annotation: Emma-Jean Lazarus is the smartest and strangest girl at William Gladstone Middle School. Her classmates don't understand her, but that's okay because Emma-Jean doesn't quite get them either. But one afternoon, all that changes when she sees Colleen Pomerantz crying in the girl's room. It is through Colleen that Emma-Jean gets a glimpse into what it is really like to be a seventh grader. And what she finds will send her tumbling out of a tree and questioning why she ever got involved in the first place.
Author: Lauren Tarshis
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health

Title: Emma's Christmas: An Old Song
Annotation: A farm girl is courted by a prince who presents her with gifts of the twelve days of Christmas, finally winning her and moving to the farm. Children can look for the number patterns of gifts each day and can compute the number of gifts she received. Full-color illustrations enhance the story.
Author: Irene Trivas

Title: Emma’s Journal: The Story of a Colonial Girl
Annotation: From 1774 to 1776, Emma, a serving girl, describes in her journal her stay in Boston at the dawn of the American Revolution. She witnesses the British blockade and becomes a spy for the American militia. Features hand-printed text, drawings, and notes in the margins.
Author: Marissa Moss

Title: Emperor and the Nightingale, The
Annotation: This folktale retells the story of an emperor who desires eternal life but slowly learns that some things are worth more than his wish to live forever.
Author: Kuang-Ts’ai Hao (reteller)

Title: Emperor's Egg, The
Annotation: This informational text describes the harsh habitat and life cycle of the Emperor penguin, stressing the protective role of the father in caring for the eggs. Acrylic paintings in a realistic style bring the book to life. This selection is an excellent choice for habitat studies in science and includes an index of ideas and information for developing readers.
Author: Martin Jenkins
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Empress and the Silkworm, The
Annotation: This fictionalized account explores the Empress of China's discovery that the cocoons in her mulberry trees produce shiny, silken thread that can be woven into beautiful cloth. The book's stylized art depicts life in China around 2700 B.C.
Author: Lily Toy Hong

Title: Empty Pot, The
Annotation: Ping, a Chinese boy, can grow the most wonderful flowers. The emperor, looking for a successor, gives a seed to each child to find out who can grow the most beautiful flower. Ping carefully plants and tends his seed, but nothing sprouts. The small, detailed watercolor illustrations reflect the Asian setting of this story, good for starting discussions on truth and courage.
Author: - Demi

Title: En mi familia (In My Family)
Annotation: Using vivid paintings, the author tells memories of celebrations and her childhood experiences growing up in Texas near the Mexican border.
Author: Carmen Lomas Garza

Title: Encounter
Annotation: An imagined encounter between a young Taino boy of San Salvador and Christopher Columbus and his crew is presented in this book. The young boy describes the strange appearance of the creatures from the "great-sailed canoes" and tries to warn his people against welcoming them. The dramatic acrylic paintings help to convey the consequences of embracing other cultures at the expense of one's own. The author's and illustrator's notes offer historical perspectives. California illustrator.
Author: Jane Yolen

Title: Encuentro (Encounter)
Annotation: An imagined encounter between a young Taino boy of San Salvador and Christopher Columbus and his crew is presented in this book. The young boy describes the strange appearance of the creatures from the "great-sailed canoes" and tries to warn his people against welcoming them. The dramatic acrylic paintings help to convey the consequences of embracing other cultures at the expense of one's own. The author's and illustrator's notes offer historical perspectives. California illustrator.
Author: Jane Yolen

Title: Energy Island: How One Community Harnessed the Wind and Changed Their World
Annotation: The true story of how the people on the Danish island of Samso gained energy independence by eliminating their use of fossil fuels. Within a 10-year period, the islanders reduced their carbon footprint by 140 percent, using renewable resources such as wind power, solar energy, biomass furnaces, and electric cars. Sidebars explain the science. Ink-and-watercolor illustrations depict the windy conditions on the island.
Author: Allan Drummond

Title: Energy Makes Things Happen
Annotation: Science concepts are effectively explained in simple language and humorous illustrations. The author begins with simple examples of different types of energy, introduces the concepts of storage and transference of energy, and then covers various aspects of energy: wind, types of fuels, food, solar power, and the formation of fossil fuels. The concluding text offers suggestions for simple experiments using toy cars and a reasoning game requiring students to think about the origins of energy. This book is a part of the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out Science series.
Author: Kimberly Brubaker Bradley

Title: Equal Shmequal
Annotation: After watching children play tug-of-war, mouse invites his animal friends to try the game. After the first few tries, the animals decide that the teams need to be equal, but they have difficulty figuring out how to do that. After many tries, they finally decide to make the teams equal in weight and use the seesaw to make the teams equal—but then they find it is the effort that counts. This story could be used to introduce the concept of equations.
Author: Virginia Kroll
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Mathematical Reasoning

Title: Eric Carle's Animals Animals
Annotation: This illustrated collection of poems by a variety of authors describes the peculiarities of pets, wild, and domestic animals. Carle's collage illustrations are created from hand-textured tissue paper. It includes an index of animals as well as an index of first lines.
Author: Laura Whipple (compiler)
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, Science

Title: Erie Canal, The
Annotation: An introduction to America’s first great public-works project, this book combines period prints and photographs with a well-written account of the Erie Canal’s origins, construction, uses, and folklore. Provides detailed descriptions and stories about life along the canal. The engaging text includes humor as well as facts.
Author: Martha E. Kendall

Title: Esa immensa galaxia (The Gobsmacking Galaxy)
Annotation: This book includes information about the Big Bang, formation of the galaxy, planets, and stars. It gives basic information about space and is very readable. It includes simple, short activities.
Author: Kjartan Poskitt

Title: Esas endiabladas mates (The Essential Arithmetricks)
Annotation: The operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division are explained in a humorous and engaging manner. Poskitt has a talent for writing silly yet informative tales that integrate important mathematical concepts.
Author: Kjartan Poskitt
Standard: Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 5.OA.1-3, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 6.NS.1-8, Math 6.EE.1-9

Title: Esas insignificantes fracciones (The Mean and Vulgar Bits)
Annotation: This is a delightful explanation of fractions and how they are used in everyday life. Humor is used to motivate the reader and the black-and-white cartoonlike drawings are spread throughout to illustrate fraction concepts. This is a great book for all young mathematicians. See other books in the Esa Horrible Ciencia (Horrible Science) series.
Author: Kjartan Poskitt

Title: Escape of Oney Judge: Martha Washington’s Slave Finds Freedom, The
Annotation: Oney Judge, a slave in the house of George and Martha Washington, is prevented from learning to read and write. When she learns she will be given away after her mistress’ death, she plans a daring escape and faces the challenges of life as a free African American during the colonial era. Bright watercolor-and-ink artwork brings visual interest to the story.
Author: Emily Arnold McCully

Title: Escape to the Forest: Based on a True Story of the Holocaust
Annotation: A young Jewish girl living in Lida, Poland, at the beginning of World War II recalls the horrors of life under the Russians and then under the Nazis. The family flees to join a partisan group whose mission is to save as many Jews as possible.
Author: Ruth Yaffe Radin

Title: Esperame Nina, voy contigo (Wait for Me, Nina, I'm Coming)
Annotation: Pedro has a new neighbor, Nina. He doesn't really want to play with a girl, but Nina has an adventurous spirit and they have exciting adventures. The Peninsular Spanish pronoun and inflected verbal forms may discourage Spanish-speaking adolescents from the Americas.
Author: Manuel Alfonseca

Title: Esperanza Rising
Annotation: This novel tells of a Mexican girl's fall from riches and her immigration to California in the 1930s. The story highlights her awareness of Mexico's post-revolution tensions, the rivalry with Oklahoma Dust Bowl victims, and struggles of Mexican workers trying to organize themselves to ask the U.S. government for better living conditions. California author and setting.
Author: Pam Munoz Ryan
Award: Newbery Honor, Pura Belpre Narrative Winner

Title: Even an Ostrich Needs a Nest: Where Birds Begin
Annotation: This nonfiction picture book focuses on the nesting habits and materials used by dozens of bird species. The book’s whimsical format includes curved text and clear, simple illustrations. The style and layout help make this already interesting material even more engaging.
Author: Irene Kelly

Title: Ever-Living Tree: The Life and Times of a Coast Redwood, The
Annotation: The growth of a coast redwood tree is followed from the time of Alexander the Great (325 BC) until it was felled by a lightning storm during the gold rush days in California (2,100 years later). A timeline and two-page paintings document major historical events happening as the tree grows. The text describes the tree's physical changes and symbiotic relationships with the animals of the region. California author and setting.
Author: Linda Vieira

Title: Everglades Forever: Restoring America's Great Wetland
Annotation: Every year Ms. Stone's class at Avocado Elementary school in Homestead, Florida studies the Everglades. The children take a field trip and learn about the endangered wildlife and environment and the efforts under way to save this great wetland. Bright, clear, and colorful photographs enhance the book.
Author: Trish Marx

Title: Every Thing on It: Poems and Drawings
Annotation: This collection of poetry and drawings presents many sides of poet Shel Silverstein: his humor, sensitivity, crudeness, seriousness, and wisdom. The poems were chosen by Silverstein’s family members from his personal collection. Readers who enjoyed Silverstein’s WHERE THE SIDEWALK ENDS (1974), A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC (1981), and FALLING UP (1996) will find this collection equally engaging.
Author: Shel Silverstein

Title: Everybody’s Revolution: A New Look at the People Who Won America’s Freedom
Annotation: This account focuses on the contributions of many individuals who participated in the Revolutionary War, including immigrants from all over the world, African Americans, Native Americans, and women. An open layout and clean, uncluttered pages make this a good choice for reference and research work.
Author: Thomas Fleming
Topic: American History, Diversity, War, Women’s Studies

Title: Everything on a Waffle
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Primrose lives in a small fishing village in British Columbia. She recounts her experiences and all that she learns about human nature and the unpredictability of life in the months after her parents are lost at sea.
Author: Polly Horvath

Title: Everywhere
Annotation: Afraid that his beloved grandfather will die after suffering a heart attack, a ten-year-old boy agrees to join eleven-year-old Dooley in performing a mysterious ritual called soul switching.
Author: Bruce Brooks

Title: Evolution of Calpurnia Tate, The
Annotation: Callie Tate is nearly twelve, and she is not happy with the limited options available to a young Southern girl living on a cotton plantation. Rather than spending time doing needlework or cooking, she prefers to be outdoors, experiencing nature, and wants to find her own voice. She is curious about two different grasshoppers and launches on a search for answers to her questions. This is a humorous and heartwarming tale.
Author: Jacqueline Kelly
Topic: American History, Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Life Science (Biology), Women’s Studies

Title: Exclamation Mark
Annotation: An exclamation mark tries to fit in with a group of quiet periods, but he doesn't really understand his purpose in life until he meets a nosy question mark. She simply won't stop asking questions until he commands her to "STOP!"
Author: Amy Krouse Rosenthal
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Exploding Ants: Amazing Facts About How Animals Adapt
Annotation: This book describes examples of animal behavior that may strike humans as disgusting, including the "gross" ways animals find food, shelter, and safety in the natural world. It describes the behavioral adaptation of organisms and is illustrated throughout with small, full-color photographs.
Author: Joanne Settel, Ph.D.

Title: Explora la tierra (Explore the Earth)
Annotation: This book provides a look at Earth using transparent overlays, fold-outs, and flaps. The illustrations are colorful and the text is easy to read. A variety of views of Earth including satellite photographs. Includes an index and a glossary. Other titles in this series include UN MILLION DE INSECTOS (A MILLION INSECTS) and TRAS LA PISTA DE LOS MAMIFEROS (TRACKING MAMMALS).
Author: Diane Costa de Beauregard

Title: Exploring Caves: Journeys into the Earth
Annotation: This book describes adventures exploring different types of caves such as in Greenland's ice cap, Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, underwater caves, and the Grand Canyon. It includes views of rock formations, the animals that live there, and describes efforts to take care of these geological wonders. A glossary and an index for student reference are included. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Nancy Holler Aulenbach
Illustrator: Hazel A. Bargon, Marfe Ferguson Delano

Title: Exploring Saturn
Annotation: This title features a well-organized and engaging text as well as many exceptionally clear, colorful Illustrations, photographs, space-telescope images, paintings, and drawings. It describes the exploration of Saturn, from the work of ancient astronomers to the latest NASA findings, and includes Web site resources and a location guide for conducting backyard observations.
Author: Dan Bortolotti
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Exploring the Deep, Dark Sea
Annotation: The crew of a deep-diving submersible craft travels from the sunlight zone to the abyss of the ocean ecosystem highlighting the changes in terrain and animal life. The narrative describes characteristics and the illustrations show the creatures in each zone. The submersible's functions and features are fully described through the text and pictures.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Extinct Files: My Science Project, The
Annotation: Wally's science project makes the claim that dinosaurs live today. The written project, presented in this picture book, tells of where dinosaurs live, what they eat, how they communicate, and how they play. The research project includes an objective, a hypothesis, apparatus, method, observation, and a conclusion. Word of the study reaches Headquarters D.I.A. (Dinosaur Intelligence Agency), and all dinosaurs are cautioned to stay out of sight or to wear disguises. When Wally turns in his report, only a page corner remains. He tells his teacher in a note that he thinks "the dinosaurs ate his homework." The illustrations are detailed, colorful, and amusing, and plays on words are abundant throughout the "report."
Author: Wallace Edwards

Title: Extra Credit
Annotation: Two gifted students correspond as pen pals: Abby lives in Illinois, and Sadeed lives in the mountains of Afghanistan. But things get complicated because Sadeed’s culture does not allow him to have contact with girls. This is a warm, humorous, and insightful school story that will keep readers turning the pages while providing a glimpse into a life that is very different from the ones lived by most young people in the United States. The book’s full-page pencil illustrations add to its appeal.
Author: Andrew Clements
Topic: Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Global Social Issues, Lifestyles Around the World

Title: Extraordinary Life: The Story of a Monarch Butterfly, An
Annotation: This concept book introduces the life cycle, feeding habits, migration, predators, and mating of the monarch butterfly through the observation of a monarch named Danaus. The book includes a chapter on how to raise these butterflies.
Author: Laurence P. Pringle

Title: Extraordinary Mark Twain (According to Susy), The
Annotation: Mark Twain’s thirteen-year-old daughter, Susy, kept a journal documenting her observations about her father’s home life and habits in order to “set the record straight.” Susy’s actual journal entries are tucked into the gutters of the book on small pages with her words and even misspellings kept intact. The book is illustrated with digital artwork. The author concludes with a guide to writing biographies.
Author: Barbara Kerley
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Winner

Title: Extreme Scientists: Exploring Nature’s Mysteries from Perilous Places
Annotation: Three scientists are described: a hurricane hunter, a microbiologist who explores caves, and a man who studies redwood trees from top to bottom. Each section describes early interests of the scientist and his or her career path. An interview with each scientist provides more information. Photographs bring the reader into the storm, the cave, and the treetop. The book concludes with a list of additional resources. Part of the “Scientists in the Field” series.
Author: Donna M. Jackson

Title: Eyes and Ears
Annotation: Readers can "get up close and personal" with the eye and ear, discover how each functions and malfunctions, and learn about the brain’s involvement in vision and hearing. Full-page color images capture the reader's attention and are accompanied by informational text. Interactive activities provide opportunities for enrichment.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Eyes of Gray Wolf, The
Annotation: In this short lyrical text Grey Wolf encounters a new mate after having lost his first mate in a trap set by humans. This story provides an accurate description of wolf behavior and has full-page illustrations. The author's note at the end contains additional information about wolf behavior, habitat, and addresses for students to write for more information.
Author: Jonathan  London

Title: Fables
Annotation: Twenty fables of animals in zany situations with wry morals are illustrated in Lobel's inimitable style. Detailed, colorful drawings support the individual fables.
Author: Arnold Lobel

Title: Fabrics of Fairytale: Stories Spun from Far and Wide, The
Annotation: Folktales from seven cultures are told using fabrics and woven materials as a storytelling vehicle. The story and artwork go hand-in-hand. The cultures included are Armenian, Swahili, Chinese, Hawaiian, Swedish, Jewish, and Indonesian. The border patterns are especially interesting as sewing materials are used to illustrate the stories.
Author: Tanya Robyn Batt (reteller)

Title: Fabulous! A Portrait of Andy Warhol
Annotation: Replicas of Andy Warhol’s paintings are incorporated into the textured oil-and-collage illustrations in this profile of Warhol’s art. Beginning in the 1930s in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, the story chronicles Warhol’s hard work and dedication to his art up to the height of his career in the 1960s. His triumphs over personal difficulties may inspire children who feel that they don’t fit in.
Author: Bonnie Christensen

Title: Face to Face with Gorillas
Annotation: Readers will learn about lowland gorillas living in eastern and central Africa and the threats to their existence. Close-up photographs provide a glimpse of what it would be like to be in proximity to these creatures. Award-winning photographer and author Michael “Nick” Nichols provides brief descriptions and photographs detailing the gorillas’ family structure, habits, habitats, and connections to humans. See other books in the “Face to Face with Animals” series.
Author: Elizabeth Carney, Michael Nichols

Title: Face to Face with Manatees
Annotation: Children will discover the mannerisms of the gentle manatee and learn about the fragile ecosystem in which the manatee lives. Readers will be captivated by the manatees’ playful, friendly ways. Full-color photographs and firsthand adventures reveal the underwater world of these creatures. The book will inspire young environmentalists to think about the need to protect ecosystems in order to maintain the diversity of living things. See other titles in the “Face to Face with Animals” series.
Author: Brian Skerry

Title: Fairy Tale Detectives: The Sisters Grimm, The
Annotation: As descendants of the Brothers Grimm, sisters Sabrina and Daphne Grimm are thrown into a world previously unknown to them. After their parents’ mysterious disappearance, they are sent to live with their Granny Relda and soon discover that all is not as it seems in the small town of Ferryport Landing. They are given the task of living up to their family’s detective lineage, searching for clues to save the town from ultimate destruction by a giant. This is a fast-paced story with familiar characters—for example, Prince Charming is now a corrupt politician, and the three little pigs are now policemen. First book in “The Sisters Grimm” series.
Author: Michael Buckley

Title: Fairy's Mistake
Annotation: This retelling of the Perrault tale finds the fairy Ethelinda rewarding one twin sister for good behavior and punishing the other for bad behavior. However, she discovers that her punishment is more pleasing than her reward.
Author: Gail Carson Levine

Title: Faith and the Electric Dogs
Annotation: This tale is told from the point of view of Eddie, the Electric Dog. Faith, a little girl, is unhappy with her new life in Mexico, so she and her faithful dog flee by rocket and find adventures that cause her to have a change of heart. Translations of Spanish phrases appear in the margins.
Author: Patrick Jennings

Title: Faithful Elephants: A True Story of Animals, People and War
Annotation: This touching picture book for older readers conveys with great emotional intensity the unintended consequences of war as Tokyo zookeepers are ordered to "put down" the potentially dangerous animals in the zoo to avoid their escape into the city in the event of a bombing. When the trained elephants can't be destroyed in traditional ways, the zookeepers are forced to starve them to death even as the animals perform for food. The soft-edged watercolors help to diffuse the impact of the story.
Author: Yukio Tsuchiya

Title: Falcons Nest on Skyscrapers
Annotation: This book tells the story of the first pair of peregrine falcons to nest in the eastern United States in 30 years, highlighting the plight of a species that was nearly extinct. Ink drawings with watercolor washes show views of the countryside and city as well as close-ups of the falcons. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out-Science series.
Author: Priscilla Belz Jenkins

Title: Falling Down the Page: A Book of List Poems
Annotation: A tall, slim volume designed to resemble a list contains poems written by a variety of authors. They reflect the everyday experiences of children and others who present items in a new context. Some poems fall down the page, one is upside down, and some are horizontal. There are no illustrations, and none are needed. These poems may inspire young poets.
Author: Georgia Heard (editor)

Title: Falling Up
Annotation: This third (and last) collection of Silverstein's irreverent verse is accompanied by his signature pen-and-ink drawings that defy convention. The verses present a child's-eye view of the world and humorous musings about such things as people zoos, no thank-yous, gnomes, gnats, and gnus. Other Silverstein titles are A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC and WHERE THE SIDEWALK ENDS.
Author: Shel Silverstein

Title: Fame and Glory in Freedom, Georgia
Annotation: Sixth-grader "Bird" Weaver is pretty much ostracized by her classmates and when Harlem Tate, a new student, comes to school, it's clear that this glaring, silent, smelly boy will be ostracized too. That's when Bird decides to make him her friend, and she soon discovers a wealth of things in him to like. Bird and Harlem, with the help of Miss Delphine Reese find fame and glory, friendship, and worth in Freedom, Georgia.
Author: Barbara O'Connor

Title: Families
Annotation: Color photos introduce a wide variety of family groups—both large and small—representing many cultures, including families with two fathers and two mothers. Each of the families is described through interviews with the children. Illustrations include a family portrait, a photo of the child, and a photo from the family’s collection. Useful in a discussion about families and how they continue to change.
Author: Susan Kuklin

Title: Family of Poems: My Favorite Poetry for Children, A
Annotation: An illustrated poetry anthology for children and families with more than 100 poems from around the world. Caroline Kennedy has crafted a mix of poetic genres for family and classroom read-alouds. Walt Whitman, Shakespeare, E. E. Cummings, Nikki Giovanni, and Emily Dickinson are just a few of the poets included in this collection. Jon Muth’s watercolor paintings capture the essence of each poem and invite young readers to visit these verses time and time again.
Author: Caroline Kennedy

Title: Family Tree
Annotation: Tyler Stoudt lives with her father, Jakob, the only family she has ever known. When her teacher assigns a family tree project in history/social science, Tyler knows she has been given an impossible task. Although the assignment opens years of pain, Tyler discovers her Amish background and the love that made her parents "outsiders."
Author: Katherine Ayers

Title: Fannie in the Kitchen: The Whole Story from Soup to Nuts of How Fannie Farmer Invented Recipes with Precise Measurements
Annotation: This is a fictionalized account of how Fannie Farmer came to invent the modern recipe. While employed in a Victorian home in Boston, she begins to write down the precise instructions for measuring and cooking which becomes one of the first modern cookbooks. Period engravings and etchings are blended with pen-and-wash drawings to create a light-hearted picture of Victorian life.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson
Topic: Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)
Standard: PS K.1, I & E K.4, PS 3.1, Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 2.MP.1-8, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 3.MP.1-8, Math 4.MP.1-8

Title: Fantastic Feats and Failures
Annotation: Readers are invited to look inside 20 famous buildings and other structures that have stood—or not stood—the test of time. The text and illustrations reveal the minor but ultimately significant design and engineering decisions that contributed to the success or failure of each structure.
Author: Val Wyatt (editor)
Topic: American History, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Fantastic Flying Books of Mr. Morris Lessmore, The
Annotation: Morris Lessmore loved words. He loved stories. He loved books. But every story has its upsets. Everything in Morris Lessmore's life, including his own story, is scattered to the winds. But the power of story will save the day.
Author: William Joyce
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General , Literacy/Motivation
Award: California Young Reader Medal, Christopher Award

Title: Fantastic Mr. Fox
Annotation: Mr. Fox has to keep one step ahead of the nasty farmers who are obsessed with ridding their farms of the fox family and other burrowing creatures. In the end, Mr. Fox not only survives but also helps the other burrowing creatures live happily ever after. The book is available in paperback only.
Author: Roald Dahl

Title: Fantastic Undersea Life of Jacques Cousteau, The
Annotation: Brief text and lively illustrations depict Jacques Cousteau’s early love of the sea, filmmaking, and inventions. His concern for the environment is expressed in warnings to value and protect the ocean. The artwork is rendered in gouache and airbrush with a slight fuzzy quality that conveys the underwater view. Pair this title with Jennifer Berne’s MANFISH: A STORY OF JACQUES COUSTEAU (2008).
Author: Dan Yaccarino
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures, Life Science (Biology)

Title: Fantastic! Wow! and Unreal! A Book About Interjections and Conjunctions
Annotation: Ruth Heller provides an engaging lesson on interjections and conjunctions. Vivid double-page illustrations accompany rhyming text that covers these two parts of speech in an entertaining manner. This is an excellent resource for lessons on grammar and revision. It provides an effective review for older students and may be used to introduce conjunctions and interjections to younger students and English learners. See other titles in the “World of Language” series.
Author: Ruth Heller
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Faraway Island, A
Annotation: Originally published in Swedish, this story is set in 1939. Two Jewish sisters are sent to the safety offered by a small Swedish island. Sadly, the girls are not able to live together. Nellie, age eight, quickly adapts and fits in with a warm and loving family. Stephie, age twelve, is assigned to live with a cold, stern woman whose husband is kind but whose work as a fisherman keeps him away from home. This is the first of four highly acclaimed books centering on Stephie and her family during World War II.
Author: Annika Thor
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Lifestyles Around the World, War, Women’s Studies

Title: Farewell Symphony, The
Annotation: In 1772, with summer long gone and winter fast approaching, Joseph Haydn, court musician to Prince Nicholas of Esterhazy, created a symphony that persuaded his oblivious employer to close up his summer palace and allow the staff to return home. Haydn’s “Farewell” symphony was composed as a protest to his employer and directed the orchestra members to stop playing, one by one, and leave the stage. The accompanying CD includes the “Farewell” and the “Horn Signal” symphonies.
Author: Anna Harwell Celenza
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.5

Title: Farewell to Shady Glade
Annotation: A group of animals travel in search of a suitable environment in which to live because their original habitat is being cleared for human development. Peet's signature cartoonlike illustrations add humor. The story will encourage students to ponder the effect of habitat destruction to the wildlife that live there.
Author: Bill Peet

Title: Farmer Boy
Annotation: This Hmong folktale describes the events that led up to people having to work very hard on their farms and in the fields to harvest their food. The book includes watercolor illustrations and features differences in Hmong language usage. This story may be used in teaching units on farms.
Author: Peggy B. Matthews

Title: Farmer George Plants a New Nation
Annotation: This story celebrates George Washington’s role as a lifelong farmer—not just as a general and the first president of the United States. Through diary entries, readers learn about Washington’s forward-thinking farming innovations. Illustrated with stunning oil paintings. This is an excellent picture book for older readers.
Author: Peggy Thomas

Title: Farolitas of Christmas, The
Annotation: Pictures richly illustrate a young girl's perseverance as she struggles to create their usual Christmas traditions when her grandfather falls ill.
Author: Rudolfo A. Anaya

Title: Fastest Game on Two Feet: And Other Poems About How Sports Began, The
Annotation: A book of poems for sports fans and history buffs that explains how the sports and games played today began. Sports include those from ancient days as well as those from modern times. Humor appears in the ink-and-watercolor art. The book includes an author’s note and a time line that provide additional facts. Useful for language arts teachers as well as physical education teachers.
Author: Alice Low
Topic: Nutrition and Physical Activity, Physical Fitness

Title: Fatty Legs: A True Story
Annotation: Olemaun, an eight-year-old Inuvialiut girl, wants to learn to read. She convinces her father to allow her to leave their small village on an Arctic island to become a student at a residential school. Her strong spirit allows her not only to survive but also to thrive and learn in a difficult environment where she becomes the target of an extremely mean teacher. Based on the author’s childhood, this illustrated story is co-authored by her daughter-in-law. Illustrations, black-and-white family photographs, and an afterword are included.
Author: Christy Jordan-Fenton, Margaret Pokiak-Fenton
Topic: Diversity, Lifestyles Around the World, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health

Title: Feathered Dinosaurs
Annotation: This book looks at the evidence of dinosaurs with skeletal structures and feathers so similar to birds and why that is convincing many scientists that birds evolved from dinosaurs. The clearly-written text is partnered with detailed photographs, diagrams, and full-color illustrations. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Christopher Sloan

Title: Feathers and Fools
Annotation: This is a modern fable about peacocks and swans who allow the fear of their differences to become so great that they end up destroying each other. After a total disaster occurs, new life creates possibilities of hope. The book is illustrated with full-page acrylic paintings that are framed with primitive borders.
Author: Mem Fox

Title: Feathers, Flaps, and Flops: Fabulous Early Fliers
Annotation: Eight famous figures in the history of flight, male and female are introduced in this book. These dreamers, stunt artists, and madmen all contributed to our current understanding of aeronautics and flying machines. The book is illustrated with large-scale ink drawings with watercolor washes.
Author: Bo Zaunders

Title: Festivals
Annotation: Fourteen festivals from around the world are described through individual poems and illustrated with vibrant paintings that symbolize the festival or holiday. Included are Ramadan and Id-Ul-Fitr, Now-Ruz, Mardi Gras, Kwanzaa, Tet Nguyen-Dan, and Arbor Day. A comprehensive glossary describes the meaning and significance of each festival and holiday.
Author: Myra Cohn Livingston

Title: Fever, 1793
Annotation: This book is set in Philadelphia in 1793. Sixteen-year-old Matilda Cook is separated from her sick mother and learns about perseverance and self-reliance when she is forced to cope with the horrors of a yellow fever epidemic. She flees the city with her grandfather and soon discovers that the sickness is everywhere. Mattie must learn quickly how to survive in a city turned frantic with disease.
Author: Laurie Halse Anderson

Title: Field Mouse and the Dinosaur Named Sue, The
Annotation: A whimsical treatment is given to the true story of the largest, most complete T-Rex ever found. When his roof, one of many fossils in the area, is taken by scientists a field mouse sets out on a search to recover it and ends up in the Field Museum in Chicago. The poster-style art follows him through the museum.
Author: Jan Wahl

Title: Field Trips: Bug Hunting, Animal Tracking, Bird-Watching, Shore Walking
Annotation: This book for young naturalists introduces outdoor excursions, from the forest to the shore, in each chapter. Four main areas - bugs, animal tracks, birds, and plants along fresh- and saltwater shores - are addressed. Readers learn how to investigate, identify, and learn more about the various plants and animals that live in the wild. The author's pencil sketches and captions help readers to identify the various flora and fauna and serve as examples for use in creating one's own field notebook.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: Fighting Ground, The
Annotation: Set during the Revolutionary War, this realistic novel presents the reality of war as a young boy realizes that the fight for freedom has terrible consequences.
Author: - Avi

Title: Finding Winnie: The True Story of the World's Most Famous Bear
Annotation: A woman tells her young son the true story of how his great-great-grandfather, Captain Harry Colebourn, rescued and learned to love a bear cub in 1914 as he was on his way to take care of soldiers' horses during World War I. This story and its little bear became the inspiration for Winnie-the-Pooh.
Author: Lindsey Mattick

Title: Fingerprints and Talking Bones: How Real-Life Crimes Are Solved
Annotation: This book describes how insects, soil, and various markings can be used to solve even high profile crimes. Students are introduced to DNA analysis, soil analysis, ballistics, and other various crime-solving techniques. This can serve as a good introduction or reinforcement for lab techniques.
Author: Charlotte Foltz Jones
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Fire in Their Eyes: Wildfires and the People Who Fight Them
Annotation: In text and photographs, the training and real-life experiences are depicted of people who risk their lives to battle wildfires. Attention is given too, to people who use fire for ecological reasons.
Author: Karen Magnuson Beil

Title: Firebird
Annotation: Misty Copeland tells the story of a young girl whose confidence is fragile and is questioning her own ability to reach the heights that Misty has reached. Misty encourages this young girl's faith in herself and shows her exactly how, through hard work and dedication, that she too can become Firebird.
Publisher: G.P. Putnam's Sons Books for Young Readers
Author: Misty Copeland

Title: Fireboat: The Heroic Adventures of the John J. Harvey
Annotation: A story of a fireboat launched in 1931 that is resurrected by new owners in the 1990s and called into service again on September 11, 2001. It is told with Kalman's hip, energetic, expressionistic illustrations. This book on New York's response to the September 11th disaster is age appropriate.
Author: Maira Kalman

Title: Fireflies in the Dark: The Story of Friedl Dicker-Brandeis and the Children of Terezin
Annotation: Covers the years when Friedl Dicker, a Jewish woman from Czechoslovakia, taught art to children at the Terezin concentration camp. Includes artwork created by the teacher and students, excerpts from diaries, and interviews with camp survivors. California author.
Author: Susan Goldman Rubin
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, International Studies/World History, Visual Arts
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5, HSS 10.8

Title: Firekeeper’s Son, The
Annotation: In Korea in the early 1800s, firekeepers must climb to the top of the mountain and light a bonfire each night to signal to the king that all is well. Sang-hee’s father takes great pride in his role as the guardian of the signal fire in his village. One night, Sang-hee and his mother do not see the fire burning, and Sang-hee is sent to discover why. His trek to solve the mystery becomes a journey of self-discovery. Illustrations add a magical quality to Linda Sue Park’s carefully crafted text. Useful as a read-aloud or literature circle selection.
Author: Linda Sue Park

Title: Firework-Maker's Daughter
Annotation: In order to become a master maker of fireworks like her father, Lila must journey to the sacred volcano to find the necessary royal sulfur. She is assisted on her quest by her best friend Chulak and his talking white elephant.
Author: Philip Pullman

Title: First Americans: The Story of Where They Came From and Who They Became, The
Annotation: Presents in an engaging format the history of Native Americans, liberally illustrated with photographs, artists’ renderings, and primary-source artwork. Beginning with the migration to North America across a land bridge, the narrative brings alive the culture, accomplishments, daily living, and playing of seven Native American cultures. Includes an author’s note, places to visit, and an index.
Author: Anthony Aveni

Title: First Day in Grapes
Annotation: All year long, Chico's family moves up and down California to pick fruits and vegetables. Every September, Chico begins the school year in a new school, and often the other kids pick on him - maybe because he's always new or because he speaks Spanish sometimes. But third grade promises to be different: he likes his teacher, and she recognizes his excellent abilities in math. When fourth-grade bullies tease him, he surprises them with strengths of his own.
Author: L. King Perez

Title: First Dog, The
Annotation: Kip, the cave boy, and Paleowolf each face hunger and danger on a journey in Paleolithic times. When they decide to join forces and help one another, Paleowolf becomes the first dog. Some of Paleowolf's adaptations to his environment are also described.
Author: Jan Brett

Title: First Garden: The White House Garden and How It Grew
Annotation: Tells the story of Michelle Obama and the garden she established at the White House to encourage healthful eating. Pen-and-watercolor illustrations make the garden’s produce inviting. Includes stories of other gardens that preceded the Obama administration, such as Eleanor Roosevelt’s WW II Victory Garden. Describes children who lived in the White House and how they used the outdoor space. The book includes recipes that call for fresh produce.
Author: Robbin Gourley
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: First Morning: Poems About Time
Annotation: This is an anthology of poems that examine the faces of time: the first time, racing against time, different times of our lives, and times of the year. The detailed watercolor-and-ink illustrations perfectly fit each poem and draw the reader into the text. Use this title as an introduction to a unit on time.
Author: Nikki Siegen-Smith

Title: First Peas to the Table: How Thomas Jefferson Inspired a School Garden
Annotation: A shiny nickel with Thomas Jefferson’s picture on the front, “Sweet Victory” seeds, and bells on the trellis are Maya’s good luck charms for the great pea race. Who will be the first to grow, harvest, and fill a bowl with shelled peas that are ready to eat? It is spring, and the students gain valuable lessons, both factual and fictional, in history, science, notetaking, journaling, botany, observation, and life in this title. The book is enhanced with pencil-and-watercolor artwork.
Author: Susan Grigsby
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Life Science (Biology)
Standard: LS K.2, HSS K.3, LS 1.2, HSS 1.2, LS 2.2, HSS 2.1, LS 3.3, HSS 2.4, HSS 2.5, LS 4.2, HSS 3.3, LS 5.2

Title: First Time to the Movies
Annotation: This story is about a mother and her son who go to the movies for the first time. The movie is a Chinese version of THE NUTCRACKER, in which Prince Nutcracker fights the Mighty Mouse Soldiers and saves the day.
Author: Li Huang Ming

Title: Five Creatures
Annotation: A young narrator shares a whimsical and fresh look at family. The reader is encouraged to be observant in identifying the common traits among the two adults, one child, and two cats in this household. The curvilinear and childlike illustrations created in colored chalk enhance the sense of family togetherness. A good introduction to deductive reasoning and Venn diagrams.
Author: Emily Jenkins
Standard: Math K.CC.1-7, Math K.OA.1-5, Math K.MD.1-4, Math 1.OA.1-8

Title: Flag Maker, The
Annotation: This is the story of the U.S. flag, told in lyrical prose. Events of the War of 1812 are seen through the eyes of a twelve-year-old girl, who worked with her family and their servants to sew the enormous flag that waved over Fort McHenry. Delicate watercolor artwork, additional facts, and bibliographic sources enhance the text.
Author: Susan Campbell Bartoletti
Topic: American History, Visual Arts, Women’s Studies

Title: Flag We Love, The
Annotation: A patriotic poem celebrating the flag of the United States, accompanied by notes on roles the flag has played in American history and culture. The bold, detailed paintings in muted colors help to support the rhyming verse, which is accompanied by facts about the flag. The book is appropriate for young children, and its informative text also makes it suitable for older children.
Author: Pam Munoz Ryan

Title: Flash, Crash, Rumble, and Roll
Annotation: This is a revised and newly illustrated version of a book about weather. The narrative explains how and why a thunderstorm occurs and gives safety steps to follow when lightning is flashing. Bright watercolor illustrations are included. It concludes with some weather-related activities and Web sites for further information. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out-Science series.
Author: Franklyn M. Branley

Title: Flawed Dogs: The Shocking Raid on Westminster
Annotation: Sam is a dachshund that was bred to be a show dog. As the result of a cunning scheme carried out by a jealous poodle, Sam is turned out by his adoptive. After enduring a variety of misadventures with a group of abandoned animals, Sam is finally reunited with his original owner and justice is done. Featuring outstanding illustrations, this is a good read-aloud choice from the creator of the “Bloom County” comic-strip series.
Author: Berkeley Breathed

Title: Flicker Flash: Poems
Annotation: The concept of light in its many forms is presented, from candles and lightbulbs to lightning and fireflies. Each of the 23 selections is a concrete poem that seems to flicker and flash off the pages. Brightly colored geometric shapes are prominent in the illustrations. An earlier book by this team is SPLISH, SPLASH!
Author: Joan Bransfield Graham
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Flight of the Phoenix
Annotation: In 1928, ten-year-old Nate’s parents are declared lost at sea, and he is sent to live with a family relative who turns out to be the world’s last beastologist. Nate is whisked away on an adventure to Arabia, where he watches the fiery death and rebirth of a phoenix, gets lost, and must rescue his guardian from the Bedouin. Illustrated with black-and-white drawings, this is a good choice for reluctant readers. Book 1 in the series “Nathaniel Fludd, Beastologist.”
Author: R. L. LaFevers

Title: Flint Heart: A Fairy Story, The
Annotation: A heart-shaped flint heart is designed by a stone-age mystery man for ambitious Phutt, who requests a talisman to harden his heart. The talisman brings success and ultimate defeat to Phutt and is later buried with his ashes. It is found thousands of years later and corrupts a kindly farmer, an innocent fairy, and a badger. The farmer’s son must find a way to rescue humans, fairies, and animals alike from the dark influence of the flint heart. Abridged from a 1910 fantasy by Eden Phillpott.
Author: John Paterson, Katherine Paterson

Title: Floating in Space
Annotation: Clearly-written information examines the environment aboard a space shuttle. It describes how astronauts deal with weightlessness, eating, exercise, and the work they do. Bright cartoonlike illustrations include labeled diagrams that provide further information for young astronauts. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out-Science series.
Author: Franklyn M. Branley

Title: Flora and Ulysses: The Illuminated Adventures
Annotation: Cynical Flora, along with Ulysses, the squirrel she rescued from a terrible fate involving an accident with a vacuum cleaner, team up to use Ulysses' new-found superpowers to conquer evil and protect the weak.
Author: Kate DiCamillo

Title: Flossie and the Fox
Annotation: Flossie has never seen a fox before, and when she meets up with Fox, she doesn't regard him as a frightening creature. Fox is indignant at Flossie's lack of fear, and their southern-style dialogue becomes a humorous tug-of-war as Fox tries to prove just who he is. Clever Flossie wins the war of words.
Author: Patricia C. McKissack (adapter)

Title: Flotsam
Annotation: A wordless picture book featuring a young boy who goes to the beach to collect things that have washed ashore. He discovers an old-fashioned camera that contains a collection of astonishing pictures. He has the photographs developed, and among them are photographs of children from different time periods, each holding another child’s photo. After taking his own picture, the boy returns the camera to the sea, where it is carried on a journey to another child. Vibrant and detailed illustrations tell the story.
Author: David Wiesner
Topic: Lifestyles Around the World, Visual Arts

Title: Flower Hunter: William Bartram, America's First Naturalist, The
Annotation: Young Billy Bartram keeps a journal about the plants of colonial United States as he and his botanist father, John Bartram, collect specimens and study native American plants. The journal includes political events, the family's friendship with Benjamin Franklin, and some somewhat dangerous expeditions. Illustrations using watercolor, gouache, and colored pencil bring the time period to life. This book includes a partial list of the hundreds of native plants the Bartrams collected and described.
Author: Deborah Kogan Ray

Title: Flush
Annotation: With their father jailed for sinking a river boat, Noah Underwood and his younger sister, Abbey, must gather evidence that the owner of the floating casino is emptying his bilge tanks into the protected waters around their Florida Keys home. Readers will be hooked on the story as the good guys try to do the right thing for the environment.
Author: Carl Hiaasen

Title: Fly Away Home
Annotation: A homeless boy who lives in an airport with his father, moving from terminal to terminal and trying not to be noticed, is given hope when he sees a trapped bird find its freedom. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: Fly Free!
Annotation: Mai regularly comes to a Buddhist temple in Vietnam to feed some caged birds, wishing they were free. A series of good deeds, beginning with Mai, end with the birds being freed. “Fly free, fly free, in the sky so blue. When you do a good deed, it will come back to you!” This quiet story is illustrated with serene watercolors showing the good deeds done. A brief explanation of some Buddhist precepts concludes the book.
Author: Roseanne Thong
Topic: Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Ethnic Studies, Religion/Spirituality, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Fly High! The Story of Bessie Coleman
Annotation: Details the life of Bessie Coleman, an African American woman who proved her determination to become a pilot by traveling all the way to France to earn her pilot’s license after it was denied in America. In doing so, she became the first African American woman to earn the license. The book includes rich, dramatic illustrations that depict life in the 1920s.
Author: Louise Borden, Mary Kay Kroeger

Title: Flying Ark, The
Annotation: Animals that travel by airplane to zoos from the wild need special treatment. This book explains how they are made comfortable during the journey and facts about each animal are included. The animal facts are partnered with cartoonlike illustrations.
Author: Carolyn Jackson

Title: Flying Solo
Annotation: When their substitute teacher fails to show up, the sixth-grade students quickly take charge of their class when nobody in the school seems to notice that they are without a teacher. The events of the day cause each student to come to terms with the earlier death of a classmate and to reflect on the words on the class poster: "Character is how you act when nobody's watching."
Author: Ralph Fletcher

Title: Fold Me A Poem
Annotation: Bright illustrations highlight a series of poems featuring a young boy folding origami animals. The haiku-like poems are combined with the origami animals to illustrate that imagination is all that is needed to entertain oneself. Illustrated with detailed acrylic artwork that will inspire children to try some origami and perhaps write poetry.
Author: Kristine O’Connell George

Title: Folk Stories
Annotation: This well-illustrated, bilingual, two-volume collection of Chinese folktales is largely derived from Chinese idioms. A bilingual vocabulary list appears after each story.
Author: Wen Pao Lin

Title: Follow the Drinking Gourd
Annotation: The journey to freedom in the North for runaway slaves is celebrated in the words of this spiritual. The author documents the dangers involved in the escape to freedom and describes the kind and caring people, especially Peg Leg Joe, who formed the secret network that came to be known as the Underground Railroad.
Author: Jeanette Winter
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.5, HSS 2.5, HSS 8.7, HSS 8.9

Title: Follow the Line Around the World
Annotation: Presents a unique overview of world geography by using a black line for readers to follow. Introduces places around the world by touching on each continent and depicting the many animals native to each region. Illustrations use muted colors and are highlighted with black outlines as the line meanders through the pages. Use to introduce world geography.
Author: Laura Ljungkvist

Title: Following the Coast
Annotation: This picture-book for older children highlights the complex ecosystem of the East Coast. The author illustrates and describes the flora, fauna, and various landmarks found in that ecosystem. The artwork is clear and detailed, making this book a great introduction for children studying the topic. The book can also serve as a travel preview for a family planning a trip to the Atlantic Coast.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: Fool of the World and the Flying Ship, The
Annotation: With the help of magical powers, the youngest of three sons, the Fool, succeeds where his older brothers have failed. He outwits the Czar and wins the hand of the princess. The pattern of trials, rewards, and magic is rendered in this Caldecott winner. Available in paperback only.
Author: Arthur Ransome

Title: Foolish Old Man Moves a Mountain, A
Annotation: This illustrated book retelling a famous, classical Chinese legend is written in traditional Chinese.
Author: Hui Fen Pan, Xiu Ling Zhan

Title: Foot in the Mouth: Poems to Speak, Sing, and Shout, A
Annotation: A collection of more than 30 rhyming poems selected because they “are terrific candidates for reading aloud.” Includes poems to read in groups, poems that highlight different forms, and bilingual poems, including ones in Spanish and French. Raschka’s signature artwork uses paint and brightly patterned cut paper and is the perfect complement to the poems. This is the third collection by this team and follows A POKE IN THE I: A COLLECTION OF CONCRETE POEMS (2001) and A KICK IN THE HEAD: AN EVERYDAY GUIDE TO POETIC FORMS (2005).
Author: Paul B. Janeczko (selector)
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing, Literacy/Motivation

Title: Footprints on the Moon
Annotation: Crisp, clear, full-color photographs, archival drawings and lively text tell the story of the study and exploration of the Moon from ancient times to the 1998-1999 Lunar Prospector. NASA photographs highlight the missions of Project Mercury, Gemini, and the Apollo missions. A list of other books and various Web sites appear at the end.
Author: Alexandra Siy
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Footwork: The Story of Fred and Adele Astaire
Annotation: This picture-book biography highlights the early years of Fred Astaire and his sister Adele as they danced, worked hard, and performed in vaudeville, traveling together and eventually getting their own Broadway show. At the peak of their success, Adele left the act—and Fred went on to Hollywood and movie fame. The ink, watercolor, and gouache illustrations provide readers with a peek into the world of vaudeville and how hard work paired with talent is a recipe for success.
Author: Roxane Orgill

Title: For Good Measure: The Ways We Say How Much, How Far, How Heavy, How Big, How Old
Annotation: Provides a thorough description of the myriad ways things are measured. Not only does the author–photographer explain the history of measurement and define measurement vocabulary, but he uses full-color photographs, diagrams, and drawings to demonstrate this history and understanding. An outstanding complement to lessons about measurement.
Author: Ken Robbins

Title: For the Birds: The Life of Roger Tory Peterson
Annotation: American artist, author, and activist Roger Tory Peterson had a great love of birds during his childhood that turned into a lifelong passion. This is an account of Peterson’s life, taking readers through his childhood passions and explorations in the woods near his New York home. Peterson’s successes as a painter and author are explored, as well as his later efforts to protect the habitats of birds around the globe. Concludes with back matter that provides additional information. An NSTA Outstanding Science Trade Book (2012).
Author: Peggy Thomas

Title: Forces of Nature: The Awesome Power of Volcanoes, Earthquakes and Tornadoes
Annotation: This companion book to a National Geographic film is illustrated with vivid still photos from the film. The book's dramatic text introduces readers to three earth science subjects by focusing on the scientists who study them. They conduct their research in the Caribbean, Turkey, and the Midwestern U.S. and offer survival tips for each type of disaster. A bibliography, an index, suggested Internet resources, and interview citations are included.
Author: Catherine O'Neill Grace

Title: Forest Explorer: A Life-Size Field Guide
Annotation: Each large picture (made of more than 60 different photographs that have been combined to make a realistic illustration) in this book depicts in detail several different deciduous forest habitats, with field notes about the insects and animals shown, as well as tips on how to explore a real forest.
Author: Nic Bishop

Title: Forget-Me-Nots: Poems to Learn by Heart
Annotation: A potpourri of short, long, funny, serious, simple, and slightly more complicated poems are paired with appealing pastel watercolor-and-pencil illustrations in this collection. Eleven categories are listed in the table of contents. There are suggestions for learning poetry by heart. This collection would be a good resource for Poetry Month (April), poem festivals, and recitals.
Author: Mary Ann Hoberman

Title: Forgive Me, I Meant to Do It: False Apology Poems
Annotation: This collection of clever and wonderfully sarcastic poems presents adaptations of William Carlos Williams’ poem, “This Is Just to Say.” Several poems reference fairy-tale characters, and kids will love the twist on familiar personalities. Illustrated with cartoon-style pen-and-ink drawings. In addition to its individual appeal, this would make a great read-aloud and an excellent addition to a poetry unit.
Author: Gail Carson Levine

Title: Fortune-Tellers, The
Annotation: A young man in Cameroon seeks the advice of a fortune teller. Returning to his village, he is mistaken for the fortune teller, with hilarious results.
Author: Lloyd Alexander

Title: Fossil Fish Found Alive: Discovering the Coelacanth
Annotation: Illustrated with maps, diagrams, and archival and underwater photographs, this book represents a history of the work of ichthyologists in search of the elusive coelacanth, thought to be extinct for 70 million years but discovered again in the twentieth century. The rich text traces the story of how scientists discovered this long-lost species. The information presented is exciting, and this book makes an excellent tool for students to gain an understanding of the process of scientific inquiry.
Author: Sally M. Walker

Title: Four Feet, Two Sandals
Annotation: Living in a refugee camp in Pakistan, two girls meet when each finds half of a pair of sandals. They agree to share the shoes, taking turns wearing them as a pair and sometimes wearing only one apiece. When one girl learns that her family has received permission to emigrate to the United States, they both decide to split the sandals to ensure that their friendship won’t be forgotten. Illustrated with double-page spreads. Inspired by a refugee girl who asked the authors why there were no books about children like her.
Author: Karen Lynn Williams, Khadra Mohammed
Topic: Global Social Issues, Immigration/Migration, Lifestyles Around the World

Title: Four of a Kind
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Andy wants to drive a team of draft horses in a pulling contest.
