Rebuffed by his divorced parents and left in the care of his crotchety grandfather, Andy finds that his Percheron horses are a comfort as they teach him how to cope with his situation and help him to discover his own inner strengths. This selection is written in first-person narrative.
Author: Patti Sherlock

Title: Fourth Grade Rats
Annotation: A little boy named Suds has just entered fourth grade and is told by his friends that he has to be tough and mean in order to be a true fourth-grader. Suds believes that he is supposed to be a rat—but whenever he tries to act like one, something goes wrong. This book provides valuable lessons on the importance of being yourself, friendship, and doing the right thing. It also touches on bullying and peer pressure.
Author: Jerry Spinelli

Title: Fraction Action
Annotation: Miss Prime and her students explore fractions by finding many examples in the world around them. In the process they divide geometric shapes into fractions, divide sets of objects into equal parts, cut fruit into equal shares, and divide a dollar into fractions. The bright illustrations help to clarify the concepts.
Author: Loreen Leedy

Title: Fraction Fun
Annotation: This is a hands-on activity approach to fractions. Colorful, cartoonlike illustrations assist in making the concepts of fractions and patterns in fraction notation clear. It demonstrates how to divide a paper plate into halves, fourths, and eighths, and relates weight to fractions of an ounce.
Author: David A. Adler

Title: Fractions = Trouble!
Annotation: Wilson is a third-grader with two big problems: he must take a test on fractions in two weeks and he has to figure out what to do for a science-fair project. With the help of a math tutor, Wilson finds that hamsters are the solution to both problems. This story is a good introduction to fractions of a set, equivalent fractions, and adding fractions. Students who struggle with mathematics will relate to this humorous and easy-to-read chapter book.
Author: Claudia Mills
Standard: I & E 3.5, I & E 4.6, I & E 5.6, Math 3.NF.1-3, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 5.NF.1-7

Title: Fractions, Decimals, and Percents
Annotation: The county fair becomes a place to learn about decimals, decimal place value, percentages, and the relationships between fractions. Readers also learn how to make conversions between the forms. Several contexts are used at the fair, such as money, slices of pie, batting average, and games involving spinning the wheel. The last page has directions for making a game and references a related Web site.
Author: David A. Adler

Title: Framed
Annotation: Dylan and his sisters have some ideas about how to make Snowdonia Oasis Auto Marvel into a more profitable business. However, it is not until some strange men arrive in their small town in Wales with valuable paintings and their father disappears that they consider turning to crime. Inspired by the evacuation of paintings from the National Gallery to the safety of a Welsh mine during World War II.
Author: Frank Cottrell Boyce

Title: Free at Last! Stories and Songs of Emancipation
Annotation: This book covers the years from the Emancipation Proclamation in 1863 to the 1954 Supreme Court decision declaring school segregation illegal. It is filled with songs, poems, first-person accounts, memoirs, and letters. The illustrations are bold oil paintings that perfectly represent the text. Language reflects the times of the memoirs.
Author: Doreen Rappaport
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Ethnic Studies, Music
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Freedom on the Menu: The Greensboro Sit-ins
Annotation: This is the story of the 1960 civil rights sit-ins at the Woolworth’s lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina. The book presents a child’s perspective of ordinary men and women doing extraordinary things to stand up for civil rights; a young African American girl describes events within the context of her close-knit family. Illustrated with impressionistic oil paintings.
Author: Carole Boston Weatherford

Title: Freedom River
Annotation: This book tells the true story of John Parker, an ex-slave who became a successful businessman in Ripley, Ohio. This story chronicles just one of many incidents in which Parker helped families to escape from Kentucky, a slave state, across the river to freedom in Ohio. Dramatic collage illustrations use cut and torn papers and photographs combined with watercolors.
Author: Doreen Rappaport
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements

Title: Freedom Summer
Annotation: In 1964, Joe, who is white, is pleased that a new law will allow his best friend John Henry, who is African American, to share the town pool and other public places with him. On the morning after the law is announced, the pool is filled with tar to express opposition to enforced integration. Joe is dismayed to find that racial prejudice still exists. Illustrated with oil paintings that capture the heat of the summer and reflect the friendship of the two young boys.
Author: Deborah Wiles

Title: Freedom Walkers: The Story of the Montgomery Bus Boycott
Annotation: Presents the story of the Montgomery, Alabama, bus boycott and the key persons and events in the year-long struggle for equal rights on Montgomery’s city buses. Illustrated with many black-and-white photographs and fine captions. Pair with Diane McWhorter’s A DREAM OF FREEDOM to place this event in the broader context of the civil rights movement.
Author: Russell Freedman
Award: Hugo Award, James Madison Book Award

Title: Frida
Annotation: Simple text helps chronicle the life of artist Magdalena Carmen Frida Kahlo—how she learned to paint, how painting saved her life, and why her paintings are so unique. Illustrated with Mexican folk-art motifs, but not with Frida Kahlo’s art.
Author: Jonah Winter
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Friendship for Today, A
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Rosemary Patterson learns that she will attend an all-white school in the fall. When her best friend is diagnosed with polio, Rosemary must face the first day of school alone. Her only friend is another girl who is shunned by her white classmates because she lives in poverty.
Author: Patricia C. McKissack

Title: Friendship, The
Annotation: This short novel relates the circumstances of a confrontation between a white storekeeper and an elderly African American in rural Mississippi in the 1930s. Four observers witness the effects that racism and peer pressure have on the tenuous friendship between the two men. The dialogue uses language reflecting the times, and the story climaxes in violence, depicting a violation of human rights. An author's note explains the origin of the story. There are two other books in the series, THE WELL and THE GOLD CADILLAC.
Author: Mildred D. Taylor

Title: Frightful's Mountain
Annotation: Frightful, the peregrine falcon who was Sam Gribley's companion in MY SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN, must now learn to live as a wild bird. In this adventure she grows through the first years of her life, interacts with a falconer who rescues her, poachers, and many animals that are part of the Catskill Mountain's ecological balance.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: Frindle
Annotation: When he decides to turn his fifth-grade teacher's love of the dictionary around on her, clever Nick Allen invents a new word and begins a chain of events that quickly move beyond his control.
Author: Andrew Clements
Award: California Young Reader Medal, Christopher Award

Title: Fritz's Fish
Annotation: Fritz wants a pet but his father has allergies. After a heavy rain has fallen he finds a fish in a flooded street, brings it home, and keeps it in the tub. Sadly, he realizes that the fish needs to be returned to its natural habitat. After sending it on its way, he returns home to find a "proper" pet fish - a goldfish in a fishbowl. Illustrated with primitive-style artwork, this book can be read aloud to introduce the study of habitats.
Author: Geraldine Elschner

Title: Frog Scientist, The
Annotation: With full-color photographs, this book describes frogs and the current environmental threats they face. It highlights Dr. Tyrone Hayes, a field biologist at the University of California, Berkeley, who studies frogs. Students will learn about his childhood love of catching frogs and snakes and his struggles to fit in as an African American student at Harvard University. See also other titles in the “Scientists in the Field” series.
Author: Pamela S. Turner

Title: Frogs, Toads, Lizards, and Salamanders
Annotation: This book provides an introduction to the study of amphibians. The detailed and attractively drawn specimens are paired with interesting facts about adaptations and behavior. Each subject is introduced with a rhyming verse and is accompanied by further information. This is a companion volume to BUGS by the same author.
Author: Nancy Winslow Parker

Title: From Pictures to Words: A Book About Making a Book
Annotation: In this story the author sits in her studio, surrounded by various animals who urge her to write a story. She selects Rhino, Koala, and Cat to appear in the tale and sets out to render the book. This selection is a fine resource to use with aspiring young authors and illustrators.
Author: Janet Stevens
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: From Sea to Shining Sea: A Treasury of American Folklore and Folksongs
Annotation: More than 140 folk songs, tales, poems, and stories tell the history of America and reflect its multicultural society. Illustrations are provided by award-winning artists.
Author: Amy Cohn (editor)

Title: From the Bellybutton of the Moon and Other Summer Poems (Del ombligo de la luna y otros poemas de verano)
Annotation: This seasonal collection of 22 bilingual poems is inspired by childhood memories of summers spent by Latino poet Alarcon in Mexico. Gonzalez's paintings blend bright colors with Mexican folk art and textile designs. This anthology connects with discussions of family traditions and history. California author.
Author: Francisco X. Alarcon

Title: From the Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler
Annotation: Claudia decides to run away to teach her parents a lesson in "Claudia appreciation." She takes her brother along and, together, they hide and live for a week in New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art. While there, Claudia discovers a statue so beautiful that she must find out the identity of the artist. Her quest leads her to the statue's former owner, Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler.
Author: E. L. Konigsburg

Title: Full House: An Invitation to Fractions
Annotation: Miss Bloom wants to fill each of the six rooms at the Strawberry Inn. As guests check in, the number of rooms filled is represented in words, fraction form, and as lit windows in the inn. When all six rooms are full, they are expressed as 6/6 = 1. At night, the guests sneak into the kitchen for a fraction of the strawberry cake. The rhyming text and large, watercolor illustrations provide a delicious introduction to fractions. California author.
Author: Dayle Ann Dodds
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Full of Energy
Annotation: This book offers an interactive approach introducing the concept of energy as it is found in food, sun, wind, water, and other sources and as it is used for nutrition, warmth, and motion. The full-color photographs assist in familiarizing children to the science that surrounds them in their everyday world. See other books in the It's Science! series.
Author: Sally Hewitt

Title: Fun with Roman Numerals
Annotation: Explains the system and “place value” of Roman numerals and contrasts this system with the Arabic numeral system. Current examples of the use of Roman numerals are provided, such as Super Bowls, book chapters, and clocks. Concludes with an activity to help readers build quantities in the Roman numeral system. Helpful for upper elementary students to review the Arabic place value system and to study ancient Rome.
Author: David A. Adler

Title: Fungus That Ate My School, The
Annotation: When students return to school after a rainy spring vacation, they discover that the fungus they were growing in the classroom has taken over the entire school. Colorful Seuss-like illustrations enhance this funny read-aloud book.
Author: Arthur Dorros

Title: Funny Bones: Posada and His Day of the Dead Calaveras
Annotation: Funny Bones tells the story of how the amusing calaveras—skeletons performing various everyday or festive activities—came to be. They are the creation of Mexican artist José Guadalupe (Lupe) Posada (1852–1913). In a country that was not known for freedom of speech, he first drew political cartoons, much to the amusement of the local population but not the politicians. He continued to draw cartoons throughout much of his life, but he is best known today for his calavera drawings. They have become synonymous with Mexico’s Día de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) festival.
Author: Duncan Tonatiuh
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Visual Arts
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General
Award: Pura Belpre Illustration Honor, Robert F. Sibert Award

Title: Funny Little Woman, The
Annotation: A giggly little lady in medieval Japan chases a rolling rice dumpling into a cavern, where she is captured by a fearsome oni who needs a good cook. Lent's colorful, cartoonlike illustrations add to the humor of the story.
Author: Arlene Mosel

Title: G Is for Galaxy: An Out of This World Alphabet
Annotation: This informational and pictorial journey though the galaxy is a delightful way to learn about the galaxy. Each letter of the alphabet features two ways to learn about the topic. In addition to expository text, this book presents short poems and friendly, appealing illustrations.
Author: Cathy Collison, Janis Campbell

Title: G Is for Golden: A California Alphabet
Annotation: An alphabet of things that characterize the State of California. Each alphabet entry consists of a short rhyme followed by brief information about the entry and its place in California history. Illustrated with bright artwork.
Author: David Domeniconi

Title: G Is for Googol: A Math Alphabet Book
Annotation: This alphabet book explains the meaning of mathematical terms from abacus to zillion. Each term is explained by text and bright watercolor-washed drawings and cartoons. A glossary is included. Pair up with Q IS FOR QUARK: A SCIENCE ALPHABET BOOK.
Author: David M. Schwartz

Title: Galapagos George
Annotation: This is the story of the famous Lonesome George, a giant tortoise who was the last of his species and lived to be one hundred years old. His story gives us a glimpse of the amazing creatures living on the ever-fascinating Galápagos Islands.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: Galapagos Means Tortoises
Annotation: Poems communicate details about the habitat, behavior, and adaptations of 12 animals native to the Galápagos Islands, including the giant tortoise, boobies, the marine iguana, and the sea lion. Heller's poetic text is partnered with realistic paintings that fill the page in single- and double-page spreads. An author's note provides additional information about the Galápagos Islands. California author/illustrator.
Author: Ruth Heller

Title: Galileo y el universo (Galileo and the Universe)
Annotation: This is a straightforward account of Galileo's life and times. Extensive illustrations help make it clear what Galileo discovered, how it was different from conventional wisdom, and why those differences earned him the enmity of the church. Other titles in the Pioneros de la Ciencia (Pioneers of Science) series that have been translated into Spanish include LOUIS PASTEUR Y LOS GERMENES (LOUIS PASTEUR AND GERMS), MARIE CURIE Y EL RADIO (MARIE CURIE AND RADIUM), GUGLIELMO MARCONI Y LA RADIO (GUGLIELMO MARCONI AND THE RADIO), CHARLES DARWIN Y LA EVOLUCION (CHARLES DARWIN AND EVOLUTION), and ISAAC NEWTON Y LA GRAVEDAD (ISAAC NEWTON AND GRAVITY).
Author: Steve Parker

Title: Galileo's Treasure Box
Annotation: While Galileo sleeps, his young daughter explores his study and discovers some of the objects he uses in his scientific experiments. The simple text is accompanied by artwork rendered in a Renaissance style and the book concludes with a brief biography of Galileo. This would be a good choice to launch a discussion of Galileo, his life, and his scientific endeavors or to stimulate student predictions about Galileo's uses of the objects in the box.
Author: Catherine Brighton

Title: Galileo's Universe
Annotation: In this sophisticated book of poetry and paper engineering, the reader interacts with the paper engineering (pop-ups) to better understand Galileo Galilei's beliefs. The poetry leads the reader to the world of science and the superstitions of the sixteenth-century. The language used is both elegant and comprehensive. While paper-engineering books are not for every library or classroom, they do offer hands-on engagement for reluctant readers or science participants. Included is a timeline of Galileo's life.
Author: J. Patrick Lewis
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)

Title: Galileo: The Genius Who Faced the Inquisition
Annotation: This is a well-told biography of Galileo. It begins with his childhood and takes the reader through his life as an astronomer and physicist. Key to the text is the controversy surrounding the theory that the earth is not the center of the universe; that, rather, the earth revolves around the sun. The narrative and well-placed illustrations help to tell a complicated story and paint an accurate picture of everyday life in Florence, Italy, in the 1500s.
Author: Philip Steele

Title: Galileo’s Leaning Tower Experiment: A Science Adventure
Annotation: A fictionalized account of Galileo’s experiments on calculating the speed of falling objects. Galileo observes a poor farm boy, Massimo, who drops bread and cheese on his uncle’s boat as it passes under a bridge. Galileo is surprised to see the bread and cheese hit the boat at the same time, contradicting Aristotle’s teachings. Galileo begins experimenting with other pairs of falling objects, proving that they fall at the same speed and hit the ground simultaneously. An afterword notes the fictionalized details. Introduces physics and experimentation to young scientists.
Author: Wendy Macdonald

Title: Game of Silence
Annotation: Nine-year-old Omakaya and her family, members of the Ojibwa tribe, are forced to leave their island on Lake Superior in 1850 when white settlers move into the territory. The girl comes to realize that the things most important to her are her home and way of life. This is a satisfying sequel to THE BIRCHBARK HOUSE, the author’s first book about Omakaya and her family.
Author: Louise Erdrich

Title: Gandhi
Annotation: This story of Gandhi's life and work is told in a simple, straightforward manner, presenting his social and political goals with reverence. Includes author's notes. The author/illustrator's signature artwork using gold borders and accents of brilliant color evoke the East Indian culture. Can be used as a picture book for older readers.
Author: - Demi

Title: Garden of the Spirit Bear: Life in the Great Northern Rainforest
Annotation: This is an introduction to the Great Bear Rainforest, which lies along the Pacific Coast in British Columbia, Canada. The book highlights the lives of the black bears that live in the region as well as the old-growth trees, native peoples, salmon, and other plants and animals found there. Also discussed is the threat posed to the forest by logging interests. Watercolor illustrations show the vast, unspoiled landscapes of the region.
Author: Dorothy Hinshaw Patent

Title: Gardener, The
Annotation: Young Lydia Grace has to go to New York to live with her uncle during the Depression. Told entirely in letters written to her family, the story traces her efforts to make the city more beautiful and to get her uncle to smile. Pictures fill out the plot outline and are done in muted colors except for the flowers. This is a great book to introduce the 1930s and to start discussions on families.
Author: Sarah Stewart

Title: Gathering of Days: A New England Girl's Journal, A
Annotation: A young girl's journal pulls the reader into life in New Hampshire in 1830. Many precepts are woven into this story, illustrating both the sparseness and richness of life in the past compared with life today.
Author: Joan W. Blos

Title: Gathering the Sun: An Alphabet in Spanish and English
Annotation: Using the theme of crops and gleaning produce, the author covers each letter of the alphabet with thoughtful phrases that celebrate the land and the Latinos who work on it. The poetic text, in English and Spanish, and the warm illustrations reflect the author's feelings about the land. California author and setting.
Author: Alma Flor Ada

Title: Genius of Leonardo, The
Annotation: This richly illustrated book uses original journal entries and drawings to tell a story from the viewpoint of Giacomo, Leonardo da Vinci's assistant. The text helps the reader understand da Vinci's love of exploration and experimentation and how this helped him make scientific discoveries that still have impact today. Quotes and sketches from da Vinci's notebooks appear throughout the book.
Author: Guido Visconti
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: Genius: A Photobiography of Albert Einstein
Annotation: The life of Albert Einstein is told through myriad pictures and a strong narrative that provides wonderfully simple explanations of many of his theories. The black-and-white and sepia photographs throughout the book follow Einstein from boyhood to old age and show him in a variety of settings. The overall effect brings Einstein to life for young readers.
Author: Marfe Ferguson Delano

Title: George and Martha
Annotation: The joys and problems that friendships entail are portrayed in five stories about two good friends, the hippos George and Martha. The author's childlike drawings help to create a joyful sense of the ridiculous, which will appeal both to grown-ups and to young children.
Author: James Marshall

Title: George Did It
Annotation: The life of George Washington is presented through humorous accounts of how the reluctant president tried to avoid the role of president after serving in the U.S. military during the Revolutionary War. Even though Washington doubted his abilities, the story focuses on his accomplishments. Illustrated with humorous but respectful drawings. Use to introduce the post-Revolutionary War period.
Author: Suzanne Tripp Jurmain

Title: George vs. George: The American Revolution as Seen from Both Sides
Annotation: Presents an unusually balanced view of the American Revolution, examining George Washington and King George III and their respective governments and policies. The two perspectives are shown on double-spread pages to compare the man with the monarch. Fully illustrated with maps, charts, scenes depicting the action, and a hefty dose of humor. The causes, events, and aftermath of the American Revolution are fully mapped out.
Author: Rosalyn Schanzer

Title: George Washington Carver
Annotation: A biography of African American botanical researcher and educator George Washington Carver. His work to promote alternative crops in the post-Civil-War South played a major role in revolutionizing Southern agriculture. Illustrated with historical artifacts and photographs and a mixture of Carver’s own paintings and botanical illustrations.
Author: Tonya Bolden

Title: George Washington's Socks
Annotation: During a backyard slumber party, five children are transported back in time and find themselves crossing the Delaware with George Washington and his troops. This chapter book brings the conditions of the Revolutionary War to life for the young reader.
Author: Elvira Woodruff

Title: George Washington's Teeth
Annotation: Throughout his life George Washington had bad teeth and worked hard to keep them. Rhyming text and whimsical water colors relate how Washington lost his teeth and the eighteenth-century solution that finally resolved his dilemma. The book includes a bibliography.
Author: Deborah Chandra, Madeleine Comora

Title: George Washington, Spymaster: How the Americans Outspied the British and Won the Revolutionary War
Annotation: This concise volume focuses on Washington’s use of spies to gather intelligence that helped the colonies win the Revolutionary War. The engaging text is laced with details about invisible ink, codes, and double agents. The book design is intended to resemble an antique publication from the 1700s and is illustrated with reproductions of archival art and pen-and-ink sketches.
Author: Thomas B. Allen

Title: George: George Washington, Our Founding Father
Annotation: A biographical picture book narrated by George Washington. It highlights key moments in the famous American’s life, from his birth to his presidency. The oil-on-canvas illustrations on each spread appear like portraits. Includes an author’s note, an artist’s note, historical notes, and a bibliography.
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
Author: Frank Keating

Title: George’s Marvelous Medicine
Annotation: George is forced to babysit his grouchy, nasty grandmother and feed her a daily dose of medicine. He decides to play a trick on her and creates a potent potion that has bewitching effects. This book may be used for sequencing and for teaching cause and effect.
Author: Roald Dahl

Title: Georgia in Hawaii: When Georgia O’Keefe Painted What She Pleased
Annotation: Hired in 1939 by the Hawaiian Pineapple Company (now Dole), artist Georgia O’Keeffe was directed to produce two paintings promoting her sponsor’s product but was denied access to the fields. She embarked on a tour of the islands and captured in her paintings the lush, vibrant scenes and flora she observed. This little-known story includes author and illustrator notes, a map, and endpapers that identify O’Keefe’s favorite Hawaiian flowers. The bright artwork is rendered in the style of O’Keefe. Appropriate as a picture book for older readers. California illustrator.
Author: Amy Novesky
Topic: Earth Science, English-Language Arts/General, Life Science (Biology), Visual Arts
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General , Science
Standard: LS K.2, LS 1.2, LS 2.2, ES 2.3, VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4

Title: Germs! Germs! Germs!
Annotation: This humorous look at germs is told in simple verse with colorful illustrations. Written from the point of view of the germs, students are provided with information on how germs enter their bodies and what actions the students can take to prevent infection.
Author: Bobbi Katz

Title: Gershwin’s Rhapsody in Blue
Annotation: In 1924, twenty-six-year-old pianist George Gershwin finds himself slated to compose, in only five weeks, a concerto that defines American music. The result is Gershwin’s masterpiece: “Rhapsody in Blue.” An accompanying CD enriches the story.
Author: Anna Harwell Celenza
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.3

Title: Ghost Diamond!
Annotation: This first volume of the “Agent Amelia” series features a spunky elementary school detective. Three cases are presented for Amelia to solve in her quest to save the world from evil. She foils a jewel thief, identifies cat burglars, and battles plants that have come alive. The stories are narrated in the first person and feature black-line drawings. A good read-aloud choice and selection for newly independent readers.
Author: Michael Broad

Title: Ghost Hands: A Story Inspired by Patagonia’s Cave of the Hands
Annotation: Auki, a young Tehuelche hunter from Patagonia, desperately wants to prove that he is mature enough to hunt with the men. After a run-in with a puma, he falls into a cave decorated with hundreds of handprints. He helps fight the puma by using his left foot. In doing so, he protects the “painter of the people,” whose job is to preserve his people by painting their hands in the cave. This is a “pourquoi” story that explains why there is one left foot in the Cueva de las Manos (the Cave of the Hands).
Author: T. A. Barron
Topic: Diversity, Global Historical Events and Figures, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Ghost Knight
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Jon Whitcroft is sent away to attend his late father’s boarding school. Jon soon finds himself haunted by a group of ghosts seeking revenge against his family. Jon and his new friend, Ella, summon the ghost of Sir William Longspee, a medieval knight, for protection. Features many black-and-white drawings and includes historical notes.
Author: Cornelia Funke

Title: Ghost Train
Annotation: The daughter of a Chinese laborer who was killed while building the railroad is directed by ghosts to paint a Ghost Train so that dead workers can return to their homeland to rest. Haunting illustrations carry this poignant story of the hardships encountered by migrant laborers.
Author: Paul Yee
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Ghosthunters and the Gruesome Invincible Lightning Ghost!
Annotation: Hetty, a famous ghosthunter, her sidekick Tom, and their affiliate ghost, Hugo, have formed an agency devoted to dealing with ghostly apparitions. They are called to solve a haunting problem at a seaside hotel. The Gruesome Invincible Lightning Ghost has claimed the penthouse suite, where it passes the time turning guests into ghosts. More silly than scary, this is the second book in the “Ghosthunters” series.
Author: Cornelia Funke

Title: Giant and the Spring, The
Annotation: Capturing the spirit of Spring, a kind and wise giant comes to realize that he is being selfish after bringing Spring into his home and refusing to let him go. Bright, full-page watercolor illustrations enrich the text.
Author: Eva Wang, Kuang-Ts’ai Hao (reteller)

Title: Giant Rat of Sumatra or Pirates Galore, The
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Edmond Amos Peters is rescued from the sea by Captain Gallows and his pirate crew, is nicknamed “Shipwreck,” and becomes the captain’s cabin boy. When the ship anchors in San Diego in 1846, the swashbuckling adventures begin. This lively tale involves the war with Mexico over ownership of California, dastardly crew members bent on mutiny, a pirate captain who wants to become a Spanish land-grant owner, hidden emeralds, a search for a lost love, and a pack of bandits led by a beautiful woman. California author.
Author: Sid Fleischman

Title: Giant Shark: Megalodon, Prehistoric Super Predator
Annotation: Data complied from many partial finds of a huge prehistoric shark, combined with scientific speculation, provides a backdrop for a description of the life cycle and habits of the "largest ocean predator." Extinct for over two million years, this enormous shark comes to life in double-spread watercolor illustrations enhanced by diagrams and graphs.
Author: Caroline Arnold

Title: Gift of the Tree, The
Annotation: In poetic form, the author describes the life cycle of an oak tree including how animals depend on it for shelter and food. New illustrations feature vibrant paintings which show the life, death, and decay of the tree as it finally becomes part of the forest floor.
Author: Alvin Tresselt

Title: Gift: The Hmong New Year, The (Qhov Phajtshab: Hmoob ib Lub Xyoo)
Annotation: Dao, a young Hmong American girl, feels that her culture has nothing to contribute to the way in which Christmas is celebrated in America. While doing a school project, however, she discovers the beauty of her culture and its connection to a multicultural society. Paintings illustrate the events of the story.
Author: Ia Xiong

Title: Gigante del desierton, El (Desert Giant: The World of the Saguaro Cactus)
Annotation: The life cycle and ecosystem of the giant saguaro cactus and the multitude of animals and plants it helps to support or affect is told in well-crafted text and lush, realistic paintings. Included is how the cactus provides homes for woodpeckers, owls, and hawks, and food for bats, birds, coyotes, and the indigenous people of Arizona's Sonoran Desert.
Author: Barbara Bash

Title: Gimme Cracked Corn and I Will Share
Annotation: A very “corny” tale filled with jokes, wordplay, and puns about corn, fowl, and eggs. A chicken dreams about cracked corn and, accompanied by her pal George, follows her dream until she arrives at a pig’s barn, where she is sure that cracked corn will be hidden. The book’s pen-and-watercolor artwork features balloon dialogue that adds to the fun.
Author: Kevin O'Malley

Title: Giraffes Can't Dance
Annotation: At the Annual Jungle Dance, Gerald the clumsy giraffe is unable to dance with all the other animals. A friendly cricket appears in the moonlight and suggests that he listen to his surroundings and find his own music. When he hears the sound of the wind in the trees, he starts to move in a gentle swaying and circling motion.
Author: Giles Andreae
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.2

Title: Girl Who Loved Caterpillars: A Twelfth-Century Tale from Japan, The
Annotation: In this retelling of an old Japanese story, a young woman resists social and family pressures as she befriends caterpillars and other socially unacceptable animals. The full-color paintings include renderings of portraits and exquisite fabrics. The story could lead to discussion of the difficulties faced by women with a passion for science.
Author: Jean Merrill (adapter)

Title: Girl Who Spun Gold, The
Annotation: In this West Indian version of Rumpelstiltskin, Quashiba, a young spinner, is married to Big King, who insists that she produce gold. A cruel-looking little creature appears and says he'll spin gold for her if she can guess his name. The acrylic illustrations use gold lavishly, and the easygoing West Indian text makes this a fun read-aloud.
Author: Virginia Hamilton

Title: Girl with 500 Middle Names, The
Annotation: Janie's parents move to the suburbs so she can go to a better school, but when she discovers that all the other students are richer than she is, she feels out of place until she realizes that there are more important things than money.
Author: Margaret Peterson Haddix

Title: Girls Think of Everything: Stories of Ingenious Inventions by Women
Annotation: Readers become acquainted with the various ways in which inventions come about. The readers meet 12 resourceful females whose inventions are now common to everyday life, such as Snugli, Liquid Paper, and Scotchgard. Written in a conversational style and accompanied by casual watercolor-collage illustrations, this book encourages readers to become inventors and provides information on the patent process, a bibliography, and a source list. A chronology featuring additional female inventors is included.
Author: Catherine Thimmesh

Title: Give Me Liberty
Annotation: Thirteen-year-old Nathaniel is an indentured servant in Williamsburg, Virginia, in 1774. This chapter book has a plethora of characters interacting at a pivotal time for the American colonies and depicts many points of view. Includes a timeline and bibliography.
Author: Laura Elliot

Title: Glaciers: Nature's Icy Caps
Annotation: This title provides an introduction to glaciers, explaining how they form, move, and shift. It describes the effects of glaciers on the earth as it cycles in and out of ice ages. Illustrated with digital collage in double-page spreads, this book includes two maps and an author's note.
Author: David L. Harrison

Title: Global Warming: The Threat of Earth's Changing Climate
Annotation: In this revision of his 1991 work, the author makes an impassioned plea for action against the causes of global warming. He provides details on global warming, climatic changes and the greenhouse effect, and highlights responses to their consequences. The text is illustrated with numerous color photographs, diagrams, and charts. A glossary, a bibliography of further readings, and an index are included.
Author: Laurence P. Pringle

Title: Gloria's Way
Annotation: Gloria has plenty on her mind, from the importance of knowing where she stands with her dad, to the ups and downs of friendship. Other stories in this series are STORIES JULIAN TELLS, STORIES HUEY TELLS, and MORE STORIES JULIAN TELLS.
Author: Ann Cameron

Title: Glorious Flight: Across the Channel with Louis Bleriot, July 25, 1909, The
Annotation: A fascination with flying machines leads Louis Bleriot to design a plane that crosses the English Channel in 37 minutes in the 1900s. This book provides a treasure of information, well laid out and perfectly illustrated. Use with FLY, A BRIEF HISTORY OF FLIGHT by Barry Moser.
Author: Alice Provensen
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures, International Studies/World History, Lifestyles Around the World, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Glory Be
Annotation: Set in Mississippi during the summer of 1964, this story centers on Gloriana, an eleven-year-old girl who discovers that the swimming pool she planned to use all summer will be closed—but not for the reason given to the public. Gloriana becomes friends with a girl whose mother, a nurse, will run a Freedom Clinic for poor black people. Gloriana learns some new truths. This book may be used to introduce the civil rights movement and spark discussion. See also the picture book FREEDOM SUMMER by Deborah Wiles, which is set in the same time period and covers similar issues.
Author: Augusta Scattergood
Topic: American History, Diversity, Global Historical Events and Figures

Title: Go Fish
Annotation: The story tells of a day in the life of a young African American, Thomas, and his grandfather. Readers follow along as the two read, fish, and play cards while conversing about life and sharing stories from their African ancestors. Watercolor illustrations add detail and convey the loving relationship between grandfather and grandson. This book is part of a series by this author.
Author: Mary Stolz

Title: Go Hang a Salami!  I'm a Lasagna Hog! And Other Palindromes
Annotation: Humorous comic-strip-style illustrations bring to life a wide-ranging collection of palindromes. Readers of all ages who begin browsing pages such as “Yell Alley” and “Last egg gets Al” will find themselves addicted and wanting to write their own palindromes.
Author: Jon Agee

Title: Go, Go, America
Annotation: The Farley family is taking a road trip covering all 50 United States. A map provides the route, and along the way quirky facts about each state are presented, describing strange festivals, traditions, contests, laws, people, and landmarks across the country. Bright, cartoonlike illustrations will engage children as the text sneaks in a fair amount of history and geography. Concludes with a list of the states, in alphabetical order, that offers more traditional information (state flowers, capitals, and the like).
Author: Dan Yaccarino

Title: Gobble, Quack, Moon
Annotation: A host of barn animals cheer up Katie the cow by staging a dance party on the moon. They build a rocket ship and spend time dancing on the craters to such classic numbers as the Watusi and the Mashed Potato. The rhyming text is accompanied by good-humored ink drawings. Includes the story and music on a CD/ROM.
Author: Mathew Gollub
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.2

Title: God Bless the Child
Annotation: The lyrics of Billie Holiday's classic "God Bless the Child" are illustrated with images of a southern African American family's move to a northern city during the Great Migration. The book includes a CD of Holiday's 1941 recording of the title song.
Author: Arthur Herzog, Jr., Billie Holiday

Title: Goin' Someplace Special
Annotation: In segregated 1950s Nashville, a young African American girl braves a series of indignities and obstacles to get to one of the few integrated places in town where "all are welcome" - the public library. The watercolor paintings realistically represent southern city streets and sidewalks in the 1950s.
Author: Patricia C. McKissack

Title: Going North
Annotation: A young African American girl and her family leave their home in Alabama and head for Lincoln, Nebraska, where they hope to escape segregation and find a better life. As the girl watches the world go by from her car window, students can follow the journey, which is mapped on the endpapers. This is an autobiographical story illustrated with colorful, impressionistic paintings.
Author: Janice N. Harrington

Title: Going West
Annotation: Describes a pioneer family’s migration by prairie schooner from the East, across the plains, to Kansas. The adventure of the journey and their first year of life on the frontier are narrated by a seven-year-old girl. The charcoal-and-colored-pencil illustrations give the illusion of an old journal. This book would be an excellent introduction to pioneer life for young students.
Author: Jean Van Leeuwen

Title: Gold Cadillac
Annotation: This novel acquaints readers with racism in Mississippi in the 1950s, told through the eyes of Lois, the young African American narrator. Lois and her sister Wilma know nothing of the racial prejudice of the south until their prideful daddy decides to drive them in their flashy new gold Cadillac to visit relatives. Dramatic sepia paintings depict human rights violations that change the girls' lives. There are two other books in the series, THE WELL and THE FRIENDSHIP.
Author: Mildred D. Taylor

Title: Gold Fever
Annotation: In terse verse the author tells the story of Jasper, who leaves his farm in the Midwest to fulfill his dream of discovering gold in California. After many mishaps and no discoveries, Jasper calls it quits and returns to his family. Very succinct but descriptive text accompanied by colored pencil drawings give the reader much information about the California Gold Rush. This book is an excellent resource for the fourth-grade California studies. California author and setting.
Author: Verla Kay
Genre: Fiction in Verse, Historical Fiction, Poetry

Title: Gold Fever! Tales from the California Gold Rush
Annotation: Presents historical anecdotes and accounts of the California Gold Rush, starting with the January 1848 discovery of gold at Sutter’s Mill. Comic book–style panels are accompanied by snippets from diaries, letters, and newspaper accounts. Includes routes by land and sea to the hustle and bustle of the West Coast boomtowns. Describes the triumphs and disappointments of the prospectors. Paintings full of color and motion show the rocky roads of the overland trails, the excitement at the digging sites, and the liveliness of San Francisco.
Author: Rosalyn Schanzer

Title: Gold! Gold from the American River
Annotation: Through firsthand accounts from the Library of Congress, this book recounts the discovery of gold in the American River, providing a realistic look at what it was like to travel west and pan for gold in the mid-nineteenth century. Includes the historical role that women, Native Americans, Chinese, and African Americans played in the California Gold Rush. Featuring pen-and-ink and watercolor illustrations, the book also includes an author’s note and a bibliography.
Author: Don Brown
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Golden Numbers: A California Number Book
Annotation: This is a counting book, but so much more. Each number page has the number word, the numeral, a colorful illustration of a California feature to show the quantity, a short rhyme for the quantity, and more information about California for older readers or adults. A few examples: one garibaldi, four presidios, and 100 monarch butterflies. The book starts with the numbers 1 through 12 and then covers the tens, from 20 to 100. Both the author and the illustrator are from California.
Author: David Domeniconi

Title: Golden Selections of Tang Poems
Annotation: This easy rhyming book in Chinese uses famous Tang dynasty poems to develop children's oral language ability in Chinese.
Author: Kan Xiong

Title: Gone Again Ptarmigan
Annotation: In poetic text, this book introduces the ptarmigan, the state bird of Alaska. It tells how it is able to blend into their surroundings in each of the different seasons of the year. The full-color paintings include thumbnail sketches to show details of the birds and their life cycle. This is an effective read-aloud choice to introduce adaptations and camouflage. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Jonathan  London

Title: Gone Fishing: Ocean Life by the Numbers
Annotation: This title introduces threatened marine life creatures, which are shaped in numbers 1 through 10 and presented with scientific and environmental data (printed in black and white on a blue background). The book is illustrated with pencil, pen, brush, and India ink enhanced with digital art. References also feature rounded numbers, 1 to 1 billion, in the center of the book; end materials; and a map.
Author: David McLimans
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Global Social Issues, Life Science (Biology), Number Sense
Standard: LS K.2, LS 1.2, LS 2.2, Math K.CC.1-7, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 4.NBT.1-6

Title: Gone Forever! An Alphabet of Extinct Animals
Annotation: Extinct animals are introduced in an alphabet book format illustrated with bright, full-page acrylic paintings. Accompanying each letter and animal illustration is concise information describing the characteristics of the animal and why it is extinct. Animals selected include insects, fish, amphibians, birds, and mammals.
Author: Sandra Markle, William Markle

Title: Good Books, Good Times!
Annotation: This short volume presents 14 poems by favorite children's poets that relate to books, words, and reading. Included are such poets as Jack Prelutsky, David McCord, and Myra Cohn Livingston.
Author: Lee Bennett Hopkins (selector)

Title: Good Dog, The
Annotation: This tale, told in the first person, centers on a malamute named McKinley, who lives with a boy named Jack. McKinley is the head dog of the 300 dogs in a Colorado mountain town. A she-wolf named Lupin appears on a hillside and has come to recruit dogs to replenish her dwindling wolf pack in the wild. McKinley, a good dog, hears Lupin’s call and needs to make a decision: Should he leave with Lupin or stay to protect Jack?
Author: Avi

Title: Good Fortune: My Journey to Gold Mountain
Annotation: In 1933, when Li Keng was seven, she emigrated with her mother and two sisters from China to join her father in Oakland, California. The story begins in a village in China, follows the family’s trip by sea to California and Angel Island, describes the process of passing through Angel Island, and covers their first eight years in America. This is a good companion piece to LANDED by Milly Lee. Includes an author’s note, bibliography, and archival photos. California author.
Author: Li Keng Wong

Title: Good Luck Gold and Other Poems
Annotation: This collection of 42 original poems, written from a Chinese-Korean American child's point of view, explores the experiences of growing up Asian in America as well as experiences that are universal to childhood. This selection is useful for discussions about growing up, diversity, prejudice, and self-esteem. California author.
Author: Janet S. Wong

Title: Good Luck, Mrs. K!
Annotation: All the students in third grade are affected when their beloved teacher, Mrs. Kempczinski, is hospitalized with cancer. This lovely, uplifting story is a tribute to caring teachers and resilient children.
Author: Louise Borden

Title: Good Night for Freedom, A
Annotation: Hallie discovers two runaway slave girls hiding in the cellar of Katy and Levi Coffin’s home. She must decide whether to turn the girls over to the slave catchers or help the girls escape. This fictional story is based on actual historical events involving Levi Coffin, a Quaker and abolitionist whose home was a stop on the Underground Railroad. The collage-style, mixed-media art highlights the drama of the story. Concludes with a historical note about Levi and Catharine Coffin, who provided safe haven for about 2,000 slaves escaping to Canada.
Author: Barbara Olenyik Morrow

Title: Good Sports: Rhymes About Running, Jumping, Throwing, and More
Annotation: This exuberant book links art, poetry, and sports. Seventeen poems describe many of the sports played by children today. The snappy watercolor-and-pen illustrations bring a great deal of spirit and fun to the reader. An excellent read-aloud choice for children who would rather play ball than read poetry.
Author: Jack Prelutsky
Topic: Motor Skills/Movement Patterns, Nutrition and Physical Activity, Physical Fitness

Title: Gooney Bird on the Map
Annotation: When the students in Gooney Bird’s second-grade class become glum because they won’t be traveling to an exciting vacation spot during winter vacation, she comes up with a plan to build a map of the entire United States outside, in the snow that has covered the playground. Black-and-white illustrations throughout the text add detail to this short chapter book. Gooney Bird continues to provide quality reading and humor for younger students.
Author: Lois Lowry

Title: Gooseberry Park
Annotation: An ice storm separates Stumpy the squirrel from her newborns, but her animal friends come to the rescue in this playful - and at times suspenseful - read-aloud story.
Author: Cynthia Rylant

Title: Gorilla Doctors: Saving Endangered Great Apes
Annotation: Scientists and staff take care of gorillas and work to save the endangered animals in Rwanda's National Volcano Park. The engaging narrative describes the effects of human exposure on the gorillas, how emergency medical care is provided to them in the wild, and ways in which to protect the species from poachers and common human diseases. Illustrated with clear, full-color, close-up photographs. This title includes suggested Web sites and an index. It is a part of the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Pamela S. Turner

Title: Gorilla Walk
Annotation: A husband and wife team describe their real-life adventure into the Impenetrable Forest in Uganda to meet the mountain gorilla. Realistic watercolors highlight the narrative writing style as they recreate their experiences and reveal this remote habitat. Gorilla facts, a map, and an index are included.
Author: Betsy Lewin, Ted Lewin

Title: Gorillas
Annotation: This book accurately describes the gentle gorilla with information on several different species, their habits, diet, behavior, and decreasing population. Full-color photographs bring the clear child-friendly text to life. Another title by this author is WILD BABIES which describes the various parenting techniques of some wild animals, and the behavior and characteristics of their offspring.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Got Geography!
Annotation: This collection of poems explores themes of geography and adventure. It introduces latitude and longitude and landforms such as mountains, islands, and oceans. The poems represent a variety of writers and are enhanced with bright acrylic and watercolor illustrations. Read these poems aloud and share the artwork when launching geography studies.
Author: Lee Bennett Hopkins

Title: Got to Dance
Annotation: Too young to go to day camp with her big brother, a young city girl dances away her summertime blues with her grandfather. They dance through breakfast, down hot streets, and at the zoo all through the day together. The bright illustrations capture motion as the girl twirls on the street, runs through water from a hose, and bounces on her bed. Large watercolor artwork is part cartoon and part impressionistic.
Author: Mary-Claire Helldorfer
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.4, VAPA D PreK-12.5

Title: Grace for President
Annotation: After finding out there has never been a female U.S. president, Grace decides to run in her school’s mock election. She learns about the American electoral system and sets out to be the best person for the job even though her opponent, Thomas, seems to be winning all the boys’ votes. The story includes information about the electoral college, number of votes per state, comparing votes, taking a poll, and so on. The writing style explains the process effectively for young readers while illustrations depict campaign details. California illustrator.
Author: Kelly DiPucchio

Title: Grain of Rice, A
Annotation: A clever, cheerful, hard-working farmer's son wishes to marry the emperor's daughter but the request is denied. When the princess takes ill, only he can cure her. As a payment he requests one grain of rice, doubled each day, for 100 days and soon becomes the richest man in China. This is an effective way to explain exponential growth.
Author: Helena Clare Pittman
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Mathematical Reasoning, Number Sense
Standard: Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.OA.1-3, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.MP.1-8, Math 6.NS.1-8, Math 6.EE.1-9, Math 6.MP.1-8

Title: Grand Mosque of Paris: A Story of How Muslims Rescued Jews During the Holocaust, The
Annotation: Jews and Muslims had lived peaceably in North Africa before World War II, so when both groups found themselves caught in Paris under the rule of Nazi Germany, it was natural for Muslims to reach out to their Jewish brothers during the holocaust. This book tells the story of how the Grand Mosque became a place of refuge for many people, including hundreds of Jews and Jewish children. Illustrated with stirring paintings rendered in dark colors.
Author: Karen Gray Ruelle
Topic: Diversity, Global Historical Events and Figures, Religion/Spirituality, War
Award: Orbis Pictus Award, Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: Grandfather Tang's Story
Annotation: Grandfather Tang tells a story about fox fairies from Chinese folklore who use geometry and magical powers to alternately change into predator and prey in a shape changing game. As he tells the story, he makes the animal shapes with tangrams. The illustrations have an oriental brushwork appearance and include both the animal and the tangram representation of the animal so students can create the changes with their tangram sets.
Author: Ann Tompert
Standard: HSS K.1, HSS 1.5, Math K.G.1-6, Math 1.G.1-3, Math 2.G.1-3, Math 3.G.1-2, Math 4.G.1-3, Math 5.G.1-6

Title: Grandfather's Journey
Annotation: This book is a powerful tribute to the author's grandfather. Brief text captions, sepia-toned portraits, and muted watercolors depict the grandfather's and author's trips between Japan and the United States and their love of both lands. Useful in lessons about history and family ties, this selection promotes intergenerational appreciation and understanding. California author/illustrator.
Author: Allen Say

Title: Grandma’s Gift
Annotation: An autobiographical prequel to GRANDMA’S RECORDS (2001), this book recalls a special Christmas vacation spent by the author with his grandmother in Spanish Harlem. Eric and his grandmother shop for ingredients to prepare pasteles, her special Christmas Eve dish. Later, she takes him to the Metropolitan Museum of Art as part of a school assignment to view the painting “Juan de Pareja” by Diego Velasquez. The painting has a profound and lasting effect on Eric. Realistic oil paintings enhance the story.
Author: Eric Velasquez
Topic: Diversity, Immigration/Migration, Lifestyles Around the World

Title: Grandma’s Records
Annotation: A young man remembers summers spent with his grandmother in Spanish Harlem.  Her love of music, incredible record collection, and pride in her Dominican Republic heritage spill into his heart. The connection to his immigrant grandmother and her passion for music make a sweet story and a great read-aloud. Illustrated with full-color artwork.
Author: Eric Velasquez
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Grandmother's Pigeon
Annotation: The discovery of passenger pigeon hatchlings, thought to be extinct, in Grandmother's room after she departs on a voyage to Greenland causes a media sensation. Highly realistic acrylic and colored pencil illustrations accompany this gentle tale. Can be used as a read aloud when introducing units on endangered or extinct animals.
Author: Louise Erdrich

Title: Grandpa Green
Annotation: Great-Grandpa’s memories are failing. His “great-grandkid” narrates how fanciful topiary garden sculptures provide visual form for Great-Grandpa’s memories. This book can help children begin to understand old age. May also be used as a model or mentor text for older children who are learning to compose a memoir or a piece of humorous writing.
Author: Lane Smith

Title: Grandpa’s Face
Annotation: Tamika’s grandfather is a stage actor who practices changing his expression in front of a mirror before his performances. Tamika is frightened by Grandpa’s mad face. When she is playing with her food at dinner, an accident happens and Grandpa’s face changes. This well-crafted story of the bond between grandparent and child is highlighted with soft paintings. Read aloud when discussing family connections, discipline, and the difference between reality and make-believe.
Author: Eloise Greenfield
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, Personal and Community Health, Theatre

Title: Granny Torrelli Makes Soup
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Rosie and Bailey, the boy next door, have been best friends since infancy. When their friendship is strained because of a new girl in their neighborhood, Granny Torrelli knows just how to smooth over the rough spots. Readers will learn much about Italian cooking, family love, and friendship.
Author: Sharon Creech

Title: Grant Wood: The Artist in the Hayloft
Annotation: Presents several paintings by twentieth-century American artist Grant Wood, including “American Gothic,” and describes the influence of his childhood, family, and small-town life on his work. The text is large and succinct, and the pages are bright and appealing. Grant Wood’s paintings—included on each page—invite the reader to explore the artwork and the artist himself.
Author: Debra Foxley Leach
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3

Title: Grapes of Math: Mind-Stretching Math Riddles, The
Annotation: These engaging math riddles which are presented in verse encourage children to solve math problems using the visual clues. Bright digital illustrations challenge children to search for groups in order to become effective problem solvers. A helpful answer section is included in the back.
Author: Greg Tang
Topic: Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Mathematical Analysis, Mathematical Reasoning, Number Sense
Standard: I & E 7.7, Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3

Title: Graphic Alphabet
Annotation: This unique alphabet book uses computer imagery in which each letter of the alphabet interprets a single word. This book won the Caldecott Honor for striking, sophisticated artwork.
Author: David Pelletier

Title: Grass Sandals: The Travels of Basho
Annotation: This book follows the seventeenth-century poet, Basho, on a journey across Japan. Based on his journal of prose and poetry, this book is a reflection of what he saw on the journey and includes haiku composed by Basho. A Japanese character introduces each haiku.
Author: Dawnine Spivak

Title: Grassroots: Poems by Carl Sandburg
Annotation: Fourteen poems, written by one of America's premier poets, depict the life, activities, themes, and settings of the Midwest. The illustrations by award–winning painter Wendell Minor reflect both the beauty of the Midwest and the words of Carl Sandburg.
Author: Carl Sandburg
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Graveyards of the Dinosaurs: What It's Like to Discover Prehistoric Creatures
Annotation: This selection features the work of paleontologists from past and contemporary times and the dinosaur graveyards around the world where recent significant finds have been made. Facts and speculation about dinosaurs are combined to offer readers information about what lead or might have lead to the demise of dinosaurs 65 million years ago. Color photographs are supported by dramatic scenarios in full-page illustrations. Maps, diagrams, sidebars, chronologies, a glossary, and a bibliography are included. This book is part of the I Was There series.
Author: Shelley Tanaka

Title: Great American Mousical, The
Annotation: Presents the adventures of theater mice that live and work in a miniature world beneath Broadway. Characters include actors as well as the backstage pros. The story references Broadway musicals and includes a glossary.
Author: Emma Walton Hamilton, Julie Andrews
Standard: VAPA T PreK-12.1, VAPA T PreK-12.3

Title: Great Brain, The
Annotation: The witty and humorous schemes of Tom, alias the Great Brain of Adenville, Utah, are narrated by his seven-year-old brother John, who is often the victim of Tom's schemes. His narratives include imagination and exaggeration. This is the first book in The Great Brain series.
Author: John D. Fitzgerald

Title: Great Divide, The
Annotation: Eighty people begin a bicycle race in the Great Divide, but each new challenge divides the number of racers in half. Through the bright acrylic illustrations and the rhyming text, the author demonstrates rather than describes the math.
Author: Dayle Ann Dodds

Title: Great Fire, The
Annotation: Dramatic text, eyewitness accounts, double-page spread of maps, photographs, and illustrations bare the facts surrounding Chicago's Great Fire of 1871. The author integrates the fire science behind the successive events that destroyed the city. It goes on to describe the rebuilding of the city. An index and a bibliography accompany the engrossing text.
Author: Jim Murphy
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Great Frog Race and Other Poems, The
Annotation: These poems deal with many familiar aspects of indoor and outdoor life, such as frogs and dragonflies, wind and rain, a visit to the tree farm, and the garden hose. Warm oil painting illustrations of the rural landscape illustrate the thoughts in the poem. California author.
Author: Kristine O'Connell George
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: Great Gilly Hopkins, The
Annotation: Gilly, a foster child, has been angry, lonely, and hurting for so long that she is always ready to fight anyone who tries to be friendly. She begrudgingly accepts love from her guardian, Trotter, and a freaky kid in a foster home, giving her the strength to face tough days ahead. This book reflects contemporary language used by the story's defiant character.
Author: Katherine Paterson

Title: Great Graph Contest, The
Annotation: Gonk and Beezy, two amphibian friends, hold a contest to see who can make better graphs. This book's lively text, contained in dialogue and thought balloons, is well supported by vivid cartoon illustrations. The story is informative, and instruction is provided at the end of the book, where each graph's data collection and construction are carefully explained. Page references are provided.
Author: Loreen Leedy

Title: Great Kapok Tree: A Tale of the Amazon Rain Forest, The
Annotation: This book tells the story of what happens when the rain forest is destroyed. Animals living in the kapok tree whisper the importance of the rain forest ecosystem in the ears of a sleeping tree cutter. Watercolor illustrations accompany the text.
Author: Lynne Cherry

Title: Great Math Tattle Battle, The
Annotation: Harley is the best math student in second grade, but he spends a lot of time keeping track of others’ behavior and writing notes to report on that behavior. Because of his tattling, Harley has no friends. When Emma Jean joins the class, Harley meets his match and learns that it is better to work with a partner. Use as an introduction to data gathering and graphing. Harley’s tattletale data provide good opportunities to add, average, find the rate, and add time. The story ends with Math Tattle Battle Teasers— math problems based on the story.
Author: Anne Bowen

Title: Great Moon Hoax, The
Annotation: In 1835, to increase sales of newspapers, the New York Sun printed fake articles about bizarre inhabitants on the moon, supposedly observed by scientists through a powerful new telescope. Newsboys Jake and Charlie are fascinated by the story and benefit from the increased newspaper sales. They are disappointed when the truth is revealed. The story includes actual details published by the New York Sun. An author’s note is included.
Author: Stephen Krensky

Title: Great Number Rumble: A Story of Math in Surprising Places, The
Annotation: When mathematics is cut from the school curriculum, Sam sets out to prove that math is a part of everything. He debates the director of education and explains triangles and ratios in bikes; the math of shooting a basket; and elements of math in art, music, science, puzzles, topology, and much more. Includes sidebars with information about special math and biographies of mathematicians. The book ends with a glossary, additional resources for further learning, and an index.
Author: Cora Lee, Gillian O'Reilly
Standard: Math 5.OA.1-3, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 6.RP.1-3, Math 6.NS.1-8, Math 6.SP.1-5, Math 7.RP.1-3, Math 7.NS.1-5, Math 7.G.1-7, Math 7.SP.1-8

Title: Great Poochini, The
Annotation: Full of word play, such as "Maestro Pawvarotti, "Dog Giovanni," and "Muttropolitan Opera House," this is the humorous story about "Poochini," a dog who, by day, is an ordinary dog, and by night performs as a opera star. Amusing and detailed full-color illustrations.
Author: Gary Clement

Title: Great Show-and-Tell Disaster, The
Annotation: Ned’s show-and-tell item is a Word Mix-Up Ray that turns a regular school day into chaos. Objects are transformed into anagrams of themselves: a bus becomes a submarine (a “sub”), and Mrs. Eton, the teacher, becomes a monster. Perfect for talking about letter arrangement in words, this book would serve as a good introduction to wordplay for older readers. Illustrated with cartoon-style artwork.
Publisher: Penguin Putnam Books for Young Readers
Author: Mike Reiss

Title: Great Trash Bash, The
Annotation: The animal citizens of Beaston discover solutions to control their trash and learn to recycle. Leedy's humorous cartoonlike  illustrations assist in making this an entertaining introduction to ecological principles.
Author: Loreen Leedy
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Great Turkey Walk, The
Annotation: This is a hilarious story about fifteen-year-old Simon, who resolves to walk 1,000 turkeys from Missouri to Denver, Colorado. He may not be too bright, but he figures he can make his fortune by buying turkeys for a quarter apiece and selling them in Denver for $5 each. The story is based in truth - there really were turkey drives in the American West. It is a great story to read aloud.
Author: Kathleen Karr

Title: Great Unknown, The
Annotation: The excavation and display of a mastodon in rural New York in 1799 is chronicled as the efforts of the artist and paleontologist Charles Willson Peale are described. The carefully-researched paintings showing the excavation and assembling of the body of the extinct animal are well executed in somber earth tones.
Author: Taylor Morrison

Title: Great Wall of Lucy Wu, The
Annotation: Lucy Wu has her sixth-grade year all planned out. Her sister is going to college, so Lucy will now have a room of her own, and she is looking forward to playing basketball again. But then her parents insist that she sign up for Chinese school, which conflicts with basketball. When Lucy finds out that Yi Po, her great aunt, is coming for an extended visit from China, Lucy learns that she will have to share her room with her aunt—and her plans for the perfect year are shattered.
Author: Wendy Shang

Title: Greatest Skating Race: A World War II Story from the Netherlands, The
Annotation: During World War II, in German-occupied Holland, ten-year-old Piet dreams of someday participating in the most famous Dutch ice-skating race, the Elfstendentocht. Because of Piet’s skating ability, he is asked to guide two children over the canals to Belgium, where they will be free. The story follows the children on a journey fraught with danger as they are stopped and questioned by German soldiers.
Author: Louise Borden

Title: Green Air
Annotation: Set in an Australian rain forest this story chronicles the life cycle and times of Silus, a Southern Platypus Frog, a rare frog species which gave birth through the mouth but has been missing since 1981. The striking illustrations are photographs of three-dimensional, hand-built clay sculptures which add to the realism of the story.
Author: Jill Morris

Title: Green Dog: A Mostly True Story, The
Annotation: This story is based on the author's childhood in northeastern Pennsylvania and tells the story of Jeff, a black-and-white dog who comes into a young girl's life as a stray. Love between them is instant, but after awhile it is apparent that Jeff has a nose for trouble and tough decisions must be made.
Author: Suzanne Fisher Staples

Title: Green Donkey, The
Annotation: Written in traditional Chinese, this collection of very special poems includes Chinese tongue-twisters. Children will enjoy the amusing poems while practicing rhyming and pronunciation skills.
Author: Tzu Jung Li

Title: Greetings from Antarctica
Annotation: Using a scrapbook-type layout, the author describes her experiences living and working in Antarctica in a series of letters to her godson. Along with her personal experiences of living and traveling, she also tells about the history, topography, wildlife and climate in an informal style. The book is illustrated with photographs of her adventures accompanied by fact-filled captions.
Author: Sara Wheeler

Title: Greetings from Planet Earth
Annotation: In 1977, Theo is learning about Voyager 2 and thinking about what he would write in a message from Earth launched into space. The story is written in a combination of third-person narrative and first-person reflections in a school report. Family secrets are explored as Theo wonders why his mother refuses to talk about his father, who served in Vietnam.
Author: Barbara Kerley

Title: Grizzly Gazette, The
Annotation: In this educational and entertaining title, young readers learn about using percentages in daily life, through the story of campers who elect a mascot at Camp Grizzly. Detailed cartoon-style illustrations contribute to the fun in this learning experience about voting and the concept of math. The last section includes activities, suggestions for further learning, and a reading list of other books that deal with similar concepts. This book is a part of the Math Start series.
Author: Stuart J. Murphy

Title: Growing Patterns: Fibonacci Numbers in Nature
Annotation: Colorful photographs and clear, catchy text in this interactive picture book introduce readers to the Fibonacci sequence in an engaging way. Photographs of pinecones, pineapples, and sunflowers help illustrate the concept. Readers are engaged in the process of discovering the pattern by the repeated question, “Can you count . . .?” This math and science book will engage young children as well as more mature readers.
Author: Sarah C. Campbell
Illustrator: Richard P Campbell, Sarah C. Campbell
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Mathematics, Visual Arts, Mathematical Reasoning
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, Mathematics, Science

Title: Growing Up Wild: Penguins
Annotation: This engaging photo-essay shows the life cycle of Adelie penguins. Bright, full-color photographs accompany the clearly written text, giving young readers an accessible view of the penguin chicks as they grow and develop. The book includes an author's note, a glossary, and an index.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: Guess How Much I Love You
Annotation: Simple and charming profiles illustrated in watercolors with pen and ink portray the bedtime ritual of Little Nut Brown Hare and Big Nut Brown Hare as they share the immeasurable love between a parent and child.
Author: Sam McBratney

Title: Guests
Annotation: Unhappy that his father has invited strangers with white faces to take the harvest feast, Moss takes his away-time alone in the forest, beginning his journey into adulthood. Although this book appears simple, careful reading is needed.
Author: Michael Dorris

Title: Guinea Pig Scientists: Bold Self-Experimenters in Science and Medicine
Annotation: This title relates the true stories of ten scientists and medical researchers who endured extreme hardship and discomfort in order to test new discoveries and inventions in the fields of medicine and science. Each chapter ends with a listing of the facts that have been uncovered by their work. This book can serve as a read-aloud introduction to science lessons. Black-and-white sketches illustrate the text.
Author: Leslie A. Dendy
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Gulls, Gulls, Gulls
Annotation: This book provides an overview of the world of gulls, briefly introducing general information about the species. The main body of the book focuses on the herring gull, almost extinct and now found in numerous locations in North America. Illustrations and the text present basic, easy-to-understand facts. Habitat, physical characteristics, and behaviors are discussed with just the right amount of detail for young readers - informing them without confusing them. The format is appealing, featuring framed, simply drawn watercolor illustrations that show the birds against a bright, colorful seashore or against seascape backgrounds of blues and greens. Appendixes include illustrations of other gulls native to North America, labeled with their names, and range area, and other facts.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Guns for General Washington: A Story of the American Revolution
Annotation: During the cold, harsh winter of 1775–76, Colonel Henry Knox and his younger brother Will, both of the Continental Army, decide to help the American Patriots defend themselves against the British Navy. They develop a daring plan to move 183 cannons from Fort Ticonderoga over 300 miles of mountainous wilderness to help General George Washington defend Boston.
Author: Seymour Reit
Award: Outstanding Books for the College Bound

Title: Guts: Our Digestive System
Annotation: Simon shares all the important details of our digestive system, using large, clear, photographs. The book begins with the teeth, esophagus, and stomach, then winds its way through the small and large intestines. The importance of the pancreas and liver along the way is discussed. Colored X-rays, computer-generated pictures, and microscopic photos help the reader make sense of this topic. The material is detailed, and the terminology may be difficult for children with no background on the topic, but students will find the book fascinating.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Guys Write for Guys Read
Annotation: A collection of short stories and other pieces written for boys by a variety of authors and illustrators as requested by the editor, Jon Scieszka. They are mostly anecdotes from childhood memories. Each entry includes a short biography, which will make it easier for readers to find books written by the featured contributors. Includes occasional black-and-white illustrations. The humorous subject matter makes this a fine choice for reluctant readers.
Author: Jon Scieszka (editor)

Title: Hacha, El (Hatchet)
Annotation: Following the heart attack and death of the pilot taking him to join his father in the north woods, young Brian must learn to survive in the wilderness. Finding his own niche in the woodland biome, he gains self-confidence and an awareness of his own courage and strength. This adventure is a popular choice for reluctant readers. Paulsen's other novels about Brian include BRIAN'S WINTER, BRIAN RETURNS, and THE RIVER.
Author: Gary Paulsen

Title: Hachiko Waits
Annotation: Based on the true story of an Akita dog named Hachiko, who became a national symbol of loyalty and hope in Japan. For 10 years, the dog waited each day at a commuter train station for his master to return, not knowing that his human companion had died of a heart attack at work. Hachiko returned every day at three o'clock to welcome his master. After the dog’s death, a statue in his memory was erected near his customary spot on the train-station platform.
Author: Leslea Newman
Topic: World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Hachiko: The True Story of a Loyal Dog
Annotation: A dog that accompanied his master to and from a Tokyo train station for a year continues to wait for him there every day for many years after the master dies. The elegant watercolor artwork adds to this straightforward and moving tale. A good book to read aloud.
Author: Pamela S. Turner

Title: Hailstones and Halibut Bones
Annotation: Originally published in 1961 and revised with new artwork in 1989, this edition features vivid full-color illustrations. The poems are the same, written in rich rhythmic language that describes all the components of the rainbow of colors around us.
Author: Mary O'Neill
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Half Spoon of Rice: A Survival Story of the Cambodian Genocide
Annotation: This picture book for older readers describes the Khmer Rouge’s reign of terror from the perspective of a young Cambodian boy. He struggles to survive after being taken from his home and family and forced to work in a child labor camp. The boy faces mistreatment, starvation, and loneliness. In the end, he finds his way to a refugee camp in Thailand, is reunited with his parents, and eventually emigrates with his family to San Francisco. California author.
Author: Icy Smith
Topic: Diversity, Global Historical Events and Figures, Global Social Issues, Government and Politics, Immigration/Migration, War, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Hana in the Time of the Tulips
Annotation: In seventeenth-century Holland, the buying and selling of tulips was a huge craze and business opportunity. Hana’s Papa succumbs to “tulipmania,” making a living as a tulip broker. When the market fails, family friend Rembrandt gives Hana advice. In the end, it is Hana who shows Papa what is truly valuable. Illustrated with lush acrylic artwork that mimics the beauty of the Dutch Master’s paintings. This is a fine choice for introducing Rembrandt and his time period.
Author: Deborah Noyes
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4

Title: Handel, Who Knew What He Liked
Annotation: A man who would compose some of the world’s most beautiful music is shown as a stubborn little boy with a mind of his own. Lively text and appealing illustrations will attract readers of all ages. Includes music terminology, chronology, and discography.
Author: M. T. Anderson
