Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.3

Title: Handful of Dirt, A
Annotation: The nature and importance of soil is presented accompanied by large full-color photographs showing the myriad creatures living there. The process by which soil is created and the forms of life it supports are explained. The book concludes with directions for setting up a compost pile.
Author: Raymond Bial

Title: Hannah
Annotation: Because she is blind, nine-year-old Hannah finds that her world is confined to the family home and weekly visits to church. Set in 1887 Michigan, when the Braille method of reading and writing is new to America, Hannah's life is profoundly changed by a teacher who boards with her family and convinces them to allow Hannah to attend school and learn Braille.
Author: Gloria Whelan

Title: Hannah Pritchard: Pirate of the Revolution
Annotation: After her parents and brother are killed by Loyalists during the Revolutionary War, Hannah leaves the farm and, disguised as a boy, joins a privateer ship that preys on other ships to get supplies for the American Revolution. An adventure story that weaves a realistic tale with American history.
Author: Bonnie Pryor

Title: Hanukkah at Valley Forge
Annotation: The presence of Jews in the American Revolution is the subject of this fictional encounter between General George Washington and a Polish immigrant fighting in the Continental Army. As Washington surveys his troops on a cold winter’s evening, he stops at a hut to watch a soldier light candles and recite a prayer. The man tells the general the story of the Maccabees and the miracle that Hanukkah celebrates. This story is based on a true incident. Illustrated with paintings.
Author: Stephen Krensky

Title: Happy Endings: A Story About Suffixes
Annotation: On the last day of school, Mr. Wright insists that his pupils study word endings. The students rudely rebel, and one day the worried word endings escape. Later, students must follow clues (words without suffixes and prefixes) to locate the missing word endings. The book includes rules and clues about adding suffixes to words. Full-color illustrations are painted in acrylic on canvas and digitally reproduced.
Author: Robin Pulver

Title: Happy Feet: The Savoy Ballroom Lindy Hoppers and Me
Annotation: In the mid-1930s, a young boy who loves to dance listens as his father retells the story of the night when his son was born, which coincided with the opening of the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem. He describes his encounters with famous people who danced at the Savoy and who came into his father’s shoe-shine shop. The artwork perfectly captures a bygone era. The book is a good choice for a discussion of music, dance, multiculturalism, and black history or as an introduction to historical fiction.
Author: Richard Michelson
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.4

Title: Happy Path, The
Annotation: This book received a Taiwanese Honor Award for its illustrations. This story is about a pond that grew after a rainstorm. The clever frogs used water lily pads to make a path for the other animals.
Author: ZhiMing Hong

Title: Happy, Happy Chinese New Year!
Annotation: Examines the customs, traditions, food, and lore associated with the celebration of Chinese New Year.
Author: Demi
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Religion/Spirituality, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Harlem
Annotation: This poetry book reveals the richness and diversity of the African American experience through verses filled with hope and "colors loud enough to be heard." It is illustrated by the author's son.
Author: Walter Dean Myers
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Honor

Title: Harmonica, The
Annotation: A young boy’s harmonica, a gift from his father, sustains him and other people living in a German concentration camp during World War II. Even their captors are soothed by the music of Schubert. The illustrations evoke warm memories of his Polish home but also capture the chilling brutality of the boy’s prison environment. This is a picture book for older readers. California author.
Author: Tony Johnston
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, International Studies/World History, Music, War
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3, HSS 10.8

Title: Harriet the Spy
Annotation: Intensely curious and intelligent, eleven-year-old Harriet M. Welsch aspires to become a writer and begins by keeping a secret notebook of her observations. When her friends discover the notebook, learn about her spying on them, and read her painfully blunt comments, they decide to teach Harriet a lesson. Harriet talks to a psychiatrist, who convinces her to channel her abilities along more constructive lines.
Author: Louise Fitzhugh

Title: Harrowing Ascent of Half Dome
Annotation: Describes a breathtaking adventure involving ten-year-old twins James and Morgan Parker as their family goes to Yosemite National Park for a vacation. Includes drawings, photographs, and facts about the history, geology, plants, and animals of the region. The children write in their diaries, describing their thoughts, as the dialogue tells the story. An excellent read-aloud to introduce the mountain region.
Author: Mike Graf

Title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone
Annotation: The exciting experiences of Harry Potter are described as he goes from being an ordinary boy to being an unusual student at Hogwarts School for Witchcraft and Wizardry. This story is highly useful as a read-aloud book as well as for independent reading. It is the first book in the series that includes HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, and HARRY POTTER AND THE GOBLET OF FIRE.
Author: J. K. Rowling

Title: Harry Potter y la camara secreta (Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets)
Annotation: This book explores Harry Potter's exploits during his second year at Hogwarts School for Witchcraft and Wizardry. The grotesque monster housed in the Chamber of Secrets and the rumor that Harry is the long-dreaded heir of Slytherin make life difficult for Harry. Some Spanish speakers from the Americas will be bothered by the Peninsular Spanish pronouns and conjugations. Translated by Adolfo Munoz and Nieves Martin Azofra.
Author: J. K. Rowling

Title: Harry Potter y la piedra filosofal (Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone)
Annotation: The exciting experiences of Harry Potter are described as he goes from being an ordinary boy to being an unusual student at Hogwarts School for Witchcraft and Wizardry. This story is highly useful as a read-aloud book as well as for independent reading. It is the first book in the series that includes HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, and HARRY POTTER AND THE GOBLET OF FIRE. Some Spanish speakers may be bothered by occasional Peninsular Spanish conjugations.
Author: J. K. Rowling

Title: Harvesting Hope: The Story of Cesar Chavez
Annotation: This picture book biography relates the life of Cesar Chavez and his efforts to organize the National Farm Workers Association to improve working and living conditions for migrant farm workers. The illustrations evoke the settings and the Hispanic culture. The Spanish version of this book is COSECHANDO ESPERANZA: LA HISTORIA DE CESAR CHAVEZ, translated from the English by F. Isabel Campoy and Alma Flor Ada. California author, illustrator, and setting.
Author: Kathleen Krull
Award: Christopher Award, John and Patricia Beatty Award, Pura Belpre Illustration Honor

Title: Hat Tricks Count: A Hockey Number Book
Annotation: This counting book helps young readers with counting skills and provides a rich background on the sport of hockey. The text is made available in two ways: one, an engaging poetic verse: the other, a narrative that gives information that will help children learn more about the world of hockey.
Author: Matt Napier

Title: Hatchet
Annotation: Following the heart attack and death of a pilot taking him to join his father in the north woods, a boy must learn to survive in the wilderness. Finding his own niche in the woodland biome, he gains self-confidence and an awareness of his own courage and strength. This adventure is appropriate for reluctant readers. See also BRIAN'S WINTER, BRIAN RETURNS, and THE RIVER.
Author: Gary Paulsen
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Hate That Cat
Annotation: In a sequel to LOVE THAT DOG (2001), Jack is in fifth grade with Miss Stretchberry and is learning more about writing poetry. He is grieving over the loss of his dog. In free verse he describes his tenuous new relationship with his Christmas gift: a furry black cat. Jack gradually reveals that his mother is deaf. At the end of the story, poems that inspire Jack are included, as are some of Jack’s original poems.
Author: Sharon Creech

Title: Have You Seen Bugs?
Annotation: Rhyming, alliterative text provides a detailed look at the variety of appearance, movement, and behavior of insects. Detailed three-dimensional paper sculptures enhance the text which weaves factual information into the verse. Use as a read-aloud introduction to insects and as a writing model for bug poems.
Author: Joanne Oppenheim

Title: Hearing
Annotation: This is one in a series about the senses and describes the parts of the ear and how they work. It also presents ways animals hear, how we maintain balance and more. The easy to understand text is illustrated with colorful diagrams and photographs that are captioned to match the text. Other books in the Explore Your Senses series are SIGHT, SMELL, TASTE, and TOUCH.
Author: Laurence P. Pringle

Title: Heart and Soul: The Story of America and African Americans
Annotation: An unnamed narrator, descended from slaves, tells the sweeping story of American history from the African American perspective. Beginning with the Colonial era and continuing through the election of the first black president, this inspiring narrative chronicles the admirable, tragic, and regrettable aspects of American history. The book is illustrated with 47 oil paintings, including six dramatic double-page spreads. California author and illustrator.
Author: Kadir Nelson
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.3, HSS 8.9, HSS 11.1, HSS 11.10
Award: Coretta Scott King Author Winner, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Honor

Title: Heat
Annotation: Twelve year-old Michael Arroyo is a star Little League pitcher who throws “heat” in New York City while dreaming of a professional career. When his father dies unexpectedly, he is left in the care of his seventeen-year-old brother Carlos. If social-services authorities find out, Michael could be taken from Carlos and perhaps sent back to Cuba. Michael does not have a birth certificate that can verify his age. When a rival coach challenges Michael’s age—and thus his eligibility to participate in Little League baseball—Michael tries to find a way to pitch in the New York Little League Championship.
Author: Mike Lupica

Title: Hecho en Mexico (Made in Mexico)
Annotation: This introduction to guitar making is illustrated with cut-paper collages, ribbon, strings, Mexican souvenirs, and wood shavings. The book tells about mariachis, guitars, and other aspects of Mexico, including the author's generalizations about poverty and economic issues in Mexico.
Author: Peter Laufer

Title: Heidi
Annotation: This 1996 edition presents the original text of the story of Heidi, the little girl who is taken from the city to live with her grandfather in the Swiss Alps. She meets Peter, the goatherd; Peter's family; Clara, who is confined to a wheelchair; and others. The text is enhanced with margin captions and pictures that explain the history, geography, culture, and customs of the time and setting of the story. This book is part of the Whole Story series, which includes THE ADVENTURES OF TOM SAWYER, AROUND THE WORLD IN EIGHTY DAYS, THE CALL OF THE WILD, THE JUNGLE BOOK, and TREASURE ISLAND.
Author: Johanna Spyri

Title: Helen Keller: Her Life in Pictures
Annotation: An illustrated photographic biography of Helen Keller, who became both deaf and blind as an infant. The large archival photos depict both the events of her life and her impact on the world. Braille letters and numbers are used throughout the book. Includes a foreword by Keller Johnson Thompson, great-grandniece of Helen Keller.  Miss Keller’s spirit is defined in a quotation from the book: “Never bend your head. Always hold it high. Look the world straight in the eye.”
Author: George Sullivan

Title: Helen Keller: The World in Her Heart
Annotation: Describes how Helen Keller used her working senses, including touch and smell, to explore the world around her. When she smells her favorite vanilla cake, feels her mother’s silk dress, and senses her dog tense with anticipation, Helen realizes something special is about to take place. A stranger arrives, and over time Helen begins to learn about the world thanks to her teacher, Annie Sullivan. Illustrated with striking oil paintings that detail Keller’s early life.
Author: Lesa Cline-Ransome
Topic: Diversity, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health

Title: Helen's Big World
Annotation: This picture book biography of Helen Keller tells the inspiring story of a woman who became blind and deaf as a toddler and grew up to become one of the most famous and admired women in the world.
Author: Doreen Rappaport
Topic: American History, Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures, Global Social Issues, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, Women’s Studies
Discipline: History/Social Science, English-Language Arts/General , English-Language Arts/Literary Elements

Title: Hello, Fish! Visiting the Coral Reef
Annotation: With simple, poetic text by an internationally known marine biologist, this concept book introduces 12 fish that occupy the waters around the coral reef. The full-page color photographs are spectacular. A map of the world's coral reefs is also included. This selection could be used in science units on ocean life and habitats.
Author: Sylvia A. Earle

Title: Hello, Red Fox
Annotation: A simple tale about a birthday party is designed as an introduction to complementary colors. Children are directed to see opposite colors by staring at images then glancing at a white page. The illustrations are bright, layered collage. Can be read aloud as an introduction for discussions on color. It includes a reproduction of the color wheel and a historical note.
Author: Eric Carle

Title: Henry and Beezus
Annotation: Henry Huggins is determined to buy a shiny red bike to outdo that show-off Scooter McCarthy. But selling bubble gum to the kids at school to earn money only brings Henry trouble. His good friend Beezus and her little sister, Ramona, are determined to help Henry earn the money for the bicycle. California author.
Author: Beverly Cleary

Title: Henry and the Buccaneer Bunnies
Annotation: Captain Barnacle Black Ear is frustrated by his nephew Henry, who refuses to help in “pirating” the Salty Carrot. Henry chooses to spend his time reading. But when a violent storm sweeps in, Henry’s book reading changes everything. This is an excellent read-aloud choice to begin the school year or simply to celebrate the value of literacy. Watercolor, gouache, and pencil illustrations complement the story.
Author: Carolyn Crimi

Title: Henry Climbs a Mountain
Annotation: This is the third in a series about a bear named Henry whose activities are based on incidents in the life of Henry David Thoreau. There are many faces of courage, and in this story Henry goes to jail rather than sacrifice his principles even though freedom is something he highly values. Others in the series are HENRY HIKES TO FITCHBURG and HENRY BUILDS A CABIN.
Author: D. B. Johnson

Title: Henry Hikes to Fitchburg
Annotation: Henry decides to walk to Fitchburg while his friend decides to earn the money to pay for transportation. The story works on several levels, as a math story involving time and money, and as a parable on the material and natural world. It is highlighted by bright geometric illustrations in a folk style and concludes with brief information about Henry David Thoreau.
Author: D. B. Johnson
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Mathematical Reasoning

Title: Henry's Freedom Box
Annotation: A fictionalized account of Henry “Box” Brown, a slave living in Virginia in 1849, who escapes to freedom by shipping himself in a wooden crate from Richmond to Philadelphia. This is an excellent read-aloud that connects to the study of the Underground Railroad, the history of slavery, and curriculum for middle and upper grades. Illustrated with pencil, watercolor, and oil. The artwork was inspired by a lithograph from the 1830s.
Author: Ellen Levine

Title: Her Seven Brothers
Annotation: This is a retelling of a Cheyenne legend in which a girl and her seven brothers become the stars in the constellation the Big Dipper. Illustrations in the Caldecott Medalist's recognizable style of detailed paintings are authentic in the representation of the Cheyenne culture. It can be read aloud to introduce units on Native Americans or the constellations.
Author: Paul Goble

Title: Her Stories: African American Folktales, Fairy Tales and True Tales
Annotation: This collection of stories about women drawn from African American cultural tradition tells tales of magic, the supernatural, and real life. The Dillons' stylized illustrations enhance reading aloud with groups of all ages.
Author: Virginia Hamilton

Title: Here Come the Girl Scouts! The Amazing All-True Story of Juliette “Daisy” Gordon Low and Her Great Adventure
Annotation: This biography of Girl Scout founder Juliette “Daisy” Gordon Low recounts her desire to inspire young women by establishing a culture of physical fitness, service in the community, and realized potential. The predominant greens, browns, and blues in the illustrations represent the Girl Scout colors, and the book’s inspirational quotes promote the ideals behind Juliette Gordon Low’s vision for young women.
Author: Shana Corey
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures, Women’s Studies

Title: Here Is the Wetland
Annotation: The wetland is a dark, moist, and mysterious world. Beneath the shadowy depths, birds, bass, minks, and muskrats struggle to survive and flourish. The relationships between the wetland’s inhabitants are described, giving young readers a clear picture of how each living creature depends on the others for survival. Illustrations include detailed paintings that portray the delicate beauty and complexity of this important ecological community.
Author: Madeleine Dunphy

Title: Here Lies the Librarian
Annotation: Set in 1914 in Indiana, this novel tells of fourteen-year-old Eleanor “Peewee” McGrath and her brother, who run an automobile repair shop. Four young women who are studying library science arrive in cars and are intent on reviving the town library. The library is closed because the stern librarian who ran the place “expired.” The book depicts small-town America during the early twentieth century, automobile racing, and early feminist issues. Wit and humor make this book fun to read and will lead readers to Richard Peck’s other titles.
Author: Richard Peck
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Women’s Studies

Title: Here We All Are
Annotation: The second book in an autobiographical series (“26 Fairmount Avenue”), this offering from Tomie dePaola shares stories of his childhood in Connecticut. His family moves into a new home, and a baby is on the way. Tomie takes tap-dancing lessons, performs in a play, and doesn’t always follow the rules in school. Delightful black-and-white drawings add to the fun in this charming slice of dePaola’s life. There are seven books in the series.
Author: Tomie dePaola

Title: Hero Schliemann: The Dreamer Who Dug for Troy, The
Annotation: During his lifetime (1822-90) Heinrich Schliemann was known as one of the world's greatest archaeologists. While he did make great discoveries, such as the lost city of Troy, he often embellished the truth and went against the law for his own gain. This story offers an example of the difference between conducting good scientific research and rushing to report results. The ink and watercolor illustrations are droll depictions of Schliemann's adventures. Notes, comments, and a bibliography are included.
Author: Laura Amy Schlitz

Title: Heroes
Annotation: A young Japanese American boy growing up in the 1960s wants to play football; instead, he experiences the legacy of war when his friends see him only as someone who looks like “the enemy” and therefore must play that part in their war games. This picture book for older readers should stimulate discussion about the true nature of heroism and the effects of “playing war.”
Author: Ken Mochizuki

Title: Heroes of the Surf
Annotation: This book is based on a true shipwreck and rescue that occurred in 1882, when a British steamship sailing from South America to New York was grounded on a shoal along the New Jersey coast. The story is told by Anthony, a young passenger who is keeping a journal of the voyage. He believes the ship is being overtaken by pirates—but those “pirates” are actually members of the United States Life-Saving Service, the precursor to the U.S. Coast Guard. Dramatic illustrations capture the power of the storm and the details of the rescue. An author’s note provides further information.
Author: Elisa Carbone

Title: Heroic Symphony, The
Annotation: Beethoven enjoyed great popularity as a pianist until his increasing deafness forced him to concentrate on composing rather than performing. Beethoven greatly admired Napoleon Bonaparte because he had overthrown a tyrant king, and thus the composer created a symphony in Napoleon’s honor. After Napoleon proclaimed himself emperor, Beethoven changed the dedication to “the hero that exists in all people.” Illustrated in a cartoon style with toile-style background featuring flowers and images of peasant life. Includes a CD of the symphony.
Author: Anna Harwell Celenza
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.2

Title: Hey World, Here I Am!
Annotation: This collection of poems and brief vignettes is presented from the perspective of Kate Bloomfield, a fictitious character. She comments on her life, being Jewish, school, turning cartwheels, and life in general. The lengths of the vignettes make them excellent for teaching comprehension skills and conducting discussions.
Author: Jean Little

Title: Hickory Chair, The
Annotation: Warm illustrations support the story of a blind boy and his close relationship with his grandmother and the gift she leaves him after her death. This story reverberates deeper and truer than what can merely be seen as Louis and his Gran read together in the cozy hickory chair.
Author: Lisa Rowe Fraustino

Title: Hidden Forest, The
Annotation: When a friend helps him retrieve the fishing trap he lost while trying to fish just off the coast of eastern Tasmania, Ben comes to see the Giant Kelp forest where he lost his fishing trap in a new light. The collage artwork combines pressed seaweed, sponges, and sand. An author's notes gives information about kelp forests including how they grow and their habitat.
Author: Jeannie Baker

Title: Hidden Worlds: Looking Through a Scientist's Microscope
Annotation: The work of two scientists, a microscopist and a biologist, is explored as they describe how microscopic images are produced and used. The book is illustrated with photographs of various specimens. The description, application, and procedural use of various microscopes are discussed. See other books in the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Stephen P. Kramer

Title: Hijo del sol: Una leyenda cubana (Child of the Sun: A Cuban Legend)
Annotation: The Ciboney people of Cuba explain the phenomenon of an eclipse, as personified by Greedy Sun's refusal to share the sky with Moon in this Latin American legend. Bold watercolors add interest to the legend, and basic information about the country is provided in the afterword.
Author: Sandra Arnold

Title: Hill of Fire
Annotation: Based on an actual eruption of the Paricutin Volcano in Mexico, this short chapter book in an easy-to-read format tells the story of a farmer and his son and how they escaped the fire and smoke.
Author: Thomas Lewis

Title: Hip-Pocket Papa
Annotation: The male Australian hip-pocket frog, no bigger than an adult human’s thumbnail, protects his offspring in hidden pouches on his hips as they grow from tadpoles to young froglets. The lyrical text, accompanied by watercolor illustrations, explains how the tiny amphibians transition from egg to frog over a period of 30 days in the Australian rainforest. The book includes a glossary, an author’s note, and a list of additional information sources.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: History of Counting, The
Annotation: This book, written by an archaeologist, traces the history of counting. Readers will enjoy the evolution of counting through the creative collaboration of history, mathematics, and literature. The book is illustrated with full-color acrylic paintings. A glossary is included.
Author: Denise Schmandt-Besserat

Title: History of Zero: Exploring Our Place-Value Number System, The
Annotation: Why does zero matter? Find out in this book, which compares counting systems.
Author: Tika Downey

Title: Hmm? The Most Interesting Book You'll Ever Read About Memory
Annotation: Students will discover many interesting and surprising facts about their memory: how it works, why it falters, how to sharpen it, and the nature of memories. Bright illustrations highlight this mix of factual information, anecdotes, and activities. See other books in the Mysterious You series.
Author: Diane Swanson

Title: Hokusai: The Man Who Painted a Mountain
Annotation: An illustrated exploration of the life and work of famous Japanese artist Hokusai. The author emphasizes Hokusai’s passion for creating art, his rise from the peasant class into which he was born, and his prolific career. Includes some reproductions of his artwork, sketchbook pages reproduced on the endpapers, and a spread devoted to a famous woodblock print.
Author: Deborah Kogan Ray
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Hombre de otra galaxica, El (The Man from the Other Galaxy)
Annotation: Javier and his classmates believe they've seen a traveler from another galaxy. They begin an adventure to find out whether or not they truly have seen such a traveler…or astronaut from another universe.
Author: Carlos Guillermo Dominguez
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Hombrecillo de papel, El (The Newspaper Man)
Annotation: A paper doll comes to life. He is full of stories about disease, famine, and war. When all his newsprint is washed off, his pages are refilled with happier tales.
Author: Fernando Alonso
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Global Social Issues, War

Title: Home
Annotation: Through a window, this wordless picture book shows the changes of an urban neighborhood over the years, reflecting urban decay, and shows how neighbors and nature can, over time, transform the blight into a wild and beautiful place. Miniature collages made with natural materials are full of details and create a three-dimensional effect.
Author: Jeannie Baker

Title: Home for Mr. Emerson, A
Annotation: Before Ralph Waldo Emerson was a great writer, he was a city boy who longed for the broad, open fields and deep, still woods of the country, and then a young man who treasured books, ideas, and people. When he grew up and set out in the world, he wondered, could he build a life around these things he loved?
Author: Barbara Kerley

Title: Home on the Range: John A. Lomax and His Cowboy Songs
Annotation: The life of John Lomax, the famous chronicler of American folk music, is presented in a picture-book biography, highlighted with the words of some of the most famous songs he collected. Growing up on a farm in Texas, young John heard songs that the cowboys made up to pass the long hours in the saddle and the cold nights. After spending time at the University of Texas, he set out with a notebook and a recording machine to search for examples of America’s folk music. An author’s note provides additional information about Lomax and his adventures.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson

Title: Home Run, The Story of Babe Ruth
Annotation: This book recounts the life of Babe Ruth, the man and the legend, in poetic prose and conveys the excitement of a baseball game in which he played. Vintage-style replicas of baseball cards highlight his career. The illustrations are reminiscent of some of Norman Rockwell's artwork.
Author: Robert Burleigh
Topic: American History, Motor Skills/Movement Patterns, Physical Fitness
Discipline: History/Social Science, Physical Education, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Home to Medicine Mountain
Annotation: This book relates the real-life experiences of the illustrator's Native American father and uncle, who were sent hundreds of miles from their home in Northern California to attend a government-run boarding school in Southern California. Homesickness, rebellion against their regimented life, and an unwillingness to unlearn their traditional ways lead the boys to hitch an unauthorized train ride home. The illustrations are executed in dark, somber tones that reflect both the harsh conditions at the boarding school and the suspense of the boys' escape to freedom. California author, illustrator, and setting.
Author: Chiori Santiago

Title: Homer Price
Annotation: The life of Homer Price is captured in six classic episodes, including one in which he and his pet skunk capture four bandits and another about a donut machine on the rampage. Young readers love the humor of his antics and escapades. Also available on audiocassette.
Author: Robert McCloskey

Title: Homesick: My Own Story
Annotation: The author tells of her youth in 1920s China with the use of family photographs. She recounts detailed memories of picnics on the Great Wall, holidays in the foreign compound, her rebelliousness in British school, and her reaction to being the object of hostility as a foreigner. "Homesick" is how Fritz felt about America, a place she'd never seen, after hearing about her parents' memories and reading letters from relatives in Pennsylvania.
Author: Jean Fritz

Title: Homespun Sarah
Annotation: Written in verse, this is the story of Sarah who lives in Pennsylvania in the early eighteenth century. Sarah is in need of a new dress because she is outgrowing her only dress. The steps for making clothes are presented: the sheep is shorn, the dye is made, the cloth is woven, and a new dress is sewn and fitted. Author's note explains how different it was to be a child living in Colonial times. California author.
Author: Verla Kay

Title: Honest-to-Goodness Truth, The
Annotation: After promising never to tell another lie, a young girl learns that it isn't a good idea to blurt out the whole truth, either. She discovers that goodness is an important part of being honest. The book is useful for emphasizing character education. Illustrated with pastel watercolor and ink artwork.
Author: Patricia C. McKissack

Title: Honey, I Love and Other Love Poems
Annotation: This delightful collection of rhythmic poems is about things the poet loves and includes a powerful poem about Harriet Tubman. Most of the poems are written from a child's point of view, with illustrations depicting African Americans. This book is useful to inspire students to write their own poetry.
Author: Eloise Greenfield

Title: Honky-Tonk Heroes and Hillbilly Angels: The Pioneers of Country and Western Music
Annotation: This picture book profiles important and influential performers of country and western music, including the Carter Family, Roy Acuff, Gene Autry, Bill Monroe, Patsy Cline, and Loretta Lynn. Each portrait contains a basic biography that includes titles of songs associated with the artist and additional facts about the musicians.
Author: Holly George-Warren

Title: Honus and Me
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Joe, while cleaning out Miss Young's attic, finds the world's most valuable baseball card picturing Honus Wagner. Joe falls asleep wrestling with the thought of telling her about the card. Then he wakes up in the night to see Wagner in his bedroom, and they travel back in time to the 1909 World Series. Black-and-white photographs of Wagner and the World Series add authenticity to the novel. The book is part of the Baseball Card Adventure series
Author: Dan Gutman

Title: Hoofbeats, Claws and Rippled Fins: Creature Poems
Annotation: Hopkins commissioned 13 poets to write poems to match the eloquence of Alcorn's animal portraits, which are rendered in relief-block prints. Most of the poems are free verse, and subjects include the porcupine, frog, camel, and iguana. This is a lovely integration of science, art, and poetry.
Author: Lee Bennett Hopkins
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, Science

Title: Hooray for Inventors!
Annotation: Famous and not-so-famous inventors and inventions from the earliest times to the present are presented in this cartoon-style informational book. Although the text is brief, facts and details abound. Inventions include the printing press, the ball point pen, legos, hula hoops, and many more. The book even has a section featuring women inventors as well as some of the author's favorite inventions.
Author: Marcia Williams

Title: Hope Chest, The
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Violet runs away from home in 1918 and takes the train to New York City to find her older sister, who is a suffragist. Along the way, Violet meets Myrtle, a young African American orphan who is escaping her environment. On their journey the girls must deal with racism and sexism; however, the author provides enough humor to soften the weighty topics. The girls end up in Nashville, Tennessee, where “Suffs” and “Antis” are gathered, awaiting the crucial vote on the Nineteenth Amendment. The book gives an excellent view of the customs and manners of the early twentieth century. Includes historical notes, archival photographs, and a time line on voting in America.
Author: Karen Schwabach
Topic: American History, Diversity, Government and Politics, Law and Legal Studies, Women’s Studies

Title: Horse Song: The Naadam of Mongolia
Annotation: Describes the landscapes, people, and activities of Mongolia, including the annual summer festival where child jockeys ride half-wild horses for miles across the steppes. This is a striking view of a rare culture and an event that will pique the interest of young readers. Illustrated in the signature style of the authors.
Author: Betsy Lewin, Ted Lewin
Topic: Diversity, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Horseshoe Crabs and Shorebirds: The Story of a Food Web
Annotation: Descriptive text tells a story of Delaware Bay and the variety of animals that create a food web. The narrative is engaging and enhanced by watercolor paintings that show the life-cycle of the horseshoe crab and how it is integral to the food web. Includes an author's note warning of a decline of horseshoe crabs and how the decline could affect shorebirds that depend on crab eggs as they migrate north.
Author: Victoria Crenson

Title: Hot Air: The (Mostly) True Story of the First Hot-Air Balloon Ride
Annotation: This book tells the story of the successful 1783 liftoff of a hot-air balloon invented by two French brothers. The passengers, a duck, a sheep, and a rooster, provide a hilarious, slap-stick adventure. Rich watercolor illustrations provide a beautiful design and perspective to this simple tale.
Author: Marjorie Priceman

Title: Hot Day on Abbott Avenue
Annotation: It’s a “fat-sun-in-the-sky” summer day. Miss Johnson says it is the kind of day when tempers will flare and trouble will happen. All of the kids are singing and double-dutch jumping when the ice-cream truck shows up. A huge fight ensues over the last blue popsicle. Rene and Kishi discover that being hot can lead to being hot-headed. This is an excellent book to share when discussing the value of friendship. Illustrated with found objects and cut-paper collages that are a signature of Javaka Steptoe.
Author: Karen English
Topic: Diversity, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, Nutrition and Physical Activity, Physical Fitness, Women’s Studies

Title: Hot Jazz Special
Annotation: With vibrant text and illustrations, this book presents an introduction to jazz and some of the most important musicians in jazz history. A double-page spread is devoted to each musician, including a portrait and bits of hand-lettered information.
Author: Jonny Hannah

Title: Hotel Deep: Light Verse from Dark Water
Annotation: A host of ocean animals are introduced to the reader as a lone sardine searches for its lost school in the depths of a coral reef. The verse is lively, and often hints of the dangers hidden in from the little sardine. Glowing illustrations with text often woven around the deep sea underwater life will hold the reader's interest.
Author: Kurt Cyrus

Title: House Baba Built: An Artist’s Childhood in China, The
Annotation: Born in 1931, Caldecott Medal winner Ed Young describes his childhood home in Shanghai, China—a house built by his father during the mid-1930s. Young reflects on fond memories of playing at home while guests moved in to seek safety from the war in China. The illustrated memoir includes collages, foldout pages, photographs of family and friends, an afterword, time line, map of Shanghai, diagram of the house, and an author’s note. An ALA Notable Children’s Book (2012).
Author: Ed Young
Topic: Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Ethnic Studies, International Studies/World History, Lifestyles Around the World, War

Title: House of Dies Drear
Annotation: When Tom Small and his parents move to a large old house in Ohio, they know that it carries a mysterious history as a station for the Underground Railroad during the Civil War. They soon learn about are the secrets and dangers left behind by the ghosts of the past. This is the first book of the Dies Drear Chronicle.
Author: Virginia Hamilton

Title: House of Wisdom
Annotation: Ishaq traveled the known world from ancient Baghdad to bring precious books and manuscripts to the Caliph and his great library known as the House of Wisdom. The illustrations evoke the Islamic world by using borders and framed boxes reminiscent of old Islamic books. This selection is an excellent resource for the study of ancient civilizations.
Author: Florence Parry Heide

Title: How a Seed Grows
Annotation: In simple, clear text this book describes how a seed gets water, nutrients, and sunlight and highlights the life cycle of a bean plant. It offers instruction on how to plant bean seeds in eggshells and encourages the reader to observe their development. The bright detailed pictures dramatize how a little seed may become a flower, a vegetable, or even a huge oak tree. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out Science series.
Author: Helene J. Jordan

Title: How Artists See the Elements: Earth, Air, Fire, Water
Annotation: This title shows how earth, air, fire, and water have been depicted in works of art from different time periods and places. The text is engaging and conversational. This is one title in a series which teaches children about the world by looking at art. Other titles in the How Artists See series are HOW ARTISTS SEE ANIMALS: MAMMAL, BIRD, FISH, REPTILE and HOW ARTISTS SEE THE WEATHER: SUN, WIND, SNOW, RAIN.
Author: Colleen Carroll
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: How Ben Franklin Stole the Lightning
Annotation: This title focuses on Ben Franklin's myriad scientific inventions, whimsical gadgets, practical contraptions, and experiment of flying a kite during a rainstorm. The narrative explains the historical context and the value of the lightning rod in saving lives. It is illustrated with brightly colored cartoon sketches that often depict Franklin in miniature.
Author: Rosalyn Schanzer

Title: How Can You Dance?
Annotation: In rhyming text, this book explores the many ways one can dance: like the leader of a marching band, like a crab on a sunny day, or like a tree as it waves in the breeze. Each page poses a question and has the answer. Bright, imaginative artwork portrays the multiethnic cast of children who long to dance.
Author: Rick Walton
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.4, VAPA D PreK-12.5

Title: How Dinosaurs Took Flight: Fossils, Science, What We Think We Know and Mysteries Yet Unsolved
Annotation: This overview looks at questions, examines evidence, and shows how scientists have come to conclusions about dinosaurs. It also introduces puzzles that are yet to be solved. The book provides a glimpse into ways in which scientists explore ideas as well as up-to-date information on the topic. This title is illustrated with full-color photographs and other artwork.
Author: Christopher Sloan

Title: How High Can a Dinosaur Count?: And Other Math Mysteries
Annotation: This delightful math mystery book presents ingenious math word problems. Lively, colorful illustrations give hints for all the solutions. further math questions extend math concepts, and the solutions to all the problems are included in the back of the book.
Author: Valorie Fisher

Title: How Hungry Are You?
Annotation: An ever-increasing group of children go on a picnic and find a way to divide the food that they all have contributed. Cleverly laid out with small thumbnail portraits identifying the speaker, this book can easily be used for reader's theatre. It offers a good introduction to simple division concepts.
Author: Donna Jo Napoli

Title: How I Learned Geography
Annotation: After his father brings home a world map instead of food, a young boy escapes the hunger and misery of refugee life by studying the map. The story is based on the author’s childhood in Kazakhstan, where he lived as a Polish refugee during World War II. The watercolor illustrations beautifully evoke the sparseness of refugee life in a strange city. The author has won the Caldecott Medal and two Caldecott Honor citations for his books.
Author: Uri Shulevitz
Topic: Geography, Global Social Issues, Government and Politics, Immigration/Migration, War

Title: How Many Ants in an Anthill
Annotation: This title looks at how scientists use math as a tool to understand data, identifies systems used to make measurements, and describes the situations in which the use of estimates is most practical. The topic of using measurement, scale, and interpreting data are discussed.
Author: Kate Boehm Jerome

Title: How Many Baby Pandas?
Annotation: Each two-page spread features full-color photographs of baby panda bears to be counted. Information about the panda’s first year of life is highlighted; the book discusses what cubs eat, how they play, and why they nap, among other topics. Helpful as a counting book and for information about pandas. The baby pandas were photographed at the Giant Panda Breeding Reserve in Wolong, China. Information about its breeding program is included.
Author: Sandra Markle
Grade Level Span: Preschool/Pre thru K, K thru 2, 3 thru 5

Title: How Many Candles
Annotation: A cat, a turtle, and two gnats tell Alex the dog how old they would be if their ages were calculated in people-years. The turtle can live to be a hundred while the gnats can't imagine living to ten. The question is how many candles should be on a ten-year-old boy's birthday cake? Cheerful illustrations in muted colors add to the humor of the story.
Author: Helen V. Griffith

Title: How Many Days to America?
Annotation: Forced to leave everything behind when they escape to America, a Caribbean family suffers many days of hardship, sickness, hunger, and thirst before safely arriving on Thanksgiving Day. This very meaningful story focuses on Thanksgiving Day as a holiday for celebrating freedom, faith, and courage. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: How Many Seeds in a Pumpkin?
Annotation: Students predict the number of seeds in pumpkins of all sizes. When the seeds are removed, the children work in groups to count them by twos, fives, and tens. Assumptions are questioned when a surprising result is shared. This book deals with predicting and estimating, justifying reasoning, and counting in different ways. It also involves science concepts. Interesting pumpkin facts are listed at the end of the book. The illustrations reflect a diverse classroom.
Author: Margaret McNamara
Topic: Diversity, Life Science (Biology), Mathematics, Number Sense
Standard: Math 1.MD.1-4, Math 1.MP.1-8, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 2.MP.1-8, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.MP.1-8

Title: How Many Ways Can You Catch a Fly?
Annotation: Readers are asked to guess how six different animals might hatch an egg, use a leaf, eat a clam, or dig a hole. In his trademark cut- and torn-paper collage illustrations, Jenkins provides double-page spreads showing close-up and detailed views of species, scientific facts, and connections between animals. Additional information about each of the animals is offered at the end of the book. An NSTA Outstanding Science Trade Book (2009).
Author: Steve Jenkins

Title: How Mountains Are Made
Annotation: A group of children go mountain climbing and discover clues about the formation and movement of the land. Fossils, Earth's layers, plate tectonics, and the wearing down of mountains are all unveiled to the reader. The bright illustrations show the forces and processes that mold mountains. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out-Science series.
Author: Kathleen Weidner Zoehfeld

Title: How Much Is a Million?
Annotation: The author stretches the vision of readers so they can see the relative size of very large numbers by using kids and goldfish as the unit of measure. The book ends with an explanation of how all of the calculations were done. It includes zany illustrations and a humorous text. This book is also available in Spanish.
Author: David M. Schwartz

Title: How My Parents Learned to Eat
Annotation: The child of an American sailor father and a Japanese mother explains why they sometimes use chopsticks and sometimes use a fork and knife to eat. Humor and a touch of insight into how people differ and how their daily habits are the same are found in this book.
Author: Ina R. Friedman

Title: How Oliver Olson Changed the World
Annotation: Oliver Olson, a third-grader, feels that he and the planet Pluto have a lot in common. His overprotective parents make all his decisions. But when his class begins a unit on astronomy, Oliver, with the encouragement of a fellow student named Crystal, asserts himself and changes his world. A fun and thought-provoking chapter book that would work well as a read-aloud for younger readers.
Author: Claudia Mills

Title: How Tall, How Short, How Far Away
Annotation: This is an introduction to the concept of measurement. It includes a lively discussion of several measuring systems such as the inch-pound system, the metric system, and the ancient Egyptian system which is based on the length of body parts. Bright cartoonlike illustrations are superimposed over montages of various measuring tools.
Author: David A. Adler

Title: How the Dinosaur Got to the Museum
Annotation: This story is set in motion when a boy in a museum asks, “So, how did the dinosaur actually get to the museum?” The reader gets a behind-the-scenes look at the Smithsonian as the story covers the 1923 discovery of a dinosaur in Utah and its eventual installation at the museum. The roles of the various people involved are also described. Child-like illustrations are filled with details.
Author: Jessie Hartland
Topic: Earth Science, English-Language Arts/General, Life Science (Biology)

Title: How the Farmer Tricked the Evil Demon
Annotation: A farmer uses traditional crops and farming techniques to outwit a demon who demands half of everything he grows. Full-page color paintings highlight the text.
Translator: Hmong: Ia Xiong; Vietnamese: Anh Nguyen
Author: Alice Lucas

Title: How the Forest Grew
Annotation: This book describes the gradual transformation of a cleared farm field into a forest. Naturalistic etchings by a California artist illustrate the book. Changes in the environment and the variety of plants and animals that live in specific habitats created by various stages of succession are described. California illustrator.
Author: William Jaspersohn

Title: How the Stars Fell into the Sky: A Navajo Legend
Annotation: In this poetic retelling of a Navajo legend, First Woman is determined to write the laws in the sky for the people to see. She foolishly asks for help from Coyote, the trickster, who simply flings the remaining stars into a jumble in the sky, creating chaos for all time. Jewel-like paintings in muted colors capture the desert at night and complement the tale.
Author: Jerrie Oughton

Title: How to Bake an American Pie
Annotation: A cat and a dog follow a unique recipe to make an American pie by using the attributes of America and Americans. The rhyming text includes phrases from “America the Beautiful” and is enhanced by whimsical full-page artwork. Use this read-aloud to introduce a unit on immigration.
Author: Karma Wilson

Title: How to Cross a Pond: Poems About Water
Annotation: Nineteen poems explore the many attributes of water, nature’s most basic element. Each double-paged presentation is complemented by a flurry of blue type and watercolor designs that convey the look, mood, and setting for each creation. The collection of poems provides a curricular bridge between a science unit and a language arts unit on poetry.
Author: Marilyn Singer
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: How to Eat Fried Worms
Annotation: Billy will win $50 if he wins the bet he made that he will eat 15 worms, one per day. This humorous book will gross out squeamish adults, but will delight young readers. This story reflects contemporary language.
Author: Thomas Rockwell

Title: How to Steal a Dog
Annotation: After being evicted from their apartment, Georgina, her brother Toby, and their mother are living in a car. Father abandoned them, leaving them only a roll of quarters and a jar filled with dollar bills. Georgina’s mother is working two jobs, and Georgina is desperate to figure out a way to help. She and Toby create a plan to steal a dog and collect the reward as a way to raise money for a new apartment. This is a tender and poignant story that shows Georgina’s strength and sense of humor.
Author: Barbara O’Connor

Title: How Underwear Got There
Annotation: An unusual exploration of the history of undergarments, explaining what people wore in times past and why. Provides humorous anecdotes and illustrations to enhance the information. In addition to covering the history of underwear, the book touches on a variety of other historical incidents and topics, including feminism, social status, and personal hygiene. Illustrated with a combination of period pictures and cartoon-style drawings.
Author: Kathy Shaskan
Topic: American History, Personal and Community Health

Title: How We Crossed the West: The Adventures of Lewis and Clark
Annotation: Nearly all of the text in this appealing book is taken from the diaries of Lewis and Clark, documenting their extraordinary expedition to the Pacific Ocean. The return trip is briefly summarized by the author at the end. Attractive acrylic illustrations are modeled on the style of American folk artists of the period. The illustrations depict many of the new species of animals and plants encountered by the expedition.
Author: Rosalyn Schanzer

Title: How Whales Walked into the Sea
Annotation: Through drawings and an easy-to-read text this book tells about the evolution of whales and their beginning as early land dwelling mesonychids, wolflike carnivores that had more success finding food in water than on land. Details of a variety of whale species' behavior and anatomy are included. The book is illustrated with mixed media paintings.
Author: Faith McNulty

Title: Huabtais Thiab Noog Nais Thees Nkaus (The Emperor and the Nightingale)
Annotation: This folktale with text in English and Hmong retells the story of an emperor who desires eternal life but slowly learns that some things are worth more than his wish to live forever. Translated by Pao Vang and Ter F. Yang.
Author: Kuang-Ts’ai Hao (reteller)

Title: Huesos y otras partes del cuerpo, Los (How it Works: Funny Bones)
Annotation: The human body is depicted as a collection of machines. Short blocks of text accompany double-page illustrations. It covers the body systems: digestion, circulation, respiration, and includes information on the senses.
Author: Anita Ganeri
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Human Alphabet, The
Annotation: The internationally renowned Pilobolus dance company brings to life the twenty-six letters of the alphabet. Ingenious grips, bends, and twists of the human form portray each letter in photographs. In a spirit of pure fun and experimentation, the agile dancers celebrate creativity, the body, and the human alphabet.
Author: Pilobolus
Grade Level Span: Preschool/Pre thru K, K thru 2, 3 thru 5
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.2

Title: Hummingbird Nest: A Journal of Poems
Annotation: When a mother hummingbird builds a nest in a tree on the patio of the author’s California home, the author keeps a journal as she and her family watch and record the actions of the hummingbird and the hatching and development of her fledglings. The title is illustrated with detailed artwork. California setting and author.
Author: Kristine O'Connell George

Title: Hundred Dresses, The
Annotation: Wanda, a little Polish American girl, wears the same faded dress to school every day but claims to have 100 dresses at home. Her classmates tease her and make fun of her name and her accent. After she moves away, they feel shame and guilt in knowing that they were unkind to her.
Author: Eleanor Estes

Title: Hundred Penny Box, The
Annotation: Michael's one-hundred-year-old great-great-aunt Dew lives mostly in the memories of her past, represented by the 100 pennies she keeps in a wooden box. When Michael's mother tries to toss out all of Aunt Dew's old things, including the prized box of pennies, Michael intercedes. Dramatic, sepia-toned illustrations convey the mood of the story.
Author: Sharon Bell Mathis

Title: Hungry Coat: A Tale from Turkey, The
Annotation: After a run-in with a goat forces Nasrettin Hoca to change into a fancy new coat to attend a party, he stuffs food into his pockets, reasoning that it was the coat that was the invited guest. Demi manages to teach young readers an important lesson about appearances.
Author: - Demi

Title: Hunt for the Past: My Life as an Explorer (A Dinosaur Named Sue)
Annotation: This engaging autobiography chronicles the accidental discovery by Sue Hendrickson of the most complete T-rex ever found. It encourages further study of dinosaurs and paleontology, especially for girls and young women, and is packed with full-color photographs.
Author: Kimberly Weinberger (editor), Sue Hendrickson

Title: Hunterman and the Crocodile, The
Annotation: Donso the Hunterman rescues a crocodile family, but they turn on him and threaten to eat him. The other animals side with the crocodiles because of their experiences with humans' ingratitude. Finally, trickster Rabbit comes to the rescue. Hand-painted ceramic tiles and borders with ethnic motifs illustrate this West African folktale.
Author: Baba Wague Diakite

Title: Huracanes, Los (Hurricanes)
Annotation: The natural weather phenomenon of hurricanes is described in this book. How, when, and where hurricanes occur is discussed. Lots of photographs, diagrams, and charts are included to provide a clear picture of hurricanes and their effects. See other books in the Fenomenos Naturales (Natural Phenomenon) series.
Author: Ernesto Marquez Nerey

Title: Hurricane Hunters: Riders on the Storm
Annotation: This book describes the mission of a Mississippi-based flight crew as they fly into the eye of a hurricane to drop instruments that will track the storm's course and measure its wind speed. Full-color illustrations show the details of the propeller-driven WC-130 Hercules and the work of the crew as well as the lands before and after the storm's devastation.
Author: Chris L. Demarest

Title: Hurricanes: Earth's Mightiest Storms
Annotation: The reader is introduced to the power of hurricanes through descriptions of some of the most devastating hurricanes in history. Information on how hurricanes form, how they are investigated, and their impact on people and the environment is also provided. The book includes photographs and satellite pictures of hurricanes and their after-effects as well as maps, charts, an index, and suggestions for further reading.
Author: Patricia Lauber

Title: Hurry and the Monarch
Annotation: This is a fictionalized account of one monarch butterfly’s life cycle. As she stops in a Texas garden during her migration from Canada to Mexico, she is befriended by Hurry the tortoise. They talk about winter plans, then the butterfly flies off. When she returns in the spring, she lays her eggs and then rests her wings. The story is Illustrated with bright watercolors in an impressionistic style and includes some realistic sketches of monarchs and caterpillars.
Author: Antoine O'Flatharta

Title: I Am the First
Annotation: Is there any trouble one can get into for being first? This story deals with all of the issues involved in the desire to be first! It is written in traditional Chinese.
Author: Taro Gomi

Title: I Call My Grandma Nana
Annotation: In this rhyming picture book, Wolff features a group of students in a multicultural class. Each student shares stories about his or her grandmother. The reader learns different cultural names for grandmothers: Nai-Nai, Naani, Bubbe, Abuelita, and so on. Grandmothers are displayed in a positive light and are described as leading active, vibrant lives.
Author: Ashley Wolff
Grade Level Span: Preschool/Pre thru K, K thru 2, 3 thru 5

Title: I Could Do That! Esther Morris Gets Women the Vote
Annotation: In 1869, Wyoming became the first territory to allow women to vote—an accomplishment attributed to Esther Morris, a woman with a “can-do” attitude that enabled her to become the first woman to hold public office in the United States. Lively illustrations make this an engaging book. An author’s note provides facts about Morris and resources for further exploration.
Author: Linda Arms White

Title: I Dream of Trains
Annotation: The son of a sharecropper dreams of leaving Mississippi on a train with the legendary engineer Casey Jones and his fireman Sim Webb, away from his life of picking cotton. An afterword suggests a link between the trains that Jones and others ran through the Mississippi Delta and the Great Migration. The poetic text is complemented by intense acrylic paintings.
Author: Angela Johnson

Title: I Feel Better with a Frog in My Throat: History’s Strangest Cures
Annotation: Readers are introduced to some of history’s strangest cures for common maladies. The book is organized by maladies: coughs, colds, sore throats, wounds, stomachaches, fevers, headaches, and other sicknesses. It presents possible cures for each malady and then challenges readers to guess which of the cures are effective at treating the ailment. Artwork imbued with humorous details and droll, conversational text make this an appealing and informative book for younger readers.
Author: Carlyn Beccia
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Personal and Community Health
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: I Have a Dream
Annotation: Martin Luther King, Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech is richly illustrated with paintings portraying scenes from the civil rights movement. The works are by 15 artists, who are winners of the Coretta Scott King and Honor Book awards. The book includes a two-page biography of Dr. King.
Author: Martin Luther King, Jr.
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.3, HSS K.6, HSS 1.3, HSS 2.4, HSS 8.11, HSS 11.10

Title: I Have a Dream
Annotation: This book presents the speech given by Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. on August 28, 1963, at the Lincoln Memorial, in which he described his dream of equality and brotherhood for humankind.
Author: Martin Luther King

Title: I Heard It from Alice Zucchini, Poems About the Garden
Annotation: This collection of twenty poems is about the joys associated with gardens and the variety of products that grow in them. Pen-and-ink and watercolor artwork takes the reader to the ground level of the garden and showcases mice, snails, crickets, and a busy young fairy.
Author: Juanita Havill

Title: I See a Kookaburra! Discovering Animal Habitats Around the World
Annotation: This book describes the various animals, insects, and sea life that inhabit six different habitats around the world. Jenkins's signature collage illustrations are filled with color and textures and highlight the details of each animal. Thumbnails at the back of the book provide additional information about each animal as well as information about each habitat. This is a book that will engage and encourage young readers to seek more information.
Author: Robin Page, Steve Jenkins

Title: I See the Rhythm
Annotation: Poems and paintings combine to give a succinct overview of African American music from African origins and slave songs through ragtime; the blues; big band, bebop, and cool jazz; gospel; rhythm and blues; and the contemporary sounds of rock, hip-hop, and rap.
Author: Toyomi Igus
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: I Was Dreaming to Come to America: Memories from the Ellis Island Oral History Project
Annotation: In their own words, immigrants recall their arrival in the United States. Includes brief biographies and facts about the Ellis Island Oral History Project. Illustrated with hand-painted collages. Excellent resource for research and study about immigration.
Author: Veronica Lawlor

Title: I Wonder Why Snakes Shed Their Skin: And Other Questions About Reptiles
Annotation: This book about reptiles is set-up in a question and answer format. It answers such questions about reptiles as why do snakes stare, are frogs and newts reptiles, and which reptile lives the longest. Information is paired with a combination of realistic and cartoonlike illustrations. See other books in the I Wonder Why series.
Author: Amanda O'Neill

Title: I'll Meet You at the Cucumbers
Annotation: Country mouse Adam goes to the city with his friend, Junius. They marvel at the urban sights, sounds, and experiences and learn about themselves in the process. The sequel to this story is DON'T BE AFRAID, AMANDA (1992). This selection is useful for language arts instruction in writing descriptions.
Author: Lilian Moore

Title: I'm Nobody! Who Are You? Poems of Emily Dickinson for Children
Annotation: This illustrated collection of poems is by nineteenth-century American poet Emily Dickinson. Explanations of the poems are presented at the front of the book. Also included are bibliographic references and biographical information about the poet.
Author: Emily Dickinson

Title: I, Matthew Henson: Polar Explorer
Annotation: Tells the story of Matthew Henson, an African American man who relentlessly pursued his dream to reach the North Pole along with explorer Robert Peary. His adventures began when, as a thirteen-year-old orphan, he signed up to go to sea as a cabin boy. Later he met Admiral Peary and dedicated his life to reaching the North Pole, which he did (with Peary) on April 6, 1909. Later, some authorities dismissed the achievement because Henson was African American. Includes an author’s note.
Author: Carole Boston Weatherford

Title: I, Too, Am America
Annotation: This book shares Langston Hughes' poem, which highlights the courage and dignity of the African American railway porters in the early twentieth century.
Author: Langston Hughes

Title: I, Vivaldi
Annotation: Composer Antonio Vivaldi was born in 1678 during an earthquake and nearly died. His mother vowed to God that her son would become a priest if his life was spared. Against his wishes, Vivaldi did become a priest, but music was his passion. After some years, he was relieved of saying Mass and assigned to teach orphan girls how to play the violin. He was inspired to write “The Four Seasons” for this group, and they became famous all over Europe for their performances. Includes a “Fact and Fiction” section, glossary, and several bars of “Spring” from “The Four Seasons” for the reader to play.
Author: Janice Shefelman

Title: Ice Story: Shackleton's Lost Expedition
Annotation: Told through memoirs, original expedition photographs, maps, and a well-crafted narrative text, the book chronicles a disastrous 1914 sailing expedition to the Antarctic Pole. When their ship was crushed by the frozen sea, the captain and crew made a perilous journey across dangerous seas and frozen land to safety.
Author: Elizabeth Cody Kimmel

Title: Ida B . . . and Her Plans to Maximize Fun, Avoid Disaster, and (Possibly) Save the World
Annotation: In Wisconsin, fourth-grader Ida B spends happy hours being home-schooled and playing in her family’s apple orchard until her mother begins treatment for breast cancer. Then her parents must sell part of the orchard and send her to public school. Ida B is resentful and plots ways to keep the orchard since she has named each tree, talks to the trees, and feels that each is a dear friend.
Author: Katherine Hannigan
Topic: Economics, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health

Title: If
Annotation: This deceptively simple text with imaginative illustrations contemplates such possibilities as "If music could be held . . ." and more profound thoughts, such as "If ugly were beautiful . . ." Young children can enjoy this book on an imaginative level; older children may enjoy it on a philosophical level.
Publisher: J. Paul Getty Museum and Children's Library Press
Author: Sarah Perry
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: If a Bus Could Talk: The Story of Rosa Parks
Annotation: The bus's perspective is used to recount the biography of Rosa Parks, the African American woman and civil rights worker whose refusal to give up her seat on a bus led to a boycott that lasted for more than a year in Montgomery, Alabama. Teacher support with explanation and background may be needed when using this text. California author/illustrator.
Author: Faith Ringgold
Standard: HSS 1.1, HSS 1.3, HSS 1.4, HSS 1.5, HSS 2.5, HSS 3.3

Title: If America Were a Village: A Book about the People of the United States
Annotation: Imagine that the United States of America is a village of 100 people. That is the metaphor used by this author to explore where we live, what our families are like, how old we are, how healthy we are, and many other aspects of life for America’s 300 million citizens. Bright, acrylic paintings depict the diversity of the United States and show families at work and at play. The book concludes with suggested activities and discussion questions.
Author: David J. Smith
Topic: Diversity, Geography, Lifestyles Around the World, Psychology/Sociology

Title: If Dogs Were Dinosaurs
Annotation: This book explores the concepts of ratio and proportion by growing or shrinking various objects by the same amounts. The detailed artwork shows visualizations of the concepts and helps to provide readers with questions for further research. This book concludes with notes, calculations, and related problems to solve.
Author: David M. Schwartz

Title: If I Had a Tail
Annotation: The reader is asked to guess what a creature is from the description of the appearance and use of the animal's tail. From peacocks to sea horses, lizards and skunks, a variety of animals are illustrated in gouache and colored pencil. The story helps the reader imagine what it would be like to have a tail.
Author: Karen Clemens Warrick

Title: If I Only Had a Horn: Young Louis Armstrong
Annotation: Relates how the famous jazz trumpeter, Louis Armstrong, began his musical career as a poor boy in New Orleans. He began by singing songs on street corners and playing a battered cornet in a marching band. The story is derived from autobiographical information. The acrylic, pastel, and spray-paint illustrations give the effect of a collage.
Author: Roxane Orgill

Title: If I Ran for President
Annotation: Several children imagine what it would be like to run for U.S. president; they consider the fun parts, such as being on T-shirts and bumper stickers, as well as the work involved. Bright illustrations feature a multicultural cast. An excellent tool for opening a discussion about elections.
Author: Catherine Stier

Title: If I Were in Charge of the World and Other Worries: Poems for Children and Their Parents
Annotation: From a young person's perspective, 41 poems about ordinary, everyday things are presented. Grouped under such headings as "Cats and Other People," "Thanks and No Thanks," and "Wicked Thoughts," the rhymes turn secrets, worries, wishes, jealousy, envy, fairytales and bullies into objects of amusement. The poems are embellished by detailed pen-and-ink illustrations.
Author: Judith Viorst

Title: If The Walls Could Talk: Family Life at the White House
Annotation: A collection of funny, surprising stories about America’s First Families and life in the White House. Includes humorous facts about past presidents who have lived in the White House. The watercolor art, done in a political-cartoon style, makes this an appealing book for children, especially reluctant readers.
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
Author: Jane O'Connor
Topic: American History, Women’s Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: If You Are a Hunter of Fossils
Annotation: A fossil hunter who is looking for signs of an ancient sea in the rocks of a western Texas mountain describes how the area must have looked millions of years ago. The illustrations and poetic language invite the reader into the world of geology.
Author: Byrd Baylor

Title: If You Decide to Go to the Moon
Annotation: This adventure takes readers from a blast-off into space to touchdown on the moon and back again. The text contains a fascinating union of science and mathematics, evoking the emotions and the experiences of the solitary reader-astronaut and the hard facts of space. The illustrations show space and moonscapes in watercolors that make the most of the stark grays and whites of space.
Author: Faith McNulty

Title: If You Find a Rock
Annotation: Hand-tinted, black-and-white photographs provide a background to poetic text celebrating the variety of rocks that children might find, such as those for skipping across ponds, for wishing, for hiding creatures, and to use for leaping across a river. This book can be used to peak interest in rocks, although there is no scientific classification for them.
Author: Peggy Christian

Title: If You Lived at the Time of the Great San Francisco Earthquake
Annotation: The 8.0 earthquake that struck San Francisco was one of the biggest in the United States. The full-color artwork helps the reader see the changes that were left as a result of the rapid movement of Earth's surface. A teacher might also use this book to discuss the exponential nature of seismic readings. See other books in the If You Lived at the Time Of series.
Author: Ellen Levine

Title: If You Lived with the Cherokee
Annotation: Full-color illustrations by a Cherokee artist complement the facts about Cherokee life—their language, names, games, dwellings, medicine, and much more. This selection is from the series of If You Lived . . . books.
Author: Connie Roop, Peter Roop

Title: If You Made a Million
Annotation: This book describes the various forms which money can take, including coins, paper money, and personal checks, and how it can be used to make purchases, pay off loans, or build interest in the bank. Realistic illustrations help the reader see equivalent amounts of money and how it can be used. It includes endnotes on banks, interest, loans, and taxes.
Author: David M. Schwartz
Standard: Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 2.MP.1-8, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.MP.1-8, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.MD.1-5, Math 7.RP.1-3

Title: If You Should Hear a Honey Guide
Annotation: In the East African savanna, a small brown bird, known as a honey guide, leads the way to a hidden bee's nest. The story is told in short, poetic text that lends itself as a read aloud. The realistic, detailed watercolor illustrations highlight the African landscape and the wildlife found there. An author's note explains how the honey guides locate the wild bees and their honey.
Author: April Pulley Sayre

Title: Igraine the Brave
Annotation: Igraine, the daughter of two medieval magicians, is looking for something different for her life. She yearns to be a knight who wins tournaments and goes on grand adventures. Her parents accidentally turn themselves into pigs, while the castle is threatened by an intruder who is after a set of magical singing books. Igraine’s wish to be a knight comes true, and she launches a quest to find the magic that will restore her parents. Occasional black-and-white drawings are included. A good read-aloud choice.
Author: Cornelia Funke

Title: Iguanas in the Snow: And Other Winter Poems (Iguanas en la nieve: y otros poemas de invierno)
Annotation: This collection of bilingual poems is a celebration of winter by the seashore, in the city of San Francisco, and in the redwood forests of the Sierras. The rich illustrations capture the diversity of the people of California and the short poems capture the diversity of the California environment. This is one of four books in the series. California author and California setting.
Author: Francisco X. Alarcon

Title: Illustrated Tang Poem, Volumes 1 and 2
Annotation: This illustrated collection of famous Tang dynasty poems encourages children's interest in early Chinese poetic forms. Life and nature are captured in images and words.
Author: Qian Qiu

Title: Illustrated Three Character Classic Stories
Annotation: The themes of courage and perseverance are examined in these illustrated stories of characters from an old classical poem.
Author: Shek Kim

Title: Illuvia, La (The Rain)
Annotation: The water cycle, clouds, weather, and climate are all discussed in this well-written, colorful, and informative book. The effects of weather and climate are related to humans and their place on Earth. See other books in the Fenomenos Naturales (Natural Phenomenon) series.
Author: Estrella Burgos

Title: Immigrant Girl: Becky of Eldridge Street
Annotation: Ten-year-old Becky Moscowitz's family immigrates to New York's Lower East Side from Russia in 1910. Becky gives a complete picture of her family, their lives in the tenements, and the customs of Russian Jews in the early years of the twentieth century. Black-and-white pencil drawings suggest the harshness of the times. A glossary is included.
Author: Brett Harvey

Title: Immigrant Kids
Annotation: This photo-essay relates how immigrant children lived, played, went to school, and worked in America's cities during the late 1880s and early 1900s. The font is large and inviting, and the book is filled with archival photographs.
Author: Russell Freedman

Title: Impossible Patriotism Project, The
Annotation: Caleb has a hard time coming up with a way to symbolize patriotism for a Presidents’ Day project until he realizes that his dad, who is away from home because he is in the military, is what patriotism is all about. Caleb’s project is simple and poignant. This picture book provides an opportunity to discuss the concerns of children whose parents are in the military. Illustrated with watercolor art in a cartoon style.
Author: Linda Skeers

Title: In Daddy's Arms I Am Tall: African Americans Celebrating Fathers
Annotation: This collection of poetry by African American writers is presented as a tribute to the influence African American fathers have on their children and grandchildren. The book features images created from torn paper, cut-paper with pastel, applique, collage, and a variety of found objects, including coins, insects, floorboards, seashells, and a real fish dipped in paint. Bits of information on the contributing poets are appended.
Author: Javaka Steptoe (editor)
Standard: HSS K.1, HSS K.4, HSS 1.1, HSS 1.5

Title: In Our Mothers’ House
Annotation: Three adopted children are raised and loved by two same-sex parents in a multicultural and nontraditional family. Mothers Marmee and Meema build a happy home in a supportive community despite one crabby neighbor openly disapproving of the relationship between the mothers. The story is narrated by the oldest daughter and describes their holiday celebrations and special times. Illustrated with detailed artwork in pencil and marker. The book features a positive model of inclusiveness for children who may have or know of a family with same-sex parents.
Author: Patricia Polacco

Title: In the Forest with the Elephants
Annotation: This book describes how elephants are trained to help in timber camps in Myanmar and their contribution to the harvest of teak, paduak, and other valuable woods. Both the elephants and the forests are protected in this environmentally-minded country. Full-color photographs chronicle the important partnership of the elephants and the men who ride and train them for logging that has been a carefully controlled system for over 150 years.
Author: Roland Smith

Title: In the Garden with Dr. Carver
Annotation: Botanist Dr. George Washington Carver arrives in Sally’s small Alabama town to give everyone a potpourri of ideas for growing plants in the tired earth and help establish a school garden. Brilliant watercolor illustrations, including drawings of flowers and insects, enrich the content. A National Council for the Social Studies Trade Book (2011).
Author: Susan Grigsby
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Life Science (Biology)
Standard: LS K.2, HSS K.3, LS 1.2, HSS 1.2, LS 2.2, HSS 2.1, LS 3.3, HSS 2.4, HSS 2.5, LS 4.2, HSS 3.3, HSS 4.2, LS 5.2

Title: In the Heart of the Village: The World of the Indian Banyan Tree
Annotation: This book highlights the importance and interrelationships of the banyan tree to a village in India. It features the activities of the village people and the local wildlife in and around the tree. The artwork includes double-page spread paintings that provide a close-up view.
Author: Barbara Bash

Title: In the Next Three Seconds
