Annotation: This is an intriguing collection of time-related predictions that will occur in the near and distant future as measured in multiples of three. The book is illustrated with small, detailed illustrations, and includes an explanation about making predictions.
Author: Rowland Morgan
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry), Statistics, Data Analysis, & Probability
Standard: I & E 3.5, Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 5.MD.1-5

Title: In the Swim: Poems and Paintings
Annotation: Humorous twists and wit are evident in 21 poems characterizing the habits of fresh and saltwater fish. Employing puns, wordplays, and internal rhymes, each double-page spread features a painting and text arranged in a variety of formations that toy with unusual aspects of the subject.
Author: Douglas Florian
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, Science

Title: In the Time of the Drums
Annotation: This is a Gullah tale of mysticism, intrigue, and courage featuring an African American slave who listens intently to his powerful grandmother's stories and songs from the past and learns from her to beat Ibo rhythms on his goatskin drum. He witnesses his grandmother leading a ship full of Ibo people into the water at Teakettle Creek in order for them to walk back to Africa and to freedom. The emotional intensity of this legend is elevated by Pinkney's signature scratchboard-on-oil drawings, each covering two pages in rich, dark tones.
Author: Kim Siegelson

Title: In the Year of the Boar and Jackie Robinson
Annotation: Jackie Robinson and baseball help Shirley Temple Wong, a young Chinese immigrant, assimilate into the American culture. This junior novel is poignant yet outrageously humorous.
Author: Bette Bao Lord

Title: In Your Face: The Facts About Your Features
Annotation: This extensive study of the face presents a wide breadth of information, beginning with evolutionary development, and includes facial decoration and reconstruction. It also discusses how facial recognition technology can help find missing children as well as how different cultures define beauty. Well-captioned color photos fit well with the text.
Author: Donna M. Jackson

Title: Inchworm and a Half
Annotation: Several small worms use their varying lengths to measure the vegetables in a garden. The bouncy rhyming text makes this a read-aloud choice in introducing the concept of fractions. The book is illustrated in linocuts with deep colors. Also by the same author are REMAINDER OF ONE and ONE HUNDRED HUNGRY ANTS.
Author: Elinor J. Pinczes

Title: Independent Dames: What You Never Knew About the Women and Girls of the American Revolution
Annotation: Describes the role that women and young girls played in the American Revolution, highlighting the contributions and exploits of women who had a significant impact on the colonists’ fight for freedom. Presented in a double-page-spread format that includes brief biographies of a variety of females who participated in the Revolution. Illustrated in a cartoon style.
Author: Laurie Halse Anderson

Title: Indian Chiefs
Annotation: Six of the greatest Indian leaders of the nineteenth century are examined, along with their attempts to hold on to their way of life as the white man encroached on their lands. Portraits of the Indian leaders and some of their adversaries and benefactors enhance these carefully researched and well-told histories. A bibliography and an index are included. The book is available in paperback or prebind.
Author: Russell Freedman

Title: Ink Garden of Brother Theophane, The
Annotation: A monk in medieval Ireland is bored with his work and his colorless life. He walks through the fields to find bark for the brown ink used in the writings of the brothers and discovers things in nature that can be used to create inks of different colors. Written in verse and illustrated in watercolors and with cut paper, this picture book is informative and inspirational. Includes an author’s note, list of additional titles, and Web links on how to make ink colors and on the history of illuminated manuscripts.
Author: C. M. Millen
Topic: International Studies/World History, Religion/Spirituality, Visual Arts
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Insectlopedia: Poems and Paintings
Annotation: This collection of 21 short poems about insects and spiders blends science and wordplay through rhyme, sound, and meter. Each poem is accompanied by a full-color illustration. The selection is useful for language arts units and the study of entomology and connects to the curriculum for sixth-grade science.
Author: Douglas Florian
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: Inside Out and Back Again
Annotation: In 1975, just prior to the fall of Saigon, ten-year-old Ha, her mother, and her three older brothers flee South Vietnam aboard an American military vessel. After their arrival in America, the family is sponsored by a cowboy from Alabama. Ha faces cruel bullying by her classmates but eventually gains academic honor and social acceptance. This novel, told in verse, is based on the author’s personal experiences and expresses hope and humor. Newbery Honor (2012); ALA Notable Children’s Book (2012); Notable Book for a Global Society (2012).
Author: Thanhha Lai
Genre: Fiction, Fiction in Verse, Historical Fiction
Topic: American History, Diversity, Immigration/Migration, International Studies/World History, War, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: International Space Station, The
Annotation: In a question and answer format, readers are guided through the construction of the international space station. It describes what it is like to live 400 kilometers above Earth. Well-designed, informative diagrams inspire readers to think beyond the box. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out-Science series.
Author: Franklyn M. Branley

Title: Interrupted Journey: Saving Endangered Sea Turtles
Annotation: This informative and involving photo-essay describes the attempts by dedicated scientists and volunteers to rescue stranded Kemp's ridley sea turtles, nurse them back to health, release them into the sea, and help save this endangered species. The reader follows the juvenile turtles' journey from the cold, winter waters of Cape Cod to Florida, and also visits the breeding grounds in Mexico.
Author: Kathryn Lasky

Title: Into the Firestorm: A Novel of San Francisco, 1906
Annotation: Days after arriving in San Francisco from Texas, eleven-year-old orphan Nicholas Dray tries to help his new neighbors survive the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and the subsequent fires. Includes a bibliography and an afterword. A fast-paced, action-filled piece of historical fiction that might appeal to reluctant readers as well as those interested in a well-told story with an appealing young central character who acts bravely and even saves a dog appropriately named Shake (Shakespeare)! See also Laurence Yep’s THE EARTH DRAGON AWAKES.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson
Topic: American History, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Into the Ice: The Story of Arctic Exploration
Annotation: This book describes the ice cap above the northernmost shores of Asia, North America, and Greenland, and the expeditions that crisscrossed this frozen environment in search of the North Pole. A timeline, a bibliography, and an index for student reference are included.
Author: Lynn Curlee

Title: Into the Sea
Annotation: This literary narrative takes the reader on a tour of the life cycle of a sea turtle from its hatching on a beach, through its years in the ocean, to its return trip where it lays its eggs. In addition, the author includes an explanation of why sea turtles are endangered. Bright colored-pencil-and-gouache paintings provide detailed portraits of the turtles.
Author: Brenda Z. Guiberson

Title: Into the Unknown: How Great Explorers Found Their Way by Land, Sea, and Air
Annotation: Clear text, shaded colored-pencil artwork, numerous maps, and cross-section illustrations make this a high-interest title that is valuable for research. Describes 14 journeys of exploration: from Pytheas the Greek (240 BC) through the 1969 Apollo mission. Historical figures include Leif Eriksson, Marco Polo, Zheng He, Christopher Columbus, Ferdinand Magellan, David Livingstone, Mary Kingsley, Tenzing Norgay, and others. The book offers foldout pages, a glossary, an index, and a bibliography with numerous primary sources.
Author: Stewart Ross
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Geography, Global Historical Events and Figures, International Studies/World History, Mathematical Analysis, Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)

Title: Into the Woods: John James Audubon Lives His Dream
Annotation: This book features poetic text in the form of an imagined conversation between the famed artist-naturalist Audubon and his father. Included are quotations from Audubon's journals. Some of Audubon's drawings of birds are incorporated into the lush watercolor illustrations of his wanderings amid nature. This book is useful as an introduction to the naturalist and to units on nature and habitats.
Author: Robert Burleigh

Title: Inventions
Annotation: Questions and answers explore the world of inventions and their effects on daily life. It includes explanations of how ordinary things that we take for granted came to be such as commas, periods, and the first movie. Also by this author is UP IN THE AIR where questions such as "Does air weigh anything?" and "Can air keep things warm?" are answered. See other books in the Questions and Answers series.
Author: Wendy Madgwick

Title: Inventions of Ancient China
Annotation: This four-volume illustrated series features ancient Chinese medicine and architecture.
Author: - Unknown

Title: Ira Sleeps Over
Annotation: Excited about an invitation to spend the night at his friend Reggie's house, Ira must decide whether to take his teddy bear with him. He has never slept without it before, but what would Reggie think? This story of family rivalry and friendship is enhanced by dialogue that is spare and authentic.
Author: Bernard Waber

Title: Irena Sendler and the Children of the Warsaw Ghetto
Annotation: Irena Sendler, a young Polish Catholic social worker in Warsaw during World War II, was responsible for saving the lives of nearly 400 Jewish children from the Nazis. Although she was captured by Nazi soldiers, Sendler eventually escaped and continued her life-saving efforts. Large-scale oil paintings extend the narrative and add drama to this compelling story.
Author: Susan Goldman Rubin
Topic: Global Social Issues, War, Women’s Studies

Title: Iron Dragon Never Sleeps, The
Annotation: In 1867, while staying with her father in a small California mining town, ten-year-old Winnie meets a Chinese boy close to her age and discovers the role of his people in completing the transcontinental railroad. Based upon actual places and events, this story and the illustrations provide a thought-provoking perspective of California’s history during the mid-1800s.
Author: Stephen Krensky

Title: Iron Horses
Annotation: Simple but strong rhyming text is used to tell the story of the race to build the transcontinental railroad in the mid-1800s. For example, "Thumping, bumping, Ties and rails. Clanging banging, Spikes and nails." The illustrations, done in scratchboard and watercolors, blend with the text perfectly. California author and California setting.
Author: Verla Kay

Title: Is There Life in Outer Space?
Annotation: Brightly colored cartoonlike drawings add a humorous flavor to this introductory discussion of the ideas and misconceptions about life in the solar system. This book speculates on the existence of such life in light of space explorations as of 1984.
Author: Franklyn M. Branley

Title: Isabel's House of Butterflies
Annotation: Eight-year-old Isabel creates a plan to spare her favorite tree, keep the monarch butterflies coming, and provide an income for her poor family in Mexico. A well-crafted story, illustrated with richly textured paintings, bordered with frames that are reminiscent of folk art. California author and California illustrator.
Author: Tony Johnston

Title: Ish
Annotation: Ramon loses confidence in his ability to draw, but his sister gives him a new perspective on things by telling him a house can be “house-ish” or a fish “fish-ish.” Thinking “ish-ly” inspires Ramon to let his artwork flow again. Illustrated with simple black-line artwork highlighted with splashes of watercolor. A wonderful companion to DOT (2004), another title by Reynolds.
Author: Peter H. Reynolds
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Isla de los delfines azules, La (Island of the Blue Dolphins)
Annotation: This is the story of Karana who lived alone on the Island of the Blue Dolphins, one of the Channel Islands off the coast of Southern California, for almost 20 years in the early 1800s. The novel describes her efforts at surviving in a harsh environment. It also describes the animals which shared her island and the surrounding ocean. It includes a few scientific inaccuracies. California setting.
Author: Scott O'Dell

Title: Island of the Blue Dolphins
Annotation: This is the story of Karana who lived alone on the Island of the Blue Dolphins, one of the Channel Islands off the coast of Southern California, for almost 20 years in the early 1800s. The novel describes her efforts at surviving in a harsh environment. It also describes the animals which shared her island and the surrounding ocean. It includes a few scientific inaccuracies. California setting.
Author: Scott O'Dell

Title: Island Scrapbook: Dawn to Dusk on a Barrier Island, An
Annotation: In this first-person narrative, an artist and her daughter explore a North Carolina barrier island. The journal/scrapbook shows and tells what they observe during the course of a September day including various habitats, plants, and animals. Pencil sketches, simulated photographs, and hand-written notes assist in explaining the island ecology. Read aloud to introduce units on ecology and habitats. Also by the same author is A DESERT SCRAPBOOK: DAWN TO DUSK IN THE SONORAN DESERT.
Author: Virginia Wright-Frierson
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: It's an Ant's Life, My Story of Life in the Nest
Annotation: This whimsical, first-person narrative is told from the view of an ant living in the nest. Factual information on the life cycle, behavior, and daily routine is presented in the form of a journal. Vivid watercolors with pen-and-ink drawings enhance the story in a humorous, as well as scientific view of everyday life in an ant colony.
Author: Steve Parker
Illustrator: Adam Stower, Robin Carter, Tim Hayward

Title: It's Disgusting and We Ate It! True Food Facts from Around the World and Throughout History
Annotation: This is a humorous look at the diversity of nutrition and food eaten throughout history and all over the world. Don't be fooled by the funny title - there's a lot of science woven in, such as the protein and vitamin C content of various foods, the extinction of the passenger pigeon, how milk and honey are made, how cheese is produced, what a fungus is, etc.
Author: James Solheim
Discipline: History/Social Science, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, Science

Title: It's Snowing! It's Snowing!
Annotation: This collection of 17 poems highlights the seasonal changes that winter brings. The poems contain strong meter and rhyme and cover cold weather activities, changes in the environment, snowflakes, and snowmen. Pencil sketches rendered in muted tones enhance the poems and create a wintry mood.
Author: Jack Prelutsky
Standard: LS K.2, ES K.3, ES 1.3, LS 3.3

Title: Ivy and Bean
Annotation: Bean is sure that Ivy, the new girl across the street, is boring and will not be any fun. She finds out differently when a trick played on Bean’s sister goes terribly wrong, and Ivy comes to the rescue. Bean discovers that Ivy is studying to be a witch, and a friendship is born. This beginning chapter book is illustrated with detailed black-and-white drawings that take the story to a higher level. This is the first book in the “Ivy and Bean” series.
Author: Annie Barrows

Title: Jabuti, the Tortoise: A Trickster Tale from the Amazon
Annotation: This trickster tale from the Amazon is about a flute-playing tortoise who wants to play for the King. Vulture offers him a ride but deliberately drops him, causing his shell to break. Other animals gather him up and glue his pieces back together. Vivid colors and geometrically drawn shapes help to tell the story.
Author: Gerald McDermott

Title: Jack Plank Tells Tales
Annotation: Jack Plank started out as a pirate, but after a while it was clear that he wasn’t any good at plundering and pirating. Jack takes a room in a boardinghouse with an eclectic group of folks who offer suggestions for possible jobs. Each evening at dinner, he tells a story explaining why he has ruled out each suggestion. When he decides to go back to sea, one suggested job seems to be the perfect fit. Illustrated with fine black-and-white illustrations. Highly recommended as a read-aloud.
Author: Natalie Babbitt

Title: Jade Dragon, The
Annotation: Second-grader Ginny is torn between being Chinese and American. Her friendship with the new girl, Stephanie, who is a Chinese girl adopted by American parents, brings her tension to the forefront. Together, Ginny and Stephanie learn to embrace their diversity. This book touches on Chinese cultural traditions and foods, Chinese New Year traditions, and Chinese school.
Author: Carolyn Marsden, Virginia Shin-Mui Loh

Title: Jambo Means Hello: Swahili Alphabet Book
Annotation: This alphabet book presents 24 words and concepts, one to accompany each letter of the Swahili alphabet; a pronunciation guide; and a definition of the word and its cultural implications. Soft sepia and charcoal illustrations evoke the Swahili culture.
Author: Muriel L. Feelings
Classification: Alphabet Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: James and the Giant Peach
Annotation: This classic tale of fantasy and wonder appeals to readers of all ages. Everyone is rooting for James as the magic peach grows in his yard, enabling him to escape "the aunts."
Author: Roald Dahl

Title: James Printer: A Novel of Rebellion
Annotation: The courageous story of James Printer, a Nipmuch Indian from Massachusetts, is told through the voice of young Bartholomew Green. James, raised by the English after his mother's death, becomes a printer's apprentice. When conflicts break out between the white settlers and the local Indian tribes, James is forced to demonstrate his loyalties. The language and characters' attitudes reflect life in the 1670s.
Author: Paul Samuel Jacobs

Title: Janitor's Boy, The
Annotation: Fifth grader Jack finds himself the target of ridicule at school when it becomes known that his father is one of the janitors, and he turns his anger onto his father. The novel is engaging and establishes a good jumping-off point for classroom discussions about social class and economic status in America.
Author: Andrew Clements

Title: Jar of Dreams, A
Annotation: When Aunt Waka from Japan visits Rinko's family in America, eleven-year-old Rinko learns to transcend the racial prejudice she experiences in the 1930s. Aunt Waka inspires the entire family to pursue their dreams and achieve their goals. The story includes violence, but also contains a strong message about remaining true to oneself that is stressed throughout the story, which ends on a positive note. California author.
Author: Yoshiko Uchida

Title: Jazz
Annotation: A collection of illustrated poems celebrate the roots and various styles of jazz music—such as ragtime, bebop, and swing—through poetry and paintings. The book includes an explanatory introduction, a glossary of jazz terms, and a jazz time line.
Author: Walter Dean Myers

Title: Jazz Fly
Annotation: The jazz fly meets a frog, a hog, a donkey, and a dog and is looking for directions on his way to a jazz-club gig. He discovers that the rhythms from his new friends jazz up the sound of his band’s music. An accompanying CD features the author reading the story along with music played by a jazz quartet. The digital artwork features black, white, and gray, with splashes of color to accentuate the jazzy style
Author: Matthew Gollub
Standard: VAPA T PreK-12.3, VAPA T PreK-12.4

Title: Jazz on a Saturday Night
Annotation: Brief, rhythmic poems and paintings help tell the story of a fictional Saturday night on which a crowd gathers to hear jazz played by a band of all-time greats, including Miles Davis, Max Roach, Charlie Parker, John Coltrane, Thelonius Monk, Stanley Parker, and Ella Fitzgerald. Illustrated with paintings that glow and seem to pulse with rhythm. Includes a CD with information about jazz, instruments, and performers and an original jazz song. Introduces young listeners to jazz.
Author: Diane Dillon, Leo Dillon

Title: Jazzy Miz Mozetta
Annotation: On a beautiful evening, Miz Mozetta puts on her red dress and blue shoes and dances the jitterbug just like she did many years before. The exuberant spirit of Miz Mozetta is expressed in the bright, acrylic illustrations that dance to the beat of a fresh, rhythmic story. Duke Ellington was right when he wrote, “It don’t mean a thing if it ain’t got that swing.” Play swing music as you read this story aloud.
Author: Brenda C. Roberts
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.5

Title: Jellies: The Life of Jellyfish
Annotation: The simple and readable text provides an introduction to the physical characteristics, habits, and natural environment of a variety of jellyfish species. The book is illustrated with spectacular full-color underwater photographs.
Author: Twig C. George

Title: Jennifer, Hecate, Macbeth, William McKinley, and Me, Elizabeth
Annotation: Two fifth-grade girls, one of whom is the first black child in a middle-income suburb, play at being apprentice witches.
Author: E. L. Konigsburg

Title: Jesse Owens: Fastest Man Alive
Annotation: A poetic tribute to Jesse Owens and his amazing performance in the 1936 Berlin Olympics. Mainly set during the Olympics, the story also touches on Owens’ disdain for Nazi Germany as well as the racial discrimination he faced throughout his life in America. Illustrated with textured pastels that enhance the presentation. Concludes with biographical information and suggestions for further reading.
Author: Carole Boston Weatherford

Title: Jim and the Beanstalk
Annotation: Jim climbs the beanstalk and finds a very old giant who needs glasses, false teeth and a wig. Jim takes measurements and helps the giant get what he needs. The illustrations alternate between color and black-and-white. This story can begin a unit on measuring, scale, proportion, or statistics.
Author: Raymond Briggs
Topic: Measurement & Geometry (Geometry), Statistics, Data Analysis, & Probability
Standard: Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 5.NF.1-7, Math 5.MD.1-5, Math 6.RP.1-3

Title: Jim Thorpe's Bright Path
Annotation: This biography of Native American athlete Jim Thorpe focuses on how his boyhood education set the stage for his athletic achievements, which gained him international fame and Olympic gold medals. Author's note details Thorpe's life after college. This inspiring American portrait is illustrated with acrylic paintings.
Author: Joseph Bruchac

Title: Jim Ugly
Annotation: It's 1894 in the wild West and twelve-year-old Jake and Jim Ugly, his father's part mongrel, part-wolf dog, travel from the Sierra Nevada to San Francisco looking for Jake's father. California author and setting.
Author: Sid Fleischman

Title: Jimi: Sounds Like a Rainbow: A Story of the Young Jimi Hendrix
Annotation: This book introduces revolutionary rock legend Jimi Hendrix, poetically describing his humble early life, his struggles alongside his single dad, and the bustling Seattle world outside his boardinghouse. The story focuses on Jimi’s rise to fame and his influence on the youths of the 1960s. His drug addiction is discussed, and the author provides some helpful Web sites for children and teens. Illustrated with colorful, textured mixed-media artwork. An author’s note offers further details.
Author: Gary Golio
Award: Coretta Scott King Illustrator Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Winner, Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: Jingle Dancer
Annotation: Jenna, a contemporary member of the Muscogee (Creek) Nation living in Oklahoma, wants to honor a family tradition by jingle dancing at the next powwow. She borrows jingles from the dresses of several friends and relatives so that she can perform the dance. This beautiful book has a special section about the jingle-dance tradition and regalia.
Author: Cynthia Leitich Smith
Topic: Dance, Diversity, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.3, HSS K.4, VAPA D PreK-12.5, HSS K.6, HSS 1.3, HSS 1.5

Title: Jingle the Brass
Annotation: Readers embark on a train adventure filled with the jargon of the men and women who ride the rails. When the “ashcat feeds the black diamonds into the firebox,” young readers will be ready to leave the roundhouse and “ride the point.” This well-crafted work of realistic fiction is paired with smoky watercolor artwork to make the journey well worth the bumpy ride. Use as a mentor text for demonstrating the importance of word choice, the writer’s purpose, and writing for a specific audience.
Author: Patricia Newman

Title: Joe Louis, My Champion
Annotation: After listening to the radio broadcast of the heavyweight championship boxing fight of his hero, Joe Louis, a young African American boy realizes that he can emulate the boxer's persistence and strive to become whatever he wants to be. Illustrated with realistic oil paintings.
Author: William Miller

Title: Joey Pigza Loses Control
Annotation: When Joey Pigza meets his dad, Carter, for the first time in years, he meets a grown-up version of his old hyperactive self. When his dad wants to teach him how to be a winner and how to take control of his own life, Joey is willing to do whatever his dad says, even though he fears it will do him more harm than good. The book is a sequel to JOEY PIGZA SWALLOWED THE KEY.
Author: Jack Gantos

Title: John Coltrane’s Giant Steps
Annotation: This spirited introduction to the music of John Coltrane is a visual treat that strives to make music jump off the page. Four images become supporting band members: raindrops that symbolize the tempo; a box that lays down the foundation; a snowflake that provides harmony; and a kitten that provides melody. The shapes and colors combine as if they are different instruments—in reference to Coltrane’s famous arrangement of “My Favorite Things.”
Author: Chris Raschka

Title: John Henry
Annotation: The story of America's bigger-than-life folk hero John Henry is retold keeping the legendary events of the story the same and adding modern touches to make this story unique. The watercolor illustrations reflect both the strength and gentleness of the mighty man. Use the man-versus-machine theme to trigger students' writing their own tall tales.
Author: Julius Lester
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: John Henry: An American Legend
Annotation: John Henry, bigger than life, was born with a hammer in his hand. He did heroic things in his lifetime, but in the final test of his courage and strength, he battled a machine and lost his life. Teachers might want to pursue the theme of human versus machine and the origin of such stories. The book is available in paperback or prebind.
Author: Ezra Jack Keats

Title: John Lewis in the Lead: A Story of the Civil Rights Movement
Annotation: A biography of John Lewis, one of the “Big Six” civil rights leaders of the 1960s. It focuses on his involvement in Freedom Rides, the March on Washington, and the march across the Edmund Pettus Bridge from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama. The text is complemented by illustrations done in a folk-art style.
Author: James Haskins

Title: John Muir: America's First Environmentalist
Annotation: This is a picture-book portrait of the life and work of environmentalist John Muir. It describes his early life in Scotland, his move to America, his appreciation of nature, and his work to establish Yosemite National Park and the Sierra Club. Included is the often-told story of his Alaska adventure with his dog Stickeen in 1870. Full-color acrylic artwork illustrates the text.
Author: Kathryn Lasky

Title: John Muir: America's Naturalist
Annotation: This illustrated biography of John Muir focuses on his time in Yosemite National Park. Each page has a few lines of text and a quote from Muir's writing and faces a full-page lush landscape painting. A fine introduction to the naturalist and founder of the Sierra Club.
Author: Thomas Locker
Standard: HSS K.3, HSS K.6, HSS 1.2, HSS 1.5, HSS 2.5, HSS 3.1, HSS 3.3, HSS 4.1, HSS 4.3

Title: John Muir: Saving the Wilderness
Annotation: This is a brief biography about John Muir, a naturalist, who wrote articles and books about plants and animals in their environment and whose efforts helped to create the National Parks Service. Several vintage photographs are included.
Author: Corinne J. Naden, Rose Blue

Title: John Smith Escapes Again!
Annotation: Describes the daring escapades of seventeenth-century English explorer John Smith, who faced dangers such as pirates, slave drivers, angry mobs, and attacks by Native Americans. This book is based on extensive research, including works by Smith himself and the work of scholarly biographers. Illustrated with comic-strip panels and traditional artwork that bring detail and humor to the adventures.
Author: Rosalyn Schanzer

Title: John Sutter and the California Gold Rush
Annotation: Written in graphic-novel format, this book gives a short history of the 1849 California Gold Rush. It focuses on the discovery of gold at John Sutter’s Mill and how that discovery changed both California and the rest of the nation. An engaging choice for reluctant readers.
Author: Matt Doeden

Title: John, Paul, George, and Ben
Annotation: This is the humorous story of four mischievous lads (and a fifth, Thomas Jefferson) who were always getting into trouble for one reason or another until they grew up to be the founding fathers of the United States. The illustrations blend period elements—such as wood-grain texturing, woodcut lines, and formal compositions typical of the era—with exaggerated figures in a modern cartoon style.
Author: Lane Smith

Title: Jose Rizal: Ang Martir ng Bagumbayan (Jose Rizal: The Martyr of Bagumbayan)
Annotation: This biography narrates the important events in Rizal's life and his role in Philippine history. The book focuses on the values of love of one's country, freedom and justice, and the courage and bravery exemplified by Filipino national heroes.
Author: Mike Bigornia

Title: José! Born to Dance: The Story of José Limon
Annotation: An illustrated biography of Mexican-born dancer José Limon, who moved to the United States and later became world famous as a dancer and choreographer. The illustrations by Raul Colon capture the dancer’s strength and grace.
Author: Susanna Reich

Title: Josefina
Annotation: This is a counting book inspired by Mexican folk artist Josefina Aguilar, who makes painted clay figures. Richly detailed illustrations capture the essence of the Mexican culture and Aguilar’s artwork.
Author: Jeanette Winter
Topic: Ethnic Studies, Visual Arts, Women’s Studies
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Josephine: The Dazzling Life of Josephine Baker
Annotation: Josephine Baker was a performer and civil rights advocate who worked her way from the slums of St. Louis to the grandest stages in the world.
Author: Patricia Hruby Powell
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General
Award: Coretta Scott King Illustrator Honor, Robert F. Sibert Award

Title: Jouanah: A Hmong Cinderella (Ntsuag Nos: Ib Tug Cinderella Hmoob)
Annotation: Despite a cruel stepmother's schemes, Ntsuag Nos, a young Hmong girl, finds true love and happiness with the aid of her dead mother's spirit and a pair of special sandals. This higher-level text is illustrated with acrylic paintings. English and Hmong versions and a teacher's guide are also available. Translated by Jean Moua and Tzexa Cherta Lee.
Author: Jewell Reinhart Coburn, Tzexa Cherta Lee

Title: Journal of Wong Ming: A Chinese Miner, The
Annotation: The Chinese immigrant experience in 1852 California is related in diary form through the journal writings of ten-year-old Wong Ming-Chung (Runt), who leaves the famine and war of China only to find hardship, bitter racism, and death while prospecting for gold on the great "Golden Mountain." Despite the hostile environment, Runt makes numerous new friendships, overcoming cultural and language differences. California author and setting.
Author: Laurence Yep

Title: Journey Home
Annotation: After being released from an internment camp, a Japanese American girl and her family try to reconstruct their lives amidst a community's anti-Japanese sentiments. Human rights violations are depicted in this sequel to JOURNEY TO TOPAZ. The book can easily be used for character education. California author.
Author: Yoshiko Uchida

Title: Journey into the Rainforest
Annotation: This is a tour of the rain forest ecosystem, including ecology, animals, food chains, and interrelationships between plants and animals. An examination of the human impact and deforestation on this habitat is included. Large and detailed color photographs on every page bring the text to life as the reader takes this guided tour through the rain forest.
Author: Tim Knight

Title: Journey of the One and Only Declaration of Independence, The
Annotation: An informational picture book that introduces the sometimes bumpy travels of the Declaration of Independence, from its adoption and printing to its final home in the National Archives. Illustrated with bright multimedia artwork that brings a hint of old political cartoons and enhances the informal tone of the text. Readers will come away with a new appreciation for this piece of history.
Author: Judith St. George

Title: Journey to the New World: The Diary of Remember Patience Whipple, Mayflower, 1620, A
Annotation: Mem is a twelve-year-old passenger on the "Mayflower" in 1620. Through her diary readers learn what it might have been like to sail across the Atlantic Ocean with the Pilgrims. The diary concludes after Mem's first year in the New World. Included are a historical note, prints, and maps. The book is part of the Dear America series.
Author: Kathryn Lasky

Title: Journey to the River Sea
Annotation: Sent from England in 1910 with her governess to live with distant relatives in Brazil, Maia finds that her new family is not at all what she hoped it would be. In this complex and entertaining adventure set amid the sights and sounds of the Amazon rainforest, Maia's encounters with a large cast of colorful, eccentric characters finally bring her to the life of her dreams.
Author: Eva Ibbotson

Title: Journey to Topaz
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Japanese American Yuki has plans for Christmas in 1941. But those plans are abruptly altered as Japanese living on the West Coast are labeled enemy aliens and her father is arrested by the FBI. Yuki, her mother, and her older brother are incarcerated - first in a horse stall and then in a barbed-wire enclosed camp in the Utah desert. California author.
Author: Yoshiko Uchida

Title: Journey: Stories of Migration, The
Annotation: This picture book about migration features six migratory animals: monarch butterflies, desert locusts, gray whales, American silver eels, caribou, and arctic terns. Each vignette tells of the beginning and the end of the creature's migratory journey. Large, colorful full-page illustrations beautifully enhance the text.
Author: Cynthia Rylant

Title: Journeys for Freedom: A New Look at America’s Story
Annotation: Presents the true stories of people who sought freedom and shaped the events of America’s past. Double-page spreads of each story are accompanied by detailed color illustrations. Includes a collection of maps. Useful for reports as well as for browsing. California author.
Author: Elspeth Leacock, Susan Washburn Buckley
Standard: HSS 5.4, HSS 5.5, HSS 5.6, HSS 5.7, HSS 5.8, HSS 5.9, HSS 8.4, HSS 8.7, HSS 8.8, HSS 8.9, HSS 8.10, HSS 8.11, HSS 8.12

Title: Jovenes astronomos (Young Astronomers)
Annotation: A brief history of astronomy, basic information, and advice on how to get started in astronomy are described in this guide for young people. Pictures, photographs, and easy-to-follow activities all provide information on stars, planets, galaxies, and how astronomers research the universe.
Author: Harry Ford

Title: Joyful Noise: Poems for Two Voices, A
Annotation: This collection of poems about insects is written for two voices. The poems provide information on the behaviors and characteristics of 14 different insects, including honey bees, grasshoppers, fireflies, and the chrysalis stage of butterflies. Whimsical pencil drawings illustrate each poem.
Author: Paul Fleischman
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing, Mathematics, Science

Title: Juan Bobo Goes to Work: A Puerto Rican Folktale
Annotation: This Puerto Rican folktale tells how a boy tries to do exactly as his mother tells him, but keeps getting things all wrong. Some Spanish words and phrases are incorporated into the text. The award-winning illustrations use varied perspectives and bright Caribbean colors.
Author: Marisa Montes (reteller)

Title: Juan Bobo y el caballo de siete colores: Una leyenda puertorriquena (Juan Bobo and the Horse of Seven Colors: A Puerto Rican Legend)
Annotation: Juan Bobo wins seven wishes from a magical horse and wastes six of them while trying to make the king's daughter laugh. Bold watercolors add interest to the legend, and basic information about Puerto Rico is provided in the closing notes.
Author: Jan Mike

Title: Juan Quezada
Annotation: Based on his own oral history, artist Juan Quezada passes on to his grandson the tradition of making pottery while they retell the story of how he single-handedly re-created the lost art of the Casas Grandes culture and eventually transformed the abandoned Mexican town of Mata Ortiz into a famous village of potters. The watercolor illustrations realistically depict their local Mexican landscapes and pottery motifs. A Spanish version is available.
Author: Shelley Dale
Topic: Diversity, Ethnic Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Jubela
Annotation: After a mother rhino is killed by poachers, the baby is adopted and survives. Pastel illustrations capture the African savannah, intense heat, and Jubela's plight. Based on a true story, this book illustrates how the actions of poachers are causing the rhino to become extinct.
Author: Cristina Kessler

Title: Judy Moody Saves the World
Annotation: In this book the third in the Judy Moody series, Judy is inspired by her third grade class's environmental preservation project. She devises a project that impacts the family's recycling efforts and requires the confiscation of her classmates' wooden pencils. California author and illustrator.
Author: Megan McDonald

Title: Julia Morgan Built a Castle
Annotation: Tells the story of Julia Morgan, the architect of the Hearst Castle in San Simeon, California. Morgan forged her career at a time when female architects were very rare. She was the first woman to graduate with a certificate of architecture from the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris and worked as an architect of Hearst Castle for years. The use of color and light in the full-page illustrations enhance the depictions of structures and space. California author.
Author: Celeste Davidson Mannis
Topic: American History, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Visual Arts, Women’s Studies
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Julio’s Magic
Annotation: Julio, a young boy in Mexico who is an aspiring wood carver, discovers the power of friendship when he helps his mentor win a prestigious wood-carving contest. Instead of entering his work into a local contest, Julio helps his nearly blind mentor finish a series of carvings for which the mentor wins a sizable cash prize. Illustrations include photo collages and insets that show beautiful carvings. Includes some Spanish words.
Author: Arthur Dorros
Topic: Visual Arts, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Jumanji
Annotation: One boring afternoon, Peter and Judy play a strange board game that they find in a park. Fantasy and reality blend together in Van Allsburg's signature black-and-white illustrations as the bizarre game comes to life and the pair's quiet house transforms into an exotic jungle. Also written by this author are the stories WRETCHED STONE and WRECK OF THE ZEPHYR.
Author: Chris Van Allsburg

Title: Junebug
Annotation: Because age ten is when boys living in the Auburn Street projects are forced to join gangs, Junebug would rather remain nine years old. Junebug shows great courage in his resistance to gang membership and his devotion to his family.
Author: Alice Mead

Title: Jungle Book, The
Annotation: This collection of stories relate the adventures of Mowgli, a young boy raised by wolves, as he learns the ways of the jungle. Pinkney's watercolor illustrations bring the exciting adventure to life.
Author: Rudyard Kipling

Title: Just a Dream
Annotation: A boy begins to understand the importance of taking care of the environment when he has a dream about a future Earth devastated by pollution. The well-crafted text is accompanied by striking full-color paintings and could introduce units dealing with pollution and the protection of Earth's resources.
Author: Chris Van Allsburg
Standard: HSS K.1, HSS 1.1, LS 3.3, LS 4.3, ES 6.6

Title: Just a Minute: A Trickster Tale and Counting Book
Annotation: Grandma Beetle stalls for time when Senor Calavera, a skeleton representing Death, comes to collect her. After helping her count, in English and Spanish, as she makes her birthday preparations, he changes his mind. The illustrations draw strongly upon Mexican culture. California author and illustrator.
Author: Yuyi Morales
Classification: Counting Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Just a Second: A Different Way to Look at Time
Annotation: On the first page of this book, author Steve Jenkins explains that a lot can happen in just one second, amazing things can happen in a short time, and other things “unfold more slowly.” What follows are examples of things that happen in a second, a minute, an hour, a day, and so on. Each realistic cut-paper collage is accompanied by a sentence that describes what happens in that amount of time. End matter includes a history of the universe and life spans of plants and animals.
Author: Steve Jenkins

Title: Just as Good: How Larry Doby Changed America’s Game
Annotation: The life of African American baseball player Larry Doby is seen through the eyes of a young boy who loves baseball. Just 11 weeks after Jackie Robinson broke the color barrier in professional baseball, Doby joined the Cleveland Indians. Doby’s performance helped the Indians win the World Series in 1948, and it paved the way for many other African Americans to join the major leagues. Period details are vividly portrayed in the illustrations.
Author: Chris Crowe

Title: Just Behave, Pablo Picasso!
Annotation: This title about Picasso reflects the author and illustrator’s intent to boldly capture the variety of Picasso’s evolving styles in art and his moods, including the inspiration and motivation he experienced despite negative reactions to his art from critics. Readers can view many paintings, including the unique portraits of African masks and Cubist abstracts that send a message about staying true to one’s passion. A Spanish version of this book (COMPORTATE, PABLO PICASSO!) is also available.
Author: Jonah Winter
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures, Visual Arts
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: Just Being Audrey
Annotation: This picture-book biography introduces Audrey Hepburn, actress and humanitarian. As a child, she wanted to be a dancer, but the other girls made fun of her because she was too tall, her feet were too big, and her neck was too long. The book describes Hepburn’s life during Nazi-occupied Holland, her budding career as an actress, and her humanitarian work for UNICEF. Illustrated with expressive pen-and-ink and watercolor artwork.
Author: Margaret Cardillo

Title: Just Juice
Annotation: Set in Appalachia, nine-year-old Juice realizes that her father's unemployment has endangered her family and decides that she must return to school and learn to read in order to help their chances of surviving, keeping their house - and their dignity. The book contains mature situations.
Author: Karen Hesse

Title: Just One Flick of a Finger
Annotation: When a young boy takes a gun to school to scare off the bully who has been tormenting him, the gun is accidentally fired during a scuffle. This picture book has large, acrylic images that clearly show the actions and expressions of those who are wittingly and those who are unwittingly caught up in the violence. California illustrator.
Author: Marybeth Lorbiecki
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Just So Stories
Annotation: Originally published in 1902, this collection of 12 original and classic folktales is set in India. Among those included are "How the Rhinoceros Got his Skin," "How the First Letter was Written," and "How the Whale Got His Throat." The illustrations perfectly enhance the exotic setting of the stories. This book is also available on audiocassette.
Author: Rudyard Kipling

Title: Justin Case: School, Drool, and Other Daily Disasters
Annotation: Justin Case is a worrywart who records his hilarious observations about third grade in a diary. He is such a worrywart that he worries “about what to worry about.” The easy, direct language in the diary shows him as a believable character. May lead to discussions about getting along with others and about self-esteem. Occasional line drawings add humor to the story. First in the “Justin Case” series.
Author: Rachel Vail

Title: Justin Morgan Had a Horse
Annotation: Little Bub is taken as payment by schoolmaster Justin Morgan in late eighteenth-century Vermont. Bub is a workhorse by day and a race and pulling horse after sunset each night. His fame grows as a wondrous horse with stamina and courage. This book is a fine springboard to interest students in research about this breed of horses and their place in American history.
Author: Marguerite Henry

Title: Kai’s Journey to Gold Mountain: An Angel Island Story
Annotation: Based on the experiences of a real person, this compelling story tells of twelve-year-old Kai’s emigration from China to the United States in the 1930s to join his father. Traveling alone, Kai exhibits a courageous and adventurous spirit as he faces his lengthy journey, a humiliating medical examination, and an interrogation by immigration officials. Exquisite watercolor-and-pencil illustrations depict the environment and enrich the text.
Author: Katrina Saltonstall Currier

Title: Kakapo Rescue: Saving the World’s Strangest Parrot
Annotation: Author Sy Montgomery and photographer Nic Bishop head to remote Codfish Island, off the coast of New Zealand, to study, write about, and photograph an animal heading for extinction. Millions of kakapo parrots roamed the area in the past, but now fewer than 90 are known to exist. Montgomery and Bishop join a group of volunteers as they work to protect these beautiful, flightless birds. Illustrated with full-color photographs, the book is part of the “Scientists in the Field” series. Sibert Medal winner (2011); NSTA Outstanding Science Trade Book (2011).
Author: Sy Montgomery

Title: Kami and the Yaks
Annotation: A young deaf Sherpa boy in the Himalayas helps his father and brother as they search for the family’s missing yaks. Kami must struggle up steep paths through a hailstorm and, after discovering that a small yak has become wedged between rocks, he must work to make his family understand what he has discovered. Striking watercolor artwork complements the story. Use to spark discussions about symbolic illustrations, courage, communication, and disabilities.
Author: Andrea Stenn Stryer

Title: Kaspar the Titanic Cat
Annotation: Johnny Trott, an orphan, works as a bellboy at the Savoy Hotel in London and  becomes the caretaker of Kaspar, a cat whose owner, a famous opera singer, suddenly dies. A wealthy family at the hotel befriends Johnny, decides to adopt Kaspar, and takes the cat with them as they travel aboard the Titanic to New York. Johnny stows away on the ill-fated ship to stay close to his new friends. Illustrated with black-and-white sketches. The story examines the relationship between social classes in England in the early 1900s.
Author: Michael Morpurgo
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures

Title: Kate and the Beanstalk
Annotation: This retelling of the classic folktale features a gutsy, resourceful heroine who climbs the beanstalk to outsmart the greedy giant. Potter's signature expressionistic illustrations, rendered in ink, gouache, and watercolor with a large-sized format, perfectly enhance this feminist version.
Author: Mary Pope Osborne

Title: Kathleen O’Byrne, Irish Dancer
Annotation: Kathleen loves being an Irish dancer, so when she is not selected to participate in a dance competition, she puts on her own show with the help and encouragement of her neighborhood friends.
Author: Declan Carville
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA D PreK-12.3

Title: Katie's Sunday Afternoon
Annotation: On a hot day, Katie and her grandmother visit the art museum, where Katie climbs into the paintings of pointillist artists Seurat, Pisarro, and Signac. Includes information about pointillism. See also KATIE AND THE SUNFLOWERS (2001), KATIE AND THE MONA LISA (1991), and KATIE MEETS THE IMPRESSIONISTS (1999).
Author: James Mayhew
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Katie's Trunk
Annotation: Katie, a member of a family of Tory sympathizers, is dismayed by the snubs of former friends who side with American rebels. She stubbornly risks her own safety in an attempt to protect her family's home and belongings when neighbors ransack her home. Watercolor illustrations convey the emotion of the story and provide historical detail.
Author: Ann Warren Turner

Title: Katy no tiene bolsa (Katy No-Pocket)
Annotation: From the author of the CURIOUS GEORGE stories, comes the story of Katy, a kangaroo, in search of finding her pouch or pocket. She visits the city and discovers a way to have more pockets than any kangaroo ever did.
Author: Emmy Payne

Title: Keep Your Eye on the Kid: The Early Years of Buster Keaton
Annotation: This beautifully illustrated biography of Buster Keaton evokes the streets of early twentieth-century America and brings the remarkable childhood of a timeless comedian to life. The story recounts his early experiences in his parents’ vaudeville act and his fascination with the emerging film industry. Illustrated with cartoon-style panels and line drawings.
Author: Catherine Brighton
Standard: VAPA T PreK-12.1, VAPA T PreK-12.3, VAPA T PreK-12.4, VAPA T PreK-12.5

Title: Keeper of the Doves
Annotation: In the late 1800s in Kentucky, Amen McBee and her four sisters both fear and torment the seemingly sinister Mr. Tominski, yet their father continues to provide for his needs. Amie's own love of words is central to the story. The plot moves with gentle tension to its poignant conclusion and the truth about Mr. Tominski and Amen's own family. This book is a good choice for small groups and book clubs.
Author: Betsy Cromer Byars

Title: Keeping Quilt, The
Annotation: Great-Grandma Anna comes to America from Russia during her childhood and brings with her a quilt that her mother has made for her. Over the ensuing years, the quilt is handed down through five generations. The quilt is used for the wedding canopy as well as to welcome new babies into the world. This book incorporates Jewish beliefs with family traditions. Black-and-white illustrations with some color highlights help to convey the passage of time.
Author: Patricia Polacco
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Keeping the Night Watch
Annotation: In this sequel to THE WAY A DOOR CLOSES, thirteen-year-old C. J. chronicles what happens to his family when his father, who temporarily left, returns home, and those who were left behind must deal with their anger, hope, fear, sense of abandonment, and forgiveness. Using a variety of poetic forms, the author reveals the emotions of an African American family that is learning to heal and stay together. The story is accompanied by watercolor illustrations. An ALA Notable Children’s Book (2009). California author.
Author: Hope Anita Smith

Title: Kid Blink Beats the World
Annotation: This engaging picture book for older children tells of the newsboys and girls of 1899 who went on strike to protest the extra penny that the powerful newspaper owners decided to charge for each stack of papers. It depicts underprivileged youngsters whose actions made a difference in the world. Illustrated with sepia-tone artwork done with ink and watercolor.
Author: Don Brown

Title: Kid Who Named Pluto and the Stories of Other Extraordinary Young People in Science, The
Annotation: Presented in this small book are short biographies of nine children and young adults who made an impact on the world through their discoveries and talents. Featured are Robert Goddard, Venetia Burney, Isaac Asimov, Philo Taylor Farnsworth, Mary Anning, Sarah Flannery, Truman Henry Safford, Emily Rosa, and Louis Braille. Photos and whimsical illustrations enhance the text.
Author: Marc McCutcheon
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Kid Who Ran for President, The
Annotation: Sixth-grader Judd Moon runs for president with the help of his best friend, Lane, as his campaign manager. Judd establishes the Lemonade Party and promises to abolish all homework. Throughout the campaign, Lane brings up interesting political issues for discussion. This humorous and informative book teaches about different aspects of running for office. It is a fun read anytime, but particularly during election years. THE KID WHO BECAME PRESIDENT is a sequel.
Author: Dan Gutman

Title: Kids Around the World Celebrate!: The Best Feast and Festivals from Many Lands
Annotation: "Welcoming the New Year," "Celebrating Before and After Fasts," "Giving Thanks," and "Renewing the Spirit" are the four main headings. Festivals and holidays of various countries are divided into those topics. Jones describes each celebration and related hands-on projects. Useful in the studies of cultures around the world and holidays.
Author: Lynda Jones

Title: Killing Germs, Saving Lives: The Quest for the First Vaccines
Annotation: This book traces the discovery and development of various vaccines. Text and pictures relate biographical information about each featured scientist who is credited with the discovery and development of a particular vaccine. Diseases discussed include smallpox, cholera, polio, rabies, and anthrax. The inviting text is enhanced by many color photos and prints. This book, which includes a glossary, resources, and an index, is a part of the Science Quest series.
Author: Glen Phelan

Title: Kindred Souls
Annotation: Young Jake and his grandfather, Billy, are “kindred souls.” Their family has been on the farm for the duration of Billy’s life and prior to his birth. When Billy falls ill, Jake and his family decide to rebuild the sod house where Billy grew up. As it turns out, the sod house becomes not only the place where Billy will live, but also the place where he will die. A poignant tale that has a touching second plot about a stray dog bonding with young Jake.
Author: Patricia MacLachlan

Title: King Long Shanks
Annotation: This version of Hans Christian Andersen's THE EMPEROR'S NEW CLOTHES features a frog as the egocentric king in a "nice shade of green" and with "very good legs." Two conniving tailors dazzle King Long Shanks with poetic descriptions of their invisible cloth and the King participates in the Summer Parade in the buff. The sly humor of the text is matched by the detailed, cartoonlike illustrations done in watercolors, pencil, and pen-and-ink.
Author: Jane Yolen

Title: King's Chessboard, The
Annotation: A wise man asks to be rewarded by a king in grains of rice on a chessboard. He requests one grain of rice on the first square and double the amount on each successive square. This story illustrates an exponential function.
Author: David Birch

Title: King's Commissioners, The
Annotation: The king appoints a new commissioner to solve each problem he encounters. Fearing that his government is getting too big, he decides to count them, and in the process, learns new ways of counting and the importance of place value. The bright acrylic paintings feature hidden puzzles and burst with humor. California illustrator.
Author: Aileen Friedman
Classification: Counting Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: King’s Equal, The
Annotation: A dying king leaves his kingdom to his son, on one condition: the son must find a wife who is his equal. Counselors are given a year to find the perfect wife, but the prince finds each of the prospects lacking. Rosamund, a worthy candidate, challenges the prince to prove his worth to her. Features many elements common in fairy tales: romance, repetition of language, the number three, and a moral in which good triumphs over selfishness and greed. Detailed, colorful illustrations reveal life in the era. A short chapter book that also works well as a read-aloud.
Author: Katherine Paterson

Title: Kingdom of the Sun: A Book of the Planets
Annotation: The Greeks and Romans attempted to explain natural phenomenon through myths. This book combines modern-day knowledge about the sun, moon, and planets with ancient mythology. The vivid illustrations depict the mythological aspects and incorporate shades of golds, yellows, oranges, blues, and black, the colors of the universe. A chart at the back of the book gives current information about each topic presented.
Author: Jacqueline Mitton

Title: Kingfisher Book of Family Poems, The
Annotation: The 159 poems in this anthology explore the dynamics of families and family situations. The poems are poignant, funny, sad, and insightful. Includes index of poets and index of first lines.
Author: Belinda Hollyer (selector)

Title: Kite Fighters, The
Annotation: In Korea in 1473, eleven-year-old Young-sup overcomes a rivalry with his older brother who, as the first-born son, receives special treatment from their father and combines his kite-flying skill with his brother's kite-making skill in an attempt to win the New Year kite competition.
Author: Linda Sue Park

Title: Kites Sail High: A Book About Verbs
Annotation: Ruth Heller provides an engaging lesson on verbs. Vivid double-page spreads accompany rhyming text that addresses verb tenses, the subjunctive mood, helping verbs, irregular verbs, and passive and active voices. This is an excellent resource for grammar and revision lessons. It provides an effective review of verb forms for older students and may be used to introduce verbs for younger students and English learners. See other titles in the “World of Language” series.
Author: Ruth Heller
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Knee-High Man and Other Tales, The
Annotation: The six delightfully funny stories in this selection deal with animals and their problems; one explains nature, and the last two are concerned with humans' stupidity and insatiable desires.
Author: Julius Lester

Title: Knights of the Kitchen Table
Annotation: Three modern-day boys are transported back in time to battle fire-breathing dragons and vile-smelling giants in the time of King Arthur. Short chapters, contemporary and humorous dialogue, and nonstop action are featured in an early chapter-book format. Lane Smith's zany pencil and charcoal illustrations are suitably gross to match the story line. This book is part of The Time Warp Trio series.
Author: Jon Scieszka

Title: Knights of the Lunch Table: The Dodgeball Chronicles
Annotation: New student Artie struggles to fit into Camelot Middle School. He befriends a group of less-popular students to fight a group of bullies and the evil principal, while enlisting the help of one of his teachers, Mr. Merlyn. After opening a mysterious school locker, Artie finds it full of intriguing items. He instigates a dodge-ball game that will determine who rules the school. Loosely based on the King Arthur stories, this colorful graphic novel—the first in a series—will entertain even the most reluctant readers.
Author: Frank Cammuso

Title: Knock at a Star: A Child's Introduction to Poetry
Annotation: This book is an appealing collection of American and English poetry. The revised edition is one of the best introductions to poetry available for children.
Author: Dorothy Kennedy, X. J. Kennedy

Title: Knockin' on Wood: Starring Peg Leg Bates
Annotation: This picture book tells the story of Clayton "Peg Leg" Bates, an African American who lost his leg in a factory accident at the age of twelve and went on to become a world-famous tap dancer. The watercolor and ink illustrations are full of movement and flair.
Author: Lynne Barasch
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Knots on a Counting Rope
Annotation: Each time Grandfather tells his blind grandson a story about the boy's birth and his accomplishments, Grandfather adds a knot on a counting rope. The little boy learns to have no fear of the darkness and to see with his heart and know that his grandfather will love him forever. The text underscores the power of storytelling. This story can be read aloud by two voices, and could be used to introduce a unit on Native Americans or the desert ecosystem.
Author: Bill Martin, Jr., John Archambault
Classification: Counting Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, Mathematics, Science

Title: Knucklehead: Tall Tales and Mostly True Stories About Growing Up Scieszka
Annotation: Jon Scieszka grew up in Michigan in a family of six boys. In this book, he shares vignettes from his childhood. Numerous images appear throughout, including many family photographs, so that the work resembles a scrapbook. Lively and humorous, this is an excellent selection for reluctant readers—especially boys.
Author: Jon Scieszka

Title: Koko's Kitten
Annotation: This true story is about teaching a female gorilla named Koko how to communicate using the gestures of American Sign Language. Prior to Koko's twelfth birthday, she asks for a cat as her birthday gift. This story relates the touching relationship that developed between Koko and her kitten, Ball. Available in paperback only.
Author: Francine Patterson

Title: Korean Cinderella
Annotation: Pear Blossom goes to the village festival in spite of her wicked stepmother. This Korean adaptation provides another cultural version of a popular fairy tale. California author.
Author: Shirley Climo

Title: Kua Fu Races with the Sun
Annotation: Kua Fu was a man of great strength. He could not bear to see the people suffering in darkness all day long without the sun shining upon them so he decides to race with the sun to bring it under his control. This well-illustrated bilingual book is written in simplified Chinese and in English.
Author: Jiannan Feng

Title: La boda de la ratoncita: Una leyenda Maya (The Mouse Bride: A Mayan Legend)
Annotation: Searching for the strongest husband for his daughter, a mouse goes to the sun, cloud, wind, and wall in search of a qualified candidate, only to find him among his fellow mice. Full-page watercolor illustrations accompany the text.
Author: Judith Dupre

Title: La familia de Mic (Mic's Family)
Annotation: Although Mic appears to be a completely normal and sensible boy, his family has a wide range of oddities or strange practices. Mic, however, loves their idiosyncrasies. The double-page watercolor illustrations are as clever and amusing as the narrative.
Author: Miguel Angel Pacheco

Title: La leyenda de la cometa (The Kite's Legend)
Annotation: Dong-Dong cannot get over the loss of his new kite. To console him, his grandfather tells him the legend of Ying-Ying and Ming-Ming who, through their love and ingenuity, outwit the Chinese emperor and his men. Double-page illustrations executed in traditional India ink on rice paper depict the ambience of contemporary and classical China in this story.
Author: Chen Jiang Hong

Title: La mariposa (The Butterfly)
Annotation: Because he can speak only Spanish, Francisco, a child of migrant workers, has trouble when he begins first grade. He cannot understand anything that is being said; however, a small caterpillar in a jar in the classroom opens the way for respect and acceptance. Based on an incident in the author's life, this story is adapted from a chapter in THE CIRCUIT. California author and setting.
Author: Francisco Jimenez
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, Science

Title: La procesion de Naty (Naty's Parade)
Annotation: Naty wears a giant mouse costume and her brand-new cowboy boots for a traditional music and dance festival in Mexico. She gets separated from her father, but he finds her and carries her home to bed. The vibrant color illustrations depict masked characters, regional dancers, and whimsical animals.
Author: Gina Freschet

Title: La silla de Pedro (Peter's Chair)
Annotation: When Peter discovers his blue furniture is being painted pink for a new baby sister, he rescues an unpainted chair and runs away with his dog Willie. Later he realizes he has grown so big that he needs a grown-up chair and helps his father paint his little chair pink. The drawings and collage are in rich, warm colors.
Author: Ezra Jack Keats

Title: La vuelta de Pedro Urdemales (Pedro Urdemales's Return)
Annotation: This collection of 11 stories relates the adventures and misadventures of an amusing peasant who manages to always come out ahead in every situation. This selection contains black-and-white illustrations and a glossary.
Author: Floridor Perez

Title: Lady Liberty: A Biography
Annotation: This well-researched picture book tells the story of the Statue of Liberty from many points of view. It begins with a Latvian immigrant who sees the statue for the first time and ends with quotes from other European immigrants describing their thoughts as Lady Liberty welcomed them to America. Illustrated with stunning full-page artwork done with watercolor, ink, and pencil. Includes a foldout page showing Lady Liberty at her unveiling.
Author: Doreen Rappaport

Title: Lady of Chi'ao Kuo: Warrior of the South, Southern China, A.D. 531
Annotation: Using diary entries written in the sixth century, sixteen-year-old Princess Redbird of the Hsien tribe reveals her role as liaison between her own people and the local Chinese colonists in southern China during times of peace and war. The epilogue presents the historical facts about the real Lady of Ch'ao Kuo and a historical note provides a summary of the period. Includes family tree, map, and archival reproductions. From the Royal Diaries series. California author.
Author: Laurence Yep

Title: Lamp, the Ice, and the Boat Called Fish: Based on a True Story, The
Annotation: In 1913 a Canadian research vessel named KARLUK, Aleutian for "fish," became trapped in Arctic ice. The group, including two children, survived using Inupiaq Indian cultural traditions. Scratchboard illustrations provide details in hues of brown and ice blue.
Author: Jacqueline Briggs Martin

Title: Land I Lost: Adventures of a Boy in Vietnam, The
Annotation: This selection contains action-filled memoirs of the author's childhood in rural Vietnam, reveals the quality of day-to-day village life, and describes dangerous confrontations with wild animals. The last story reflects the violence of the war that forever changed the quality of life described in these stories.
Author: Quang Nhuong Huynh

Title: Landed
Annotation: A young boy leaves his Chinese village for the United States and is held under the Chinese Exclusion Act at Angel Island, where he waits to be reunited with his father. This poignant story is based on the experiences of the author’s father-in-law and includes information about the history of Chinese immigration as well as resources for student research. Featuring full-page illustrations, this work can be used as a picture-book read-aloud for middle and upper grades to introduce the subject of Chinese immigration in California. Compare with Louise Peacock’s AT ELLIS ISLAND: A HISTORY IN MANY VOICES (2007). California author.
Author: Milly Lee

Title: Landry News, The
Annotation: A fifth-grader starts a newspaper with an editorial that prompts her unmotivated classroom teacher to really begin teaching again. He is later threatened with disciplinary action as a result of his teaching. The story deals with First Amendment rights.
Author: Andrew Clements

Title: LaRue for Mayor: Letters from the Campaign Trail
Annotation: Mrs. LaRue’s dog, Ike, decides to run for mayor of Snort City after realizing the front-runner, Chief Bugwort, wants to enforce leash, curfew, and other laws for dogs. The campaign turns into a frenzy while poor Mrs. LaRue is confined to the hospital. Letters from Ike on the campaign trail to Mrs. LaRue keep both Mrs. LaRue and readers informed. Part of a series about the dog, Ike LaRue.
Author: Mark Teague

Title: Las aventuras de Maxi, el perro taxista (The Adventures of Taxi Dog)
Annotation: Maxi, a stray dog in New York City, is adopted by a taxi driver. They ride around together and share adventures each day. The illustrations in oil paint over acrylic draw readers into the action.
Author: Debra Barracca, Sal Barracca

Title: Las bellas hijas de Mufaro (Mufaro's Beautiful Daughters)
Annotation: Based on the Cinderella story, this version features Mufaro's daughters, who are opposites—one is kind and compassionate, the other is selfish and mean-spirited. Readers follow the daughters on their trip to see the King for the purpose of marriage and learn about the rewards of being kind, regardless of the circumstances. Lush and dramatic ink-and-watercolor illustrations detail the clothing, flora, and fauna of the Zimbabwe setting.
Author: John Steptoe
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Winner

Title: Las Christmas: Escritores latinos recuerdan las tradiciones navidenas (Las Christmas: Favorite Latino Authors Share Their Holiday Memories)
Annotation: Twenty-five celebrated Latino authors, including Julia Alvarez, Sandra Cisnero, Victor Martinez, and Gary Soto, share a collection of holiday memoirs. The collection includes more than 20 recipes for a complete holiday dinner.
Author: Esmeralda Santiago (editor), Joile Davidow (editor)

Title: Las cosas que odio y otras exageraciones (Things I Hate and Other Exaggerations)
Annotation: This collection of 27 poems is told in a child's charming voice. The poems tell why the child hates to get up early, get a haircut, and other things. The illustrations are black-and-white line caricatures.
Author: Ana Maria Shua

Title: Las tres naranjas de la vida (The Three Oranges of Life)
Annotation: This classic tale tells about a sickly prince who saves himself and a beautiful princess after killing a mean dragon. The text is easy-to-read, and the illustrations are modernistic, full-page watercolors.
Author: Francesc Boada (adapter), Joan Amades

Title: Last Bit-Bear: A Fable, The
Annotation: This is a fable about a Bit-Bear, an endangered animal, looking for another of its kind. On his search he is distraught by the pollution and habitat alteration he sees. He becomes hopeful when he learns about the existence of National Parks which protect the environment. This book is available only in paperback.
Author: Sandra Chisholm Robinson

Title: Last Holiday Concert, The
Annotation: Life is usually easy for popular sixth-grader Hart Evans. When his music teacher puts him in charge of the holiday concert, Hart must use all of his leadership skills to unite the other students. Hart runs the show with his teacher watching, learning, and eventually helping out. The final result of their work is a success. The quick pace of the story makes it a good choice for reluctant readers.
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
Author: Andrew Clements

Title: Last Princess: The Story of Princess Ka'iulani of Hawaii
Annotation: This picture-book biography acquaints readers with the life story of Princess Ka‘iulani of Hawaii and the political upheaval that led to Hawaii's annexation to the United States in 1897. Hawaii's last princess, who never married, never ruled, and died at age twenty-three. Full-page gouache paintings reflect the islands' lush surroundings, the grayness of England, and the mixed heritage of the Hawaiians.
Author: Fay Stanley

Title: Last Stop on Market Street
Annotation: CJ, a young black boy, has a flurry of questions for his grandmother one rainy day. "How come we always gotta go here after church?" "Here" is a soup kitchen, where they work every Sunday.
Author: Matt de la Pena
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Winner, Newbery Winner

Title: Last Tales of Uncle Remus
Annotation: This edition of the Brer Rabbit tales retells the final adventures and misadventures of Brer Rabbit and his friends and enemies. Presented in authentic Southern dialect, the tales make great read-aloud choices.
Author: Julius Lester

Title: Last Train Journey, The
Annotation: A farmer's son doesn't pass his high school exam in spite of the family's hard work to save money for his studies. On his return from the city, he realizes his place was among his beloved family and in his land, not in the city.
Author: Thao Le

Title: Laughing Out Loud, I Fly: Poems in English and Spanish
Annotation: This is a series of vivid poems in both English and Spanish that celebrate the author's childhood. The poems paint pictures with their words and are illustrated with pale figures of images from Mexican folk art. California author.
Author: Juan Felipe Herrera

Title: Laughing Tomatoes and Other Spring Poems (Jitomates risuenos y otros poemas de primavera)
Annotation: California Latino poet Alarcon's bilingual collection of 19 poems celebrates spring and the fruits of family and sunshine. Colorful double-page illustrations feature a lively cast of characters, old and young, human and animal. California author.
Author: Francisco X. Alarcon

Title: Leaf by Leaf: Autumn Poems
Annotation: A collection of poems and excerpts of poems are introduced with photographs of wide, sweeping landscapes to highlight the magnificent colors of autumn. Short excerpts from the works of classic poets such as Yeats, Shelley, and Whitman are featured.
Author: Barbara Rogasky (selector)

Title: Leah’s Pony
Annotation: When drought in the 1930s turns a farm into dust, Leah sells her beloved pony for one dollar and uses the money to buy back her father’s tractor when the family’s belongings are put up for auction. This sets off a “penny auction”: neighbors buy the family’s belongings for small amounts and then return them. Illustrated with striking oil paintings.
Author: Elizabeth Friedrich

Title: Leaping Grasshoppers
Annotation: The author presents information on grasshoppers, including their anatomy, life cycle, and their habitats. The vivid illustrations include pictures of various types of grasshoppers as well as close-up views. A glossary is included. See other books in the Pull-Ahead Books series.
Author: Christine Zuchora-Walske

Title: Leaves in October, The
Annotation: Two children and their unemployed father struggle to leave a homeless shelter for a better life before the leaves turn color in October.
Author: Karen Ackerman

Title: Lee Ann: The Story of a Vietnamese-American Girl
Annotation: Eight-year-old Lee Ann, a Vietnamese girl, grows up in an American school and society. This books shows how aspects of both worlds are incorporated into a new life.
Author: Tricia Brown

Title: Legend of Freedom Hill, The
Annotation: Rosabel, a freed slave, and Sophie, a Jewish girl, team up to make enough money to free Rosabel’s mother from the slave catcher. The girls go gold hunting and find a vein of gold. They earn enough money to free Rosabel’s mother and trade the claim for the freedom of another five slaves. Illustrated with watercolor artwork.
Author: Linda Jacobs Altman

Title: Legend of Jimmy Spoon
Annotation: Jimmy Spoon is a young white boy who lived among the Shoshoni Indians during the early frontier days in Wyoming. This junior novel is based on facts.
Author: Kristiana Gregory

Title: Lemonade and Other Poems Squeezed from a Single Word
Annotation: Raczka explains that ever since he came across a poet who used a single word to create poetry, he wanted to try writing some for himself. The example he saw was “rain,” in which the poet Andrew Russ wrote a poem of three words using only the four letters from that word. What follows is a book that is part puzzle and part poetry. Each poem is presented in two different formats and is accompanied by playful illustrations.
Author: Bob Raczka

Title: Lemonade Crime, The
Annotation: Jessie and her brother Evan are both in fourth grade in a new school. When $200 in profits from a lemonade stand is stolen from Evan’s room, Jessie is sure she knows who the culprit is. Jessie organizes a secret after-school trial with herself as Evan’s lawyer. Ultimately the issue is resolved. Each chapter begins with the definition of a legal term. Although this is a sequel (to THE LEMONADE WAR), this work can stand on its own because the author provides sufficient background information.
Author: Jacqueline Davies
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Law and Legal Studies

Title: Lemurs on Location
Annotation: A personal introduction by a mother and daughter team highlights the physical characteristics and behavior of lemurs that are encountered at one of the last forests in Madagascar. Full-color photographs are captioned and support the lively text. A page of lemur facts provides information for beginning report writing. See other books in the On Location series.
Author: Kathy Darling

Title: Lenny’s Space
