Annotation: Academically gifted but devoid of emotions, Lenny drives people crazy and has no friends. He winds up in the office of the school counselor, who seems to be the only person who likes him. Lenny has cut himself off from all his feelings, but eventually he becomes friends with Van, who has leukemia. As Lenny continues to be helped by the counselor, he begins to mature. Foreshadowing is apparent in Lenny’s relationship with Van, and readers are likely to develop empathy as they read this story.
Author: Kate Banks

Title: Leon's Story
Annotation: This autobiographical selection relates the human rights violations suffered by the African American author as the son of a poor sharecropper in 1940s North Carolina. Edited oral interviews by the author reveal incidents of hatred and racism regarding schooling, seating in public facilities, and encounters with justice and the law. An author's afterword and an editor's note provide additional insight on the origins of the book.
Author: Leon Walter Tillage

Title: Leonardo da Vinci
Annotation: This biography captures the Italian Renaissance artist and inventor who, at around age thirty, began writing the outpourings of his amazing mind in the now famous notebooks. Text and illustrations illuminate this genius' life for young and old readers alike.
Author: Diane Stanley
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing, Mathematics, Science
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5, LS 5.2, PS 8.1, PS 8.2

Title: Leonardo da Vinci
Annotation: This biography of Leonardo da Vinci focuses on his scientific work rather than his artistic work. Krull has a great talent for engaging readers with her lively text. Occasional pen-and-ink drawings appear throughout. This book is the first in a new series, Giants of Science. California author.
Author: Kathleen Krull
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Leonardo Da Vinci: The Genius Who Defined the Renaissance
Annotation: This engaging biography examines the life of Renaissance genius Leonardo da Vinci, discussing not only his inquiries and accomplishments in art but his accomplishments in the various fields of science as well. It is illustrated throughout with photos of important locations, artwork of the period, and reproductions of his writing and artwork.
Author: John Phillips
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, Mathematics, Science

Title: Leonardo, Beautiful Dreamer
Annotation: This biography about Leonardo Da Vinci is filled with detailed illustrations and interesting facts about both Da Vinci and the Renaissance, as well as quotations from his notebooks. Da Vinci was a painter, sculptor, scientist, mathematician, and architect. However, he had little formal schooling and throughout his lifetime left many projects unfinished. An author's note, timeline, and bibliography are included.
Author: Robert Byrd
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Let It Begin Here! Lexington and Concord: First Battles of the American Revolution
Annotation: Presents a short history of the battles of Lexington and Concord and describes how the rebel leaders were warned of the approaching British and the standoff between 70 Lexington militiamen and 250 British regulars. Active verbs in the present tense work to create a vivid “you-are-there” account. The appealing format and double-page illustrations make it a good read-aloud choice.
Author: Dennis Brindell Fradin

Title: Let It Shine: Stories of Black Women Freedom Fighters
Annotation: This book compiles the life stories of 10 African American activists who struggled for freedom, women’s rights, and civil rights. Biographies of well-known leaders (Sojourner Truth, Harriet Tubman, Rosa Parks), as well as less familiar but important ones (Biddy Mason, Dorothy Irene Height), are included. The straightforward narrative is delivered with a lively storytelling style to show the prejudice and inequality each woman faced. Stephen Alcorn’s bold, abstract art offers allegorical interpretations of these heroines.
Author: Andrea Davis Pinkney
Topic: American History, Diversity, Ethnic Studies, Music, Women’s Studies
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA T PreK-12.1, HSS 3.4, HSS 8.9, HSS 8.11, HSS 11.10

Title: Let It Shine: Three Favorite Spirituals
Annotation: Bright collage illustrations accompany the lyrics of three well-known spirituals: “This Little Light of Mine,” “When the Saints Go Marching In,” and “He’s Got the Whole World in His Hands.” Includes a brief music score and a short history of pre-Civil War slave songs. Useful for studying African American culture and folklore or just for singing.
Author: Ashley Bryan
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.4

Title: Let Me Help! (¡Quiero Ayudar!)
Annotation: A pet parrot, Perico, wants to help his family get ready for the Cinco de Mayo celebration. He insists on helping with the preparation of tamales and pan dulce, tissue flowers, and the braiding of hair with ribbons. The family finds the perfect way for Perico to help: by perching on top of a float. Bright artwork catches the mood of the fiesta. Spanish translations appear on each page.
Author: Alma Flor Ada
Topic: Diversity, Lifestyles Around the World, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Let the River Run Silver Again
Annotation: The author, a classroom teacher, provides an informative and illustrative exploration of the efforts one school made to greatly impact the environment and nature of the Potomac River in a positive way and the difference those efforts made. Readers will learn that making a difference is not all that difficult. This book is highly recommended reading, especially for biology and environmental science teachers to use as a curriculum supplemental resource. It can also serve as a valuable addition to any personal, school, or community library.
Author: Sandy Burk

Title: Let's Go Downtown
Annotation: Sam and Mark take the bus to go downtown and experience the sights and sounds of the busy world in which they live and move.
Publisher: National Asian Center for Bilingual Education
Author: Jae Hyun Hahn, Le Van Loc, Mieko S. Han

Title: Let’s Talk About Race
Annotation: Author Julius Lester asks the reader about his/her “story” and introduces the concept of race as only one part of an individual or nation’s story. He asks questions and encourages readers to explore who they are and to tell their own stories. This book looks at race and prejudices and then conveys the message that if our skin were removed, all of us would look the same. The bold illustrations, done in a folk-art style, reflect the various races of the world. This is an excellent vehicle for starting discussions about families and race.
Author: Julius Lester

Title: Letter to Mrs. Roosevelt
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Margo fulfills a class assignment by writing a letter to Eleanor Roosevelt. She asks for help to save her family's home during the Great Depression.
Author: C. Coco De Young

Title: Letters from Rifka
Annotation: Letters by a young Russian Jewish girl describe her escape from Russia and the many challenges she faces trying to emigrate to America. This novel is based on the author's great-aunt's experiences and is useful for units on immigration and the exploration of the lives of our grandparents.
Author: Karen Hesse

Title: Letters from the Corrugated Castle: A Novel of Gold Rush California, 1850–1852
Annotation: An epistolary novel set in the 1850s, this is the story of thirteen-year-old Eldora, an orphan who moves with her guardians from Massachusetts to San Francisco. Eldora begins teaching English to two “Mexicano” children, befriends a boy searching for gold, and finds herself face-to-face with her influential mother. Connect with units on California history and the Gold Rush era.
Author: Joan W. Blos

Title: Letters to Leo
Annotation: Annie Rossi finally talks her father into getting a dog named Leo. She begins writing letters to Leo about her life as a fourth-grader—missives that are sweet, funny, and real. Writing to Leo also helps Annie process her feelings about her mother’s death the previous year and adapt to life without her. Lighthearted, with simple vocabulary and pencil sketches, this book may appeal to reluctant readers. Although it is a sequel to REMEMBERING MRS. ROSSI (2007), in which Annie writes about her mother’s death, the text stands on its own.
Author: Amy Hest
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health

Title: Letters to the Valley: A Harvest of Memories
Annotation: A collection of essays in the form of letters that explore the life of a Central Valley farming family. Read aloud about immigrant grandparents, the rhythms of life and work in an orchard, and the weaving together of a family and farm over three generations. Accompanied by warm, full-color illustrations that were created specifically for each of the letters in the book. California author and California setting.
Author: David Mas Masumoto

Title: Letting Swift River Go
Annotation: This is the bittersweet, historically-based story of how the Swift River Valley was swallowed up to create a reservoir for "thirsty" Boston, relating the changing times in rural America through the eyes of Sally Jane. The author and illustrator pair poetic text and detailed paintings in this portrayal of the alteration of an environment through the modernization of a community.
Author: Jane  Yolen

Title: Levi Strauss and Blue Jeans
Annotation: An account of Levi Strauss’s creation of blue jeans in the mid-1800s in response to the demand from gold miners in California for durable pants. Presented in graphic format. Includes a bibliography, glossary, and index.
Author: Nathan Olson

Title: Liao House, The
Annotation: Written in simplified Chinese, this famous, classical novel about ghosts and other spirits is illustrated and told in an amusing style. The popular stories include "The Story of Master Wan," "Raining Coins," and "The Swallow Girl."
Author: Mei Ling Tang

Title: Liar, Liar, Pants on Fire
Annotation: Zoe is in third grade, and she has a very active imagination. She thinks that she has to make things up to be interesting. Pretty soon, her classmates don't believe anything she says—even when it is the truth. This tale is a modern spin on the story about the boy who cried "wolf" too many times.
Author: Gordon Korman

Title: Liberty!
Annotation: Describes the unveiling of the Statue of Liberty as well as its importance as a symbol of freedom. The narrator is a young boy whose job is to signal Bartholdi with a wave of his handkerchief to drop the veil on the statue for the world to see for the first time. Pen-and-watercolor illustrations show details, including boats full of suffragettes protesting when they were not allowed to vote, as well as the vast amount of red, white, and blue French and American flags.
Author: Allan Drummond

Title: Librarian of Basra: A True Story from Iraq, The
Annotation: Based on the true story of librarian Alia Muhammad Baker, who—with the help of her friends and neighbors—saved 70 percent of a library collection in Basra at the beginning of the war in Iraq. Featuring folk-art illustrations, this is an accessible and inspirational book about war, fighting without violence, and the universal love of books and learning. For older readers, this work might be paired with ALIA’S MISSION: SAVING THE BOOKS OF IRAQ to compare two different accounts of the same story. It could also be used as a read-aloud picture book for middle- and upper-grades students.
Author: Jeanette Winter
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Global Social Issues, War

Title: Librarian Who Measured the Earth, The
Annotation: Eratosthenes became the chief librarian at the renowned Alexandria Library. His best-known discovery was to determine the circumference of Earth using simple geometry and shadows cast by the sun at noon on June 21. The book includes an addendum that gives a summary of important discoveries throughout time, many of which use Eratosthenes' work as their basis.
Author: Kathryn Lasky
Topic: Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)

Title: Library Card, The
Annotation: This short story collection relates four tales about young people in trouble and the mysterious blue library cards that transform their lives. Mature contemporary situations that include vandalism, homelessness, and hijacking are resolved through the power of books, reading, and the library!
Author: Jerry Spinelli

Title: Library Mouse
Annotation: Sam is a mouse that loves to read and lives in the walls of a library. Inspired by the wonderful stories he reads, Sam begins to write and illustrate his own books, which he then places on the library shelves. Children who read his stories demand to meet the author. So the librarian leaves a note inviting Sam to attend a “Meet the Author” session. Illustrated with bright artwork, this book is useful for introducing students to writing projects.
Author: Daniel Kirk

Title: Life and Times of the Ant, The
Annotation: The evolution, physical characteristics, behavior, and social nature of ants are enthusiastically described in this accurate and humorous book. A flowchart, timeline, diagrams, and decorative illustrations provide significant visual appeal and valuable information. A list of suggested titles for further reading is included. Other titles in the Discover More Books series by this author/illustrator include LIFE AND TIMES OF THE APPLE, LIFE AND TIMES OF THE HONEYBEE, and LIFE AND TIMES OF THE PEANUT.
Author: Charles Micucci

Title: Life and Times of the Honeybee, The
Annotation: In this witty, informative salute to honeybees, readers discover what beekeepers do, how bees make honey, and what people do with honey. Many interesting and amusing facts about the life cycle, habitat, behavior, and history of the honeybee are included. Another book on this topic is THE HONEYMAKERS by Gail Gibbons.
Author: Charles Micucci

Title: Life in the Boreal Forest
Annotation: Highlights the important role of northern boreal forests in the earth’s ecosystems. Vignettes present factual information with lively action scenes and feature a wide variety of animals that live in these forests. The beauty and majesty of the forests will inspire young readers. Intricate illustrations complement the text. Includes information on groups committed to preserving boreal forests.
Author: Brenda Guiberson

Title: Life in the Ocean: The Story of Oceanographer Sylvia Earle
Annotation: Oceanographer Sylvia Earle is the subject of this picture-book biography. As a child in Florida, she fell in love with the water and began her lifelong goal of understanding and preserving the ocean. Detailed watercolor illustrations, done in a folk-art style, help tell the life story of this inspiring scientist. Quotes from her journal are included, along with an author’s note at the end of the book that urges readers to help preserve world’s oceans.
Author: Claire A. Nivola

Title: Life in the Rain Forests
Annotation: The importance of rain forests, their plant and animal populations, and how they are threatened by deforestation are described. Focuses particularly on the damage humans have caused to rain forests and what can be done to save them. An African tale at the end encourages readers to apply their knowledge of rain forests.
Author: Lucy Baker

Title: Life on Earth: The Story of Evolution
Annotation: The author provides an overview of the origin and evolution of life on earth and what has been learned from the study of evolution. Illustrated with stunning cut-and-torn paper collage artwork that highlights the diversity of species, the text ends with an overview of the earth's history. A bibliography for further reading is included.
Author: Steve Jenkins

Title: Life on Mars
Annotation: An imaginary three-year space exploration of Mars mixes fact and speculation and includes information gathered through interviews with scientists and astronauts. The book presents an accurate summary of what we know of Mars' history as well as information about space travel. Findings of the Viking landers is included and the author speculates on how Mars might be adapted for colonization. Illustrated with many black-and-white satellite photographs, drawings, paintings, NASA photographs, and reproductions.
Author: David Getz

Title: Life on the Ice
Annotation: This title introduces some aspects of the Earth's polar regions. Topics presented include the difficulties of flying to and landing at the poles, the scientific research done at each pole, and the challenge of human survival in the extreme cold. Illustrated with full-page artwork that provides a comprehensive glimpse of Arctic locations, this book includes a bibliography and an index.
Author: Susan E. Goodman

Title: Lifetimes
Annotation: A selection of plants and animals of the world are presented in order of their longevity and each reveals a special quality of their lifetime. Notes at the bottom of each page present ideas for readers to think about and research. The realistic full-color paintings reveal special characteristics of the plants and animals.
Author: David L. Rice

Title: Liftoff: A Photobiography of John Glenn
Annotation: This photo-essay biography tells of John Glenn's illustrious life. It describes his childhood in Ohio; his years as a war hero and test pilot; his selection to be the first American to orbit the earth; his tenure as a U.S. Senator; and his status as the oldest person (77 years of age) in space. Glenn's story is inspirational, and his years of public service offer examples of dedication to one's country. In the foreword Glenn challenges young people to work actively to make the world a better place for everyone. The archival illustrations are large and inviting to the reader. Even reluctant readers will be drawn to this biography.
Author: Don Mitchell

Title: Light in the Attic, A
Annotation: This second collection of Silverstein's irreverent verse features an entertaining cast that includes Backward Bill, Sour Face Ann, the Quick-Digesting Gink, a Gooloo bird, and the Meehoo with an Exactlywatt. The text is accompanied by humorous pen-and-ink drawings. Other Silverstein titles are WHERE THE SIDEWALK ENDS and FALLING UP.
Author: Shel Silverstein

Title: Lightning
Annotation: Fascinating facts about lightning are revealed, beginning with ancient cultures' beliefs and continuing to space-age research. Terms related to electricity and lightning are introduced. This short book includes simple experiments and full-page color photographs and is useful as a reference source.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Lights on Broadway: A Theatrical Tour from A to Z
Annotation: This alphabet book takes the reader on a tour of Broadway with splashy, full-page illustrations that are computer-generated and reflect a retro style. The illustrations are paired with quotes from famous theater professionals and facts about productions. Busy pages introduce theatrical terms and capture the excitement of live theater. A CD single written by Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty and performed by actor Brian Stokes Mitchell is included.
Author: Harriet Ziefert

Title: Like Jake and Me
Annotation: Alex wants to help his stepfather, Jake, but Jake always puts him off because he thinks that Alex isn't strong enough or might hurt himself. However, when Alex finds a wolf spider on Jake's neck, it is Alex who is calm and helps the fearful Jake get rid of the spider. This incident brings them together in a warm and positive way. California author.
Author: Mavis Jukes

Title: Lili at Ballet
Annotation: Lili dreams of becoming a ballerina and goes to her ballet lessons four afternoons a week. The author, who danced professionally and now watches her daughter train for the ballet, offers a lovely picture book showing a child’s dance experiences: the inspiration of watching a performance of “Giselle,” the humdrum routine of dressing and waiting for class, and the hard work required in a dance lesson.
Author: Rachel Isadora

Title: Lily Cupboard: A Story of the Holocaust, The
Annotation: A young Jewish girl is sent to the Dutch countryside to hide from the Nazis during the German occupation of Holland in World War II. Her friendship with a non-Jewish boy named Nello and a rabbit help make her time of hiding more bearable. This is also a story about the brave non-Jews who risked their own lives to help the Jews during the Holocaust.
Author: Shulamith Oppenheim

Title: Lily's Crossing
Annotation: During the summer of 1944, Lily stays with her grandmother at Rockaway Beach while her father fights in the war in Europe. She reluctantly develops a friendship with Albert, a young Hungarian war refugee. Through this friendship Lily learns to see the war and her own world differently.
Author: Patricia Reilly Giff

Title: Lincoln and His Boys
Annotation: A fictionalized biography of Abraham Lincoln as seen through the eyes of his two younger sons. The first part is through Willie’s eyes and the second is through Tad’s. Lincoln is seen as a tolerant father, full of patience, love, and good humor. This is a short but memorable book about the period of Lincoln’s life when he was in the White House and just before his death. Illustrated with paintings by artist P. J. Lynch.
Author: Rosemary Wells
Topic: American History, Global Historical Events and Figures

Title: Lincoln Tells a Joke: How Laughter Saved the President (And the Country)
Annotation: This upbeat book centers on President Lincoln’s use of wit, humor, and wordplay in his speeches and everyday communications. Use as a read-aloud for younger students and middle-schoolers to show the human side of this familiar American president. Acrylic artwork complements the text, and the book offers source materials and a Web link to Lincoln’s speeches. California authors. See also GEORGE WASHINGTON’S TEETH (by Deborah Chandra and Madeleine Comora) for another unusual picture book about an American president.
Author: Kathleen Krull, Paul Brewer

Title: Lincoln: A Photobiography
Annotation: The biography of Abraham Lincoln is enhanced by period photos and drawings. The photo-essay contrasts the legend of Lincoln with the real Lincoln and uses quotes from original sources, including Lincoln's own writings. It also lists historic sites to visit. The selection connects with the curriculum for fifth- and eighth-grade history/social science.
Author: Russell Freedman
Award: Golden Kite Author Winner, Newbery Winner

Title: Linnea en el jardin de Monet (Linnea in Monet's Garden)
Annotation: A little girl visits the home and garden of Claude Monet in Giverny, France, and learns about the artist's paintings and his life. The ink-and-watercolor illustrations are accompanied by photographs of the painter and his family as well as examples of his work. This book can be used as a general introduction to gardens.
Author: Christina Bjork

Title: Linnea in Monet's Garden
Annotation: A little girl visits the home and garden of Claude Monet in Giverny, France, and learns about the artist's paintings and his life. The ink-and-watercolor illustrations are accompanied by photographs of the painter and his family as well as examples of his work. This book can be used as a general introduction to gardens.
Author: Christina Bjork

Title: Linnea's Windowsill Garden
Annotation: This is an illustrated introduction to plants and how they grow in small places with information on creating an urban garden. Interspersed in the information on birds, seeds, and bulbs are activities that range from simple to complex. Lively line drawings in two colors enhance the text.
Author: Christina Bjork

Title: Lion’s Share: A Tale of Halving Cake and Eating It, Too, The
Annotation: An ant is invited to the lion’s elegant dinner. The other guests are greedy. When the cake is passed around, the elephant takes half, and each animal takes half of what is left. By the time the cake reaches the lion and the ant, there is only a crumb left. The ant volunteers to bake the king another cake, and the guests, not wanting to be outdone, vow to double the ant’s offer. The book features watercolor-and-ink artwork that is enhanced with digital elements.
Author: Matthew McElligott

Title: Listening for Lions
Annotation: This is a story about thirteen-year-old Rachel, who is left an orphan after the influenza epidemic in British East Africa in 1918. She is tricked into assuming a deceased neighbor's identity to travel to England. There, her only dream is to return to Africa and rebuild her parents' mission hospital. Pair this title with THE 1918 INFLUENZA PANDEMIC, by Stephanie T. Peters, for a factual comparison of the events behind this story.
Author: Gloria Whelan

Title: Little Boy with a Big Horn
Annotation: Ollie is trying to practice on his tuba, but no one likes to hear him play “Asleep in the Deep.” He sets out in a small boat to play in the ocean, where he won’t bother anyone. While he is playing, Ollie saves a ship and becomes a hero. First published in 1950, this new edition has fresh, retro-style illustrations.
Author: Jack Bechdolt
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.4, VAPA M PreK-12.5

Title: Little House on the Prairie
Annotation: In this book, the second in the Little House series, the Ingalls family moves by wagon from Wisconsin to the prairies of the Kansas territory. After many days of travel, the family finds just the right spot to build their new home. Life on the prairie can be difficult, but the pioneering family meets each hardship with resolve and unity.
Author: Laura Ingalls Wilder

Title: Little Lost Bat
Annotation: This title chronicles the early life of an orphaned Mexican free-tailed bat, from its birth to its adoption by a new mother. Many details and facts about bats and their life cycle are included in the narrative. Double-page watercolor illustrations support the narrative effectively.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: Little Melba and Her Big Trombone
Annotation: At age seven, Melba fell in love with a big, shiny trombone, and soon taught herself to play the instrument. By the time she was a teenager, Melba’s extraordinary gift for music led her to the world of jazz. She joined a band led by trumpet player Gerald Wilson and toured the country. Overcoming obstacles of race and gender, Melba went on to become a famed trombone player and arranger, spinning rhythms, harmonies, and melodies into gorgeous songs for all the jazz greats of the twentieth century: Randy Weston, Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Billie Holiday, and Quincy Jones, to name just a few.
Author: Katheryn Russell-Brown
Topic: American History, Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Music
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Little Plump
Annotation: This children's rhyming book is embedded with a Chinese rhetorical device called a "chain connection." The last sentence of a paragraph becomes the first sentence of the next paragraph.
Author: Ren Mu Pan

Title: Little Prince, The
Annotation: The Little Prince lives alone on a tiny, tiny planet. He owns a beautiful flower, of which he is very proud, but it is this pride that causes his loss of serenity. He travels to earth, where a fox shares with him the secret of what is really important in life. Whimsical watercolor illustrations reflect the magic of this classic.
Author: Antoine de Saint-Exupery
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary

Title: Little Ships: The Heroic Rescue at Dunkirk in World War II, The
Annotation: Told in first-person narrative, this story is about a young English girl and her fisherman father who join other civilian vessels crossing the English Channel in a daring attempt to rescue Allied and British troops trapped by Nazi soldiers at Dunkirk.
Author: Louise Borden
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures, War

Title: Little Stevie Wonder
Annotation: This biography is told in the form of a long poem that serves as a tribute to musician Stevie Wonder. It describes, in verse, his musical talent and cultural impact. The dynamic acrylic artwork uses bold, pure colors and big shapes. Includes a CD with two songs.
Author: Quincy Troupe

Title: Little Tadpoles Search for Their Mother
Annotation: This wordless picture book features a well-known Chinese fairy tale.
Author: Xin Jiang

Title: Little Weaver of Thai Yen Village, The
Annotation: The atrocities of war are shown in this real-life story of Hien, who was flown to the U.S. for medical treatment of her war wounds. Nostalgia drives her to weave blankets to be sent home each year. This book may be controversial for Vietnamese students whose parents' political interests might not necessarily agree with the author. Contains a small picture of a communist flag.
Author: Tran Khanh Tuyet

Title: Lives of the Artists: Masterpieces, Messes (And What the Neighbors Thought)
Annotation: Short, informative biographies focus on the personal lives of artists, including Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo Buonarroti, Henri Matisse, Pablo Picasso, Marc Chagall, Georgia O’Keefe, Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo, Andy Warhol, and others. The biographical sketches are accompanied by humorous caricatures, and the text emphasizes the artists’ unique personalities and the impressions they made on the people who knew them.
Author: Kathleen Krull
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Lives of the Athletes: Thrills, Spills (And What the Neighbors Thought)
Annotation: Short biographies of 23 athletes who have gained fame and fortune through their athletic abilities are presented in this collection. Each biography is introduced with a full-page color watercolor and color pencil "portrait" of the subject. Other titles in the series are LIVES OF THE MUSICIANS, LIVES OF THE WRITERS, LIVES OF THE ARTISTS, and LIVES OF THE PRESIDENTS.
Author: Kathleen Krull

Title: Lives of the Musicians: Good Times, Bad Times (And What the Neighbors Thought)
Annotation: This book presents short biographical profiles of 20 famous composers and musicians, including Vivaldi, Gershwin, Gilbert and Sullivan, and others. The text features interesting and historically accurate anecdotes. Each biographical entry is enhanced by an elegant caricature.
Author: Kathleen Krull

Title: Lizards, Frogs, and Polliwogs
Annotation: This collection of 21 short poems takes a humorous look at the characteristics, activities, and habits of a variety of reptiles and amphibians. Animals include the gecko, crocodile, iguana, komodo dragon, newt, and poison-dart frog. Each poem is accompanied by a full-page watercolor illustration with some collage elements. This can also be used as a model for writing poetry.
Author: Douglas Florian

Title: Locomotion
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Lonnie Collins Motion has had a rough life - both parents are dead, and he and his little sister are sent to different foster homes. Then in school, he learns to express himself through poetry. In learning to communicate, he learns to cope with his present and even look forward to the future.
Author: Jacqueline Woodson

Title: Locomotive
Annotation: This nonfiction picture book is set in 1869 and describes a family traveling from Omaha to Sacramento on the newly completed transcontinental railroad. The book describes the building of the railroad, parts of the train, the jobs of people working on the train, and the feelings of the passengers.
Author: Brian Floca
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures

Title: Log's Life, A
Annotation: Falling onto the forest floor, an oak tree has another life as a home to a variety of creatures. It decomposes and becomes soil in which a seedling oak sprouts and grows. Lifelike collage illustrations encourage children to search and find the organisms introduced in the text.
Author: Wendy Pfeffer

Title: Lon Po Po: A Red-Riding Hood Story from China
Annotation: Three young Chinese girls find themselves in a frightening situation as Lon Po Po, the Granny Wolf, visits their house one night while their mother is off visiting their real grandmother. The scariness of the wolf's deception and the girls' cleverness in dealing with him are revealed through panels of impressionistic watercolor-and-pastel illustrations.
Author: Ed Young

Title: London Eye Mystery, The
Annotation: Ted and his older sister, Kat, watch their cousin Salim board the London Eye, an immense observation wheel. But when Salim’s capsule comes around again, Ted and Kat don’t see Salim, who has mysteriously vanished. The siblings join forces to solve the mystery after the police are unable to do so. Ultimately, the key to the mystery is discovered by one of the siblings, whose brain works in a very unique way as a result of Asperger’s syndrome.
Author: Siobhan Dowd

Title: Long Gone Lonesome History of Country Music, The
Annotation: A tongue-in-cheek history of American country music that features brief profiles of country-music legends, directions on how to yodel, short sections about the different types of country music (gospel, honky-tonk, rockabilly, bluegrass, and more), as well as country words, dances, and a chance to create some original country-music lyrics. Illustrated with caricatures.
Author: Bret Bertholf

Title: Long Way From Chicago: A Novel in Stories, A
Annotation: A boy recounts his annual summer trips with his sister to rural Illinois to visit their larger-than-life grandmother during the Great Depression. Each chapter revisits an adventure or awareness experienced during a memorable year.
Author: Richard Peck
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Women’s Studies

Title: Look to the Stars
Annotation: Buzz Aldrin introduces the pioneers of space and reminds readers that mankind has always looked to the stars. His informative, child-friendly text is paired with realistic artwork. Includes information on the first rockets, America’s space race with Russia, details of all the Apollo missions, and the international space station. Each page provides a jumping-off point for young readers and will inspire them to look to the stars themselves.
Author: Buzz Aldrin

Title: Look up!: Bird-watching in Your Own Backyard
Annotation: This book is an introduction to bird-watching for elementary students and encourages kids to get outdoors to watch and draw.
Author: Annette Cate
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General , Science

Title: Looking at Lincoln
Annotation: A young girl wants to learn about Abraham Lincoln. In the library, she discovers that he was a man who believed in freedom for everyone; had a dog named Fido; loved Mozart, apples, and his wife’s vanilla cake; and kept notes in his hat. The artwork in this book is bold and bright. Kalman includes sources and appended notes that add breadth to the presentation. A read-aloud choice for younger children, this work offers many possibilities for discussion and a jumping-off point for older readers who are motivated to conduct further research on Lincoln.
Author: Maira Kalman

Title: Looking for Jaguar and Other Rainforest Poems
Annotation: This is a collection of 19 poems about the plants and animals of the rain forest. It encompasses the senses through the rich adjectives used in this poetic exploration of rain forests. The poems are accompanied by a section on facts and an informative essay on rain forests and their significance. The illustrations are lush and softly detailed, showing the habitats as shadowy, misty places.
Author: Susan Katz

Title: Looking for Life in the Universe: The Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence
Annotation: The author and the photographer introduce the reader to the life and work of astrophysicist Jill Tarter, Director of the Phoenix Project of the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence (SETI) in Mountain View, California. The book describes Tarter’s daily routine at work and at home, how she became an astronomer, and the science and technology involved in searching for signs of life in the universe. Both the text and the large, dynamic color photographs focus on the world’s largest radio telescope in Arecibo, Puerto Rico, and the work of the scientist and her colleagues at that location. Additional resources are recommended in the concluding pages. This book is a part of the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Ellen Jackson
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Looking for Seabirds: Journal from an Alaskan Voyage
Annotation: Webb, a biologist and artist, documents a springtime voyage to the Aleutian Islands to observe seabirds as a part of a larger study of the arctic ecosystem. Her journal is detailed and lushly illustrated with watercolor and gouache paintings. Readers will come away with a sense of the adventure as well as details about this fragile ecosystem.
Author: Sophie Webb

Title: Lorax, El (The Lorax)
Annotation: Dr. Seuss delivers a vivid picture of environmental disaster through habitat destruction, pollution, and overuse of natural resources. Bright, colorful illustrations accompany the verse and depict the environmental damage caused when people move ahead without considering the full impact of scientific progress.
Author: Dr. (Theodor Geisel) Seuss

Title: Lorax, The
Annotation: Dr. Seuss delivers a vivid picture of environmental disaster through habitat destruction, pollution, and overuse of natural resources. Bright, colorful illustrations accompany the verse and depict the environmental damage caused when people move ahead without considering the full impact of scientific progress.
Author: Dr. (Theodor Geisel) Seuss

Title: Los tres pequenos jabalies (The Three Little Javelinas)
Annotation: Javelinas in the Southwest are featured in this version of THE THREE LITTLE PIGS. Coyote is the villain who huffs and puffs and blows down the tumbleweed house and the one built of cactus spines. The adobe house, however, won't fall, and Coyote is left without his dinner. Illustrations show the surrounding landscape and the wildlife of the desert.
Author: Susan Lowell

Title: Lost Boy: The Story of the Man Who Created Peter Pan
Annotation: This picture-book biography is the story of James M. Barrie, the creator of Peter Pan. It tells of the five boys of the Davies family who changed his life. As a child, Barrie suffered tragedies but was able to overcome his sorrow by using his imagination to entertain himself and others. His relationship with the Davies boys inspired his stories. The book includes quotes from Barrie’s books and excerpts from the Peter Pan tales and play. Acrylic artwork complements this well-researched biography.
Author: Jane Yolen

Title: Lost Flower Children
Annotation: After their mother's death, Olivia and Nellie go to live with their great-aunt. They slowly bring her overgrown and weedy old garden back to life, enabling them to adjust to a new life as well.
Author: Janet Taylor Lisle

Title: Lotus Seed, The
Annotation: A young Vietnamese girl carries a precious lotus seed as she flees her war-torn homeland for a strange new country. Years later, her grandson takes the seed from the family altar and plants it in the yard. The grandmother mourns her loss until a beautiful pink lotus appears in the yard. She then presents each grandchild with his or her own seed and keeps one for herself to remember her country of birth.
Author: Sherry Garland
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, Mathematics, Science

Title: Louis Sockalexis: Native American Baseball Pioneer
Annotation: This picture-book biography tells the story of Louis Sockalexis, a Penobscot who, in the late nineteenth century, pursued his childhood love of baseball and became the first Native American to play in the major leagues. Sockalexis faced racial discrimination from spectators and opposition from his family because of the profession he chose. Includes colorful illustrations, an afterword, and a bibliography.
Author: Bill Wise
Topic: American History, Diversity, Motor Skills/Movement Patterns

Title: Love That Dog
Annotation: Told in free verse, this story tells of a boy who comes to enjoy poetry through a wise teacher's introduction. His reluctance becomes interest, then enjoyment, and finally a passion for reading and writing poetry. Through poetry he is finally able to communicate his feelings and thoughts.
Author: Sharon Creech

Title: Love to Langston
Annotation: Fourteen free-verse poems written from the point of view of the African American poet Langston Hughes, provides an overview of key events and themes in his life: childhood, dreams, love of words, travels, and overcoming obstacles. Vivid, colorful, and exaggerated illustrations accompany the engaging poems. The notes at the end of the book interpret each poem. Can be used as an introduction to the life of a Harlem Renaissance poet and/or for biography and poetry units.
Author: Tony Medina

Title: Love to Mama: A Tribute to Mothers
Annotation: Thirteen Latin American poets present a collection of works that combine English and Spanish and describe the bonds between mothers, grandmothers, and children. Mixed-media illustrations capture the cultures of the Latin American themes.
Author: Pat Mora (editor)
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Love, Aubrey
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Aubrey has her world turned upside down when a tragic car accident takes the lives of her little sister and her father. Her mother is unable to cope with the loss and leaves Aubrey to fend for herself. Aubrey writes letters that no one will read but that make her feel better. With support from her grandmother and friends, Aubrey eventually begins to heal and finds the words to express her feelings. A hopeful ending brings closure.
Author: Suzanne LaFleur

Title: Lucille Lost: A True Adventure
Annotation: A pet Burmese turtle searches for adventure and escapes from her yard. Finding herself lost in the woods, she has many adventures and meets a variety of animals who give her advice along the way. The engaging text is interspersed with tortoise facts, adding information children can use for research. The book's full-page paintings are highly detailed and richly colored.
Author: Christopher Murphy, Margaret George

Title: Luck
Annotation: A young sandhill crane named Luck finds his place in the crane migration from northern Canada to the Platte River after he is freed by a young girl from a plastic six-pack holder caught around his neck. Impressive paintings provide varied perspectives of the world below as viewed by the flying cranes. Maps tracing the cranes' migration appear on the endpapers.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: Lucky Beans
Annotation: Marshall, a young African American boy, is beginning to hate beans, which his mother serves frequently during the days of the Great Depression. But beans look a bit better to Marshall when he sees a contest advertised in the window of a furniture store: the store will give away a new sewing machine to the person who can guess the number of beans held in a huge jar that is on display. Marshall uses the lessons he has learned in school to help him win the sewing machine for his mother. Warm watercolor art accurately depicts the small-town setting. This is a story that can be used across the curriculum.
Author: Becky Birtha

Title: Lucky Thing, A
Annotation: Thirteen poems, rhyming and free verse, celebrate the sounds, smells, and movements of natural life on a farm. The poems are accompanied by warm and whimsical watercolor paintings. California author.
Author: Alice Schertle

Title: Lunch at the Zoo: What Zoo Animals Eat and Why
Annotation: Go behind the scenes at the zoo to see how nutritionists research and prepare a variety of meals for animals of all sizes. Illustrations include some photographs as well as drawings. A good choice when planning a field trip to the zoo.
Author: Joyce Altman

Title: Lunch Lady and the Cyborg Substitute
Annotation: A group of students discover that the Lunch Lady and her assistant do more than dish out lunch: they are superheroes who fight crime with the tools of their trade—namely, a spatu-copter, lunch tray laptop, and hair net. With the familiar good-versus-evil story line, humorous encounters, and attractive illustrations, this graphic novel, the first in a series, will delight young readers.
Author: Jarrett Krosoczka

Title: Lunch Money
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Greg Kenton, who has always been good at moneymaking projects, is surprised to find himself teaming up with his lifelong rival, Maura, to create a series of comic books to sell at school. Should students be able to make profits in school? Greg takes the case to the school board.
Author: Andrew Clements

Title: Lupa maravillosa, La (The Marvelous Magnifying Glass)
Annotation: Children visit a museum and make many discoveries using a magnifying glass, light reflection, and mirrors. As the characters in the story participate in observations we feel as though we are in the museum with them. Students will love this unique approach to science.
Author: Nomi Joval

Title: Luz (Fun with Light)
Annotation: This Spanish title is an introduction to the study of light. The humorous text and illustrations walk students through the properties of light and includes some simple experiments. See other books in the Ciencia Simple (Simple Science) series.
Author: Maria Gordon

Title: Luz, sonido, electricidad y magnetismo (Light, Sound, Electricity, and Magnetism)
Annotation: Color photographs, charts, and diagrams, along with basic text, offer information on electricity, sound, and light. The easy-to-read book connects these topics to other disciplines. See other books in the Aula Abierta (Open Classroom) series.
Author: Barbara Taylor

Title: M Is for Masterpiece: An Art Alphabet
Annotation: An A-to-Z pictorial that uses simple poetry to introduce topics such as color, Easter Island, impressionism, and landscape. With a broad, multicultural survey of artistic terms, this book covers art history from around the world. It also discusses technique. Brief rhyming poems and colorful visuals make it appropriate for younger students. Sidebars provide additional information useful for older students.
Author: David Domeniconi
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: M Is for Music
Annotation: This alphabet book introduces musical terms as well as musical styles, instruments, and artists. Many examples are given for each letter (e.g., the letter “A” includes anthem, aria, Armstrong, and more). The slightly abstract oil-and-acrylic illustrations and sophisticated content make this book suitable for older audiences.
Author: Kathleen Krull
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.5

Title: Ma Dear's Aprons
Annotation: Young David Earl always knows what day of the week it is because his mother, Ma Dear, has a different apron for every day except Sunday. Misty oil-wash illustrations build a sense of warmth in this turn-of-the-century story.
Author: Patricia C. McKissack

Title: Madame Butterfly: The Story of the Opera by Giacomo Puccini
Annotation: An adaptation of Giacomo Puccini’s tragic opera “Madame Butterfly,” in which a young Japanese girl falls in love with an American navy officer and marries him only to have him abandon her. Elaborate paintings that are modeled on Japanese woodblock prints complement the story. Use to introduce opera and accompany with selected arias.
Author: Giacomo Puccini, J. Alison James

Title: Madeleine’s Light: A Story of Camille Claudel
Annotation: Inspired by a true event, this story is about the young protagonist, Madeleine Boyer, who anxiously awaits a visit from Camille Claudel, the famous female sculptor. That summer, Madeleine gains the experience of a lifetime. She learns about art and about becoming an artist from Mademoiselle Claudel—and in return, Mademoiselle Claudel is inspired by Madeleine’s “light of becoming.” Readers will enjoy learning about the benefits of mentorship.
Author: Natalie Ziarnik
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Visual Arts
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Magic Dogs of the Volcanoes (Los perros magicos de los volcanes)
Annotation: Based on a legend from El Salvador, this story tells of magical dogs that appear to help protect people from danger. The story deals with the people's struggle against oppression and may be used to discuss how good can triumph over evil.
Author: Manlio Argueta

Title: Magic Fellows and the King
Annotation: Seven brothers who look exactly alike outwit the Emperor's executioner by using their individual supernatural powers. The story is similar to Bishop's FIVE CHINESE BROTHERS, and Mahy's SEVEN CHINESE BROTHERS.
Author: Kuang-Ts’ai Hao (reteller)

Title: Magic Pickle and the Garden of Evil
Annotation: Magic Pickle, a superpowered pickle who lives under the floor of Jo Jo Wigman’s bedroom, sets out with Jo Jo to stop the Brotherhood of the Evil Produce. The text is sprinkled with sound effects and illustrated with visual punch that will engage readers in the action and provide ease of reading. Comic segments are included with the text. This is a good selection for struggling readers.
Author: Scott Morse

Title: Magic School Bus at the Waterworks, The
Annotation: A class of children take an imaginary field trip through the water cycle and a city's water purification system. The engaging text is a mix of fact and fiction highlighted by detailed, full-color illustrations that encourage the reader to explore. See other books in the Magic School Bus series.
Author: Joanna Cole

Title: Magic School Bus Explores the Senses
Annotation: The new assistant principal drives the Magic School Bus as the class tries to catch up with Ms. Frizzle to relay an important message. They explore the five senses as the bus shrinks and travels through a police officer's eye, a boy's ear, a dog's nose, onto Ms. Frizzle's tongue, and into her nervous system. See other books in the Magic School Bus series.
Author: Joanna Cole

Title: Magic School Bus Explores the World of Animals, The
Annotation: This is a new format for the Magic School Bus books where the reader looks at the diverse world of animals in a variety of habitats. Detailed information and an adventurous storyline is presented that highlights animal adaptations and the environments in which they live. See other books in the Magic School Bus series.
Author: Joanna Cole

Title: Magic School Bus in the Time of the Dinosaurs
Annotation: A visit to a dinosaur dig turns into a time-travel journey through the Triassic, Jurassic, and Cretaceous periods to see dinosaurs and fossils. Every page is brimming with the latest dinosaur facts and theories. Degen's watercolor, pen, and gouache illustrations are energetic. See other books in the Magic School Bus series.
Author: Joanna Cole

Title: Magic School Bus Inside the Human Body, The
Annotation: Miss Frizzle takes her students on the Magic School Bus to explore the wonders of the human body. Colorful, imaginative illustrations and a text that delivers a lot of information in a comic book style draw readers into the subject. Look for other Magic School Bus titles that make learning fun. Miss Frizzle's outfits "speak a lot" about the adventures of the subject of the Magic School Bus ride.
Author: Joanna Cole

Title: Magic School Bus on the Ocean Floor
Annotation: This time the Magic School Bus turns into a submarine as the class and Ms. Frizzle learn about the landforms on the ocean floor and the adaptations the ocean animals make to live there. Degen's line drawings washed with watercolor are full of energy and details. See other books in the Magic School Bus series.
Author: Joanna Cole
Standard: LS K.2, ES K.3, LS 1.2, LS 3.3

Title: Magic School Bus: Inside a Hurricane, The
Annotation: Ms. Frizzle takes her class on a Magic School Bus trip into the clouds to gather facts about hurricanes firsthand. The science is presented in an easy-to-understand format that includes samples of journals and reports. The illustrations are done with a variety of media and offer a detailed glimpse into the elements of a hurricane. See other books in the Magic School Bus series.
Author: Joanna Cole

Title: Magic School Bus: Inside the Earth
Annotation: On a special field trip, the Magic School Bus takes Ms. Frizzle and her class deep into Earth. They learn first-hand about different kinds of rocks and the formation of Earth. The detailed illustrations offer an opportunity for further exploration. See other books in the Magic School Bus series.
Author: Joanna Cole

Title: Magic School Bus: Inside the Human Body, The
Annotation: Miss Frizzle takes her students on the Magic School Bus to explore the wonders of the human body. Colorful illustrations and a text that delivers a lot of information with a comic book style draw readers into the subject. See other books in the Magic School Bus series.
Author: Joanna Cole

Title: Magic School Bus: Lost in the Solar System, The
Annotation: In a fantasy field trip through the solar system, scientific facts are presented in a clever and humorous manner. The Magic School Bus travels past the sun and around the planets. The full-color illustrations are perfect for browsing as they contain details and information bytes. See other books in the Magic School Bus series.
Author: Joanna Cole

Title: Magic Trash: A Story of Tyree Guyton and His Art
Annotation: Growing up in a poor area of Detroit, young Tyree Guyton reused cast-off items he found in his neighborhood. After working in different occupations, he attended art school and moved back home, where he saw that his neighborhood had deteriorated. Encouraged by his grandfather, he began painting houses and decorating the neighborhood with his art. Though the city tried to destroy Tyree’s work, neighbors rallied in support of him, and his street became internationally famous. This book’s text and mixed-media art are full of rhythm and life.
Author: J. H. Shapiro
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Magic Windows: Ventanas Magicas
Annotation: Garza shows her life as an artist and explores her Mexican culture, family, community, and Aztec legends through the traditional folk-art form of papel picado (cut-paper). Text is in English and Spanish.
Author: Carmen Lomas Garza
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Magical Garden of Claude Monet, The
Annotation: Julie loves living in Paris, but she wishes she could walk in a country garden. When she goes with her mother to visit a friend, she mistakes the famous artist Claude Monet for the gardener. The artwork uses sunny colors with drawings that are brightened with colorful washes and incorporate some of Monet’s paintings. A two-page biography at the end of the book provides more information about the artist’s life.
Author: Laurence Anholt

Title: Mailing May
Annotation: In order to get five-year-old Charlotte May Pierstorff to her grandmother's house 75 miles away, May's father cleverly uses new mail regulations to his advantage and mails May via railway. Vivid watercolors add detail and authenticity to replications of photographs, postage stamps, a "deliver to" tag, and a train schedule. An author's note adds historical detail to this true story of 1914.
Author: Michael O. Tunnell

Title: Major Taylor: The Extraordinary Career of a Champion Cyclist
Annotation: This is a picture-book biography of Marshall Taylor, a young African American bicycle racer from Indianapolis who won the 1899 World Championship title. His father was a coachman for a wealthy family, and young Marshall was hired to be a live-in companion to the family’s only son. Marshall was given a bicycle, and his love affair with stunts and racing began.
Author: Lesa Cline-Ransome

Title: Make Things Fly: Poems About the Wind
Annotation: This is a collection of 27 weather poems about wind written by familiar names in children's literature. The pencil illustrations enhance the moving, sweeping, sometimes wild and sometimes gentle, movements that the words evoke. A perfect read aloud to introduce the subject of wind.
Author: Dorothy M. Kennedy

Title: Make Way for Dyamonde Daniel
Annotation: Spunky third-grader Dyamonde Daniel has moved to a new town and is in a new school. She wonders why, after three weeks, she still doesn’t have a best friend. Reed “Free” Freeman, another new student, arrives and is rude to everyone. When Free scares a young student in the lunchroom, Dyamonde confronts Free, and they slowly begin to develop a friendship. Set in an urban neighborhood, this story—the first of a series—is illustrated with black-and-white sketches that enhance the narrative.
Author: Nikki Grimes

Title: Make Your Mark, Franklin Roosevelt
Annotation: This illustrated biography portrays the influences that helped to shape young Franklin Roosevelt. Although he is growing up in luxury, Roosevelt does not become an idle young man; instead, he has a mission of outdoor pursuits and civic responsibility. The book is illustrated with paintings of watercolor, gouache, and ink that highlight details of Roosevelt’s upbringing and life of privilege. Concludes with an author’s note.
Author: Judith St. George

Title: Mama Miti: Wangari Maathai and the Trees of Kenya
Annotation: When the women of Kenya come to see Wangari Muta Maathai, known as “Mama Miti,” for advice about the scarcity of food, the dwindling supply of firewood, and the ailing animals, she advises them to replant trees as a way to improve their lives. A recommended read-aloud for all ages, this true story about the first African woman to win the Nobel Peace Prize is told with spare, poetic text and is accompanied by colorful collage artwork. A glossary of Kikuyu and Swahili words used throughout the text concludes the narrative. The book also includes an author’s note about sources. National Council for Social Studies Trade Book (2011).
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
Author: Donna Jo Napoli
Topic: Earth Science, Global Social Issues, Life Science (Biology)

Title: Mammal Misfits
Annotation: A general description of mammal characteristics is followed by examples of mammals that don't fit the description. The text is engaging and contains highlighted vocabulary words that appear in a glossary. Includes information about the echidna, platypus, pangolin, anteater, aardvark, naked mole rat, and the banded armadillo. Color photographs of each animal appear and an index is included. Other titles in the Watts Library series include AMAZING AMPHIBIANS, BIZARRE BIRDS, FUNNY FISHES, and RADICAL REPTILES.
Author: Sara Swan Miller

Title: Mammalabilia: Poems and Paintings
Annotation: Twenty-one mammals are presented in poem form, along with a full-page watercolor illustration describing each animal. Each poem brings out the humorous characteristics of the mammal. What a fun way to explore animals!
Author: Douglas Florian

Title: Mammoths and Mastodons: Titans of the Ice Age
Annotation: The book begins with the discovery of a frozen baby woolly mammoth in Siberia, which was an important find for scientists. Includes information on the known facts and theories regarding mammoths and mastodons and compares them with their modern counterpart, the elephant. There is an emphasis on how a better understanding of mammoths and mastodons may help to save elephants from the same fate. The book is illustrated with photographs and specially commissioned artwork.
Author: Cheryl Bardoe

Title: Mammoths on the Move
Annotation: The rhyming text of this book includes snippets of information about a herd of mammoths going south for the winter. Readers will learn what they eat, how they cope with the cold along the way, and how they protect their young from predators. This title is illustrated with scratchboard-and-watercolor artwork that captures the majesty of the mammoths and the landscape of their journey.
Author: Lisa  Wheeler

Title: Man for All Seasons: The Life of George Washington Carver, A
Annotation: An engaging picture-book biography of George Washington Carver that follows his life from childhood, where he was always planting and working in gardens, to his college education. It tells how Booker T. Washington recruited Carver to become a professor at Tuskegee Institute. Carver is depicted as a gentle and curious individual. Illustrated with striking full-page paintings.
Author: Stephen Krensky

Title: Man Who Made Time Travel, The
Annotation: In 1714 Great Britain offered the Longitude Prize to anyone who could create an accurate and reliable means of measuring longitude. There were many attempts but only one man, John Harrison, a carpenter and clock maker, was able to unlock the secret of measuring longitude.
Author: Kathryn Lasky

Title: Man Who Walked Between the Towers, The
Annotation: In 1974, when the World Trade Center was being completed, a young French tightrope walker could not resist the challenge and spent over an hour walking, dancing, resting, and doing tricks a quarter of a mile above pedestrians on the streets below. Fascinating ink work and oil paintings provide a real sense of perspective and daring to the story. A picture book for older readers.
Author: Mordicai Gerstein
Discipline: History/Social Science, Physical Education, English-Language Arts/Writing, Literacy/Motivation

Title: Man Who Went to the Far Side of the Moon, The
Annotation: The experience of Michael Collins, the Apollo 11 astronaut who did not walk on the moon, is presented in this slim volume. It not only gives details of the COLUMBIA but captures the excitement of space travel as well. The book is illustrated in scrapbook style with a mixture of photographs, illustrations, and charts. The book includes a list of all 1967-75 space flights and a glossary.
Author: Bea Uusma Schyffert

Title: Man-Eating Tigers of Sundarbans, The
Annotation: Through scientific observation, legends, and first-person accounts, a mystery in which over 300 people are killed by tigers each year is uncovered. This book provides readers the opportunity to develop their own conclusions. Color photographs and diagrams complement the text which integrates information on the tigers and their habitat with the culture of the people in this region between India and Bangladesh. It concludes with a fact page and additional resources.
Author: Sy Montgomery

Title: Manfish: A Story of Jacques Cousteau
Annotation: With poetic text and acrylic paintings in blues and greens, this biography chronicles the life of Jacques Cousteau from his childhood to his later years. As a young boy, Jacques loved water and was busy experimenting with all sorts of things, including moviemaking. After a stint in the French Navy, he began to dive, and he and his friends developed rubber suits and flippers. Through his discoveries and films, people all over the world discovered the wonders of the sea. The book also includes Cousteau’s warning about keeping the ocean alive and healthy.
Author: Jennifer Berne

Title: Mangrove Tree: Planting Trees to Feed Families, The
Annotation: Free verse and prose alternate to tell the story of Dr. Gordon Sato’s project to plant mangrove trees along the coast of the drought-stricken African country of Eritrea. Villagers provide the labor to plant and tend the trees—which provide food for sheep and goats, which in turn provide milk and meat. The book is illustrated with cut-paper and fabric collage in intense colors. An afterword provides additional information about Dr. Sato, a survivor of the Manzanar War Relocation Center.
Author: Cindy Trumbore, Susan L. Roth
Award: Orbis Pictus Award, Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Winner

Title: Mantenerse a salvo (Keeping Safe)
Annotation: The informative text of this book explains how animals use their claws, teeth, horns, spikes, poison, camouflage, and other ways to protect themselves from enemies and nature. The book is illustrated with full-color photographs. See other books in the Actividades de los Animales (Animal Activities) series.
Author: Jane Burton

Title: Many Luscious Lollipops: A Book About Adjectives
Annotation: Ruth Heller provides an engaging lesson on adjectives. Vivid double-page illustrations accompany rhyming text that addresses proper, demonstrative, superlative, and possessive adjectives. The book is useful as a review of adjective forms for older students and may be used to introduce adjectives to younger students and English learners. See other titles in the “World of Language” series. California author.
Author: Ruth Heller
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Many Rides of Paul Revere, The
Annotation: This is a comprehensive, large-format biography of Paul Revere that includes stories of his childhood, his family life, his leadership during the Revolutionary War, and the many horseback rides he took to deliver important messages. The book is illustrated with period artwork, including portraits, engravings, drawings, maps, and photos of historical sites and artifacts. Sections highlighting the events of the period can be read aloud.
Author: James Cross Giblin

Title: Maples in the Mist: Children's Poems from the Tang Dynasty
Annotation: Translations of poems from 14 Tang dynasty poets (A.D. 618-907) are featured in this volume of cultural treasures. The blend of art and words makes this book exceptional for classroom use.
Author: Minfong Ho

Title: Mapping Penny's World
Annotation: After learning about maps in school, Lisa maps all the favorite places of her dog Penny. In the process the reader learns about key and symbols, labels, scale, and more. The cheerful illustrations are colorful and support the story and a variety of maps are presented.
Author: Loreen Leedy
Standard: HSS K.4, HSS 1.2, HSS 2.2, Math K.MD.1-4, Math 1.MD.1-4, Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 3.MP.1-8, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.NF.1-7

Title: Marcel Marceau: Master of Mime
Annotation: This unique biography introduces Marcel Marceau. It describes how he was inspired by Charlie Chaplin to become a silent actor and how his talent helped him to smuggle Jewish children out of France during World War II. Mixed-media artwork helps to tell the story of his later theatrical successes. Illustrated with color and black-and-white photographs of Marceau as Bip the Clown.
Author: Gloria Spielman
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA T PreK-12.2, VAPA T PreK-12.3

Title: Maria: A Christmas Story
Annotation: As Maria's wealthy neighbors talk excitedly about their families' fancy floats for the annual Christmas parade, she boldly obligates her Latino family's tiny vegetable farm to produce a parade float also. The resulting modest Nativity scene, built on a farm wagon and pulled by other Latinos, changes the community tradition from then on. California author and setting.
Author: Theodore Taylor

Title: Marianthe's Story: Painted Words, Spoken Memories
Annotation: Readers become acquainted with Marianthe's story in two ways. PAINTED WORDS tells what happens when she comes to school in a new country, not knowing the language, but paints pictures to tell her new classmates about herself. Turn the book upside down and you have SPOKEN MEMORIES, in which Marianthe tells about her life before she came to the new country. Colorful paintings by the author complement the story. This is a good book for classes when a new student arrives, especially one without English language skills.
Author: - Aliki
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Marie Curie y el radio (Marie Curie and Radium)
Annotation: This title focuses on Polish scientist Marie Curie, providing information on her early life and education, her marriage to fellow scientist Pierre Curie, their discovery of the element radium which led to the development of nuclear physics, and her further scientific work. The engaging text is extended by illustrations, photographs, boxed information, and timeline. Other titles in the Pioneros de la Ciencia (Pioneers of Science) series that have been translated into Spanish include GALILEO Y EL UNIVERSO (GALILEO AND THE UNIVERSE), LOUIS PASTEUR Y LOS GERMENES (LOUIS PASTEUR AND GERMS), GUGLIELMO MARCONI Y LA RADIO (GUGLIELMO MARCONI AND THE RADIO), CHARLES DARWIN Y LA EVOLUCION (CHARLES DARWIN AND EVOLUTION), and ISAAC NEWTON Y LA GRAVEDAD (ISAAC NEWTON AND GRAVITY).
Author: Steve Parker

Title: Marie Curie: The Woman Who Changed the Course of Science
Annotation: This is an engaging portrait of the life and work of Marie Curie. The book begins with her childhood in Warsaw, Poland, and concludes with her important accomplishments in research on radium. The illustrations include period photographs and other images that bring Curie's story to life.
Author: Philip Steele

Title: Marisol
Annotation: Marisol Luna, a ten-year-old girl who loves to dance, moves with her family from Chicago to the suburbs. She is heartbroken when she learns that there is no dance studio in her new neighborhood—and there is definitely no Mexican folk-dance troupe like the one in her former neighborhood. She comes to realize that no matter where she is, her dreams and passion to dance represent who she is.
Author: Gary Soto
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.4, VAPA D PreK-12.5

Title: Marley: A Dog Like No Other
Annotation: This adaptation of John Grogan’s memoir, MARLEY AND ME: LIFE AND LOVE WITH THE WORLD’S WORST DOG, was created for elementary and middle-school students. The story focuses on the antics of Marley, Grogan’s unruly Labrador retriever. Both humorous and sentimental, the book has wide appeal and is of high interest to otherwise reluctant readers and boys. Includes photographs of Marley.
Author: John Grogan

Title: Marsupial Sue Presents the Runaway Pancake
Annotation: Sue, a kangaroo, teams up with some of her Australian animal friends to put on a play called “The Runaway Pancake.” Illustrated with colored pencil, acrylic, dye, and ink. Includes a CD with music, lyrics, and a performance by the author.
Author: John Lithgow

Title: Martin's Big Words: The Life of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
Annotation: This picture book biography of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., pairs words from his speeches with striking collage illustrations to present important moments in his life. Each collage combines cut-paper, photographs, and watercolor to interpret the big words spoken by Dr. King.
Author: Doreen Rappaport
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Honor

Title: Martina, the Beautiful Cockroach
Annotation: A humorous retelling of a Cuban folktale in which a cockroach interviews her suitors to decide whom to marry. The text, sprinkled with Spanish words, and the vivid illustrations will bring rollicking laughter when the tale is read aloud. Spanish edition is available.
Author: Carmen Agra Deedy
Topic: Diversity, Life Science (Biology), Lifestyles Around the World, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products
Award: California Young Reader Medal, Pura Belpre Narrative Honor

Title: Marvelous Math: A Book of Poems
Annotation: This book is a collection of 16 poems by a variety of authors including Lee Bennet Hopkins, Janet Wong, David McCord, and others. The poems present different aspects of mathematics in daily life and highlight the relationship of math to nature. The book is illustrated with full-color paintings.
Author: Lee Bennett Hopkins (selector)

Title: Mary Celeste: An Unsolved Mystery from History
Annotation: The ship "Mary Celeste" is discovered on the high seas in 1872 with its entire crew missing. The story is related by a female narrator who shares her methods of investigation, the facts surrounding the discovery, and possible explanations for this mystery as she challenges readers to come to their own conclusions. Two-page, pencil-and-watercolor illustrations add historical detail.
Author: Heidi E. Y. Stemple, Jane Yolen

Title: Mary on Horseback: Three Mountain Stories
Annotation: Three poignant vignettes bring to life the true story of Mary Breckenridge, the founder of the Frontier Nursing Service which, since 1925, has provided medical services to the people of rural Appalachian Kentucky. A preface and afterword add details about rural Kentucky life in the 1920s, Breckenridge's life, and her contributions.
Author: Rosemary Wells

Title: Mary Smith
Annotation: This historically based picture book recounts how Mary Smith performed her duties of waking up key citizens of the community by blowing her pea-shooter at their windows in the early industrial age before the advent of alarm clocks. The thick black lines and muted colors are reminiscent of early twentieth-century illustrations.
Author: Andrea U'Ren
Discipline: History/Social Science, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, Mathematics

Title: Mas mortiferas mates (More Murderous Math)
Annotation: A group of prisoners are desperately seeking a way to break out of their cells. They find out that their math skills can help. The engaging illustrations show how measurement and geometry along with number operations are essential. Cartoonlike illustrations help tie the story in with the math concepts. See other books in the Esa Horrible Ciencia (Horrible Science) series.
Author: Kjartan Poskitt
Topic: Mathematical Reasoning, Measurement & Geometry (Geometry), Number Sense
Standard: Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 4.G.1-3, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.MD.1-5, Math 5.G.1-6, Math 6.RP.1-3, Math 6.G.1-6

Title: Matchbox Diary, The
Annotation: When a little girl visits her great-grandfather at his curio-filled home, she chooses an unusual object to learn about, an old cigar box. The box holds a collection of matchboxes, making up her great-grandfather’s diary. What is inside the matchboxes tells the story of her great-grandfather's journey from Italy to a new country, before he could read and write.
Author: Paul Fleischmann

Title: Math Appeal
Annotation: Rhyming anecdotes present opportunities for simple math activities and provide hints for problem solving. The book uses arrays and patterns for counting.
Author: Greg Tang

Title: Math Curse
Annotation: This book looks at life through the eyes of an obsessed student who develops extreme math anxiety when her teacher encourages the class to "think of almost everything as a math problem." The complexity of word problems is taken to new heights as totally irrelevant non-mathematical factors are introduced and the narrator's world spins out of control. The illustrations feature oversized drawings with collage.
Author: Jon Scieszka
Standard: Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NF.1-3, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 5.NBT.1-7

Title: Math for All Seasons: Mind-Stretching Math Riddles
Annotation: This book presents 12 rhyming riddles that pose math puzzles connected to the seasons of the year. The riddles are meant to challenge readers to look at the puzzles in different ways. Readers will learn quick tricks and will discover the variety of patterns in the world around them. Illustrated with full-color artwork, the book concludes with explanations about different ways to see and solve each problem. Useful as an introduction to multiplication.
Author: Greg Tang

Title: Math Man
Annotation: Marnie and her class take a field trip to the grocery store where they meet Garth, the stock boy, who is also known as Math Man. The children discover percentages, fractions, division, multiplication, and other math concepts. A group of mathematically gifted mice hang out on the edges of the pages and translate the math into equations. The book is illustrated with humorous line-and-watercolor pictures.
Author: Teri Daniels
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Mathematical Reasoning, Number Sense

Title: Math Potatoes
Annotation: Sixteen math riddles are presented in rhyme. Each poses a problem and gives the readers a hint, encouraging children to group numbers to arrive at sums and products. Illustrated with bright and engaging digital artwork.
Author: Greg Tang
Standard: Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 3.MP.1-8, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.OA.1-3, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.MP.1-8

Title: Math Talk: Mathematical Ideas in Poems for Two Voices
Annotation: This collection of 25 poems presents a variety of mathematical ideas including fractals, Fibonnaci numbers, imaginary numbers, pi, tessellations, and infinity. The poems are presented through poetic dialogues written for two people to read.
Author: Theoni Pappas
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry), Number Sense, Statistics, Data Analysis, & Probability
Standard: Math 3.G.1-2, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 5.OA.1-3, Math 5.NF.1-7, Math 5.G.1-6, Math 6.RP.1-3, Math 6.EE.1-9, Math 6.G.1-6, Math 7.RP.1-3, Math 7.NS.1-5, Math 7.EE.1-6, Math 7.G.1-7, Math HS.Functions, Math HS.Geometry

Title: Mathematickles! Poems
Annotation: Poems that cleverly reflect mathematical forms and concepts are presented in a seasonal format. The watercolor and gouache illustrations use bright colors and broad, grainy brush strokes: freely painted swirls and angles form bold designs. This is a pattern book that integrates mathematics and language arts seamlessly.
Author: Betsy Franco

Title: Matisse, the King of Color
Annotation: Artist Henri Matisse develops a strong friendship with Monique, a girl who helped nurse him back to health after a serious illness. This narrative includes the story of the Chapelle de Rosaire in France, a small chapel Matisse designed as a gift for Monique after she had entered a nunnery, and where he created beautiful stained-glass windows for her to enjoy. Based on the life of Matisse.
Author: Laurence Anholt
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4

Title: Maude March on the Run!
Annotation: Because of a misunderstanding over her involvement in a botched robbery, Maude, with her younger sister Sallie, hides out at the home of an uncle. When Maude is discovered and arrested, the orphaned sisters flee, hoping to clear Maude’s name. This Wild West adventure, the sequel to THE MISADVENTURES OF MAUDE MARCH, is filled with warmth and humor.
Author: Audrey Couloumbis

Title: Max
Annotation: Max is an excellent baseball player. On Saturday mornings he walks with his sister, Lisa, to her dancing school on his way to the park for his weekly game. One morning, Max is early, and Lisa’s teacher invites him to join the dance class. Before he knows it, he is having fun. Young ballplayers and ballet dancers will share Max’s delight when he discovers that dance class is a great way to warm up for a home run.
Author: Rachel Isadora
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA D PreK-12.5

Title: Max Goes to Mars
Annotation: This book is filled with interesting scientific facts and other information in fictional story form.
