The scientific information is explained fully in readable, understandable terms, and the illustrations make a perfect match for the text. Almost every page has sidebars for the readers who want to learn more about the science of space travel, Mars, and ancient mythology about the planets. An activity page demonstrating the orbit of Mars through a movement exercise is included. Most special are the heartwarming photographs of the real Max, which bring the readers closer to Max and his adventures.
Author: Jeffrey Bennett

Title: Mayroon Akong Alagang Puno (I Have a Tree That I Nurture)
Annotation: This award-winning book demonstrates the power of imagination: how it can lead a person, especially a child, to dream and reach places beyond this world, create different things, and even see the past and the future.
Author: Carla M. Pacis

Title: Maze of Bones, The
Annotation: In this first book of “The 39 CLUES” series, Amy and Dan, members of the powerful Cahill family, try to uncover the 39 clues which will reveal the secrets of their lineage and show what really happened to their parents. The Cahills are swept up into mystery and mayhem, traveling across the country and around the world with their nanny in search of clues. This book series encompasses hundreds of game cards and an online world that allows readers to play a part in the story and compete for prizes.
Author: Rick Riordan

Title: McMummy
Annotation: When Mozie is left to care for a greenhouse of experimental plants, all sorts of wild things begin to happen. With the support of his best friend, Mozie learns the reward for his perseverance.
Author: Betsy Cromer Byars

Title: Me and Uncle Romie: A Story Inspired by the Life and Art of Romare Bearden
Annotation: A young boy spends the summer in New York City, visiting the neighborhood of Harlem, where his uncle, collage artist Romare Bearden, grew up. This story shows how Bearden, who was a renowned artist in the Harlem Renaissance, used paint and collage to create his art. Instructions explain how to make a story collage.
Author: Claire Hartfield
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Me, Frida
Annotation: This biography of Frida Kahlo, set in San Francisco in 1930, describes when she and her husband Diego Rivera arrived from Mexico as Rivera is commissioned to paint murals for the Pacific Stock Exchange. At first, Frida is shy and lonely, but she soon shows she is strong, feisty, and creative. This true story encourages children to believe in themselves so they can make their dreams come true. Illustrated with brilliant charcoal-and-acrylic paintings. California author and California illustrator.
Author: Amy Novesky
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4

Title: Meadowlands: A Wetlands Survival Story
Annotation: This is an ecological history of the Meadowlands, an estuary in New Jersey. It describes the decline that began when settlers from Europe began draining the land and filling the marshes. Over time, the Meadowlands, once a thriving estuary, had become polluted. Illustrations and text show the slow recovery of the area and the activists and volunteers involved in recovery efforts. Useful for initiating a unit of study on ecology or habitats. Illustrated with double-page spread of watercolor artwork and sketches of animal and plant life.
Author: Thomas F. Yezerski

Title: Meanwhile
Annotation: When Raymond writes the word "Meanwhile . . ." on his wall with a red marker, he comes face-to-face with pirates, a Western posse, and Martians. Feiffer uses a watercolor, comic-strip style for the action-filled illustrations.
Author: Jules Feiffer

Title: Measuring Penny
Annotation: Assigned a homework project to measure an object in several different ways, Lisa chooses her dog, Penny. She uses standard units, such as inches, and nonstandard units, such as cotton swabs and dog biscuits. Illustrated with acrylics in a primitive style, this selection is a good read-aloud book for introducing a lesson on measurement.
Author: Loreen Leedy

Title: Meditations of John Muir: Nature’s Temple
Annotation: Offering sixty selections of John Muir’s writings, this book can be read aloud daily to introduce children to different regions of California. The patriarch of the American environmental movement wrote about subjects such as Yosemite, a walk to the gulf, the mountains of California, and summer in the Sierra Nevada. Each entry takes three to five minutes to read and transports children to another world. Illustrated with black-and-white photos that enhance the journey.
Author: Chris Highland
Topic: American History, Earth Science, Geography, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Meeting Dolphins: My Adventures in the Sea
Annotation: This lively, first-person narrative by marine biologist Kathleen Dudzinski highlights the characteristics and habits of dolphins, as well as her research projects and use of scientific equipment. The book is illustrated with well chosen full-color photographs as well as stills from the IMAX film "Dolphins," in which she is featured. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Kathleen Dudzinski

Title: Megatooth
Annotation: Large, colorful illustrations accompany a short description of Megalodon, "giant tooth," a huge prehistoric shark. The book includes watercolor illustrations of animals that lived ten million years ago. An explanation of how scientists estimate the size of Megalodon and ideas about how they evolved to such a large size and ultimately disappeared are discussed. This book may appeal to reluctant readers.
Author: Patrick O’Brien

Title: Mermaid Queen: The Spectacular True Story of Annette Kellerman, Who Swam Her Way to Fame, Fortune, and Swimsuit History
Annotation: Born in Australia at the turn of the twentieth century, Annette Kellerman was forced to wear leg braces as a young child and turned to swimming to strengthen her body. Overcoming physical and societal constraints, she became an internationally recognized endurance swimmer, invented water ballet, and designed the modern swimsuit for women, which at the time was considered too risqué for American tastes. Large, bold illustrations provide period details, and back matter offers additional information on the life of this early feminist.
Author: Shana Corey

Title: Merry-Go-Round: A Book About Nouns
Annotation: Ruth Heller provides a lesson on nouns. Vivid double-page illustrations accompany rhyming text that explains proper, common, abstract, concrete, and collective nouns. This book provides an effective review of noun forms for students in upper grades and may be used to introduce nouns to students in the lower grades and to English learners. See other titles in the “World of Language” series. California author–illustrator.
Author: Ruth Heller

Title: Mesmerized: How Ben Franklin Solved a Mystery that Baffled All of France
Annotation:
The day Ben Franklin first set foot in Paris, France, he found the city all abuzz. Everyone was talking about something new—remarkable, thrilling, and strange. Something called science!

But soon the straightforward American inventor Benjamin Franklin is upstaged by a compelling and enigmatic figure: Dr. Mesmer. In staged shows, Mesmer convinces the people of Paris that he controls a magic force that can make water taste like a hundred different things, cure illness, and control thoughts! But Ben Franklin is not convinced. Will his practical approach of observing, hypothesizing, and testing get to the bottom of the mysterious Mesmer's tricks?
Author: Mara Rockliff
Award: Cook Prize, Golden Kite Author Honor, Orbis Pictus Award

Title: Meteor!
Annotation: A meteor landing in the front yard of the Gaw family sets off a chain of events and gossip in the quiet rural community of Mudsock Meadow. The story is based on a true event and is illustrated with Polacco's signature imaginative, full-color paintings.
Author: Patricia Polacco

Title: Mi hija, mi hijo, el aguila, la paloma: Un canto Azteca (My Daughter, My Son, the Eagle, the Dove: An Aztec Chant)
Annotation: This retelling of early Aztec teachings was meant to instruct young people about life. It is a sample of the intellectual creations of the inhabitants of ancient Mexico. Guevara's illustrations combine elements taken directly from the Codex Mendoza, with contemporary views of young Latino people's lives painted on amate (Mexican bark) paper.
Author: Ana Castillo

Title: Mi primer libro de matematicas (My First Math Book)
Annotation: This is a colorful introduction to a variety of mathematical concepts through games and puzzles which encourage young readers to develop math skills. Readers experience graphs, decimals, multiplication, word problems, and more.
Author: David Clemson, Wendy Clemson
Classification: Concept Book, Counting Book, Picture Book
Topic: Mathematical Reasoning, Measurement & Geometry (Geometry), Number Sense
Standard: Math NS K.2, Math MR K.1, Math MR K.2, Math MG 2.1, Math NS 3.2

Title: Mi rincon en la montana (My Side of the Mountain)
Annotation: Sam Gribley does what many young people dream of doing—he builds a treehouse in the Catskill Mountains, where he lives alone for a year. The story features his struggle for survival and his ultimate realization that he needs human companionship. The sequel to this selection is THE OTHER SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: Mia’s Story: A Sketchbook of Hopes and Dreams
Annotation: In looking for her beloved puppy one winter day, a girl living in a small village in Chile discovers a way to add beauty to her village and help her family. Captioned illustrations are done in pencil and watercolor. Presents a glimpse of contemporary life in a faraway place and demonstrates how creativity and hope can make things better. Appropriate for reading aloud to students of many ages.
Author: Michael Foreman
Topic: Economics, Life Science (Biology), Lifestyles Around the World, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Micawber
Annotation: Micawber, a squirrel who is fascinated by art, lives in the Central Park carousel in New York City. He enjoys looking at famous paintings through the skylight of a nearby museum. One day, he follows a young artist home from the museum and, as the artist sleeps, Micawber uses her paint and his bushy tail to make his own paintings. The book features bright, realistic illustrations and includes a CD recording of the author reading the story.
Author: John Lithgow
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.4

Title: Michelangelo
Annotation: In this extended-text picture book, Stanley uses the chronology of Michelangelo's life to explain the style, technique, and meaning of his sculpture, architecture, and paintings. Computer-manipulated drawings of his actual work and Stanley's original watercolors work together to make this a thorough, easy-to-understand, and informative biography.
Author: Diane Stanley
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Mick Harte Was Here
Annotation: Thirteen-year-old Phoebe recalls the life and personality of her younger brother Mick and his death in a bicycle accident. This selection is a great discussion starter and read-aloud book that is useful for lessons on narrative writing involving personal experiences with death or with siblings.
Author: Barbara Park

Title: Midnight Forests: A Story of Gifford Pinchot and Our National Forests
Annotation: Gifford Pinchot is regarded by many as the father of the conservation movement. Growing up in Pennsylvania in the nineteenth century, Pinchot first learned about forestry and conservation at L'Ecole Nationale Forestiere in France. When he returned to the United States, he was appointed the first manager of the new, national Forest Service. This title includes an afterword.
Author: Gary Hines

Title: Midnight Fox
Annotation: Tom reluctantly goes to his aunt's farm when his parents embark on a European vacation. The discovery of a black fox and her den leads to a summer of learning and ultimately some difficult choices. The book is available in paperback or prebind.
Author: Betsy Cromer Byars

Title: Midnight Math: Twelve Terrific Math Games
Annotation: In this humorous story mice are challenged by a series of mathematical puzzles involving addition, subtraction, and other math skills. The collage illustrations have a 3-D quality that is created by a mix of computer-generated pictures, fabric, and dark backgrounds.
Author: Peter Lewdon
Standard: Math K.CC.1-7, Math K.OA.1-5, Math K.NBT.1, Math K.MD.1-4, Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 2.OA.1-6

Title: Mightiest Heart
Annotation: Steadfastness, loyalty, and courage emerge as major themes in this retelling of a Welsh legend about Prince Llywelyn and his faithful dog, Gelert. The illustrations are rich paintings that eloquently capture the love between boy and dog.
Author: Lynn Cullen

Title: Mighty Jackie, the Strike-out Queen
Annotation: In 1931, a seventeen-year-old girl pitched against Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig in an exhibition game and struck out both of them. This true story of Jackie Mitchell’s place in baseball history reflects her lifelong determination to be a pitcher. After that historic game, Mitchell was banned from playing professional baseball because the sport was considered “too strenuous” for women. Includes an author’s note and bibliography. California author.
Author: Marissa Moss

Title: Milkman, The
Annotation: In the early morning, the milkman makes his rounds, helping his neighbors in a variety of ways. Children learn about home delivery of milk and cream, a regular practice in the not-too-distant past. This is a delightful taste of Americana and may encourage children to reminisce with their grandparents about “the olden days” and to talk about other community jobs that have vanished. The artwork features colors that lighten from nighttime blue to pre-dawn gray to sun-washed orange, as the milkman makes his rounds.
Author: Carol Foskett Cordsen

Title: Millicent Min, Girl Genius
Annotation: Written as journal entries, eleven-year-old child prodigy Millicent Min records the highs and lows of the summer before her senior year in high school. They include a college poetry class and many attempts by her Chinese American parents and grandmother to give her a more "normal" childhood. This funny, heartwarming tale can be used for units on journal writing and Asian Americans.
Author: Lisa Yee

Title: Million Dollar Shot, The
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Eddie, who lives in a Louisiana trailer park with his widowed mother, gets a chance to win a million dollars by sinking a foul shot at the National Basketball Association finals.
Author: Dan Gutman

Title: Million Dots, A
Annotation: With a million dots printed on its pages, the young reader can see what a million looks like in this large-format picture book. On each page Clements features a selected number and connects it to a numerical fact.
Author: Andrew Clements
Standard: Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 5.NBT.1-7

Title: Million Fish...More or Less, A
Annotation: A young boy learns that the Bayou Clapateau is a very peculiar place. Here truth is often stretched and numbers are exaggerated. Soon he gets the chance to tell his own version of a fish-that-got-away tale. The full-color impressionistic illustrations depict the Bayou.
Author: Patricia C. McKissack

Title: Millions to Measure
Annotation: This is the third in the Discover More Books series of "million dollar" titles by Schwartz and Kellogg. This time Marvelosissimo the Magician explains the history and development of standard units of measure and shows how to calculate length, height, weight, and volume. This title includes "Measuring and the Metric System." California author.
Author: David M. Schwartz

Title: Mine, All Mine: A Book About Pronouns
Annotation: Ruth Heller provides a lesson on pronouns. Vivid double-page illustrations accompany rhyming text that covers demonstrative, personal, possessive, relative, and interrogative pronouns. This book provides an effective review of the use of pronouns for older students and may be used to introduce pronouns to younger students and English learners. See other titles in the “World of Language” series. California author–illustrator.
Author: Ruth Heller

Title: Minnie's Diner: A Multiplying Menu
Annotation: This is a rhyming tale about brothers who, despite their father's instructions to finish their work before stopping to eat, forget about their chores on the farm when drawn to enjoy the good cooking at Minnie's Diner. Each one requests double what the brother ahead has ordered. Clear, cartoon-style gouache illustrations whimsically illustrate the farmyard and diner scenes.
Author: Dayle Ann Dodds
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, English-Language Arts/Writing, Mathematics
Standard: Math K.CC.1-7, Math K.OA.1-5, Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6

Title: Minty: A Story of Young Harriet Tubman
Annotation: This selection introduces African American Underground Railroad leader Harriet Tubman, offering a fictionalized account of her childhood on a Maryland plantation. Human rights violations against slaves are depicted in powerful text and artwork in pencil, colored pencil, and watercolors. California author.
Author: Alan Schroeder
Award: Christopher Award, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Winner, Golden Kite Author Honor

Title: Miraculous Journey of Edward Tulane, The
Annotation: Edward is an expensive and beautifully dressed china rabbit. His owner, Abilene, cherishes him. In an unfortunate accident, Edward falls into the ocean and is launched on a turbulent journey into the lives of several eccentric, well-developed characters. The journey ends happily. Enhanced by sepia-tone drawings and full-color plates. Recommended as a read-aloud.
Author: Kate DiCamillo

Title: Mirror
Annotation: This wordless book contains two stories of two cultures. The stories are placed side by side, and they parallel a day in the life of two boys and their families: one in Australia and the other in Morocco. As the reader views the layered, three-dimensional collages, some of the cultural activities are similar, while others are distinctly different—for example, transportation, foods, markets, surrounding terrain, and clothing. Small window inserts add detail to this mirror story that ends with both boys enjoying their new purchases.
Author: Jeannie Baker
Topic: Diversity, Ethnic Studies, Geography, Global Social Institutions, Lifestyles Around the World

Title: Mirror Mirror: A Book of Reversible Verse
Annotation: Author Marilyn Singer says, “We read most poems down a page. But what if we read them up? That’s the question I asked myself when I created the reverso.” She has taken 12 familiar fairy-tale characters and created reverse poems to show that there are two sides to every story. This is a unique and witty look at fairy tales and poetry, with two illustrations for each presentation. Use as a model text for student writing.
Author: Marilyn Singer

Title: Misadventures of Maude March, The
Annotation: After the death of their stern aunt, who raised them since they were orphaned, eleven-year-old Sallie and her fifteen-year-old sister escape their self-serving guardians and begin an adventure resembling those in the dime-store novels Sallie loves to read. This rollicking Wild West adventure is a wonderful read-aloud.
Author: Audrey Couloumbis

Title: Miss Bridie Chose a Shovel
Annotation: Miss Bridie immigrates to America in 1856 and chooses to bring a shovel, which proves to be a useful tool throughout her life. She uses it diligently and finds work, marries, raises a family, improves her family’s farm, and eventually plants a tree in her husband’s memory. This is a lyrical tribute to hardworking immigrants. Woodcut illustrations provide additional details about the story’s setting.
Author: Leslie Conner

Title: Miss Lady Bird's Wildflowers: How a First Lady Changed America
Annotation: As the wife of President Lyndon Johnson, Lady Bird Johnson reminded citizens about the importance of conserving natural resources and promoted the beautification of cities and highways through the planting of wildflowers. The colorful gouache artwork provides a visual garden for children to explore. The book includes an identification key to the multitude of wildflowers depicted and an endnote on the Lady Bird Wildflower Center.
Author: Kathi Applet

Title: Miss Nelson Is Missing!
Annotation: When Miss Nelson's class misbehaves, she disappears. She is replaced by the dreaded substitute, Miss Viola Swamp, the meanest teacher in the world. This and other Miss Nelson books are great to be read aloud, especially by substitute teachers.
Author: Harry Allard

Title: Miss Rumphius
Annotation: Great-Aunt Alice Rumphius promises her grandfather that when she grows up she will live by the sea, visit faraway places, and do something to make the world more beautiful. She accomplishes the first two but is stumped by the third until she becomes the Lupine Lady.
Author: Barbara Cooney
Standard: HSS K.1, LS 1.2, HSS 1.1, LS 2.2, HSS 1.4, HSS 2.1, HSS 2.5

Title: Miss Smith Under the Ocean
Annotation: Miss Smith’s latest adventures unravel near the deep blue sea. Her “Incredible Storybook” awakens the Owl, the Pussycat, Moby Dick, Gulliver, various mermaids and pirates, along with an entire shipload of sea-faring characters from classic literature. As they board the Nautilus and encounter many mysteries of the deep, Miss Smith once again prevails in her mastery of all of the characters she has awakened with her storytelling. May be used with older students as a text-to-text connection. Illustrated with full-color digital artwork.
Author: Michael Garland

Title: Miss Smith's Incredible Storybook
Annotation: As Miss Smith shares a book with her students, the characters come alive and surround her classroom until she finishes each story and they return to their appropriate pages. When Miss Smith is stuck in traffic, the principal steps in to read aloud. Control of the story characters is lost, and bedlam ensues. Finally, Miss Smith sweeps in to restore order. Illustrated with computer-generated artwork.
Author: Michael Garland
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Missing 'Gator of Gumbo Limbo: An Ecological Mystery
Annotation: Dajun, the resident alligator of Gumbo Limbo in the Everglades, is missing and residents of the nearby condos want him gone for good. However, without Dajun, the ecology of the swamp is deteriorating, and Lisa K. works with others living in Gumbo Limbo to save Dajun and the swamp environment. This book is part of the series An Eco Mystery.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: Mississippi
Annotation: Stirring poetry is complemented by watercolor illustrations to provide a moving documentary of the Mighty Mississippi River. The geological and ecological evolution is traced as well as its coexistence and difficulties with the people who settled along its banks.
Author: Diane Siebert

Title: Mississippi Bridge
Annotation: This novel relates a disturbing tale of racism, set in 1930s Mississippi, as seen through the eyes of a ten-year-old white boy. Language reflecting the times tells of the civil rights violations that occur as paying African American customers are forced from a bus in order to accommodate whites. One of these ousted African Americans tries to save the whites from a raging river as the bus runs off the bridge. Black-and-white pencil sketches convey the drama and high emotions.
Author: Mildred D. Taylor

Title: Mississippi Mud: Three Prairie Journals
Annotation: This collection of poems from the journals of three pioneer children reflects their experiences in crossing the prairie in a covered wagon from Kentucky to Oregon. Two-page watercolor illustrations serve as the backdrop for the free-form verse and document the poignancy of leaving one home for another, the expanse of the prairie, the camaraderie around the campfire, and the sorrow of losing a dog.
Author: Ann Warren Turner

Title: Missy Violet and Me
Annotation: During the early 1900s, eleven-year-old Viney spends her summer working for the local midwife and learns firsthand about birth, death, and “catchin’ babies.” The book is based on stories told by the author’s mother. It is a warm, humorous, and heartfelt look into the lives of an early twentieth-century African American family. Author Barbara Hathaway received the 2005 John Steptoe New Talent Award for this work.
Author: Barbara Hathaway

Title: Mistakes that Worked
Annotation: The origin of Velcro, how aspirin was discovered, and why Ivory soap floats are examples of inventions or discoveries that happened by accident. A wide variety of this type of "mistakes" are presented in this book. Whimsical cartoonlike illustrations complement the writing to engage readers.
Author: Charlotte Foltz Jones

Title: Misterios del oceano (Mysteries of the Ocean)
Annotation: Ocean mysteries such as underwater volcanoes, unusual creatures, and tropical to polar waters are all discussed in this well-written book. Pictures, plastic overlays, and clear text provide basic information on the world's oceans.
Translator: Tony Hargreaves and Brin Edwards Tony Hargreaves and Brin Edwards
Author: Peter Riley

Title: Mockingbird: (Mok'ing-burd)
Annotation: Caitlin has Asberger’s syndrome and sees things as black or white and good or bad. She has always depended on her brother to gently explain the workings of the world. She is desperately trying to recover from the death of her brother, and her father is no help at all. With the help of her counselor, Caitlin begins the search for closure and finds it in a most unusual form. The first-person narrative allows readers to experience the way Caitlin experiences and interacts with the world.
Author: Kathryn Erskine
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health

Title: Mojave
Annotation: The vast desert region of Southern California is depicted in this poem celebrating the region's beauty and wonder. Oil painting illustrations by Wendall Minor add a deeper dimension to the text.
Author: Diane Siebert

Title: Mole Music
Annotation: Mole is lonely underground, so he acquires a violin and learns to make joyful, beautiful music. His music travels above the earth and touches others’ hearts, making the world a better place. The illustrations show scenes both below and above ground, allowing readers to see that Mole’s music truly makes a difference.
Author: David McPhail
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.4, VAPA M PreK-12.5

Title: Molly Bannaky
Annotation: This is the remarkable story of Molly Bannaky, who was exiled at age seventeen from England as a punishment for stealing. She was sent to the colony of Maryland in the late seventeenth century as an indentured servant. After seven years of labor, she was granted her freedom and began a farm of her own, later marrying a freed slave. She eventually taught her grandson, Benjamin Banneker, how to read and write by using the family bible. Watercolor illustrations accompany the text.
Author: Alice McGill

Title: Molly's Pilgrim
Annotation: Molly's assignment is to make a pilgrim doll for the class Thanksgiving display. Her mother helps, but doesn't understand the American term "pilgrim." Much to Molly's embarrassment, her mother dresses the doll as she dressed before leaving Russia to seek religious freedom.
Author: Barbara Cohen

Title: Moon and I, The
Annotation: While describing her adventures with a "resident" black snake (Moon), noted author Betsy Byars tells of her childhood and explains how she writes a book. The work is available in paperback or prebind and includes family photographs. Readers may want to read the author's Newbery Award-winning novel SUMMER OF THE SWANS.
Author: Betsy Cromer Byars

Title: Moon Book, The
Annotation: This book includes an explanation of the movement and phases of the Moon, its effect on Earth's oceans, moon exploration, as well as a discussion of how people have observed and explored it through time and in various cultures. The writing is clear and simple, while the colorful detailed illustrations encourage careful study.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Moon Festival
Annotation: This tale explains the Mid-Autumn Festival in Vietnam in which children parade with lanterns around the villages. Many important Vietnamese customs are depicted; the scenes are graphic and depict violent situations.
Author: Le Quang Vinh

Title: Moon in Bear's Eyes
Annotation: This title recounts the story of a mother grizzly and her two cubs as they emerge from hibernation in Yellowstone National Park. The narrative is engaging for readers of all ages: "In the stillness of a wild and barren mountain ridge, the snow lies deep. A full moon casts thin, sharp shadows of spruce trees, black on white like a zebra's hide. At the base of one of the old, fallen spruce trees, a great mound of snow begins to shudder." The illustrations include panoramic views of Yellowstone in the springtime.
Author: Stephen R. Swinburne

Title: Moon Tales: Myths of the Moon from Around the World
Annotation: Tales from around the world attempt to explain the mysteries of the moon. Why does the moon wax and wane? What are those marks on its surface? The answers are found in the myths of a variety of cultures. The book is illustrated with appropriately-hued paintings.
Author: Rina Singh

Title: Moon Was at a Fiesta, The (La luna se fue de fiesta)
Annotation: An original porquoi story set in Oaxaca, Mexico explains why the moon is sometimes still visible in the morning sky. Jealous of the sun, the moon creates her own fiesta and celebrates so much that she stays out past dawn. Spanish words are woven through the text making for a perfect read-aloud choice. The watercolor and acrylic paintings are full of details highlighting Oaxacan culture including paper cut-out decorations, fireworks, and wooden masks. California author.
Author: Matthew Gollub

Title: Moon, The
Annotation: This is a revision of Simon's 1984 introduction to the moon. New, full-color photographs of the earth from space and of the surface of the moon and color reproductions are included with Simon's updated narrative text.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Moonshot: The Flight of Apollo 11
Annotation: This large-format, nonfiction picture book introduces young readers to the historic space flight that first brought astronauts to the moon in 1969. The front endpapers provide detailed diagrams and a pictorial chronology; the back endpapers contain a brief history of NASA’s lunar program. Illustrated with watercolor-and-ink artwork.
Author: Brian Floca

Title: Moonstick: The Seasons of the Sioux
Annotation: A young Native American boy describes the seasonal changes in nature and notches each new moon of the Sioux year on a moonstick. The poetic text is enhanced with lush double-spread paintings that depict the wilderness and activities of the Sioux before Europeans arrived. Also connects to fifth-grade standards for history/social science. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: More Stories to Solve
Annotation: This follow-up to STORIES TO SOLVE offers 15 short tales, each of which poses a mathematical problem or puzzle. The tales are taken from a variety of cultures, and each is followed by an explanation or solution. Notes in the back of the book give details on the origins of each tale. Black-and-white illustrations accompany the text and sometimes assist the reader in arriving at a solution.
Author: George Shannon

Title: More Than Anything Else
Annotation: Booker T. Washington toils hard at the saltworks alongside his father and brother each day. With equal determination and hard work he realizes his dream to learn to read. This book presents a powerful literacy statement.
Author: Marie Bradby

Title: Morgy’s Musical Summer
Annotation: To encourage his talent for playing the trumpet, Morgy’s parents send him to a music camp over the summer, where he meets Damian, an advanced student who likes to tease “promising beginners.” Despite the bullying, Morgy shows determination and gains enough skill to play a satisfying solo. Black-and-white illustrations complement the story.
Author: Maggie Lewis

Title: Morning Girl
Annotation: Morning Girl and Star Boy each describe their life on an island in pre-Columbus America. Morning Girl explores her meeting with the men in Christopher Columbus's expedition. The epilogue is a page from Columbus's journal describing the island people.
Author: Michael Dorris

Title: Moses: When Harriet Tubman Led Her People to Freedom
Annotation: A fictional story based on the spiritual life of Harriet Tubman. She saw visions and believed she was called by God to free slaves. This poetic text, which spans Tubman’s days as a slave and her life as a free person, makes it clear that Tubman’s faith sustained her on many journeys as she helped slaves escape through the Underground Railroad.
Author: Carole Boston Weatherford
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Author Winner

Title: Mosquito Bite
Annotation: This riveting story is about a boy playing hide-and-seek while a female mosquito is out looking for blood. The mosquito is shown through brightly colored, greatly magnified photographs. The reader learns about the mosquito’s life cycle and how she bites for the survival of her species. Additional facts about mosquitoes are included.
Author: Alexandra Siy

Title: Most Beautiful Roof in the World: Exploring the Rainforest Canopy, The
Annotation: This book chronicles the daily work of biologist Meg Lowman as she studies the rain forest ecosystem in Belize. She engages in experiments, observes the activities of various animal species, and brings her two young sons to join her in the rain forest canopy. The engaging text is enhanced with full-color photographs.
Author: Kathryn Lasky

Title: Mother to Tigers
Annotation: This picture-book biography tells the story of Helen Delaney Martini, founder of the Bronx Zoo's animal nursery. The childless Martini began taking care of infant tigers in her apartment when her zookeeper husband brought the baby tigers home. She eventually became the zoo's first female zookeeper and successfully raised 27 tigers, a variety of primates, and miscellaneous other animals. The author's detailed yet elegant text emphasizes Martini's dedication to the animals in her care. The illustrator's use of watercolor, charcoal, and torn-paper art is effective, and newsreel-type pictures add to the nostalgic aura of this story that took place in the 1940s and 1950s. An author's note fills in some details of Martini's life and mentions her autobiography, MY ZOO FAMILY.
Author: George Ella Lyon

Title: Motivo de una flor, El (The Reason for a Flower)
Annotation: This poetic presentation tells about plant reproduction, manufacturing of seeds, and seed propagation. It also shows plants which don't seem to be flowers but are flowers. The text is supported by Heller's trademark full-color detailed illustrations that help explain the concepts presented. California author/illustrator.
Author: Ruth Heller

Title: Mountain Dance
Annotation: The majesty of mountains is celebrated in this beautiful book that tells the geologic evolution of mountains, beginning with volcanic eruptions and continuing with the natural forces of nature building them up or wearing them down. The text, told in free-verse poetry, creates a feeling of power, movement and grace, expressing nature's "dance" through time. An oil painting opposite each text page helps to describe each lyric. Can be used as a picture book for older readers.
Author: Thomas Locker

Title: Mountain that Loved a Bird, The
Annotation: This is a story about a barren mountain that ends up providing a suitable environment for plants and animals with the help of a bird and her many descendents. Carle's signature artwork utilizes hand-painted papers and collage.
Author: Alice McLerran

Title: Mouse and the Motorcycle, The
Annotation: When Keith and his family vacation at the Mountain View Inn, a little hotel mouse called Ralph learns to ride one of Keith's toy motorcycles. Boy and mouse become fast friends, and their adventures will bring laughter to the young reader. California author and setting.
Author: Beverly Cleary

Title: Mouse Bride, The
Annotation: Searching for the strongest husband for his daughter, a mouse goes to the sun, cloud, wind, and wall in search of a qualified candidate, only to find him among his fellow mice. Full-page watercolor illustrations accompany the text.
Author: Monica Chang

Title: Mouse Called Wolf, A
Annotation: Wolfgang Amadeus Mouse lives in a hole behind the piano leg in the house of the elderly Mrs. Honeybee. They develop a wonderful friendship while sharing their musical talents - Wolf sings and Mrs. Honeybee plays the piano. One day, Mrs. Honeybee falls and it is through Wolf's efforts that his friend is rescued. This is an effective read-aloud book.
Author: Dick King-Smith

Title: Movers and Shapers: Bones, Muscles, and Joints
Annotation: Interesting facts about bones, muscles, and joints are energetically introduced in this well-designed title. Colorful, two-page spreads invite readers to browse through photographs, captions, and brief paragraphs to learn valuable secrets about bony structures and the function of each in the human body. An emphasis is placed on physical fitness. Opportunities for enrichment provided by this book include a glossary, cartoons, quizzes, and suggested Web sites.
Author: Patricia Macnair
Discipline: Physical Education, Visual and Performing Arts, Science

Title: Mozart Question, The
Annotation: A young journalist goes to Venice, Italy, to interview a famous violinist, Paolo Levi, who tells the story of his parents’ incarceration by the Nazis. The journalist discovers why the violinist never plays Mozart. This short, illustrated novel gives readers another perspective on the horrors of the Holocaust.
Author: Michael Morpurgo

Title: Mozart Tonight
Annotation: As Wolfgang Mozart arrives at the debut of his opera "Don Giovanni," he relates the events of his life that have led up to this triumph. Expressive watercolor paintings evoke the time and setting of this picture book biography. California author and illustrator.
Author: Julie Downing
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Mr. Ferris and His Wheel
Annotation: When George Washington Gale Ferris Jr. was a child growing up in the countryside of Nevada, he was fascinated by a water wheel at a nearby mill. This picture book biography tells the story of how George Ferris built the first Ferris Wheel ride for the World's Fair.
Author: Kathryn Gibbs Davis
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures, Mathematical Analysis, Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)

Title: Mr. Lincoln's Way
Annotation: Mr. Lincoln is the coolest principal ever! He wears cool clothes and has a cool smile. He knows how to do everything, but can he find a way to reach "Mean Gene," who is a bad student and a bully? Colorful, expressive watercolor art enhances the text.
Author: Patricia Polacco

Title: Mr. Maxwell's Mouse
Annotation: An executive-level cat on his lunch break orders a live mouse instead of his usual baked mouse and finds himself talking with his meal.
Author: Frank Asch

Title: Mrs. Frisby and the Rats of NIMH
Annotation: A widowed mouse, Mrs. Frisby, and a group of rats have escaped from a NIMH laboratory after being taught to read. The rats help Mrs. Frisby move her children to safety; she in turn helps the rats escape to a utopian civilization of their own design.
Author: Robert C. O'Brien

Title: Mrs. Harkness and the Panda
Annotation: In 1936, Ruth Harkness sets out to complete her late husband’s expedition to China to capture and bring back a panda. Overcoming great challenges, and with the help of a guide and explorer, Ruth captures a baby panda and returns with it to America. Chinese watercolor-style illustrations, as well as collages of Chinese fabrics, maps, and postcards, complement the text. Also includes bibliographical references.
Author: Alicia Potter
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Life Science (Biology), Women’s Studies

Title: Ms. McCaw Learns to Draw
Annotation: School is not easy for Dudley Ellington, and he drifts into daydreams when he should be paying attention to his lessons. His patient teacher, Ms. McCaw, takes the time to explain things to him over and over. Drawing comes easily to Dudley, and when Ms. McCaw is unable to draw a face on the board, he patiently helps her figure out how to do it. Detailed artwork is done with ink and watercolor in a retro style, reminiscent of the 1950s.
Author: Kaethe Zemach

Title: Mua Hoa Phuong and Con Duong Vang Bong Thien (The Season of the Flamboyant Flowers and The Street Without Thien)
Annotation: There are two stories in this Vietnamese practice reader. The first story is about summertime. Phuong and Ti have a happy and relaxing vacation with different games and activities. The second story is about friendship. Two best friends, Phuong and Thien, suffer from the separation as Thien leaves the country by boat without saying good-bye.
Author: Tran Thi Nhuong

Title: Mufaro's Beautiful Daughters: An African Tale
Annotation: Based on the Cinderella story, this version features Mufaro's daughters, who are opposites - one is kind and compassionate, the other is selfish and mean-spirited. Readers follow the daughters on their trip to see the King for the purpose of marriage and learn about the rewards of being kind, regardless of the circumstances. Lush and dramatic ink-and-watercolor illustrations detail the clothing, flora, and fauna of the Zimbabwe setting.
Author: John Steptoe
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Winner

Title: Multiplying Menace: The Revenge of Rumpelstiltskin
Annotation: Ten years after being tricked, Rumpelstiltskin returns to the royal family to wreak vengeance by means of multiplication. The royal family's little prince takes possession of Rumpelstiltskin's magical stick and sets about restoring normalcy to the kingdom. An endnote includes nonfiction math notes about multiplying by whole numbers and by fractions.
Author: Pam Calvert
Standard: Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.NF.1-7

Title: Munting Ningas-Apoy (Little Flame)
Annotation: It is said that fire can be one's good friend or worst enemy. This book illustrates the many uses and advantages of fire in personal as well as industrial and economic development.
Author: Mike Bigornia

Title: Munting Patak-Ulan: Saan Nagpupunta ang Tubig Pagkaraan ng Ulan? (Little Raindrop: Where Does the Water Go After the Rain?)
Annotation: This concept book describes the many uses of water after falling on earth as rain. In a storylike fashion, the journey of a raindrop and the importance of water for all living things are told.
Author: Gloria Villaraza-Guzman

Title: Muscles: Our Muscular System
Annotation: The anatomy and function of muscles are described in clear text, including the three different types of muscles and how exercise affects them. The picture-book format includes MRI scans, x-rays, drawings, and full-page, computer-generated illustrations. This is one in a series of books on the human body by this author.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Museum Shapes
Annotation: A wide range of works of art are used to illustrate 10 plane shapes in words and images. Each shape is paired with a work of art in which the shape is prominent, a set of questions, and four other examples. The art examples are from a variety of cultures and highlight many artistic styles. Concludes with a list of the titles and sources of the works of art.
Author: Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York)
Standard: Math K.G.1-6, Math 1.G.1-3, Math 2.G.1-3, Math 3.G.1-2, Math 4.G.1-3

Title: Museum Trip
Annotation: A wordless book that celebrates imagination. A boy wanders away from his group in a museum and enters a series of mazes. When the boy completes the final maze, he finds a few surprises. Bright, cartoon-style artwork is rendered in watercolor, gouache, and ink and shows the boy traveling through the mazes.
Author: Barbara Lehman

Title: Music for Alice
Annotation: During World War II, Alice Sumida, a Japanese American, and her husband Mark were sent to an internment camp and then to sugar-beet fields as laborers. After the war, their hard work helped them become successful gladiola farmers. Alice loved to dance when she was in high school, but it was only after her working years were done and her beloved husband died that she had time to dance again.
Author: Allen Say
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Music in Derrick’s Heart, The
Annotation: Uncle Booker T., who makes magic by playing his harmonica music from his heart, spends the summer teaching Derrick how to play. When arthritis prevents Uncle Booker T. from giving a lesson one day, Derrick soothes his mentor with his own playing. Illustrated with full-color paintings. Highlights the rewards of practice and the healing power of music.
Author: Gwendolyn Battle-Lavert

Title: Music Math: Exploring Different Interpretations of Fractions
Annotation: The author explains math fractions by means of musical notation. This full-color, photo-illustrated math reader seamlessly integrates mathematics with the curriculum areas of science and social science. An index is included.
Author: Kathleen Collins

Title: Music of the Dolphins, The
Annotation: Diary entries recount the rehabilitation process experienced by Mila, a girl raised by a family of dolphins, after her parents die at sea. The development of language is contrasted with the restrictions of living on land that Mila soon experiences. She longs again to be free.
Author: Karen Hesse

Title: My America: A Poetry Atlas of the United States
Annotation: The diversity found in the United States is captured in this anthology of poems that represent each section of America. Included in the collection of 51 poems are some by Carl Sandburg, Langston Hughes, and Myra Cohn Livingston. Each poem is accompanied by a full-color stylized painting. Useful for integrating literature with history/social science.
Author: Lee Bennett Hopkins

Title: My Brother Martin: A Sister Remembers Growing Up with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
Annotation: The early life of Martin Luther King, Jr., the fun-loving and often mischievous boy, is told through the eyes of his older sister. The realistic, full-page watercolor illustrations are handsome additions that bring this family to life. Includes a poetic tribute to Martin Luther King, Jr., by Mildred D. Johnson, an afterword, and an illustrator's note.
Author: Christopher Farris

Title: My Dadima Wears a Sari
Annotation: Two young sisters raised in America learn from their Indian grandmother about the beauty and art of wearing a sari. The children learn all the things a sari can be used for, how to wear a sari, and information about the culture of the sari. The book includes bright watercolor illustrations, an author’s note, and directions on how to wrap a sari.
Author: Kashmira Sheth
Topic: Diversity, Ethnic Studies, Lifestyles Around the World, Women’s Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: My Diary from Here to There/Mi diario de aqui hasta alla
Annotation: Amada's parents have decided to emigrate from Juarez, Mexico, to California in the hopes of her father finding a better job. Amada writes a detailed diary of her feelings and the events of the move. The text is in both English and Spanish. The vibrant illustrations help convey the strong feelings of the diary. Based on the true-life experience of the author. California author and illustrator.
Author: Amada Irma Perez

Title: My Freedom Trip
Annotation: As the Korean War approaches, Soo’s father escapes to South Korea. A guide is sent to escort Soo to her father, promising that he will return to bring her mother. Soo is reunited with her father; however, war begins and Soo never sees her mother again. Throughout her life, Soo recalls her mother’s last words to her: “Be brave.” Based on the life of the author’s mother. A guide to Korean words and characters is included.
Author: Frances Park, Ginger Park
Topic: Diversity, Global Historical Events and Figures, War

Title: My Great-Aunt Arizona
Annotation: Great-Aunt Arizona grew up in the Blue Ridge Mountains, went to a one-room school, loved to read, and dreamed of visiting faraway places. Her faraway place turned out to be a teachers' college. Then she returned home to teach for 57 years in the school of her childhood. Soft, detailed, and charming illustrations evoke the time and place of the story perfectly.
Author: Gloria Houston

Title: My Hands Sing the Blues: Romare Bearden’s Childhood Journey
Annotation: Romare Bearden, the famous Harlem Renaissance artist, called his art “visual jazz.” This fictionalized first-person biography is told in the style of a blues song—with rhythm, rhyme, and repetition. The story begins with Bearden’s childhood in South Carolina and his move north, where he stayed and created his art. The oil and mixed-media collage illustrations enhance the story.
Author: Jeanne Walker Harvey
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: My Librarian Is a Camel: How Books Are Brought to Children Around the World
Annotation: This photo essay is filled with photographs, information, and personal stories about mobile libraries and their young patrons in 13 countries around the world. Photos show some of the unique ways by which books are delivered—including boat, camel, and elephant. Maps and basic facts about each featured country are included in sidebars.
Author: Margriet Ruurs
Topic: Diversity, Global Social Issues, Lifestyles Around the World, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: My Life in Dog Years
Annotation: This collection contains eight autobiographical stories about the dogs the author has owned and loved. This selection is useful as a part of an author study and as a model for autobiographical and short story writing.
Author: Gary Paulsen

Title: My Life with the Wave
Annotation: A boy befriends a wave and brings it home, where they romp together until the onset of winter storms turns it bleak and angry. The wave is returned to the sea in frozen form, and the boy dreams of a new predicament. Acrylic and oil illustrations complement the story.
Author: Catherine Cowan

Title: My Light
Annotation: This richly illustrated story relates the journey of sunlight to Earth and its connection to various types of energy generated by water, wind, and plants. Endnotes provide background information and should be read first to support concepts and ideas for small-group read-aloud and discussion. California author.
Author: Molly Bang

Title: My Mama Had a Dancing Heart
Annotation: Captured by her mother's love of dance, a young girl joyously follows her in a dance through the seasons. Raul Colon uses an art technique that incorporates colored pencil and watercolor washes textured with scratching tools.
Author: Libba Moore Gray
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.5

Title: My Name Is Georgia: A Portrait
Annotation: The life of Georgia O'Keefe, the famous painter who drew much of her inspiration from nature, is presented in brief text and illustrations in deep, muted colors. Bibliographical references are included.
Author: Jeanette Winter
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: My Name Is Jorge: On Both Sides of the River
Annotation: This book of poems explores the struggles of a boy from Mexico attending school in the United States. All poems are in English and Spanish and are set in contemporary time.
Author: Jane Medina

Title: My Name Is Maria Isabel
Annotation: Third-grader Maria Isabel, born in Puerto Rico and now living in the United States, wants badly to fit in at school. The teacher's writing assignment "My Greatest Wish" gives her that opportunity. Through the assignment Maria Isabel is able to convey her wish to be known by her given name, not as "Mary." California author.
Author: Alma Flor Ada

Title: My Name Is Sally Little Song
Annotation: In 1803, the slave master plans to sell Pa’s children—so the family, including twelve-year-old Sally, runs away from their Georgia plantation to look for freedom from slavery and a home in Florida with the Seminole Indians. In this first-person narrative, each chapter begins with a simple poem. The story is based on historical accounts and centers on escape to the South rather than the North.
Author: Brenda Woods

Title: My Painted House, My Friendly Chicken, and Me
Annotation: Eight-year-old Thandi describes the traditional artwork of the Ndebele people of South Africa, highlighting her village’s painted houses and her mother’s detailed beadwork. Author Maya Angelou collaborated with the Ndebele people to develop this story. Vibrant blocks of color are combined with photos of the painted houses.
Author: Maya Angelou

Title: My People
Annotation: This 33-word poem celebrates diversity among the African American people, displaying their uniqueness in varied skin colors, ages, and expressions on simple black backgrounds. Each sepia-toned, black-and-white photo (including the thumbnails that resemble filmstrips) evokes the mood and sets the tone for the simple verse.
Author: Langston Hughes
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: My Prairie Christmas
Annotation: When Papa does not return on Christmas Eve after going out to find a Christmas tree, little Eleanor and the rest of the family are filled with worry. Determined to make Christmas festive, Mama and the children trudge through the snow to cut a little cottonwood tree. Papa arrives home after being held up in a snowstorm, and the first Christmas on the prairie is the very best ever. Soft, colored illustrations illuminate the caring of the family for one another.
Author: Brett Harvey

Title: My Rows and Piles of Coins
Annotation: This contemporary East African story tells of a proud and helpful boy who is determined to learn to ride and purchase a bicycle in order to ease his mother's task of taking goods to market. Warm, earth-tone illustrations highlight this story of love and determination.
Author: Tololwa Mollel

Title: My Season with Penguins: An Antarctic Journal
Annotation: Author, artist, and ornithologist Sophie Webb studied and documented the eating, swimming, and travel habits of Antarctica's Adélie penguins while gathering data for two months on a research expedition. Gouache and watercolor paintings, some highlighted with full-page stark gray/white backgrounds, help readers interpret the behavior of the birds engaged in typical activities. A glossary provides definitions of unfamiliar terms.
Author: Sophie Webb
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: My Senator and Me: A Dog’s-Eye View of Washington, D.C.
Annotation: Senator Edward Kennedy’s dog, Splash, takes readers on a short tour of Washington, D.C., and follows the senator around Capitol Hill for a day. This lighthearted, informative, and nonpartisan view of how a bill becomes a law is presented in a clear style that will appeal to children. Cartoon-style illustrations accompany the text.
Author: Senator Edward M. Kennedy

Title: My Side of the Mountain
Annotation: Sam Gribley does what many young people dream of doing—he builds a treehouse in the Catskill Mountains, where he lives alone for a year. The story features his struggle for survival and his ultimate realization that he needs human companionship. The sequel to this selection is THE OTHER SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: My Very First Mother Goose
Annotation: In this oversized book, more than 60 nursery rhymes are presented with warmth and humor. The illustrations are filled with Wells' familiar book characters that perfectly evoke, and add to the message of, the nursery rhyme. For all ages.
Author: Iona Opie (editor)

Title: My Visit to the Aquarium
Annotation: A visit to the aquarium features a variety of aquatic habitats including tropical coral reefs, kelp beds, fresh water swamps, tide pools and the many creatures that inhabit these ecosystems. The bright, detailed illustrations show the diversity of life in these habitats. The story is based on several existing aquariums.
Author: Aliki

Title: Mysterious Benedict Society, The
Annotation: Reynie Muldoon answers a newspaper advertisement calling for “gifted students looking for special opportunities.” He and three other orphans are chosen by Mr. Benedict to become members of the Mysterious Benedict Society. Sent to the Learning Institute for the Very Enlightened, Reynie and his friends investigate and try to stop a criminal mastermind who is training children to take over the world. Illustrated with occasional pen-and-ink drawings. Book 1 in the “Mysterious Benedict Society” series.
Author: Trenton Lee Stewart

Title: Mysterious Collection of Dr. David Harleyson, The
Annotation: When world-famous artist David Harleyson disappears, his nephew pieces together the clues found on the backs of a group of portraits, which feature characters from Mother Goose, Grimm, and Aesop, to determine where he went.
Author: Jean Cassels

Title: Mysterious Patterns: Finding Fractals in Nature
Annotation: Nature's repeating patterns, called fractals, are beautiful and explain a lot about how things grow. This book is an introduction to understanding fractals through patterns that can be seen in parks, rivers, and our very own backyards.
Author: Sarah Campbell

Title: Mystery Math: A First Book of Algebra
Annotation: Mandy and Billy need to solve some problems as they explore a creepy haunted house. They use algebra to find the mystery numbers (variables) as they add, subtract, multiply, and divide. Collage-like digital illustrations centered on a Halloween theme guide readers by supplying visual clues to the problem. Appropriate for reluctant and struggling readers.
Author: David A. Adler
Topic: Mathematics, Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Mathematical Reasoning

Title: Mystery of Mars, The
Annotation: Factual comparisons between Earth and Mars as well as information on the exploration of Mars are presented in a highly readable text by a former astronaut and a science teacher. The book is illustrated with photographs taken from space interspersed with charts and artist renderings of the Martian landscape. Included are a timeline of Mars missions and a list of Web resources.
Author: Sally Ride, Tam O'Shaughnessy

Title: Mystery of the Mammoth Bones: And How it Was Solved
Annotation: Noted portrait artist Charles Willson Peale created the first American natural history museum in 1786, in which he displayed specimens of animals and birds, as well as his own paintings. In 1801 he excavated two mastodon skeletons and became a largely self-taught paleontologist. His research and excavations are described and illustrated with art prints and photographs. Also included is a bibliography, source notes, and an index.
Author: James Cross Giblin
Topic: Earth Science, English-Language Arts/General, Life Science (Biology)

Title: Naked Mole Rats
Annotation: This book explores the unique naked mole-rat of Africa and provides information about this animal's adaptations to its habitat, including physical characteristics, home, feeding habits, social structure, and defenses. A table of contents, a glossary, and an index are included for student reference.
Author: Gail Jarrow, Paul W. Sherman

Title: Name of the Tree, The
Annotation: This Bantu folktale tells of animals strong and weak who venture out of the grassland environment due to drought to find a tree that will give them food. They find one that bears a variety of fruit, but none can reach the fruit. Striking illustrations of the desert landscape clearly portray the grassland biome.
Author: Celia Barker Lottridge

Title: Naming Liberty
Annotation: Parallel narratives intersect in this book. In one, a Jewish family prepares to emigrate from Russia to America. Gitl, the youngest child, looks forward to escaping the violent attacks by local, non-Jewish neighbors and to getting a new name in America. The other story tells about Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, who designs, raises funds for, and builds the Statue of Liberty in honor of the United States’ centennial. When the family arrives in New York’s harbor, Lady Liberty welcomes them and inspires a new name for Gitl. Large, realistic oil paintings help to tell both stories.
Author: Jane Yolen
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Nana Upstairs and Nana Downstairs
Annotation: Tommy enjoyed his visits with Grandmother, who lived downstairs, and with Great-Grandmother upstairs. When ninety-four-year-old Nana dies, his family helps Tommy understand that death is part of life's natural process. This warm, comforting story helps children deal with losses. This is the new edition with retouched artwork.
Author: Tomie dePaola

Title: Nana’s Big Surprise (Nana, ¡Qué Sorpresa!)
Annotation: Amada and her family build a chicken coop, hoping that Amada’s grandmother, who is visiting from Mexico, will enjoy raising the chickens and be distracted from her grief over Grandfather’s death. This picture book includes text in both Spanish and English. Bright illustrations, done in a folk-art style, enhance and bring life to the story. California author and California illustrator.
Author: Amada Irma Pérez
Topic: Diversity, Economics, Ethnic Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Nas Tsuag Tus Nkauj Nyab: Zaj Dab Neeg Suav (The Mouse Bride: A Chinese Folktale)
Annotation: Searching for the strongest husband for his daughter, a mouse goes to the sun, cloud, wind, and wall in search of a qualified candidate, only to find him among his fellow mice. Full-page watercolor illustrations accompany the text. Regional dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text. Translated by Tong Mua, Pao Vang, and Terfong Yang.
Author: Monica Chang

Title: Nasty Bugs
Annotation: This collection of poems by a variety of children’s writers presents undesirable bugs in a humorous context. The poems are informative and funny and provide interesting descriptions of various creepy crawlers. Bright, bold illustrations of mischievous and menacing bugs accompany the poems. Short notes that appear at the end of the book include the scientific name for each bug. An excellent read-aloud choice.
Author: Lee Bennett Hopkins
Classification: Picture Book, Read Aloud, Struggling Reader

Title: Nation’s Hope: The Story of Boxing Legend Joe Louis, A
Annotation: Traces the life of Joe Louis, the famous African American boxer, and dramatically recounts the story behind his 1938 boxing match with “Hitler’s German,” Max Schmeling. Realistic oil paintings add drama and extend the story of this symbolic event that occurred on the eve of America’s involvement in World War II.
Author: Matt de la Peña

Title: Nature Art With Chiura Obata
Annotation: Learning about nature through the eyes of an artist is the premise of this book. Chiura Obata came to California from Japan as a young man to continue his painting career. His paintings of Yosemite became his signature work during the twentieth century. Obata was an art instructor at U.C. Berkeley until he and his family were interned for three years at Tanforan and Topaz during World War II. Obata also sketched and painted many interpretations of life in the internment camps. This book is a fine integration of nature, history, and art. Art projects and sidebars on natural history are interspersed throughout the book. Important dates, a bibliography, and an index are included. California author.
Author: Michael Elsohn Ross
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, Science

Title: Nature in the Neighborhood
Annotation: Using detailed and colorful pen-and-ink drawings to model a naturalist's notebook, the author/illustrator focuses on a small ecosystem, in a single neighborhood in an unnamed North American city. The plants and animals found in the ecosystem are described in detail and such concepts as habitat are explained. This is a useful resource for nature study or community units.
Author: Gordon Morrison

Title: Nature's Paintbrush: The Patterns and Colors Around You
Annotation: Nature's camouflage is revealed through clever text and strong visuals. The author explores ways in which patterns and colors are helpful to living things within their habitat. The artwork of defined forms and bright colors encourages children to observe, think about, and enjoy colors and patterns in the natural world.
Author: Susan Stockdale

Title: Navajo Long Walk: The Tragic Story of a Proud People’s Forced March from Their Homeland
Annotation: Illustrations and simple text chronicle the forced march of thousands of Navajos from their homeland to the Bosque Redondo Reservation in January 1864. The Navajos were forced to leave their homeland and walk 470 miles to a place that was ill-suited for survival. Navajo artist Shonto Begay’s captions and his thoughtful, dynamic paintings help tell the story from the point of view of the people who survived the brutal walk. Includes reproductions of acrylic paintings and sepia-tone watercolor portraits.
Author: Joseph Bruchac

Title: Negro Speaks of Rivers, The
Annotation: Presents Langston Hughes’ classic poem, which captures the strength and courage of the African American people. Written during the Harlem Renaissance, the poem is a favorite in American culture. Each line of the poem is presented with a realistic landscape illustrated with watercolor paint. The artwork makes the verses more accessible and provides a visual interpretation of Hughes’ timeless piece.
Author: Langston Hughes
Discipline: English-Language Arts/General , English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Neighborhood Sharks: Hunting with the Great Whites of California's Farallon Islands
Annotation: This book offers illustrations and descriptions of the great white sharks who feed on the pinniped colony of the protected Farallon Islands thirty miles from San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge. The sharks are ready to feast on the young elephant seals and sea lions that populate the shores of these islands every fall when the adults come to breed and give birth.
Author: Katherine Roy

Title: Neil Armstrong Is My Uncle: And Other Lies Muscle Man McGinty Told Me
Annotation: Ten-year old Tamara Simpson is not having a good summer. Her best friend Kebsie moved away, and a new foster child has moved into the house where Kebsie used to live. Set against the backdrop of the Vietnam War and the 1969 moon landing, this story has Tamara on a personal mission to prove to everyone that the new boy is a liar. The story is told with wit and a light touch that does not minimize the sorrows Tamara faces.
Author: Nan Marino
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures, War

Title: Neo Leo: The Ageless Ideas of Leonardo da Vinci
Annotation: Vivid cartoon-style illustrations depict the modern inventions of da Vinci, including the hang glider, contact lenses, the tank, and robots inspired by his thinking. Includes re-creations of his notes and original sketches of the elderly da Vinci observing the world around him or testing his own theories. His notes are printed in reverse, and an author’s note explains how a mirror can be used to view the inventor’s writing style. The emphasis on da Vinci’s notes can be used to introduce scientific journaling to students as they emulate the process of observation and invention.
Author: Gene Barretta
Topic: Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Visual Arts

Title: Nettie's Trip South
Annotation: In a letter written by ten-year-old Nettie to Addie, her Northern friend, Nettie reflects on her journey South, including the witnessing of a slave auction and the inhuman treatment of the slaves. Pencil sketches document the realities and emotional intensity of the pre-Civil War South. See other titles by this author, KATIE'S TRUNK and RED FLOWER GOES WEST.
Author: Ann Warren Turner

Title: Never Forgotten
Annotation: Details the experiences of a West African boy from the Mende tribe who was kidnapped, sent across the sea, and sold into slavery. This powerful story of a widowed father who loses his beloved son is written in verse and illustrated with thickly outlined acrylic-and-watercolor artwork. Conveys themes of family, memory, and freedom. Human rights violations and emotional intensity are depicted. Includes an author’s note. Coretta Scott King Author Honor (2012); ALA Notable Children’s Book (2012); Notable Book for a Global Society (2012).
Author: Patricia C. McKissack
Topic: American History, Diversity, Global Social Issues

Title: Never Smile at a Monkey: And 17 Other Important Things to Remember
Annotation: Using alliteration, Jenkins warns the reader what not to do with 17 different animals, such as “never poach a puffer fish” and “never clutch a cane toad.” Each warning comes with an explanation and is accompanied by a vibrant collage. Further information about each animal is provided at the end. An engaging look at some interesting animal behavior.
Author: Steve Jenkins
Discipline: English-Language Arts/General , English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, Science

Title: New Dinos: The Latest Finds! The Coolest Dinosaur Discoveries!
Annotation: The author relates information about new dinosaur discoveries in the Sahara, Madagascar, China, and Patagonia. She discusses eggs, dung, feathers, and physiology. Includes a bibliography and an index.
Author: Shelley Tanaka

Title: New Kid on the Block
Annotation: This group of more than 100 humorous poems for young people varies in subject and includes jellyfish stew and a wolf at the laundromat. Lively pen-and-ink sketches illustrate the zany poems.
Author: Jack Prelutsky

Title: New Way Things Work, The
Annotation: Text and numerous detailed illustrations in this edition introduce and explain the scientific principles and workings of hundreds of machines and present new material about digital technology. The book includes humorous details and small cartoons to increase its appeal and provide access to an enormous amount of information that would otherwise overwhelm readers. This selection can be linked to the science curriculum.
Author: David Macaulay, Neil Ardley

Title: Next Stop, Neptune: Experiencing the Solar System
Annotation: In this tour of the solar system, the reader learns many amazing facts about asteroids, moons, planets, comets, and the sun. The text is succinct, with many illustrations and sidebars that enhance the information presented. Many of the collage illustrations seem three-dimensional. A discussion of size and relative size makes this book a supplemental source for mathematics. A bibliography is included.
Author: Alvin Jenkins
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, Mathematics, Science

Title: Nic Bishop Butterflies and Moths
Annotation: This large-format book features outstanding color photographs and engaging, informative text. It discusses the distinctions between butterflies and moths, their habits, habitats, life cycles, senses, and defenses against predators. Each full-page or double-page photo is accompanied by short paragraphs. A caption identifies the species shown and ends with a 5X magnification of the image. A brief glossary and illustrated author’s notes are included.
Author: Nic Bishop

Title: Nic Bishop Lizards
Annotation: Introduces young readers to the life cycle, appearance, habitat, survival skills, and diversity of lizards. These amazing reptiles are presented with simple, engaging text, interesting facts, and full-page and double-page color photographs. The book includes actual-size and magnified photos. It concludes with a reading list, glossary, and author’s note. ALA Notable Children’s Book (2011); NSTA Outstanding Science Trade Book (2011).
Author: Nic Bishop

Title: Nic Bishop Spiders
Annotation: This well-written and informative book will appeal to a wide audience. It is accompanied by outstanding photographs that are crisp, colorful, and show amazing details. Most notable is a four-page spread of a jumping spider in midflight. Other photos show a spider molting, eating an insect, and wrapping a wasp caught in a web. An ALA Notable Children’s Book (2008).
Author: Nic Bishop

Title: Night Boat to Freedom
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Christmas John risks his life to ferry runaway slaves from Kentucky to Ohio over a period of four years—until it becomes too dangerous for him to stay in Kentucky. Color, fabric, quilts, and art are integral parts of the story. The illustrations add to the narrative and are worthy of close study on their own. This picture book is appropriate for many grade levels and can be used to introduce units on slavery in American history, character traits, the Underground Railroad, and art appreciation.
Author: Margot Theis Raven
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: HSS 2.5, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, HSS 8.9, HSS 8.10

Title: Night Crossing, The
Annotation: In this brief book set in 1938, Clara and her family escape Nazi persecution by fleeing from Austria to Switzerland. Fear is seen through the eyes of a child.
Author: Karen Ackerman

Title: Night Fairy
Annotation: Flory, a young night fairy no taller than an acorn, has lost her wings and can no longer fly. She discovers that the world is very big and very dangerous. Flory’s character is well developed, her wit and bravery evident, and her magic spells explored. Detailed full-color illustrations in each short chapter, drawn to scale, reveal just how small Flory really is compared with the animals around her. A good read-aloud choice.
Author: Laura Amy Schlitz

Title: Night Flight: Amelia Earhart Crosses the Atlantic
Annotation: In the calm of the night, Amelia Earhart, a legendary woman pilot, reflects on “her first-time things” while on a 1932 solo flight from Newfoundland to Ireland. At midnight, danger lurks, and the drama of the journey is captured in the suspense-filled yet poetic text, which is accompanied by stunning gouache-and-watercolor illustrations. An afterword and endpapers provide additional biographical information.
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
Author: Robert Burleigh
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Global Historical Events and Figures, Women’s Studies
Standard: HSS K.6, HSS 1.4, HSS 2.1, HSS 2.5, HSS 3.4

Title: Night Has Ears
Annotation: This collection features 26 proverbs, some serious and some humorous, from a variety of African tribes. Bright illustrations evoke the details of each proverb.
Author: Ashley Bryan (editor)

Title: Night Journeys
Annotation: A suspenseful historical adventure that takes place in pre-Revolutionary Philadelphia. Twelve-year-old Peter York was adopted by a strict Quaker family and now must decide whether to help capture two runaway indentured servants and collect a reward or help them to freedom and perhaps escape with them. As he makes his decision, Peter gains insights into his own character and that of his guardian.
Author: Avi

Title: Night of the Twisters
Annotation: In 1980, a series of devastating tornados stormed through portions of Nebraska. This is the story of a fictional character, Dan Hatch, and his friend who survive the tornados and the aftermath of the storms. This engaging story is a good choice for reluctant readers and for literature circles.
Author: Ivy Ruckman
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Statistics, Data Analysis, & Probability

Title: Night Rainbow, The
Annotation: The Northern Lights are described in free verse in this dramatically illustrated book. Ancient legends of Northern cultures explain how they understand what the lights are and why they show up. Factual material about the aurora is found at the end of the book for more detail about this phenomenon.
Author: Barbara Juster Esbensen

Title: Night Running: How James Escaped with the Help of His Faithful Dog
Annotation: James, a young slave on Master Graham’s farm, makes a daring escape to freedom with the help of his faithful hunting dog, Zeus. Although James thinks Zeus will doom his attempt to escape, Zeus saves the boy’s life several times. Based on the true story of James Smith’s journey from Virginia to Ohio in the mid-1800s. Full-page illustrations, done in an impressionistic style, enhance the story.
Author: Elisa Carbone

Title: Nights of the Pufflings
Annotation: On the island of Heimaey, Iceland, children work to rescue puffin offspring by helping them take their first flight. The children rescue the pufflings who crash land in their town and release them on the beach. The crystal-clear color photographs are enhanced by clearly-written text to showcase these children making a difference in their natural environment.
Author: Bruce McMillan

Title: Nihancan’s Feast of Beaver: Animal Tales of the North American Indians
Annotation: A collection of animal myths from 36 Native American tribes dealing with the origin of life and light. The stories feature trickster animals. Each story begins with a map showing the region of the featured tribe. These are short reads that range from a few paragraphs to two pages.
Author: Edward Lavitt, Robert E. McDowell

Title: Nim and the War Effort
Annotation: Nim, a little Chinese American girl growing up in San Francisco's Chinatown during World War II, collects newspapers to help the war effort. Her rival in this business is Garland Stephenson, who claims that since this is a war effort, only Americans can collect newspapers. Nim sets out to prove to Garland that she is an American - just like him! But Nim must come to terms with her grandfather, who lives by the old ways. The story is based on an experience in the author's life. California author and setting.
Author: Milly Lee

Title: Nine Animals and the Well
Annotation: The reader learns that the nine number signs and the zero came from the Europeans, who got them from the North Africans, who got them from the Arabs, who got them from India. Nine animal friends each want to bring the perfect gift to the raja-king's birthday party but end up taking only their friendship.
Author: James Rumford

Title: Nine Candles
Annotation: Raymond's mother "made a mistake" and "was wrong to take that money," but he still loves her and looks forward to their weekly visits at the correctional facility. He nervously hopes that she'll remember his seventh birthday and longs for the day when his cake will have nine candles and his mama will be free to come home. Appended author's note discusses how to be supportive of young people whose parents are incarcerated. California illustrator.
Author: Maria Testa
