Title: Nine for California
Annotation: Amanda travels by stagecoach from Missouri to California with her four siblings and mother to join her father during the Gold Rush. Maps of the journey are in the end papers. Other titles in the series include BOOM TOWN and TAKING CHARGE. This selection is useful for lessons in California history in fourth grade. California author and setting.
Author: Sonia Levitin

Title: Nino cuervo (Crow Boy)
Annotation: Chibbi is an outcast in the school. The shy little boy from the Japanese hillside is ignored by his classmates until suddenly, and almost too late, a new teacher shows them that Crow Boy has much to offer. The text is expressive, and the illustrations are distinctive.
Author: Taro Yashima

Title: No Monkeys, No Chocolate
Annotation: What does a capuchin monkey have in common with a pollen-sucking midge, an aphid-munching anole lizard, and brain-eating coffin fly maggots? Chocolate! Our favorite dessert comes from cocoa beans, which grow on cocoa trees in tropical rain forests. And those trees couldn’t survive without help from a menagerie of rain forest critters. This book tells their story.
Author: Allen Young, Melissa Stewart
Topic: Life Science (Biology), World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: No More Dead Dogs
Annotation: Eighth-grade football hero Wallace Wallace is sentenced to detention attending rehearsals of the school play. In spite of himself, he becomes wrapped up in the production and begins to suggest changes that improve not only the play but his life as well.
Author: Gordon Korman

Title: No Talking
Annotation: The rowdy fourth-grade boys challenge the equally loud fourth-grade girls to a two-day “No Talking” contest inspired by Gandhi’s practice of being silent one day per week. The rules allow students to answer their teachers’ questions with responses of only three words, but they may not speak after school is dismissed. When the students continue with their silent ways, the principal demands that they resume their normal behavior. Illustrated with occasional black-and-white drawings.
Author: Andrew Clements

Title: No!
Annotation: A young boy witnesses many forms of bullying as he attempts to take a letter to the mailbox. This is a nearly wordless story using only the word “no.” Powerful images convey a message against bullying and support taking a stand and speaking out. Illustrated with watercolor artwork that is enhanced with cross-hatching.
Author: David McPhail
Topic: Global Social Issues, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, War
Discipline: History/Social Science, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Noah Webster and His Words
Annotation: Noah Webster was a Connecticut farm boy who was more interested in books and words than in growing things on his father's land. Over his lifetime (1758-1843) he standardized American spelling through the publication of his spelling book Webster's American Dictionary.
Author: Jeri Ferris
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Discipline: English-Language Arts/General , English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Noah's Ark
Annotation: This book retells the biblical story of the great flood and how Noah and his family faithfully responded to God's call to save life on the Earth. Spectacular pencil-and-watercolor illustrations bring detail of the crowds of animals and of the drowned Earth.
Author: Jerry Pinkney

Title: Nobody Gonna Turn Me ’Round: Stories and Songs of the Civil Rights Movement
Annotation: The final book of a trilogy, this work offers a moving portrayal of the experiences of African Americans from the time of the 1955 Montgomery bus boycott to the Voting Rights Act in July 1965. Events from the summer of 1955 are central to the stories: Moses Wright braved danger to testify against three white men accused of murdering Emmett Till. The book includes double-page-spread illustrations, source notes, a bibliography, recommended further readings, and an index. The first two books in the trilogy are NO MORE! (2002) and FREE AT LAST (2004).
Author: Doreen Rappaport

Title: Nobody Owns the Sky: The Story of "Brave Bessie" Coleman
Annotation: This inspirational story, told in rhyme, is about the first African American woman aviator, Bessie Coleman. She began to dream of flying as a child in the cotton fields of Texas and, despite many obstacles, never lost sight of her goal. The book could be useful in lessons about women's studies and African American history.
Author: Reeve Lindbergh

Title: Noche de Humo (Smoky Night)
Annotation: When the Los Angeles riots break out in the streets of their neighborhood, a young boy and his mother learn the value of getting along with others no matter what their background or ethnicity. California author, illustrator, and setting. Also available in English.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: Noisy Paint Box, The: The Colors and Sounds of Kandinsky's Abstract Art
Annotation: This is the story of Vasily Kandinsky, one of the very first painters of abstract art. Throughout his life, Kandinsky experienced colors as sounds, and sounds as colors—and bold, groundbreaking works burst forth from his noisy paint box.
Author: Barb Rosenstock
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: North: The Amazing Story of Arctic Migration
Annotation: Introduces the wide variety of animals that migrate to the Arctic for the summer months. The arrival of spring brings animals from every corner of the earth; they raise their young and feed on the abundant Arctic tundra in sunlight that lasts all summer. As winter returns, animals leave, but they return the following year. Oversized pages are filled with watercolor and pen-and-pencil illustrations that capture the Arctic winter, the tundra in midsummer, and the groups of migrating animals.
Author: Nick Dowson

Title: Nothing but Trouble: The Story of Althea Gibson
Annotation: This picture-book biography explores the life and achievements of Althea Gibson, the first African American woman to win the Wimbledon tennis championship—the oldest tennis tournament in the world. Raised in Harlem, Althea had a reputation for making trouble, but she knew she would become an important person someday. The book’s illustrations were created using a combination of digital imaging and acrylic painting. Includes an author’s note and a chronology of Gibson’s life.
Author: Sue Stauffacher
Topic: American History, Diversity, Ethnic Studies, Physical Fitness, Women’s Studies

Title: Nothing Here but Stones
Annotation: In 1882, eleven-year-old Emma and her family leave Tsarist Russia and terrifying discrimination to start a new life in the American West. They take the train to their new home in the mountains of Colorado, only to find extreme hardships and heartbreak. Emma is resilient, and the novel concludes with hope. The story is based on actual struggles experienced by Jewish immigrants to the West in the nineteenth century.
Author: Nancy Oswald

Title: Now You See It, Now You Don't: The Amazing World of Optical Illusions
Annotation: Optical illusions are clearly explained and illustrated with clear and effective drawings. Along with the explanations of why we see them, there are suggestions for creating illusions.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Ntuj Tsim Huabtais Liab (The Making of Monkey King)
Annotation: Bursting forth from a rock on Flower Fruit Mountain, the mythical Chinese Monkey King is born. The story tells of his 20-year apprenticeship with a magical immortal and his defeat of the demon of Chaos. Watercolor illustrations are highlighted with black ink. Connects to the history/social science curriculum for the sixth grade. The text is in English and Hmong. Regional dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text.
Author: Robert Kraus

Title: Nubs: The True Story of a Mutt, a Marine and a Miracle
Annotation: This is a story of a wild dog who befriended Marine Major Brian Dennis in Iraq, and who, when they were separated, trekked seventy miles through the desert winter to rejoin his friend.
Author: Brian Dennis, Kirby Larson, Mary Nethery
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Nugget on the Flight Deck
Annotation: Life on an aircraft carrier is the focus of this story, in which the “nugget”—the new man aboard ship—is given a complete tour of a massive aircraft carrier. Along the way, he learns the nicknames, color codes, and radio calls that allow an aircraft carrier to run efficiently. Recommended for children who are interested in flight, boats, the military, jets, and history. The book features bright, colored-pencil illustrations. California author.
Author: Patricia Newman
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: Number Devil: A Mathematical Adventure, The
Annotation: Annoyed with his math teacher who assigns word problems and won't let him use a calculator, twelve-year-old Robert finds help from the number devil in his dreams. The author presents the great beauty and patterns of numbers through humor when introducing basic and complex mathematical ideas. The reader also learns about the achievements of celebrated mathematicians through the ages. Excerpts could be read aloud.
Author: Hans Magnus Enzensberger
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Mathematical Analysis, Mathematical Reasoning, Number Sense
Standard: Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.NF.1-7, Math 6.RP.1-3, Math 6.NS.1-8, Math 6.EE.1-9, Math 7.RP.1-3, Math 7.NS.1-5, Math 7.EE.1-6, Math HS.NQ, Math HS.Functions

Title: Number Stories of Long Ago
Annotation: This book contains ten short stories on topics such as place value, addition, multiplication, division, fractions, and square and cube roots. The first eight are narrative stories. The last two chapters contain math puzzles and riddles that deal with fractions, exponents, rules for divisibility, and number sense concepts with the solutions explained.
Publisher: National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
Author: David Eugene Smith
Standard: Math NS 3.2, Math NS 4.3, Math NS 5.2, Math NS 6.2, Math NS 7.2

Title: Number the Stars
Annotation: In 1943, during the German occupation of Denmark, ten-year-old Annemarie learns how to be courageous when she helps to shelter her Jewish friend from the Nazis. Readers will feel the tension and danger as the Danes help their Jewish friends escape to safety.
Author: Lois Lowry

Title: Nutik, the Wolf Pup
Annotation: This book is an illustrated story about Amaroq, brother to Julie of the Wolves. He raises a wolf pup but must return the pup to its family when it is grown. In the end, however, the pup returns to join the human family of Amaroq and Julie. The illustrations depict the Artic world.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: Nyu Wa Mended the Sky
Annotation: This illustrated book retells the famous, classical Chinese myth written in traditional Chinese.
Author: Hui Fen Pan, Xiu Ling Zhan

Title: O Beautiful for Spacious Skies
Annotation: The nineteenth-century poem, later set to music and sung by schoolchildren throughout the United States, is presented with bold, contemporary paintings rendered by noted California artist Wayne Thiebaud. The book is currently out of print.
Author: Katharine Lee Bates, Sara Jane Bogers (editor)
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: O, Say Can You See? America’s Symbols, Landmarks, and Inspiring Words
Annotation: Tells the stories behind places, documents, holidays, and other important symbols of importance to America. Most topics are covered in double-page spreads with basic information and interesting trivia. The book features bright, colored-pencil illustrations and concludes with a page devoted to remembering September 11, 2011. An excellent choice for elementary units on civics.
Author: Sheila Keenan

Title: Oak Tree
Annotation: A year in the life of a grand oak tree is depicted through detailed pencil and watercolor paintings, expressive text, and explanatory margin notes. The ecology of the tree as a host for a number of small creatures is explained.
Author: Gordon Morrison

Title: Ocean Sunlight: How Tiny Plants Feed the Seas
Annotation: From tiny aquatic plants to the biggest whale or fish, this book tells the story of the living picture of the life cycle and food chain deep within our wondrous oceans.
Author: Molly Bang, Penny Chisholm

Title: Oceans
Annotation: Simon explores the importance of the oceans and their impact on the Earth's climate. He includes high-quality black-and-white diagrams of how tides work and how waves form and transfer energy. This is one of a series of science books by this author. The 2006 2nd edition has been revised and updated.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Oculto bajo el agua (Hidden Underwater)
Annotation: This book describes animals living in fresh and salt water environments. The informative text describes their habitats and the full-color photographs support the information. See other books in the Mundos Secretos (Secret Worlds) series.
Author: Kim Taylor

Title: Odd Boy Out: Young Albert Einstein
Annotation: In this picture-book biography, Albert Einstein's early life is presented, revealing a child who was a misfit among his childhood peers and one whom teachers thought might be "dull-witted." While not a sociable child, he was a brilliant problem solver who grew up to be one of the great thinkers of all time. The whimsical pen-and-ink and watercolor-on-watercolor illustrations are enhanced with digital renderings.
Author: Don Brown

Title: Oddhopper Opera: A Bug's Garden of Verses
Annotation: This collection of poems depict the web of life at ground-level in a vegetable garden. The poems highlight the activities of the insects and animals that live there. The strong artwork is clever and enriches the whimsical text that develops the concepts of biodiversity and interdependence.
Author: Kurt Cyrus

Title: Odetta: The Queen of Folk
Annotation: Paintings done in a folk-art style are paired with lyrical text to introduce young readers to Odetta, the famous American folk singer. The biography describes Odetta’s childhood in Alabama, which was impacted by Jim Crow laws; her family’s eventual move to Los Angeles; her involvement in the civil rights movement; and her significant influence on folk music. Much of the information is based on the author’s friendship and personal conversations with Odetta. The book includes an author’s note and a list of recommended recordings.
Author: Stephen Alcorn
Topic: American History, Visual Arts, Women’s Studies

Title: Oh, Rats! The Story of Rats and People
Annotation: The author provides well-presented information about rats that includes their history, their interaction with humans, their behavior, and an explanation of how they continue to survive. This book illustrated with handsome black-and-white scratchboard illustrations with red highlights. Sidebars provide additional interesting facts.
Author: Albert Marrin

Title: Oil Spill! Disaster in the Gulf of Mexico
Annotation: Documents the enormous disaster that occurred in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010 when British Petroleum’s Deepwater Horizon oil rig exploded. The book describes the frustrating attempts to stop the flow of oil, along with the eventual success. Includes information on the cleanup efforts and offers suggestions for the prevention of future spills. Illustrated with powerful full-color photographs.
Author: Elaine Landau
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Life Science (Biology)

Title: Old Elm Speaks: Tree Poems
Annotation: Original tree poems full of imagery and description are complemented by rich, warm oil painting illustrations. This volume forgoes humor to focus on poetry, including free verse, rhyme, and haiku. California author.
Author: Kristine O'Connell George
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: Old Jake's Skirts
Annotation: Old Jake, the reclusive bachelor farmer, has his life changed forever when he finds a trunkful of colorful calico skirts and discovers their practical and psychological value. Folksy, expressive oil paintings include humorous details and illustrate Jake's transformation from loner to semi-social man-about-town. Authentic country dialect makes this a fun read-aloud choice.
Author: Cynthia Anne Scott

Title: Old Man Mad About Drawing: A Tale of Hokusai, The
Annotation: Tojiro, a young seller of rice cakes in the Japanese capital of Edo, later known as Tokyo, is amazed to discover that the grumpy and shabby old man who buys his cakes is a famous artist renowned for his sketches, prints, and paintings of flowers, animals, and landscapes. The tale is illustrated with reproductions of Hokusai’s drawings.
Author: Francois Place
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Visual Arts

Title: Old Yeller
Annotation: The emotional story of the relationship of Travis with his dog, Old Yeller, is set in the Texas hill country in the late 1860s. The novel focuses on the dog's devotion to its duty and its master and on Travis's heartbreaking realization that he must kill Yeller when the dog becomes rabid. The language in the story reflects the times.
Author: Fred Gipson

Title: Ole! Flamenco
Annotation: Flamenco is an art form that encompasses dancing, singing, and guitar playing and is practiced across the United States and throughout the world. This photoessay focuses on a group of young people who are learning flamenco in New Mexico. Includes full-color photographs; a map that traces the art form’s origins from the musical traditions of Indian, Arab, and North African cultures; a glossary; and a bibliography. This is a useful introduction to a multicultural art form.
Author: George Ancona
Topic: Dance, Diversity, Motor Skills/Movement Patterns, Music, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: On Earth
Annotation: The motions of the earth and their connections to time, such as the year, the seasons, and the day are presented. The text alternates between personal and technical descriptions. The artistic illustrations of the earth and its cycles introduces readers to diagrams offering concrete images that show what happens as day turns into night, as seasons change, and as the earth rotates.
Author: G. Brian Karas

Title: On My Honor
Annotation: On a dare, two twelve-year-old boys swim in a forbidden river. When Tony drowns, Joel doesn't know how to tell the parents how their disobedience led to the tragedy.
Author: Marion Dane Bauer

Title: On My Way
Annotation: In the third book of the autobiographical “23 Fairmount Avenue” series, author Tomie dePaola shares stories from 1940, when he was five years old. His baby sister comes home from the hospital; he learns to read; he participates in a dance recital; and he goes to the World’s Fair. The story is told in a casual, appealing tone with black-and-white drawings that add an element of warmth. The series consists of seven titles.
Author: Tomie dePaola

Title: On the Day You Were Born
Annotation: Short descriptions of some of the natural phenomena of Earth are included in this read-aloud book. Each item is described in the context of welcoming a new person into the world. The last part of the book provides text-dense information on animal migration, Earth's rotation, gravity, the sun, the moon, stars, tides, rain, photosynthesis, atmosphere, and skin color.
Author: Debra Frasier

Title: On the Wing: American Birds in Migration
Annotation: This book explains why birds migrate and looks at the migration patterns of birds in North and South America. The text is balanced with the addition of finely detailed paintings and migration route maps, and shows a link between the environment and the effect it has on migration patterns.
Author: Carol Lerner

Title: On the Wings of Heroes
Annotation: A boy in Illinois remembers the years of World War II on the home front, especially his two heroes: his brother in the Air Force and his father, who fought in the previous war. This is not only a story of life in America during the 1940s, but also a story of friendship, family, and humorous anecdotes that make Richard Peck’s novels perfect for reading aloud.
Author: Richard Peck

Title: Once a Wolf: How Wildlife Biologists Fought to Bring Back the Gray Wolf
Annotation: This book presents the troubled relationship between man and wolf, including biologists' efforts to dispel misunderstandings about wolves as they are reintroduced to wilderness areas. It includes wolf legends and quotes from children's literature, and introduces the scientists who have studied wolves over the years to find their place in the ecosystem, particularly in Yellowstone National Park. Black-and-white and color photographs on every page support the text. A bibliography and index are appended. See other books in the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Stephen R. Swinburne

Title: Once in Vietnam
Annotation: This collection of six Vietnamese folktales weaves hardships with magic and problem solving.
Author: - Unknown

Title: Once There Was a Tree
Annotation: This is the story about an old stump that attracts many living creatures, even man, and when it is gone, a new tree attracts the same creatures, who need it for a variety of reasons. The delicately detailed illustrations are compelling and lend substance to the story of the cycle of life.
Author: Natalia Ramanova

Title: Once Upon a Dime: A Math Adventure
Annotation: Money really does grow on trees, and surprisingly enough, it depends on the fertilizer! Readers have the opportunity to calculate various amounts of money produced by the tree.
Author: Nancy Kelly Allen

Title: Once Upon a Starry Night: A Book of Constellations
Annotation: In sparkling text and illustrations, this title offers brief introductions to ten constellations and the mythology associated with them. Endpapers offer diagrams of the northern and southern skies. The final two pages offer information about the stars, nebulae, galaxies, and constellations and give astronomical descriptions of the constellations featured.
Author: Jacqueline Mitton

Title: One Candle
Annotation: Grandma and Aunt Rose retell the story of the risks they took to celebrate Hanukkah in a German concentration camp, hoping to pass on the value of keeping their religious traditions alive. Illustrated with sepia-tone artwork that resembles photographs. This story is appropriate for young children and allows for thoughtful discussion of religious tolerance and the Holocaust. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting
Classification: Picture Book, Read Aloud, Struggling Reader

Title: One Day in the Tropical Rain Forest
Annotation: An indigenous boy and a naturalist search for an unnamed species of butterfly during one day in the Venezuelan rain forest. If it is found, the forest will be saved from destruction by a wealthy industrialist. Many creatures are introduced and illustrated with soft, black-and-white pencil drawings. This is a well-written introduction to the ecology of the endangered rain forest.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: One Giant Leap: The Story of Neil Armstrong
Annotation: The first part of this picture-book biography relates the childhood dreams and experiences of Neil Armstrong and highlights how he was hooked on aeronautics at an early age. The second half relates his historic moon flight. Pen-and-ink illustrations highlighted with watercolor accent this simple, yet informative text.
Author: Don Brown

Title: One Good Apple: Growing Our Food for the Sake of Our Earth
Annotation: The use of pesticides in the past and present and the affect on the food web is discussed along with information on the benefits of organic farming. Full-color photographs enrich the clearly-written text. Comprehensive information provides extensive background and includes suggested activities to help grow good food for the sake of Earth.
Author: Catherine Paladino

Title: One Grain of Rice: A Mathematical Folktale
Annotation: This mathematical folktale links the cultural traditions and atmosphere of India through gold-leaf illustrations. These illustrations enrich the story of a clever young girl who outsmarts a very selfish Raja and saves her village from starving with a simple grain of rice.
Author: - Demi
Standard: Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.OA.1-3, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.MD.1-5, Math 5.MP.1-8, Math 6.NS.1-8, Math 6.EE.1-9, Math 6.MP.1-8

Title: One Green Apple
Annotation: The topic of contemporary immigration is handled in a sensitive, age-appropriate fashion. On just her second day of school, a young Arab girl joins her class on a trip to an apple orchard. The selection of apples for the cider press (hers is the only green one) serves as a metaphor for the blending of peoples from different cultures. The watercolor illustrations by Ted Lewin are full of light and emotion, extending this timely story. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: One Hen: How One Small Loan Made a Big Difference
Annotation: This picture book tells the story of Kojo, a boy from Ghana who turns a small loan from his mother into a thriving business. The book was inspired by the story of Kwabena Darko, who began his poultry farm with a small loan. It is now the largest poultry farm in East Africa. The book explains the microloan system and presents ways in which readers can become involved.
Author: Katie Smith Milway
Topic: Economics, Global Social Issues, Lifestyles Around the World, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: One Hundred Hungry Ants
Annotation: One hundred hungry ants march off to a picnic. The littlest ant suggests that marching single file is much too slow so they reorganize themselves into two rows of 50, then four rows of 20, etc. The artwork looks like linoleum cuts and features comical facial expressions on the ants. This lively rhyming tale provides an informal introduction to multiplication and division.
Author: Elinor J. Pinczes
Standard: Math K.CC.1-7, Math K.NBT.1, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 4.OA.1-5

Title: One Leaf Rides the Wind: Counting in a Japanese Garden
Annotation: A young girl makes her way slowly through a Japanese garden where she spots one leaf, two carved temple dogs, and three miniature bonsai. This counting book with haiku poetry introduces the youngest readers to the beauty of a Japanese garden and to haiku. Lush watercolor illustrations enhance the ten haiku poems. The book can be used as a writing model of poetry for students up to middle school. California author.
Author: Celeste Davidson Mannis
Classification: Counting Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: One Potato, Two Potato
Annotation: Mr. and Mrs. O'Grady are a very poor, humble couple, living so simple a life that they share everything. Mr. O'Grady discovers a pot with magical powers buried under the very last potato in the garden. The pot makes a copy of anything dropped into it and when Mrs. O'Grady trips and falls into the pot, things get very complicated! This story can be used for introducing number patterns.
Author: Cynthia DeFelice

Title: One Riddle, One Answer
Annotation: A sultan's daughter who loves numbers and riddles devises a mathematical riddle to be answered by the man she would marry. The riddle involves place value, fractions, and multiplication. Persian motifs and patterns are incorporated into the lush acrylic paintings that illustrate this original tale.
Author: Lauren Thompson
Standard: Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 3.NF.1-3, Math 3.MP.1-8, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.NF.1-7, Math 5.MP.1-8

Title: One Small Place by the Sea
Annotation: The child visitor observes the cycle of change with the tide pool habitat, a small place at the edge of the sea that is home to many plants and animals. Brenner's prose shows how life flourishes in the tide pool and the interconnectedness of each of the creatures and plants there. Leonard's brightly colored illustrations are realistic, scientific, and dramatic. A companion title is ONE SMALL PLACE IN A TREE.
Author: Barbara Brenner

Title: One Small Square Backyard
Annotation: This book explains how to observe and explore plants, animals, and their interactions in one's own backyard. Detailed, colored illustrations enhance the text. Topics include adaptations, diverse organisms, food chains, and decomposition. Also discusses how plants use the sun's energy. Other titles in the One Small Square series are CAVE, POND, AFRICAN SAVANNA, and ARCTIC TUNDRA.
Author: Donald M. Silver
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: One Small Square: The Night Sky
Annotation: This series focuses on one small square of a variety of habitats. In this one about the night sky, facts about stars, planets, nebulae, comets, meteors, the moon, constellations, and classic myths are presented. Full-color illustrations, rich with detail highlight the text. Other titles in the One Small Square series include AFRICAN SAVANNA, ARCTIC TUNDRA, CACTUS DESERT, CAVE, CORAL REEF, POND, SEASHORE, SWAMP, TROPICAL RAIN FOREST, and WOODS.
Author: Donald M. Silver

Title: One World, One Day
Annotation: This book presents daily routines that all children will recognize, no matter where they live—such as washing, eating, attending school, and doing chores. Bright, color photographs of children engaged in these activities appear side by side, inviting a comparison and showing that we all have much in common no matter where we live. Concludes with notes that identify all the locations and the cultural contexts of the images. Also includes some perspectives from the photographer. A National Council for Social Studies Trade Book (2010).
Author: Barbara Kerley
Topic: Diversity, Ethnic Studies, Lifestyles Around the World

Title: One Yellow Daffodil: A Hanukkah Story
Annotation: A florist has not celebrated Hanukkah since he was a boy in Poland, but two children help him rediscover the joys of the holiday.
Author: David A. Adler

Title: Only a Toad
Annotation: A toad, dissatisfied with his lot in life, ventures out into the world and discovers that being a toad is not so bad after all. The book is presented in English with a Hmong translation. Black-and-white drawings highlight the text. Regional and dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text. Available in paperback.
Author: Brian Marchant, Heather Marchant

Title: Only Passing Through: The Story of Sojourner Truth
Annotation: This is an inspiring story of how an African American woman, born a slave with no status or dignity, transformed herself into one of the most powerful voices of the abolitionist movement. Compelling full-page paintings use intense colors in some cases and at other times use subdued earth tones.
Author: Anne Rockwell
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements

Title: Onward: A Photobiography of African-American Polar Explorer Matthew Henson
Annotation: African American Matthew Henson traveled with Robert Peary on his many attempted expeditions to be the first to reach the North Pole. It was Henson's ability to speak Inuit and the survival skills he learned from the native people that saved the expeditions many times. When the final expedition of 1909 succeeded, Henson received none of the credit other than having been Peary's assistant. In 1944, at the age of 77, he finally received an award from Congress and the recognition he so richly deserved. Archival photographs will fascinate students as they read the story of Polar explorer Matthew Henson.
Author: Dolores Johnson

Title: Opera Cat
Annotation: Madame SoSo, the famous opera star, has come down with laryngitis just before her performance. She is astonished when her cat Alma stands up and begins to sing with a voice like an angel’s. Alma is wrapped in Madame’s immense tower of curls and sings for her, saving the day. Illustrated with watercolor artwork.
Author: Tess Weaver

Title: Orange Shoes, The
Annotation: Delly Porter enjoys the feel of soft dirt beneath her feet as she walks to and from school. But after a classmate makes her feel ashamed of having no shoes, her father buys her a lovely orange pair to wear to the Shoebox Social. When Delly wears the shoes to school, the other children step on and soil them. Resourceful Delly paints both the shoes and the shoebox for the Social and earns the most money while wearing her “new” painted shoes.
Author: Trinka Hakes Noble
Topic: Lifestyles Around the World, Visual Arts

Title: Orani, My Father’s Village
Annotation: The author presents an illustrated memoir of summers spent in her father’s childhood village of Orani, which is on the island of Sardinia, Italy. The village of the 1950s that she remembers was filled with relatives, lively meals, celebrations, and a simpler way of life. The town and the close-knit community are highlighted in the watercolor-and-gouache paintings.
Author: Claire A. Nivola

Title: Originals: Animals that Time Forgot, The
Annotation: A variety of unusual animals that have hardly changed through time are presented through poems and dramatic paintings. The evolutionary roots and endurance of these creatures are highlighted. The book includes notes that extend the information presented in the poems.
Author: Jane  Yolen

Title: Orphan and the Stolen Duck, The
Annotation: Bai Xiao Er steals a duck and eats it, then discovers the next day that he has grown feathers all over his body. Illustrations and a reading guide are included.
Author: - Unknown

Title: Other Half of My Heart, The
Annotation: Minni and Keira are biracial twins. Minni is white, like the twins’ father, and Keira is dark, resembling their African American mother. The girls are invited to North Carolina by their maternal grandmother, who enters them into the Miss Black Pearl Preteen of America pageant. Back home, Minni has unknowingly benefited from her white appearance, while Keira has often been subjected to prejudice. However, in the pageant, it is Minni who stands out while Keira fits in. The story provides a lesson about prejudice and reinforces the idea that a person’s character is more important than his or her outward appearance.
Author: Sundee Tucker Frazier

Title: Other Mozart: The Life of the Famous Chevalier de Saint George, The
Annotation: Recounts the true story of the life of Joseph Bologne, an eighteenth-century French musician born to a slave mother and a wealthy father on the Caribbean island of Guadeloupe. Joseph was taken to France, renamed the Chevalier de Saint-George, and educated as a young aristocrat. Illustrated with full-page paintings. Includes bibliographical references and other resources.
Author: Hugh Brewster
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Music
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Other Side, The
Annotation: Two little girls, Clover and Annie, have been warned not to cross over the fence that divides the black side of town from the white side. Nevertheless, the girls spend hours and hours together on top of the fence and gradually discover that the fence that was built to separate them has become the perfect gateway to a new world for them and their town. Illustrated with realistic watercolor artwork.
Author: Jacqueline Woodson
Standard: HSS K.1, HSS K.6, HSS 1.1, HSS 1.4, HSS 1.5, HSS 2.1, HSS 2.3

Title: Otto Runs for President
Annotation: It is election time at school, and two very popular kids are running for school president—but they seem more concerned about themselves than the school. Otto decides to enter the race and begins asking his classmates what they want for the school. He wins the election but realizes that it is not easy to be president.
Author: Rosemary Wells

Title: Our Big Home: An Earth Poem
Annotation: Ecological interdependence is introduced by means of a rhymed poem that describes water, air, soil, sky, sun, and more shared by all living creatures. The illustrations are created with mixed media including collage, chalk, and paint. A variety of world cultures are shown as children and adults play, dance, and work. It would be useful as a read aloud to introduce units in earth science.
Author: Linda Glaser

Title: Our California
Annotation: This lively read-aloud covers the major regions of and 14 locations/cities in California. The illustrations are eye-catching and can serve as a model for mural paintings that tell a story. The book ends with pages devoted to California facts and details of the 14 locations. It may be used as an introduction to geographical study of California.
Author: Pam Munoz Ryan

Title: Our Liberty Bell
Annotation: This lively text, which is appropriate for reading aloud, explains how the Liberty Bell became a symbol of American freedom and tells about its role in the origins of the United States. The bell was used to announce the Boston Tea Party, the adoption of a flag by Congress, and the formation of the thirteen colonies into an independent nation. Illustrated with detailed pen-and-ink drawings. Will appeal to upper- and middle-grades students.
Author: Henry Jonas Magaziner

Title: Our Marching Band
Annotation: When all the girls and boys in the neighborhood take up musical instruments, they produce awful tones at first. But after much practice, they are able to come together as a marching band that brings brassy, classy fun. The band is invited by the mayor to march in the town’s Fourth of July parade. The rhymed story is illustrated with cheerful, cartoon-style artwork.
Author: Lloyd Moss
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.5

Title: Our Natural Homes: Exploring Terrestrial Biomes of North and South America
Annotation: This is a description of the climates of 12 biomes starting with the tundra and moving through to the warm and wet tropical rain forest. Each ecosystem is defined through the characteristic plants and animals found in each. Double-page spreads introduce each biome in a full-color scene of typical flora and fauna.
Author: Sneed B. Collard, III

Title: Our Only May Amelia
Annotation: Being the only girl in a family of seven brothers can be a real hardship for anyone. Most often, May Amelia becomes "one of the boys" and does what they do. That works until she is reminded that she is some sort of "miracle," and papa begins ordering her around again. Readers can enjoy the growing pains of this unlikely Finnish American character in Washington State in the early 1900s.
Author: Jennifer L. Holm

Title: Out of Sight: Pictures of Hidden Worlds
Annotation: Objects are shown that are too small, too far away, or too small to be seen without microscopes, telescopes, and other techniques. Explanations are given on how the pictures were taken. Objects as small as the head of a bedbug are shown along with far away images photographed by the Hubble Space Telescope. Scientific terms are thoroughly explained.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Out of the Ocean
Annotation: A mother and child walk along the beach collecting shells, beach glass, and bigger things, such as the sun and the wash of waves on the beach. Full-color seashore photographs and cut-paper collages in tropical colors enhance this beachcombing adventure.
Author: Debra Frasier
Classification: Counting Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, Science

Title: Outside and Inside Alligators
Annotation: This photo-essay's enthusiastic emphasis on anatomy and precise details distinguish it from other books about alligators. It describes the external and internal characteristics of alligators and how they find food, mate, and raise their young.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: Outside and Inside Big Cats
Annotation: Through clearly written text and full-color photographs, readers learn all about cats, including lions, tigers, jaguars, cougars, and even ordinary house cats. The author/photographer explains every physical attribute of a cat - inside and outside! This book is a part of the Outside and Inside series.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: Outside and Inside Giant Squid
Annotation: This book describes the inner and outer workings of giant squids, the enormous deep-sea creatures that have never been seen alive. It discusses their diet, anatomy, and reproduction. Full-color photographs of dead and dissected squids provide luminous details about these strange creatures. Scientific words are highlighted in red and explained in a glossary. This book is a part of the Outside and Inside series.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: Outside and Inside Kangaroos
Annotation: The inner workings and the outer body characteristics of kangaroos are described in this book. The book is illustrated with clear, full-color photographs that show vivid close-ups of the "insides." Additional facts and questions are included in a "Looking Back" section which invites the reader to re-evaluate the photographs and information. Other titles in the Outside and Inside series include BATS, BIRDS, DINOSAURS, RATS AND MICE, SHARKS, SNAKES, and SPIDERS.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: Outside and Inside Mummies
Annotation: This title describes the technology that is used to uncover the many secrets of mummies, including how they died, their age, and their diet. Vivid full-color photographs add perspective to the interesting text. Included are directions for making your own mummy, using a simulated version of natron. This book is certain to engage students in an exploration of this fascinating topic. This book is a part of the Outside and Inside series.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: Outside and Inside Rats and Mice
Annotation: Engaging photographs by this scientist are paired with short blocks of text to draw comparisons between the behavior, reproductive cycle, anatomy, and body systems of rats and mice. A "Looking Back" section asks questions at the end of the book. Other titles in the Outside and Inside series include BATS, BIRDS, DINOSAURS, KANGAROOS, SHARKS, SNAKES, and SPIDERS.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: Outside, Inside Poems
Annotation: These poems are about such experiences as standing in baseball shoes or expressing one's thoughts and feelings about being young and growing. The drawings are in black-and-white.
Author: Arnold Adoff

Title: Owen and Mzee: The True Story of a Remarkable Friendship
Annotation: The illustrated text and full-color photographs tell the true story of the unusual relationship between Owen, a baby hippopotamus orphaned during a December storm in Kenya, and Mzee, a 130-year-old giant tortoise. The bond between the two inseparable animals helps Owen recover from the traumatic ordeal he endured - the storm and the resulting separation from his mother. The photos are priceless, and the power of this extraordinary friendship will captivate readers of all ages. Never before has there been such a bond between a reptile and a mammal.
Author: Isabella Hatkoff

Title: Owen Foote, Frontiersman
Annotation: Wearing his coonskin cap, carrying his book about animal tracks, and armed with a jar of red pepper flakes in case he meets a bear or a mountain lion, Owen feels like a pioneer when he goes into the woods with his best friend, Joseph. But there are other kinds of varmints—two big kids who have nothing better to do than trash a treehouse fort. One of several books in the series about Owen Foote.
Author: Stephanie Greene

Title: Owen Foote, Mighty Scientist
Annotation: Owen and Joseph are partnered for the annual science fair and can not agree on their project. Owen wants to study lizards, but Joseph finds them yucky. They decide to raise tadpoles, but when the tadpoles die just before the fair, the boys learn that sometimes scientists can gather a great deal of information when an experiment fails.
Author: Stephanie Greene

Title: Owl Moon
Annotation: A little girl and her father go owling through the snow-covered fields and into the dark woods. A quiet mood is depicted through dramatic, moonlit illustrations. The book works best when read one-on-one to convey the closeness between the father and daughter .
Author: Jane Yolen

Title: Owls in the Family
Annotation: Set on the Saskatchewan prairie in Canada, a young boy discovers an abandoned wild owlet and later rescues an orphaned owlet from neighborhood bullies. The owlets manage to turn his household upside down, outwit a dog, and shake up the neighborhood. Use as a read aloud in grades three and up.
Author: Farley Mowat

Title: Oxford Illustrated Book of American Children’s Poems, The
Annotation: An anthology of enduring American poems, arranged chronologically according to each poet’s date of birth. The anthology begins with Native American cradle songs and early classics, moves on to well-known poets such as Emily Dickinson, Robert Frost, and T. S. Eliot, and shifts to contemporary writers such as Gwendolyn Brooks, Sandra Cisneros, Janet S. Wong, and others. This book provides a unique opportunity to read across generations. The poems are paired with a wide range of black-and-white and full-color illustrations, including archival selections from early book editions as well as pictures from nineteenth- and twentieth-century children’s magazines.
Author: Donald Hall (editor)

Title: Oxford Treasury of Time Poems, The
Annotation: This book is a collection of widely diverse poems with time as a theme. These poems cover how time is measured, why days exist, how childhood can be measured, topics of old age, and the ending of time as we know it. The volume includes illustrations by a variety of artists.
Author: Christopher Stuart-Clark, Michael Harrison
Topic: Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)

Title: Oye, Celia! A Song for Celia Cruz
Annotation: Illustrations and rhythmic text celebrate the life and salsa music of singer Celia Cruz. A young fan attends a neighborhood dance party and gives tribute to the singer as she hears loss, happiness, Cuban culture, and more in Cruz’s voice and lyrics. Includes translations of Spanish words used.
Author: Katie Sciurba
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Pablo Remembers: The Fiesta of the Day of the Dead
Annotation: In this story, Pablo celebrates The Day of the Dead with his family and friends. Everyone is busy preparing for the festivities, and Pablo remembers the death of his abuela (grandmother), whom he misses very much. This special day helps him to honor his abuela.
Author: George Ancona

Title: Pachamama, nuestra tierra - nuestro futuro (Pachamama, Our Earth - Our Future)
Annotation: The natural environment, ecology, and the future of man and Earth are the main topics covered in this book written by children of the world. Their concerns and hopes for the future are introduced and described through personal accounts, poems, and illustrations.
Translator: Maria del Pilar Vicente Diez et.  al.
Author: - Children of the World

Title: Packet of Seeds, A
Annotation: Young Annie and her family leave their home to journey west. Her father is anxious to start a new life on new land, but her mother is sad to leave family and friends. On the morning of their departure, her mother is given packets of seeds by her friends. When the family is settled, Annie digs a kitchen garden, and she and her mother plant daisies and hollyhocks. Her mother begins to heal from her sadness. Oil-paint illustrations bring the prairie to life. An endnote describes the inspiration for the story.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson

Title: Paco y la bruja: Cuento popular puertorriqueno (Paco and the Witch: A Puerto Rican Folktale)
Annotation: In this Puerto Rican version of Rumpelstiltskin, a young boy is trapped on an island by a crafty witch who will not free him unless he can guess her name. The story is an easy-flowing Spanish narrative, and the illustrations are brilliant and exaggerated in bright colors.
Author: Felix Pitre

Title: Paint the Wind
Annotation: Maya has lived in California with her overly protective paternal grandmother since the accidental death of Maya’s parents when she was six. When her grandmother suddenly dies, Maya moves to a ranch in Wyoming with her mother’s aunt, and she finds herself in a whole new world. A companion story is told about a mustang mare named Artemisia that was once owned by Maya’s mother and is now wild and free. This book weaves together a horse story, a coming-of-age tale, and a survival adventure. Includes a glossary, a bibliography, and a list of related Web sites. California author.
Author: Pam Muñoz Ryan

Title: Painting the Wind
Annotation: Painters and their dogs come every summer to paint scenes of the island where a child, the narrator of the story, lives. A landscape painter, a portrait painter, a painter of flowers, and the child paint what they see. At the end of the summer, when the paintings are hung in a barn for display, the child discovers that he has learned to paint the wind. This title is illustrated with vibrant and richly detailed artwork.
Author: Emily MacLachlan, Patricia MacLachlan

Title: Paisano, the Roadrunner
Annotation: The author relates her personal experiences with a family of roadrunners who lived with her for three years. The author's sketches and Meinzer's photographs provide a joyful mix of journal and story and models descriptive journaling for students. A "Useful Facts" section and an index are included.
Author: Jennifer Owings Dewey

Title: Pale Male, Citizen Hawk of New York City
Annotation: Pale Male, a red-tail hawk who made his nest on a high-rise building in New York City, and his family were beloved by almost everyone—except the people who lived in the building where the hawk made his home. This book describes the political battle that took place between nature lovers and the building’s owner. The watercolor paintings put readers on the streets of New York, where protests occurred when Pale Male’s nest was destroyed. An author’s note and sources for further study are included.
Author: Janet Schulman
Topic: Government and Politics, Law and Legal Studies, Life Science (Biology)

Title: Palindromania!
Annotation: Palindromes are words or numbers that read the same forward or backward, such as “wow” or “52125.” This book is a collection of palindrome words, expressions, and sentences presented with bright, cartoon-style illustrations. It may be used to begin an investigation of numbers that are palindromes, or numbers that can become palindromes when they are reversed and added together, such as “34 + 43 = 77.” California author.
Author: Jon Agee

Title: Pancho Rabbit and the Coyote: A Migrant's Tale
Annotation: In this picture book, a young rabbit named Pancho eagerly awaits his papa’s return. Papa Rabbit traveled north two years ago to find work in the great carrot and lettuce fields to earn money for his family. When Papa does not return, Pancho sets out to find him. He packs Papa’s favorite meal—mole, rice and beans, a heap of warm tortillas, and a jug of aguamiel—and heads north. He meets a coyote, who offers to help Pancho in exchange for some of Papa’s food.
Author: Duncan Tonatiuh
Award: Pura Belpre Illustration Honor, Pura Belpre Narrative Honor

Title: Panda Math: Learning About Subtraction from Hua Mei and Mei Sheng
Annotation: This book for young readers teaches subtraction skills through information presented about giant pandas. Right-hand pages tell about the birth and growth of Hua Mei and Mei Sheng, panda cubs at the San Diego Zoo. Each left-hand page zeros in on a particular fact and turns it into a subtraction problem. The text is illustrated with full-color photographs.
Author: Ann Whitehead Nagda
Standard: LS 4.3, Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 3.NBT.1-3

Title: Panda Rescue: Changing the Future for Endangered Wildlife
Annotation: The author discusses threats to the survival of the giant panda and examines panda conservation efforts being made around the world. Included is a timeline of conservation efforts, short profiles of conservationists, and forecasts of the animals' future. The book is illustrated with full-color photographs.
Author: Dan Bortolotti

Title: Panda's World, A
Annotation: The author opens up the world of pandas in this book, one in the author's "black and white" Caroline Arnold's Animals series. She illustrates her own books and has crafted cut-paper illustrations and vibrant backgrounds to tell the life cycle of the panda and the world in which it lives. The other books are A KILLER WHALE'S WORLD, A ZEBRA'S WORLD, and A PENGUIN'S WORLD. California author.
Author: Caroline Arnold

Title: Papa ¿me echaras de menos? (Daddy, Will You Miss Me?)
Annotation: A boy and his father find numerous ways to stay close to each other while the father is in Africa for four weeks. The full-page illustrations are in pastels.
Author: Wendy McCormick

Title: Papa ya no vive con nosotros (Papa Doesn't Live with Us Anymore)
Annotation: One day, young Pablo notices that Mama is very sad and Papa doesn't come home at night. When Papa comes home to pack his things, he holds Pablo and tells him that he loves him very much but that he is moving to another house. The sad realities of separation and change are themes in this selection. The illustrations are pen and watercolor.
Author: Manuel L. Alonso

Title: Paper Crane, The
Annotation: Given as payment for a meal, an unusual paper crane comes alive and dances - to the delight of the restaurant's owner and customers. Colorful photographs enhance paper collages, giving a three-dimensional effect.
Author: Molly Bang

Title: Pappy’s Handkerchief
Annotation: In 1889, Moses, a young African American boy, and his family sell everything they own and leave their home in Baltimore, Maryland, to join many other settlers in a race to claim land in the newly opened territory of Oklahoma. During the land rush, the family’s wagon is disabled, and Moses’s father breaks his leg. Moses must go on alone. Illustrated with dark, atmospheric paintings, the book is part of the “Tales of Young Americans” series.
Author: Devin Scillian

Title: Paris in the Spring with Picasso
Annotation: Clearly written text and bright, impressionistic illustrations artfully introduce readers to early twentieth-century Paris and some famous artists and writers of the time. Readers are led to the salon of Gertrude and Leo Stein, who collected the works of rising artists. The activities of the artist Pablo Picasso and writers Max Jacob and Guillaume Apollinaire are depicted as they prepare to attend the Steins’ evening soiree. Brief biographies of the historical characters are provided at the beginning of the book.
Author: Joan Yolleck
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General

Title: Park Beat: Rhymin' Through the Seasons
Annotation: The four seasons are described in rhyming text and shown in whimsical illustrations. Each season is depicted in artwork that begins with a wide view of the park, and then moves in closer and closer through a series of double-page spreads. The poetry comprised of short noun-verb phrases is active and energizing. Can be used as a model for writing.
Author: Jonathan  London

Title: Parrots Over Puerto Rico
Annotation: In ancient times, when humans arrived on the island now called Puerto Rico, there were hundreds of thousands of colorful parrots. By 1967, there were only twenty four parrots left. This picture book tells how events in the history of this small island endangered the survival of the green and yellow parrot and how scientists have begun to save them.
Author: Cindy Trumbore, Susan L. Roth
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Life Science (Biology), Visual Arts
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General , Science

Title: Pass It Down: Five Picture-Book Families Make Their Mark
Annotation: Five famous picture-book families share their memories, scrapbooks, book dummies, model shots, and final art. They reveal how their books were created, how their artistic skills have evolved, and how one’s roots influence who and what they become. The families consist of Donald Crews, Ann Jonas, and Nina Crews; Clement Hurd, Edith Thatcher Hurd, and Thatcher Hurd; Walter Dean Myers and Christopher Myers; Jerry Pinkney and Brian Pinkney; and Harlow Rockwell, Anne Rockwell, and Lizzy Rockwell.
Author: Leonard S. Marcus

Title: Pass the Energy, Please!
Annotation: The exchange of energy and nutrients within the environment is addressed through rhyming text. Various food chains, including woodland, Arctic, meadow, and African plain, are presented. The role decomposers play is also discussed. Illustrations done in oil paints are large and colorful and provide visual details.
Author: Barbara Shaw McKinney

Title: Passage to Freedom: The Sugihara Story
Annotation: Chiune Sugihara, a Japanese diplomat stationed in Lithuania in 1940, risks his job, his life, and the safety of his family by issuing visas to as many as 10,000 Jews who would have faced certain death had they not obtained visas. This book can be used with discussions of the Holocaust as well as stories of the Japanese and Japanese Americans who were sent to internment camps in the United States.
Author: Ken Mochizuki

Title: Passing the Music Down
Annotation: This story, in poetic text, is based on a friendship between real-life musicians Melvin Wine and Jake Krack. A young boy admires the music of a traditional old-time fiddler, who teaches the boy all the old tunes. The boy and the man develop a deep friendship, and the boy promises to “pass the music down.” The poetic text is enhanced by watercolor artwork. Includes an author’s note, discography, and more about the lives and work of the musicians depicted in the story.
Author: Sarah Sullivan

Title: Pastry School in Paris: An Adventure in Capacity
Annotation: Twins Matt and Bibi love to make dessert. When their family travels to Paris, they get to go to pastry school and learn how to work with quarts and liters. They convert between cups, pints, quarts, and milliliters. To solve a problem, they need to use all of their newly acquired knowledge. The book is illustrated with bold, bright, and amusing watercolor illustrations. It concludes with suggested activities that will engage children in exploring capacity at home.
Author: Cindy Neuschwander
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Patience Wright: America’s First Sculptor and Revolutionary Spy
Annotation: A biography of Patience Wright, America’s first recognized sculptor, who assisted the colonies during the American Revolution by using her wax sculptures to hide secret messages about British plans. Wright gained secret information from the English while they posed for her sculptures. Text is accompanied by detailed illustrations.
Author: Pegi Deitz Shea
Topic: American History, Visual Arts, Women’s Studies
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Paul Bunyan
Annotation: This legendary character of Maine, Paul Bunyan, weighed 156 pounds at birth. Even as a young lad, he wrestled grizzly bears. With Babe, the super ox, he dug the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence River as he led a band of lumbermen westward.
Author: Steven Kellogg (reteller)

Title: Paul Goble Gallery: Three Native American Stories
Annotation: Brought together in one volume are three previously published legends by Paul Goble. HER SEVEN BROTHERS, THE GIFT OF THE SACRED DOG, and THE GIRL WHO LOVED WILD HORSES all concern young people who leave their homes and return something important to their people about the natural world. The illustrations are stylized renditions that evoke the Native American culture. Each story is also published separately.
Author: Paul Goble

Title: Pebble in My Pocket: A History of Our Earth, A
Annotation: The history of a pebble begins with the cooling of lava from an ancient volcano. As the story unfolds, the changes in the formation and development of life on Earth is explained and illustrated with rich double-page spread paintings. Concepts touched upon include erosion, wave action, glaciations, and sedimentation. It includes a timeline charting the main periods in Earth's history.
Author: Meredith Hooper

Title: Pecorino’s First Concert
Annotation: Everyone thinks that Pecorino Sasquatch is the silliest boy in the world, and he proves them right when he and his mother go to hear a concert conducted by the great Pimplelini. Before the concert begins, Pecorino climbs on stage and gets stuck in a tuba. Illustrated with mixed-media collages that include pieces of sheet music and brushstrokes of color.
Author: Alan Madison

Title: Pedro’s Journal: A Voyage with Christopher Columbus, August 3, 1492–February 14, 1493
Annotation: Written as a diary of a cabin boy whose task is to record the first voyage of Christopher Columbus. Personalities and historical events are shown in a realistic light, and Pedro records his concerns about the natives they take on board. This is compelling reading that will appeal to many ages.
Author: Pam Conrad
Topic: American History, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Peepers
Annotation: Two local boys snicker at the tourists who come to view the colors on their father's Fall Colors Tour in New England. The boys never realize the beauty that surrounds them until their father asks them to participate in the "Peepers Tour." This story is a good introduction to the changes of the seasons. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: Penderwicks at Point Mouette, The
Annotation: In this third book of a series, three Penderwick sisters and their good friend Jeffrey spend time on the Maine Coast, supervised by their beloved Aunt Claire. Things look good as they settle into their cozy cottage, with a rocky shore, enthusiastic seagulls, a corner store, and a charming next-door neighbor. The warmth of the family and the balance between old-fashioned flavor and modern-day details make this a story to savor. The first two books in the series are THE PENDERWICKS (2005) and THE PENDERWICKS ON GARDAM STREET (2008).
Author: Jeanne Birdsall

Title: Pennies in a Jar
Annotation: A young boy whose father is serving overseas during World War II struggles to overcome his fear of the horses that pull trade wagons through his neighborhood. He works odd jobs to earn money to buy his father a birthday present. Overcoming his fears, the boy uses his earnings to have his picture taken on a pony to show his father that everything is fine at home. Includes an author’s note.
Author: Dori Chaconas

Title: People Could Fly: The Picture Book, The
Annotation: This is a retelling of a folktale in which a group of slaves, unable to bear their sadness and starvation any longer, call upon African magic that allows them to fly away. Illustrated with large paintings that are magic realism at its finest, this is an illustrated version of the title story in Hamilton's 1985 book, PEOPLE COULD FLY: AMERICAN BLACK FOLKTALES.
Author: Virginia Hamilton

Title: People with Five Fingers: A Native Californian Creation Tale, The
Annotation: This creation myth explains why every valley in California had a separate Native American nation, each with different customs and languages. In the beginning, Coyote and all the animals busily prepared California for people. Upon the people's arrival, there was so much laughing and talking, all in different languages, that the animals went to the woods, waters, and sky and never spoke again. Good read-aloud.
Author: John Bierhorst (reteller)

Title: Peppe the Lamplighter
Annotation: Peppe, an Italian immigrant boy, toils as a lamplighter when his father becomes too ill to work. The Caldecott Honor illustrations glow with light and dark images and evoke the streets of New York's Little Italy during the nineteenth century.
Author: Elisa Bartone

Title: Perez y Martina: Un cuento folklorico puertorriqueno (Perez and Martina: A Puerto Rican Folktale)
Annotation: This popular Hispanic folktale is about a cockroach and a mouse. The numerous marriage proposals, surprise ending, colorful illustrations, and simple directness of the Spanish language will continue to make this tale a special joy to listen to or to read.
Author: Pura Belpre

Title: Perilous Journey of the Donner Party, The
Annotation: The Westward Movement to California was a journey that required bravery, skill, and strong determination. One of the most remembered trips was the ill-fated journey of the Donner Party. The journey started in the spring of 1846 and ended when the party became trapped and snowbound in the wild Sierras. Many died, and those who survived did so at a tremendous cost. The tale connects with the eighth-grade history/social science curriculum.
Author: Marian Calabro

Title: Perro y gato (Dog and Cat)
Annotation: Two household pets, a dog and a cat, attempt to make life miserable for each other. But when nighttime comes and everything is dark, they discover the need to work together. Expressive, full-page cartoon illustrations enhance this story.
Author: Ricardo Alcantara

Title: Phantom of the Prairie: Year of the Black-Footed Ferret, The
Annotation: This fictional adventure of a black-footed ferret goes through the seasons. Facts about the life cycle and habits of this rare North American mammal is woven into the story. The watercolor illustrations emphasize the interrelationships among animals in the prairie ecosystem. Can be used as an introduction to science units about endangered animals and habitats.
Author: Jonathan  London

Title: Phantom Tollbooth, The
Annotation: Milo enters a world full of imaginary creatures when he drives his toy car through a toy tollbooth. Milo meets "1/2 a boy" who represents .58 since he is the member of the average family that has 2.58 kids. A journey through a land where Milo learns the importance of words and numbers provides a cure for his boredom. Through wordplay and humor the reader is introduced to examples of decimals, fractions and other mathematical ideas. It is also available in a Spanish edition.
Author: Norton Juster
Standard: Math 3.NF.1-3, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.NF.1-7, Math 5.MD.1-5, Math 5.MP.1-8, Math 6.NS.1-8, Math 6.EE.1-9, Math 6.MP.1-8

Title: Philharmonic Gets Dressed, The
Annotation: This unique book relates how the members of the Philharmonic Orchestra get ready for work. Each arrives at Philharmonic Hall separately, and then each loses his or her individuality to become a group of 105 musicians playing and creating beautiful music together.
Author: Karla Kuskin
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3

Title: Phillis’s Big Test
Annotation: Phillis Wheatley was a young slave when she came to Boston. She was encouraged by her owners to write poetry. In 1772, Phillis was preparing to publish a book of poems but was suspected of plagiarizing the work. She was ordered to an examination to prove that she was the actual author of the poems. The day of the examination is the focus of this powerful picture book. Illustrated with mixed-media art in somber colors.
Author: Catherine Clinton

Title: Phineas Gage: A Gruesome but True Story About Brain Science
Annotation: Phineas Gage was working on the railroad in 1848 when an accident blew a 13-pound iron rod through his head. He survived, and the changes in his personality helped doctors begin to understand the workings of the brain. This is book illustrated with photographs and diagrams.
Author: John Fleischman

Title: Phineas L. MacGuire . . . Erupts!
Annotation: Phineas Listerman MacGuire, a young science enthusiast, plans to win the fourth-grade science fair—but his plans are foiled when his teacher pairs him with an obnoxious boy who has already alienated the rest of the class. This humorous first-person narrative centers on the friendship that develops between Phineas and his classmate while they collaborate on a science experiment about volcanoes. Illustrated with occasional black-and-white drawings, the book includes directions for performing several experiments mentioned in the story.
Author: Frances O’Roark Dowell

Title: Phoebe the Spy
Annotation: During the American Revolution, Phoebe Fraunces, an African American girl, has the chance to save the life of George Washington while the general is eating dinner in New York City. This book was originally published as PHOEBE AND THE GENERAL, a tale based on a degree of historical accuracy. Samuel Fraunces, a free African American who lived during the Revolutionary War period, allowed his restaurant to be used as a meeting place for the American patriots.
Author: Judith Berry Griffin

Title: Piano Starts Here: The Young Art Tatum
Annotation: Told in the first person, this picture-book biography tells the story of the jazz great Art Tatum. It highlights his childhood and his musical development, which took him from school and his first recital in church to Toledo bars, the club circuit, and New York City. The lyrical text evokes sounds and smells and presents the people who influenced him. Features ink-lined watercolor artwork with bright washes.
Author: Robert Andrew Parker

Title: Picture Book of George Washington Carver, A
Annotation: George Washington Carver's dedication to helping poor Southern farmers is introduced in a brief overview of his life and includes details about his agricultural discoveries. Colorful illustrations complement the clear and informative text that highlights the many uses he discovered for peanuts.
Author: David A. Adler
Standard: HSS K.3, HSS K.6, LS 2.2, I & E 2.4, LS 3.3, I & E 3.5, HSS 2.5

Title: Picture Book of Sacagawea
Annotation: Sacagawea, a Shoshone woman, joined the Lewis and Clark expedition and led them West to the Pacific Ocean. This picture biography includes the chronology of Sacagawea's life, an author's note, and a bibliography.
Author: David A. Adler

Title: Picture for Marc, A
Annotation: Marc, an imaginative Russian boy, always sees beauty in the dull Russian village where he lives. He discovers his talent for drawing and, with the encouragement of a friend and an art teacher, decides to become an artist. Whimsical black-and-white illustrations show the creativity of this great artist. Based loosely on the childhood of Marc Chagall. Includes an author’s note and a bibliography.
Author: Eric A. Kimmel

Title: Pictures at an Exhibition
Annotation: A children’s book based on real events, this story shows how the death of one friend and the encouragement of another led to nineteenth-century composer Modest Mussorgsky’s creation of the piano suite “Pictures at an Exhibition.” Includes piano and orchestral versions of the piece on a CD.
Author: Anna Harwell Celenza
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.4

Title: Pictures of Hollis Woods
Annotation: A troublesome twelve-year-old orphan, staying with an elderly artist suffering from the beginning stages of Alzheimer's disease, remembers the only other time she was happy in a foster home. In the end, she is reunited with the family she has longed for.
Author: Patricia Reilly Giff
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Pie
Annotation: Alice’s Aunt Polly has a knack for making delicious pies and joyfully gives them away to her friends, neighbors, and tourists. Her small-town pie shop becomes famous as tourists flock to taste the pies. When Aunt Polly suddenly dies, her piecrust recipe is left to her cat, Lardo, and Lardo is left to Alice. When the pie shop is burglarized, Alice realizes someone is looking for the recipe. She and her friend Charlie set out to solve the mystery. Pie recipes are included.
Author: Sarah Weeks

Title: Pie-Biter (Comepasteles)
Annotation: While working on the Transcontinental Railroad, Chinese worker Pie-Biter gains legendary strength by eating pies. After the railroad is completed, he makes a fortune with his pack trains and returns to China. This title is also available in Chinese and Spanish translations. California author.
Translator: Chinese: Ellen Lai-shan Yeung; Spanish: Teresa Mlawer
Author: Ruthanne Lum McCunn

Title: Piece=Part=Portion: Fractions=Decimals=Percents
Annotation: Vibrant photographs illustrate and help explain that in the language of mathematics, fractions, decimals and percents are three different ways of describing the same parts of things. There is no story line, but the visual representation of the percent, decimal, and/or percent can help the reader to understand the concept and relate the three different ways to describe a part. California author and California illustrator.
Author: Scott Gifford
Standard: Math 3.NF.1-3, Math 3.G.1-2, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.NF.1-7, Math 6.RP.1-3, Math 7.RP.1-3

Title: Pieces: A Year in Poems and Quilts
Annotation: This book combines a patchwork of 20 short seasonal poems paired with original quilt patterns which deal with such things as winter cold, fall leaves, flowers in spring, and the return of weeds. The last two pages of the book include a detailed section which tells the reader how the quilts were constructed. Other books about quilting are THE BEDSPREAD by Sylvia Fair, and THE QUILT STORY by Tony Johnston.
Author: Anna Grossnickle Hines
Topic: Earth Science, English-Language Arts/General, Life Science (Biology), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing, Mathematics, Science
Standard: ES K.3, ES 1.3, VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Piggybook
Annotation: The Piggotts appear to be just a normal family; however, when Mrs. Piggott leaves one day, her demanding husband and children find out just how much she did for them. Soon the house looks like a pigsty, and they are reduced to rooting around for scraps - until Mrs. Piggott returns to a very contrite and helpful family. The illustrations are realistic but droll and will bring chuckles to every reader.
Author: Anthony Browne

Title: Pigs at Odds: Fun with Math and Games
Annotation: The Pig family's visit to the county fair is a humorous introduction to odds and probability. While trying their luck at various games, they find out what the odds are that they will go home winners. The colorful ink, watercolor, and acrylic illustrations go along with the carnival setting. Math questions related to the story are included at the end.
Author: Amy Axelrod

Title: Pigs Go to Market: Fun with Math and Shopping
Annotation: As the Pig family is preparing for a Halloween party, they discover that Grandma and Grandpa have eaten all the candy. While at the store to buy more, Mrs. Pig wins five minutes of free shopping. The labels on the groceries provide many opportunities to work on multiplication and many types of measurement. Illustrations done with watercolor, ink, and acrylic add to the craziness of the Pig family in costume. The book ends with multiplication problems that ask readers to compute how much candy the pigs ate on the ride home from the store.
Author: Amy Axelrod

Title: Pigs Will Be Pigs: Fun with Math and Money
Annotation: The hungry Pig family learns about money and buying power as they turn the house upside down looking for enough money to buy dinner at the local restaurant. The bright illustrations have a Southwestern flair. Problems for the reader to solve are included. See other titles are: PIGS ON A BLANKET, PIGS IN THE PANTRY, PIGS GO TO MARKET, and PIGS AT ODDS: FUN WITH MATH AND GAMES.
Author: Amy Axelrod
Standard: Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NF.1-3, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 5.NBT.1-7

Title: Pink and Say
Annotation: Racism and prejudice are set aside when Say Curtis remembers his meeting with Pinkus Aylee, a black solider, during the Civil War. While recovering from battle wounds, Pink teaches Say to read. The two are captured by Southern troops, and only one survives to pass down this story of friendship and caring.
Author: Patricia Polacco

Title: Pinocho (Pinocchio)
Annotation: The story tells of the remarkable adventures of a talking wooden puppet whose nose grows whenever he tells a lie. The modernistic, full-page watercolor illustrations alternate with easy-to-read text.
Author: Carlo Collodi, Merce Escardo Bas (adapter)

Title: Pioneer Sampler: The Daily Life of a Pioneer Family in 1840, A
Annotation: The life and times of a pioneer family living in the Western frontier come alive in this story. The book contains factual information about farming, harvesting, cooking, building shelters, and hunting. It also depicts the work demanded of all members of the family. It is a valuable resource for history/social science exploration and writing opportunities.
Author: Barbara Greenwood

Title: Place for Birds, A
Annotation: Provides information about a variety of North American birds, including what they need to survive and how people can help the birds continue into the future. Each double-page spread of acrylic artwork is accompanied with information, and sidebars highlight individual species. Maps identify the range of each species. The book emphasizes ecosystem balance and basic ideas for species conservation. Will inspire young readers to take a closer look at the birds they encounter in their daily lives.
Author: Melissa Stewart

Title: Place for Fish, A
Annotation: Environmental threats facing fish in various habitats around the world are introduced. Each two-page entry contains a general statement of a problem and an action statement that offers hope. Sidebars provide descriptions of specific species, and full-color acrylic paintings enhance the text. Young readers will easily grasp the concept and the urgency of threats to particular fish species throughout the world.
Author: Melissa Stewart

Title: Place for Zero: A Math Adventure, A
Annotation: Zero is all alone in the land of Digitaria. His friends play "Addemup" with each other, but Zero can not because he has nothing to add. So he goes on a journey to discover his place. On the way he learns of his additive and multiplicative identities. Then he establishes place value.
Author: Angeline Sparagna LoPresti
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Standard: Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6

Title: Place Where Sunflowers Grow, A
Annotation: Mari and her Japanese American family are sent to the Topaz Relocation Center during World War II. An art class helps Mari adjust to her new environment. She makes a new friend, plants sunflowers, and learns to express her feelings about living at the internment camp through drawing. The soft illustrations bring a sense of poignancy to the internment experience. A Japanese translation accompanies the English text. California illustrator.
Author: Amy Lee-Tai
Topic: American History, Diversity, Ethnic Studies, Linguistics and Second Language Acquisition, Visual Arts, War
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: HSS 1.5, HSS 2.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, HSS 3.4, HSS 4.4

Title: Planet Earth/Inside Out
Annotation: This is a colorful, fact-filled book that explores the geologic history of Earth, from it's formation to present-day features and landforms.
