The processes and forces that shape Earth and make it a constantly changing planet are explored. Plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanoes, glaciers, rocks, and minerals are described in reader-friendly terms.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Planetas, Los (I Know About Planets)
Annotation: This is an easy-to-read and entertaining look at planets. This simple format cites important information essential for a student scientist investigating planets. See other books in the Rand McNally for Kids series.
Author: Chris Jaeggi

Title: Planets, The
Annotation: This title uses simple sentences to describe the sun and the planets of the solar system and introduces related concepts such as day, year, orbit, and rotation. The pages are filled with appealing full-color illustrations of astronomers, the solar system, each of the planets, and more in this revised version of the 1993 edition. This beginning book on astronomy will easily engage the interest of young readers.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Plantas del desierto (Desert Plants)
Annotation: This book describes how desert plants adapt to their environment with its extreme temperatures, drought conditions, and shifting sands. Detailed illustrations support the text descriptions.
Author: Andreu Llamas

Title: Planting the Trees of Kenya: The Story of Wangari Maathai
Annotation: This picture-book biography presents the life of Wangari Maathai, a native Kenyan who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2004 for environmental and human rights achievements. Returning to Kenya after spending her college years in Kansas, Maathai was distressed to learn that forests had been destroyed for tea plantations and people were living in poverty. She taught the people living in the highlands how to plant trees and care for the land. Since 1977, more than 30 million trees have been planted, and people have learned new farming techniques. NOTE: Wangari Maathai was elected to parliament in Kenya in 2002 and died in September 2011. This book was published prior to her death.
Author: Claire A. Nivola
Topic: Earth Science, Economics, Global Historical Events and Figures, Global Social Institutions, Government and Politics, Women’s Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Plants on the Trail with Lewis and Clark
Annotation: This book takes the reader on the trail of Lewis and Clark, documenting the many plants seen during the expedition and how many of those plants were used along the way. The investigation of plant and animal life was one of the many goals President Jefferson had for the expedition. Color photographs not only show the plants along the route, but also depict the route itself. A complement to the study of the Westward Expansion, this book is a companion to Patent and Munoz’s ANIMALS ON THE TRAIL WITH LEWIS AND CLARK.
Author: Dorothy Hinshaw Patent

Title: Pocahontas: Princess of the New World
Annotation: An illustrated introduction to the life of Pocahontas, the Native American princess, and her contact with English settlers—especially John Smith. Includes background information on Jamestown; John Smith; her husband, John Rolfe; her father, Powhatan; and her son, Thomas Rolfe. Award-winning artist David Diaz illustrates her life with cut-paper collages using bright, tropical colors.
Author: Kathleen Krull

Title: Poem Runs: Baseball Poems and Paintings
Annotation: Fifteen upbeat poems use rhymes and images to capture a full season of baseball enthusiasm around the diamond. Position players and batters take the limelight on pages that feature mixed-media artwork, done with watercolors, pastels, and pine tar on a canvas of paper bags.
Author: Douglas Florian

Title: Poems for Children Nowhere Near Old Enough to Vote
Annotation: This collection acquaints young readers with previously unpublished poetry by the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet. The poems feature everyday objects and parts of the body and are made accessible and stimulating through the comic pen-and-ink sketches that distort and shape the words into the objects being described.
Author: Carl Sandburg

Title: Poet: The Remarkable Story of George Moses Horton of Chapel Hill
Annotation: Shares the story of George Moses Horton, who was born into slavery, taught himself to read, and earned money by selling his poems to the students of the University of North Carolina, before becoming the first published African American poet of the South.
Author: Don Tate

Title: Poetrees
Annotation: Through serious and humorous poetic portrayals, unique species of trees and their traits become a living force. Hidden words, faces, and images reinforce each poem’s message. A page explaining the themes of each verse in more detail follows the creative imagery. Puns and other wordplay make this an engaging presentation of language for all ages.
Author: Douglas Florian

Title: Polar Bear Math: Learning About Fractions from Klondike and Snow
Annotation: This book teaches about fractions by presenting charts and recipes for milk for two baby polar bears born in a zoo. The story of the cubs is told through photographs and narrative on the right-hand pages and the respective fractions elements on the left-hand pages.
Author: Ann Whitehead Nagda

Title: Polar Bears
Annotation: The polar bear is the biggest, most powerful terrestrial animal able to survive the hostile climate of the arctic. This selection provides information about how polar bears swim and hunt, how they keep warm and dry, and other ways they adapt to the climate and habitat of the arctic. The book also includes explanations of the polar bear's life cycle. This is a good selection for beginning report writers; it also works well as a nonfiction read-aloud for young children.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Poles Apart: Why Penguins and Polar Bears Will Never Be Neighbors
Annotation: This engaging introduction to the earth's poles, both geographic and magnetic, covers a wide range of subjects as it describes their histories, geographic and physical features, fauna, human exploration, similarities and differences, and futures. Some of the scientific topics included are magnetism, animal and human migration, weather, global warming, fossils, continental drift, and plate tectonics. The text is accompanied by color and archival black-and-white photographs, other graphics, an index, an annotated bibliography of further readings for children, and a list of suggested Web sites to visit.
Author: Elaine Scott
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Pompeii: Lost and Found
Annotation: The reader is taken back in time to the city of Pompeii just before Mt. Vesuvius erupted. The narrative then shifts to the archaeological activities of the scientists who have studied the event. A guessing game is woven through-out the book, and answers are provided at the end. Fresco paintings complement the historical setting and provide details of Roman life. End notes explain the illustrator’s artistic process.
Author: Mary Pope Osborne
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, Science

Title: Pond
Annotation: The plants and animals that flourish and change over the course of a year in and around the waters of a healthy pond are documented in this book. Detailed watercolor illustrations enhance the text, and small ink drawings present further information. Written by a noted nature artist, this title is useful for teaching pond ecology and discussing habitats.
Author: Gordon Morrison

Title: Pond Watching with Ann Morgan
Annotation: The life and work of Ann Haven Morgan (1882-1966) included studying, teaching, and writing about the animals of ponds and streams with a focus on the importance of an ecological approach to conservation. Archival photographs highlight her education and work and are accompanied by full-color illustrations that illustrate pond dwellers.
Author: Michael Elsohn Ross

Title: Pony Express
Annotation: A lively, fast-paced text and soft-colored oil painting illustrations bring the excitement of the Pony Express to the reader. Although this form of mail express lasted only 18 months, it was an important step in establishing postal service to the West. A map of the Pony Express route, historical photographs, author's notes, a bibliography, and an index are included. The book can be used for enrichment for the fourth-grade California history curriculum. California setting.
Author: Steven Kroll

Title: Pop's Bridge
Annotation: Robert learns that all of the workers building the Golden Gate Bridge are important to the project. His father is a high-iron man, or “skywalker,” and his friend Charlie’s father is a painter. Robert secretly thinks his father’s job is more important than the painting done by Charlie’s father, but an accident causes him to realize that the bridge belongs to everyone who worked on it. Features bold, bright illustrations. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: Poppy
Annotation: When the deer mice that live in the Gray house want to move to a better location for food and shelter, they must secure permission from a powerful, controlling owl that rules Dimwood Forest. Brave Poppy and her friend Ragweed attempt to defy the owl and strike out on their own. An adventure of good versus evil ensues.
Author: - Avi

Title: Por que zumban los mosquitos en los oidos de la gente: Un cuento de Africa occidental (Why Mosquitoes Buzz in People's Ears: A West African Tale)
Annotation: This African folktale begins with a mosquito teasing an iguana, causing the iguana to panic. The panic is contagious, but all of the trouble is traced back to the mosquito. The African motif illustrations feature colorful, outlined pictures.
Author: Verna Aardema

Title: Porcupine Year, The
Annotation: In 1852, forced by the U.S. government to leave their island, twelve-year-old Omokayas and her Ojibwe family travel in search of a new home. The family endures violent raids in the freezing winter and comes close to starvation in the search for a new home. Omokayas learns the childhood story of her bold, tough mentor, Old Tallow. The culture and way of life of the Ojibwe is woven into the story to make an engaging read. Sequel to THE BIRCHBARK HOUSE and THE GAME OF SILENCE.
Author: Louise Erdrich

Title: Porque de las cosas: Naturaleza y ciencia, El (The Picture Book of Knowledge: How Things Work)
Annotation: With an easy-to-read text and illustrations, this book provides information on three areas of science: the human body, the environment, and physical science. A good, basic introduction to the three general areas of science. See other books in the Porque de las Cosas (Book of Knowledge) series.
Translator: Jose Luis Tamayo and Ines Martin Jose Luis Tamayo and Ines Martin
Author: Ines Martin (translator), Jose Luis Tamayo (translator)
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Post Card Passages
Annotation: Young Susan receives postcards from all over the world from her Great-Aunt Gladys and dreams of the day when she will be able to travel the globe. Each page is a new postcard from "Aunt Glad" and is illustrated with photo collages and pastels of the scenery. In the last postcard, an adult Susan tells Aunt Glad that she is off to see the world! This book is a fine enrichment selection for geography and the writing process.
Author: Susan Joyce

Title: Pot That Juan Built, The
Annotation: This picture book biography explains how Juan Quezada rediscovered the art of pottery making practiced by the ancient Casa Grandes people of Mexico and how this discovery led to the revitalization of the village of Mata Ortiz. The left-hand pages tell the story with the cumulative pattern similar to "The House That Jack Built," and the right-hand pages describe in narrative text details about Juan's life and work. Includes photographs and explanation of Quezada's work. Luminous illustrations enhance the text. Useful for learning about pottery, economics, and cultures. California author and illustrator.
Author: Nancy Andrews-Goebel
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: HSS K.3, HSS K.4, HSS 1.4, VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Prairie Builders: Reconstructing America's Lost Grasslands, The
Annotation: This book tells of the success, through hard work and patience, of naturalists and volunteers who restored the native tallgrass prairie at the Neal Smith National Wildlife Refuge in central Iowa. The wide-format of the book lends itself to descriptions of the process of reintroducing prairie plants and wildlife, including the regal fritillary butterfly. Illustrated with full-color photographs, this work also includes suggested readings and Web sites for further information. This book is a part of the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Sneed B. Collard, III

Title: Prairie Dogs
Annotation: This well-researched, authoritative book explores the prairie dog's habitat and lifestyle while presenting evidence that their towns enrich the grass in their habitat. The book is illustrated with well-placed color photographs that include images of their neighbors and the habitat and includes a bibliography and an index.
Author: Dorothy Hinshaw Patent

Title: Prairie Dogs Kiss and Lobsters Wave: How Animals Say Hello
Annotation: Animal communication and social behavior are described by showing how animals greet others of their own species. A variety of animals are highlighted including mammals, insects, and ocean creatures. Photographs and watercolor illustrations fill two-page spreads and are accompanied by several paragraphs of entertaining and informative text. Can be read aloud to introduce animal research.
Author: Marilyn Singer

Title: Prancing, Dancing Lily
Annotation: Lily will someday be the “bell cow” leading her herd, but because her prancing and dancing disrupt their order, she travels the world in search of the right place and dance for her. She breaks up a square dance by turning the wrong way; flubs an appearance with the Radio City Rockettes; tries out stilt dancing, flamenco, and belly dancing in various countries; and finally finds her true calling in a Caribbean conga line. Illustrated with humorous cartoon-style drawings.
Author: Marsha Diane Arnold

Title: President’s Stuck in the Bathtub: Poems About the Presidents, The
Annotation: Author Susan Katz researched presidents of the United States and discovered that all were funny people. Bright, digitally colored ink drawings accompany the humorous facts and trivia about every president. The book offers suggested classroom activities for poetry month, Presidents’ Day, and presidential elections.
Author: Susan Katz
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Government and Politics

Title: Prince of the Pond, Otherwise Known as De Fawg Pin
Annotation: Having been turned into a frog by a hag, the frog prince makes the best of his new life as he mates, raises a family, and instills a new kind of thinking in his frog family. Humorous situations and language problems will amuse young listeners. This story is useful in lessons about using humor in the language arts and in making comparisons with other frog prince stories.
Author: Donna Jo Napoli

Title: Printer, The
Annotation: In New York City in 1940, a young boy talks about his deaf father, who loves his job as a printer with a big daily newspaper. When a fire erupts in the noisy pressroom, he and his deaf colleagues use their hands to signal the danger to their other coworkers, and everyone escapes the inferno. Illustrated with handsome paintings. Concludes with notes about the history of printing, the use of American Sign Language, and the author’s own deaf father, also a printer.
Author: Myron Uhlberg

Title: Priscilla’s Paw de Deux
Annotation: A rat’s ambition to become a ballerina is tested when she discovers that a prowling “watch cat” also lives in the dance studio where she practices. The illustrations are filled with comical details and capture the ballet poses accurately, whether the dancers are humans or rats. Sequel to PRISCILLA AND ROSY (2001).
Author: Sharon Jennings

Title: Private Joel and the Sewell Mountain Seder
Annotation: Based on a true story of a Union soldier in the Civil War who was unable to go home for the Passover Seder and how the soldiers created a Passover together. The participation of three former slaves who had become members of the soldiers’ company gave special meaning to this celebration of freedom. Illustrated with paintings that blend realistic and abstract styles.
Author: Bryna J. Fireside

Title: Project Mulberry
Annotation: Julia, a Korean American new in her neighborhood, makes friends with Patrick. Together they begin a school project on animal husbandry. With the help of Julia's mother, they design a silkworm project. Information about raising silkworms is described throughout the story. Interspersed between chapters are interesting chats between the fictional Julia and the author, in which they discuss the story within the story.
Author: Linda Sue Park

Title: Project Ultra Swan
Annotation: The author describes in text and photographs the life of trumpeter swans and how they nearly became extinct. The efforts to reintroduce them to the Northeastern U.S. and help them relearn migration routes are described. Insights into the environments and the scientific process are provided. This book is a part of the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Elinor Osborn

Title: Prometheus Project: Trapped, The
Annotation: This fast-paced adventure story is about Ryan and Regan Resnick, two children who lament the family's move from San Diego to rural Pennsylvania. Their scientist parents will not reveal why they uprooted the family so quickly. When Ryan overhears their parents talking, he decides to explore this strange situation. The children discover more than they bargained for and experience danger, possible aliens, and a strange, underground world. They use the scientific method and information problem solving to come to conclusions throughout the story. A follow-up class discussion could address the ethics of scientific discovery.
Author: Douglas E. Richards
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Promises to Keep: How Jackie Robinson Changed America
Annotation: A biography of baseball legend Jackie Robinson, the first African American to play in the major leagues, as told by his daughter. This compelling story highlights the role Jackie Robinson played in advancing the rights of blacks through his life and work. Generously illustrated with photographs and letters.
Author: Sharon Robinson

Title: Proverbios de todo el mundo (Proverbs from Far and Wide)
Annotation: This collection of proverbs from around the world expresses basic truths and practical ideas with humor and cleverness. Each proverb is accompanied by an amusing color illustrations with appropriate national and cultural identifications.
Author: Axel Scheffler

Title: Puff, the Magic Dragon
Annotation: The adventures of a boy, Jackie Paper, and his dragon friend are recounted in this classic song from the 1960s. At the end of this story, Jackie’s daughter takes his place as Puff’s best buddy, making the ending less melancholy than the original song. The book features bright, acrylic-on-linen illustrations and includes an audio CD of “Puff” and two other songs sung by Peter Yarrow and his daughter.
Author: Lenny Lipton, Peter Yarrow
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3

Title: Puffins Are Back
Annotation: This selection contains a simple introduction to the physical characteristics, life cycle, and natural environment of the puffins living off the coast of Maine. Also included is information about how National Audubon Society scientists have worked since 1969 to ensure the survival of this species.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Punctuation Takes a Vacation
Annotation: On a very hot day, Mr. Wright, a teacher, decides to give punctuation a vacation. The punctuation marks are insulted and rush out the door. When Mr. Wright’s class returns, the students realize that “nothing made sense without punctuation.” Soon the class begins to receive postcards from the various punctuation marks. The class begs them to come back, and order is reinstated. Vibrant acrylic paintings enhance this entertaining look at punctuation. The rules of punctuation are provided at the end of the book.
Author: Robin Pulver
Discipline: English-Language Arts/General , English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Punished!
Annotation: Logan is roughhousing in the library and bumps into an older gentleman, Professor Wordsworth, who punishes him by placing a curse on him. Everything that comes out of Logan’s mouth is a really bad pun. His family and friends think he’s a smart aleck, and Logan is desperate to lift the curse. Professor Wordsworth tells him the only way to break the curse is to collect examples of palindromes, oxymorons, and anagrams. The many examples of wordplay in the story make this a good read-aloud choice.
Author: David Lubar

Title: Punk Farm
Annotation: While Farmer Joe gets ready for bed, his animals tune their instruments to perform their version of “Old MacDonald Had a Farm.” The book is illustrated with cartoon-style artwork on single- and double-page spreads. The sequel is PUNK FARM: ON TOUR.
Author: Jarrett J. Krosoczka

Title: Punk Farm: On Tour
Annotation: While Farmer Joe attends the National Tractor Society Conference in Reno, his animals go on tour in a broken-down van, performing as a band called Punk Farm. As they cross the United States, they perform various renditions of “The Wheels on the Bus.” Illustrated with acrylic artwork featuring the animals sporting “shades” (sunglasses). This is the sequel to PUNK FARM. The book provides maps on endpapers.
Author: Jarrett J. Krosoczka

Title: Pushing Up the Sky: Seven Native Plays for Children
Annotation: This collection of seven Native American plays is adapted from different traditional tales and is filled with heroes and tricksters, comedy and drama. The plays are suitable for elementary audiences.
Author: Joseph Bruchac

Title: Puss in Boots
Annotation: In this richly illustrated version of the French fairy tale, a cat cleverly arranges for his master to win the hand of the princess in marriage, along with a royal fortune. The artwork in this selection represents various perspectives, including that of Puss in Boots, allowing readers to identify with the characters.
Author: Charles Perrault

Title: Quake! Disaster in San Francisco, 1906
Annotation: During the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, a thirteen-year-old Jewish boy named Jacob is separated from his father and younger sister. Jacob rescues Chang, a Chinese boy, from a crushed building, and together the boys look for their family members. The narration gives a vivid picture of both the destruction of the earthquake and the resourcefulness of the survivors.
Author: Gail Langer Karwoski

Title: Queen of the Falls
Annotation: At the turn of the twentieth century, Annie Edson Taylor, widowed and elderly, decides she'll go over Niagara Falls in a barrel, a feat never before attempted. Though the stunt seems miraculous, Van Allsburg's matter-of-fact narrative emphasizes her advanced technical planning. Sepia-toned illustrations depict Annie as prim and proper but also convey her grit and determination.
Author: Chris Van Allsburg

Title: Queen of the Falls
Annotation: Presents the true story of Annie Edson Taylor’s daring plunge over Niagara Falls in a wooden barrel in 1901. The sixty-two-year-old Edson Taylor, a former charm-school teacher, hoped to gain fame and avoid the poorhouse by becoming the first person to go over Niagara Falls. She did not gain a fortune, but she was proud of her accomplishment. Van Allsburg’s signature artwork, rendered in sepia, captures the high drama and excitement of this adventure. Includes an author’s note and a brief biography.
Author: Chris Van Allsburg
Topic: American History, Global Historical Events and Figures, Women’s Studies

Title: Queen's Progress: An Elizabethan Alphabet, The
Annotation: Every summer, Elizabeth I, Queen of England, goes on a holiday known as the royal progress. As she and her entourage travel through the English countryside, they meet with Adventure (A), Bear (B), and so on until all of the letters of the alphabet are presented. Both the illustrations and the text bring to the reader many details of country and courtly life in Elizabethan England. California author and illustrator.
Author: Celeste Davidson Mannis

Title: Querido senor Henshaw (Dear Mr. Henshaw)
Annotation: Leigh Botts, now a sixth-grader, began writing to his favorite author, Boyd Henshaw, when Leigh was in the second grade. The reader journeys with Leigh and learns how he adjusts to new situations, including the absence of his father from the home. California author. English version available.
Author: Beverly Cleary

Title: Quest for the Tree Kangaroo: An Expedition to the Cloud Forest of New Guinea
Annotation: Author Sy Montgomery and photographer Nic Bishop travel to the ancient forests of Papua New Guinea in search of the rare Matschie’s tree kangaroo. With a team of scientists and local guides, they make their way through difficult terrain to find, tag, and study these rare animals. End materials include advice for young naturalists, Web sites for further research, an index, and a glossary of words from Tok Pisin, the language of the native guides. Part of the “Scientists in the Field” series.
Author: Sy Montgomery
Award: Orbis Pictus Award, Robert F. Sibert Award

Title: Queta, la vaca coqueta (Queta, the Flirtatious Cow)
Annotation: Queta, the cow, knows she is a flirt and takes pride in her beauty. But as she crosses a bridge, she loses her tail and her teeth. A brazen dog and a gluttonous cat take advantage of Queta's misfortune. Martinez's illustrations give the animals the necessary character in this fable-like story with a rhyming text.
Author: Martha Sastrias

Title: Quiltmaker’s Journey, The
Annotation: The Elders have forbidden the wealthy townspeople to wander beyond the safety of the walls surrounding the village, but an independent young girl defies the edict and travels beyond the wall. She discovers good people who are less fortunate that the residents of her village. Her desire to bring happiness to others becomes her life’s journey. Double-page watercolor spreads add drama to the story. Use as a read-aloud before a discussion on poverty and wealth, wants versus needs, and how small things can make big differences in people’s lives. This book is a prequel to THE QUILTMAKER’S GIFT (1999).
Author: Jeff Brumbeau
Topic: Economics, English-Language Arts/General, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, Personal and Community Health, Visual Arts, Women’s Studies

Title: Quite Contrary Man: A True American Tale, The
Annotation: In the early nineteenth century, social conventions dictated that men be clean shaven, which was a sign of godliness. Joseph Palmer, a friend of Ralph Waldo Emerson and the Alcotts, lived by his own code and grew a long beard flowing to his belly. His neighbors tried to shave it, and he fought back, ending up in prison for a year. This true story is illustrated with pen-and-ink and watercolor artwork. It celebrates nonconformity and encourages children to question social rules they may take for granted.
Author: Patricia Rusch Hyatt

Title: Quotations for Kids
Annotation: This collection acquaints readers with over 2,000 quotations selected specifically with young people in mind. The quotations were selected from a wide range of sources, including children's literature, the Bible, songs, historical documents, advertising slogans, poems, folklore, speeches, interviews, and biographical works. Entries are easy to access because they are alphabetically arranged within the topics and are also indexed by subject and source. Cartoonlike illustrations add to the fun of this unusual book.
Author: J. A. Senn (compiler)

Title: Rabbit Hill
Annotation: The small animals who live at Rabbit Hill in the Connecticut countryside are excited when they hear that "big folks are coming" to inhabit the empty house on the property. The animals hope that the big folks will keep a proper garden to help maintain their lifestyle and watch carefully as the moving efforts begin. Each of the small creatures has a distinctive personality that adds spice and humor to this classic tale.
Author: Robert Lawson

Title: Rabbit, The
Annotation: The life cycle and activities of rabbits is presented in lyrical text and includes discussion about predators, mating, reproduction, as well as the growth and defenses of young rabbits. Soft paintings add to the charm of this book. Rabbit facts are also included. See other books in the Animal Lives series.
Author: Sally Tagholm

Title: Rachel Carson: Pioneer of Ecology
Annotation: This biography of Rachel Carson relates her development as a biologist and writer. Her work with ocean ecosystems is highlighted as well as her fight to create public awareness of the dangers of pesticides. See other books in the Women of Our Time series.
Author: Kathleen V. Kudlinski
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Rachel Field's Hitty: Her First Hundred Years
Annotation: This adaptation of the 1930 Newbery Award-winning book shortens the text, omits dialect and stereotypical labels, and adds new adventures to the memoirs of the carved wooden doll. The oversized format allows room for the illustrator's detailed gouache watercolors, which heighten the adventure and add historical, cultural, and geographical authenticity.
Author: Rosemary Wells

Title: Rachel's Journal: The Story of a Pioneer Girl
Annotation: This story relates the experiences of a young girl who travels with her family by wagon train from Illinois to California in 1850. During the journey Rachel keeps a journal, in the form of a lined book filled with sketches and cursive writing, to record the adventures and trials that she and her family experience along the way. Other journal books by this author are available. California author and setting.
Author: Marissa Moss

Title: Rachel: The Story of Rachel Carson
Annotation: This picture-book biography presents twelve one-page segments of the life of Rachel Carson, scientist, environmentalist, activist, and writer. The soft watercolor and gouache paintings and lyrical prose reflect nature while the theme reflects the impact of an advocate’s role in the preservation of the environment. Use this title to celebrate Earth Day, promote an environmental unit, introduce SILENT SPRING, or herald Women’s History month.
Author: Amy E. Ehrlich

Title: Raft, The
Annotation: A young boy is sent to spend the summer with his grandmother. There he gains an appreciation of the forest habitat and river wildlife he sees as he floats on a raft, and develops his own talent for drawing and painting. The natural environment along the Wisconsin river is shown in realistic pastel artwork.
Author: Jim LaMarche

Title: Ragtime Tumpie
Annotation: Tumpie, a young African American girl, dreams of being a dancer as she watches musicians on the streets of St. Louis in the early 1900s. Tumpie grows up to become the famous dancer Josephine Baker. California author.
Author: Alan Schroeder
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Railroad Fever
Annotation: The building of the Transcontinental Railroad is told through engaging text, illustrative borders, and a variety of illustrations, including vintage black-and-white photos and maps. This visually appealing book provides succinct text that covers the planning and building of the railroad and focuses on the workers and the working conditions. Includes a glossary and an index.
Author: Monica Halpern

Title: Rain Forest
Annotation: The fragile balance of nature is presented as animals, living peacefully in the tropical rain forest, witness machines invading their world. Striking full-color paintings helps to introduce the issue of conservation of natural resources and the fragility of nature.
Author: Helen Cowcher

Title: Rain Reign
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Rose Howard is a fifth grader obsessed with homonyms, rules, and routines. She lives with her hard-drinking single father and struggles with Asperger's syndrome but must break rules when a beloved dog becomes lost.
Author: Ann M. Martin
Topic: Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Drugs, Diversity, Personal and Community Health

Title: Rain, Rain, Rain Forest
Annotation: This book takes the reader on a journey through a rain forest, trailing a sloth, capuchin monkeys, and a poison-dart frog, to investigate the plants and animals that dwell there. The lyrical text incorporates a great deal of information. Onomatopoeia enhances the text by adding jungle sounds. Jenkins’s signature collage Illustrations enhance the text creatively.
Author: Brenda Z. Guiberson

Title: Rainbow and You, The
Annotation: This book provides a historical look at the importance of rainbows in ancient cultures, as well as giving the scientific perspective of why rainbows occur. The scientific explanations introduce the physical properties of light and color. Can be read aloud to assist student understanding of how sunlight shining through water forms the colors of the rainbow.
Author: Edwin C. Krupp
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Rainbow Bridge, The
Annotation: This Pourquoi tale tells how the Chumash people came to the mainland of California from their island, Limuw, and how the dolphins originated. Illustrated with lavish, dramatic paintings, this appealing read-aloud can be used to introduce children to the Native Americans of California. California author.
Author: Audrey Wood

Title: Rainbow Fish, The
Annotation: Shunned by the other fish when he refuses to give away even one of his beautiful scales, Rainbow Fish eventually learns to share and finds happiness in friendship. Watercolor paintings of fish are highlighted with shiny scales.
Translator: English: J. Alison James; Vietnamese: Nguyen Ngu
Author: Marcus Pfister

Title: Raisel's Riddle
Annotation: This Jewish holiday-themed version of the Cinderella story features an independent-thinking heroine and places emphasis on wisdom and virtue rather than on outward appearances. Raisel is portrayed as a scholar who prudently uses the wishes granted her. Instead of passing the traditional glass slipper test, she turns the tables and challenges the "prince" (rabbi's son) with a riddle! Large page-and-a-half illustrations vary in points-of-view, supporting this book's nontraditional telling of a familiar fairy tale. California author.
Author: Erica Silverman

Title: Ramona and Her Father
Annotation: Ramona is now in second grade, and life at home changes when her father loses his job. She begins to see the important role that she plays in her family. California author.
Author: Beverly Cleary

Title: Ramona la chinche (Ramona the Pest)
Annotation: Ramona Quimby is off to kindergarten and her world changes forever. Although she has endearing charms, Ramona still manages to get in trouble - she pulls Susan's curls, misunderstands her teacher's directions, and complains about the hand-me-down boots she must wear. This tale is one of a series about Ramona, all of which are timeless stories to read aloud. California author.
Author: Beverly Cleary

Title: Ramona the Pest
Annotation: Ramona Quimby is off to kindergarten and her world changes forever. Although she has endearing charms, Ramona still manages to get in trouble - she pulls Susan's curls, misunderstands her teacher's directions, and complains about the hand-me-down boots she must wear. This tale is one of a series about Ramona, all of which are timeless stories to read aloud. California author.
Author: Beverly Cleary

Title: Ramona's World
Annotation: Ramona is now in fourth grade, has a baby sister, meets her new best friend, and wishes that "Yard Ape" would take more notice of her. She learns that growing up can present some interesting challenges. California author.
Author: Beverly Cleary

Title: Random House Book of Poetry for Children: A Treasury of 572 Poems for Today's Child, The
Annotation: This collection, selected by poet and anthologist Jack Prelutsky, is divided into broad subject areas such as nature, seasons, living things, children, and home. The poems convey both humorous and serious information and are representative of a wide variety of contemporary and classic poets.
Author: Jack Prelutsky (selector)
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, Science

Title: Rap a Tap Tap: Here's Bojangles - Think of That!
Annotation: Rhyming text and vibrant illustrations make for a succinct picture book biography of tap dancer Bill "Bojangles" Robinson. An afterword summarizes the life of one of the most famous tap dancers of all time.
Author: Diane Dillon, Leo Dillon
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements

Title: Rapunzel
Annotation: The age-old tale of the imprisoned young girl with the exceptionally long hair is retold using elements from the early French, Italian, and the Brothers Grimm versions. Classical oil paintings in the style of the masters create an Italian Renaissance setting for the story. An author's note discussing the history of Rapunzel-themed stories is appended.
Author: Paul O. Zelinsky

Title: Rare Treasure: Mary Anning and Her Remarkable Discoveries
Annotation: This is a short biography of Mary Anning (1800-1847) who spent her life looking for and collecting fossils. It includes details about her discovery of an ichthyosaur fossil as well as many others. The soft watercolor illustrations detail the events in the life of this early female paleontologist. A brief description of how fossils form is included.
Author: Don Brown

Title: Rats on the Roof and Other Stories
Annotation: This collection of seven stories about animals who overcome obstacles features a frog with magnificent legs, a hungry brontosaurus, and a mouse who gets married. With a touch of satire, all the stories are fancifully and humorously illustrated.
Author: James Marshall

Title: Reaching for the Moon
Annotation: Aldrin presents an illustrated account of his life and the determination and experiences that led him to Apollo 11, the first mission to land men on the moon. Colorful and detailed illustrations support this selection; especially noteworthy are the images of Aldrin's space journeys. The book concludes with a brief chronology, that blends events in the history of flight and space exploration with a few events of Aldrin's life.
Author: Buzz Aldrin

Title: Read for Me, Mama
Annotation: The local librarian lets Joseph take two books at a time, one for him to read, and one for someone to read to him. The problem is that his mom cannot read. She finally faces that reality and seeks help to learn to read. This warm, compassionate story will show young readers that some adults share their struggle to learn to read. Use with Eve Bunting's THE WEDNESDAY SURPRISE.
Author: Vashanti Rahaman

Title: Real McCoy: The Life of an African American Inventor
Annotation: This book presents the biography of Canadian-born African American Elijah McCoy, who patented over 50 inventions, including his famous automatic oil cup that was widely imitated and distinguished as "the real McCoy." Acrylic paintings on canvas illustrate the significant events in his extraordinary life. An author's note adds background information.
Author: Wendy Towle

Title: Reason for a Flower, The
Annotation: This poetic presentation tells about plant reproduction, manufacturing of seeds, and seed propagation. It also shows plants which don't seem to be flowers but are flowers. The text is supported by Heller's trademark full-color detailed illustrations that help explain the concepts presented. California author/illustrator.
Author: Ruth Heller

Title: Reasons for Seasons, The
Annotation: This book explains how the position of the earth brings about the seasons and how the seasons affect people and animals. The author uses colorful pictures to explain seasons, solstices, and equinoxes. Labeled pictures show the earth's tilt and orbit.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Rechenka's Eggs
Annotation: Babushka, known for her exquisite hand-painted eggs, finds Rechenka, a wounded goose, and takes her home. When she's ready to try her wings again, Rechenka accidentally breaks all of Babushka's lovingly crafted eggs. But the next morning Babushka awakens to a miraculous surprise. The story is enhanced by illustrations of Ukrainian painted eggs.
Author: Patricia Polacco
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, Mathematics

Title: Red Bird SIngs: The Story of Zitkala-Sa, Native American Author, Musician, and Activist
Annotation: Zitkala-Sa Red Bird—aka Gertrude Simmons, a Sioux author, musician, and activist—was sent from her home on the reservation to be educated at a boarding school where Indian children were taught the ways of white Americans. She thrived in her new world but never forgot her Sioux roots, and she used her musical and writing talents to be an advocate for Native American rights. This book is illustrated with collages of newspaper clippings, railroad tickets, and other archival materials. Extensive source material is provided in an afterword, bibliography, and partial list of Zitkala-Sa’s writings, books, and Web sites for further study.
Author: Gina Capaldi, Q. L. Pearce
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: Red Book, The
Annotation: In this wordless story, a little girl finds a red book in the snow that holds an astonishing surprise. The bright artwork is simply drawn and incorporates geometric forms. Pair this title with ZOOM by Istvan Banyai (1995).
Author: Barbara Lehman

Title: Red Flower Goes West
Annotation: This story chronicles a family's cross-country trip to California during the Gold Rush and tells of the red geranium that becomes a symbol of good luck and survival. The family overcomes such hardships as a near-drowning, extreme thirst, and a treacherous crossing of the Sierra Nevada. Muted one-page paintings capture the events of the trip, while bright hues are reserved for the all-important geranium. California setting.
Author: Ann Warren Turner

Title: Red Rose Box, The
Annotation: On her tenth birthday, Leah receives a traveling case decorated with red roses from her glamorous Aunt Olivia. This is a touching story of a girl and her younger sister growing up between two worlds, the deep south of Louisiana and Los Angeles in the 1950s.
Author: Brenda Woods

Title: Red Sings from Treetops: A Year in Colors
Annotation: This book uses poetic text and mixed-media illustrations (in a folk-art style) to encourage the reader to experience the colors of the seasons through the senses. The detailed artwork hides many small stories that are waiting to be found. Use with older students as a model text for descriptive writing.
Author: Joyce Sidman

Title: Red, White, Blue, and Uncle Who? The Stories Behind Some of America’s Patriotic Symbols
Annotation: Tells the stories behind nearly 30 places, objects, documents, holidays, and other symbols of importance to America, including Plymouth Rock, the Liberty Bell, the Pledge of Allegiance, and Memorial Day. Illustrated with colorful artwork that has unexpected touches of humor. Light fare that might encourage readers to become researchers.
Author: Theresa Bateman
Standard: HSS 3.4, HSS 5.1, HSS 5.4, HSS 5.5, HSS 5.6, HSS 5.7

Title: Red-Eyed Tree Frog
Annotation: Close-up photographs depict the nocturnal adventures of a red-eyed tree frog. Simple text supports the frog's close encounters with predators.
Author: Joy Cowley

Title: Redcoats and Petticoats
Annotation: Members of a family in the village of Setauket, Long Island, are displaced by the Redcoats and serve as spies for Washington’s Revolutionary Army. The mother hangs petticoats and handkerchiefs on the clothesline as a code for relaying information to the Patriots across Long Island Sound. Illustrated with watercolor artwork and maps. Historical notes help make the story understandable for students learning about the American Revolution.
Author: Katherine Kirkpatrick

Title: Regarding the Bathrooms: A Privy to the Past
Annotation: This unique novel tells of a middle-school principal’s bathroom renovation project that leads to the discovery of stolen Roman antiquities. The story unfolds through letters, newspaper articles, and police reports. This humorous story features a colorful cast of characters, multiple mix-ups, and historical information about bathrooms stretching back to Roman times.
Author: Kate Klise
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Visual Arts, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Relampagos! (Wild Weather: Lightning!)
Annotation: This is an easy-to-read first chapter book which describes the power of lightning and its positive and negative effects on living things. It includes safety tips on what to do in case lightning strikes. The watercolor illustrations feature maps, diagrams, and action scenes. See other books in the Hola, Lector (Hello Reader!) series.
Author: Lorraine Jean Hopping
Classification: Early Chapter Book, Easy Reader, Picture Book

Title: Relatives Came, The
Annotation: When a carload of relatives arrives for a summer visit, the hosting family cannot tell one cousin from another. Everyone ends up having a wonderful time in this celebration of family affection. The book's vivid illustrations are whimsical and convey the story's hectic nature.
Author: Cynthia Rylant

Title: Reluctant Dragon, The
Annotation: This is a classic story about friendship, compassion, and loyalty retold with humor and engaging dialogue. After Jack's father finds a fire-breathing dragon nearby, Jack discovers the dragon is really a gentle, poetic giant who would rather read and write than fight knights and breathe fire. The miniature, watercolor paintings add to the growing camaraderie between Jack and the Dragon and the satisfying conclusion. California author. Good read-aloud.
Author: Robert D. San Souci

Title: Remainder of One, A
Annotation: When the queen of the bugs demands that her army march in even lines, Private Joe divides the marchers into more and more lines so that he will not be left out of the formations as the remainder of one. The rhyming text is illustrated in a linocut-style art utilizing dusky colors. As they practice division, students can try forming equal lines with other numbers and see what remains.
Author: Elinor J. Pinczes

Title: Remarkable Benjamin Franklin, The
Annotation: An illustrated biography of Benjamin Franklin, highlighting his childhood, achievements, and participation in America’s bid for independence. Detailed watercolor artwork accompanied by quotes and captions, along with lively text, makes this book exceptional. Includes a time line of Franklin’s life and accomplishments.
Author: Cheryl Harness

Title: Remarkable Farkle McBride, The
Annotation: Young Farkle McBride is musically gifted. He tries a number of instruments before he discovers that conducting the orchestra makes him happy. Cartoon drawings present the different musical instruments Farkle tries before the big finish: a fold-out drawing of an orchestra.
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
Author: John Lithgow
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.5

Title: Remember Valley Forge: Patriots, Tories, and Redcoats Tell Their Stories
Annotation: Letters, journal entries, reports, photographs, and maps are used to tell the true story of the survival of General George Washington’s Continental Army while camped at Valley Forge, Pennsylvania, during the American Revolution. The experience is examined from the perspectives of different characters: a teenage soldier, a doctor, a farmer, and a spy.
Author: Thomas B. Allen

Title: Remember: The Journey to School Integration
Annotation: A selection of archival photographs document events surrounding the integration of U.S. schools following the 1954 Supreme Court decision in Brown v. Board of Education. The book includes captions in which Toni Morrison imagines what the people in the pictures might have been thinking and feeling.
Author: Toni Morrison
Standard: HSS K.6, HSS 1.4, HSS 3.4, HSS 11.10, HSS G 12.10

Title: Remembering Mrs. Rossi
Annotation: Eight-year-old Annie and her father struggle to cope after the unexpected death of her mother and his wife. When the students from her mother’s sixth-grade class share their scrapbook memories with Annie and Mr. Rossi, it helps. Illustrated with occasional ink sketches. A gracious, sensitive book about life and death.
Author: Amy Hest

Title: Respiracion, La (Respiration)
Annotation: This book describes the respiratory system of humans and some animals. It includes a discussion of the cellular structures, organs, and actual process of how respiration occurs. Information on what happens during exercise and if the respiratory system is threatened (as in smoking) is also provided as related health issues. See other books in the Fenomenos Naturales (Natural Phenomenon) series.
Author: Luci Cruz Wilson

Title: Rhyolite: The True Story of a Ghost Town
Annotation: Told through poetry, this is the story of the rise and fall of Rhyolite, Nevada, which began as a small mining camp with only one gold claim and grew to a town of 10,000 people at the turn of the twentieth century. After just a few years, financial woes caused the mine to shut down, and the town was quickly deserted. Illustrated with detailed woodcuts rendered in browns and golds.
Author: Diane Siebert

Title: Ribbons
Annotation: Robin is told that she must give up her passion - ballet lessons - in order for her parents to save money to bring her grandmother to the United States. When Robin tries to practice on her own and damages her feet, the experience gives her insight into the suffering of her grandmother, who, as a child in China, had her feet bound. This story carries a strong message about overcoming cultural and intergenerational misunderstandings. California author and setting.
Author: Laurence Yep
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Richard Wright and the Library Card
Annotation: This story is based on a scene from Richard Wright's autobiography Black Boy. Seventeen-year-old Wright borrows a white man's library card and reads constantly, knowing that reading will be his ticket to freedom.
Author: William Miller

Title: Rickie and Henri: A True Story
Annotation: Orphaned and stolen by poachers in Central Africa, Rickie, an infant chimpanzee, is saved by a kind stranger and adopts Henri, a shaggy dog, as her "mother." The expressive paintings in this book are detailed and show a range of emotions from terror to joy. Goodall includes an afterword asking for support in the work of her sanctuary.
Author: Jane Goodall

Title: Riddle of Penncroft Farm, The
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Lars Olafson is miserable when he has to move to Valley Forge, Pennsylvania, to live with his Aunt Cass at an old family farm. Penncroft Farm is full of puzzles. With the help of his new friend Geordie, the ghost of an eighteenth-century ancestor who tells stories of the Revolutionary War, Lars is able to solve the mystery of a missing will.
Author: Dorothea Jensen

Title: Ride Like the Wind: A Tale of the Pony Express
Annotation: Known for their courage, self-confidence, speed, and willingness to face adversity, the riders of the Pony Express quickly became legendary heroes. Dramatic oil paintings by award-winning artist Bernie Fuchs capture the spirit, strength and stamina of one young rider, Johnny Free, as he and his beloved pony, JennySoo, face an unusually dangerous journey. Includes front and endnotes about the Pony Express and the Paiute Indian people.
Author: Bernie Fuchs

Title: Ride the Wind: Airborne Journeys of Animals and Plants
Annotation: Attractive watercolor illustrations enhance the text of this engaging introduction to animal migration and plant seed dispersal. The animals covered include birds, bats, butterflies, insects, and spiders. This is a companion to THEY SWIM THE SEAS: THE MYSTERY OF ANIMAL MIGRATION and THEY WALK THE EARTH: THE EXTRAORDINARY TRAVELS OF ANIMALS ON LAND.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Riding Freedom
Annotation: Charley (Charlotte) Parkhurst ran away from an orphanage in the mid-nineteenth century, posed as a boy, moved to California as a stagecoach driver, and fooled everyone by her appearance. Based on a true story, this book about Charley's life has interesting connections to California history. California author and setting.
Author: Pam Munoz Ryan

Title: Right Word: Roget and His Thesaurus, The
Annotation: Peter Mark Roget was born in England in 1879. A shy, studious, and creative child, he began his first book when only eight, starting with Latin words and their English meanings, and eventually creating lists of words and ideas organized by themes and categories. His first thesaurus was published in 1852 and has remained in print ever since.
Author: Jennifer Bryant
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General , English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary
Award: Caldecott Honor, Robert F. Sibert Award

Title: Rio, El (River Life)
Annotation: River life is shown through spectacular full-color photographs and plastic overlays that include detailed close-up views of animals and plants in their natural habitat. This book will spark young readers' interest in water habitats, such as rock pools, ponds, rivers, and meadows.
Author: Barbara Taylor

Title: Rio, El (The River)
Annotation: This is one in the series Mundo Maravilloso (A First Discovery Book) dealing with various math and science topics. In this title, the simple text introduces rivers. The reader can explore how rivers are formed and how they flow. It also describes the life within and along the riparian habitat.
Author: Gallimard Jeunesse, Laura Bour

Title: Rip Van Winkle’s Return
Annotation: An adaptation of Washington Irving’s classic story in which a man who sleeps in the Catskill Mountains for 20 years awakens to find that the world has changed significantly. In this version, Van Winkle redeems himself, rebuilding his old house and mending his ways. The illustrations indicate that the 20 years he slept ended at about the same time that the American Revolution was under way.
Author: Eric A. Kimmel

Title: River God Gets Married, The
Annotation: This is an illustrated retelling of a classic Chinese legend written in traditional Chinese.
Author: Hui Fen Pan, Xiu Ling Zhan

Title: River of Words: The Story of William Carlos Williams, A
Annotation: Told in lyrical text, this picture-book biography of American poet–doctor William Carlos Williams begins with his New Jersey childhood. He loved to roam outside and “watched everything.” Poetry was his gift and passion; however, realizing he needed a vocation, he went to study medicine at age nineteen. Although he practiced medicine, Williams continued to write poetry. Collages and use of ephemera match the text beautifully. A time line, author’s note, and illustrator’s note are included.
Author: Jennifer Bryant

Title: River Ran Wild: An Environmental History, A
Annotation: This book traces the environmental history of the Nashua River from the time a group of Native Americans settled there through the present. The story focuses on the impact of civilization on the river, the resulting pollution, and how a group of activists were able to clean up the water. The full-color paintings are bordered with miniature illustrations of local wildlife, artifacts, and scenes.
Author: Lynne Cherry

Title: Road to Revolution!
Annotation: Nick and Penny are fictional teenagers living in Boston in 1775. They help Paul Revere and the patriots take on the British soldiers who have occupied their city. This entertaining graphic novel mixes fact with fiction to tell the story of the early events of America’s Revolutionary War. Notes at the beginning and end of the book clearly separate fact from fiction. Part of the “Cartoon Chronicles of America” series.
Author: Stan Mack, Susan Champlin

Title: Roanoke: The Lost Colony—An Unsolved Mystery from History
Annotation: Chronicles the history of the Roanoke colony and offers possible explanations for its mysterious disappearance. Students will learn good research techniques as they are asked to decide what they think really happened. Includes bibliographical references.
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
Author: Heidi Elisabet Yolen Stemple, Jane Yolen

Title: Robin Makes a Laughing Sound: a Birder’s Journal, The
Annotation: Children and adults get a glimpse of a birder’s journal through the author’s observational notes and draft sketches. Rich watercolor artwork accompanies poetic narratives and field notes about a variety of birds and their environment. Use as a model text for student journals. It contains much concrete information about backyard birds and their behaviors.
Author: Sallie Wolf
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: Robot Zoo (Robot Zoo)
Annotation: In an unusual approach to body structures and shapes, this book relates 16 mechanical robots to their real-life counterparts and how they move and function. Color illustrations and brief descriptions help students understand the biomechanics of animals.
Translator: Franca Jorda and Begona Arrizabalaga Franca Jorda and Begona Arrizabalaga
Author: John Kelly, Phillip Whitfield

Title: Rocas y minerales (Rocks and Minerals)
Annotation: This illustrated text examines creation, and the importance and uses of rocks and minerals. Other books in the Todas las Maneras de Ver (Seeing Things in Different Ways) series include VOLCANOES (VOLCANOES), EL TIEMPO (WEATHER), and EL SISTEMA SOLAR (THE SOLAR SYSTEM).
Author: Jane Walker

Title: Rodzina
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Rodzina Clara Jadwiga Anatazya Brodski is an orphan whose only home is the Little Wanderers' Refuge in Chicago. When she is told she is going west on an Orphan Train, Rodzina is sure that a family will not want a large, unpretty, standoffish girl to love, but they want a slave instead. California author.
Author: Karen Cushman

Title: Roller Girl
Annotation: For most of her twelve years, Astrid has done everything with her best friend Nicole. But after Astrid falls in love with roller derby and signs up for derby camp, Nicole decides to go to dance camp instead. And so begins the most difficult summer of Astrid’s life as she struggles to keep up with the older girls at camp, hang on to the friend she feels slipping away, and cautiously embark on a new friendship. As the end of summer nears and her first roller derby bout (and junior high!) draws closer, Astrid realizes that maybe she is strong enough to handle the bout, a lost friendship, and middle school... in short, strong enough to be a roller girl.
Author: Victoria Jamieson

Title: Roman Numerals I to MM
Annotation: This title introduces Roman numerals. By counting pigs in the illustrations, the reader's understanding of the mathematical concept is reinforced. Later pages in the book challenge readers to decipher roman numerals that have been combined to create useful numbers. Deciphering can be accomplished either by using the Roman system or by counting the objects in the pictures. The book's etchings, tinted with washes, make for lively illustrations in this unusual book.
Author: Arthur Geisert

Title: Romare Bearden: Collage of Memories
Annotation: This picture book biography illustrates the lifetime memories of Romare Bearden through his collages. His bold art form shows the influences of his childhood in the South, life in New York and Paris, and his love of jazz. Includes author's note, important dates, bibliography, text notes, glossary, and some places to view artwork by Romare Bearden.
Author: Jan Greenberg

Title: Romina’s Rangoli
Annotation: When the teacher asks each student to bring something to school that reflects his or her heritage, Romina struggles over how to represent both her father’s Indian culture and her mother’s Mexican culture. Her solution is to make a design reflecting an Indian art form (Rangoli) but use a traditional Mexican medium (papel picado). Notes provide additional information on Rangoli and papel picado. California author.
Author: Malathi Michelle Iyengar
Culture: East Indian/East Indian American, Latino/Latino American, Multicultural
Topic: Ethnic Studies, Visual Arts, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Root Cellar, The
Annotation: Rose, a twelve-year-old orphan, sets out to live with relatives in an old farmhouse in Ontario, Canada. There she discovers an old root cellar, where she is transported back to the world of the late 1860s. This novel combines history with fantasy to make the American Civil War come alive. Available in paperback or prebind.
Author: Janet Lunn

Title: Roots and Blues: A Celebration
Annotation: Poetry and vignettes celebrate the blues, a uniquely American form of music created by slaves and carried on by their descendants to tell the stories of their lives. The 60 free-verse poems flow like music, with rhythmic spacing and slides, which makes them as interesting to look at as they are to read. Colorful paintings honor the artists who sang the blues. Notable Book for a Global Society (2012); NCSS Notable Trade Book (2011).
Author: Arnold Adoff
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: Rough, Tough Charley
Annotation: Told in rhyming text, this is the true story of Charley Parkhurst, an orphan who became a fearless and respected stagecoach driver in the Old West. Charley disguised herself as a man for the duration of her life, demonstrating that a female can work successfully in a job and vote. Oil-painting illustrations enhance this engaging read-aloud. Includes a time line.
Author: Verla Kay

Title: Ruby Holler
Annotation: Thirteen-year-old twins, Dallas and Florida, have grown up in an orphanage and are convinced they're clumsy, stupid, and unlovable until they are taken in by Sairy and Tiller. Time, patience, plenty of home-cooked food, and caring prove to the twins that they are worthy of love. Filled with humor, adventure, mischief, mystery, and good will, this book is an entertaining read.
Author: Sharon Creech

Title: Ruby’s Wish
Annotation: After the California Gold Rush, Ruby’s grandfather returns to China to set up a household and raise a family. Despite a culture that expects girls to keep house and raise children, little Ruby has other plans. She does not want to settle for anything less than her dream to go to a university. With love and respect, she shares her wish with Grandfather, who gives her a bright red packet of “lucky money.” Asian-inspired illustrations enhance the story.
Author: Shirin Yim Bridges
Topic: Diversity, International Studies/World History, Lifestyles Around the World, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, Women’s Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products
Standard: HSS K.6, HSS 1.1, HSS 1.4, HSS 2.1, HSS 2.5, HSS 4.3

Title: Run Away Home
Annotation: Set in 1886 Alabama, this story tells of an eleven-year-old African American girl and her family befriending and giving refuge to a runaway Apache boy. He shows his loyalty when bad times visit the family.
Author: Patricia C. McKissack

Title: Runt
Annotation: Runt is the smallest wolf cub of the litter and seeks to prove himself to his father and the rest of the pack. He survives an encounter with a porcupine that kills his brother, and he ultimately rescues the pack, earning a new name. The author vividly presents the wild world of wolves: their habitat, hierarchical relationships, behavior, and culture.
Author: Marion Dane Bauer

Title: Rushmore
Annotation: The monument at Mount Rushmore, South Dakota, honors four American presidents in majestic fashion. This book describes how this patriotic shrine and tourist attraction was conceived, designed, and created by the dedicated artist Gutzon Borglum.
Author: Lynn Curlee
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Ruth Law Thrills a Nation
Annotation: In 1916, aviation pioneer Ruth Law broke the existing records for nonstop air travel in the United States by flying from Chicago to New York. The author uses primary-source material to retell Law’s amazing achievement. This picture book features full-page illustrations done with pen and ink and watercolors.
Author: Don Brown

Title: S Is for S’mores: A Camping Alphabet
Annotation: This ABC rhyming book features topics related to camping, such as s’mores, canyons, parks, and zippers. Each page layout presents a word with a camping theme set in a rhyme form and accompanied by a wonderful illustration and information about the topic.
Author: Helen Foster James

Title: S Is for Scientists: A Discovery Alphabet
Annotation: Stories about scientists and scientific methods are presented in an alphabetical format. Topics range from aviation to zoology, and the book includes terms that are useful for all scientists—such as “compare,” “adapt,” and “build.” Poems highlight science skills such as proving, questioning, and recording. Sidebars provide narrative material about scientists who have made significant discoveries. An NSTA Outstanding Science Book (2011).
Author: Larry Verstraete

Title: Sabertooth
Annotation: This informative and clearly written book describes the evolution of several different saber-tooth cat species and shows comparisons with contemporary cats. Information about other prehistoric animals is included, as is text about the La Brea Tar Pits. The book highlights the important role that archaeologists play in finding and identifying fossils. Realistic watercolor illustrations of these ferocious animals fit in well with the text. Share with reluctant readers. An NSTA Outstanding Science Trade Book (2009).
Author: Patrick O’Brien

Title: Sable
Annotation: When a stray dog shows up on the front porch of her Vermont farmhouse, Tate Marshall is delighted because she has always wanted a dog. But when Sable, named for her dark, silky fur, starts roaming, the neighbors become irate, and Sable has to go. Tate, however, has her heart set on getting her beloved dog back.
Author: Karen Hesse

Title: Sachiko Means Happiness
Annotation: A Japanese girl is frustrated when she helps take care of her grandmother, who has Alzheimer's disease. Sachiko expresses honest feelings of frustration and anger as she sees the changes that affect her grandmother. Soft pastel drawings are accented with Japanese banners.
Author: Kimiko Sakai

Title: Sad Underwear and Other Complications: More Poems for Children and Their Parents
Annotation: This companion book to IF I WERE IN CHARGE OF THE WORLD includes fairytale pieces of a more reflective nature. It presents 48 poems written from a young person's perspective and poking fun at school, rules, bathrooms, manners, and the like.
Author: Judith Viorst

Title: Sadako
Annotation: Hospitalized with the dreaded atom bomb disease, leukemia, a child in Hiroshima races against time to fold one thousand paper cranes to verify the legend that by doing so a sick person will become healthy. There are two publications of this story: this picture book illustrated version by Ed Young, and the original early chapter book.
Author: Eleanor B. Coerr

Title: Sadako and the Thousand Paper Cranes
Annotation: This tale is based on the true story of Sadako Sasaki, who is hospitalized with the "atom bomb disease," leukemia. She races against time to fold 1,000 paper cranes, an act which according to legend, will make her well again.
Author: Eleanor B. Coerr

Title: Saint Louis Armstrong Beach
Annotation: A young African American musician named Saint narrates this moving novel. Saint earns money by playing his clarinet for tourists in New Orleans. When Hurricane Katrina threatens his city, he refuses to leave until he can find his dog Shadow. Saint, Shadow, and an elderly neighbor find themselves trapped by floodwaters. The story highlights the speed with which the hurricane shattered the lives of so many people in New Orleans, but it ends with a message of hope.
Author: Brenda Woods

Title: Saladin: Noble Prince of Islam
Annotation: This biography depicts the life of Saladin, an influential Muslim leader and sultan who led his people during the time of the twelfth-century Crusades. It discusses the Crusades and the political and religious history of the Middle East and Western Europe. The author's detailed color paintings are inspired from Islamic art of the period. The text includes a glossary and a bibliography.
Author: Diane Stanley

Title: Salamander Room, The
Annotation: A young boy finds a salamander and thinks about what he needs to do to make a perfect home for it. The boy's room eventually turns into a forest, leading him to the understanding that wild animals need to be kept in their natural habitat. This selection provides a context in which to discuss ecology, observation, and wild animals in captivity.
Author: Anne Mazer

Title: Salem Witch Trials: An Unsolved Mystery from History, The
Annotation: In 1692, a group of young girls in Salem, Massachusetts, had seizures and came down with mysterious illnesses. Local officials determined that they were under a spell of witchcraft, and the frenzied hunting for local witches began. The young narrator of this book invites students to become detectives and decide for themselves what really happened.
Author: Heidi Elisabet Yolen Stemple, Jane Yolen
Topic: American History, Women’s Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Sallie Fox: The Story of a Pioneer Girl
Annotation: The journey from Keosauqua, Iowa, to Vacaville, California, in the 1850s was a hard one for Sallie Fox’s family. Based on a true story, this historical novel paints a picture of determined people working diligently for the good of everyone. Quotes from Sallie Fox’s diary bring the story to life. California author.
Author: Dorothy Kupcha Leland

Title: Sally and the Limpet
Annotation: Sally is playing at the beach when she pries a shell off a rock. The shell belongs to a creature called a limpet, which immediately suctions itself onto Sally's finger and won't let go. Nothing will remove the limpet from her finger until she remembers hearing that limpets live in the sea. Sally jumps into the sea and the limpet immediately releases itself from her finger. Watercolor washes and whimsical pen-and-ink drawings enhance the text nicely. The message conveyed is that creatures need their native environment to survive.
Author: Simon James

Title: Salmon Stream
Annotation: The struggle for survival and the multiple threats to the life cycle of the Pacific salmon is captured in this poetic offering. The importance of each creature in the web of life is emphasized. The book is illustrated with lush, detailed paintings and concludes with an appendix of additional information. See other books in the Sharing Nature with Children series.
Author: Carol Reed-Jones

Title: Saltypie: A Choctaw Journey from Darkness into Light
Annotation: Choctaw storyteller Tim Tingle presents a narrative that honors his grandmother, who was rendered blind by an act of violence, and the power of family during times of crisis. Can be used as a read-aloud or as a picture book for older readers. May lead to discussions about bullying, stereotypes, invented words, blindness, Native Americans, and extended families. Author’s notes provide background information about the Choctaw nation as well as ideas for using the book in classroom lessons. California illustrator.
Author: Tim Tingle
Topic: Diversity, Personal and Community Health, Religion/Spirituality

Title: Sam and the Lucky Money
Annotation: Sam must decide how to spend his "lucky money" from Chinese New Year. As he wavers between his choices, one seems just right. This selection is useful in language arts prediction lessons. This thoughtful tale of generosity shows the colorful locals and the festival dragon.
Author: Karen Chinn

Title: Sam Johnson and the Blue Ribbon Quilt
Annotation: Sam mends the awning over the pig pen and discovers that he enjoys sewing. He asks to join his wife’s quilting club and is subjected to ridicule. Despite rejection, he organizes his own sewing circle. The story depicts life on a farm long ago and examines gender roles. The quilt patterns illustrated in the borders of the pages and in the quilts provide an opportunity to discuss plane shapes, tessellations, right angles, and fractions.
Author: Lisa Campbell Ernst

Title: Same Sun Here
Annotation: River Dean Justice lives in the mountains of eastern Kentucky. Meena Joshi now lives in New York City’s Chinatown, but she is a native of northern India. Through a pen-pal relationship, these two middle-school students overcome their stereotypes of each other’s culture and come to see that they have a lot in common.
Author: Neela Vaswani, Silas House

Title: Samuel Eaton's Day: A Day in the Life of a Pilgrim Boy
Annotation: A six-year-old Pilgrim boy describes a busy spring day in 1627 doing chores, getting to know his Wampanoag Indian neighbors, and spending time with his family. The book was photographed in full-color on the Plimoth Plantation living history museum and is told in first-person narrative. Notes about the roles and the museum are included.
Author: Kate Waters
Classification: Photo Essay, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Sand
Annotation: This title presents a clever look at the formation of sand from such materials as coral, rock, or crystals as well as how sand moves from one location to another. A seagull disguised as a sleuth describes the information as it surfs, river rafts, and ice climbs. This is a highly engaging and informative book.
Author: Ellen J. Prager

Title: Sangre, huesos, y otros pedazos del cuerpo (Blood, Bones, and Body Bits)
Annotation: Scientific information about the human body is offered in an engaging format for the middle school crowd in this title from a series. The science of things which some would consider gross, disgusting, or repulsive are explained to the reader. Cartoonlike drawings accompany the text. The book includes details about diseases, body odors, and body pain. This book should be reviewed by an adult to determine appropriateness for specific readers. See other books in the Esa Horrible Ciencia (Horrible Science) series.
Author: Nick Arnold
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Sapo y Sepo son amigos (Frog and Toad Are Friends)
Annotation: Five tales about the adventures of two best friends are presented with humor, style, and distinctive animal illustrations. Frog and Toad quarrel, make up, share, plan projects, and have fun in this easy-reading book. Soft illustrations in tones of browns and greens are used throughout the stories.
Author: Arnold Lobel

Title: Sarah Morton's Day; A Day in the Life of a Pilgrim Girl
Annotation: A typical day in the life of a young pilgrim girl is examined as she milks goats, cooks and serves meals, learns her letters, and adjusts to her new stepfather. This full-color photo-essay was staged at the Plimoth Plantation living history museum. Notes about the roles and the museum as well as a glossary are included.
Author: Kate Waters

Title: Sarah, Plain and Tall
Annotation: This short novel, rich in language, images, and emotions, tells the story of a nineteenth-century "mail order bride" who comes to the vast prairie and decides to stay as wife to papa, and mother to young Caleb and Anna. First in a series of books about Sarah and her family.
Author: Patricia MacLachlan

Title: Satchel Paige
Annotation: The life of the legendary baseball player, the first African American to pitch in a Major League World Series, is examined in this sports biography. Its informal, anecdotal style makes the book a good read-aloud book. Limitations imposed on black players of the day are mentioned.
Author: Lesa Cline-Ransome

Title: Save Queen of Sheba
Annotation: Two children miraculously survive a raid of their wagon train by Sioux Indians on the trail to Oregon. Twelve-year-old King David finds the courage and energy to take care of his sister, Queen of Sheba, as he manages to cross the barren plains to find the remaining settlers. Available in paperback or prebind. California author.
Author: Louise Moeri

Title: Saving the Buffalo
Annotation: This book provides vivid details on the history of the buffalo, telling how the animals came close to extinction in the nineteenth century, discussing the various causes, and explaining their slow recovery and the efforts of early conservationists. Illustrated with a wide variety of primary sources, photographs, and period paintings.
Author: Albert Marrin

Title: Saving the Liberty Bell
Annotation: Based on an actual episode in American history, this book tells how a young boy prevented the British army from capturing the Liberty Bell in 1777. When British soldiers were looking for metal to melt down and reshape as cannons, the Liberty Bell was smuggled to safety in a farmer’s cart. The story is told from the perspective of young Johnny Mickley, who was part of the group that hid the bell until the end of the war. With full-color, cartoon-style illustrations, this is a good read-aloud for introducing a unit on the Revolutionary War. California author.
Author: Megan McDonald

Title: Scarlet Stockings Spy, The
Annotation: A young spy living in Philadelphia in 1777 demonstrates her courage, loyalty, and dedication during the American Revolution by communicating secret information to General Washington’s army, using a clever code. The story involves the death of the heroine’s brother, a soldier fighting in Washington’s army—but the subject is handled compassionately. A suspenseful book with beautiful illustrations.
Author: Trinka Hakes Noble

Title: School at Crooked Creek, The
Annotation: Six-year-old Beansie lives on the Indiana frontier in the nineteenth century with his parents and irritable older sister, Louise. He dreads his first day of school, but his resilience surprises even his sister. This chapter book presents a young boy’s perspective on frontier struggles and is illustrated with lovely black-and-white drawings.
Author: Laurie Lawlor

Title: School Story, The
Annotation: After twelve-year-old Natalie writes a wonderful novel, her friend Zoe helps her devise a scheme to get it accepted at the publishing house where Natalie's mother works as an editor. Children will be drawn quickly into the story's action as the girls plan, connive, write, rewrite, and ultimately celebrate the book's publication.
Author: Andrew Clements

Title: Science and Technology
Annotation: This book documents achievements in both science and technology through the ages. It will encourage students to explore science and technology through its use of rich illustration, timelines, photographs, and historical concepts. See other books in the Exploring History series.
Author: John Farndon
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)
