Title: Science Verse
Annotation: In this picture book a teacher tells his students that they can hear the poetry of science in everything. One student is struck with a science curse, and he hears nothing but science verses that sound very much like some well-known poems. A CD with readings and singing of verses and additional poems is included. Select a poem to introduce a science topic rather than read the whole book out loud. It addresses evolution but contains limited scientific facts.
Author: Jon Scieszka
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Scooter
Annotation: Elana Rose Rosen copes with divorce, moves to a new apartment in New York City, and becomes a member of a diverse community. This story's first-person narrative allows readers to experience "Lanny's" life right alongside her as she makes new friends and practices favorite scooter tricks. Childlike authenticity is added by hand-lettered acrostics that open each chapter, and the book includes recipes and basic, black-and-white illustrations.
Author: Vera B. Williams

Title: Score One for the Sloths
Annotation: Sparky, a new energetic student at a sloth school, saves her lazy classmates when a wild boar from a government agency tries to shut the school down. Words and humorous pictures full of detail set the scene in this farce that is packed with silly puns. The puns and humor make this a read-aloud choice.
Author: Helen Lester

Title: Sea Clocks: The Story of Longitude
Annotation: This title is a well-written narrative on the struggles and achievement of John Harrison, the British clock maker who solved the “biggest scientific problem of the eighteenth century.” He discovered how longitude can be determined on a moving ship, but it took 40 years for him to receive recognition for his discovery. The fine pen-and-ink, detailed drawings lend information and visual pleasure to this excellent book. An afterword explains the fate of significant people in this story; another page lists related facts of interest.
Author: Louise Borden
Standard: HSS 5.2, HSS 7.11, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.G.1-6

Title: Sea Critters
Annotation: This well-designed introduction to some of the groupings of ocean animals including jellyfish, worms, corals, anemones, scallops, and squids. Each double-page format shows a grouping that is illustrated with a full-color photograph, full-color drawings, and brief, explanatory text. See other books in the National Geographic Society series. California author.
Author: Sylvia A. Earle

Title: Sea of Tranquility, The
Annotation: A young boy's interest in space and space travel is captured in a simple, flowing text accompanied by full-page illustrations. While the text does not contain scientific facts about space, it depicts his interest in an important scientific and historic event, man's first moon walk. Can be used to introduce children to a unit on space or ways they can pursue their scientific interests.
Author: Mark Haddon

Title: Sea Soup: Phytoplankton
Annotation: The role and importance of phytoplankton in the marine food chain is clearly explained. Each section in the book answers a question and is illustrated with bright, full-color photographs. The volume includes excellent microscopic views of phytoplankton. A paperback companion SEA SOUP: TEACHER'S GUIDE by Betsy T. Stevens is also available.
Author: Mary M. Cerullo

Title: Sea Squares
Annotation: The realistic illustrations of animals in the ocean accompany rhyming lessons in counting and squaring numbers. Children can predict what comes next by studying the borders on each page. The book concludes with factual information on each animal.
Author: Joy N. Hulme
Standard: LS K.2, LS 1.2, LS 2.2, LS 3.3, LS 4.3, Math K.CC.1-7, Math K.OA.1-5, Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 4.OA.1-5

Title: Sea Turtles
Annotation: This title introduces young readers to several species of sea turtles, including the hawksbill, loggerhead, green sea turtle, Australian flatback, and leatherback. The author provides general information about this reptile family, including notable physical characteristics, life cycle, and adaptations to life in saltwater. A valuable feature is a two-page spread identifying the differences between a sea turtle and a terrestrial turtle. This is a useful resource for beginning report writers.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Sea Within a Sea: Secrets of the Sargasso, A
Annotation: This book explores the folklore and biology of the Sargasso Sea with rhyming text and illustrations. It begins on the surface with Columbus's voyage, and then travels underwater to explore the sea's fascinating creatures. The dramatic double-page spreads are in full-color and detail this unique environment. California author/ illustrator.
Author: Ruth Heller

Title: Sea, the Storm, and the Mangrove Tangle, The
Annotation: The life cycle of a mangrove, from a seedling to an island, is presented in this richly illustrated picture book. The fish, birds, and sea creatures that use the mangrove for food and shelter are featured and identified. The importance of the mangrove in the ecological chain and the mangrove's endangered status are described in the introduction and author's note.
Author: Lynne Cherry

Title: Sea: Exploring Life on an Ocean Planet, The
Annotation: This dramatic photo-essay is combined with interesting textual commentary to create pleasing visual and informative reading for students interested in the dangers, beauty, and mysteries of the sea. The contents cover a broad range of topics, including fish and sea mammals, storms, shipwrecks, environmental issues, fishing, scuba diving, and surfing.
Author: Robert Burleigh

Title: Search for the Golden Moon Bear: Science and Adventure in the Asian Tropics
Annotation: Montgomery shares the story of her dangerous journeys throughout Southeast Asia with evolutionary biologist Gary Galbreath. The journeys were undertaken to search for the golden moon bear and for evidence that would prove whether the golden moon bear was a previously unknown species or a subspecies. Illustrated with clear, crisp full-color photographs, the text includes information on DNA decoding and on mammals recently discovered in Southeast Asia. Statistics and suggested Web sites are included. This book is a part of the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Sy Montgomery

Title: Season of Gifts, A
Annotation: A companion to A LONG WAY FROM CHICAGO (1998) and A YEAR DOWN YONDER (2000), this story has heart, humor, and wisdom. The new preacher’s family moves next door to Mrs. (Grandma) Dowdel, a larger-than-life neighbor whose mischievous antics add hilarity to the events of the story. The preacher’s family is the recipient of Grandma’s kindness, which is doled out secretly. Readers do not need to be familiar with Peck’s other books to enjoy this work. Highly recommended as a read-aloud.
Author: Richard Peck

Title: Sebastian: A Book about Bach
Annotation: A simple, picture-book biography of the life of Bach written in an understandable style. The text presents interesting facts about his life and tells of his love for and devotion to his music. The illustrations have a simple quality as well; they are like squares in a quilt, rendered in bright colors.
Author: Jeanette Winter
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Secret Garden, The
Annotation: Ten-year-old Mary, a spoiled and sour child, has not known love or discipline. She moves to her uncle's house in Yorkshire, England, after the death of her parents. There she discovers the mysteries hidden away in his dark and gloomy estate. Mary and Collin continue to be classic characters 85 years after their creation. This work is also available on audiocassette.
Author: Frances Hodgson Burnett

Title: Secret Letters from 0 to 10
Annotation: Ernest leads an unadventurous and routine life until he meets Victoria, who teaches him about families, living, and loving. Translated from French, this title has won 16 international awards, including France's Prix Totem.
Author: Susie Morgenstern

Title: Secret Place
Annotation: A young boy discovers a secret place in the city where a river flows and is hidden between two concrete walls. He decides to keep this place a secret because it attracts a variety of wild animals who come to nest and drink. The poetic text is complemented by lush paintings that contrast the gray city with the wild creatures. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: Secret School, The
Annotation: In 1925, fourteen-year-old Ida Bidson secretly takes over as the teacher of the remote one-room schoolhouse after the trained teacher quits. Ida's dream is to become a teacher, but in order to do that she must pass entrance exams to high school at the end of the year. Could Ida be the "secret" teacher to all of the students for the rest of the year? An inspiring story about finding a way to follow a dream. California author.
Author: - Avi

Title: Secret Science Alliance and the Copycat Crook, The
Annotation: Julian Calendar wants to fit into his new school by shedding his reputation as a science nerd. Obviously unable to do so, he is recruited by popular jock Ben Garza and “bad girl” Greta Hughes to join their secret science club. Together the trio, housed in a secret lab, work diligently on their inventions. After their blueprints are stolen by an evil scientist, they embark on a wild adventure. This graphic novel’s fast-paced action, detailed illustrations, and scientific facts help to make science cool.
Author: Eleanor Davis
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Secret Science Project That Almost Ate the School, The
Annotation: Told in verse, this is a silly read-aloud book about a little girl who sends off for "Professor Swami's Super Slime" to use as her science fair project. When she sets the slime into action, chaos and disaster happen to her family and the entire school. Stated on the flyleaf is, "Students, heed this little rhyme: When it's science project time, Do not make goop, or glop, or grime, And never mess with mutant slime." The humorous and colorful illustrations perfectly evoke slime and chaos. The kids will love it. California author.
Author: Judy Sierra

Title: Secret World of Walter Anderson, The
Annotation: Artist Walter Anderson spent years in the South, along the Mississippi Gulf Coast and Horn Island, painting from nature. He lived among wild animals, wrote journals, and painted. Includes an extensive author’s note about his reclusive life and amazing secret room. The walls were covered with southern flora and fauna and were discovered after his death. Illustrated with Lewis’ watercolors and reproductions of Anderson’s works. This title will enrich units on American artists or the environment.
Author: Hester Bass

Title: Secrets from the Rocks: Dinosaur Hunting with Roy Chapman Andrews
Annotation: This biography of scientist-adventurer Roy Chapman Andrews is presented as an exciting story of exploration, adventure, and scientific inquiry. He survived attacks by wild dogs, violent sandstorms, and more. He also crawled "into the belly of a dead whale to see how it felt." The narrative focuses on the expeditions he led for New York's American Museum of Natural History, taking him to the Gobi Desert in Mongolia in search of dinosaur fossils.
Author: Albert Marrin

Title: Secrets of Sound: Studying the Calls and Songs of Whales, Elephants, and Birds
Annotation: This book examines the work of bioacousticians-scientists who study sounds made by living creatures. It shows scientific discovery up close, provides a clear explanation of scientific concepts, and gives readers an introduction to a little-known field. This book, which includes suggested Web sites, a bibliography, a glossary, and an index is a part of the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: April Pulley Sayre

Title: Sector 7
Annotation: A young boy's field trip to the Empire State Building turns surreal when fog envelops the observation deck and a friendly cloud assumes the role of tour guide. The pair's wordless adventure leads to Sector 7, the Cloud Dispatch Center, where the mischievous twosome meddle with cloud assignments and designs. Watercolors of varying size and placement enhance the mood of the story.
Author: David Wiesner

Title: Seeds of Change: Planting a Path to Peace
Annotation: Kenyan Nobel Peace Prize winner and environmentalist Wangari Maathai is a female scientist who stood for women's rights and her own Greenbelt Movement, an effort to restore Kenya's ecosystem by planting millions of trees.
Author: Jen Cullerton Johnson
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Life Science (Biology), Women’s Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Seeds of Hope: The Gold Rush Diary of Susanna Fairchild
Annotation: A diary account of fourteen-year old Susanna Fairchild’s life in 1849. After losing his wife and child on a steamship journey from New York, Susanna’s father succumbs to “gold rush fever” on his way to establish a medical practice in Oregon. Susanna’s diary tells of the daily struggles, dangers, and lawlessness of the mining camps as well as episodes of frontier justice and prejudice.
Author: Kristiana Gregory

Title: Seeing Earth from Space
Annotation: Striking photographs taken by astronauts and satellites illustrate this discussion of astronomy. The author explains the different types of remote sensing and how they apply to weather forecasting, tectonic movement, and Earth's ecological health. It includes personal remarks of astronauts, a glossary, an index, and a list of further readings for both children and adults.
Author: Patricia Lauber
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Seen Art?
Annotation: The 2004 reopening of the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York City was the inspiration for this humorous story, in which a boy searches for his friend Art in many places and ends up taking a tour of the MoMA. The book has an extra-wide format and is illustrated with reproductions of works by Picasso, Warhol, and others. An endnote provides details about the works that appear in the publication.
Author: Jon Scieszka, Lane Smith

Title: Seer of Shadows, The
Annotation: Horace Carpetine, a photographer’s apprentice, becomes unwillingly involved in a swindle, as his mentor uses a trick to impose the image of a dead girl’s ghost on her mother’s photo portrait. But Horace and the girl’s black maid expose the photographer’s deed and the true story of the dead girl—and Horace discovers that he really can bring back the restless image of the dead girl.
Author: Avi

Title: Selvas, La (The Forests)
Annotation: The diverse ecosystem of the tropical rain forests around the world is described and explained. This is one of the Planeta Vivo (The Modern Planet) series which includes APARATO RESPIRATORIO: SOPLO DE VIDA (RESPIRATORY SYSTEM: BREATH OF LIFE), and EL SISTEM NERVIOSO: NUESTRO PROCESO DE DATOS (THE NERVOUS SYSTEM: OUR DATA PROCESSING).
Author: Marta Serrano

Title: Senorita Runfio, La (Miss Rumphius)
Annotation: Great-Aunt Alice Rumphius promises her grandfather that when she grows up she will live by the sea, visit faraway places, and do something to make the world more beautiful. She accomplishes the first two but is stumped by the third until she becomes the Lupine Lady.
Author: Barbara Cooney
Standard: HSS K.1, LS 1.2, HSS 1.1, LS 2.2, HSS 1.4, HSS 2.1, HSS 2.5

Title: Separate is Never Equal: Sylvia Mendez and Her Family's Fight for Desegregation
Annotation: Almost 10 years before Brown vs. Board of Education, Sylvia Mendez and her parents helped end school segregation in California. An American citizen of Mexican and Puerto Rican heritage who spoke and wrote perfect English, Mendez was denied enrollment to a “Whites only” school. Her parents took action by organizing the Hispanic community and filing a lawsuit in federal district court. Their success eventually brought an end to the era of segregated education in California.
Author: Duncan Tonatiuh
Topic: American History, Law and Legal Studies
Award: Pura Belpre Illustration Honor, Robert F. Sibert Award

Title: September Roses
Annotation: On September 11, 2001, two sisters from South Africa are flying to New York City with 2,400 roses to be displayed at a flower show. Their plane lands in New York just after the World Trade Center is attacked, and the sisters are stranded at the airport. They devise a way to use the roses to create a memorial for all those who lost their lives in the destruction of the Twin Towers. The story is told with simple words and artwork that show how kindness and flowers helped comfort and heal in the aftermath of the 9/11 tragedy. Use to promote thoughtful discussions and writing exercises.
Author: Jeanette Winter
Classification: Picture Book, Read Aloud, Struggling Reader
Topic: American History, Global Historical Events and Figures, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, Visual Arts
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, HSS 10.11

Title: Sequoyah: The Cherokee Man Who Gave His People Writing
Annotation: This is the biography of Sequoyah, a member of the Cherokee Nation who was born in the 1760s in eastern Tennessee and who developed the first written alphabet and language for the Cherokee people. This accomplishment enabled the publication of books and newspapers and survives to this day. The narrative is accompanied by stately ink, watercolor, pastel, and pencil illustrations that are primitive in appearance. The text is presented in English and Cherokee.
Author: James Rumford

Title: Sergei Prokofiev’s Peter and the Wolf
Annotation: Retells the orchestral fairy tale in which a boy ignores his grandfather’s warnings and proceeds to capture a wolf. In this version, the wolf coughs out the duck and is returned to the forest. The accompanying CD features the composition played by the Cincinnati Pops Orchestra and narrated by Peter Thomas. Illustrated with paintings that bring a Russian flavor to the story.
Author: Janet Schulman
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.3

Title: Serpientes venenosas (Snakes with Venom)
Annotation: This book is about the lives and behaviors of venomous snakes. Each book in the series contains photographs and easy-to-read text. Harder vocabulary words are in bold type and an index and a glossary are included. Other books in the Cara a Cara Con Serpiente (Face to Face with Snakes) series include EL INTERESANTE MUNDO DE LAS SERPIENTES (INTERESTING WORLD OF SNAKES), CUANDO LAS SERPIENTES VAN A CAZAR (SNAKES ON THE HUNT), SERPIENTES QUE ATRAPAN Y ESTRUJAN (SNAKES THAT SQUEEZE AND SNATCH), and LA VIDA SECRETA DE LAS SERPIENTES (THE SECRET LIVES OF SNAKES).
Author: Lynn M. Stone

Title: Seven Magic Brothers (Hmong: Xya Kwv Tij Uas Muaj Fwj Chim)
Annotation: An angry emperor wishes to execute seven clever brothers, but they trick him through their extraordinary individual qualities. Full-page watercolor illustrations reflect the Chinese culture. Regional dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text. Translated to by Hmong: Tong Mua, Pao Vang, and Terfong Yang.
Author: Kuang-Ts’ai Hao (reteller)

Title: Seven Wonders of Sassafras Springs, The
Annotation: In the summer of 1923 in Missouri, twelve-year-old Eben is looking at a book about the Seven Wonders of the World. Eben’s father makes a deal with him: If Eben can find seven local wonders in seven days, his father will give him a train ticket to visit relatives in the Colorado mountains. Artwork features a full-page drawing of each “wonder.”
Author: Betty G. Birney

Title: Several Lives of Orphan Jack, The
Annotation: When Jack is placed in the Opportunities School for Orphans and Foundlings, he learns to be optimistic and to do his best. When things don't work out for the best, Jack runs away and finds himself selling ideas, whims, concepts, opinions, and plans. Jack is a wonderful success but soon sets off again to find his fortune and see the world.
Author: Sarah Ellis

Title: Shadows in the Dawn: The Lemurs of Madagascar
Annotation: Excellent-quality full-color photographs document the work of a primatologist and her team of researchers as they study lemurs in the only place where they live, the island of Madagascar. The characteristics and origins of these unusual mammals is described along with new discoveries. The photographs highlight the terrain as well as the lemurs themselves.
Author: Kathryn Lasky

Title: Shadows of the Night: The Hidden World of the Little Brown Bat
Annotation: The life cycle of the common North American brown bat is depicted as the young reach maturity, hunt for insects, hibernate in caves, and emerge to begin another yearly cycle. Double-spread paintings depict the various habitats and bat details. This is a good book to read aloud and is useful for research.
Author: Barbara Bash

Title: Shaka, King of the Zulus
Annotation: This is the dramatic life story of the outcast Zulu boy who developed himself into a fearsome warrior, trained Zulu fighters into a stunningly powerful army, and ruled over Zululand, South Africa, until he was assassinated. This well-researched picture book contains full-page watercolors depicting the lifestyle, clothing, and shelters of the Zulus. Beaded border accents add ethnic authenticity. Other titles available from this author include BARD OF AVON: THE STORY OF WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE, CLEOPATRA, JOAN OF ARC, MICHELANGELO, PETER THE GREAT, and GOOD QUEEN BESS. This selection holds a history/social science connection for the sixth-grade curriculum.
Author: Diane Stanley

Title: Shake, Rattle & Turn That Noise Down! How Elvis Changed Music, Me, and Mom
Annotation: In 1955, young Mark is driven wild by Elvis Presley’s music—and his mom is driven crazy. In this story, told through cartoons and words, the family dynamics are altered by the loud music. Finally, a truce is reached when Mark’s mother discovers the softer side of Elvis. Mark eventually learns to play guitar, and the story closes with his successful impression of Elvis on stage at a Cub Scout dinner. Includes an author’s note and photos of the author at age eight with an Elvis hairdo and guitar.
Author: Mark Alan Stamaty
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA T PreK-12.3

Title: Shake, Rattle, & Roll: The Founders of Rock & Roll
Annotation: A collection of one-page biographies (and accompanying illustrations) of some of the most influential stars of rock music, such as Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis, and Buddy Holly. Illustrated with folk-art portraits done with acrylic and mixed media. Teachers may want to use CDs of the artists’ music in combination with the book, as young readers may not be familiar with the musicians.
Author: Holly George-Warren

Title: Shaman's Apprentice, The
Annotation: In the Amazon rain forest a young Tirio boy follows the shaman, learns the healing properties of the plants, and aspires to become a healer. White missionaries arrive, cure diseases the shaman cannot, and the people turn away from the traditional cures. Years later, a scientist comes to learn about forest medicines and restores respect for the shaman. Based on a true story, the rich, watercolor paintings highlight the flora and their uses. An author's note provides additional information.
Author: Lynne Cherry

Title: Shape Game
Annotation: In this autobiographical account, Browne describes how his mother's wish to spend her birthday visiting the art museum with her family changed the course of his life. His surreal style is once again evident in art and text. Young readers can do the drawing exercise the author/illustrator shares in the endpapers. This book can also be used as a picture book for older readers.
Author: Anthony Browne
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Shape Up! Fun with Triangles and Other Polygons
Annotation: Various polygons including triangles, quadrilaterals, rhombuses, and dodecagons are introduced and illustrated by comparing them to common foods such as pretzels, slices of cheese, and bread. It can serve as a hands-on guide to constructing patterns. Bright cartoonlike illustrations highlight the text. There is some inaccuracy in the depiction of triangles.
Author: David A. Adler

Title: Shark Life: True Stories About Sharks and the Sea
Annotation: Adapted for young people by Karen Wojtyla from the author's adult work, SHARK TROUBLE, this book's essays, recollections of personal adventures, and advice on water safety focus on Benchley's passion and respect for the sea and its creatures. A case is made for reducing the actions of humans that threaten the survival of the oceans and their plants and animals (e.g., overfishing and air and water pollution). The text is accompanied by black-and-white photos, a glossary of terms, and recommendations for Internet sources on sharks and conservation.
Author: Peter Benchley

Title: Sharks
Annotation: This title examines facts and myths about a variety of sharks. The author provides basic anatomical and life-cycle information as well as specific facts about 12 common shark species ranging from the dwarf shark to the whale shark. This is a good choice for young students needing to gather information for a simple shark report. The text is specific and generally accurate, although sources consulted referred to months rather than the "few weeks" given in the text regarding the development of sharks' "thorny cased eggs".
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Sharks
Annotation: Along with snakes and wolves, sharks are stereotyped as one of nature's bad guys. But are all sharks the giant man hunters they are so often made out to be? What do they eat, where do they swim, and what do they do between meals? Acclaimed science writer Seymour Simon and the Smithsonian Institution have teamed up to present this new edition of Simon's classic text on sharks. It has been updated with recent scientific research on one of the world's most mysterious creatures. This title is a part of the Smithsonian series.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Sharks! Strange and Wonderful
Annotation: The clearly-written text highlights fascinating information about sharks including anatomy and habits of different species. The dramatic and realistic acrylic paintings enhance the information and bring the sharks to life in their environment.
Author: Laurence P. Pringle

Title: She Touched the World: Laura Bridgman, Deaf-Blind Pioneer
Annotation: Presents the life of Laura Bridgman—who, like Helen Keller, became both blind and deaf at a young age. The book tells how Laura learned to communicate and how she became famous. Well researched and well written, this book will engage children and provide a story to compare with that of Helen Keller. Illustrated with many black-and-white photographs.
Author: Robert Alexander, Sally Hobart Alexander

Title: She's Wearing a Dead Bird on her Head!
Annotation: This fictionalized account explores the birth of the Massachusetts Audubon Society at the end of the nineteenth century. Harriet Hemenway and Minna Hall, two proper Bostonians, were cofounders of the Massachusetts organization that had an impact on the bird-protection movement. The female activists in the story serve as strong female role models for today's students. The charming and humorous illustrations are watercolors and ink.
Author: Kathryn Lasky

Title: She’ll Be Coming ’Round the Mountain
Annotation: New verses to a traditional American folk song herald the arrival of a spunky cowgirl in pink pajamas who is “coming ’round the mountain.” The text includes multiple verses of the famous song, each with an exclamation for children to call out. Illustrated with bright, lively artwork. Includes the music and suggested hand motions.
Author: Jonathan Emmett
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3

Title: Sheep
Annotation: A border collie pup named Jack learns to herd sheep on a California ranch. When the ranch is destroyed by fire, he is taken to a pet store—and thus begins a series of adventures. The memory of herding sheep always stays with Jack, and he searches for his life’s work: caring for a few sheep. Eventually, he finds a lost orphan boy, bonds with him, and together they fulfill their respective dreams. Well told in the voice of Jack, this selection is a good read-aloud choice. Or use as an introduction to narrative style and point of view.
Author: Valerie Hobbs

Title: Shell Book, The
Annotation: Fourteen shells, common to rare, are introduced through brief, informative text and shown in hand-tinted, muted, still-life photographs. Interesting facts are included which will inspire further research.
Author: Barbara Hirsch Lember

Title: Shelterwood
Annotation: Illustrated in oils, this story takes the reader on a summer adventure through the woods to learn how environmentally conscious foresters protect the inhabitants by selectively cutting trees to leave shelter for animals, as well as to protect young trees. Many of the animals that live in the environment are highlighted.
Author: Susan Hand Shetterly

Title: Shiloh
Annotation: When Marty finds a lost beagle in the hills behind his West Virginia home, he tries to hide the dog from his family and from its real owner, who is a mean-spirited man. Convinced that he's Shiloh's last chance, Marty risks his own safety for the puppy's sake and strikes a bargain with an unlikely partner. This book is the first in a trilogy; SHILOH SEASON and SAVING SHILOH are also available.
Author: Phyllis Reynolds Naylor

Title: Shoe Tree of Chagrin, The
Annotation: In this tall tale, a frontier woman of legendary height and fame journeys across the plains making shoes and telling of her adventures. The illustrations are executed with a fine line and use of tans and browns in a misty palette.
Author: J. Patrick Lewis

Title: Shoebag
Annotation: A young cockroach awakens one morning to find he has metamorphosed into a little boy, and he becomes part of the Biddle family who live upstairs. His name is changed from Shoebag to Stu Bagg and in some ways he enjoys learning to be a boy. He soon learns that people are sometimes rude and uncaring, and he ultimately teaches them the importance of kindness and self-esteem.
Author: Mary James

Title: Shoeshine Girl
Annotation: A summer job at her aunt's helps ten-year-old Sarah to become more self-reliant and understanding. California author.
Author: Clyde Bulla

Title: Show and Tell: Exploring the Fine Art of Children’s Book Illustration
Annotation: Dilys Evans selects and discusses picture books she has identified as having earned the distinction of fine art, showcasing a wide range of styles, techniques, and content. Twelve artists are presented and discussed, including Kay Thompson, Brian Selznick, and David Shannon. The author presents an interesting overview of each artist’s education, approach to art, and unique qualities. Illustrated with reproductions of the artists’ works.
Author: Dilys Evans

Title: Show Way
Annotation: The making of “Show Ways”—quilts that once served as secret maps for slaves who sought freedom—is a tradition passed from mother to daughter in the author’s family. Striking collages and poetic text make this award-winning book a powerful tribute to the bravery of African American women across generations.
Author: Jacqueline Woodson

Title: Shredderman: Secret Identity
Annotation: Bubba has been the bane of Nolan's existence for five long years. So when Mr. Green asks the class to become reporters, Nolan decides he'll write an exposé on Bubba. He doesn't want to sign his name to it, so Nolan creates a secret identity for himself on the Internet. He launches Shredderman.com as a place where truth and justice prevail and bullies get what's coming to them. Will engage reluctant readers, especially boys.
Author: Wendelin Van Draanen

Title: Si Pilandok at ang Buwaya (Pilandok and the Crocodile)
Annotation: Pilandok is a well-loved character in Philippine folklore because of the way he uses his intelligence to escape danger. In this amusing tale, Pilandok manages to cross a river guarded by crocodiles.
Author: Victoria Anonuevo

Title: Side by Side: Five Favorite Picture-Book Teams Go to Work
Annotation: Readers are introduced to five famous author–illustrator teams whose books can be found in most school libraries. Examples of rough drafts and finished works are shown with text that indicates how teamwork, cooperation, and friendship combine to create wonderful books. Includes bibliographies of each team’s books, a glossary, and an index.
Author: Leonard S. Marcus

Title: Side by Side: New Poems Inspired by Art from Around the World
Annotation: A striking book that pairs poetry and art from around the world. This collection examines the connections between an artist’s work and a poet’s response, putting the artist and poet literally on the same page. Each poem is presented in its original language, along with an English translation. The book features a variety of cultures and languages. Editor Jan Greenberg also assembled HEART TO HEART: NEW POEMS INSPIRED BY TWENTIETH-CENTURY AMERICAN ART (2001).
Author: Jan Greenberg (editor)

Title: Sideways Arithmetic from Wayside School
Annotation: This is a collection of humorous mind-boggling math puzzles and brain teasers that present problems such as how many meals Miss Mush will have to cook for the food to taste as bad as it smells. Another book in the Wayside School series is MORE SIDEWAYS ARITHMETIC FROM WAYSIDE SCHOOL.
Author: Louis Sachar
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Mathematical Reasoning, Number Sense
Standard: Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 3.MP.1-8, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.MP.1-8, Math 5.OA.1-3, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.MP.1-8, Math 6.MP.1-8

Title: Sienna’s Scrapbook: Our African American Heritage Trip
Annotation: A young African American girl and her family take a summer trip visiting significant sites in African American history, from Connecticut to North Carolina. As they visit places, such as Harlem’s Apollo Theater, the Amistad, and homes of famous African Americans, Sienna adds short journal entries that are humorous and personal to her scrapbook. Illustrated with childlike drawings, photos, paintings, and replicas of souvenirs she has collected. Use when studying black history, journal writing, or geography.
Author: Toni Trent Parker

Title: Sierra
Annotation: The majesty of California's Sierra Nevada is introduced through the voice of one mountain speaking of the beauty and timelessness of the range and its inhabitants. The reverential tone of the verse is well supported by one-and-a-half page acrylic paintings of varying perspectives and compositions of the mountainous region. MOJAVE is another Siebert book with a California setting. See also HEARTLAND by this author/illustrator team.
Author: Diane Siebert

Title: Sign of the Seahorse: A Tale of Greed and High Adventure in Two Acts, The
Annotation: The inhabitants of a coral reef ecosystem are threatened when a shady real estate deal started by the greedy grouper floods their area with poisonous waste and pollution. The story is written in rhyming verse in two dramatic acts, and is illustrated with detailed full-color artwork.
Author: Graeme Base

Title: Signed, Abiah Rose
Annotation: In nineteenth-century America, female artists were rarely given credit for their work. But in this picture book, Abiah Rose is determined to become a painter and signs her name with a rose in each of her paintings. The book’s folk-art-style illustrations are rendered in acrylic and pencil. An appended historical note, glossary, and reading list are included.
Author: Diane Browning
Topic: American History, Visual Arts, Women’s Studies
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Signers: The 56 Stories Behind the Declaration of Independence, The
Annotation: Profiles each of the 56 formidable men who signed the Declaration of Independence—men who risked their lives, futures, and fortunes to guarantee independence for future generations. The book is well organized, placing each biography in the context of the colony from which each man came. Illustrated with handsome scratchboard artwork that shows a cameo of the individual and a vignette. Includes a copy of the Declaration of Independence, an afterword detailing the events that led to independence, a bibliography, and an index.
Author: Dennis Brindell Fradin

Title: Silent Movie
Annotation: This black-and-white picture book gives the reader the sense of watching a silent movie. At the turn of the twentieth century Gustave's Papa immigrates to the United States and later sends for his wife and son. Because of the large crowds of immigrants, Papa does not find them after the ship arrives. Papa searches for them, while Gustave and his mother try to survive in the city. How they come together again is heartwarming, and the reader catches a realistic glimpse of life as an immigrant in the large city. California author. Small-group read-aloud.
Author: - Avi
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Silent Star: The Story of Deaf Major Leaguer William Hoy
Annotation: A biography of William Hoy (1862–1961), one of the first deaf players in Major League Baseball. The book covers Hoy’s childhood in Ohio, his discovery by an amateur coach, his career in baseball, and his determination and perseverance in overcoming hardships and prejudice. Oil paintings bring this historical period to life. Additional information and a photo are included.
Author: Bill Wise
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Physical Fitness

Title: Silent Thunder: A Civil War Story
Annotation: In 1862 eleven-year-old Summer and her thirteen-year-old brother, Rosco, describe life on the quiet Virginia plantation where they live as slaves. Then their lives are affected by the Civil War and the changes brought about by the conflict. The book could be used with the fifth- and eighth-grade history/social science curricula. It is available in paperback or prebind.
Author: Andrea Davis Pinkney

Title: Silent Witness: A True Story of the Civil War, The
Annotation: The true story of the family of Wilmer McLean, who was living near Bull Run Creek when the Civil War began in July of 1861 at the Battle of Manassas. Dismayed at being so close to the fight, McLean moved his family, including his daughter Lulu and her rag doll, to Appomattox Courthouse. Their home became the site of Lee’s surrender to Grant. Through it all, the rag doll was a witness to events of the Civil War. Detailed illustrations accompany the text.
Author: Robin Friedman

Title: Silk Umbrellas
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Noi worries that she will have to stop painting the silk umbrellas her family sells at the market near their Thai village and be forced to join her older sister in difficult work at a local factory instead. Featuring strong characters, this book depicts a struggling family in a section of contemporary Thailand where development of vacation homes takes away the lands that Noi’s father has farmed. The family is left with few options for making a living. Includes a short glossary of Thai words used in the story.
Author: Carolyn Marsden
Topic: Diversity, Economics, Global Social Issues, Lifestyles Around the World

Title: Silver Balloon
Annotation: Gregory, who is in fourth grade, releases a helium-filled balloon into the sky with his name and address attached to it. This act leads to an unusual friendship and an exchange of mystery gifts that require research investigations for them to be understood.
Author: Susan Bonners

Title: Silver Path, The
Annotation: Niko, a young boy, is forced to flee his homeland because of war. He writes about his life as a refugee to his American pen pal, Penny. His experiences in his new home and his hopes of returning to his homeland are conveyed through the simple text and evocative illustrations.
Author: Christine Harris

Title: Silver Seeds: A Book of Nature Poems
Annotation: Uncomplicated acrostic verse fills the illustrated pages of this poetry collection. Use as an introduction to acrostic poetry for children in elementary school and as a mentor text for student writing. Each illustration seems to glow behind the text. The simplicity of the language is ideal for children who are learning to speak and write in English.
Author: Dan Brewer, Paul Paolilli

Title: Simon and His Boxes
Annotation: A young boy builds houses out of cardboard boxes for animals. But when the animals begin to run away, he ends up sharing his boxes with other children. Acrylic paintings illustrate this story for young children. Regional dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text.
Author: Gilles Tibo

Title: Sinfonia de cuna (Cradle's Symphony)
Annotation: This poem shows, in a lighthearted manner, why the author is considered the creator of "antipoetry." Lovers of wit and irony will relish this selection featuring animal protagonists as they encounter the vicissitudes of life. Colorful full-page illustrations add interest to the enjoyable text.
Author: Nicanor Parra

Title: Sing a Song of Popcorn: Every Child's Book of Poems
Annotation: This wide selection of children's poetry includes old favorites, limericks, humorous verse, and poems from many cultures. Each section of poems is illustrated by a different Caldecott artist. Biographical notes on the nine illustrators are appended. The work is indexed by title, first line, and author.
Author: Beatrice Schenk de Regniers (editor)

Title: Sing Down the Moon
Annotation: This is the tragic story of “The Long Walk”: the 300-mile journey that the Navajo nation was forced to take. The book is based on true events that took place from 1863 to1865 when Kit Carson and the U.S. troops were ordered to remove the Navajo people from their native land. This poignant narrative is told through the eyes of Bright Morning as she describes the unfair treatment of her people and the courage of the Navajo.
Author: Scott O’Dell

Title: Sing Me a Story: Song-and-Dance Tales from the Caribbean
Annotation: A collection of five traditional tales from the Caribbean region, each accompanied by a song and instructions for dance steps. The stories feature clever tricksters who use song and sometimes dance to escape a bad situation, rescue someone, get rich, or just prove a point. Illustrated with bright, full-color collage artwork.
Author: Grace Hallworth
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.5, VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.5

Title: Sir Charlie: Chaplin, the Funniest Man in the World
Annotation: A lively biography tracing the life of Charlie Chaplin, from his destitute childhood in London to the epitome of stardom in Hollywood. Written in short chapters with extensive time-line features that make the book accessible and engaging. Chaplin’s experiences prove that perseverance can change one’s fate. Illustrated with archival photographs.
Author: Sid Fleischman
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Theatre
Standard: VAPA T PreK-12.2, VAPA T PreK-12.3

Title: Sir Cumference and All the King’s Tens: A Math Adventure
Annotation: Sir Cumference and his wife, Lady Di of Ameter, host a surprise birthday party for King Arthur. More guests than expected arrive, so the couple needs to organize the growing number of guests for the event to run smoothly. They finally realize that the simplest way to figure out the total is to group the guests into tens, hundreds, and thousands. Part of the “Sir Cumference” series, this is a humorous introduction to place value. California author.
Author: Cindy Neuschwander

Title: Sir Cumference and the Dragon of Pi: A Math Adventure
Annotation: Sir Cumference's son, Prince Radius, is sent on a quest to find his grandfather who has been turned into a dragon. The prince uses the magical number of pi to restore the man to his regular shape. Mathematical terms and concepts are used to tell the story. See other books in the Sir Cumference series.
Author: Cindy Neuschwander

Title: Sir Cumference and the First Round Table
Annotation: In Camelot, Sir Cumference and Lady Di design the perfect round table with the assistance of carpenters and geometric solutions. This is a humorous look at the Middle Ages replete with mathematical puns and factual relationships among diameter, circumference, and pi. See other books in the Sir Cumference series.
Author: Cindy Neuschwander

Title: Sir Cumference and the Great Knight of Angleland: A Math Adventure
Annotation: Prince Radius is on a quest to earn his knighthood and must rescue a lost king. His parents give him a circular medallion that helps him to measure and examine every angle as he finds his way through a maze. He is able to complete his quest thanks to geometry. See other books in the Sir Cumference series.
Author: Cindy Neuschwander

Title: Sir Cumference and the Sword in the Cone
Annotation: To find the king’s sword, Vertex and Radius need to solve a geometry and ratio puzzle that begins with nets of solid shapes. They need to figure out the relationship that “makes two.” The puzzle continues with a ratio and scale factor. The last page of the book describes Euler’s Law. The story is enhanced by warm, textured acrylic-and-oil illustrations. Part of the “Sir Cumference” series.
Author: Cindy Neuschwander

Title: Sistema solar, El (The Solar System)
Annotation: This illustrated text explains the basic facts about the solar system. Other books in the Todas las Maneras de Ver (Seeing Things in Different Ways) series include VOLCANOES (VOLCANOES), EL TIEMPO (WEATHER), and ROCA Y MINERALES (ROCKS AND MINERALS).
Author: Jane Walker

Title: Sister Anne's Hands
Annotation: Sister Anne, an African American, is a new second-grade teacher who brings fun and spirit to the classroom. A hateful note causes one of her young students to come to terms with prejudice and the pain that such ignorance can cause. Realistic paintings set the tone for the 1960s time period and support the text.
Author: Marybeth Lorbiecki

Title: Sisters of the Scituate Light
Annotation: Based on a true story, this book centers on two brave teenage sisters who were left in charge of the Scituate Lighthouse in Massachusetts during events of the War of 1812. When a raiding party of British sailors approached the town, intending to loot and burn it, the sisters used their wits to chase away the raiders. Illustrated with double-page spreads that bring a strong sense of drama and realism to the story.
Author: Stephen Krensky

Title: Sitting Bull Remembers
Annotation: Told through poetry and striking double-page paintings, this is the story of Sitting Bull, the Sioux chief. In a first-person narrative, he describes how life was and how it all changed with the arrival of the white man, who slaughtered the buffalo and wanted to own the land and sell it, piece by piece. He also remembers General Custer and how the Sioux Indians were hunted and forced onto a reservation.
Author: Ann Warren Turner

Title: Six Dinner Sid
Annotation: Sid, an enterprising cat, has convinced six people on Aristotle Street that each is his owner, thus getting six different dinners every day. This works well until a cold results in six trips to the vet, who blows Sid's cover. Students can try to figure out how many dinners Sid gets in a week or month.
Author: Inga Moore

Title: Sixteen Years in Sixteen Seconds: The Sammy Lee Story
Annotation: The true story of Dr. Sammy Lee and his desire to be an Olympic diver at a time when he had to overcome formidable odds. Although he had a passion for diving, he was hindered by the fact that the local swimming pool was open only once a week to nonwhites. The story also describes how he honored his father’s wish to become a doctor. A notable tribute to the first Asian American to win an Olympic gold medal.
Author: Paula Yoo

Title: Skirt
Annotation: This early chapter book portrays a contemporary Latino family with ties to the traditions of Mexico. Fourth-grader Miata is entrusted with her mother's folklorico skirt to wear in her upcoming recital, only to leave it behind on the school bus. Detailed pencil sketches complement the telling of Miata scheming to retrieve the skirt. California author. Available in paperback or prebind.
Author: Gary Soto

Title: Skit-Scat Raggedy Cat: Ella Fitzgerald
Annotation: This picture-book biography of Ella Fitzgerald follows her from her early life, when she earned nickels by dancing the Lindy Hop on the streets of New York City, through her success as a singer and entertainer in the nightclubs of Harlem in the 1930s. The book is illustrated with red and blue artwork, which is a perfect complement to this story of a jazz legend.
Author: Roxane Orgill

Title: Sky High: The True Story of Maggie Gee
Annotation: Growing up in the San Francisco Bay Area in the 1930s, Maggie Gee dreamed of becoming a pilot. When World War II began, she decided to try to join the Women Airforce Service Pilots (WASP). Maggie was accepted and began her training, which she says was “hard and tiring and wonderful.” She was one of only two Chinese American WASP pilots and “felt big and strong in her plane.” An inspiring story of a little-known person who followed her dream.
Author: Marissa Moss

Title: Sky Pioneer: A Photobiography of Amelia Earhart
Annotation: This photo-biography tells the remarkable life story of pilot Amelia Earhart. Sixty primary source photographs, flight plan maps, quotes from her writings, and a text full of anecdotes contribute to this celebration of her accomplishments. A foreword, chronology, and afterword help to give readers a sense of Earhart's place in history and the possible reasons for her disappearance. A bibliography and a detailed index are appended.
Author: Corinne Szabo

Title: Sky Tree: Seeing Science Through Art
Annotation: Oil paintings by artist Thomas Locker chronicle the life of a tree throughout the seasons. Questions and answers by Candace Christiansen bring together art appreciation and scientific exploration through inquiry. This selection is also useful for lessons in literary response and analysis.
Author: Thomas Locker
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, Science

Title: Skylark
Annotation: In this sequel to SARAH, PLAIN AND TALL, a fire and a serious drought drive Sarah to return to Maine with Caleb and Anna for the summer. The children are afraid that they will never return to their home on the prairie. Anna's journal provides a first-person narrative that speaks of the children's fears and longing. When Father arrives, their return to the farm is emotional and hopeful.
Author: Patricia MacLachlan

Title: Slap, Squeak and Scatter: How Animals Communicate
Annotation: Brief informative text examines the ways in which a variety of animal behaviors are used to communicate warnings, territorial displays, and other messages. Crushed paper collages in soft colors depict animals as they flash fur, perform dances, cower, etc. A bibliography is included.
Author: Steve Jenkins

Title: Sleds on Boston Common: A Story from the American Revolution
Annotation: Nine-year-old Henry Price looks forward to the day when he can ride his sled on Boston Common. Unfortunately, it is the winter of 1774, and thousands of British soldiers who were sent by King George are encamped on Boston Common. Not to be thwarted, Henry complains to the royal governor, General Thomas Gage, who orders the troops to allow the town children to sled where they wish. Henry learns that even an enemy can be a good man. A fictional story based on local folklore and illustrated with watercolor art.
Author: Louise Borden

Title: Slinky, Scaly, Slithery Snakes
Annotation: This bright, colorful book describes different species of snakes and their habitats, body structure, adaptations, hunting, and reproduction. Vibrant paintings surround and underlay the well-written text and offer close-up views of the snakes.
Author: Dorothy Hinshaw Patent

Title: Sloppy Copy Slipup, The
Annotation: Brian Higman arrives at school without the sloppy copy that was his homework writing assignment. His excuse is that he has nothing interesting to write about. As he tries to explain to the teacher why he doesn’t have his homework, his stories become more complicated and compelling. The teacher helps Brian understand that his very ordinary life is a great source for stories. Reluctant writers might be inspired by Brian’s success. Illustrated throughout with pencil drawings.
Author: DyAnne DiSalvo

Title: Slugs
Annotation: Magnified photographs and clear text provide information about slugs, an often scorned creature. The book describes the physical characteristics, habitat, and behavior of slugs.
Author: Anthony D. Fredericks

Title: Small Adventure of Popeye and Elvis, The
Annotation: Popeye lives in rural South Carolina and is not looking forward to another boring summer. His outlook changes when an RV with a family of six wild kids is stranded in the red mud near his home. He and Elvis, the oldest child in the stranded family, begin adventures, discover a secret, and meet a new friend. A wonderful summer friendship is born.
Author: Barbara O’Connor

Title: Small Beauties: The Journey of Darcy Heart O’Hara
Annotation: Darcy Heart O’Hara, a young Irish girl who neglects her chores to observe the “small beauties” of nature and everyday life, shares family memories with her homesick parents and siblings after the family emigrates to America in the 1840s. Mixed-media illustrations provide detailed images of individuals and places described in the story.
Author: Elvira Woodruff

Title: Smallpox in the New World
Annotation: Describes the history of smallpox in the Americas, with the arrival of the Spanish as carriers, the spread of the disease throughout the New World, the development of a vaccine, the elimination of the disease, and its potential use as a terrorist weapon. The book highlights the impact of the epidemic on Western history and society. Illustrated with archival materials and reproduced paintings. Pair with FEVER, 1793 (Laurie Halse Anderson) and AN AMERICAN PLAGUE: THE TRUE AND TERRIFYING STORY OF THE YELLOW FEVER EPIDEMIC OF 1793 (Jim Murphy).
Author: Stephanie True Peters

Title: Smile
Annotation: The author tells the story of her trials and tribulations involving her teeth. In sixth grade, her two front teeth were knocked out when she tripped and fell down. She then went on to have surgeries, braces, and headgear—all happening while she was dealing with the stress of being a middle-school student. She describes how her career choice as an animator took root during these experiences. Students will relate to the self-consciousness and embarrassing situations the author experienced.
Author: Raina Telgemeier
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health

Title: Smoky Night
Annotation: When the Los Angeles riots break out in the streets of their neighborhood, a young boy and his mother learn the value of getting along with others no matter what their background or ethnicity. California author, illustrator, and setting.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: Snake Scientist, The
Annotation: This nonfiction selection discusses the work of Bob Mason and his efforts to study and protect snakes, particularly the red-sided garter snake. This book provides an excellent resource for readers interested in snakes and reptiles.
Author: Sy Montgomery

Title: Snakes! Strange and Wonderful
Annotation: Pringle presents a well-written narrative that highlights these remarkable reptiles' major physical and behavioral characteristics as well as some of the distinctive traits of several kinds of snakes. A variety of snakes are depicted in detailed drawings and watercolor illustrations. The book concludes with an afterword on people and snakes. This book makes an excellent choice for report writers as well as for browsers.
Author: Laurence P. Pringle

Title: Sneeze!
Annotation: This book presents many reasons for sneezing. The explanations are illustrated by a combination of black-and-white photographs of children and amazing color electron micrographs. The micrographs are the main focus here, reproduced in vibrant colors on black backgrounds. The author discusses the things that make people sneeze and the parts of the human body that are responsible for the automatic sneeze reflex. A list of resources and a glossary are included.
Author: Alexandra Siy

Title: Snook Alone
Annotation: Snook is a small, loyal dog who is the faithful companion to Abba Jacob, an East Indian monk. They live together on a remote island, and as Abba Jacob goes about his daily routine, Snook is always by his side. This quiet life is interrupted when Snook is stranded on a small atoll during a fierce storm and must survive on his own. Snook observes, attacks, and watches as the nights come and go. The eventual reunion between the two is heartfelt. Illustrated with full-page artwork done with ink and acrylic. The text features metaphors and similes.
Author: Marilyn Nelson

Title: Snow Baby: The Arctic Childhood of Admiral Robert E. Peary’s Daring Daughter, The
Annotation: Marie Peary, the daughter of the famous explorer Robert E. Peary, had a unique childhood. She was known as “The Snow Baby” by the Inuit of Greenland, where she was born in 1893. Marie’s friendships with Inuit children, her adventures (including a shipwreck), and her touching letters to her often-absent father will appeal to middle- and upper-grades students. Interesting photographs, a bibliography, and a list of primary and secondary sources make this a valuable resource for young readers.
Author: Katherine Kirkpatrick
Topic: American History, Geography, Women’s Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Snow Bear, The
Annotation: A Inuit boy saves a polar bear from starvation and she, in turn, saves him from a blizzard. The fictional writing weaves an abundance of factual information about the life cycle of the polar bear and it could be used as an introduction to endangered animals. The illustrations include snowy landscapes enhance the text.
Author: Liliana Stafford

Title: Snowbound: The Tragic Story of the Donner Party
Annotation: A group of pioneers endured incredible hardships on their journey from Illinois to California in 1846. Considered one of the most famous and poignant journeys in American history, it ended tragically for many, and for the survivors, their lives were never the same. Archival photographs and prints, current photographs, maps, a bibliography, and an index are included. This book is an excellent resource for the study of California history and the westward movement. California setting.
Author: David Lavender

Title: Snowflake Bentley
Annotation: Wilson Bentley was a self-taught scientist who photographed thousands of individual snowflakes in order to study their unique formations. This is his phenomenal story. Sidebars tell the readers more about Bentley's research and life, and woodcut illustrations reflect the early technology of the nineteenth century.
Author: Jacqueline Briggs Martin

Title: Snowshoe Thompson
Annotation: This story is based on an actual incident in the early 1850s. John Thompson skis across the Sierra Nevada from Placerville to Carson City to deliver the mail - thus starting a new tradition and earning him the name "Snowshoe Thompson." This selection is useful for lessons in California history. California author and setting.
Author: Nancy Smiler Levinson
Classification: Early Chapter Book, Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Standard: HSS K.1, HSS K.6, HSS 1.2, HSS 1.4, HSS 2.1

Title: So Far from the Sea
Annotation: When seven-year-old Laura and her family visit Grandfather's grave at the Manzanar War Relocation Center, the Japanese American child leaves behind a special symbol about belonging and caring. California author and setting.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: So Said Ben
Annotation: An illustrated collection of Benjamin Franklin’s bits of wisdom, this book reflects some of the experiences that shaped the famous American’s life and beliefs. Each adage is accompanied by a short anecdote from Franklin’s life and by a black-and-white illustration. Includes an author’s note at the end. Useful when introducing American heroes. May be used as a pattern book when teaching about proverbs.
Author: Michael McCurdy

Title: So You Want to Be an Inventor?
Annotation: Lively text and humorous watercolor illustrations by this Caldecott award-winning team offer readers a brief introduction to some of the most famous and lesser known inventors throughout history. More than 40 inventors are featured, including Thomas Edison, Ben Franklin, Thomas Jefferson, Henry Ford, Eli Whitney, and Hedy Lamarr.
Author: Judith St. George

Title: So You Want to Be President?
Annotation: This selection highlights historical triumphs and troubles of our first 41 presidents. The author and the illustrator combine tidbits of information as well as comical anecdotes with caricatures of the presidents to create an entertaining and educational resource that is suitable for research and for recreation.
Author: Judith St. George

Title: Software y el arte de hacer media (Software Superslug and the Nutty Novelty Knitting)
Annotation: Software the superslug becomes excited and intrigued when his teacher compares him to Pythagoras. He undertakes an adventure to discover more about the mathematician. This easy-to-read story includes brief information about Pythagoras's life and the math he developed. See other titles in this series about Software.
Author: Joyce Dunbar

Title: Software y el estupor informatico (Software Superslug and the Great Computer Stupor)
Annotation: Software the superslug lives in a colony that depends on him to use his great intellectual powers to save them from danger. Software, however is distracted from his investigation by other things. Other titles in the series include SOFTWARE, LA SUPERBABOSA (SOFTWARE THE SUPERSLUG), and SOFTWARE, Y EL ARTE DE HACER MEDIA (SOFTWARE SUPERSLUG AND THE NUTTY NOVELTY KNITTING).
Author: Joyce Dunbar

Title: Sombras y reflejos (Shadows and Reflections)
Annotation: Text, pictures, photographs, diagrams, and charts demonstrate properties of light and reflection. Other books in the Descubre y Experimenta: Ciencia Divertida (Fun with Simple Science) series includes LUZ Y COLOR (LIGHT AND COLOR), CULTIVO DE PLANTAS (CULTIVATING PLANTS), and SONIDA Y MUSICA (SOUND AND MUSIC). Each book covers separate science concepts and ideas. Activities and easy-to-follow directions help support science concepts.
Author: Barbara Taylor

Title: Some Bugs Glow in the Dark (I Didn't Know That)
Annotation: This book explores the diversity of insect life and provides information about various insects' adaptations to their habitats including physical characteristics, homes, feeding habits, and defenses. A glossary and an index are included for student reference.
Author: Claire Llewellyn
Illustrator: Francis Phillips, Ian Thompson, Jo Moore, Myke Taylor, Rob Shone

Title: Someday a Tree
Annotation: A young girl, her parents, and their neighbors try to save an old oak tree that has been poisoned by pollution in the soil. Unable to save the tree, the girl remembers the acorns she collected when the tree was still healthy and plants them. Delicate watercolors complement this emotional story. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: Song and Dance Man
Annotation: In this tender story, Grandpa, a former vaudeville song and dance man, reclaims his youth and performs for his three young grandchildren. The illustrations show Grandpa in shadow and silhouette with warmth and nostalgia. This book is useful for lessons about family history.
Author: Karen Ackerman
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.5, VAPA T PreK-12.3, VAPA T PreK-12.5

Title: Song for Cambodia, A
Annotation: This biography covers the childhood of real-life humanitarian Arn Chorn-Pond, describing how Khmer Rouge soldiers murdered Arn’s family and sent him to a children’s work camp. There he endured long work hours and was close to starvation. When the guards requested volunteers to play music, Arn dared to volunteer, receiving his only chance for survival. He learned to play a traditional Cambodian musical instrument. Consequently, music became the one thing that gave him hope and comfort through his ordeal of escape, sickness, and survival in a refugee camp. Arn was eventually adopted by an American. An afterword tells of his award-winning humanitarian work with survivors of war and his efforts to reclaim and spread knowledge of Cambodian music.
Author: Michelle Lord
Topic: Diversity, Global Social Issues, Immigration/Migration, Music
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Song of the Water Boatman and Other Pond Poems
Annotation: Poems in a variety of voices provide a look at some of the animals, insects, and plants that are found in northern ponds. A variety of poetic forms are used, and each poem is illustrated with woodcut-and-watercolor artwork that reflects the changing seasons. This book can be used for classes engaged in the study of pond life as well as for pleasure reading.
Author: Joyce Sidman

Title: Space Station Science: Life in Free Fall
Annotation: A former NASA flight controller describes space stations, the training and activities of its crew, and living conditions. This discussion includes weightlessness and the dangers of radiation and meteors. This well-researched book is illustrated with cartoons and color photographs. Web sites and activities simulating conditions in space are included.
Author: Marianne J. Dyson

Title: Spaceheadz
Annotation: In this humorous science-fiction and fantasy story, a fifth-grader named Michael goes to a new school and meets two kids who turn out to be aliens that want to save the world. Their leader is the class hamster, and they believe that Michael can be instrumental in their quest. The book is filled with secret codes and messages. Illustrated with black-and-white drawings, the book also includes Web sites that will add to the fun. This is a high-energy read that reluctant readers will enjoy. Book one of a series.
Author: Jon Scieszka

Title: Spaghetti and Meatballs for All! A Mathematical Story
Annotation: In making plans for a family reunion, Mrs. Comfort designs the seating for 32 people. She orders eight tables, each seating four, but the plan becomes complicated as the guests begin rearranging the tables. The humorous story is illustrated with cartoonlike art and introduces the concepts of regrouping and relationships between area and perimeter.
Author: Marilyn Burns
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry), Number Sense

Title: Sparrow Girl
Annotation: When Chairman Mao Tse-Tung declares a “war” on sparrows for eating the farmers’ wheat crops, citizens are called upon to make as much noise as possible to cause the sparrows to die of heart attacks and/or exhaustion. Within three days, the sparrow population declines. However, without the sparrows, the locusts, weevils, and worms destroy the crops and cause famine. Ming-li, with the aid of her brother, rescues injured sparrows that have fallen. She releases her sparrows and saves her village’s farms. Based on actual events, the book features illustrations done in a folk-art style.
Author: Sara Pennypacker
Topic: Diversity, Global Historical Events and Figures, Life Science (Biology)

Title: Spectacular Spiders
Annotation: This concept book tells of a day in the life of a common garden spider. Rhythmic narrative provides a good introduction to arachnids for young children. Colorful drawings keep illustrations uncluttered. This selection is appended with spider facts and has a life science connection.
Author: Linda Glaser

Title: Spider and the Fly, The
Annotation: This cautionary poem was written in 1829 about a vain, silly fly and the cunning spider who does her in. The black-and-white artwork evokes the era of silent films, and the gothic flavor and details will appeal to older readers as well. Older readers will identify the macabre details and appreciate connections with the likes of Charles Adamms, Edward Gorey, and Lemony Snickett. Picture book for older readers.
Author: Mary Botham Howitt
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Spiders
Annotation: Using his signature approach - combining incredible photographs with clear yet elegant prose - Simon provides an introduction to the physical characteristics, behavior, and life cycle of a variety of spider species.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Spiders
Annotation: Several spider species are highlighted, with descriptions given of their habitat, physical characteristics, and behavioral characteristics. Clear, colorful illustrations and labels help to clarify the information for young readers. Particularly interesting is a side-by-side comparison of spider structures with those of insects. A page providing spider facts is useful for young report writers.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Spiders and Their Web Sites
Annotation: This book provides a detailed look at the physical characteristics and habits of 12 different spiders and daddy-longlegs. Each spider is featured in a full page with text and a detailed, full-color portrait. The pages are bordered with thumbnail pictures showing spider variations, spiders in action, and spider parts.
Author: Margery Facklam

Title: Spiders Spin Webs
Annotation: This book provides a variety of webs and spiders in illustrations and verse. It shows how spiders are marvels at adaptation and have marvelous variations in body type, their webs, and feeding habits.
Author: Yvonne Winer

Title: Spinky Sulks
Annotation: Bad boy Spinky's family tries everything they can think of to cajole him out of his major sulk. The extremes they go to emphasize the absurdity of his behavior, sending a not-so-subtle message to readers. Spinky manages to save face (and his self-respect) by pulling himself out of his funk and showing his family that he loves them. Pen-and-ink watercolors enhance the telling in this picture book.
Author: William Steig

Title: Spinning Through the Universe: A Novel in Poems from Room 214
Annotation: This short novel in verse features the voices of the teacher, custodian, and students of room 214. They share life experiences, private thoughts, and stories that sometimes intersect. The heartfelt stories and variety of poetic patterns give this book extra appeal. The final section of the book provides notes on the 22 poetry forms represented in the book. Students can use the notes to create their own poems.
Author: Helen Frost

Title: Spinster Goose
Annotation: This is the story of Mother Goose’s twisted sister, Spinster Goose, who oversees a reform school for children who exhibit bad behavior—such as stealing, cheating, bullying, and tattling. Spinster Goose corrects their behavior through the use of fractured nursery rhymes that are dark and sinister. This is a good first lesson in parody. Illustrated with delicate watercolor-and-ink artwork.
Author: Lisa Wheeler

Title: Spirit of Tío Fernando: A Day of the Dead Story, The (El espiritu de tío Fernando)
Annotation: In this bilingual story, a Mexican boy remembers his deceased Uncle Fernando’s favorite things while preparing to celebrate the Day of the Dead. The boy tells how he and his mother bring a skeleton made of candy, marigolds, and his uncle’s favorite songs to the grave site as a remembrance. Illustrated with watercolor artwork. The story shows children how the Day of the Dead is celebrated in Mexico.
Author: Janice Levy
Topic: Diversity, Religion/Spirituality, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Spunky Tells All
Annotation: This chapter book for early readers features Julian and Huey, characters from Ann Cameron’s book THE STORIES JULIAN TELLS. The story is told from the perspective of the family dog, Spunky. While Spunky does not speak Human, he does understand a few words and tries hard to communicate with his family and teach them Dog. Thinking that Spunky needs a companion, the family adopts Fiona, a purebred cat. Spunky feels displaced, but when Fiona is trapped, he rescues her—and a new friendship is born. Illustrated with black-and-white drawings that provide a visual reference for newly independent readers. Recommended as a read-aloud.
Author: Ann Cameron

Title: Squirrel and John Muir
Annotation: "Floy was the first white child born in Yosemite Valley. She tore around it like a squirrel, so that was what they called her.” When John Muir arrives at Floy's parent’s hotel in the valley and becomes the hired hand, he shares his love and respect for nature with the young girl. McCully's watercolor illustrations capture the beauty of the unspoiled Yosemite Valley. An author's note and a bibliography are included.
Author: Emily Arnold McCully

Title: Squish: Super Amoeba
Annotation: This is the first book in the “Squish” graphic-novel series. Squish is an amoeba who pals around with his two microscopic friends. Together they attend school, have recess dilemmas, and face the school bully. The simple drawings, positive message, and biology facts scattered throughout the book will appeal to many readers.
Author: Jennifer L. Holm, Matthew Holm

Title: Stand Straight, Ella Kate: The True Story of a Real Giant
Annotation: A fictionalized biography of Ella Kate Ewing, who was born in 1872 and had gigantism, a condition which caused her to grow at an alarming rate. When Ella is teased at school, her parents try to protect her. At age seventeen, Ella stands eight feet tall and takes a job as an exhibit at the Chicago Museum. Ella learns that traveling the world as an exhibit will provide her with wealth and a life of adventure. The book includes a sepia-toned photo of the real Ella and an author’s note. An excellent choice for introducing discussions about differences between people.
Author: Kate Klise

Title: Stand Tall, Abe Lincoln
Annotation: An illustrated account of Abraham Lincoln’s early life, which was spent in the backwoods of Kentucky and Indiana. The short chapters in this oversize picture book highlight how the support and encouragement of Lincoln’s stepmother, Sally Johnston, helped propel him to success. The joys and sorrows of Lincoln’s difficult early life are shown in this engaging story, which includes full-color paintings as illustrations. Concludes with a short biography and bibliography. May be used as an introductory text in upper grades or for reluctant readers.
Author: Judith St. George

Title: Stanford Wong Flunks Big-Time
Annotation: Stanford has flunked sixth-grade English and must spend the summer being tutored by his adversary, Millicent, instead of attending basketball camp. He also faces a series of worries at home. Stanford creates a humorous tangle of lies in order to save face. This is the companion book to MILLICENT MIN, GIRL GENIUS (2003) and tells the story of the summer from Stanford’s point of view. A good choice for sports fans, reluctant readers, and boys.
Author: Lisa Yee

Title: Star in the Forest
Annotation: Zitlally’s father has been deported to Mexico, and she loses interest in everything. She retreats to a cemetery of old car parts behind her trailer park. In time, she befriends a neighbor and takes care of a stray dog that she believes she must keep safe in order for her father to return. When the dog, Star, disappears, she must communicate with others to find him. A well-told story that involves illegal immigration.
Author: Laura Resau

Title: Star Mother's Youngest Child
Annotation: A lonely old woman who has never properly celebrated Christmas does so when the Star Mother's youngest child comes to Earth to discover what Christmas Eve signifies. The two come together on Christmas Eve and create wonderful memories. California author.
Author: Louise Moeri

Title: Star of Fear, Star of Hope
Annotation: An elderly woman reminisces about her experiences as a young girl during World War II in Nazi-occupied France. As a child, she was confused by the disappearance of her Jewish friend during the German occupation of Paris. Simplistic paintings in muted tones convey the somber mood of this poignant story. Originally published in France.
Author: Jo Hoestlandt

Title: Star of the Week
Annotation: Jasper John Dooley is finally the Star of the Week in his class; however, a new baby at his friend’s home steals his attention. Thinking his family is too small, Jasper creates a brother out of wood to share with his classmates, which lands him in the principal’s office. Illustrated with occasional pencil artwork. First book in the “Jasper John Dooley” series.
Author: Caroline Adderson

Title: Star Stuff: Carl Sagan and the Mysteries of the Cosmos
Annotation: This is the story of Carl Sagan, a scientist who taught the world to marvel at the mysteries of the cosmos and continues to inspire generations of dreamers and stargazers.
Author: Stephanie Roth Sisson

Title: Star-Spangled Banner, The
Annotation: Watercolor drawings illustrate each phrase of three verses of America’s national anthem, written at the battle of Fort McHenry during the War of 1812. Biographical and historical information are included, along with the music.
Author: Francis Scott Key, Peter Spier
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: HSS K.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3, HSS 1.3, HSS 3.4

Title: Stargazers
Annotation: This introduction to stars explains what they are, why they twinkle, how the constellations were named, how telescopes are used, and more. Gibbons describes several major constellations, outlining the shapes that suggested their names, and details the differences between refracting telescopes and reflecting telescopes. Many illustrations are labeled (with specialized words defined), adding both clarity and substance to the text.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Stars Beneath Your Bed: The Surprising Story of Dust
Annotation: The origins of dust, what dust is, and how it affects children are all poetically explained in this informative picture book. Vivid watercolor illustrations and an afterword expand the text.
Author: April Pulley Sayre

Title: Ste-e-e-e-eamboat a-comin’!
Annotation: This poetic narrative was inspired by a passage from Mark Twain’s LIFE ON THE MISSISSIPPI. The author eloquently captures the bustle and commotion surrounding a steam boat’s arrival in a small river town in 1867. She introduces a variety of words that help to paint a picture of life on the river. The story is accompanied by detailed paintings in the style of Norman Rockwell. The illustrations make the book an excellent resource for historical study.
Author: Jill Esbaum

Title: Steel Town
Annotation: In Steel Town, it is always raining, freight trains come and go, the big furnace roars, and the steel mill never sleeps. Steel production continues day and night with the men working as hard as the machines. When the men go home, another side of the town comes to life—one filled with neighbors, churches, family dinners, and music. Double-page acrylic paintings in somber hues bring to life the era of steel and iron production, circa 1935.
Author: Jonah Winter
