Title: Stelaluna (Stellaluna)
Annotation: After falling head first into a bird's nest, a baby bat is raised as a bird until she is reunited with her mother. The adaptations and survival of birds and bats in their respective habitats is explored. The colored-pencil-and-acrylic paintings are paired with small pen-and-ink drawings that show mother bat's search for her baby. California author/illustrator.
Author: Janell Cannon

Title: Stellaluna
Annotation: After falling head first into a bird's nest, a baby bat is raised as a bird until she is reunited with her mother. The adaptations and survival of birds and bats in their respective habitats is explored. The colored-pencil-and-acrylic paintings are paired with small pen-and-ink drawings that show mother bat's search for her baby. California author/illustrator.
Author: Janell Cannon

Title: Step Gently Out
Annotation: This title features close-up macro photography that invites readers to view the stunning images of tiny insects found in nature and to appreciate the actions, movements, and sounds captured in the magic of the poet’s verse. Thumbnail sketches in the back matter describe the creatures featured in the book.
Author: Helen Frost
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Life Science (Biology), Visual Arts
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/General , English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, Science
Standard: LS K.2, LS 1.2, LS 2.2, LS 3.3, VAPA V PreK-12.1, LS 4.2, ES 5.3

Title: Stinker from Space
Annotation: The dilemma of alien space warrior Tsynq Yr (Stinker) is humorously explored in this selection. When his spaceship crashes, Stinker must switch from his injured body into that of a skunk. Humans Karen and Jonathan scheme with Stinker to get him back into orbit, but the plan will involve all the local skunks and a space shuttle.
Author: Pamela F. Service

Title: Stinky Cheese Man and Other Fairly Stupid Tales
Annotation: These ten fractured fairy tales are designed to entertain readers whose familiarity with original folklore enables them to appreciate the humor. Text and artwork are equally irreverent in relating the fate of the Stinky Cheese Man (reminiscent of the more traditional Gingerbread Boy) or the demise of the whiney Little Red Hen, who intrudes on other stories throughout the book.
Author: Jon Scieszka

Title: Stinky Stern Forever
Annotation: A young Hmong girl, Pa Lia, witnesses an accident with her brother that ultimately takes the life of the second-grade bully, Matthew “Stinky” Stern. After the accident, the teacher asks the children to share their memories of Stinky. Because she never liked him, Pa Lia is conflicted but finds solace in drawing pictures of events in Stinky’s life. While potentially charged with emotion, this story is gently and truthfully presented for young readers. Illustrated with black-and-white artwork.
Author: Michelle Edwards

Title: Stompin’ at the Savoy
Annotation: On the night of the jazz dance recital, Mindy feels too nervous to go. Then a magical drum whisks her away to the Savoy Ballroom in 1920s Harlem, where she finds her happy feet dancing to the sounds of legendary bands. Energetic watercolor and pastel paintings enhance this lyrical story. Out of print.
Author: Bebe Moore Campbell

Title: Stompin’ at the Savoy: The Story of Norma Miller
Annotation: This is the story of professional jazz dancer Norma Miller and her coming of age in the heyday of swing. Her autobiography is enhanced by illustrations that evoke the vibrant sound and style of this jazz era.
Author: Alan Govenar (Editor)

Title: Stone Age Boy
Annotation: A short picture book that could be an entertaining introduction to the study of ancient man. A young boy is transported back in time and finds himself among a group of stone-age people. He befriends a young girl named Om and learns about prehistoric society by watching her people make fire, prepare food, use tools, and celebrate a successful hunt. Illustrated with double-page, cartoon-style characters.
Author: Satoshi Kitamura

Title: Stone Fox
Annotation: In order to save his grandfather's Wyoming farm, Little Willy enters the National Dog Sled Races hoping to win the money to pay her back taxes. His formidable opponent is Stone Fox, who has never lost a race. The courageous Little Willy and his gallant dog, Searchlight, give the race their best try. California author.
Author: John Reynolds Gardiner

Title: Stone Girl, Bone Girl
Annotation: This is a biography of the English girl who discovered an Ichthyosaurus skeleton in 1811 when she was twelve, leading to a life-long interest in fossils. An author's note provides information on Mary Anning's life and work. The illustrations are executed in a folk art style utilizing a variety of colors.
Author: Laurence Anholt

Title: Stone Rabbit: BC Mambo
Annotation: After Stone Rabbit discovers a black hole in his bathroom, he finds himself in a prehistoric world filled with danger and mystery. He evades velociraptors and Tyrannosaurus rexes and joins forces to save the past. Colorful, fun, and fast, this selection has a cartoon-like quality that will appeal to readers who enjoy graphic novels. First in the “Stone Rabbit” series.
Author: Erik Craddock

Title: Stone Wall Secrets
Annotation: As he and his grandson walk along the stone walls surrounding his New England farm, an old man shares stories about the geologic history of the stones as well as some of the memories they hold for him. This book is illustrated with rich watercolor artwork. STONE WALL SECRETS: EXPLORING GEOLOGY IN THE CLASSROOM; TEACHER'S GUIDE by Ruth Deike, a geologist with the USGS, is also available.
Author: Kristine Thorson, Robert Thorson

Title: Stories from Laos: Folktales and Cultures of the Lao, Hmong, Khammu, and Lu-Mien
Annotation: These eight folktales introduce four cultural groups from Laos and Southeast Asia. Each section begins with cultural notes related to the folktale, and black-line drawings illustrate each folktale. Regional dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text. Illustrated by staff of Ecoles Sans Frontieres, Vientiane, Lao PDR.
Author: Rosalie Giacchino-Baker

Title: Stories from Mencius
Annotation: This collection contains 24 well-illustrated and insightful short stories, legends, and folklore associated with the teachings and philosophy of Mencius.
Author: Wei Hsuing Li

Title: Stories Julian Tells, The
Annotation: Julian can lead his young brother Huey into a pack of trouble in a flick of an eye. Relationships with their father are central in the six stand-alone stories. Other titles in this series are STORIES HUEY TELLS, MORE STORIES JULIAN TELLS.
Author: Ann Cameron

Title: Storm Called Katrina, A
Annotation: A ten-year-old boy endures Hurricane Katrina in his hometown of New Orleans by using his cornet to maintain his courage. The family encounters various obstacles while being sheltered at the Louisiana Superdome. When Daddy goes off to find food for the family, he cannot find his way back. Louis plays his horn, and his father is reunited with the family. Illustrated with acrylic paintings featuring shades of blue, brown, and gray. Children will see what it is like to live through a harrowing experience.
Author: Myron Uhlberg
Topic: American History, Earth Science, Global Historical Events and Figures

Title: Storms
Annotation: The atmospheric conditions which create thunderstorms, hailstorms, lightning, tornadoes, and hurricanes are vividly portrayed in this book. It also tells how violent weather affects the environment and people in clear, concise text accompanied by 20 spectacular full-color photographs. This is one of a series of science books by this author.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Story of a Thousand Characters, The
Annotation: This collection of short stories, in an appealing format, is about the 1,000 basic Chinese characters.
Author: - Sun Ya Children's Education

Title: Story of Clocks and Calendars: Marking a Millennium, The
Annotation: Although it is geared to the beginning of the new millennium, this book serves as a basic introduction to a history of calendars and measuring time by discussing the use of everyday tools and marking important events. The illustrations are rendered in a variety of media such as colored pencil and watercolor, and diagrams and labels are included.
Author: Betsy Maestro

Title: Story of Johnny Appleseed, The
Annotation: Legendary Johnny Appleseed traveled west with a pouch of apple seeds, stopping to befriend and visit Indians and settlers and planting the seeds along the way. Use this book with THE LIFE AND TIMES OF THE APPLE, by Charles Misucci, and encourage students to read about apples and how they grow. Available in paperback only.
Author: - Aliki

Title: Story of Mah: A Hmong 'Romeo and Juliet' Folktale, The
Annotation: This Hmong version of ROMEO AND JULIET, set in the northern mountains of Laos, tells the story and loss of two young lovers. The story is illustrated with paintings that highlight the Hmong culture. Regional dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text. A teacher's guide is available.
Author: Rosalie Giacchino-Baker

Title: Story of Money, The
Annotation: The history of money from the barter system in ancient times to the development of modern monetary systems is discussed in this book. It also includes information about American currency. A sense of story is revealed through dramatic full-color illustrations rendered in a variety of media. This book would be useful for 6th grade ancient civilizations and 5th grade American history.
Author: Betsy Maestro
Standard: HSS 4.2, HSS 6.2, HSS 6.3, HSS 6.4, HSS 6.7, Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 3.NF.1-3, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 4.MD.1-7, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 6.NS.1-8

Title: Story of Ruby Bridges, The
Annotation: The experiences of the first African American child integrated into an all-Caucasian school in the south in the 1960s are detailed in this biography. Strong character traits of bravery, perseverance, and tolerance are demonstrated by six-year-old Ruby when faced with the prejudices of cruel adults.
Author: Robert Coles

Title: Story of Salt, The
Annotation: Presents a global history of salt, giving a scientific portrait of the compound and discussing cultural connections around the world. Includes maps and humorous illustrations that help explain the science, technology, and history of this product that is essential to human survival. One segment of the book covers the Salt March of 1930, led by Gandhi as a protest to the British monopoly on salt sales in India. This is an informational picture book that will intrigue readers in middle and upper grades.
Author: Mark Kurlansky
Topic: Economics, Global Historical Events and Figures, International Studies/World History, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Story of Snow: The Science of Winter’s Wonder, The
Annotation: Detailed, close-up photographs of snow crystals and snowflakes distinguish this title from others about snow. Concepts are presented in a clear, concise narrative that explains the formation and falling of snowflakes. The book includes ink-and-watercolor illustrations in addition to photographs. Different kinds of snowflakes are explained, and directions for catching snow crystals are presented. Children will come away from this book with a renewed sense of wonder.
Author: Jon Nelson, Mark Cassino
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Story of the Chinese Zodiac
Annotation: This bilingual text retells the story of how the gods decided on the names of the Chinese zodiac by holding a race for the animals. It is illustrated with paper sculpture collage. It is written in traditional Chinese and in English.
Author: Monica Chang

Title: Story of the Orchestra, The
Annotation: Orchestra Bob teaches children about classical music and its most influential composers. Children are introduced to composers, the orchestra, families of instruments, and the individual instruments in each family. Illustrated with colorful photos and cartoon-style drawings. Includes a CD-ROM with recordings of popular classical-music pieces.
Author: Robert Levine
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.4

Title: Story, a Story: An African Tale, A
Annotation: Anansi, the famed African trickster, makes a bargain with the Sky God and gains all the stories in the world, thus explaining how "spider stories" came to be. Woodcut illustrations highlight this tale.
Author: Gail E. Haley
Discipline: History/Social Science, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Storyteller
Annotation: Elizabeth lives with her aunt and is drawn to an ancestor, Zee, whose picture hangs on the wall. The story involves Zee’s hardships during the Revolutionary War and Elizabeth’s personal troubles. Their lives mirror each other as each one finds her own way to cope and discovers the strength to persevere. This is a moving story about love and loss.
Author: Patricia Reilly Giff
Topic: American History, Global Historical Events and Figures, War

Title: Strange Mr. Satie
Annotation: Introduces the life of French composer Erik Satie, who spent his entire career challenging the established conventions in music. The colorful artwork suits the Bohemian atmosphere surrounding Satie’s eccentric life and work. Although this book will not appeal to everyone, it should interest people who respect unique personalities.
Author: M. T. Anderson

Title: Streets of Gold
Annotation: Based on Mary Antin's PROMISED LAND, this adaptation is a memoir of her harsh childhood in Russia, her arrival in America, and her life in the Boston slums. The book goes on to relate Antin's course, through free education, in becoming a successful writer. This book is written in the first-person narrative, with quotes in the margins from the original work.
Author: Rosemary Wells

Title: Strega Nona: Her Story
Annotation: Strega Nona, a witch with a special gift, can cure illnesses, help girls find husbands, and get rid of warts. Big Anthony, her helper, misuses a bit of her magic, with terrible consequences, and learns a lesson. The book is illustrated in dePaola's comic style with bright colors and simple shapes.
Author: Tomie dePaola

Title: Stringbean's Trip to the Shining Sea
Annotation: This scrapbook features postcard and photo replicating reflects those that Stringbean and his brother Fred mail to their family in Jeloway, Kansas, as they travel west on a cross-country odyssey. The detailed watercolor, marker, and colored-pencil illustrations in folk-art style bring the journey to life in this imaginary and humorous slice of Americana.
Author: Vera B. Williams

Title: Strong Man: The Story of Charles Atlas
Annotation: An illustrated account of the life of Angelo Siciliano, an Italian immigrant who was tired of being pushed around and developed a program of physical fitness that transformed his life and earned him the name Charles Atlas. The book features appealing, comic-book-style illustrations. It also includes illustrated physical-fitness tips and an author’s note.
Author: Meghan McCarthy
Topic: Motor Skills/Movement Patterns, Nutrition and Physical Activity, Personal and Community Health, Physical Fitness

Title: Strudel Stories
Annotation: For seven generations a family has baked apple strudel to comfort and nourish its members. Readers enjoy the warm vignettes that span 100 years. Recipes and the author's family tree are included.
Author: Joanne Rocklin

Title: Stuart Little
Annotation: A heroic little mouse with very human qualities travels across the American countryside and finds himself involved in one adventure after another as he searches for his lost friend. This story is also available on audiocassette.
Author: E. B. White

Title: Suitcase of Seaweed, A
Annotation: This collection portrays the diversity of the author's Korean, Chinese, and American background through her poetry. Free and rhymed verse about family, being Asian, and general life experiences are divided into sections and prefaced by brief family histories. California author.
Author: Janet S. Wong

Title: Sukey and the Mermaid
Annotation: This is an African American folktale about a young girl named Sukey, who befriends the water spirit, a mermaid called Mama Jo. Sukey's friendship with Mama Jo allows her to escape hardships at home with Ma and Step-Pa, Mister Hard-Times. Told in a picture-book format, this story is enhanced by striking illustrations in scratchboard and oil pastels, which earned illustrator Brian Pinkney the Coretta Scott King Illustrator Honor Award in 1993. California author.
Author: Robert D. San Souci

Title: Summer of the Swans, The
Annotation: Fourteen-year-old Sara is jolted out of a period of discontent by the disappearance of her mentally handicapped ten-year-old brother, Charlie. She gains new insight into herself and her family as she forgets about her self-perceived miseries and realizes her love for Charlie.
Author: Betsy Cromer Byars

Title: Summer Reading Is Killing Me!
Annotation: Fred, Sam, and Joe mistakenly put their summer reading list in "The Book," which magically transports them to other places, other times. Nonstop literary humor occurs in this early chapter book adventure. The three boys get involved with characters from all the books on their list. Well-read readers will enjoy being "in the know" and those not familiar with the characters and books may be inspired to read more about them. This book is part of The Time Warp Trio series.
Author: Jon Scieszka

Title: Summer Wheels
Annotation: Two young boys wrestle with their sense of injustice when a new kid in the neighborhood does not return a bike belonging to "The Bicycle Man." This is a charming story of community and its meaning. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: Summer: An Alphabet Acrostic
Annotation: This acrostic poetry collection alphabetically describes animals and activities of the summer season. Each poem is accompanied by a framed linoleum block illustration incorporating rich colors and bold lines. Clever wordplay provides an excellent model for student writing and art. Companion volumes AUTUMN: AN ALPHABET ACROSTIC and SPRING: AN ALPHABET ACROSTIC.
Author: Steven Schnur
Classification: Alphabet Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: Sun
Annotation: This book takes an interactive approach to answering questions about the sun. With the help of two children and a lavender cat, readers are introduced to the physics of the sun. Concepts discussed include its distance from Earth, size, composition, temperature, sunspots, and solar flares. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Steve Tomecek
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Sun and Spoon
Annotation: After the death of his beloved grandmother, ten-year-old Spoon is afraid he might forget her and tries to find the perfect artifact to preserve his memories of her. This tender story is about family, the death of a loved one, honesty, and trust.
Author: Kevin Henkes

Title: Sun, Moon and Stars
Annotation: Legends and myths from around the world about the movements and appearance of the sun, the moon, and the stars are accompanied by brief information and lore in this read-aloud choice. Full-page illustrations and sidebars incorporate costumes and designs from a variety of cultures and are sprinkled with bits of gold and silver.
Author: Mary Hoffman

Title: Sun, the Wind, and the Rain, The
Annotation: The author uses a little girl's sand mountain to explain the formation of mountains and their erosion. Colorful illustrations clarify the concepts introduced in this book. This is a good introduction to the ways that Earth's surface is reshaped by natural processes.
Author: Lisa Westberg Peters

Title: Sunburned Prayer, A
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Eloy defies his parents' wishes and participates in a 17-mile pilgrimage on Good Friday to save his dying abuelita (grandmother). Eloy's spiritual and physical ordeal in the hot New Mexico sun becomes a trip of self-discovery as he ponders issues of devotion, faith, and unconditional love. This book portrays emotional intensity.
Author: Mark Talbert

Title: Sunsets of the West
Annotation: Pa wants to see the endless prairie, so the family packs up and undertakes the difficult journey to a new life in the West. A quiet, gentle story that presents details about what it was like to leave everything you know and go into the unknown. Illustrated with handsome, realistic watercolor paintings. California author.
Author: Tony Johnston

Title: Sunshine Makes the Seasons
Annotation: Colorful illustrations and clear, easy-to-read text give this revised edition more appeal than the 1974 edition. It includes less descriptive information about the four seasons and places more emphasis on the causes of seasonal changes. A simply stated and carefully illustrated experiment is included in which children use an orange, a pencil, and a flashlight to actually see the differences on earth caused by the tilt of the earth as it rotates on its axis and revolves around the sun. For younger children, Gibbons' SUN UP, SUN DOWN is a simpler version on this subject.
Author: Franklyn M. Branley

Title: Surfer of the Century: The Life of Duke Kahanamoku
Annotation: In this picture-book biography of Hawaiian Duke Kahanamoku, five-time Olympic swimming champion from the early 1900s, the reader learns that Kahanamoku is also considered the father of modern surfing. The bright illustrations evoke the art-deco period when Kahanamoku became famous.
Author: Ellie Crowe
Topic: Diversity, Global Historical Events and Figures, Motor Skills/Movement Patterns, Physical Fitness

Title: Surviving the Applewhites
Annotation: A troubled teen is sent to live with an eccentric family in this funny, contemporary story. Humorous style and characterization make this an excellent read-aloud novel.
Author: Stephanie S. Tolan
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements
Standard: VAPA T PreK-12.1, VAPA T PreK-12.3, VAPA T PreK-12.4, VAPA T PreK-12.5

Title: Swamp Angel
Annotation: Angelica Longrider, also known as Swamp Angel, lifts a wagon train out of a swamp, reroutes a river to put out a fire, and defeats a marauding bear to save the winter supplies of Tennessee settlers in this tall tale. American primitive paintings are framed in wood grains and highlight Swamp Angel's amazing exploits. Pair up this selection with a Paul Bunyan story for a tall-tale fest. California author.
Author: Anne Isaacs

Title: Sweet Clara and the Freedom Quilt
Annotation: Twelve-year-old Clara, a slave in the Big House, has two dreams - being with her mother once again and being free. Careful listening and learning about the Underground Railroad convinces Clara that she can piece a quilt that can actually be a used as a map of the Underground Railroad's route to freedom. Clara escapes but leaves the quilt as a map to guide other slaves to the Underground Railroad.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, Mathematics

Title: Sweet Land of Liberty
Annotation: This picture-book biography tells the story of Oscar Chapman, Assistant Secretary of the Interior under President Franklin Roosevelt, explaining how a childhood injustice influenced his decision to organize the 1939 concert given by African American opera singer Marian Anderson at the Lincoln Memorial after she had been denied the use of Constitution Hall. The book features mixed-media illustrations and includes an author’s note.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Sweet Music in Harlem
Annotation: C.J., who aspires to be as great a jazz musician as his uncle, searches for Uncle Click's hat in preparation for an important photograph and inadvertently gathers some of the greatest musicians of 1950s Harlem to join in on the picture. The text is jazzy with hip dialogue and is illustrated with bright acrylic paintings that show elongated characters. Includes author's note and the 1958 Art Kane photograph.
Author: Debbie A. Taylor
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary

Title: Sweet Potato Pie
Annotation: During a drought in the early 1900s, a large, loving African American family finds a delicious way to earn the money they need to save the family farm. Everyone in the family pitches in to help Mama bake sweet potato pies to sell. Acrylic paintings are done in an Impressionist style. Includes a recipe for sweet potato pie.
Author: Kathleen D. Lindsey

Title: Sweethearts of Rhythm: The Story of the Greatest All-Girl Swing Band in the World
Annotation: This poetic biography provides information about the all-female, racially integrated swing band that toured the United States from 1937 to 1946. It also has references to World War II, the Dust Bowl, segregation, and rationing. The vibrant illustrations blend drawing and painting with collage and evoke the rhythms and feelings of the music. Includes a bibliography, a time line, and a list of related Web sites. ALA Notable Children’s Book (2010); National Council for Social Studies Trade Book (2010).
Author: Marilyn Nelson
Topic: American History, Diversity, Music, Women’s Studies
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Swimming with Hammerhead Sharks
Annotation: The author dives with a marine biologist to study hammerhead sharks in Baja California and Costa Rica. Working scientists are quoted throughout explaining their research and investigation processes. The book is illustrated with dramatic color photographs and is a useful resource for students writing reports as well as an exciting book to read. See other books in the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Kenneth Mallory
Illustrator: Howard Hall, Kenneth Mallory, Michele Hall

Title: Sword of the Samurai: Adventure Stories from Japan
Annotation: Eleven short stories are presented about samurai warriors, their way of life, code of conduct, courage, wit, and foolishness. The samurai warrior stories from Japan might be compared for similarities to the King Arthur stories that came from Europe's Middle Ages. Each story can be read in one sitting and gives insight into the ancient cultures of Japan.
Author: Eric A. Kimmel

Title: Sybil’s Night Ride
Annotation: Presents the true story of sixteen-year-old Sybil Ludington, a little-known heroine of the American Revolution who rode through the countryside of New York to alert the colonists that the British were coming. On hearing her alarm, the colonists gathered and were able to push the British back. Detailed illustrations and an archival map of Sybil’s route are included. Muted paintings complement this true adventure.
Author: Karen B. Winnick

Title: Sylvester and the Magic Pebble
Annotation: A young donkey finds a magic pebble that grants him three wishes. When frightened by a lion, the donkey wishes he were a rock. His wish is granted, but the rock is too far away from the magic pebble to undo the wish after the danger has passed. Use this book to encourage readers to speculate what they would wish for if they were granted three wishes.
Author: William Steig

Title: Symphony of Whales, A
Annotation: Glashka, a young girl, is the only one in her village who can hear the voice of Narna, the whale. This gift leads her to great responsibility when she discovers thousands of whales trapped in a Siberian bay. The narrow route to the sea is rapidly icing over, covering more of the open water the whales need to breathe. This selection, inspired by an actual event, tells about a dramatic rescue, a tale of bravery and faith, and the power of music.
Author: Steve Schuch

Title: Tadpole
Annotation: When Tad, the thirteen-year-old cousin of Kentucky, Georgia, and Carolina, suddenly comes into their lives, they and Mama welcome him even though they can hardly afford to feed another person. After they discover that Tad's Uncle Matthew is an abusive guardian, they do all that they can to keep him safe. Set in the South in 1955. Good read-aloud.
Author: Ruth White

Title: Tadpole's Promise
Annotation: When a caterpillar meets her perfect love, a tadpole, she begs him to never change, but their relationship is doomed. Each of them changes into what they are destined to become. At the end, the frog leaps up and swallows the butterfly, not realizing that she is his "beautiful rainbow." Some readers may be shocked by this surprise ending.
Author: Jeanne Willis

Title: Tadpoles, The
Annotation: Frog's eggs are stolen by Catfish, who claims ownership as they turn into tadpoles that look like him. But when brought to court, the tadpoles turn into frogs, and Catfish is beaten up. This tale explains why the catfish's head is flat.
Author: Tran Quoc Hung

Title: Tai nang Cua Dua (Turtle Power)
Annotation: This Korean tale told in both Vietnamese and English tells of a turtle that is able to save a king because he can speak the language of both the sea and the land.
Publisher: National Asian Center for Bilingual Education
Author: Le Van Loc, Mieko S. Han

Title: Take Me Out to the Ballgame
Annotation: Presents the lyrics of the familiar song, illustrated with a backdrop of game five of the 1947 World Series (played by the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Yankees at Ebbets Field). The bold, bright artwork is true to the period and highlights the excitement and passion of vintage baseball. Includes the song’s music and lyrics.
Author: Jack Norworth
Standard: VAPA M PreK-12.2, VAPA M PreK-12.3

Title: Tale Dark and Grimm, A
Annotation: A story with interrelated chapters that follows Hansel and Gretel as they walk out of their story and into a variety of obscure fairy tales by the Brothers Grimm. The gruesomeness of the original tales is presented with a few touches of humor. Occasionally, the author interrupts the main text to speak directly to the readers, to warn them about what they have read or to add a humorous observation. This is a frightening and funny story that will keep readers engaged.
Author: Adam Gidwitz

Title: Tale of Despereaux: Being the Story of a Mouse, a Princess, Some Soup, and a Spool of Thread, The
Annotation: This tale tells the adventures of a very small mouse who is ridiculed because he is different, the princess that he loves and vows to protect, the servant girl who longs to be a princess, and a devious rat determined to bring them all to ruin. The simple style and short chapters make this a good choice for reluctant readers. Good read-aloud.
Author: Kate DiCamillo

Title: Talented Clementine, The
Annotation: Eight-year-old Clementine, convinced that she has no talent, tries to find a way to avoid participating in a school talent show. All of Clementine’s efforts are forgotten when, at the last minute, she saves the talent show from disaster. Critics see Clementine as the next Ramona Quimby (the beloved Beverly Cleary character). A fun read-aloud.
Author: Sara Pennypacker

Title: Tales from Gold Mountain: Stories of the Chinese in the New World
Annotation: Brave Chinese immigrants and their experiences are the basis of this collection of eight stories. In a masterful weaving of Chinese customs and of the prejudice and adversity they faced in North America, the stories describe the unique place the Chinese created for themselves.
Author: Paul Yee

Title: Tales of Famous Americans
Annotation: Describes the lives and accomplishments of 19 Americans, including Benjamin Franklin, George Washington, Sitting Bull, Jackie Robinson, and Mia Hamm. Each tale begins with a bright caricature of the person, set against a photograph of a relevant locale, and includes entertaining information about the individual’s childhood and youth.
Author: Connie Roop, Peter Roop

Title: Tales Our Abuelitas Told: A Hispanic Folktale Collection
Annotation: Stories presented here are from the authors’ grandmothers and are told in the particular style that the authors remember from childhood. Other stories in the collection are gathered from around the Spanish-speaking world, from Spain to Mexico and Cuba, and represent a variety of subcultures, including Basque and Sephardic Jews. Illustrated by four outstanding Latino artists. Includes information about the artists and authors.
Author: Alma Flor Ada, F. Isabel Campoy
Illustrator: Felipe Davalos, Leyla Torres, Susan Guevara, Vivi Escriva
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Talkin' About Bessie: The Story of Aviator Elizabeth Coleman
Annotation: An imagined monologue on each page tells about the life of Bessie Coleman by those who knew her best. As a young girl, Bessie was determined to be the first African American female pilot. This picture book biography for older readers is filled with facts about a brave woman and enables young readers to understand her spirit.
Author: Nikki Grimes
Award: Coretta Scott King Author Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Winner

Title: Talking Eggs: A Folktale from the American South
Annotation: This Creole version of the Cinderella folktale features African American characters. Blanche befriends an old woman who has extraordinary powers and is rewarded for her virtue, while her greedy sister is punished by a plague of snakes, toads, yellow jackets, and more. The book's full-color pencil and watercolor artwork is detailed and expressive. California author.
Author: Robert D. San Souci
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Honor

Title: Talking to the Sun: An Illustrated Anthology of Poems for Young People
Annotation: This book features poems from various time periods and many countries, organized by theme and illustrated with reproductions of artworks from the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. This is an excellent resource for history projects and may also be used as a read-aloud or inspiration for Reader’s Theater.
Author: Kate Farrell, Kenneth Koch
Topic: American History, Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Ethnic Studies, Global Historical Events and Figures, Visual Arts
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.3, HSS 3.2, VAPA V PreK-12.5, HSS 4.2, HSS 5.4

Title: Talking Walls
Annotation: Walls around the world can separate or hold communities together. The Australian Aboriginal rock wall art, the Wailing Wall, the Great Wall of China, and the Berlin Wall are featured in this book.
Author: Margy Burns Knight

Title: Talking with Adventurers
Annotation: The lives of 12 scientists are profiled in this collection of autobiographical data and interview-question responses. Among those profiled are Robert Ballard, Christina Allen, Jane Goodall, Dereck Joubert, and Beverly Joubert. A favorite question posed was, "What is the scariest thing that ever happened to you in your work?"
Author: Pat Cummings (compiler/editor)

Title: Tall Tales: Six Amazing Basketball Dreams
Annotation: Six short stories about basketball are told with the use of brightly colored print, various fonts, and words splashed across the pages in energetic arrangements. The photographs in the background depict mostly inner-city basketball and include all sizes, genders, and abilities. This page size is extra tall, making these truly "tall" tales. Basketball lovers will enjoy the action and energy.
Author: Charles R. Smith, Jr.

Title: Tallchief: America's Prima Ballerina
Annotation: This first-person narrative presents Maria Tallchief's childhood and adolescence up to the point when she leaves home to seek a dancing career in New York. Full-page pastels in soft tones reflect Tallchief's remembrances of growing up in a loving and supportive family. Co-author Rosemary Wells adds a personal note in the foreword that underscores Tallchief's reputation as a ballerina.
Author: Maria Tallchief, Rosemary Wells
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.5

Title: Tam Va Nam (Tam and Nam)
Annotation: Tam and Nam are brother and sister in this coloring book format, which has simple passages on each page that are good for practicing Vietnamese reading.
Author: - Unknown

Title: Tanya and the Red Shoes
Annotation: In this sixth book about Tanya, she has been studying ballet and longs to begin pointe work with her first pair of toe shoes, especially after she watches the movie version of “The Red Shoes.” She perseveres through blisters, and with a lot of practice she finally succeeds. The expressive watercolor-and-ink illustrations show an understanding of the proper positions and dynamics of ballet, right down to finger placement and the correct tilt of the head.
Author: Patricia Lee Gauch

Title: Tapenum's Day: A Wampanoag Indian Boy in Pilgrim Times
Annotation: This photo-story explores the life of Native American Tapenum, a Wampanoag boy, in 1620s Plymouth, Massachusetts. In this story Tapenum struggles to find his place in his community. Habitat, artifacts, clothing, tools, weapons, and the daily activities of the tribe and setting are shown. Appended material includes a map and a glossary. See also SARAH MORTON'S DAY, and SAMUEL EATON'S DAY.
Author: Kate Waters

Title: Tar Beach
Annotation: With hopes for a better life, young Cassie imagines that she can fly over Harlem and toward happiness. Quilt paintings illustrate Cassie's fanciful journeys and her unwavering hope. California author/illustrator.
Author: Faith Ringgold
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Winner

Title: Tarantula in My Purse and 172 Other Wild Pets, The
Annotation: The author tells a variety of stories about raising a houseful of children and wild pets including crows, skunks, and raccoons. Each chapter describes a different animal or incident and begins with an intriguing title making this a read-aloud choice.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: Tarantula Scientist, The
Annotation: Arachnologist Sam Marshall collects tarantulas in French Guiana and takes them to Hiram College in Ohio, where he and his students study them. Full-color photographs show detailed views of the spiders and are an excellent accompaniment to the interesting and often humorous narrative. Readers will come away with a sense of how answers that come from research lead to new questions. Included are an index, a glossary, a bibliography, suggested Web sites, and an index. This book is a part of the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Sy Montgomery

Title: Taste of Blackberries, A
Annotation: This touching novel relates the struggle a young boy faces when he must accept the accidental death of his best friend Jamie. The young narrator suffers not only a sense of loss but also feelings of guilt, because he believes that Jamie's reaction to the fatal bee sting was just another attempt to get attention. This work of realistic fiction is emotionally intense, presenting the subject of death from a young person's perspective. This is an outstanding book for literary studies.
Author: Doris Buchanan Smith

Title: Taste of Colored Water, A
Annotation: Living in a small Southern town in the 1960s, Jelly and LuLu are intrigued when they hear a friend’s story of a “colored” water fountain in the big city. They imagine rainbow flavors of water spilling out of the fountain. A trip to the city gives them a chance to witness the fountain for themselves. As they get a cool drink of water, they see firefighters and police officers meeting civil rights marchers in the streets and are horrified when hoses are turned on the marchers. An afterword gives historical context.
Author: Matt Faulkner

Title: Tchaikovsky Discovers America
Annotation: Tchaikovsky visited America in 1891 and kept a detailed diary of his trip. His observations are woven into the fictional diary of a shy eleven-year-old, Jenny Petroff, who meets the composer during his stay in America. This book promotes a nice integration of history/social science and music.
Author: Esther Kalman
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Te atreves? Electroimanes en accion (Do You Dare? Electromagnets in Action)
Annotation: This book on electromagnets includes full-color photographs, brief text, charts, and diagrams which help students understand today's technological advances. Directions for simple activities and experiments are also provided. Another book in the Serie Electricidad (Electricity Series) series is TE ATREVES? IMANES Y CORRIENTE ELECTRICA (DO YOU DARE? MAGNETS AND ELECTRICITY).
Author: Albert Rovira Sumalia

Title: Te atreves? Imanes y corriente electrica (Do You Dare? Magnets and Electricity)
Annotation: This book features full-color photographs, brief text, charts, and diagrams to help students understand electricity. Numerous simple activities and experiments are also described to help them understand the place of electricity in today's technological world. Another book in the Serie Electricidad (Electricity Series) series is TE ATREVES? ELECTROIMANES EN ACCION (DO YOU DARE? ELECTROMAGNETS IN ACTION).
Author: Albert Rovira Sumalia

Title: Tea with Milk
Annotation: After graduating from high school in California, May's family takes her back to prewar Japan so that a matchmaker can find her a suitable husband. Instead, May finds herself a job. This story of immigration and cultural identity includes elegant illustrations. California author/illustrator.
Author: Allen Say
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Team Moon: How 400,000 People Landed Apollo 11 on the Moon
Annotation: With admiration and enthusiasm, the author pays tribute to the 400,000 people who got Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin on the moon and back to the earth again. The team contributed to the eight years of work that helped lead to the accomplishment of that feat. Using many primary resources and interviews with surviving participants, the text covers the period from May 1961 to July 1969 and describes the work of NASA and its many contractors - the building of the command and lunar modules, the sewing of the spacesuits, the development of the portable life-support systems, the efforts of the Australian telescope operators, the testing of the recovery parachutes, the contingency plans, and more. Numerous stunning photographs accompany the text, printed mostly in white type over black or photo backgrounds. Source notes, a glossary, an index, and a brief description of the Apollo missions are appended.
Author: Catherine Thimmesh
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Teammates
Annotation: When Branch Rickey brought Jackie Robinson to baseball's Major Leagues, Robinson endured prejudice and racism as the first black Major League player. White teammate Pee Wee Reese stood by Robinson when the crowds verbally abused him. The book is illustrated with watercolor illustrations and archival photographs.
Author: Peter Golenbock

Title: Tell Me, Tree: All About Trees for Kids
Annotation: This is a bright, colorful introduction to leaves, trees, and their inner workings. It describes a wide variety of trees and how to identify them. The author gives readers a description of the growth of trees from seed to tree; provides labeled diagrams of trees inside and out; and explains specialized terms, such as cambium, phloem, sapwood, heartwood, chlorophyll, and photosynthesis. Directions for leaf pressing and bark-rubbing activities can be found at the end of the book along with additional facts about trees.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Ten Mile Day and the Building of the Transcontinental Railroad, The
Annotation: In 1869, the Central Pacific Railroad raced to build ten miles of track in one day and thus best the Union Pacific's earlier record of seven-plus miles. This book describes the track-laying process, materials used, workers involved, hardships, and the culminating success that led to the completion of the transcontinental railroad. A bibliography, a glossary, and a map are included. This book is available in paperback or prebind. California author and setting.
Author: Mary Ann Fraser

Title: Ten Times Better
Annotation: A variety of animals introduce the multiples of ten by trying to outdo each other. Rich vocabulary and humor expressed through poetry make this math/science book an excellent read aloud. The watercolor illustrations vary in size to represent the animals and their numbers. Included are information on the animals and some multiplication problems.
Author: Richard Michelson
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear)

Title: Tenth Good Thing About Barney, The
Annotation: A little boy is saddened by the death of his cat, Barney. Prompted by his mom to think of ten good things to say about Barney at the funeral, he can come up with only nine. Later, his father helps him to discover a tenth good thing about Barney.
Author: Judith Viorst

Title: Testing Miss Malarkey
Annotation: The students in Miss Malarkey’s class believe her when she says that state testing is not important, but then they see how the rest of the faculty is dealing with test week. This humorous and insightful look at the pressures of testing provides great comic relief before any big test. Recommended as a read-aloud.
Author: Judy Finchler

Title: Tet: The New Year
Annotation: While preparing for Tet, a group of Vietnamese students discuss the different customs and traditions to celebrate this special holiday. The book is currently out of print but is available in many school library collections.
Author: Tran Kim Lan

Title: Thank You, Mr. Falker
Annotation: Trisha has looked forward to learning to read. But it isn't until she is in fifth grade that she finds a dedicated teacher who helps her to understand and overcome her problem. This powerful literacy story is based on the author's actual experience.
Author: Patricia Polacco

Title: Thank You, Sarah: The Woman Who Saved Thanksgiving
Annotation: Presents the story of how Sarah Hale convinced Abraham Lincoln to make Thanksgiving a national holiday. The story is illustrated with droll, humorous artwork rendered in ink and watercolor. An interesting account of how one person can bring about change through persistence and hard work, the book includes a historical note offering additional information.
Publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
Author: Laurie Halse Anderson
Topic: American History, Government and Politics, Women’s Studies

Title: Theo and the Blue Note
Annotation: Theo the cat has learned to play only one blue note on his saxophone, but when a magical rocket ship carries him to the moon, he joins Charlie Porker, Nat King Cobra, Duck Ellington, and other great jazz musicians in a jam session. Illustrated with watercolor paints, colored pencils, and collage artwork. Provides children with an introduction to jazz music and artists.
Author: Peter Kuper

Title: Theodosia and the Serpents of Chaos
Annotation: Theodosia Throckmorton’s parents are archaeologists, and Theodosia spends her time in the museum ridding newly arrived antiquities of hexes and evil spells. When her mother returns to the museum with an ancient amulet that carries an exceptionally evil power, Theodosia is thrust into an adventure and mystery. This story is a good choice for readers interested in ancient Egypt, mythology, strong female characters, and mystery. First book in the “Theodosia” series.
Author: R. L. LaFevers

Title: There's a Frog in My Throat: 440 Animal Sayings a Little Bird Told Me
Annotation: The authors collected 440 animal sayings - similes, metaphors, idioms, and proverbs. The inventory of animals includes household pets, farm animals, wild animals, birds, insects, underground creatures, and fish. The sayings are Illustrated in a variety of styles that create better understanding and lend additional humor. An index is included.
Author: Loreen Leedy, Pat Street

Title: There's a Zoo on You
Annotation: The variety of microorganisms that inhabit the human body are described in a direct and, at times, humorous manner. The book focuses on symbiotic organisms that live together and share food. Complementing the text are numerous color photographs of microorganisms including, bacteria, E. coli, dust mites, eyelash mites, staphylococcus aureus, and papoviruses.
Author: Kathy Darling

Title: There's an Owl in the Shower
Annotation: Protecting endangered spotted owls has cost a young boy's father his job as a logger in the old growth forest of Northern California. The boy intends to kill any spotted owl he sees until he and his father find themselves taking care of a young owlet. California setting.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: There's Still Time: The Success of the Endangered Species Act
Annotation: Success stories of the Endangered Species Act are highlighted in this book. The difference between threatened and endangered species is explained along with information about animals and plants that are or were threatened with extinction. The book is illustrated with large, crystal-clear full-color photographs. Included is a foreword by Bruce Babbitt. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Mark A. Galan

Title: They Called Her Molly Pitcher
Annotation: True story of the courage of Molly Hays, better known as Molly Pitcher, at the Battle of Monmouth during the American Revolution. Oil paintings and text vividly describe the heroic actions Molly Pitcher took while under fire.
Author: Anne Rockwell

Title: They Swim the Seas: The Mystery of Animal Migration
Annotation: The migratory habits of animals are described in this book. Information is provided on the reasons for migration, where large migrations occur, and how this adaptive pattern benefits some animals. Watercolor illustrations are a perfect complement to Simon's clear, narrative writing. This book is the second in a series of three books, the companion titles are THEY WALK THE EARTH: THE EXTRAORDINARY TRAVELS OF ANIMALS ON LAND and RIDE THE WIND: AIRBORNE JOURNEYS OF ANIMALS AND PLANTS.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: They Walk the Earth: The Extraordinary Travels of Animals on Land
Annotation: This book describes the movement of mammals and amphibians on long seasonal journeys. It includes caribou, squirrels, and lemmings. It also the effects humans have on animal migration. Quiet, detailed paintings illustrate the movement of the animals. This is a companion title to THEY SWIM THE SEAS and RIDE THE WIND.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Thinking It Through
Annotation: This book introduces students to thinking logically. It discusses how scientists use reasoning and logical thinking to do their work; explains how Venn diagrams provide a logical way to classify data; teaches how to recognize valid conclusions by examining if-then statements; and explains how to interpret graphs to explain relationships between different living things and how changes in environments can be influenced by humans.
Author: Kate Boehm Jerome

Title: Thirteen Nights of Halloween, The
Annotation: This Halloween version of the 12 Days of Christmas has detailed illustrations on every page with the gifts and a hidden little wizard for children to find. The predictable text with repeated phrases is ideal for emerging readers. Young children can count the gifts, older learners can compute numbers of gifts.
Author: Rebecca Dickinson
Standard: Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 5.OA.1-3, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.G.1-6

Title: Thirty-Six Characters
Annotation: Based on a Children's Movie Award-Winning film, this selection features abbreviated, humorous traditional Chinese folktales about three monks.
Author: Haizi Wang
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements

Title: This Big Sky
Annotation: This award-winning Latino poet captures the wonder of the Southwest in this collection of 14 poems. The poems focus on the animals, weather, and people of the region. Cut-paper illustrations complement the poems. The book includes a glossary of the Spanish words that are used in some of the poems.
Author: Pat Mora

Title: This Bridge Will Not Be Gray
Annotation:
The Golden Gate Bridge is the most famous bridge in the world, and it is the world’s only bright-orange bridge. But it wasn't supposed to be that way.

This book tells the story of how the bridge that some people wanted to be red and white, and some people wanted to be yellow and black, and most people wanted simply to be gray, instead became orange.
Author: Dave Eggers

Title: This Is the Dream
Annotation: Opening with scenes of segregation, this book chronicles events that were part of the civil rights movement. Rhythmic language, together with paintings and collage artwork featuring archival photographs, helps the reader understand the power of nonviolent change and recognize the steps leaders took to correct inequality.
Author: Diane Z. Shore, Jessica Alexander

Title: This Is the Ocean
Annotation: This book explores the cycle of water from the ocean to the clouds, mountains, rivers and streams, and back to the ocean. The rhyming text is rich in its simplicity. The full-color illustrations are composed of three-dimensional textured-paper collages.
Author: Kersten Hamilton

Title: This Is the Tree
Annotation: This is a poetic story of an ancient baobab tree and the wildlife in Africa that dwell within the tree. The author has chosen a prose poem as the literary form for telling the story of this amazing tree. The final page of the book has a detailed diagram of the parts of the tree.
Author: Miriam Moss

Title: This Land Is Your Land
Annotation: The words of one of America's most popular folk songs are enhanced by colorful folk-art illustrations of Americans and their land, past and present. A wealth of United States cultural and social history are packed into each page. Also includes Woody Guthrie scrapbook, maps, the musical score of the song, and a tribute to Woody Guthrie, written by Pete Seeger.
Author: Woody Guthrie
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: This Land Is Your Land: Words and Music by Woody Guthrie
Annotation: This well-known folk song is presented and accompanied by a tribute from folk singer Pete Seeger, the musical notation, and a biographical scrapbook. The book is illustrated with vibrant postcard views of America showing the geography, landscapes, and diversity of people found in the United States. Helpful for introducing discussions about the Dust Bowl and the Depression and for studying the United States and its symbols.
Author: Woody Guthrie
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: This Place Is Cold
Annotation: Full-color paintings and drawings enhance this text about Alaska's environment. It focuses on the land, animals, plants, and climate of Alaska, presenting it as an example of a place where it is so cold your hair can freeze and break off. Information is provided about Alaska's geographical location and its weather. See other books in the Imagine Living Here series.
Author: Vicki Cobb

Title: This Place Is Dry
Annotation: Colorful illustrations and an engaging text describe a North American desert ecosystem. Information is provided on the adaptations of plants and animals to the dry environment. The story provides a good overview of Arizona's Sonoran Desert habitat. See other books in the Imagine Living Here series.
Author: Vicki Cobb

Title: This Place Is Wet
Annotation: Colorful illustrations and engaging text describe the ecosystem of the Amazon rain forest in Brazil and the people that live there. The text provides information on the adaptations of the plants and animals found in such a wet environment. It also notes the ways this ecosystem is becoming endangered. See other books in the Imagine Living Here series.
Author: Vicki Cobb

Title: Thomas Edison y la electricidad (Thomas Edison and Electricity)
Annotation: This book about one of America's most famous inventors combines clear writing with a layout of black-and-white photographs, illustrations, graphics, and sidebars that will interest and inform readers. Other titles in the Pioneros de la Ciencia (Pioneers of Science) series that have been translated into Spanish include LOUIS PASTEUR Y LOS GERMENES (LOUIS PASTEUR AND GERMS), MARIE CURIE Y EL RADIO (MARIE CURIE AND RADIUM), GUGLIELMO MARCONI Y LA RADIO (GUGLIELMO MARCONI AND THE RADIO), and ISAAC NEWTON Y LA GRAVEDAD (ISAAC NEWTON AND GRAVITY).
Author: Steve Parker

Title: Thomas Jefferson Grows a Nation
Annotation: Jefferson's passion for agriculture takes center stage in this picture-book biography. The book follows Jefferson's many efforts to promote America as a nation of farmers including growing new crops, smuggling rice, and commissioning Lewis and Clark's expedition.
Author: Peggy Thomas

Title: Those Amazing Musical Instruments! Your Guide to the Orchestra Through Sounds and Stories
Annotation: Contains facts and stories about the history and construction of the individual instruments that make up an orchestra, including strings, woodwinds, brass, percussion, and keyboards. Features a discussion of the human voice, electronic instruments, and the conductor. Includes musical examples on a CD-ROM. This comprehensive and accessible title also offers many full-color illustrations.
Author: Genevieve Helsby

Title: Those Rebels, John & Tom
Annotation: John Adams and Thomas Jefferson may have been different in their appearance and in their behavior, but they were strongly connected in their feelings about the new United States of America. This is a humorous look at the differences between the two founding fathers and the ways that they came together in support and friendship, forming an alliance that launched a new nation. Illustrated in a style that resembles political cartoons. An excellent read-aloud choice.
Author: Barbara Kerley

Title: Those Rebels, John and Tom
Annotation: This book introduces children to the lives and accomplishments of John Adams and Thomas Jefferson.
Author: Barbara Kerley

Title: Three Days on a River in a Red Canoe
Annotation: This book, designed as a journal, tells of a young girl who records the events of a three-day camping trip in a red canoe with her mother, her Aunt Rosie, and her cousin. Pencil-and-watercolor illustrations are done in a childlike style. This book can be used effectively as a model for a travel journal. Helpful camping information is included.
Author: Vera B. Williams

Title: Three Pigs, The
Annotation: The three pigs escape the wolf by going to another world where they meet the cat and the fiddle, the cow that jumped over the moon, and a dragon. The artwork shifts into various illustrative styles as the pigs step out of the pages of the book and leave the wolf behind.
Author: David Wiesner
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements

Title: Three Questions, The
Annotation: Based on a story by Leo Tolstoy, this tale centers on a young boy named Nikolai and his animal friends, who attempt to answer three important questions: (1) “When is the best time to do things?”; (2) “Who is the most important one?”; and (3) “What is the right thing to do?” Nikolai yearns to be a good person, and this book sends a simple and direct message that will stimulate conversation. Beautiful, evocative watercolor illustrations enhance the story.
Author: Jon J. Muth

Title: Through My Eyes
Annotation: Ruby Bridges recounts the story of her involvement at age six in the integration of her school in New Orleans in 1960. Powerful sepia-toned photographs enhance the story. The selection may be used in the fifth- and eighth-grade history/social science curricula and in civil rights units.
Author: Margo Lundell, Ruby Bridges
Classification: Photo Essay, Picture Book, Read Aloud, Struggling Reader

Title: Thunder Birds: Nature's Flying Predators
Annotation: More than 20 large birds of prey are displayed on two-page spreads, featuring Arnosky’s signature artwork using acrylics and pencil sketches. Includes some foldout pages for larger images. Each spread provides a brief description of how the bird hunts and catches its prey. An author’s note lists the parks, refuges, and sanctuaries visited, as well as books for further reading.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: Thunder Rose
Annotation: Unusual from the day she is born, Thunder Rose performs all sorts of amazing feats, including building metal structures, taming a stampeding herd of steers, capturing a gang of rustlers, and turning aside a tornado. Oil, watercolor, and pencil illustrations capture the vistas of the Wild West and the spunky personalities.
Author: Jerdine Nolen

Title: Thuy Tells Her Life Story
Annotation: Thuy's dramatic life is told as her family struggles to survive the war and its consequences.
Author: - Unknown

Title: Tiger and the Frog, The
Annotation: This Vietnamese folktale teaches readers that by using one's wits, one can outsmart a bigger bully.
Author: Bui Thach

Title: Tiger Math: Learning to Graph from a Baby Tiger
Annotation: The authors follow the growth of an orphaned Siberian tiger cub as it goes through its developmental changes. The story is presented in engaging text supported by several types of graphs and full-color photographs. This is a fine example of the integration of science and math.
Author: Ann Whitehead Nagda, Cindy Bickel
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Statistics, Data Analysis, & Probability
Standard: LS 2.2, LS 7.2, Math 1.MD.1-4, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.MD.1-10, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 3.MD.1-8, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.MD.1-7

Title: Tiger Rescue: Changing the Future for Endangered Wildlife
Annotation: The author discusses threats to the tiger's survival and examines tiger conservation efforts being made around the world. The tiger’s natural habitat, habits, physiology, and behavior in captivity are discussed. Also included are a timeline of conservation efforts and stunning and exciting full-color photographs.
Author: Dan Bortolotti

Title: Tigers, Frogs, and Rice Cakes, A Book of Korean Proverbs
Annotation: Twenty Korean proverbs are glowingly illustrated in this collection. The proverbs are written in Korean characters, with English translations. Included is an adaptation that shows how the words should be spoken aloud. Explanations of each proverb as they relate to character; cooperation; accomplishment; or eating follow the collection. California author and illustrator.
Author: Daniel D. Holt

Title: Tigress
Annotation: When an Indian tigress and her cubs threaten a nearby herd, a sanctuary ranger persuades the people to use fireworks to frighten her back into the forest rather than use poison. Brilliant paintings show the animal's fear as well as the herdsman's fear for his livestock. The book highlights the role of creatures in the food chain.
Author: Helen Cowcher

Title: Tillie the Terrible Swede: How One Woman, a Sewing Needle, and a Bicycle Changed History
Annotation: Tillie Anderson emigrates from Sweden to America in the late 1800s, and all she has is a needle. One day, she sees a bicycle, and from that moment she begins to dream of riding in bike races. She begins to work out and uses her needle to make clothing so she will not be encumbered by her dresses. Though shunned by many, she begins winning races and breaking records—in spite of attempts by others to make her fail. This is a lively look at an inspiring but little-known champion.
Author: Sue Stauffacher
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Immigration/Migration, Nutrition and Physical Activity, Women’s Studies

Title: Time and the Clockmice, Etcetera
Annotation: This short, funny, chapter book relates the adventures of clockmice coming alive in the Branton Town Hall clock. When the grandson of the original clockmaster is engaged to fix the clock, he decides to teach the city of mice a lesson. However, it is the grandson who learns the lesson that the Hickorys, the Dickorys, and the Docks are very special mice families.
Author: Peter Dickinson

Title: Time for Ballet
Annotation: Tilly, who loves ballet, plays the part of a cat in her class’s dance recital. This story is narrated in a fresh, childlike voice with realistic details of everyday life. The illustrations vary from action-filled double-page spreads to smaller spot art; all are filled with humorous and realistic detail.
Author: Adèle Geras
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.2

Title: Time Train
Annotation: Children take a field trip on the Rocky Mountain Unlimited back through time to observe living dinosaurs in their natural habitat. The tongue-in-cheek text and illustrations spark the imagination and curiosity about time travel. The full-color illustrations make a dramatic use of light and points of view.
Author: Paul Fleischman

Title: To Be an Artist
Annotation: An introduction to various forms of creative expression, this book includes eye-catching photographs of children from around the world. It offers a vibrant look at children drawing, painting, singing, dancing, writing, and more.
Author: John D. Ivanko, Maya Ajmera
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.1, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.4, VAPA D PreK-12.5, VAPA M PreK-12.1, VAPA M PreK-12.3, VAPA M PreK-12.4, VAPA M PreK-12.5, VAPA T PreK-12.4, VAPA T PreK-12.5, VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: To Dance: A Ballerina’s Graphic Novel
Annotation: This memoir, in graphic-novel format, follows the career of author Siena Cherson Siegel, detailing her dance-school experiences, performances, and personal life. Born in Puerto Rico, she came to America to become a student at the School of American Ballet in New York City and danced onstage in children’s roles during the late 1970s and early 1980s. The watercolor-and-ink illustrations give a unique feel to this dancer’s memoir.
Author: Siena Cherson Siegel
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA D PreK-12.3, VAPA D PreK-12.5

Title: To Fly: The Story of the Wright Brothers
Annotation: The story of the Wright Brothers is portrayed in brief, accessible chapters, beginning with their childhood fascination with flight and love of problem solving to their stunning achievement. Parker's loose, airy watercolor illustrations are suited to this story of flight.
Author: Wendie Old

Title: To Space and Back
Annotation: Sally Ride's account of her journey as a space shuttle astronaut is informative, fascinating and has an immediacy that is engaging. The text is accompanied by a glossary, an index, and numerous color photographs of many other space shuttle astronauts, in addition to the five who served on Ride's mission.
Author: Sally Ride, Susan Okie

Title: Toad Is the Uncle of Heaven
Annotation: This Vietnamese folktale explains why it rains when the toad croaks and how he became the uncle of heaven.
Author: Jeanne M. Lee

Title: Todo acerca de la luna (All About the Moon)
Annotation: Using a question and answer format, this book explains what a beginning scientist would want to know about the moon. It is one in a series of books on science topics. Other titles include: LOS ARBOLES (TREES), AIRE, AIRE, AIRE (AIR), LA ENERGIA (ENERGY), LOS ESTACIONES (THE SEASONS), and many others.
Author: David A. Adler

Title: Todo doble o como divorciarse con buen humor (Two of Everything)
Annotation: Demetrio and Paula's parents have a disastrous marriage. The two children decide to organize an "unwedding." After their separate honeymoons, they return to live in two separate houses where now they can live happily separated forever. The watercolor illustrations are combined with direct, no-nonsense text.
Author: Babette Cole

Title: Todo empezo con caracol (Snail Started It)
Annotation: When Snail insults Mother Pig about being stout, the other animals begin making unkind remarks to each other. Finally, Goose insults Snail, and they realize how mean-spirited comments can hurt. Goose offers his apology and the other animals follow his example.
Author: Katja Reider

Title: Toliver’s Secret
Annotation: Timid Ellen Toliver gains self-confidence as she undertakes a dangerous mission on behalf of the Patriots during the American Revolution. Her injured grandfather, an American spy, asks Ellen to take his place and deliver an important message—hidden in a loaf of bread—to General George Washington. Available only in paperback.
Author: Esther Wood Brady

Title: Tomas and the Library Lady (Tomas y la senora de la biblioteca)
Annotation: While helping his family work as migrant laborers far from home, Tomas discovers a new world in the books at the public library. This multicultural-theme story is based on the true story of Tomas Rivera, who later became a leader in education and the chancellor of University of California, Riverside.
Author: Pat Mora

Title: Tomas lee al reves (The Upside-Down Reader)
Annotation: Sitting opposite his sister Tina while she does her homework, Tim, a preschooler, learns to read right along with her. The only problem is, he learns to read upside down! The illustrations are colorful and humorous.
Author: Wilhelm Gruber

Title: Ton
Annotation: In graphically simple illustrations of relative weight, industrial workers lift, push, hoist, and pull girders, cement, bricks and other materials weighing from 50 pounds to more than one ton. The text indicates the weight but nothing else. Information on different ways to measure weight is included at the end of the book.
Author: Taro Miura

Title: Too Many Tamales
Annotation: The importance of honesty is shown as four Latino children spend an unforgettable Christmas Eve searching for Maria's mother's diamond wedding ring, lost in the tamale masa (dough). The illustrations feature expressive oil paintings in warm tones that match the festive holiday mood. California author.
Author: Gary Soto
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: Tooth and Claw: Animal Adventures in the Wild
Annotation: The author, a gifted story teller, relates his experiences with animals in the wild while traveling the world, following each section with facts about the featured animal and its habitat. These well told adventures make excellent read-aloud choices. Watercolors and photographs are scattered throughout the book to show the people, animals, geographical features, and modes of transport, providing a travel-diary quality to the story.
Author: Ted Lewin

Title: Toothpaste Millionaire, The
Annotation: A young white girl describes how her African American friend, Rufus Mayflower, made more than a million dollars by creating and marketing a cheaper and better toothpaste. Rufus started his own toothpaste business with local children. From humble beginnings, when he used discarded baby-food jars for his product, Rufus moved up to a professional operation with stockholders and a tube-filling machine. The characters solve many real-life mathematical problems to succeed in their business.
Author: Jean Merrill

Title: Top of the World: Climbing Mount Everest, The
Annotation: The conditions and terrain of Mount Everest are described through short paragraphs and illustrated with cut-paper collage artwork. Topics discussed include survival in the elements, the dangers of crevasses and unstable snow layers, temperature, and strong winds. Suggestions and sources for further research are included.
Author: Steve Jenkins
Discipline: Physical Education, Visual and Performing Arts, Science

Title: Topsy Turvy Songs
Annotation: These amusing, simple songs and poems will appeal to young readers because of the surprising twists and turns in the language.
Author: Hsia Ling Hua
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements

Title: Tornado
Annotation: Waiting out a tornado in a storm cellar becomes a time to share stories of a dog that was blown into a farmhand's life. In each chapter the farmhand tells one story about Tornado the dog and his amazing feats.
Author: Betsy Cromer Byars

Title: Tornadoes
Annotation: This book is a narrative introduction to the subject of tornadoes. It describes scientists' study of these tremendous weather systems including the development, measurement, and destructive effects of tornadoes. This book is illustrated with full-color photographs. This is one of a series of science books by this author.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Touch the Sky: Alice Coachman, Olympic High Jumper
Annotation: Presents the life of the first African American woman to win a gold medal at the Olympic Games. Free-verse poetry recounts the life of Alice Coachman: from her childhood on a farm in rural Georgia to her time at the Tuskegee Institute and as an Olympic champion. Alice’s coaches—not her parents—recognized and encouraged her talent, offering opportunities to train and compete. Includes bibliographical references and black-and-white photographs. The book also features striking illustrations created with oils on watercolor paper.
Author: Ann Malaspina
Topic: American History, Diversity, Physical Fitness, Women’s Studies

Title: Toulouse-Lautrec: The Moulin Rouge and the City of Light
Annotation: Presents information on the life and times of the famous French artist, including depictions of some of his best-known paintings, drawings, and posters. The book shows how his art reflected the places and characters of nineteenth-century Paris. It is illustrated with period photos and paintings of Paris by artists such as Pissarro and Renoir, which are mingled with reproductions of Toulouse-Lautrec’s drawings, paintings, and lithographs, many in color.
Author: Robert Burleigh
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3

Title: Tour America: A Journey Through Poems and Art
Annotation: Diane Siebert’s poems are paired with Stephen T. Johnson’s imagery in this book, which celebrates scenic treasures—natural and man-made—found in the United States. From the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse on the East Coast to the Golden Gate Bridge on the West Coast, each landmark includes a sidebar of information accompanied by a painting or collage. Suggested activities for further exploration are also included.
Author: Diane Siebert
Topic: American History, English-Language Arts/General, Geography, Visual Arts
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Tragic Tale of Narcissa Whitman and a Faithful History of the Oregon Trail, The
Annotation: In 1836, Narcissa and Marcus Whitman set off across the continent to be missionaries in the Oregon Territory. This is the story of their journey across the continent, their lives in a country that had seen few white settlers, Narcissa’s time as a teacher to Native Americans at the Waiilatpu Mission, and her untimely death at the age of thirty-nine. This well-researched book includes excerpts of Narcissa’s letters, detailed drawings and maps, and lively narration. At the bottom of each page is a running time line of significant events that took place in Europe, Africa, and Asia. Also includes an extensive bibliography.
Author: Cheryl Harness

Title: Train to Somewhere
Annotation: The story of the nineteenth-century Orphan Train is told through the voice of a young girl nobody wants. At each stop on the journey, children are selected for adoption until only Marianne and Miss Randolph from the orphan's society remain. The book can be used for fifth-grade history/social science. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting
Standard: HSS 1.4, HSS 1.5, HSS 1.6, HSS 2.1, HSS 2.2, HSS 2.5

Title: Trang's Classmates
Annotation: This story describes Trang's classmates and their different personalities, characteristics, and dreams.
Author: - Unknown

Title: Travel Team
Annotation: Richie Walker is a short, twelve-year-old boy obsessed with basketball. When he does not make the travel team, he senses it has less to do with his size than with the bad blood between his divorced father and the coach. Richie’s father, a former NBA player who was sidelined by an injury, decides to assemble and coach his own travel team. Richie becomes one of the team’s starting guards, and the squad pursues a national title. The sequel to this story is SUMMER BALL (2007).
Author: Mike Lupica

Title: Tree in the Ancient Forest, The
Annotation: Using the poetic style of THE HOUSE THAT JACK BUILT, the author describes food chains and the cycle of interdependence between plants and animals in the Pacific Northwest forest ecosystem. Detailed double-page spread paintings illustrate the ecological concepts of this environment.
Author: Carol Reed-Jones

Title: Tree Is Growing, A
Annotation: This book tells how trees grow, plus gives general information about leaves, roots, bark, flowers, seeds, and how they change through the seasons. The double-page-spread illustrations are created with colored pencil and are placed on parchment and pastel papers.
Author: Arthur Dorros

Title: Tree of Cranes
Annotation: The idea of the Christmas holiday is introduced to a young Japanese boy by his American-born mother. Full-page watercolors depict the serenity of a traditional Japanese lifestyle and a quiet mother-son relationship. California author/illustrator.
Author: Allen Say

Title: Tree of Life: A Book Depicting the Life of Charles Darwin, Naturalist, Geologist and Thinker, The
Annotation: This uniquely illustrated biography of Charles Darwin incorporates phrases and text with finely detailed artwork. A tremendous amount of information is presented through the art work and the multilayered narrative text that tells the life story of Darwin's life and gives a visually rich introduction to his scientific work.
Author: Peter Sis
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing, Science

Title: Treehouse Tales
Annotation: The treehouse of three farm children in the 1880s plays an important part in their lives. Each child creates his or her fantastic adventure. California author.
Author: Anne Isaacs

Title: Treekeepers, The
Annotation: Bird is a tough, little street urchin who sets out to find her real father. When her protectors are captured by the evil Lord Rendarren, she and three other children, a friendly chimera (part lion, part snake), and a kitten set off to the Kingdom of Wen to rescue their protectors.
Author: Susan McGee Britton

Title: Trombone Shorty
Annotation: Hailing from the Tremé neighborhood in New Orleans, Troy “Trombone Shorty” Andrews got his nickname by wielding a trombone twice as long as he was high. He was leading his own band by age six, and today this Grammy-nominated artist headlines the legendary New Orleans Jazz Fest.
Author: Bill Taylor, Troy Andrews
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Winner

Title: Trouble Begins at 8: A Life of Mark Twain in the Wild, Wild West, The
Annotation: An entertaining biography that connects the boyhood of Samuel Clemens with Mark Twain’s novels and shows how Twain’s works are autobiographical in scope. This book focuses on the years Twain spent wandering throughout the Wild West and his fits of gold fever and get-rich-quick schemes in the Nevada Territory and San Francisco area. Illustrated with artwork and photographs. California author.
Author: Sid Fleischman

Title: Trouble with Henry: A Tale of Walden Pond, The
Annotation: A lighthearted fictional story based on the life of Henry David Thoreau and his time at Walden Pond. The story highlights the tensions in the town that develop when a Boston company wants to build a toothpick factory near Thoreau's retreat.
