Illustrated with detailed ink drawings, the book provides a glimpse into the life of this gentle character. A biographical afterword is included.
Author: Angela Weestengar, Deborah O'Neal

Title: True Story of Stellina, The
Annotation: Stellina, a common wild finch, was found by the author's future wife, Holly, after the bird abandoned her nest, which was inside a pipe holding a traffic light in New York City. She lived with Holly in her apartment and learned to eat, sing, and fly. After the author and Holly were married, Stellina continued to live with them. She died in 2003 after eight years of captivity. This is a lovely story about the bonding of a human and a wild bird and the small bird's adaptation to city life in an apartment.
Author: Matteo Pericoli

Title: Trueno (Sounder)
Annotation: Sounder, a black sharecropper's family dog, plays a key role in this story about poverty, injustice, and the special bond between a boy and his dog.
Author: William H. Armstrong

Title: Trumpet of the Swan
Annotation: Follow the adventures of Louis, a trumpeter swan, as he sets out to learn how to play the trumpet in order to attract the attention of his girlfriend. With help from his father and a human friend, Louis is able to attract a mate and eventually to return to the wilderness. This book contains strong connections to the life of a bird.
Author: E. B. White
Award: Caldecott Winner, California Young Reader Medal, Newbery Winner

Title: Truth About Great White Sharks, The
Annotation: Information on the habits and behavior of the white shark is presented in an attempt to dispel myths about this ocean predator. The informative text is enhanced by drawings and full-color photographs that include the work of marine biologists and how they're learning more about these animals. A short bibliography and a listing of shark-friendly organizations and activities are included.
Author: Mary M. Cerullo

Title: Tuan
Annotation: A Vietnamese boy is bitten by a dog. Because doctors and medicine are scarce, his life hangs in the balance. Written in English, the book contains illustrations that depict authentic Vietnamese life. A Vietnamese communist soldier's uniform is shown.
Author: Eva Boholm-Olsson, Phom Van Don

Title: Tuck Everlasting
Annotation: The Tuck family have become ageless by drinking from a magic spring. When ten-year-old Winnie Foster and a greedy evil stranger discover their secret, the Tucks are determined to prevent a disaster. This selection is excellent for use in literature circles and theme study.
Author: Natalie Babbitt

Title: Tuesday
Annotation: This nearly wordless picture book shows lily pads and frogs rising from a pond on a Tuesday evening. The frogs sail around town on the lily pads until they fall to the ground at sunrise and the adventure comes to an end. Large, detailed watercolors in rich purples, blues, and greens draw readers into this fantastic world of frog flight.
Author: David Wiesner

Title: Turkey Girl: A Zuni Cinderella Story, The
Annotation: In this Zuni Indian variant of the Cinderella theme, turkeys make a doeskin dress for the poor girl who tends them. Wearing the dress, she participates in a sacred dance, but finds that the turkeys have deserted her when she fails to return as promised.
Author: Penny Pollack

Title: Turn It Loose: The Scientist in Absolutely Everybody
Annotation: Enhanced with full-color illustrations and an index, this book offers a fun and lighthearted look at how people discover science, including art and music, through observation, recording, and the formulation of hypotheses. Included are brief biographical vignettes of famous and not-so-famous scientists and trailblazers whose identities are revealed throughout the text.
Author: Diane Swanson
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Turtle in Paradise
Annotation: When her mother gets a job working for a woman who does not like children, eleven-year-old Turtle is sent to Key West to live with relatives she doesn’t know. Set against the backdrop of the Great Depression, this story is filled with colorful characters, lively humor, and childhood adventures. Many of the characters were inspired by the author’s family. Photos from the era and historical information are included in the author’s note. Recommended as a read-aloud. Newbery Honor Book (2011); ALA Notable Children’s Book (2011).
Author: Jennifer L. Holm

Title: Turtle in the Sea
Annotation: This picture book gives a poignant account of a female sea turtle's successful battles against the elements that threaten her survival. It presents an accurate picture of sea life as well as a subtle message about the importance of staying safe. The narrative includes some information on the sea turtle's life cycle. The captivating watercolor pictures bring nature to life.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: Tus Neeg Loj Loj Thiab Caij Nplooj Hlav (The Giant and the Spring)
Annotation: Capturing the spirit of Spring, a kind and wise giant comes to realize that he is being selfish after bringing Spring into his home and refusing to let him go. Bright, full-page watercolor illustrations enrich the text. Regional dialectical differences are present in the Hmong text. Translated by Pao Vang and Ter F. Yang.
Author: Kuang-Ts’ai Hao (reteller)

Title: Tus Ntses Leesbo (The Rainbow Fish)
Annotation: Shunned by the other fish when he refuses to give away even one of his beautiful scales, Rainbow Fish eventually learns to share and finds happiness in friendship. Watercolor paintings of fish are highlighted with shiny scales. Hmong text translation contains compound words and a mixture of dialects. Translated into English by J. Alison James; into Hmong by Blia Xiong.
Author: Marcus Pfister

Title: Tus Ntses Lessbo Rau Tus Cawm! (The Rainbow Fish to the Rescue!)
Annotation: Although his friends want to ignore the new striped fish in their midst, Rainbow Fish decides to help him when a shark attacks. The text is in Hmong and English.  Translated into English by J. Alison James; into Hmong by Celine S. Vang.
Author: Marcus Pfister

Title: Tuttle’s Red Barn: The Story of America’s Oldest Family Farm
Annotation: Beginning in the early 1600s, this is the story of 12 generations of the Tuttle family, one of New England’s oldest farming families. Each short chapter describes one generation, describing the hardships they faced and how they worked to make the farm larger and more productive. The book concludes with today’s family members, who still operate a farm on the property. Illustrated with colored woodblock prints.
Author: Richard Michelson

Title: Twelve Lizards Leaping: A New Twelve Days of Christmas
Annotation: Based on the traditional carol this southwestern version delights children with its vibrant illustrations of some unusual gifts. Students can count and look for patterns as they encounter prickly pears, horned toads, piñatas swaying, and ten lizards leaping.
Author: Jan Romero Stevens
Classification: Counting Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Number Sense
Standard: Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 4.OA.1-5

Title: Twentieth-Century Children's Poetry Treasury
Annotation: This collection contains more than 200 poems by such poets as Nikki Grimes, John Ciardi, Karla Kuskin, Ted Hughes, E. E. Cummings, Deborah Chandra, Arnold Adoff, and many others. Each of the watercolor illustrations reflects a theme.
Author: Jack Prelutsky (compiler)

Title: Twenty-One Elephants and Still Standing
Annotation: When the Brooklyn Bridge was completed in 1883, many people considered it the "eighth wonder of the world." However, many felt it was unsafe and wondered how much weight it could hold before collapsing. P. T. Barnum, creator of "The Greatest Show on Earth," stepped forward and offered to send a parade of 21 elephants across the bridge to prove that it was indeed safe. The elephants paraded, and the bridge did not collapse; in fact, today - 123 years later - it carries thousands of cars daily. The author's note explains her research.
Author: April Jones Prince

Title: Two Bear Cubs: A Miwok Legend from California's Yosemite Valley
Annotation: Two bear cubs become stranded on El Capitan rock in Yosemite National Park. Mother grizzly recruits several other animals to rescue them, but it is the tiny measuring worm who succeeds. Full-page watercolors incorporate symbols, attire, and implements from the Miwok tradition. Titles for related readings as well as useful Web site addresses are included. California author, illustrator, and setting.
Author: Robert D. San Souci

Title: Two Folktales from South-East Asia
Annotation: This book contains two Vietnamese folktales. "The Clever Bird and the Stupid Bird" tells of two birds who fight over a nest and are outsmarted by a cat. "The Salty Sea" tells why seawater is salty.
Author: Annette Avery (compiler)

Title: Two of Everything: A Chinese Folktale
Annotation: An old Chinese farmer digs up a magic brass pot in his garden that doubles whatever is dropped in. They enjoy watching their gold coins double, but when the wife tumbles into the pot and emerges with her double, their troubles begin. The airbrushed acrylic and gouache illustrations utilize earth tones in a graphic style.
Author: Lily Toy Hong
Topic: Algebra (Functions, I, II, Linear), Mathematical Reasoning, Number Sense

Title: Tyrannosaurus Math
Annotation: As soon as the dinosaur was hatched, he began to add his fingers and toes—so his mother named him Tyrannosaurus Math. He counted footprints by twos, counted groups of triceratops by fives, added and subtracted large numbers, multiplied, graphed, and even worked with fractions. Textured acrylics reinforce the math and add humor to this story. A final page describes the different math skills applied throughout the book.
Author: Michelle Markel
Standard: Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 4.NF.1-7, Math 4.MD.1-7

Title: Tyrannosaurus Was a Beast
Annotation: The habits and characteristics of 14 different dinosaurs are revealed in humorous verse. A geologic timeline is included in the back of the book and information about the location, size, and time period in which each dinosaur lived can be found in the table of contents. Full-page illustrations and sophisticated vocabulary enhance each poem.
Author: Jack Prelutsky

Title: Ubiquitous: Celebrating Nature’s Survivors
Annotation: Employing a variety of poetic forms, this book intertwines poetry, prose, and illustration as it focuses on the topic of why certain life forms have beaten the odds and remained viable on Earth over great lengths of time while the vast majority of life forms have come and gone. Each poem is accompanied by watercolor-tinted linocut illustrations. An unusual time line on the endpapers accurately depicts the emergence of each life form included in the book. ALA Notable Children’s Book (2011); NSTA Outstanding Science Trade Book (2011).
Author: Joyce Sidman
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Winner

Title: Ugly Princess and the Wise Fool, The
Annotation: When plain Princess Rose longs for beauty to snag a handsome prince, a wise fool who longs to restore wisdom to the kingdom partners with her to find and face the magical Godmother Board of Trustees. The book is generously illustrated with whimsical pencil drawings and is full of humorous wordplay, clever plot twists, and well-developed characters.
Author: Margaret Gray

Title: Ultimate Field Trip 3: Wading into Marine Biology
Annotation: A group of students visit Cobscook Bay, Maine, to learn about the marine biology of its tidal zone. Their discoveries and conversations are related in lively text enhanced by full-color photographs. The book includes a glossary and further reading suggestions. Other titles in the Ultimate Field Trip series include: BATS, BUGS, AND BIODIVERSITY: ADVENTURES IN THE AMAZONIAN RAIN FOREST, and STONES, BONES, AND PETROGLYPHS: DIGGING INTO SOUTHWEST ARCHAEOLOGY.
Author: Susan E. Goodman

Title: Un million de insectos (A Million Insects)
Annotation: This book explores a variety of insects using transparent overlays, fold-outs, and flaps. The illustrations are colorful and the text is easy to read. It includes an index and a glossary. Other titles in this series include EXPLORA LA TIERRA (EXPLORE THE EARTH) and TRAS LA PISTA DE LOS MAMIFEROS (TRACKING MAMMALS).
Author: Vincent Albouy

Title: Una rueda en eltejado (The Wheel on the School)
Annotation: Set in a small Dutch fishing village, this heart-warming story is about a group of children who create a plan to bring a pair of storks back to their village. The storks return and nest on the roof of their schoolhouse. This story is a strong portrayal of hope as the whole village works together to make the dream come true.
Author: Meindert DeJong

Title: Una unión más perfecta: la historia de nuestra constitución (A More Perfect Union)
Annotation: The authors present a re-creation of history with this illustrated account of the signing of the U.S. Constitution. This book is also a valuable reference source, as it contains a synopsis of the Constitutional Amendments.
Author: Betsy Maestro
Topic: American History, Government and Politics, Law and Legal Studies

Title: Unbeelievables: Honeybee Poems and Paintings
Annotation: Florian presents a pleasing mix of poems and colorful collages that blend whimsy and fact. The poems introduce the roles of the queen, drones, and worker bees and touch on matters such as anatomy, development from egg to bee, and even colony collapse disorder. Concise text, in smaller type, explains why bees swarm, the role of scout bees, and what happens after a new home site is found. This is a humorous blend of wordplay and science.
Author: Douglas Florian

Title: Unbreakable Code, The
Annotation: While comforting his grandson about an anticipated move, a Navajo grandfather tells the story of serving as a Marine and being a code talker during World War II. He explains how difficult it was to leave his family members and his canyon home. The importance of faith, language, and ingenuity comes alive as facts are retold. Illustrated with textured, realistic oil paintings. The original Navajo code, letters, pronunciation guide, and English translation are included.
Author: Sara Hoagland Hunter

Title: Uncle Daddy
Annotation: When his long-absent father suddenly reappears, nine-year-old Rivers struggles with conflicting feelings and reexamines his relationship with the great-uncle who had served as his father.
Author: Ralph Fletcher

Title: Uncle Jed's Barbershop
Annotation: Uncle Jed opens his own barbershop, overcoming great odds to become the only black barber in the county. He shows compassion and perseverance throughout all the hardships and challenges he encounters. The richly colored paintings bring this story to life.
Author: Margaree King Mitchell

Title: Uncle Rain Cloud
Annotation: Carlos’s uncle, Tomás—whom Carlos refers to as “Uncle Rain Cloud”—expresses frustration over his inability to speak English. He captivates his nephew with stories of the Aztec gods but troubles the boy with his bad temper. Their relationship is sometimes turbulent, until the day they discover that both are struggling with English. Carlos agrees to help his uncle with English, and Uncle Tomás agrees to teach his nephew more stories, but in Spanish. California author and California setting.
Author: Tony Johnston
Topic: American History, Diversity, Ethnic Studies, Immigration/Migration

Title: Uncle Sam and Old Glory: Symbols of America
Annotation: Symbols have always played a crucial role in shaping the identity and fabric of the United States. Fifteen American icons are introduced, each in a double-page spread: one page provides information about the symbol, and the other page has a handsome woodcut illustration. Includes historical stories and anecdotes. This book for young readers offers an excellent introduction to American symbols.
Author: Delno C. West, Jean M. West

Title: Under the Blood-Red Sun
Annotation: This novel depicts 1941 Hawaii through the eyes of a thirteen-year-old Japanese American boy, Tomi Nakaji, as he struggles with the racism, violence, and hardship that arise when his father and grandfather are wrongfully arrested after the bombing of Pearl Harbor. The language used in the book and the emotional intensity of the story aptly reflect the theme and setting.
Author: Graham Salisbury
Award: California Young Reader Medal, Scott O'Dell Award

Title: Under the Quilt of Night
Annotation: A young girl flees from the farm where she has been worked as a slave and uses the Underground Railroad to escape to freedom in the north. Told in first-person narrative, her story tells of the treacherous flight. Illustrated with rich, dark oil paintings that lend realism to the setting.
Author: Deborah Hopkinson

Title: Under the Wild Western Sky
Annotation: The colorful illustrations in this book depict a number of western scenes, including buffalo, prairie dogs, rattlesnakes, and other animals in their natural habitat. The artwork includes black-and-white pencil sketches and full-color acrylic paintings that highlight the details of the habitat. Use as a read-aloud introduction to the various habitats or for students' independent reading.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: United Tweets of America
Annotation: This is a joyful and irreverent look at the 50 state birds of the United States. Each entry features puns and parodies, bits of history, geography about each state, the state bird and capital, a small map of the state, and the state’s nickname. The humorous, cartoon-style illustrations were done with ink and watercolor.
Author: Hudson Talbott

Title: Universe, The
Annotation: The vastness of the universe is introduced by a veteran science writer through clear, explanatory text. The full-color matching photographs show nebulas, galaxies, and serve to support the wide range of topic discussed including the Big Bang and theories about the future of the universe.
Author: Seymour Simon
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Unlikely Pairs: Fun with Famous Works of Art
Annotation: Paired selections of famous artwork invite readers to discover the humorous story that comes from viewing the paintings together. The premise of the book is that one work of art can take on new meaning when combined with another. Includes 26 paintings in different styles and from different eras.
Author: Bob Raczka

Title: Uno el duende de los numeros (One, the Number Fairy)
Annotation: This is an interactive introduction to the powers of numbers. A number fairy visits a young girl and together they explore fractions, Roman Numerals, addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. There is even a place for students to write their own version of THE NUMBER FAIRY.
Author: Giovanni De Carlo
Standard: Math NS 3.2, Math NS 4.1, Math NS 5.1

Title: Up Before Daybreak: Cotton and People in America
Annotation: This book traces the history of the cotton trade in America from Colonial times to the mid-twentieth century. The author uses primary sources and includes stories of real people. From slaves to sharecroppers to modern technology, this book follows one of the most important pieces of economic history in the United States. Illustrated with archival photographs. Connect with the picture book THE BOBBIN GIRL by Emily Arnold McCully (1996) and BREAD AND ROSES by Katherine Paterson (2006).
Author: Deborah Hopkinson
Topic: American History, Diversity, Economics, Women’s Studies
Standard: HSS 5.8, HSS 8.7, HSS 8.12, HSS 10.3, HSS 11.2, HSS G 12.2

Title: Up, Up and Away: A Book About Adverbs
Annotation: Author–illustrator Ruth Heller provides an engaging lesson on adverbs. Vivid double-page illustrations accompany a rhyming text that covers superlatives, double negatives, and irregular adverbs. The book provides an effective review of adverbs for older students and can be used to introduce adverbs to younger students and to English learners. See the other titles in the “World of Language” series. California author.
Publisher: Penguin Putnam Books for Young Readers
Author: Ruth Heller
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Discipline: English-Language Arts/General , English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, English-Language Arts/Writing, Literacy/Motivation

Title: Uptown
Annotation: Harlem is seen through the eyes of a young boy who lives there. As a tour guide, he shares the warmth and vitality, the brownstones and barbershops, the smells of chicken and waffles, and the sounds of jazz. Bold, colored text appears in highly detailed pictures of city life.
Author: Bryan Collier
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Valley Forge
Annotation: Presents an illustrated account of the beginnings of the Revolutionary War and how George Washington transformed ordinary citizens into an unbeatable fighting force. Most of the story focuses on the harsh living conditions the soldiers faced during the course of a difficult winter at Valley Forge. Illustrated with engaging full-page paintings.
Author: Richard Ammon

Title: Van Gogh Cafe, The
Annotation: The Van Gogh Cafe, located in Flowers, Kansas, has magic in its walls that causes strange and mysterious events to occur at the cafe. Ten-year-old Clara and her father create moments of magic that will enchant readers of this spare and intense story.
Author: Cynthia Rylant

Title: Ve lo que dices (See What You Say)
Annotation: The author presents 12 contrasting idioms in both English and Spanish in a manner that language learners will understand. This is an amusing introduction to popular English- and Spanish-language figures of speech for students of both languages.
Author: Nancy Maria Grande Tabor

Title: Velveteen Rabbit, The
Annotation: This poignant story about a toy rabbit that becomes real through the love of a little boy was first published in 1922 and has since become a classic in children's literature.
Author: Margery Williams Bianco

Title: Verdi
Annotation: A young python does not want to grow slow and boring like the older snakes he sees in the tropical jungle where he lives. He decides that he will do something about it, with some humorous consequences.
Author: Janell Cannon

Title: Very Important Day, A
Annotation: More than 200 people from 32 different countries are introduced in double-spread pages as they make their way to downtown New York in a snow storm to be sworn in as citizens of the United States. This book shows multiculturalism in its broadest sense. A pronunciation glossary is included.
Author: Maggie Rugg Herold

Title: Vida de las plantas, La (The Life of Plants)
Annotation: In this book the growth of plants, photosynthesis, transpiration, pollination, and the importance of plants in an ecosystem is discussed. Detailed full-color illustrations and diagrams support the text.
Author: Maria Angels Julivert

Title: Viking Ships at Sunrise
Annotation: In this series book, Jack and Annie's magic tree house takes them back in time to a monastery in medieval Ireland, where they try to retrieve a lost book despite being menaced by Viking raiders. A number of books in this series carry children back in time to solve a mystery, survive a challenging situation, or learn about a historical event.
Author: Mary Pope Osborne

Title: Village of Round and Square Houses, The
Annotation: In the real village of Tos in Cameroon, Africa, the women live in round houses and men in square houses. The events of a typical day and the eruption of Naka Mountain are vividly portrayed in vibrant chalk drawings and helps to illustrate the volcanic cycle. Use this book when investigating the area of circles and squares or when discussing how perimter relates to shapes.
Author: Ann Grifalconi
Topic: Earth Science, English-Language Arts/General, Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)

Title: Vinnie and Abraham
Annotation: This picture-book biography tells the story of Vinnie Ream, a determined and aspiring young artist living in Washington, DC, during the Civil War. As a sixteen-year-old, she gained a reputation as a sculptor and succeeded in persuading President Abraham Lincoln to sit for her. Eventually, she won a government commission to create a statue of Lincoln after his assassination. Illustrated with watercolor artwork.
Author: Dawn FitzGerald
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Violet Raines Almost Got Struck by Lightning
Annotation: Violet Raines is happy with things just the way they are in her sleepy Florida town, but when Melissa moves to town from big-city Detroit, suddenly things seem like they're changing whether Violet likes it or not. It'll take a few run-ins with lightning and a whole lot of courage for her to realize that growing up doesn't have to mean changing who you are.
Author: Danette Haworth

Title: Violet the Pilot
Annotation: Violet is an eight-year-old who can fix and build anything. She is constantly teased by other children at school because of the way she dresses and for her love of building and inventing machines. She decides to build an airplane and enter the local air show, but something happens along the way. She stops to rescue a Boy Scout troop and misses the race. Cartoon-style illustrations are rendered in watercolor, acrylic, and pencil. Use as an introduction to women in science and to reinforce the idea that anything is possible.
Author: Steve Breen

Title: Virgie Goes to School with Us Boys
Annotation: Virgie yearns to read just like her brothers. But they have to walk seven miles each Monday morning and stay all week at the Quaker school. Virgie convinces her family that it is important that she also learn to read and write. As Virgie is made welcome by the teachers, her joy abounds, and she vows to read every book in the school.
Author: Elizabeth Fitzgerald Howard

Title: Vision of Beauty: The Story of Sarah Breedlove Walker
Annotation: This book tells the story of Sarah Breedlove Walker, an orphaned child of former slaves, who became wealthy through her development of hair and beauty care products for African American women. The story depicts her practical use of the scientific method and scientific reasoning as well as her efforts to promote civil rights and is illustrated with rich historical detail.
Author: Kathryn Lasky

Title: Visiting Langston
Annotation: The vibrant voice of a young girl with richly textured watercolor and collage illustrations illuminate a poem celebrating the life and work of poet Langston Hughes. It also evokes the images of Harlem as well as the blues, dreams, Africa, and other subjects of Hughes' poetry.
Author: Willie Perdomo

Title: Voices of Ancient Egypt
Annotation: Individual workers who live in ancient Egypt during the time of the Olden Kingdom describe the work they do. The text is free verse and expressed in the voices of a scribe, a farmer, a bird netter, a weaver, an embalmer, a carpenter, and seven other workers. Each page has the title of the occupation in English and in hieroglyphics. Includes a historical note.
Author: Kay Winters
Genre: Fiction in Verse, Historical Fiction, Narrative Nonfiction, Nonfiction, Poetry

Title: Volcanes, Los (The Volcanoes)
Annotation: This book provides information on volcanoes around the world. Types of volcanoes, effects, and locations are all included and described in text, charts, pictures, and diagrams. How volcanoes develop and occur is also included and related to plate tectonics and continental drift. See other books in the Fenomenos Naturales (Natural Phenomenon) series.
Author: Gloria Valek

Title: Volcano
Annotation: A fire-breathing dragon leads the reader through an adventure to learn more about volcanoes. They go inside a volcano and visit sites of different volcanoes around the world. The characteristics and behaviors of volcanoes are explained in simple text that is appropriate for young children and reluctant readers. The illustrations are rendered in colorful collage. See other books in thi National Geographic Society series.
Author: Ellen J. Prager

Title: Volcanoes
Annotation: This book explains the characteristics of volcanoes in a clear, narrative text which includes descriptions of some famous eruptions and their aftermath. Bold, full-color photographs illustrate the narrative.  This is one of a series of science books by this author.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Volcanoes
Annotation: One of Earth's mightiest forces, volcanoes, is the focus of this book. Maps, drawings, and detailed illustrations reveal the facts about volcanoes in an easy-to-understand format. This book also contains practical projects and a quiz about volcanoes. See other books in the Fascinating Facts series.
Author: Jane Walker

Title: Vote 4 Amelia
Annotation: Amelia describes the student-council election in which she is participating, explaining what the student council does, how it works, and why it is important to elect the best people for office. The book, part of the “Amelia” series, is written in journal format with margin notes and illustrated with Amelia’s drawings. An excellent example of journal writing, this work is also useful for explaining a school election process. California author.
Author: Marissa Moss

Title: Vote!
Annotation: Using a town's mayoral election as a model, this lively introduction to voting covers every step in the process: from the start of the campaign all the way to the voting booth, complete with a recount and a timeline of voting history. Humorous cartoon-style art complement the informative text. A glossary, timeline, and resource list are included.
Author: Eileen Christelow

Title: Vultures
Annotation: Full-page color photographs illustrate the habitats and behaviors of vultures around the world. Opposite each photo page is text that details those habitats and behaviors. The author describes how vultures serve as the "garbagemen" of nature by eating dead animals, thus explaining a food-chain element and an ecosystem.
Author: Sandra Markle

Title: W is for Wind: A Weather Alphabet
Annotation: This book is full of information about weather, providing detailed descriptions in a pictorial format with text as well as verse. "V is for vapor" and "J is for jet stream" are just a few of the weather terms shared with readers in their journey to learning more about the weather systems that we experience every day.
Author: Pat Michael

Title: Wabi Sabi
Annotation: Wabi Sabi, a little cat in Japan, sets forth on a journey to learn the meaning of her name. Her journey takes her to the mountains, where she discovers that Wabi Sabi is a Japanese philosophy of seeing beauty in simplicity, the ordinary, and the imperfect. The book reads from top to bottom and is in the format of haibun, a combination of prose and haiku. Notes at the end of the book provide a history of the phrase “Wabi Sabi” and an explanation of haiku and haibun. The book also offers an English translation of the Japanese haiku presented as decorations on each spread.
Author: Mark Reibstein
Topic: Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Wagon Wheels
Annotation: The Muldie family, black pioneers, leave the South after the Civil War and travel west to homestead. Mama dies along the way, but the family persists, sustaining themselves through harsh winters and prairie fires. Later, Father sets off to find better land, leaving the children to join him - which they do after walking almost 150 miles. The book is based on a true story.
Author: Barbara Brenner

Title: Waiting for the Owl’s Call
Annotation: An eight-year-old girl in Afghanistan awakens to hear the crier who calls the faithful to prayer, beckoning her to rise for another long day of weaving at the rug-making loom. Throughout the tedious task, she weaves patterns in her mind of her own dreams and thoughts of the beauty of the world—until she hears the owl’s call that concludes another day. Illustrated with full-page artwork featuring jewel-toned shapes that mirror those used in the rugs. Part of the “Tales of the World” series.
Author: Gloria Whelan
Topic: Global Social Issues, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Wake Up, Emperor!
Annotation: When a poor peddler boy befriends a young emperor, he actually helps the emperor to fulfill his role of leadership.
Author: Guang He

Title: Walk in the Tundra, A
Annotation: This book takes readers on a walk through the tundra biome, showing examples of the plants and animals that live there and emphasizing their symbiotic relationships. Photographs, maps, and sketches complement the text. See other titles in the Biomes of North America series.
Author: Rebecca L. Johnson

Title: Walk on the Golden Bridge
Annotation: This rhyming book is used for small children to practice reading Chinese characters that rhyme. The content is humorous and teaches students some Chinese culture.
Author: Ren Mu Pan

Title: Walk on the Great Barrier Reef, A
Annotation: Narrative information describes the fascinating ecosystem of the Great Barrier Reef off the coast of Australia. Full-color photographs highlight the information and provide a glimpse of the underwater world of the reef.
Author: Caroline Arnold

Title: Walking with Henry: Based on the Life and Works of Henry David Thoreau
Annotation: In this fictionalized picture book for older children, Henry David Thoreau hikes in the wilderness with his walking stick and explains his philosophy of living in harmony with nature. Illustrated with Thomas Locker’s museum-quality paintings, which incorporate detail and striking use of light. Use as an introduction to regions, various landscapes, and Thoreau. Concludes with a page of quotations from Thoreau’s writings.
Author: Thomas Locker

Title: Wall, The
Annotation: A compelling story about the family that is left behind when a soldier dies. It is a fitting tribute to the veterans of all wars and to the children and grandchildren who learn to treasure the memory of their fallen soldier. The book is also a celebration of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Wall, which celebrates the valor of the men and women whose names are engraved there forever. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting

Title: Walter Wick's Optical Tricks
Annotation: Fifteen optical illusions are created by using photographic trickery. The accompanying text challenges readers to discover the secrets of each visual puzzle. Explanations of each layout are appended, providing everyone the opportunity to "see" the illusions.
Author: Walter Wick

Title: Warlord's Beads, The
Annotation: A young Chinese boy helps his father count the warlord's vast treasures by using beads threaded on a branch, thus inventing the abacus. Large-scale paintings illustrate this original tale from ancient China. A brief history of the abacus and instructions for making one are included. California author.
Author: Virginia Walton Pilegard

Title: Warlord's Fish, The
Annotation: In ancient China an artist and his young apprentice are kidnapped and taken into the desert, where their captors' caravan is lost. Chuan, the kidnapped apprentice, brings out a carved wooden fish that contains a special stone inside. He asks for a bowl of water and places the fish in it. When the fish faces south, the group finds its way out of the desert. Chuan and the artist are then granted their freedom. This book, which includes instructions to make a fish compass, is a part of the Warlord series. California author
Author: Virginia Walton Pilegard

Title: Warlord's Messengers, The
Annotation: In Ancient China two children, Chuan and Jing Jing, are determined to get the emperor's message to their warlord for a command appearance in just 14 days. With mathematical calculations and help from the wind, the boys invent land sailing and save the warlord from dishonor. Bold illustrations evoke the brown landscape of China, touched with royal red highlights This book is a part of the Warlord series. California author.
Author: Virginia Walton Pilegard

Title: Warlord's Puzzle, The
Annotation: A warlord of ancient China is delighted by an artist's square blue tile. When it is dropped and broken into seven pieces, he is convinced to hold a contest to see if it can be put back together. Lush glazed acrylic paintings support this original tale of the tangram in a meaningful historical context. California author.
Author: Virginia Walton Pilegard

Title: Warmer World: From Polar Bears to Butterflies, How Climate Change Affects Wildlife, A
Annotation: Clear writing and artwork in soft pastels help explain the impact of global warming on various animals. The text will appeal to students in middle grades, and the inclusion of animals such as walruses, penguins, butterflies, and polar bears should captivate younger children and struggling readers. A glossary and suggested resources are included. California author.
Author: Caroline Arnold

Title: Washington at Valley Forge
Annotation: During the American Revolutionary War, the pivotal winter of 1777–78 at Valley Forge had a profound effect on Washington’s continental army. The author presents a vivid description of the difficult winter and the shortages endured by the men—the lack of food, clothing, and other supplies. The result was misery and low morale among the soldiers. First-person accounts are interspersed throughout the informative text. Illustrated with photographs and reproductions of period artwork.
Author: Russell Freedman

Title: Watching Desert Wildlife
Annotation: Watercolor illustrations and text describe some of the animals the author encountered in the deserts of the American Southwest. Tips for observing wildlife are given within the narrative. Younger students may have trouble reading the text, but they can learn from studying the detailed drawings and hearing the book read aloud by an adult or a more advanced student reader.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: Water Dance
Annotation: Elegant landscape and seascape paintings present water in forms such as storm clouds, mist, rainbows, and rivers. Each painting is accompanied by poetic text that highlights the specific phenomenon. At the end of the book, the paintings appear in miniature with a brief paragraph of information provided by a scientist relating to the water cycle.
Author: Thomas  Locker

Title: Water Music: Poems for Children
Annotation: Seventeen original poems celebrate water in various forms including raindrops, waterfalls, streams, surf, ice, and snow. Crisply-focused, full-color photographs highlight the special qualities of water in all the various forms. This would be useful as a writing model as well as for enhancing a science unit.
Author: Jane Yolen

Title: Water Sings Blue: Ocean Poems
Annotation: Watercolor paintings invite the reader to wade into the ocean. The images frame each of the 23 poems in this collection, which is a tribute to the oceans of the world. The soft textures of the illustrations delicately support the poems. A good choice to share with a class when teaching units about the ocean.
Author: Kate Coombs
Grade Level Span: Preschool/Pre thru K, K thru 2, 3 thru 5

Title: Watsons Go to Birmingham - 1963: A Novel, The
Annotation: This story follows the Watsons, an African American family living in Flint, Michigan, as they travel south to visit their grandmother in Alabama. There they are confronted with the 1963 bombing of black churches. The book combines humorous characterization with important history. This selection is useful for fifth- and eighth-grade history studies.
Author: Christopher Paul Curtis
Award: California Young Reader Medal, Coretta Scott King Author Honor, Golden Kite Author Winner, Newbery Honor

Title: Waves: The Electromagnetic Universe
Annotation: This book presents a lively, informative introduction to electromagnetic waves, the various types and their characteristics, how they were discovered, and the roles that they play in our and our children's lives. The author also speculates on the existence of yet undiscovered electromagnetic waves and intelligence elsewhere in the universe. The text is illustrated with numerous photographs and diagrams, and includes an index and glossary. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Gloria Skurzynski

Title: Way a Door Closes, The
Annotation: Thirty-four poems tell the story of a proud and close-knit African American family whose lives change when the father loses his job. Told through the eyes of thirteen-year-old C. J., the story reveals the teenager's feelings as he sees his father abandon the family. Realistic illustrations and touching poetry may inspire thought-provoking discussions and writings. California author.
Author: Hope Anita Smith

Title: Way Up and Over Everything
Annotation: Author Alice McGill retells a remarkable folk tale, passed down in her family through the generations. Jane, an enslaved sixteen-year-old girl, witnesses the arrival of five newly enslaved Africans on Old Man Deboreaux’s plantation in Georgia. The newly arrived slaves rarely speak and mostly stay among themselves. After enduring backbreaking labor, the five Africans escape the horrors of slavery by disappearing into thin air. An ALA Notable Children’s Book (2009).
Author: Alice McGill

Title: Wayside School Is Falling Down
Annotation: Readers will enjoy slapstick humor of these stories about the out-of-the-ordinary, 30-stories-high Wayside School. The teacher's trials and the students' antics make for a zany read-aloud book. This is a sequel to SIDEWAYS STORIES FROM WAYSIDE SCHOOL.
Author: Louis Sachar

Title: We the Kids: The Preamble to the Constitution of the United States
Annotation: In this book, artist and political cartoonist David Catrow interprets and illustrates the text of the preamble to the U.S. Constitution. The meaning of each phrase of the preamble is explained and accompanied by a lively illustration that shows each principle in action.
Author: David Catrow
Standard: HSS K.1, HSS K.2, HSS 1.1, HSS 1.3, HSS 2.3, HSS 5.7

Title: Weasel
Annotation: Set in 1839 Ohio, this adventure story begins when a wild-looking, tongueless man leads Nathan and his sister, Molly, to their wounded father. Nathan is soon captured by the same white Indian hunter, Weasel, but he chooses not to avenge Weasel's cruel acts when he has a chance. This book is outstanding for literature studies.
Author: Cynthia DeFelice

Title: Weather
Annotation: This is the new edition of one of the most popular books on weather, a subject that changes every day. This book is an excellent selection for budding meteorologists as well as an excellent resource for teachers who want to know more about why we experience the weather we do. This title is a part of the Smithsonian series.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Weaving a California Tradition: A Native American Basketmaker
Annotation: The tradition of Native American basket weaving in California is presented as eleven-year-old Carly, a Western Mono Indian, learns the ancient art from her mother and her aunts. Contemporary tribal life is depicted in the text and color photographs, including the rituals of plant gathering and preparation, and weaving techniques are described. California author, photographer, and setting.
Author: Linda Yamane
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Web at Dragonfly Pond, The
Annotation: A boy tells of the day he spent fishing with his father at Dragonfly Pond. From the bite of a mosquito to the catching of a large bass, the boy's father explains the food chain. He begins with the mosquito, then follows the food chain with a dragonfly, a bullfrog, a black bass, and finally, the catching and eating of the bass by the boy's family. Large, vibrant illustrations take the reader right to the pond to experience the excitement of the day. California illustrator.
Author: Brian "Fox" Ellis

Title: Wednesday Surprise, The
Annotation: A young girl and her grandmother prepare a surprise gift for her dad's homecoming. Young listeners and readers discover the gift is that grandma is learning to read with coaching by her granddaughter. This tale is a poignant story that will highlight the "gift of reading" and adult illiteracy. California author.
Author: Eve Bunting
Discipline: History/Social Science, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, Literacy/Motivation

Title: Welcome to Kit’s World, 1934: Growing Up During America’s Great Depression
Annotation: Through photographs, quotes, and illustrations, this book brings to life the United States in 1934, the Great Depression, soup kitchens, the Dust Bowl, Shirley Temple, and the “New Deal.” Useful for discussing well-known people of the Depression era, such as Amelia Earhart and photographer Dorothea Lange. Part of the “American Girls Collection.” Note: this title may be out of print.
Author: Harriet Brown
Illustrator: Jamie Young, Philip Hood, et al.

Title: Welcome to the Sea of Sand
Annotation: In this book, the Sonoran Desert is described in lively verse, with waves of sand, cactus, and a great and gorgeous variety of animals. Gouache paintings capture the life of this unique landscape. This selection is useful for exploring various adaptations and habitats.
Author: Jane Yolen

Title: Well: David's Story, The
Annotation: The drought of 1910 in Mississippi leaves all wells dry except for the one on the property of David Logan's land-owning African American family. The Logans willingly share their water with their neighbors, black and white people alike, but one white family harasses them despite their generosity, poisoning their well with dead animals. The language used reflects the times; human rights violations are portrayed.
Author: Mildred D. Taylor

Title: Weslandia
Annotation: Wesley, a misfit, decides to create his own garden, food, clothes, and world in his backyard. Naming it Weslandia, he succeeds brilliantly in making friends while doing it. This book is good for discussions on individual differences. California author.
Author: Paul Fleischman

Title: Westing Game, The
Annotation: This novel investigates the mysterious death of an eccentric millionaire. It introduces an unlikely assortment of heirs who must uncover the circumstances of his death before they can claim their inheritance. This junior novel is useful for literature circles and for studies of plot, character, and prediction.
Author: Ellen Raskin

Title: Whale Rescue
Annotation: This book offers an interesting depiction of the impact of commercial whaling on whale populations worldwide. The author explains that the rescuing of the whale depends on how governments and conservation groups continue their efforts to protect these "giants of the sea." Despite the somewhat confusing order of the book's chapters, the language is clear and straightforward and the color photos will engage whale lovers. A final page of fast facts will please students, who will find plenty of information for reports or personal interest.
Author: Erich Hoyt

Title: Whales
Annotation: This is the new edition of Simon's classic text on one of the world's truly amazing animals. The book is perfect for budding young scientists and report writers. The original edition of WHALES was the first photo-essay book ever selected as a NEW YORK TIMES Best Illustrated Book.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Whales! Strange and Wonderful
Annotation: The physiology, migrations, and many types of whales are described in this well-written narrative by a renowned children’s science author. Watercolor illustrations provide additional information and a sense of scale and complete the pleasurable reading experience. Look for other titles in the Strange and Wonderful series by the same author, including: BATS! STRANGE AND WONDERFUL and SHARKS! STRANGE AND WONDERFUL.
Author: Laurence P. Pringle

Title: Whaling Season: A Year in the Life of an Arctic Whale Scientist
Annotation: Readers are transported to Barrows, Alaska, where whale scientist John Craighead George has studied whales for many years. Full-color photographs chronicle his scientific work, his partnership with the Iñupiaq whale hunters, and his childhood and source of inspiration. Students will gain a deeper appreciation of the bowhead whales, the people who hunt and respect them, and the work of scientists. Part of the “Scientists in the Field” series.
Author: Peter Lourie
Topic: Life Science (Biology), World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: What Athletes Are Made of
Annotation: Contains brief profiles of great athletes from a wide range of sports, providing information about each one’s accomplishments. The simple text is accompanied by illustrations consisting of collages of found objects that are arranged to resemble the subjects. Includes statistics and career highlights of each athlete. A good pattern book for art activities that use found objects.
Author: Sarah L. Thomson
Topic: Motor Skills/Movement Patterns, Nutrition and Physical Activity, Physical Fitness

Title: What Charlie Heard
Annotation: Twentieth-century composer Charles Ives wrote music that was so revolutionary it was mostly ignored by his contemporaries. In his old age he found an audience. Gerstein's flowing illustrations rendered in pen and ink are infused with color, vividly portraying the sounds that become the inspiration for his music.
Author: Mordicai Gerstein
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, Science

Title: What Comes in Two's, Three's, and Four's?
Annotation: The colorful illustrations show where sets of two, three, or four can be found in everyday life. This book could be used as an introduction to finding more things that come in groups. It could also be used as an introduction to multiplication, for example, if one person has two eyes, then five people have how many eyes?
Author: Suzanne Aker
Standard: Math K.CC.1-7, Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9

Title: What Do Authors Do?
Annotation: Cartoon illustrations inform readers how an author makes a picture book or a chapter book. The book is humorous, yet very informative. This selection is useful for teaching writing.
Author: Eileen Christelow

Title: What Do Illustrators Do?
Annotation: Two illustrators go through all the steps involved in creating new picture-book edition of JACK AND THE BEANSTALK. Layout, scale, and point-of-view are among the aspects included and discussed.
Author: Eileen Christelow
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: What Do You Do With a Tail Like This?
Annotation: A fun and interactive science lesson that looks at the different ways 30 animals use their ears, eyes, mouths, noses, feet, and tails. The artist's characteristic cut-paper collages add interest and realism. Endnotes offer more information on the 30 animals.
Author: Robin Page, Steve Jenkins

Title: What If You Met a Pirate?
Annotation: Pictures and text describe what pirates were really like, especially the pirates of the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries. Energetic drawings, done with brightly colored washes, show pirates engaged in a variety of activities.
Author: Jan Adkins
Topic: American History, Global Historical Events and Figures

Title: What Planet Are You from, Clarice Bean?
Annotation: When Clarice Bean's class is learning about the environment and planet Earth, Clarice takes her interest to a higher level when she learns that a neighborhood tree is about to be removed. She and her family stage a protest and hold a spaghetti-eating sit-in in the tree's branches. The illustrations are a combination of real photos, scribbles, and wild fonts. This is the third book in a series about Clarice Bean.
Author: Lauren Child

Title: What the Moon Is Like
Annotation: This is a clear introduction to the moon for early readers as it compares how the moon's composition, terrain, and atmosphere differ from the earth's. Colorful illustrations accompany the text. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out-Science series.
Author: Franklyn M. Branley

Title: What to Do About Alice? How Alice Roosevelt Broke the Rules, Charmed the Word, and Drove Her Father Crazy!
Annotation: In this enjoyable picture-book biography, children are introduced to Alice Roosevelt, the irrepressible daughter of President Theodore Roosevelt. Alice was undisciplined, strong-willed, intelligent, and altogether the “princess” of her early twentieth-century world. Although President Roosevelt referred to his daughter’s behavior as “running riot,” Alice called it “eating up the world.” The book includes an author’s note.
Author: Barbara Kerley

Title: What You Never Knew About Tubs, Toilets, and Showers
Annotation: Ever wonder about tubs, toilets, and showers, and how they developed throughout history? The author shares people's feelings about bathing and methods of keeping clean throughout history. Some of the drawings show partially clad bathers.
Author: Patricia Lauber

Title: What's Faster than a Speeding Cheetah?
Annotation: The author compares the speed of various animals, from humans to cheetahs to peregrine falcons, with even faster things like rockets, meteoroids, and light. Humorous drawings are active and bright to assist in making the concepts understandable.
Author: Robert E. Wells
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud

Title: What's Older Than a Giant Tortoise?
Annotation: The author tells how long giant tortoises can live and compares them to other things around the world that are older, such as the giant sequoias in California, the pyramids in Egypt, Meteor Crater in Arizona, and prehistoric mammals. Illustrated with bright ink-and-acrylic artwork that is filled with action and appropriately depicts the concept, This title includes an illustrated timeline that puts it all in perspective.
Author: Robert E. Wells

Title: What's Smaller than a Pygmy Shrew?
Annotation: This book shows how microscopes are used to see the tiniest parts of the universe which helps readers understand that the size of any object may be viewed in relation to things both smaller and larger. The acrylic-and-ink artwork includes touches of humor and shows proportions from elephants to atoms.
Author: Robert E. Wells
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Measurement & Geometry (Geometry)
Standard: PS K.1, LS K.2, I & E K.4, I & E 2.4, LS 3.3, PS 5.1, Math 1.MD.1-4, Math 2.MD.1-10

Title: What's that Bug? Everyday Insects and Their Really Cool Cousins
Annotation: This survey of the classification of nine familiar orders of insects has an emphasis on the common characteristics that are found in each order. The narrative text presents odd and interesting facts and is accompanied by large, detailed, full-color scientific illustrations which will draw children in.
Author: Nan Froman

Title: What's the Big Idea, Ben Franklin?
Annotation: A brief biography, highlighted by Fritz's signature humor and anecdotal style, stresses Ben Franklin's creative thinking, hard work, desire to learn, and testing of his knowledge. Tome's illustrations help the reader visualize concepts and inventions in the story.
Author: Jean Fritz

Title: What's the Matter in Mr. Whiskers' Room?
Annotation: In Mr. Whiskers's classroom, kids are encouraged to explore, discover, and share ideas about matter. Multiracial kids in this classroom are obviously having a great time uncovering "big ideas" about matter.
Author: Michael Elsohn Ross

Title: What's Your Angle, Pythagoras?
Annotation: Pythagoras learns about real-world math dilemmas. His curiosity leads him to discover the relationship of the sides of a right-angle triangle. Using this discovery he finds a new trade route and solves the problem of how long a ladder needs to be.
Author: Julie Ellis

Title: What’s for Dinner? Quirky, Squirmy Poems from the Animal World
Annotation: Clever verse and colorful cartoons combine to create a humorous (and sometimes gruesome) collection of poems about the variety of things that animals eat. Readers will learn about the preferred foods of turkey vultures, archer fish, baby wasps, and the like—foods that are not very appealing to humans. The perils of eating and being eaten are presented in an engaging way. Informative notes conclude the text. An NSTA Outstanding Science Trade Book (2012).
Author: Katherine B. Hauth

Title: Wheel on the School, The
Annotation: Set in a small Dutch fishing village, this heart-warming story is about a group of children who make a plan to attract a pair of storks back to their village. The storks return and nest on the roof of their schoolhouse. This story is a strong portrayal of hope as the whole village works together to make the dream come true.
Author: Meindert DeJong

Title: When Agnes Caws
Annotation: Sent to the Himalayas in search of the rare and endangered pink-headed duck, young bird-calling expert Agnes must thwart villainous Colonel Pittsnap, who means to use Agnes to ensnare the prize bird for his collection. Watery inks turn the characters into Victorian caricatures with tiny feet, round faces, and pointy noses. This book connects to life science units on birds and endangered animals.
Author: Candace Fleming

Title: When Birds Could Talk and Bats Could Sing: The Adventures of Bruh Sparrow, Sis Wren, and Their Friends
Annotation: Eight bird and animal stories are retold based on African American tales originally written down by Martha Young on her father's plantation in Alabama after the Civil War. Large watercolor illustrations bring added warmth and humor to the stories.
Author: Virginia Hamilton

Title: When Bob Met Woody
Annotation: Woody Guthrie inspired young Bob Zimmerman, who dreamed of playing music and singing while growing up in rural Minnesota. On hearing that Guthrie was ailing in a hospital, Zimmerman hitchhiked and was able to see Woody and sing some songs to him. Inspired by the poet Dylan Thomas, Zimmerman changed his name to Bob Dylan, became driven by music, and the rest is history. Illustrated with acrylic-and-oil paintings that are a fine accompaniment to this well-told biography.
Author: Gary Golio

Title: When Bugs Were Big, Plants Were Strange, and Tetrapods Stalked the Earth: A Cartoon Prehistory of Life Before Dinosaurs
Annotation: Employing a cartoon-like format for some of its numerous illustrations, this book is a humorous, fascinating, and informative introduction to the lesser-known Carboniferous and Permian periods of the Paleozoic Era (250-320 million years ago) and life on earth before dinosaurs appeared. Topics include the evolution of life, the development of flora and fauna, climatic change, continental drift, and habitats. The text is appended with timelines, references, further sources (print and electronic), a glossary, and a punctuation guide.
Author: Hannah Bonner

Title: When Harriet Met Sojourner
Annotation: The lives of Harriet Tubman and Sojourner Truth, two remarkable women who were born into slavery and had a profound effect on history, are presented in clear, simple words. It is believed that the two women met in 1864. The book alternates between the two women’s stories, with the author imagining what might have been said between them during that meeting. Illustrated with mixed-media artwork. Concludes with additional information and photographs of each woman.
Author: Catherine Clinton

Title: When I Heard the Learn'd Astronomer
Annotation: This book features Walt Whitman's poem, "When I Heard the Learn'd Astronomer". It is the story of a boy who is obsessed with outer space and who has been dragged to a lecture on astronomy. Unable to make sense of the speaker's talk, he wanders off into the evening air and marvels at the stars. This book, illustrated with acrylic art encourages students to go out and look at the stars instead of listening to someone else's study.
Author: Walt Whitman

Title: When I Was Young in the Mountains
Annotation: The author reminiscences about what it was like to grow up in her grandparents' home in the mountains of Appalachia. The illustrations evoke the warmth and affection of the family members and the simplicity of their lives.
Author: Cynthia Rylant
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: When Jessie Came Across the Sea
Annotation: A thirteen-year-old Jewish orphan reluctantly leaves her grandmother and emigrates to New York City, where she works for three years sewing lace and earning money to bring her grandmother to the United States. Dramatic and realistic watercolor illustrations enhance the telling.
Author: Amy Hest

Title: When Marian Sang: The True Recital of Marian Anderson
Annotation: African American classical singer Marian Anderson perseveres during the vicious segregation era. The story covers her rejection from music school, her triumphant concert on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in 1939, and her performance with the Metropolitan Opera. Selznick's compelling artwork adds drama. Includes afterword, discography, and bibliography. Useful in the study of singers, singing, American history, civil rights, prejudice, and courage. Can be used as a picture book for older readers. California author. Can be compared with THE VOICE THAT CHALLENGED A NATION by Russell Freedman.
Author: Pam Munoz Ryan
Topic: American History, Diversity, Music, Women’s Studies
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts
Award: Orbis Pictus Award, Robert F. Sibert Award

Title: When the Circus Came to Town
Annotation: Ten-year-old Ursula lives with her parents at a Montana stagecoach stop. When smallpox leaves her face scarred, she refuses to socialize, not even with the Chinese cook. It's not until the cook's cousins stage a circus for the town that Ursula comes out. In turn she puts on a Chinese New Year celebration when the circus troupe is stranded by a Montana blizzard. California author.
Author: Laurence Yep

Title: When the Moon Is Full
Annotation: A year's worth of full moons are honored in short poems. The poems include Native American names and folklore and the book is illustrated with hand-colored woodcut artwork by Caldecott winner Mary Azarian. A question and answer page provides additional information about the moon.
Author: Penny Pollock

Title: When the Shadbush Blooms
Annotation: Two Native American families from the Lenape culture participate in similar experiences through the seasons. Traditional Sister from years past and Contemporary Sister from the present describe family activities, including fishing, gardening, and playing. Side-by-side acrylic paintings show that even though times change, family traditions remain the same.
Author: Carla Messinger, Susan Katz

Title: When the Soldiers Were Gone
Annotation: After the German occupation of the Netherlands, Benjamin leaves the Christian family with whom he had been living and reunites with his real parents, who have returned from hiding. Adjustments aren't always easy when one's sense of identity has become confused.
Author: Vera W. Propp

Title: When the Wolves Returned: Restoring Nature’s Balance in Yellowstone
Annotation: Shows how each part of an ecosystem is interconnected and how the elimination of wolves from Yellowstone National Park harmed the other animals and plants in the park. Now that the wolves have returned, other plants and animals are recovering. Presented with full-color photographs. An NSTA Outstanding Science Trade Book (2009).
Author: Dorothy Hinshaw Patent

Title: When Washington Crossed the Delaware: A Wintertime Story for Young Patriots
Annotation: This book for young readers tells the story of General George Washington’s daring crossing of the icy Delaware River with his exhausted and defeated troops on Christmas night in 1776. Washington’s decision to launch a surprise attack on the British helped turn the tide in the American Revolution. The book features detailed, full-page illustrations.
Author: Lynne Cheney

Title: Where Are You Going, Manyoni?
Annotation: The life of a young girl from Zimbabwe and the flora and fauna of her native land are depicted as she makes her long trek to school. The two-page watercolors impress upon readers Manyoni's great desire to attend school. An author's note describes the story's setting and some of her own experiences in the country. Definitions of unfamiliar African words and a key to the wildlife in the illustrations are appended.
Author: Catherine Stock

Title: Where Else in the Wild? More Camouflaged Creatures Concealed . . . and Revealed
Annotation: In this sequel to WHERE IN THE WILD? (2007), photography and poetry are paired to present stories of camouflage in nature. Insects and a wide variety of vertebrates are presented in poems. Readers will enjoy looking for the hidden animals in the reproduced photographs. Includes additional information on their habits and habitats, plus an explanation of how each creature’s camouflage helps it survive.
Author: David M. Schwartz
Discipline: English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary, Science

Title: Where I Live
Annotation: This story is told in free verse by a girl named Diana. She describes her move far away from her best friend; the home she loves; her room, painted midnight blue; and the bird that made a nest in the wreath on the front door. Her father lost his job, and the family travels six hours to live with Grandpa Joe. Diana’s eventual adjustment to her new home is helped by her poetry and by her new friend Sam. This is a reassuring story for children who may be facing their own moves. Pencil illustrations highlight each poem.
Author: Eileen Spinelli

Title: Where in the Wild? Camouflaged Creatures Concealed . . . and Revealed
Annotation: Ten short poems, varying in form from rhymed couplets to haiku to concrete verse, contain clues so readers can guess the identities of 10 camouflaged animals. Each animal is revealed in a full-color photograph on a facing gatefold page. An informational page explains how each animal can hide in plain view. Ideal for lessons involving science, poetry, and visual literacy.
Author: David M. Schwartz

Title: Where the Mountain Meets the Moon
Annotation: Inspired by folklore, this original fantasy tells the story of young Minli’s quest to find good fortune for her poverty-stricken family in China. Along the way, she befriends a flightless dragon, a talking fish, and other companions. Full-color illustrations are rendered in a style influenced by traditional Chinese art.
Publisher: Little, Brown Books for Young Readers
Author: Grace Lin

Title: Where the River Begins
Annotation: Two brothers and their grandfather go on a camping trip to locate the source of the river that flows by their home. The text is richly illustrated with Locker's remarkable, museum quality oil paintings that evoke detail and reflect the changing landscape and weather.
Author: Thomas  Locker

Title: Where the Sidewalk Ends: The Poems and Drawings of Shel Silverstein
Annotation: In the first collection of Silverstein's irreverent verse and unconventional drawings, readers are entertained by the likes of "Sarah Cynthia Sylvia Stout who will not take the garbage out," a boy who turns into a TV, a girl who eats a whale, and a place where shoes fly. This collection of 130 funny, touching, naughty, and disgusting poems was followed by A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC and FALLING UP.
Author: Shel Silverstein

Title: Where Was Patrick Henry on the 29th of May?
Annotation: An overview of the life of Patrick Henry, humorously told by noted children’s historical writer Jean Fritz. This illustrated biography traces Patrick Henry’s progress from planter to statesman.
Author: Jean Fritz

Title: While a Tree Was Growing
Annotation: The growth of a 3,500-year-old giant sequoia from seed to maturity is juxtaposed with a chronology of world events from the Trojan War to the present day. The California setting deals with ecology and history.
Author: Jane Bosveld

Title: Whipping Boy
Annotation: Because disciplining the heir to the throne was forbidden, young Jemmy was taken from the streets and routinely punished in place of Prince Brat. When Prince Brat becomes bored, he decides to run away and take his whipping boy with him. Their identities are inadvertently exchanged, and high adventures and antics begin. California author.
Author: Sid Fleischman

Title: Whisper from the Woods
Annotation: The life cycle of an aging tree is poetically portrayed as the younger trees of the forest share their thoughts and the wisdom they have acquired over the years through their friendship with the older tree. Detailed acrylic paintings give a face to each tree and take the reader below the surface of the earth, where the roots of the trees have become intertwined hands.
Author: Victoria Wirth

Title: White Ballets, The
Annotation: The stories behind the three White Ballets—Swan Lake, Giselle, and La Bayadere—are told in language that is accessible to young readers. The White Ballets are so named because the “corps de ballet” in each (the dancers who are not soloists) appear in white costumes. Descriptions of each of the ballets and a history of the dance are included. The oil illustrations capture the feelings of the stories and ballets.
Author: Rajka Kupesic

Title: White Zone, The
Annotation: American bombs are falling on Baghdad during the Iraq War as ten-year-old cousins Nouri, a Shiite, and Talib, half Sunni, witness the growing violence between the Shiite and Sunni Muslims. But in early 2008, snow falls on Baghdad for the first time in memory, covering the dusty streets of the city. Guns are silent, and differences between Sunni and Shiite are forgotten as Nouri and Talib begin to see what the world might look like if the conflict were to end.
Author: Carolyn Marsden

Title: Who Eats What? Food Chains and Food Webs
Annotation: This book provides basic information about food chains and food webs on land and under water. The simple text and full-color illustrations assist in leading students to think about the interconnections of life on Earth. Children are invited to make their own observations. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out Science series.
Author: Patricia Lauber

Title: Who Lives in the Snow?
Annotation: Carefully researched and illustrated, this book describes the remarkable animals who survive and often flourish in their dark winter world. This book tells how spiders, mites, shrews, voles, chipmunks, deer, and the red fox live and find food during the winter. The realistic cutaway paintings show the animals in their habitat.
Author: Jennifer Berry Jones

Title: Who Really Killed Cock Robin? An Ecological Mystery
Annotation: A thirteen-year-old boy tries to identify the reason for the death of a robin. He investigates his community's environment, tests water for contaminants, and traces the food webs of local organisms to unravel the culprit of the mysterious death. The solution to the mystery is intriguing.
Author: Jean Craighead George

Title: Why Do Leaves Change Colors?
Annotation: This book describes how leaves change colors. The colorful illustrations assist the reader in comprehending the process while the clear, narrative text suggests additional locations to visit to see colorful fall foliage. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out-Science series.
Author: Betsy Maestro

Title: Why Ducks Sleep on One Leg
Annotation: Children often wonder why ducks sleep on one leg. This Vietnamese tale explains the mystery.
Author: Sherry Garland

Title: Why the Tides Ebb and Flow
Annotation: In this folktale about why the sea has tides, an old woman threatens to pull the rock from the hole in the ocean floor if Sky Spirit does not honor his promise to give her shelter.
Author: Joan Chase Bowden
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Why War Is Never a Good Idea
Annotation: This picture book, featuring dramatic folk-art paintings and a narrative in verse, depicts the destructiveness and hopelessness of war and shows how war destroys people and beauty. The text provides a thought-provoking experience for modern readers, especially in light of world events in the early twenty-first century. California author.
Author: Alice Walker
Classification: Picture Book, Read Aloud, Struggling Reader

Title: Wigwam and the Longhouse, The
Annotation: The daily lives of the Native Americans of the northeast woodlands are chronicled in this selection. It explains how they built their shelters, hunted for food, and celebrated through rituals and games as well as how the coming of the white man changed the lives of these Native Americans. An accounting of the present-day status of the native peoples who live in this area is provided. Illustrations and diagrams extend the text. A bibliography and an index are appended.
Author: Charlotte Yue, David Yue

Title: Wild and Swampy, Exploring with Jim Arnosky
Annotation: The artist/author presents a first-person journal style of information and reflections as he explores southern swamps. Full-page realistic acrylic paintings show swamp animals in their habitat. Additional pen-and-ink drawings enhance the journalistic style. This book can be read aloud when launching units on habitats and ecosystems.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: Wild Boy
Annotation: Based on the true story of the Wild boy of Aveyron, this book tells about a young boy who, in 1800, was discovered living alone in the woods of France, captured, and studied by doctors in Paris. Victor never became completely accustomed to French civilization and died in middle age. An interesting comparison to California's Ishi can be made with this true story.
Author: Mordicai Gerstein

Title: Wild Dogs: Past and Present
Annotation: This is an excellent survey of dog history, from prehistoric canines to the domesticated dogs of the present,. Readers learn how some species died out while others survived and evolved. An interesting narrative is accompanied by full-color photographs, sidebars, charts, and an extensive bibliography that includes Web sites.
Author: Kelly Milner Halls

Title: Wild Fibonacci: Nature's Secret Code Revealed
Annotation: This book describes the Fibonacci sequence as it appears through a special shape called an equiangular spiral. The numerical amounts are represented visually by groups of animal species. The simple rhyming text points out the physical characteristics of animals that reflect Fibonacci sequencing. This test is illustrated with realistic acrylics.
Author: Joy N. Hulme
Standard: Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 5.OA.1-3

Title: Wild Flamingos
Annotation: The wild flamingos that live on a small Caribbean island are introduced in this book. Their bodies, natural habitat, and habits are discussed and the readable text is enhanced by full-color photographs, many of which are laid out in double-page spreads.
Author: Bruce McMillan

Title: Wild Girl
Annotation: Since the death of her mother several years ago, Twelve-year-old Lidie has lived in Brazil with an aunt and uncle. Her great love is horses, and she has become a skillful rider. Lidie travels to New York to join her father and older brother, both of whom train racehorses. A parallel story unfolds: the birth of a filly, Wild Girl, who eventually meets Lidie. Themes of immigration will resonate with those who have had to deal with changes in their lives resulting from relocation. The story will also appeal to middle-graders who yearn to own or ride a horse.
Author: Patricia Reilly Giff
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Immigration/Migration, Lifestyles Around the World

Title: Wild Horses I Have Known
Annotation: Through text and photographs, mustang behavior as observed by the author is depicted. The author provides an account of how mustangs have adapted to their harsh environment. She also discusses the mustangs' origins, their colors and markings, and their social interactions with one another and with the author herself.
Author: Hope Ryden

Title: Wild Lives: A History of the People and Animals of the Bronx Zoo
Annotation: This narrative tells about the first hundred years of the Bronx Zoo and the ways in which zookeepers have improved the care and conditions of the wild animals that live there. Included are descriptions of continuing conservation and education efforts. This title is illustrated with black-and-white photographs from the late 1800s and early 1900s as well as full-color photographs of today's Bronx Zoo.
Author: Kathleen Weidner Zoehfeld

Title: Wild Ponies
Annotation: Smoothly flowing, rhyming text and vibrant, detailed paintings capture a herd of wild ponies on an island off the Atlantic coast. The ponies are shown romping in the surf, munching on sea grass, resting in the shade, and playing with a baby deer. Arnosky is unmatched in his approach to sharing nature with young children. This book is a part of the One Whole Day series.
Author: Jim Arnosky

Title: Wild Wings
Annotation: In a rural village in Scotland, Iona finds a rare osprey nest and shares the secret with her friend Callum. Soon the entire village is engaged In an effort to save this endangered bird. Callum and his friends begin to track the bird’s journey across continents to West Africa. Through the magic of e-mail, he connects with children in Gambia to find and help the osprey when the tracking signal fades. This is a warm and engaging story of hope, friendship, and care for the environment.
Author: Gill Lewis

Title: Wilfrid Gordon McDonald Partridge
Annotation: Wilfred Gordon McDonald Partridge's favorite neighbor has lost her memory, and he seeks ways to help her regain it. This gentle, humorous, and realistic story helps define memories. This book is excellent for inspiring students to create their own and others' memories. Warm, expressive watercolor illustrations enhance this tender story.
Author: Mem Fox

Title: Willie and the All-Stars
Annotation: Willie loves listening to baseball in 1942 Chicago, and he dreams of playing the sport in the future. He hears some neighbors talking about players he has never heard of—such as Satchel Paige and Cool Papa Bell—and is told that being a major-leaguer is also about the color of one’s skin and that “his is the wrong color.” Devastated to learn this, he is cheered up when he receives tickets to a game between the Negro League All-Stars and the Major League All-Stars. After the Negro League players win the game, the crowd is silenced when two players, one white and one black, shake hands on the mound. Sepia artwork brings to life the setting and the period.
Author: Floyd Cooper
Topic: American History, Diversity, English-Language Arts/General, Physical Fitness

Title: Willy and Max: A Holocaust Story
Annotation: Set in Belgium during World War II, this is the story of two young boys, Willy and Max, who become close friends when Max’s father buys a painting at an antique shop owned by Willy’s parents. When the Nazis arrive, Max and his Jewish family must flee, and the two friends become separated. After the war ends, Willy is able to locate Max’s family and returns the painting to them. Colorful, double-page illustrations capture the time and place. An author’s note discusses the Nazis’ theft of art during World War II and contemporary efforts to return stolen artworks to their rightful Jewish owners.
Author: Amy Littlesugar
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Willy el mago (Willy the Wizard)
