Annotation: Willy is eager to play soccer, but he doesn't have money for the shoes. Fortunately, a kind stranger gives him a magical pair of cleats that allows him to play soccer like a real champ.
Author: Anthony Browne

Title: Wilma Mankiller
Annotation: During her childhood, Wilma Mankiller and her family were driven by poverty from their farm in Oklahoma. They left the state, but as an adult, Wilma returned to help improve the lives of rural Cherokees and to lead the fight for Native American civil rights in the 1970s and 1980s.
Author: Linda Lowery

Title: Wilma Unlimited: How Wilma Rudolph Became the World's Fastest Woman
Annotation: Wilma Rudolf overcame crippling polio as a child to become, in 1960, the first woman to win three Olympic gold medals in track. Sepia-toned photographs enhance the text. California illustrator.
Author: Kathleen Krull

Title: Wind in the Willows, The
Annotation: The humorous adventures of four animal friends, resourceful Rat, loyal Mole, exasperating Toad of Toad Hall and stern but wise Badger are related as they share life and habitat along a river in the English countryside.
Author: Kenneth Grahame

Title: Wind-Wild Dog
Annotation: This engaging story presents the life cycle of a sled dog born with one blue eye and one brown eye, making her half-wild. The man in the story takes a liking to her and brings her home. The dog learns to trust him, learns to mush and pull a sled, and, when given the opportunity to return to the wild, chooses to stay with her master. Illustrations aptly reflect the Alaska wildlands.
Author: Barbara M. Joosse

Title: Wings of Light: The Migration of the Yellow Butterfly
Annotation: In lyrical prose, this book describes the one-way migratory flight of the yellow butterfly from the Yucatan rain forest to New England. Many butterflies scatter along the way, but a few make it to their destination in Vermont. They mate and die, leaving their offspring in a garden. Illustrated with realistic watercolor paintings, this book serves as an excellent introduction to migration. It includes an author's note that provides further information.
Author: Stephen R. Swinburne

Title: Winking, Blinking Sea: All About Bioluminescence, The
Annotation: This book explains bioluminescence in ocean life. The full-color photographs are examples of sea creatures that glow such as ostracods, Bermuda fire worms, and flashlight fish. The clearly-written, readable text describes each organism and its behavior.
Author: Mary Batten

Title: Winnie-the-Pooh
Annotation: This classic has seen many popular adaptations. However, the charming original drawings by Shepard and the innocence of the original text make this book a read-aloud choice that is a feast for young ears. Winnie the Pooh, Eeyore, Rabbit, Kanga, and other come-to-life toy animals frolic with Christopher Robin, a little boy whose character is based on the author's own child.
Author: A. A. Milne

Title: Winter Eyes: Poems and Paintings
Annotation: These 48 poems invite the reader to experience and celebrate the ever-changing winter season. The artwork is realistic and features playful, soft-toned watercolor-and-pencil pictures. This is an excellent model for writing original poems.
Author: Douglas Florian

Title: Winter Poems
Annotation: This short anthology of winter poems includes works by such authors as Shakespeare, Poe, Dickinson, Frost, Sandburg, and others. It is designed and illustrated in a picture book format making it appropriate for all ages and would lend itself as a read-aloud choice.
Author: Barbara Rogasky (selector)

Title: Wishing on a Star: Constellation Stories and Stargazing Activities for Kids
Annotation: This book presents some of the stories behind the constellations. The stars come to life with creative and entertaining activities, facts, and myths. There are illustrations and directions for the multiple projects which teachers, students, and families could easily do.
Author: Fran Lee

Title: Wishing You a Happy Birthday
Annotation: This prize-winning picture book tells the story of a little girl's bravery in coping with cancer and death. She tells her friend to remember her by looking for the stars in the sky that form a birthday cake with candles.
Publisher: Guo Yu Ri Bao Publishing Company
Author: Su-Chen Fang

Title: With a Little Luck: Surprising Stories of Amazing Discovery
Annotation: This work presents eleven breakthroughs in science and invention that occurred by accident and with just a little bit of luck. In each case the inventor-discoverer was looking at a problem when suddenly, the unexpected lead to a revelation. The episodes are told in an engaging style, and illustrations and photographs enhance the text.
Author: Dennis Brindell Fradin
Topic: Earth Science, Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: With a Whoop and a Holler
Annotation: This collection presents humorous folktales from three distinct regions of the South: Bayou, Deep South, and Mountains. Along with the stories are rhymes, riddles, superstitions, sayings, and a couple of Uncle Remus and Jack tales. Each region is introduced prior to the tales representing that section of the South. The watercolor/gouache/pastel/acrylic illustrations extend the vitality and whimsy of the text. Helpful source notes and bibliography are appended.
Author: Nancy Van Laan

Title: Witness
Annotation: Two young girls move to a small Vermont town in 1924, become best friends, and turn into targets of the Ku Klux Klan because of their race. Leonora, twelve, is black, and Esther, six, is Jewish. Eleven residents speak of personal experiences, fears, and prejudices and reflect on happenings: murder attempts, a dramatic rescue, a teenager on the run, and a suicide. This play in free-verse style weaves prejudice and hatred, the lure of the Klan, and the response of the people who desire to learn tolerance. Opportunities for reader's theater abound with this title.
Author: Karen Hesse
Genre: Fiction in Verse, Historical Fiction, Poetry
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements

Title: Wizard from the Start: The Incredible Boyhood & Amazing Inventions of Thomas Edison, A
Annotation: Describes the early years of Thomas Edison’s life, including his experience of being homeschooled by his mother when his teacher referred to him as “addled.” Edison was hardworking, inquisitive, and mischievous; he conducted science experiments in his basement; and he read everything he could get his hands on. When learning about things was simply not enough for him, he began to dream of ways to improve the world through his inventions. The book features watercolor illustrations and includes an author’s note and a bibliography.
Author: Don Brown
Topic: Global Historical Events and Figures, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Wizard of Oz, The
Annotation: In this classic in children's literature, Dorothy is transported to the Land of Oz by a cyclone and must find the great wizard in order to return home to Kansas. The story is also available on audiocassette.
Author: Frank L. Baum

Title: Wolves
Annotation: Myths, legends, curious facts, and general information is given about several species of wolves. The author discusses the wolf’s shrinking habitat, appearance, hunting habits, diet, communication systems, social order, reproduction, and relationship with humans. This is an excellent resource on wolves for students in the primary grades.
Author: Gail Gibbons

Title: Wolves
Annotation: The interesting narrative text presents information about wolves including physical characteristics, habits, and their natural environment. The book highlights ways that this animal adapts for survival in its ecosystem. The full-color photographs feature close-ups and show the animals in their habitat.
Author: Seymour Simon

Title: Wolves in the Walls, The
Annotation: Lucy is certain that wolves live in the walls of her house, but no one will believe her. Told with engaging humor and creepiness, the story is presented in a format similar to graphic novels. This picture book for older readers is illustrated with collage and other multimedia images, including artwork and photographs. The story line and illustrations are appealing to middle-grade students and reluctant readers.
Author: Neil Gaiman

Title: Woman for President: The Story of Victoria Woodhull, A
Annotation: Victoria Woodhull was one of this country’s original feminists. She dedicated her life to achieving equality for women. During the U.S. presidential election of 1872, Woodhull became the first woman to run for the nation’s highest office, even though women of that time period did not have the right to vote. Watercolor illustrations accompany the text of this fascinating biography.
Author: Kathleen Krull
Topic: American History, Government and Politics, Women’s Studies

Title: Woman Who Outshone the Sun: The Legend of Lucia Zenteno, The
Annotation: This book retells the Zapotec legend of Lucia Zenteno, a beautiful woman with magical powers who is exiled from a mountain village and takes its water away in punishment. The tale is told in English and Spanish and is illustrated with full-color paintings that resemble folk art.
Author: David Schecter, Harriet Rohmer, Rosalma Zubizarreta

Title: Women Daredevils: Thrills, Chills, and Frills
Annotation: A collective biography that profiles 14 women who flouted convention to work as entertainers in the years between 1880 and 1929, performing thrilling feats in the water, in the air, and in the circus. Each story places the woman in historical context, and the lively text makes this a perfect choice for Women’s History Month. Colorful illustrations show each woman in period costume.
Author: Julie Cummins

Title: Won Ton: A Cat Tale Told in Haiku
Annotation: Won Ton, a sleek gray cat with big blue eyes, tells his adoption tale in a series of terse senryu poems, a form of Japanese poetry similar to haiku. The verses and detailed graphite-and-gouache illustrations capture the feline’s slinky charm during a day of fun, adventure, mischief, snobbishness, and tender bonding. California author.
Author: Lee Wardlaw

Title: Wonder
Annotation: Ten-year-old Auggie Pullman, who was born with extreme facial abnormalities and was not expected to survive, goes from being home-schooled to entering fifth grade at a private middle school in Manhattan. Auggie struggles with the teasing of his classmates as he tries to be seen as just another student. This book addresses controversial issues of interest to many young people and includes scenes and language that reflect mature content. Before handing the text to a child, educators and parents should read the book and know the child.
Author: R.J Palacio
Topic: Global Social Issues, Growth, Development, and Sexual Health, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, Personal and Community Health, Psychology/Sociology

Title: Wonder Horse: The True Story of the World’s Smartest Horse
Annotation: Bill Key, a freed slave, advocated kindness and compassion for all creatures. This story describes his life as a veterinarian and the life of an orphaned foal named Jim. Jim was raised by Key to perform amazing mental feats, such as recognizing letters and numbers. Vibrant watercolor illustrations capture the excitement and details of the early 1800s, and endnotes include biographical information.
Author: Emily Arnold McCully
Standard: HSS K.6, HSS 1.4, HSS 2.1, HSS 2.5, HSS 3.4

Title: Wonderstruck: A Novel in Words and Pictures
Annotation: Relates the stories of twelve-year-old Ben, who loses his mother and his hearing in a short time frame and decides to leave his Minnesota home in 1977 to seek the father he has never known in New York City; and Rose, who lives with her father but feels compelled to search for what is missing in her life. Ben's story is told in words, Rose's in pictures.
Author: Brian Selznick
Award: California Young Reader Medal, Schneider Family Award

Title: Woods Scientist, The
Annotation: The life and efforts of Susan Morse wildlife professional and conservationist, are told in clear text illustrated with Morse's vivid photographs. The reader learns a bit about her early life, follows her on tracking expeditions, and is introduced to wolves, bears, moose, and lynx along the way. The concluding pages offer simple activities and suggest titles for further reading. This book is a part of the Scientists in the Field series.
Author: Stephen R. Swinburne

Title: Woolly Mammoth Journey, A
Annotation: The discovery of a giant tusk launches a nature adventure describing the annual migration of a small band of woolly mammoths as it might have happened 12,000 years ago. The book is illustrated with double-page acrylic paintings. A fact page includes information on habitat, discoveries, and extinction.
Author: Debbie S. Miller

Title: Word After Word After Word
Annotation: A visiting poet, Ms. Mirabel, works with fourth-graders to explore writing and the power of words. She encourages the students to delve into their own experiences and look for stories in their own lives, because she believes that everyone has a story to tell. Five of the children explore their ideas in a group, empathizing with each other and creating beautiful poetry. Recommended as a read-aloud.
Author: Patricia MacLachlan

Title: Words Set Me Free: The Story of Young Frederick Douglass
Annotation: Drawing from the NARRATIVE OF THE LIFE OF FREDERICK DOUGLASS, the authors present a first-person account, in lyrical prose, of Douglass’s difficult early life as a slave child and how learning to read changed his fate. The book is illustrated with rich, detailed acrylic-and-oil paintings.
Author: Lesa Cline-Ransome
Award: Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Winner

Title: Working Cotton
Annotation: A long day's work in the cotton fields is described through the eyes of a young child. The text is poetic, and the impressionistic illustrations are full of color. The book provides a good introduction to migrant family life. California author.
Author: Sherley Ann Williams
Award: Caldecott Honor, Coretta Scott King Illustrator Honor

Title: World of Wonders: Geographic Travels in Verse and Rhyme, A
Annotation: Engaging poems with a hint of wit introduce a variety of explorers, exotic locales, and geographic terms. The book’s illustrations perfectly complement the text, featuring oil paintings on paper with crackling varnish to give an antique look. May be used as an introduction to the explorers and to geography in general.
Author: J. Patrick Lewis
Topic: American History, Geography, Global Historical Events and Figures

Title: Worst of Friends: Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, and the True Story of an American Feud
Annotation: This is the true story of Thomas Jefferson and John Adams, who were the best of friends even though their ideas about the construction of America were completely different. After many years of walking and talking together and enjoying each other’s families, they turned against each other as a result of a disagreement—but they eventually reconciled and enjoyed their friendship once again. Drawings enhanced with watercolor washes show the spirit of these two founding fathers of America.
Author: Suzanne Tripp Jurmain

Title: Worth
Annotation: After breaking his leg, eleven-year-old Nate feels useless because he cannot work on the family farm in nineteenth century Nebraska. When his father brings home an orphan boy to help with the chores, Nate feels even worse. This is a lively story of two boys set against a backdrop of the Orphan Trains, range wars, lynchings, drownings, and sheep killings.
Author: A. LaFaye

Title: Wretched Stone, The
Annotation: In the form of a ship's log, the puzzling transformation of the Rita Anne's crew is related after a glowing rock from a deserted island is brought aboard. This selection features dramatic two-page color illustrations. The story is a good discussion-starter about the effects of watching too much television.
Author: Chris Van Allsburg

Title: Wright 3, The
Annotation: When the sixth-grade class at the University School in Chicago learns that Frank Lloyd Wright’s historic Robie House is going to be destroyed, the students go to work to save the landmark. Tommy, who lives next door to the house, and his classmates Petra and Calder, begin to experience eerie happenings as they watch the house. The book includes information about pentominoes and features numerous black-and-white illustrations, which not only depict the story’s action but also show the actual Robie House.
Author: Blue Balliett
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Wrinkle in Time, A
Annotation: Meg and Charles Wallace and Calvin O'Keefe search for Meg's father, a scientist who disappeared while trying to solve the tesseract (wrinkle in time) problem. The story combines theology, fantasy, and science in a story of time and space travel and the power of good over evil. The value of a close, loving family is emphasized. Other books in the series are SWIFTLY TILTING PLANET and WIND IN THE DOOR.
Author: Madeleine L'Engle

Title: Wump World, The
Annotation: The Wump World is an unspoiled place until the Pollutians invade and turn green meadows into a concrete jungle. When the Pollutians set off to seek new conquests, the Wumps are left to rebuild their ruined world. The story provides an opportunity for discussing how to preserve our natural resources from pollution.
Author: Bill Peet

Title: Yang the Youngest and His Terrible Ear
Annotation: Yang, the youngest of a musical Chinese family, has an untrained ear and prefers baseball to the violin. Issues of assimilation and cultural differences can be discussed in conjunction with the reading of this selection. Other informative stories about the Yang family are available.
Author: Lensey Namioka

Title: Yankee Doodle America: The Spirit of 1776 from A to Z
Annotation: Each letter of the alphabet is presented to correspond to a historical event, place, or person from the American Revolution. Each entry has a paragraph of information and is illustrated with an oil painting inspired by period artwork, rendered on hand-carved replicas of the wooden signs that hung outside public houses during the Revolutionary War. Provides a visual exploration of the time period and events and may be used to introduce units of instruction.
Author: Wendel Minor
Discipline: History/Social Science, Visual and Performing Arts

Title: Yatandou and the Pounding Stick
Annotation: Eight-year-old Yatandou helps the women of her Mali village raise money to buy a machine that will replace the pounding sticks they use for grinding millet kernels. As part of the fund-raising effort, Yatandou bravely sells her pet goat at the local market. The machine arrives in the village, and the women know that it will not only help the village prosper but will also give them the tools to become more independent. The book includes paintings with warm reds, yellows, and browns that evoke the African landscape.
Author: Gloria Whelan
Topic: Economics, English-Language Arts/General, Ethnic Studies, Global Social Institutions, Global Social Issues, Lifestyles Around the World, Women’s Studies, World Cultures: Perspectives, Practices, and Products

Title: Year Down Yonder, A
Annotation: Mary Alice moves in with her spicy Grandma Dowdel for an unforgettable year during the Depression era. This is a sequel to, and is as good as, A LONG WAY TO CHICAGO. It is a delightful tale that resounds with a storyteller's wit, humor, and vivid description.
Author: Richard Peck
Discipline: History/Social Science, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Year of Billy Miller, The
Annotation: Seven-year-old Billy Miller starts second grade with a bump on his head and a lot of worries, but by the end of the year he has developed good relationships with his teacher, his little sister, and his parents and learned many important lessons.
Author: Kevin Henkes

Title: Year of Miss Agnes, The
Annotation: Ten-year-old Fred (short for Frederika) narrates the story of school and village life among the Athabascan people in Alaska during 1948. This was the watermark year when Miss Agnes arrived in the village as their new teacher and changed their lives. This is a wonderful story about learning, trust, and friendship. Good read-aloud.
Author: Kirkpatrick Hill

Title: Year the Swallows Came Early, The
Annotation: Eleven-year-old Eleanor “Groovy” Robinson lives near the ocean and the famous church mission in San Juan Capistrano. Her main interest is cooking, and she dreams of going to a culinary school. Her mother, a hairdresser, is a warm and loving person, and life is good until Groovy’s father is arrested. Frankie, Groovy’s best friend, is also having difficulties. The two companions must find a balance between their expectations and reality. This novel, the first from California author Kathryn Fitzmaurice, is filled with memorable characters.
Author: Kathryn Fitzmaurice

Title: Year with Grandma Moses, The
Annotation: This is a collection of paintings and memoirs by Grandma Moses describing the seasons and depicting rural, seasonal activities. The author's text is appropriate for introducing the paintings to young children. Some of the excerpts from Moses' memoirs which tell about her life in upstate New York are more appropriate for more advanced readers.
Author: W. Nikola-Lisa

Title: Yeh Shen: A Cinderella Story from China
Annotation: A young Chinese girl overcomes the wickedness of her stepsister and stepmother to become the bride of a prince. Readers will be able to compare and contrast this Cinderella story with those of other countries. Mr. Young's illustrations add greatly to this retelling.
Author: Ai-Ling Louie

Title: Yellow House: Vincent van Gogh and Paul Gauguin Side by Side, The
Annotation: Published in association with the Art Institute of Chicago, this is the story of the two-month period in 1888 when Paul Gauguin moved into Vincent van Gogh’s yellow house so that the two artists could paint side by side. Images placed side by side show each artist’s interpretation of the same subject. The book offers an introduction to their styles, techniques, and mutual influences. California author.
Author: Susan Goldman Rubin
Standard: VAPA V PreK-12.1, VAPA V PreK-12.2, VAPA V PreK-12.3, VAPA V PreK-12.4, VAPA V PreK-12.5

Title: Yellow Star, The: The Legend of King Christian X of Denmark
Annotation: This legend relates how King Christian X of Denmark sewed a yellow star onto his clothing, thus defying Hitler's orders and empowering his people to proclaim solidarity with their Jewish friends and neighbors in World War II. An author's note separates fact from fiction.
Author: Carmen Agra

Title: Yikes - Lice!
Annotation: Factual information interspersed with rhyming text on the life cycle, habits, and environment of lice are presented in a clear manner. Lice are a nuisance, but not feared. The straight forward approach of this book puts having lice into perspective.
Author: Donna Caffey

Title: Yo! Yes!
Annotation: Two boys, one African American and one Caucasian, meet as strangers on a city street, strike up a conversation, and form a special friendship. Told in just 19 words, this story features simple, cartoonlike illustrations in full color.
Author: Chris Raschka

Title: York’s Adventures With Lewis and Clark: The African American’s Part in the Great Expedition
Annotation: In 1784, twelve-year-old York was assigned to be fourteen-year-old William Clark’s slave and body servant. As an adult, York journeyed with the Lewis and Clark expedition to the Pacific Ocean, and it was he who helped forge friendships with the Native American tribes encountered along the trail. Although York was considered part of the expedition while on the journey, he was not recognized for his contributions when he died years later. Author Rhoda Blumberg relied on Williams Clark’s diary as a central resource in writing this book. Includes endnotes, a bibliography, and an index.
Author: Rhoda Blumberg
Culture: Black/African American, Native American, Western European

Title: You Can, Toucan, Math
Annotation: This collection of bird-themed number riddles challenges children to add, subtract, multiply, and divide. Answers to the riddles are found upside down on each page. The bright artwork and use of a variety of birds lead children to discover the solutions. This fun book provides practice in simple operations and includes charts to help children learn their number facts.
Author: David A. Adler
Standard: Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6

Title: You Never Heard of Sandy Koufax?!
Annotation: A picture-book biography of the great left-handed pitcher who played for the Brooklyn/Los Angeles Dodgers and had his greatest seasons from 1961 to 1966. The story relates his early life, challenges, and experiences of prejudice as a Jewish ballplayer. Illustrated with digitally enhanced artwork.
Author: Jonah Winter
Award: Golden Kite Author Winner, Eureka! Nonfiction Children’s Book Award Honor

Title: You Want Women to Vote, Lizzie Stanton?
Annotation: This biography of Elizabeth Cady Stanton underscores the life of a woman far ahead of her times. Although Lizzie Stanton did not live to see the total fruits of her efforts, she was an outspoken fighter for women's suffrage and fought tirelessly for equality for everyone, men and women, black and white. This selection, with author's notes, a bibliography, and an index, is an excellent tool for intermediate grade research. Other titles in the series include AND THEN WHAT HAPPENED, PAUL REVERE?; WHAT'S THE BIG IDEA, BEN FRANKLIN?; WHERE WAS PATRICK HENRY ON THE 29TH OF MAY?; and WHY DON'T YOU GET A HORSE, SAM ADAMS?
Author: Jean Fritz

Title: You're Aboard Spaceship Earth
Annotation: Planet Earth is described as a spaceship that has everything we need to survive. Concepts about air, oxygen, the water cycle, and methods in which elements are recycled are discussed. Bright, crisp illustrations clarify the natural processes that are introduced in this easy-to-read book. See other books in the Let's-Read-and-Find-Out-Science series.
Author: Patricia Lauber

Title: You're On! Seven Plays in English and Spanish
Annotation: This collection features seven bilingual plays written by noted Hispanic authors. They include Gary Soto's "These Shoes of Mine," Oscar Hijuelo's humorous Christmas play, and a philosophical vignette by Federico Garcia Lorca.
Author: Lori Marie Carlson

Title: You’re a Grand Old Flag
Annotation: George M. Cohan’s famous patriotic song is presented line by line. Each line is illustrated with distressed wood painted with striking folk-art images that show Old Glory in unique ways. The book includes lyrics, music, and a few facts about the American flag. Be sure to take time to sing the song.
Author: George M. Cohan

Title: Young Man and the Sea, The
Annotation: After his mother's death, twelve-year-old Skiff Beaman decides that it is up to him to earn money to take care of himself and his father. He undertakes a dangerous trip alone out on the ocean off the coast of Maine to try to catch a huge bluefin tuna.
Author: Rodman Philbrick

Title: Young Man’s Dance, A
Annotation: A boy struggles to understand his grandmother’s battle with Alzheimer’s disease: she needs a wheelchair, lives in a nursing home, and doesn’t recognize him when he visits her. But the boy and his grandmother find common ground in dancing. The swirling colors in the illustrations reflect the confusion felt by the boy and the theme of dancing that is central to the story.
Author: Laurie Lazzaro Knowlton
Classification: Easy Reader, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Topic: Dance, Mental, Emotional, and Social Health, Visual Arts
Standard: VAPA D PreK-12.2, VAPA T PreK-12.1, VAPA T PreK-12.4

Title: Young Pelé: Soccer’s First Star
Annotation: This picture-book biography explores the childhood of Edson do Nascimento, better known to the world as Pelé. It tells how Edson, a poor Brazilian boy, became one of the best soccer players in the world through determination and an intense love of the game. The paintings are bright and colorful and evoke both the poverty and beauty of Brazil.
Author: Lesa Cline-Ransome

Title: Young Thomas Edison
Annotation: This is a well-told story about a determined young inventor who overcomes a variety of setbacks, including a significant hearing loss, to experiment and develop inventions that are still of benefit today. The well-crafted narrative is illustrated with lush, realistic oil paintings that bring the world of young Thomas Edison to life.
Author: Michael Dooling

Title: Yours for Justice, Ida B. Wells: The Daring Life of a Crusading Journalist
Annotation: An illustrated biography of African American civil rights advocate and journalist Ida B. Wells, who sued a railroad after she was removed from train seating reserved for white passengers. Wells is best known for her tireless crusade to stop the practice of lynching in early twentieth-century America. The vibrant illustrations were created as giclée prints of original drawings on archival vellum and hand-tinted in watercolor. The book’s afterword includes archival photos and additional biographical information.
Author: Philip Dray
Topic: American History, Diversity, Ethnic Studies, Law and Legal Studies, Women’s Studies

Title: Yukon Gold: The Story of the Klondike Gold Rush
Annotation: A quest for gold took place in the late 1890s in the Klondike region of the Yukon Territory of northwestern Canada. This book tells the story of the brave men and women who followed that quest. The size of the text and the archival photographs throughout the book make this an inviting book for young readers or researchers. It includes a glossary, a bibliography, and an index.
Author: Charlotte Foltz Jones

Title: Yum! ¡MmMm! ¡Qué Rico! (Americas’ Sproutings)
Annotation: From blueberries to vanilla, indigenous foods of the Americas are celebrated in this collection of haiku. Factual information about each food’s origins are included on the facing pages. The illustrations are vivid acrylics painted on wood panels and evoke the countries of the Americas.
Author: Pat Mora
Topic: English-Language Arts/General, Nutrition and Physical Activity

Title: Z Was Zapped: A Play in Twenty-six Acts, The
Annotation: Twenty-six letters that encounter zany mishaps are portrayed as puzzles. Rich vocabulary extends the fun in this whimsical story featuring dramatic black-and-white illustrations. This selection can be used for prediction exercises.
Author: Chris Van Allsburg
Discipline: Visual and Performing Arts, English-Language Arts/Vocabulary

Title: Zathura
Annotation: Left on their own for an evening, two boisterous brothers find more excitement than they bargained for in a mysterious and mystical space adventure board game in this sequel to JUMANJI. The black-and-gray sketched illustrations are highlighted with textured paper.
Author: Chris Van Allsburg

Title: Zebra's World, A
Annotation: Another book in this author's "black and white" Caroline Arnold's Animals series A ZEBRA'S WORLD illustrates with cut-paper illustrations and vibrant backgrounds the life cycle of the zebra and the world in which it lives. She includes a map of zebra habitats and some "fun facts" about zebras. Other books in this series are A KILLER WHALE'S WORLD and A PENGUIN'S WORLD. California author.
Author: Caroline Arnold

Title: Zero the Hero
Annotation: Zero the Hero describes the many properties of zero and the difficulties they cause him. Adding zero has no effect, so what is the point? It is the same when you subtract a zero. Zero can’t divide, and when he multiplies, all numbers become zero! However, his friends discover they need him to round numbers and to answer some computation problems. When his number friends are captured by Roman numerals, Zero saves the day. The cartoon-like illustrations include dialogue that conveys even more information.
Author: Joan Holub
Classification: Concept Book, Picture Book, Read Aloud
Standard: Math 1.OA.1-8, Math 1.NBT.1-6, Math 2.OA.1-6, Math 2.NBT.1-9, Math 3.OA.1-9, Math 3.NBT.1-3, Math 4.OA.1-5, Math 4.NBT.1-6, Math 5.NBT.1-7, Math 5.NF.1-7

Title: Zinc Alloy: Revealed!
Annotation: When Zack Allen decides to reveal his superhero identity, his life as a nerdy, bullied kid ends. He is suddenly popular and is recruited to be on the football, baseball, and swim teams. After losing his Zinc Alloy suit, he is faced with the question of whether the suit makes the boy or the boy makes the suit. Part of the “Graphic Sparks” series, this book, with its graphic-novel format and easy-to-read text, is aimed at reluctant readers.
Author: Donald Lemke

Title: Zoo in the Sky: A Book of Animal Constellations
Annotation: Animal constellations are introduced by bright portraits depicting the animals for which the constellations are named and are highlighted with sparkling silver stars. Each illustration is accompanied by very brief text. Two pages at the end provide information about the constellations and the night sky. Sky maps appear on the endpapers. See other books in the National Geographic Society series.
Author: Jacqueline Mitton
Topic: Earth Science, Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics)

Title: Zoo's Who: Poems and Paintings
Annotation: The short poems presented in this book feature a variety of animals and are accompanied by Florian's humorous mixed-media illustrations. This book will interest young students and educate them about a number of animals, including sloths, lizards, and pigs.
Author: Douglas Florian

Title: Zoom
Annotation: This provocative wordless picture book takes the reader on a journey where things are rarely as they seem. Each picture zooms out to give a more distant perspective as the reader views the ever expanding context for what comes next. The bold, colorful illustrations enhance the concept and enrich the experience. Another title by this author is RE-ZOOM.
Author: Istvan Banyai
Topic: Life Science (Biology), Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics), Number Sense
Standard: I & E K.4, I & E 2.4, PS 3.1, PS 5.1, I & E 6.7, I & E 8.9, Math K.G.1-6, Math 1.G.1-3, Math 2.G.1-3, Math 3.G.1-2, Math 4.G.1-3, Math 5.NF.1-7, Math 5.G.1-6, Math 7.RP.1-3, Math 7.G.1-7

Title: Zora Hurston and the Chinaberry Tree
Annotation: When her mother dies, nine-year-old Zora climbs up high in a chinaberry tree to reach for the sky and jump toward the sun, as her mother - who inspired her to dream - had taught her. This picture-story book depicts the intimate bond between a young girl and her inspirational mother. The story is useful in language arts lessons about metaphors.
Author: William Miller
Discipline: History/Social Science, English-Language Arts/Literary Elements, English-Language Arts/Writing

Title: Zorgamazoo
Annotation: Written entirely in rhyming couplets, this book presents the magical adventures of Katrina, who runs away from her guardian, Mrs. Krabone. Mrs. Krabone disapproves of Katrina’s imaginings and threatens her with a lobotomy. Katrina befriends a zorgle named Morty, who is hiding in a subway and helps him find the missing zorgles of Zorgamazoo. Their journey leads them to the moon, where many fantastical creatures are held captive. Black-and-white illustrations and a variety of fonts add interest to the text.
Author: Robert Paul Weston
